headline: Four Dead in Shootings in Colorado Springs
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: A shooting rampage in Colorado Springs on Saturday left four people dead, including the assailant, who was gunned down after the authorities said the person fired at officers.
lead_paragraph: A shooting rampage in Colorado Springs on Saturday left four people dead, including the assailant, who was gunned down after the authorities said the person fired at officers.

headline: 17-Year-Old Is Charged With Murder in Downtown Brooklyn Shooting
abstract: Malik Peters, a Brooklyn resident, was charged with second-degree murder in a shooting on Monday that left one teenager dead and another injured.
lead_paragraph: A 17-year-old has been arrested and charged with murder after a shooting on a busy commercial street in Brooklyn left one teenager dead and another injured, the police said late Friday.

headline: Mets’ Ruben Tejada Speaks, Convinced the Slide Was Dirty
abstract: After watching a replay of Chase Utley’s hard slide at second base that broke Tejada’s leg during Game 2 of the teams’ division series against the Dodgers, Tejada concluded it was a dirty play.
lead_paragraph: As the Mets took batting practice Saturday before Game 3 of the World Series, Ruben Tejada emerged into the dugout in full uniform, wearing a boot on his right foot and moving gingerly, using a cane adorned with the Mets logo, a gift from the Wilpon family.

headline: Noah Syndergaard’s Bold Statement Adds Spice to Series
abstract: Observers say Syndergaard’s aggressive opening pitch in Game 3 was smart strategy and brought a compelling story line to the remaining games.
lead_paragraph: Dickie Noles was watching the third game of the World Series on television Friday night when he saw a fastball sail up and in to a Kansas City Royals hitter. Like that, Noles had company among pitchers who had done this, to great effect, on baseball’s brightest stage.

headline: American Pharoah’s Final Triumph Wipes Away Effects of an Earlier Loss
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'American Pharoah (Race Horse)', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', "Breeders' Cup (Horse Races)"]
abstract: American Pharoah’s victory in the Breeders’ Cup Classic at venerable Keeneland Racecourse capped his spectacular career and erased the memories of his defeat in the Travers Stakes in August.
lead_paragraph: LEXINGTON, Ky. — The defeat in the Travers Stakes in August sucked the air out of the air-conditioned V.I.P. room at Saratoga Race Course. Television cameras recorded every emotion, from shock to horror to devastation, after the Triple Crown champion American Pharoah had lost his first race in more than a year.

headline: Royals Are Still Stewing Over Noah Syndergaard’s Knockdown Pitch
abstract: When the Royals heard about Noah Syndergaard’s comments after Game 3, they became even more enraged.
lead_paragraph: The intrigue surrounding Noah Syndergaard’s high first offering in Game 3 did not fade before Game 4 on Saturday, although it did not affect the way Game 4 was played, either, with the Kansas City Royals winning, 5-3, and moving one step from a championship.

headline: 3 Dead, 4 Injured After Car Crashes Into Trick-or-Treaters in the Bronx
abstract: Three people were killed on Saturday, including a 10-year-old girl, after a car swerved off a road in the Bronx. Four others, including the driver, were injured.
lead_paragraph: Three people were killed on Saturday, including a 10-year-old girl, after a car swerved off a road in the Bronx and ran onto a sidewalk, crashing into a group of children and adults who were trick-or-treating, the police said.

headline: Royals Defeat the Mets to Take a 3-1 Lead in the World Series
abstract: The Kansas City Royals staged a three-run rally in the eighth inning, thanks in part to a key error by Mets second baseman Daniel Murphy.
lead_paragraph: The Mets were five outs from winning a pivotal Game 4 of the World Series on Saturday night when they called on their closer, Jeurys Familia, to protect a 3-2 lead.

headline: A Crushing Error, and Now a Daunting Hole
abstract: Daniel Murphy’s defensive miscue helped the Kansas City Royals take a 3-1 series lead against the Mets, but there were plenty of failures around him as well.
lead_paragraph: History is often told in thumbnails. Bill Buckner. Mitch Williams. Steve Bartman. Grady Little. They are goats of October, never mind the context or the more complicated stories that contributed to their infamy.

headline: Al Qaeda Claims Responsibility for Attacks on 2 Publishers in Bangladesh
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The victims’ publishing houses had released work by Avijit Roy, a critic of religious extremism who was killed in a similar attack eight months ago.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Statements attributed to a regional division of Al Qaeda late on Saturday claimed responsibility for attacks on two publishers in Bangladesh who put out works critical of fundamentalist Islam, according to the SITE Intelligence Group, which monitors radical Islamic propaganda.

headline: Royals Aren’t Perfect, but Opportunistic Does Just Fine
abstract: Alex Rios made a mental blunder that helped the Mets pad their lead early in Game 4, but his teammates, as usual, waited for their chance and made it count.
lead_paragraph: As Alex Rios stood in front of his locker and patiently explained how on baseball’s biggest stage, despite being surrounded by several scoreboards and nearby teammates, he forgot how many outs there were, he could at least shrug.

headline: Erdogan’s Party in Turkey Regains Parliamentary Majority
abstract: The results of a snap election represent a stunning electoral comeback, and ensure another period of single-party government in Turkey.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — In a stunning electoral comeback, the Islamist party of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan regained its majority in Parliament on Sunday, ensuring Mr. Erdogan’s continued dominance of Turkish politics after months of political turmoil and violence.

headline: China, Japan and South Korea Pledge to Expand Trade at Joint Meeting
abstract: The return of trilateral talks among the three powers, last held in 2012, reflects their reliance on one another for badly needed growth.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Meeting for the first time in three years, leaders from China, Japan and South Korea agreed on Sunday that they would meet annually and work toward greater trade ties, even as they continued to wrangle over territorial and historical disputes.

headline: SAP Chief Bill McDermott Embarks on Health Care Mission After Losing His Eye
keywords: ['Accidents and Safety', 'Cloud Computing', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Eyes and Eyesight', 'Philanthropy', 'Software', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: SAP’s chief executive lost his eye after an accident in July. Now he wants his company to delve deeper into health care, following a tradition of tech leaders who have turned to their industry when, or after, experiencing health problems.
lead_paragraph: On July 6, Bill McDermott, the chief executive of one of the world’s largest software companies, fell down the stairs at his brother’s house. He awoke in a pool of blood.

headline: Guinea President’s Re-election Confirmed Despite Fraud Complaints
abstract: A judicial panel that reviewed claims of fraud in the Oct. 11 election certified that the incumbent, Alpha Condé, had won nearly 58 percent of the vote.
lead_paragraph: CONAKRY, Guinea — After a presidential vote that prompted a spate of violence and complaints of fraud, election results were validated in Guinea late Saturday, confirming the incumbent, Alpha Condé, as the winner.

headline: Popular Hotel in Somalia Is Bombed by Militants
abstract: The Shabab, an Islamist group, claimed responsibility after fighters killed at least 14 people at the Sahafi Hotel in Mogadishu.
lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Islamist militants stormed a popular hotel in the heart of Mogadishu, Somalia’s capital, on Sunday, blowing up the front gate with a car bomb, shooting guests and hotel workers, and then battling with security forces from the hotel’s rooftop for several hours.

abstract: I couldn’t squash a lingering sense of shame when people asked when I was going back to work.

headline: Amid Vigils and Debris, Officials Seek Cause of Sinai Peninsula Crash
abstract: A day of mourning was held Sunday for 224 who died in the Egyptian Sinai crash, while the transportation minister said flight recorders had been found.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — As Russia mourned the 224 victims of a charter flight that crashed over the weekend on the Sinai Peninsula in Egypt, investigators on Sunday began the difficult process of trying to determine whether the plane, which they said had broken up in midair, was brought down by an act of terrorism or a tragic accident.

headline: Why Consumers Often Err in Choosing Health Plans
abstract: Evaluating health insurance plans can be daunting and confusing, and most people don’t get much guidance, research shows.
lead_paragraph: It’s open enrollment season for almost every kind of health insurance in America. Millions of Americans using Medicare plans, employer-sponsored health insurance or Affordable Care Act marketplaces select health plans each fall. Many consumers face numerous options, and research shows that they make many mistakes, often paying more than they need to.

headline: Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio Grow Apart as Their Ambitions Expand
abstract: The senators brought similar backgrounds and Tea Party fervor to Washington, but any alliance between them frayed as they moved closer to seeking the White House.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When he ran for the Senate from Texas in 2012, Ted Cruz welcomed the comparisons on Capitol Hill and in the news media to Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, another 41-year-old Cuban-American and oratorically gifted conservative, who had ridden a wave of Tea Party support two years earlier to victory over his state’s Republican establishment.

headline: Running While Juggling Is Banned by Marathon Organizers
abstract: The world-record holder for joggling, as it is known, was empty-handed on the streets of New York on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: As an elite joggler — that is, someone who runs while juggling — Michal Kapral of Canada is used to doing things the hard way. But at this year’s New York City Marathon, that meant something different: settling for an ordinary 26.2 miles, empty-handed. Marathon organizers banned joggling from the course, ruling that beanbags filled with millet seed, like Kapral’s, count as “Prohibited Items.”

headline: 1915: Sarah Bernhardt Says War Took Most Leading Men
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A great artist plans her trip to the United States in 1915.
lead_paragraph: Mme. Sarah Bernhardt, who recently arrived in Paris to rehearse her new play, has announced that she will leave on December 25 for her postponed American tour. Though the great artist had just come from the theatre fatigued from the daily rehearsals, she received a Herald correspondent at her home on boulevard Pereire, and talked at length of her trip to America.

headline: Evgeny Kissin to Take a Break in U.S., But Not Europe
abstract: After a busy American season Evgeny Kissin will not appear in the United States again until 2018, his manager said.
lead_paragraph: American fans of the pianist Evgeny Kissin are about to go from feast to famine. This season Mr. Kissin seems ubiquitous at some of the country’s leading concert halls, but after May he does not plan to perform in the United States again until 2018, his representatives said.

abstract: Even longtime marijuana advocates are conflicted over a legalization measure that would grant exclusive rights to growing it commercially to a group of wealthy investors.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — As a member of the International Cannabinoid Research Society, a collector of antique marijuana apothecary jars, the founder of an industrial hemp business and “a pot smoker consistently for 47 years,” Don Wirtshafter, an Ohio lawyer, has fought for decades to make marijuana legal, calling it “my life’s work.”

headline: Plastic Boat Sinks Off Greece, Killing 11 Migrants
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: A week of bad weather and drownings in the Aegean Sea continued on Sunday with more tragedy.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — A week of drownings in the Aegean Sea was capped on Sunday by more tragedy when a plastic boat carrying migrants from Turkey capsized and sank off the Greek island of Samos in high winds, killing 11 people including six children, according to Greek officials.

headline: Beware the Fine Print
abstract: When she bought her car, Tinker Martin-Bowen signed a contract with an arbitration clause that took away her right to a jury trial. Only later did she realize just what she had given up.
lead_paragraph: When she bought her car, Tinker Martin-Bowen signed a contract with an arbitration clause that took away her right to a jury trial. Only later did she realize just what she had given up.

headline: In Arbitration, a ‘Privatization of the Justice System’
abstract: Forced individual arbitration often bears little resemblance to court: The rules tend to favor businesses, and judges and juries are replaced by arbitrators whose rulings are difficult to appeal.
lead_paragraph: Deborah L. Pierce, an emergency room doctor in Philadelphia, was optimistic when she brought a sex discrimination claim against the medical group that had dismissed her. Respected by colleagues, she said she had a stack of glowing evaluations and evidence that the practice had a pattern of denying women partnerships.

headline: Paul Ryan Says He Won’t Work With Obama on Immigration Reform
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In a series of interviews televised on Sunday, the new House speaker signaled an antagonism that is likely to appeal to the conservatives within the Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker Paul D. Ryan said in a series of televised interviews on Sunday that he would not work with the Obama administration on changing immigration policy, effectively pushing off the issue to at least 2017.

headline: Elaine May to Direct Mike Nichols Documentary for PBS
abstract: Ms. May will direct an “American Masters” installment on the acclaimed director, her former comedy partner.
lead_paragraph: Roughly six decades after she teamed with Mike Nichols to form one of comedy’s most influential duos, Elaine May has again signed on for a Nichols project. Ms. May will direct an “American Masters” documentary about the acclaimed director, who died in November 2014 at 83. The film will debut on PBS on Jan. 29 to kick off the 30th season of “American Masters.”

keywords: ['Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Campaign Finance', 'State Legislatures']

lead_paragraph: In separate federal courthouses in Lower Manhattan this month, two of the most powerful men in New York are about to go on trial, an extraordinary spectacle centering on allegations of corruption, bribery and nepotism in the state’s highest chambers of political power.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 4:20 P.M. THE LUNCHBOX (2014) Food from (and for) the heart: A neglected Mumbai housewife sends a home-cooked meal to her husband — and ends up pen pals with a widowed office worker after it goes astray. The great Irrfan Khan stars. It’s not a new conceit, but “the idea of two lonely souls connecting in a vast, modern metropolis, and remaining strangers even as their intimacy grows, has a durable charm,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. (Starz Cinema) (Image: Mr. Khan)

headline: Alex Rodriguez Is an October Surprise
abstract: The Yankees star continues his surprisingly strong season, only now as a World Series analyst.
lead_paragraph: Alex Rodriguez, the Fox pregame-show version of himself, was sitting on a black couch in a trailer outside Citi Field on Friday night talking about the World Series. This is a new role for Rodriguez, an unexpected diversion in a journey of athletic greatness tainted by performance-enhancing drugs, and one he is excelling at. So he looked happy to be talking about baseball as he peered into his interviewer’s eyes, answered some questions, avoided some others and posed a few of his own. He discussed his love of preparation, his note-taking, his working with Pete Rose (“When it comes to baseball, he has an Ivy League mind”) and his admiration of Keith Hernandez.

headline: A Dazzling Encore for Mary Keitany, and a Promising Debut for Laura Thweatt
abstract: Mary Keitany of Kenya was the first woman to finish the New York City Marathon for the second straight year, while Laura Thweatt was the top American woman, finishing seventh in her marathon debut.
lead_paragraph: Running a marathon for the first time is hard enough, especially when your debut involves vying for the top American slot in the largest race in the world. So before she took off with the other professional women Sunday in the New York City Marathon, Laura Thweatt faced a special set of concerns.

headline: Cartoon: Heng on Elections in Myanmar
abstract: Voting will take place on on Nov. 8 in what is expected to be a major test for the country’s military establishment.
lead_paragraph: Voting will take place on on Nov. 8 in what is expected to be a major test for the country’s military establishment.

headline: Natural Confusion
abstract: This isn’t hard, people.
lead_paragraph: Brad DeLong is bemused by the way Tyler Cowen makes very heavy going of the simple concept of the natural rate of interest. I will say that this kind of gratuitous complexification is somewhat characteristic.

headline: Stanley Biwott of Kenya Wins New York City Marathon Men’s Race
abstract: With a burst of late speed, including running the 21st mile at a stunning 4:24, Biwott captured his first major marathon title.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Marathon had not been forgiving for Stanley Biwott of Kenya. He was among the favorites in 2012, but the race was canceled in the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy. In 2013, Biwott hung near the front for about 23 of 26.2 miles, then faded to fifth place.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Press Operation Gets an Overhaul
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s press shop is adding staff members and reshuffling existing personnel as it prepares for the final months of the nominating contest and the general election.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s press shop, the focal point of her campaign over the summer as she tried to grapple with questions about her use of private email while at the State Department, is adding staff members and reshuffling existing personnel as it prepares for the final months of the nominating contest and the general election.

headline: 1965: Gemini Astronauts to Fly in Long Johns
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Astronauts intend to wear GI underwear during their time in space in 1965.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There’s no other way to phrase it: the Gemini-7 astronauts plan to spend ten days in orbit in GI underwear. If their funnel-shaped Gemini spacecraft doesn’t spring a leak, Air Force Maj. Frank Borman and his co-pilot, Navy Lt. Cmdr. James Lovell, intend to doff their silver spacesuits and continue the 14-day flight in regulation Air Force long johns. Long practiced by Russian cosmonauts, the so-called ‘‘shirt-sleeve’’ flight was not to become a part of the U.S. space program until the three-man Apollo spacecraft begin flying in 1967. Behind the change in plans is the absolute confidence that Gemini’s pressure hull will not expose the astronauts to the vacuum of space. If it did collide with a meteoroid or suffered explosive decompression for some other reason, the astronauts would pass out in less than a minute. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 2, 1965

headline: Fatal Crash in the Bronx Unites Two Families in Grief
abstract: Emergency medical workers told the police that Howard Unger, of the Bronx, may have had a seizure before his sedan drove onto a sidewalk packed with trick-or-treaters.
lead_paragraph: Two groups of children trick-or-treating with their older relatives on Saturday briefly crossed paths on a Bronx sidewalk. They were strangers to one another when an out-of-control car veered off the avenue and over the curb.

headline: Patricia Canning Todd, 93, Dies; Tennis Champion Refused to Play on Side Court
abstract: Todd, playing as a young mother, won four Grand Slam tennis tournaments in 1947 and 1948 but lost the chance for another in 1948 when she took a stand.
lead_paragraph: Patricia Canning Todd, who won four Grand Slam tennis tournaments in 1947 and 1948 but lost the chance for another title when she refused to play on a side court at the 1948 French singles championships, died on Sept. 5 in Encinitas, Calif. She was 93.

headline: ‘Our Brand Is Crisis’ Finds Little Love at Box Office, Where ‘The Martian’ Is No. 1
abstract: The film, starring Sandra Bullock, can’t break a cold streak for Warner Bros.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Another one bites the dust: “Our Brand Is Crisis” collected a dismal $3.4 million at North American theaters over the weekend, extending a cold streak for Warner Bros. and exacerbating concerns in Hollywood about the recent failure of high-profile dramas, including “Steve Jobs” and “The Walk,” to find audiences.

headline: A.C.C. Suspends Miami-Duke Officiating Crew for Allowing Final Play
abstract: After eight laterals, Miami’s Corn Elder rambled nearly the length of the field to beat Duke, but on Sunday the league said the game officials had made four errors.
lead_paragraph: It was one of the wildest finishes you will ever see. Using lateral after lateral, Miami managed a 97-yard kickoff return as time expired to beat Duke.

headline: Willis Carto, Far-Right Figure and Holocaust Denier, Dies at 89
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: The Anti-Defamation League called Mr. Carto “one of the most influential American anti-Semitic propagandists” and “the mastermind of the hate network.”
lead_paragraph: Willis Carto, a reclusive behind-the-scenes wizard of the far-right fringe of American politics who used lobbying and publishing to denigrate Jews and other minorities and galvanize the movement to deny the Holocaust, died last Monday at his home in Virginia. He was 89.

headline: Le’Veon Bell Carted Off After Injuring Knee in Steelers’ Loss
abstract: Bell, the Steelers’ leading rusher, was injured after catching a pass from quarterback Ben Roethlisberger, who had just returned from an injury.
lead_paragraph: The Pittsburgh Steelers barely got a chance to welcome Ben Roethlisberger back from a knee injury before Le’Veon Bell went down with what appeared to be a major injury to his right knee in a game against the Cincinnati Bengals. Bell was taken to the locker room on the back of a cart, and he did not return.

headline: Fantastic Finishes, and a Domino Effect on the Rankings
abstract: Saturday’s results, although not directly involving most top teams, could still carry consequences for the College Football Playoff rankings, which come out Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Saturday would have seemed like a good day for a cocktail party if you were a college football fan, and not just because it included the actual World’s Largest Outdoor Cocktail Party, the annual Florida-Georgia game, which the No. 11 Gators (7-1, 5-1 Southeastern Conference) dominated, 27-3.

headline: For Royals’ Edinson Volquez, a Bittersweet Start in His Father’s Memory
abstract: Volquez prepared to take the mound for Game 5 of the World Series just days after his father’s death.
lead_paragraph: As Edinson Volquez went from pitch to pitch, with the game on the line for every one of them, it was impossible to tell what was churning in his mind and his heart.

headline: Jeb Bush Says He Was Unaware of Rubio PowerPoint Deck
abstract: In an interview that aired on Sunday, Mr. Bush also volunteered that he’d “kill” for his father, and said he has questions about the use of the death penalty.
lead_paragraph: In an interview that aired on Sunday, Jeb Bush said that he was unaware of a PowerPoint presentation his aides put together raising questions about his rival, Senator Marco Rubio, volunteered that he’d “kill” for his father, and said he has questions about the use of the death penalty.

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Thunder at Rockets
abstract: The Thunder are 2-0 and back to full strength, with the return of Kevin Durant and a new coach in Billy Donovan. The Rockets are 0-2 as James Harden has struggled.
lead_paragraph: Every week, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

headline: Leo P. Kadanoff, Physicist Who Explored How Matter Changes, Dies at 78
abstract: Dr. Kadanoff, a physicist, “won basically every prize except the Nobel Prize,” a colleague said.
lead_paragraph: Leo P. Kadanoff, a physicist who provided critical insights into the transformations of matter from one state to another, died on Oct. 26 in Chicago. He was 78.

headline: In Fight to Save Young People, Brooklyn Doctor Treats Violence as a Public Health Issue
abstract: Dr. Robert Gore of Kings County Hospital Center helped start a mentoring program intended to teach teenagers that while conflict may not be avoidable, violence is.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Robert Gore was stirred awake one morning in July by an urgent phone call from work. That was not unusual, given his job in the emergency department at Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn, a level-one trauma center that provides the highest level of care. Still, his years of skillful, coolheaded practice, of stopping bleeding and saving lives, had not prepared him for what he heard.

headline: Lightweight Blankets With a Big Footprint at the Marathon
abstract: The three-ounce metalized blankets for New York City Marathon finishers are designed to help ward off hypothermia, but are also marketing vehicles and keepsakes.
lead_paragraph: Sixty-five volunteers for New York Road Runners gathered early Sunday on the west side of Central Park to tackle an unusual job: stripping 52,000 metalized blankets from industrial-size rolls several hours before the start of the New York City Marathon.

headline: Getting to the Start on Time: The Race Before the Race
abstract: For many marathoners, an early morning ride on the Staten Island Ferry is one of the miniraces that precede the 26.2-mile one.
lead_paragraph: For hundreds of New York City Marathon runners, the first line they encounter on the day of the race is along the orange rails on the outer deck of the Staten Island Ferry, where they jostle for space to photograph the Statue of Liberty, illuminated in an otherwise dark, predawn sky.

headline: Adulation Aplenty as American Pharoah Heads for the Stud Farm
abstract: Horse racing fans celebrated the Triple Crown winner on Sunday a day after he closed out his stellar career on the track.
lead_paragraph: LEXINGTON, Ky. — A perky American Pharoah greeted visitors at Barn 62 on Sunday morning, a day after he won the Breeders’ Cup Classic to punctuate a competitive career in which he won nine of 11 races and captured the first Triple Crown in 37 years. His trainer, Bob Baffert, led him out of the barn at around 10 as his jubilant owner, Ahmed Zayat, stood guard.

headline: In Pro Sports, the Fan Becomes Part of the Action
abstract: The public takes part in some teams’ philanthropic efforts by choosing the recipients of donations or by giving their own money and time.
lead_paragraph: When Jeff Vinik bought the Tampa Bay Lightning in 2010, he wanted to connect with his new community. Born in New Jersey, he had lived most of his adult life in Massachusetts, not Florida, and as an owner, Mr. Vinik said he believed that helping the local community was not just the right thing to do but would also be helpful to his team.

headline: Retiree Giving Becomes a Force of Philanthropy
abstract: Retirees are expected to drive a surge in charitable contributions in coming years; even now, some are giving their time and expertise to causes.
lead_paragraph: When Carol Nash retired four years ago from Dimensions Healthcare System in Maryland after a long career in nursing, she had no inkling that she would soon be working harder than she ever did before.

headline: Spotting a Thief in a Room Full of Masks at ‘Sleep No More’
abstract: When Charlie Pflaumer felt a hand slip into his sweater during the interactive performance in Chelsea, he wasn’t sure if it was part of the show.
lead_paragraph: They arrived at their appointed time, about 8 p.m. on Monday, and showed their tickets to the doorman.

headline: In Bid to Counter Iran, Ayatollah in Iraq May End Up Emulating It
abstract: In the face of concerns over the growing power of Iran and its militia proxies, Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani has intervened in Iraqi politics, at least for now.
lead_paragraph: NAJAF, Iraq — In the struggle to transform Iraq from a dictatorship to a democracy after the American-led invasion in 2003, Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, the highest spiritual authority for many of the world’s Shiite Muslims, stood out as a singular champion of the effort to hold direct elections and ensure that politicians, and not clerics, rule the country.

headline: Patrick Modiano, an Author of Paris Mysteries, Keeps His Own
abstract: Long regarded as one of France’s most important novelists, Mr. Modiano is gaining a new audience with English translations after winning the Nobel Prize last year.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It’s often said that Patrick Modiano, who won last year’s Nobel Prize in Literature, keeps writing the same book. That is partly true, but only in the way that Cézanne kept painting the same apples. Most of this novelist’s 30-odd atmospheric books, set in the murky waters and demimonde of occupied or newly liberated Paris, resemble and build on the others, yet each is completely distinct.

headline: Q. and A.: Chan Koonchung on Imagining a Non-Communist China
abstract: In Mr. Chan’s alternative history novel, “The Second Year of Jianfeng,” the country “would definitely have been a nicer place,” he said.
lead_paragraph: Read in Chinese | 点击查看本文中文版

headline: Zanzibar Bombings May Be Related to a Disputed Election
abstract: A string of explosions on the island over the weekend left no reported injuries, but many residents and foreign embassies were concerned.
lead_paragraph: ARUSHA, Tanzania — A string of small bombings on the island of Zanzibar has residents there fearing that the explosions could be related to last month’s disputed election and that more trouble could be coming.

headline: Your Asia Briefing: Turkey’s Election, Russian Plane Crash, Asian Leaders
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day in Asia.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, Asia.

headline: In Lee Mingwei’s ‘Sonic Blossom’ at the Met, Schubert Is Intimate Installation Art
abstract: Mr. Lee’s installation presents singers performing Schubert lieder at face-to-face proximity to visitors in a contemporary gallery.
lead_paragraph: Ahead to the left on Friday morning was Yvonne Jacquette’s painting “Little River Farm”; to the right, Chuck Close’s “Lucas I,” a portrait of the artist Lucas Samaras. Straight ahead, some dozen yards away, a young soprano, Beibei Guan, having politely inquired, “May I offer you the gift of a song?” and seated me in the lone chair, sang Schubert’s “Nacht und Träume” (“Night and Dreams”) directly to me.

headline: A Lonely End for South Koreans Who Cannot Afford to Live, or Die
abstract: As a growing number of South Koreans are dying alone with no relative willing to claim their remains and perform a final ritual, an activist and his organization help to fill the void.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — In a culture in which funerals are often lavish three-day affairs with hundreds of guests, the recent funeral for Song In-sik was modest at best. It had only one guest — an activist who volunteered to hold a ritual for a person he had never met.

headline: Review: Lionel Popkin’s ‘Ruth Doesn’t Live Here Anymore’
abstract: The multimedia work about the modern-dance pioneer Ruth St. Denis ended a run at the Abrons Arts Center in Manhattan on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: What do a leaf blower and the modern-dance pioneer Ruth St. Denis have in common? For starters, both featured prominently in “Ruth Doesn’t Live Here Anymore,” a multimedia work by the Los Angeles choreographer Lionel Popkin performed at Abrons Arts Center in Manhattan on Friday.

headline: Chucho Valdés, the Pianist, Reflects on Irakere and His Career
abstract: Mr. Valdés’s expansive career has included an influential hybrid band and, recently, a major concert in Havana.
lead_paragraph: Chucho Valdés, the eminent Cuban pianist, bandleader and composer, carries himself with a sly balance of statesmanlike deliberation and youthful gusto. One day last month, not long before his 74th birthday, he folded his big frame onto a couch in a Midtown hotel and spoke animatedly about the last 40 years of musical exchange between the United States and Cuba — a dialogue that has largely defined his career, and one that he in turn has helped define.

headline: Review: Andras Schiff Deconstructs Sonatas
abstract: The pianist played a sprawling program that included the sonatas of Haydn, Mozart, Beethoven and Schubert at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: Deep in the second movement of Beethoven’s last piano sonata there’s a passage that’s become known as the boogie-woogie variation. The music, written in the early 1820s, suddenly breaks into a syncopated, showy dance that seems to anticipate the ragtime that would come almost a century later. A swinging riff repeats again and again, punctuated each time by two bold chords.

headline: Review: ‘Black Work,’ a Mystery and Drama with Sheridan Smith
abstract: Ms. Smith plays a British police constable struggling with a blended family and covertly investigating the murder of her husband, another cop.
lead_paragraph: Sheridan Smith is one of the busiest and most popular actresses in Britain, but very little of her work has made it to the United States. She won a Bafta award for playing a famous criminal’s wife (in “Mrs. Biggs”) and was nominated for another for playing a famous singer (“Cilla”). If she’s known here at all, though, it’s for one role — Rudi, the foul-mouthed, fiercely loyal younger sister of James Corden’s Smithy in “Gavin & Stacey.”

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Nov. 2
keywords: ['Municipal Bonds', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: ‘The Diplomat,’ a Son’s Documentary on Richard C. Holbrooke
keywords: ['Television', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: The film is a career retrospective of a brilliant if infuriating statesman, coupled with a son’s search for the father who had been absent much of his life.
lead_paragraph: In January 2011, seated alongside presidents and dignitaries at the Kennedy Center memorial service for Richard C. Holbrooke, his son David finally came to see his father as a historical figure.

headline: Review: ‘Pacific’ Is Simon Winchester’s Latest Big-Picture Book
abstract: Mr. Winchester spells out how the world’s largest body of water has been a player in subjects as varied as war and pop culture.
lead_paragraph: In the prologue to “Pacific: Silicon Chips and Surfboards, Coral Reefs and Atom Bombs, Brutal Dictators, Fading Empires, and the Coming Collision of the World’s Superpowers,” Simon Winchester does such a virtuoso job of conveying the roiling enormity of his subject that readers may feel a kind of existential terror, wondering whether the vacant sky or the open sea will swallow them first.

headline: Republican Campaigns Meet in an Effort to Alter Debates
abstract: After candidates complained about the CNBC questions, the goal is to develop a strategy for how to exert more influence on the process.
lead_paragraph: ALEXANDRIA, Va. — The presidential candidates in the crowded Republican field finally can agree on at least one thing: just how frustrated they are with the debate process so far.

headline: These Competitors Measure Their Times in Years
abstract: Those who have run the New York City Marathon again and again and again are known as streakers, and there are some rivalries among them over their longevity.
lead_paragraph: The trash talking began days before Sunday’s New York City Marathon. Not among the elite runners, though, at least for this story.

headline: Dangers for the Unwary
abstract: In which I am supportive of Loren Muse Smith’s and Andrea Carla Michaels’s fun Monday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Notepad-in-the-Tuesday-Puzzle Alert! If you solve the crossword using Across Lite, the iOS app or the Windows app, please take the time to read the Notepad in the Tuesday puzzle. I can’t tell you what it says because it would spoil the puzzle, but trust the emus: you’ll have a much better experience if you read it.

headline: Petition Urges Ayatollah to Pardon Condemned Iranian Poets
abstract: A letter signed by more than 100 poets and writers pledges support for two poets sentenced to prison and floggings, calling their prosecution inhuman.
lead_paragraph: Two Iranian poets sentenced to long prison terms and floggings have vaulted to international literary prominence over their prosecution, which appears to reflect a tough new crackdown on rights and creative arts in Iran.

headline: Fred Thompson, Former Senator, Actor and Presidential Candidate, Dies at 73
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Television', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Presidential Election of 2008']
abstract: Mr. Thompson, a former Republican lawmaker, had an unusual career that bridged the worlds of national politics and mass-market entertainment.
lead_paragraph: Fred D. Thompson, a former United States senator, actor and Republican presidential candidate, died on Sunday in Nashville. He was 73.

headline: Halsman, Jump on It
abstract: Philippe Halsman’s famed method for getting his subjects to let down their defenses and offer a glimpse of their personalities.
lead_paragraph: Philippe Halsman’s famed method for getting his subjects to let down their defenses and offer a glimpse of their personalities.

headline: Drew Brees Throws Seven Touchdown Passes as Saints Beat Giants in Final Seconds
abstract: In a high-octane game, Drew Brees tied the N.F.L. single-game record for touchdown passes, and he and Eli Manning combined for 13 touchdown passes, an N.F.L. single-game record.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — After 101 points, after a punter’s illicit tackle and after a kicker’s textbook field goal had somehow decided a flabbergasting duel between two brilliant quarterbacks, some things still did not add up.

headline: David Walters, 60, Runs to Beat Father Time, if Not His Own Time
abstract: Walters, who maintains a grueling training schedule despite knowing his best times are behind him, completed the New York City Marathon in 2:47:27.
lead_paragraph: A half an hour or so after Stanley Biwott of Kenya won the New York City Marathon, he was followed by a grinning man nearly old enough to be his grandfather: David Walters, the first sexagenarian to cross the finish line Sunday.

headline: Review: Communicating With the Spirit World Through Dance
abstract: The Construction Company’s “A Trail of Irreverence” mixed pieces by three choreographers: Sally Gross, Kenneth King and Sally Silvers.
lead_paragraph: One of the spookiest events this Halloween weekend may have been the dance concert presented by the Construction Company at University Settlement. There were no vampires or zombies, yet on Friday there was more than a suggestion of communication with the spirit world.

headline: The Best Moments in College Football This Week
abstract: A look at some of the top story lines from the ninth week of the 2015 college football season.
lead_paragraph: KEENAN REYNOLDS The Navy senior quarterback scored twice in the fourth quarter to tie the collegiate mark for career rushing touchdowns, and the Midshipmen set a team record with three 100-yard rushers in a 29-17 home victory over South Florida.

headline: Ryan Fitzpatrick Is Injured and the Jets Are Routed by the Raiders
abstract: Two straight losses after a promising start to the season allow uncertainty to creep into the team’s headquarters, and the locker room.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Ryan Fitzpatrick stood at his locker, a cellphone cradled against his ear, his back to the room, his damaged left thumb wrapped. Beside him sat Geno Smith, who had returned minutes earlier from a visit to the X-ray room at O.co Coliseum.

headline: Police Investigating Colorado Springs Shooting That Left 4 Dead
abstract: Officials said they would not release more details until autopsies of three victims and the suspect, who died in an exchange of fire with the police, had been completed.
lead_paragraph: Law enforcement authorities in Colorado were investigating a shooting over the weekend that left four people dead, including the suspect, who was killed in an exchange of gunfire with police officers in Colorado Springs.

headline: Monday’s Matchup: Colts (3-4) at Panthers (6-0)
abstract: This game should serve as a chance for the Panthers to show off just how improved their defense is this season.
lead_paragraph: Colts (3-4) at Panthers (6-0)

headline: Review: In Piotr Beczala’s Recital, Melancholy Mixes With Defiance
abstract: Mr. Beczala, the Polish tenor, performed songs by Schumann, Rachmaninoff, Dvorak and Mieczyslaw Karlowicz at Zankel Hall on Friday with the pianist Martin Katz.
lead_paragraph: The Polish tenor Piotr Beczala has developed an ardent fan base in recent years. That much was evident from the adoring capacity crowd that turned out for his recital debut at Zankel Hall on Friday with the pianist Martin Katz. The program of songs by Schumann, Rachmaninoff, Dvorak and the fin-de-siècle Polish composer Mieczyslaw Karlowicz beautifully showcased his rich, virile voice, with its appealingly dark undertow.

headline: Washington State Weighs Far-Reaching Law on Animal Trafficking
abstract: An initiative that voters will decide Tuesday would criminalize the modern trade that is wiping out many threatened species but would allow, with strict rules, heirlooms.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Wildlife poachers in Africa slaughter rhinos for their horns and elephants for their tusks, and organized crime gangs from Ireland to Mexico have in recent years expanded into the trade of endangered animal parts that can command more money, pound for pound, than even gold.

headline: The 10th One Is Free
abstract: Part of life’s morning routine is watching the progress of the coffee punch card, day by day, with growing anticipation.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Officers’ Boycott of Quentin Tarantino Films Grows
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Movies', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Police']
abstract: Responding to what it called Mr. Tarantino’s “anti-police rhetoric,” the National Association of Police Organizations asked supporters to refuse to provide security or technical advice for his future projects.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A call for a police boycott of the Weinstein Company’s coming film “The Hateful Eight” and other works by Quentin Tarantino has gained support from the National Association of Police Organizations and the New Jersey State Policemen’s Benevolent Association, expanding the backlash to remarks about police violence that Mr. Tarantino made at a rally in New York on Oct. 24.

headline: Well-Known and Worn-Out Marathoners
abstract: The actor Ethan Hawke finished in 4 hours 25 minutes.
lead_paragraph: The actor Ethan Hawke finished in 4 hours 25 minutes. His time was more than two hours off the world record, but that was not the point. He and his wife, Ryan, ran to raise money for charity.

headline: The Seahawks-Cowboys Matchup Should Have Been Great. It Wasn’t.
abstract: Both teams were N.F.C. favorites when the schedule was released, but distractions and injuries have made them mediocre.
lead_paragraph: It should have been a matchup of N.F.C. heavyweights. The Seattle Seahawks, two-time defending conference champions, traveled to Dallas to face the Cowboys, who entered this season as a playoff favorite.

headline: Producer of ‘The Godfather’ Lands Rights to ‘Atlas Shrugged’ Novel
abstract: Albert S. Ruddy, who approached Ayn Rand in the 1970s about a screen version of her novel, plans to make a six- to eight-hour television mini-series.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It took a while — more than 40 years, actually.

headline: Gay Candidates Find Support, or at Least a Shrug, in Salt Lake City
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Elections, Mayors', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: A mayoral contender and two others hope to cement the area’s reputation as a rainbow island surrounded by a red state.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — It was only at the end of the debate — after arguments over city rail service, policing and homelessness — that Jackie Biskupski nodded to how her mayoral run could make history here in Utah’s capital.

headline: An Early Start Before a Flourish to the Finish
abstract: Temperatures were in the mid-50s on a cloudy morning for the start of the New York City Marathon, which was won by Stanley Biwott of the men’s division and Mary Keitany of the women’s.
lead_paragraph: Temperatures were in the mid-50s on a cloudy morning for the start of the New York City Marathon, which was won by Stanley Biwott of the men’s division and Mary Keitany of the women’s.

headline: Thousands Start Life Anew With Early Prison Releases
keywords: ['Mandatory Sentencing', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Ex-Convicts', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Probation and Parole']
abstract: The initial group of prisoners, who were released as a result of an adjustment of federal drug penalties, had sentences that averaged 10.5 years.
lead_paragraph: Michael Keating’s 11-year prison sentence for methamphetamine production was supposed to end next June. But he is one of thousands of federal prisoners who are benefiting from a reduction in drug sentences, and on Friday he became an ex-prisoner more than seven months earlier than he ever had reason to expect.

headline: BMG Expected to Announce Deal With the Pop Label S-Curve
abstract: BMG plans to acquire S-Curve’s recorded music and publishing catalogs. The deal is estimated to be worth at least $10 million.
lead_paragraph: BMG, the former record company that seven years ago started over with a new catalog and approach, has added again to its growing stable of projects with S-Curve, an independent pop label that scored a big hit this year with Andy Grammer’s “Honey, I’m Good.”

headline: Q. and A.: The Trial of Sheldon Silver
abstract: Key questions in the corruption case against Mr. Silver, once one of the most powerful men in New York.
lead_paragraph: Who is Sheldon Silver?

headline: Review: Mina Nishimura’s Peculiar and Promising Premiere
abstract: “The Celery of Everything” draws upon textual images from the writings of Tatsumi Hijikata, a founder of the Japanese dance-theater form Butoh.

headline: If Cancer Becomes Biden’s Cause, a Bold but Polarizing Doctor Is On Call
abstract: Dr. Patrick Soon-Shiong, who made a fortune developing a cancer drug, has developed a relationship with Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. as he weighs life out of office.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One day last winter, desperate as his son fought for his life against a killer brain cancer, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his family reached out to one of America’s most famous, and controversial, doctors for help.

headline: After Relenting to His Ace, Terry Collins Opens Door to More Scrutiny
abstract: For the second consecutive game, Collins had waited to use Jeurys Familia, only to put him in an awkward position with runners on base. For the second time, Familia blew the save.
lead_paragraph: In the eighth inning of Game 5 of the World Series, with the Mets facing elimination, Matt Harvey rushed over to Manager Terry Collins in the dugout, looking angry and shaking his head. Collins had tried removing Harvey from the game, in which he had held the Royals scoreless. The crowd was chanting Harvey’s name, urging Collins to keep him in.

headline: John Kerry Is Cautious on Human Rights During Uzbekistan Visit
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: On the second stop of a Central Asian tour, Mr. Kerry found himself struggling over how hard, and how publicly, to press one of the harshest authoritarian governments in the world.
lead_paragraph: SAMARKAND, Uzbekistan — Secretary of State John Kerry prides himself on his willingness to deal directly with some of the world’s most repressive governments, and his insistence on “engagement” has yielded results this year from Iran to Cuba. But even the State Department had a hard time explaining the strategy for transforming the behavior of President Islam Karimov of Uzbekistan, a ruler whose human rights record is frequently compared to North Korea’s.

headline: San Francisco Ballots Turn Up Anger Over the Technical Divide
abstract: On Tuesday, voters will weigh in on propositions linked to the technology industry and rising housing costs, including one to restrict Airbnb’s home-sharing.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Bruce Bennett is 52 and has a bum knee in need of surgery. But two Sundays ago he put on a knee brace and huffed his way up steep hills and dozens of stairs to implore residents to vote against a city measure called Proposition F.

keywords: ['Company Reports', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Computers and the Internet', 'News and News Media']

headline: Debris Suggests Russian Airliner Disintegrated While Aloft, Officials Say
abstract: The potential explanations for the fatal Egyptian Sinai crash include several possibilities, from a sudden mechanical or structural failure to a terrorist attack.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Airbus A321-200 had just reached a cruising altitude of about 33,000 feet when, around 20 minutes after taking off from the Egyptian resort town of Sharm el-Sheikh, it suddenly plummeted by some 6,000 feet.

headline: When Royals’ Wade Davis Comes In, the Game Is as Good as Over
abstract: Like the Giants’ Madison Bumgarner the year before, Wade Davis has been the immovable force of this postseason.
lead_paragraph: A popular talking point before this postseason was guessing which pitcher would be the next Madison Bumgarner. The answer, of course, was nobody — his dominance last fall, in toppling the Kansas City Royals, was nearly unparalleled in the annals of autumn.

headline: F.B.I. Tool to Identify Extremists Is Criticized
keywords: ['Muslim Americans', 'Terrorism', 'Education (K-12)', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: An interactive program, developed for teachers and students, is aimed at training them to prevent young people from being drawn into violent extremism. However some religious leaders say it only focuses on Islamic extremism.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. is about to introduce an interactive program it developed for teachers and students, aimed at training them to prevent young people from being drawn into violent extremism. But Muslim, Arab and other religious and civil rights leaders who were invited to preview the program have raised strong objections, saying it focuses almost entirely on Islamic extremism, which they say has not been a factor in the epidemic of school shootings and attacks in the United States.

headline: Long Line at the Library? It’s Story Time Again
keywords: ['Libraries and Librarians', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Amid an increasing emphasis on the importance of early literacy, libraries in New York are seeing attendance surge at the once-informal reading circles that are becoming fixtures of family routines.
lead_paragraph: Forty strollers were double- and triple-parked on the main floor of the Fort Washington Library in Upper Manhattan. As another one came through the door, Velda Asbury waved toward a spot beside a book stack.

headline: Lotto Campaign Ribbing the Rich Seizes a Moment

headline: Günter Schabowski, Whose Gaffe Helped Burst the Berlin Wall, Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Schabowski’s bumbling answer to a reporter’s question inadvertently led to the opening of the Cold War’s most notorious closed border.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Günter Schabowski, whose bumbling answer to a reporter’s question on the night of Nov. 9, 1989, inadvertently led throngs of East Germans to force their way across the Berlin Wall, effectively opening the Cold War’s most notorious closed border, died here on Sunday. He was 86.

headline: The Hustle of Publishing Art News in the Postprint Era

lead_paragraph: Phong Bui, an artist and curator and a founder of the art newspaper The Brooklyn Rail, makes an unlikely media executive.

headline: Raven-Symoné of ‘The View’ and CNN’s Don Lemon Face Backlash
abstract: Petitions calling for their dismissal over remarks on a South Carolina deputy’s rough arrest of a student have received tens of thousands of signatures.
lead_paragraph: As videos of a South Carolina deputy’s rough arrest of an African-American female student ricocheted across the Internet last week, the condemnation was swift. But some black television viewers, upset by comments they saw as excusing the deputy’s use of force, have begun circulating petitions condemning two prominent black personalities.

headline: Owner of The Orange County Register Files for Bankruptcy Protection
abstract: Rich Mirman, the chief executive of Freedom Communications and the publisher of the Register, said he was leading a group of investors hoping purchase the company at a court-supervised auction.
lead_paragraph: Burdened by debt and struggling to meet its financial obligations, Freedom Communications, the media company that owns The Orange County Register, filed for bankruptcy protection on Sunday with an eye toward selling the company to the publisher and a group of local investors.

headline: The Best of Week 8 in the N.F.L.
abstract: The top performers and key injuries in the league this week.
lead_paragraph: Even with linebacker Jadeveon Clowney sidelined — he injured his back in the first quarter and left for good in the second — the Texans turned in a dominating defensive performance, forcing three Titans turnovers and tying a franchise record with seven sacks to rebound from a 44-26 loss to the Dolphins last week. Whitney Mercilus accounted for three and a half of those sacks, a career high, and J. J. Watt had two and a half, forcing a fumble on one early in the fourth quarter. Watt, who tied a career high with nine quarterback hits, said, “That’s the type of defense we expect to be.”

headline: Battles in San Francisco, but Not in Mayoral Race
abstract: Ballot initiatives reflect deep divisions over development and housing, but Mayor Edwin Lee is gliding to re-election.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — This city has been racked by battles over development, a homeless population that spills onto its stoops and sidewalks, rocketing housing costs and increases in violent crime. With its gleaming new buildings and influx of Silicon Valley wealth, San Francisco has the fastest-growing income inequality gap in the nation.

headline: Review: In ‘King Charles III,’ Glimpsing the Near Future of Monarchy
abstract: Mike Bartlett’s prize-winning play comes to Broadway from London with its cast, Shakespearean stylings and free verse intact.
lead_paragraph: To sign, or not to sign. That is the question that hangs so urgently over the wavering title character of “King Charles III,” Mike Bartlett’s flat-out brilliant portrait of a monarchy in crisis, which blazed open on Sunday night at the Music Box Theater.

abstract: And poor Quinn, left to his brooding angel.

lead_paragraph: Ixtell Almonte wears sparkling barrettes in her thick black hair, belts decorated with bluebird-colored flowers and silver sparkling shoes — clothes bought by parents who treat her like a princess.

lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Malcolm Turnbull has ended the use of knights and dames as part of the Order of Australia, in a rebuttal of the leadership style of his predecessor, Tony Abbott.

headline: Caged Hostages From Syrian President’s Sect Paraded Through Rebel-Held Suburb
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Propaganda', 'Political Prisoners', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: An activist close to the antigovernment Army of Islam said prisoners would be placed on rooftops and in streets in territory it holds outside Damascus “so they can taste our misery.”
lead_paragraph: Two days after Syrian government forces shelled a rebel-held suburb of the capital, Damascus, killing at least 40 people in a market, according to antigovernment activists, caged prisoners, said to be former army officers from the president’s sect, were displayed on the streets there, apparently to shield the area from further bombardment.

headline: Leaders of South Korea and Japan Meet in Effort to Mend Ties

lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — President Park Geun-hye of South Korea and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan held the first high-level meeting between their two nations in more than three years on Monday and agreed to accelerate talks on repairing ties strained by bitterness rooted in Japan’s colonial rule of Korea.

headline: ‘Project Greenlight’ Gives Rookie Director a Hollywood Education

headline: ‘The Affair’ Season 2 Episode 5: Never Read the Book
abstract: Alison continues to be a bundle of guilt, neurosis and awkwardness.
lead_paragraph: O.K., it’s obvious that writing snippets of a fictional novel so that they can be read aloud on television — a novel whose author, we’ve been told, is “an incredibly strong writer” — is a losing proposition. They’re never going to be good enough. But when we finally heard bits and pieces of Noah Solloway’s “Descent” on “The Affair” on Sunday night, it was hard to have much sympathy for the screenwriter (in this case the playwright Sharr White).

headline: What’s Streaming Now

Her colleagues expect her to mind her own business. But when sinister secrets surface, as you know they inevitably will (like how her husband was spying on her and probably knew about the affair she was almost having), she sets out to uncover the killer. Matt Charman, a writer on Steven Spielberg’s “Bridge of Spies,” created this three-part thriller, which stars Sheridan Smith. (Acorn TV) (Image: Ms. Smith and Matthew McNulty)

headline: A Rooftop View of Insect Migration in a Warming Climate
abstract: Researchers at the Natural History Museum of Denmark say that climate change is affecting specialized insects that rely on a single food source.
lead_paragraph: The Natural History Museum of Denmark has studied the insect population on its rooftop for 18 years, tracking 1,543 species of moths and beetles and more than 250,000 individuals. In a study appearing in The Journal of Animal Ecology, museum researchers conclude that warming temperatures are affecting specialized insects that rely on a single food source. The nut weevil, for example, feeds only on hazelnuts; it appeared on the roof during the first half of the study but not the second. Scientists at the museum suspect that the nut weevil and other specialists are moving north, where the climate is cooler.

headline: How to Live a Lie
abstract: We can act as if God, morality and free will exist, even when we are certain they don’t.
lead_paragraph: Few things are more annoying than watching a movie with someone who repeatedly tells you, “That couldn’t happen.” After all, we engage with artistic fictions by suspending disbelief. For the sake of enjoying a movie like “Back to the Future,” I may accept that time travel is possible even though I do not believe it. There seems no harm in that, and it does some good to the extent that it entertains and edifies me.

headline: More Stand Your Ground Mischief in Florida
abstract: The State Legislature wants to make it even easier for defendants to use the notorious law as a shield.
lead_paragraph: The Florida Legislature, never one to leave bad enough alone when it comes to gun safety, is returning to the state’s notorious Stand Your Ground law to make it even easier for defendants to use it as a shield for intimidating and shooting people. Senate committees approved legislation this month that would relieve defendants of the need to prove that they were in fear for their lives. Instead, prosecutors would be required to disprove the self-defense claim in a pretrial evidentiary hearing.

headline: Amartya Sen: Women’s Progress Outdid China’s One-Child Policy
keywords: ['Birth Rates', 'Population', 'Women and Girls', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Child Abandonment', "Women's Rights", 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: What really brought down China’s birthrate was its education and empowerment of women, not the one-child policy.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — THE abandonment of the one-child policy in China is a momentous change, and there is much to celebrate in the easing of restrictions on human freedom in a particularly private sphere of life. But we need to recognize that the big fall in fertility in China over the decades, for which the one-child policy is often credited, has, in fact, been less related to compulsion and much more to reasoned family decisions in favor of a new norm of smaller families.

headline: Halsman, Jump on It
abstract: A reissue of Philippe Halsman’s “Jump Book” displays his famed method for getting his subjects to let down their defenses and offer a glimpse of their personalities.
lead_paragraph: Any portrait photographer knows how hard it can be to get beyond a subject’s facade, especially in a studio setting. Irving Penn famously positioned celebrities into a narrow corner. Yousuf Karsh sometimes left his subjects alone for a few minutes between exposures. Richard Avedon is said to have told the Duke and Duchess of Windsor a made-up story about a dog being run over by his taxi in order to move past the royal pretense and evoke a sympathetic expression (it worked).

headline: Former Editor of Xinjiang Newspaper in China Is Ousted From Communist Party
abstract: The party said the former editor, Zhao Xinyu, had been expelled for openly discussing party policy and for corruption.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Communist Party has expelled the recent editor in chief of the official newspaper of the volatile western region of Xinjiang for openly discussing party policy and for corruption, according to an online announcement on Monday by the regional party anticorruption agency. The former editor is expected to face criminal prosecution on related charges.

headline: Ad Helped Chris Christie Win a New Jersey Race, but Then He Had to Apologize
abstract: An attack by the future presidential candidate while seeking office in Morris County showed his tactics early. There was just one problem: It was inaccurate.
lead_paragraph: In his Williamstown, N.J., home, tucked away among family ephemera, Christopher Laureys keeps that rarest of New Jersey treasures: an apology from Chris Christie.

headline: ‘Winter Is Coming,’ by Garry Kasparov
abstract: Kasparov makes his case against the Putin presidency and points to the West’s role in his rule.
lead_paragraph: Russians in positions of power tend to measure their country’s standing in the world against the United States, longing to be recognized as equally important and powerful and getting very angry when they’re not so treated. President Vladimir Putin has made victimhood at America’s hands a leitmotif of his reign, and many Russians have bought into his claim that Washington tirelessly seeks ways to weaken, impoverish and otherwise humiliate their country. Many critics of Putin, in Russia and in the West, similarly hold that Washington’s treatment of Russia after the collapse of the Soviet Union was disdainful and thus undermined embryonic moves toward democracy, contributing to the rise of Putinism.

headline: ‘The New Tsar: The Rise and Reign of Vladimir Putin,’ by Steven Lee Myers
abstract: The ascent of the ambitious autocrat from K.G.B. operative to self-appointed defender of his nation.
lead_paragraph: Vladimir Putin has an origin story. It takes place in Dresden in the fall of 1989, in the dying days of East Germany, on the night that thousands of protesters stormed the city’s Stasi headquarters. Once they were done ransacking the offices that had inspired so much terror, they directed their anger down the street toward the K.G.B. residence where Lieutenant Colonel Putin, a young intelligence officer, stood looking out the window. Watching the approaching mob, Putin called the local Soviet military command and asked for reinforcements. But no higher authority would approve it. “Moscow is silent,” he was told.

headline: Michel Houellebecq’s ‘Submission’
abstract: Karl Ove Knausgaard reviews Michel Houellebecq’s new novel, which imagines France as a Muslim state in 2022.
lead_paragraph: Before I begin this review, I have to make a small confession. I have never read Michel Houellebecq’s books. This is odd, I concede, since Houellebecq is considered a great contemporary author, and one cannot be said to be keeping abreast of contemporary literature without reading his work. His books have been recommended to me ever since 1998, most often “The Elementary Particles,” by one friend in particular, who says the same thing every time I see him. You have to read “The Elementary Particles,” he tells me, it’s awesome, the best book I’ve ever read. Several times I’ve been on the verge of heeding his advice, plucking “The Elementary Particles” from its place on my shelf and considering it for a while, though always returning it unread. The resistance to starting a book by Houellebecq is too great. I’m not entirely sure where it comes from, though I do have a suspicion, because the same thing goes for the films of Lars von Trier: When “Antichrist” came out I couldn’t bring myself to see it, neither in the cinema nor at home on the DVD I eventually bought, which remains in its box unwatched. They’re simply too good. What prevents me from reading Houellebecq and watching von Trier is a kind of envy — not that I begrudge them success, but by reading the books and watching the films I would be reminded of how excellent a work of art can be, and of how far beneath that level my own work is. Such a reminder, which can be crushing, is something I shield myself from by ignoring Houellebecq’s books and von Trier’s films. That may sound strange, and yet it can hardly be unusual. If you’re a carpenter, for instance, and you keep hearing about the amazing work of another carpenter, you’re not necessarily going to seek it out, because what would be the good of having it confirmed that there is a level of excellence to which you may never aspire? Better to close your eyes and carry on with your own work, pretending the master carpenter doesn’t exist.

headline: Obama Takes Steps to Help Former Inmates Find Jobs and Homes
keywords: ['Ex-Convicts', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: The measures announced by President Obama include a push to give ex-prisoners greater leeway to apply for jobs and housing without disclosing their criminal records.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — President Obama ordered federal agencies on Monday to stop asking most prospective employees about their criminal histories at the beginning of the application process, a change long sought by activists to help reintegrate former inmates into society.

headline: ScienceTake | Cricket Ballet
abstract: Some crickets manage their soaring leaps — 50 to 60 times their body length — with dancelike movements of their legs and antennae.
lead_paragraph: Some crickets manage their soaring leaps — 50 to 60 times their body length — with dancelike movements of their legs and antennae.

headline: Crickets and Their Spectacular Dancelike Leaps
abstract: The soaring jumps of an invasive cricket look like an insect ballet in slow motion.

headline: Taking the Measure of Body Temperature
abstract: If our normal body temperature is about 98.6 degrees Fahrenheit, or 37 degrees centigrade, why aren’t we most comfortable when the temperature around us is the same?
lead_paragraph: Q. If our normal body temperature is about 98.6 degrees Fahrenheit, or 37 degrees Celsius, why aren’t we most comfortable when the temperature around us is the same?

lead_paragraph: Hurricane Patricia was a surprise. The eastern Pacific hurricane strengthened explosively before hitting the coast of Mexico, far exceeding projections of scientists who study such storms.

headline: Seen a Spy? With New Hotline, China Invites You to Call It In
abstract: The hotline comes after a spate of reported spying episodes around the country.
lead_paragraph: To the tangle of emergency phone numbers in China — 110 for the police, 119 for fire, 120 for ambulance — add another: dial 12339 to report a spy.

headline: Know Your Risks, but Meat Still Isn’t the Enemy
abstract: The link between processed meat and cancer is not as scary as many headlines would have you believe.
lead_paragraph: Smoking tobacco causes cancer. So does eating salted fish, drinking alcohol, breathing polluted air and being exposed to the sun. All of these things are classified as cancer-causing by the World Health Organization.

headline: Mystery Deepens Over Russian Plane Crash in Egypt
abstract: The Russian charter airline company that operated the flight ruled out mechanical or pilot error. The government said such conclusions were premature.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The mystery deepened Monday over the weekend crash of a Russian charter plane on the Sinai Peninsula in Egypt that killed all 224 aboard, with company executives ruling out technical or human error only to be upbraided by aviation officials who called such assertions premature.

headline: After Rough Patch, Bush Begins His ‘Jeb Can Fix It’ Tour
abstract: Mr. Bush, who is straining to reassure donors and other supporters after another underwhelming debate performance last week, will give what his team has previewed as “an important speech” on Monday about the direction of the campaign and the messages he plans to promote going forward.
lead_paragraph: The much-discussed Jeb Bush campaign reset has come with an unsubtle name: the “Jeb Can Fix It” tour.

headline: Mary Gaitskill and the Life Unseen
abstract: In her new novel,­ the author — known for depicting violent sex and lonely people — delves into the most frightening subject of all: real connection.
lead_paragraph: When the writer Mary Gaitskill was a child in the 1950s, she was once taken to a roller-skating rink. She looked around and burst into tears. She didn’t understand why everybody was wearing the same thing, those poodle skirts and poodle hairdos.

headline: Wireless Start-up Artemis Reaches Deal With Nokia
abstract: Executives at the company believe they have found a way to maintain Internet speeds over overwhelmed wireless networks.
lead_paragraph: A little over a year ago, a start-up in San Francisco called Artemis Networks announced a new technology that it said could enable much faster Internet access speeds over wireless networks, which often slow dramatically when too many people use their smartphones in busy locations.

headline: Visa to Buy Back Former Europe Unit for Up to $23.3 Billion
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Company Reports', 'Initial Public Offerings']
abstract: The two companies had operated separately since 2007, splitting shortly before Visa went public in an $18 billion initial public offering.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Visa said on Monday that it had reached an agreement to pay as much as 21.2 billion euros, or about $23.3 billion, to acquire its former unit Visa Europe Ltd.

headline: ‘The Leftovers’ Season 2, Episode 5: Laughing With God
abstract: Sunday’s episode focused on the seemingly boundless bad luck that befalls Matt Jamison.
lead_paragraph: Sunday’s “The Leftovers” was the most compelling hour so far of season two, and that’s a bold statement considering how outstanding the second season has been. “No Room at the Inn” — which, like season one’s third episode, focused on the seemingly boundless bad luck that befalls Matt Jamison — was a pulse-pounder: intense, semi-violent, and surprising in scene after scene. It also continued to lock in on the themes of spirituality and faith that are central to “The Leftovers,” in ways overt (the conversation between John Murphy and Matt) and more subtle (the use of that Regina Spektor song that declares, “We’re all laughing with God”).

headline: Protecting Underage Models Becomes a Federal Issue
abstract: Just as a new fashion trend of young models surfaces, a House bill proposes extending workplace safety regulations to cover them.
lead_paragraph: Paul D. Ryan, the new speaker of the House of Representatives, has another potential issue on his hands. For the first time since Brooke Shields donned her Calvins in the ’80s, spurring a national conversation, the question of underage models has reached the white dome of the Capitol.

headline: Heavy Fog Envelops Parts of Europe, Canceling Flights
abstract: The thick mist is not uncommon at this time of year, but it was so dense that even fog-hardened Britons were taking to Twitter to share photographs.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Dense fog caused scores of flights to be delayed or canceled early Monday across three of the world’s busiest aviation hubs — London, Amsterdam and Frankfurt — and shrouded London landmarks like St. Paul’s Cathedral and the Houses of Parliament in a thick mist that was remarkable even by the capital’s standards.

lead_paragraph: The family’s collection includes a copy of the lunar boot worn by Neil Armstrong during his 1969 moon landing.

headline: This Time Around, Royals Catcher Salvador Perez Goes Out as the M.V.P.
abstract: After making the last out in a 2014 World Series loss to the San Francisco Giants, Perez was redeemed in 2015.
lead_paragraph: Moments after Salvador Perez was presented the World Series Most Valuable Player Award, he cradled the metallic trophy in his arms like a baby, put his head down and went jogging from the clubhouse tunnel back out to the field to find a woman he wanted to share in the moment.

headline: Iran Begins Deactivating Centrifuges Under Nuclear Deal’s Terms
abstract: The head of Iran’s nuclear energy program said in Japan that the nation has started decommissioning the first of thousands of centrifuges used for enriching uranium.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iran has started decommissioning the first of thousands of centrifuges used for enriching uranium as part of its commitments under the nuclear deal reached with global powers, the head of Iran’s nuclear energy program was quoted as saying on a visit to Japan on Monday.

headline: Irish Drug Maker Shire Agrees to Buy Dyax in Deal Worth Up to $6.5 Billion
abstract: The transaction would be the latest in an acquisition spree by Shire since its tentative agreement to be bought by the drug maker AbbVie was terminated.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Irish drug maker Shire said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire the American biotechnology company Dyax Corporation in a deal that could be worth as much as $6.5 billion.

headline: Peyton Manning of Old Shows Up, and the Broncos Stay Undefeated
abstract: Derided for his soft passes and turnovers, Manning responded by airing the ball out against the Packers, one of the top defenses in the N.F.L.
lead_paragraph: The reports of Peyton Manning’s demise may have been exaggerated.

headline: A Quiet Swiss Town’s Unlikely Treasure: Shoes
abstract: One of the world’s most important collections of footwear lives in an 18th-century manor north of the Alps.
lead_paragraph: ONE OF THE MOST IMPORTANT collections of footwear in Europe — and arguably the world — is not housed in a grand museum in Rome or Paris but in a remote 18th-century manor high north of the Swiss Alps owned by Bally, the 164-year-old fashion and leather goods brand best known for its shoes. In a storybook town between Zurich and Basel is Zum Felsengarten, home to the Bally Shoe Museum in Schönenwerd. Inside, more than 1,000 pairs of footwear represent 3,000 years of history: French court heels from the 17th century, Venetian platforms from the 16th, Queen Elizabeth II’s gold coronation shoes.

headline: How Donald Trump Leverages America’s Fault Lines
abstract: Certain personality traits, like openness to novelty, affect how people vote in presidential races, polling results show.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who has spent any time analyzing public opinion and voting data from the last 20 or so years has seen the fault lines that Donald Trump is leveraging. The data is clear: Anxiety about those who are different, support for traditional American values and a resistance toward openness all play a role in how people make up their minds in presidential elections.

headline: When Free Speech Disappears From Campus
abstract: The willingness to discuss uncomfortable ideas is under threat at American universities. What does this say about millennials as future leaders of this country?

headline: 1890: Prince Bismarck as a Brewer
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Prince Bismarck devotes money to start a new brewery in 1890.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — It is announced that Prince Bismarck, together with a syndicate of Hamburg financiers, will establish a large brewery at Friedrichsruhe, with a capital of 600,000 marks. The brewery will, it is estimated, produce about 25,000 hectoliters of beer yearly. The Hamburg Association will own the brewery for fifty years, paying the ex-Chancellor and his heirs during that time the sum of 3,000 marks for the rent, Prince Bismarck reserving the right for his heirs to buy up the concern at the termination of the fifty years. The promoters are confident that the export trade will be large, owing in a great measure to the Prince’s popularity abroad. — The New York Herald, European Edition, November 3, 1890
