lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — With a stunning landslide victory for his party in Sunday’s parliamentary election, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey has revived his ambition to establish an executive system of government, with him at its head, only a few months after political analysts had pronounced that aim dead.

headline: Bird Eggs Are Fertilized by More Than One Sperm
abstract: Penetration by multiple sperm may be unusual among animals, but it is somehow crucial to the development of the bird embryo, a new study finds.
lead_paragraph: Bird eggs are fertilized by more than one sperm, a process called polyspermy. Penetration by multiple sperm may be unusual in the animal kingdom, but it is somehow crucial to the development of the bird embryo, a new study finds.

abstract: Itches caused by the lightest of touches are created by a dedicated neural pathway, a new study suggests.
lead_paragraph: Some kinds of itching can be caused by the lightest of touches, a barely felt graze that rustles tiny hairs on the skin’s surface. This type of itch is created via a dedicated neural pathway, a new study suggests.

headline: For Statins, Cholesterol Care May Be Just the Start
abstract: Statins are the world’s leading cholesterol-lowering drugs and have other benefits for patients who take them.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after my 60th birthday, my cholesterol level inexplicably began to rise despite daily exercise, a healthy weight and a diet low in saturated fats. I tried to bring it down by cutting cheese, eggs and most meat from my diet as well as taking a daily fiber supplement, fish oils and plant sterols. Yet at every three-month checkup, my total cholesterol — and especially artery-damaging LDL cholesterol — was higher than the one before.

abstract: Telemundo had already been in discussions with the Democratic National Committee about hosting a candidate forum, but intensified its push after the Republican National Committee’s move to suspend its NBC News and Telemundo debate on Feb. 26.
lead_paragraph: Within hours of the Republican National Committee’s decision on Friday to suspend a scheduled Feb. 26 debate hosted by NBC News and Telemundo, the Spanish-language station was on the phone with the Democratic National Committee, pushing for a greater role in the Democratic Party’s early nominating process.

headline: 1940: Italians Bomb Crete
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Italian planes target troops on the island of Crete in 1940.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Italian planes have bombed and machine-gunned troops landing on the island of Crete, the high command said today [Nov. 2], and Italian troops were reported proceeding along the Kalamas (Thymais) River valley toward Janina, twenty-five miles within Greek territory. The attack on Crete, the high command said, had visible results, and ‘‘some steamships were struck and docks and material were damaged.’’ Informed quarters believed the troops landing to have been British. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 3, 1940

In the years since, it has lost 13 more to suicide. The battalion now has a suicide rate 14 times that for all Americans.

The science-fiction program that chronicled the voyages of the Starship Enterprise and its intrepid crew will return to TV in 2017, CBS said on Monday, in a new series that will be introduced on the network but will be shown primarily on its digital subscription video service.

headline: Bien Cuit Offers a Seasonal Danish

abstract: A pastry for breakfast or dessert; a cheese that takes a bath in beer; chocolates that get some unlikely additions; and more.
lead_paragraph: A new seasonal pastry in Zachary Golper’s line of Danish (or what the French call viennoiserie) at Bien Cuit has a suave center of yam seasoned with maple. I could see serving this treasure, warmed, with a scoop of vanilla ice cream alongside, one per person, as dessert at Thanksgiving dinner. It joins the raisin and apple varieties the bakery has been selling. And starting Wednesday, the pastries will also be available at 32 Whole Foods markets in the Northeast: Danish, $2 each, Bien Cuit, 120 Smith Street (Dean Street), Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, 718-852-0200, biencuit.com.

headline: Mumbai’s Lavish New Palace of Jewels
abstract: A recently opened shop offers exquisite, historically inspired gems — without an appointment.
lead_paragraph: The Gem Palace, the famous ninth-generation purveyor of exquisite Mughal-inspired jewelry, is opening a lavish new shop this month in Mumbai — its first that can be visited without an appointment. The interiors by the Dutch-born, Jaipur-based designer Marie-Anne Oudejans recall traditional Rajasthan colonial décor: checkerboard marble floors, emerald walls, salmon silk sofas. Upstairs, a private salon and showroom boasts backlit carved panels painted with elaborate floral motifs — and a canopied bed for when the burden of choice takes its toll.

lead_paragraph: Michael Fitzgerald has an unusual perspective on for-profit colleges: In the summer of 2008, he was hired to call admissions offices at colleges owned by a company he calls Big School, pretend to be an applicant, and then make sure the admissions officers’ sales techniques were both persuasive and legal. At Pacific Standard, he uses that summer as a jumping-off point to discuss student debt — including his own.

lead_paragraph: “North Holland and Friesland Bike and Sail Adventure,” departing in 2016, introduces a new destination and mode of transportation from VBT Bicycling and Walking Vacations. Highlights of the seven-night trip include nearly daily cycling through Dutch polders (land reclaimed from the sea), exploring traditional fishing villages, walking along some of Europe’s widest beaches on the island of Terschelling and an introduction to the Frisian language, similar to but separate from Dutch.

lead_paragraph: Two Syrian activists who used video and social media to expose human rights abuses committed by the Islamic State were tracked down by jihadists and killed in their home in a southern Turkish city, according to their colleagues.

headline: An Artful Rebound From the Mets’ Big Loss
abstract: One Brooklyn-born artist pays homage to her beloved team with embroidered works.
lead_paragraph: Driven out of the park, rebounded off a kneecap or ricocheted from a shattered bat into the stands — there are lots of ways to lose a ball, as evidenced by the last game of the 111th World Series on Sunday. On average, the series requires about 500 baseballs, all assembled by hand in much the same way they were a century ago: Each cork and rubber center is wrapped in yarn, encased in white cowhide and stitched together with waxed red thread. The same details inspire the Brooklyn-born and Mets-raised artist Elissa Goldstone’s work, which pays tribute to the days of knee-highs and chewing tobacco with highlight-reel scenes embroidered in bright, erratic lines; cotton sculptures of the four bases; and paper drawings done in familiar red double-stitch. For Goldstone, appreciating the minutiae of the game is the best way to cope with the inevitable heartbreak of being a baseball fan.

headline: 1852: Abraham Lincoln’s Other Party
abstract: Mark Bulik looks at early Times mentions of Abraham Lincoln.
lead_paragraph: The Republican Party is famously “the party of Lincoln” (the phrase has turned up in The Times six times since Aug. 1). But Lincoln actually spent a majority of his political career in another party — the Whigs, who were born in opposition to Andrew Jackson and his Democrats.

headline: Marc Benioff, Salesforce Chief, on the Strategic Benefits of Corporate Giving
abstract: Mr. Benioff runs Salesforce.com with a “1-1-1” philosophy, annually donating 1 percent of its equity, 1 percent of its employee time and 1 percent of its product to nonprofits. He explains why.
lead_paragraph: Marc Benioff founded Salesforce.com, one of the first and most successful cloud computing software companies, in 1999. The stock has gained over 1,800 percent since the company went public in 2004, making Mr. Benioff, a onetime Oracle executive, a billionaire.

headline: The Scare Tactics of Turkey’s President Erdogan Pay Off

lead_paragraph: Defying predictions, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s Justice and Development Party, the A.K.P., won a conclusive victory in Sunday’s national elections in Turkey, freeing it from the need to form a coalition to stay in power. Mr. Erdogan proclaimed it a vote “in favor of stability,” and that is what it apparently was — though it was Mr. Erdogan who churned up much of the turmoil that frightened voters back into his camp.

Shakey was the first machine used to pursue a range of artificial intelligence technologies such as planning, navigation, machine vision and even speech recognition. Funded by the Pentagon, it was originally modeled on the idea of an autonomous sentry for a military base.

headline: In Performance | 'Sylvia'

lead_paragraph: Annaleigh Ashford plays a stray dog with Matthew Broderick as her new owner in A.R. Gurney’s comedy "Sylvia," which ran on Broadway in 2015.

headline: Never-Before-Seen Photos of Madonna, Warhol, Basquiat and More
abstract: The publisher and activist Paige Powell shares intimate snapshots from her personal archives, which remained untouched for almost 40 years.
lead_paragraph: Some It-girls of the ’80s may regret that their youthful glory predated social media, but Interview magazine’s former associate publisher Paige Powell doesn’t have to. Powell arrived in New York in 1980 from the Pacific Northwest, looking like a granola version of Edie Sedgwick and armed with the work ethic of Mary Tyler Moore. She was soon swept up in Interview’s bid to be a more serious publication — “At first it was more for friends, like, Fran Lebowitz drove the delivery truck to drop off issues at different newsstands,” she remembers — and Andy Warhol’s select social whirlwind of downtown clubbing, midtown shopping and uptown lunches. “Andy always said, ‘Work is fun and fun is work,’” Powell says. “It was just the way I thought New York City was, all the time, for everyone — exuberant.”

headline: In Performance: Matthew Broderick and Annaleigh Ashford of ‘Sylvia’
abstract: A scene from A. R. Gurney’s comedy about a man and his feisty new dog, on Broadway at the Cort Theater.
lead_paragraph: The latest In Performance video features the Tony Award-winning actors Matthew Broderick and Annaleigh Ashford in a scene from A. R. Gurney’s comedy “Sylvia,” which opened last week on Broadway at the Cort Theater. In the play, Greg (Mr. Broderick), hoping to curtail a downer of a midlife crisis, takes home a dog (Ms. Ashford) he finds wandering around Central Park one day. An unconventional love triangle — among Greg, his wife (played by Julie White) and the dog,named Sylvia — ensues.

headline: Review: ‘A Midsummer Night’s Dream’ in Isango Ensemble’s South African Setting
abstract: This company’s adaptation of Britten’s 1960 opera reimagines the work as a tale steeped in African folklore.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin Britten fussed over the details of his operas, working hard to get every vocal line, pungent chord and instrumental color exactly as he wanted. What might he have thought of the very freely adapted production of his 1960 opera, “A Midsummer Night’s Dream,” by the South African company Isango Ensemble, which opened on Friday at the New Victory Theater?

headline: Support Houston’s Equal Rights Ordinance
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Discrimination', 'Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Law and Legislation', 'Referendums', 'Transgender and Transsexuals']
abstract: The law would not, as opponents contend, empower sexual predators or make public restrooms less safe.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Houston voters will be asked if they want to keep or repeal the city’s strong and enlightened equal rights ordinance, which was approved by the City Council last year and put on hold pending this week’s vote. Opponents of the law have perversely turned a broad, sensible measure  that protects people from discrimination in employment, city services, housing and public accommodations, among other things, into a debate about sexual predators in women’s restrooms.

headline: Review: ‘Theodora,’ Once a Handel Flop, Is Celebrated Anew
abstract: The complexity of this Handel oratorio, performed at Lincoln Center, was lost on audiences who heard it at its 1750 premiere in London.
lead_paragraph: A long line of people waited outside Alice Tully Hall on Saturday evening, hoping to get returned tickets for a performance of Handel’s “Theodora.” Handel would have felt vindicated. The 1750 premiere in London of this dramatic oratorio, a score of more than three hours, was a major flop for that celebrated composer. But of Handel’s 17 English oratorios, this was his favorite.

headline: Husband Charged in Wife’s 2009 Killing on Upper West Side
abstract: Shele Danishefsky Covlin’s estranged husband, Roderick Covlin, was charged with second-degree murder in a death that investigators initially thought might be an accident.
lead_paragraph: On the last morning of 2009, a 9-year-old girl went into a bathroom in her family apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan and found her mother lying lifeless in the tub. At first, it looked to investigators as if it might have been an accident — Shele Danishefsky Covlin, a 47-year-old finance executive, had died after a hard fall, they thought.

headline: Serial Gems Are Painstakingly Restored for the Screen

lead_paragraph: Master villains and mysterious avengers stalked the serial films that gripped audiences in cinema’s silent years. But in the thick of World War I, another twist on these shadowy figures appeared in the Kaiser’s Germany in 1916. Its hero was the Homunculus, and he was, in the impassioned words of the film’s title cards, a lab-created superhuman “not conceived by love but through science.”

headline: Suzanne Farrell and Kyra Nichols Carry On Balanchine’s Spirit
abstract: There is a surge of interest in his ballets, which have the power to endure, but do not survive unchanged.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Since the death of the choreographer George Balanchine (1904-83), his legacy has both receded and grown. The last of Balanchine’s own dancers have retired. Certain aspects of Balanchine technique have lost their gleaming edge (as he himself often predicted). Yet there’s been a vast posthumous Balanchine surge. I’ve seen more than 60 of his ballets in the last 10 years; Balanchine Without Balanchine is a growth industry.

A red truck slowly backed over the line, and employees hopped out to disassemble signs.

headline: Yemen: Powerful Storm Strikes Island
abstract: More than 2,000 families were displaced, and the main seaport for the island of Socotra was washed away.
lead_paragraph: A powerful cyclone struck an island off the coast of Yemen on Monday, washing away the island’s main seaport and displacing more than 2,000 families, according to Saeed Bahegeba, the governor of the island, Socotra. The storm, known as Chapala, then threatened the Yemeni mainland. By Monday evening, the cyclone was bearing down on Al Mukalla, the country’s fifth-largest city, which has been under the control of the Al Qaeda affiliate in Yemen since April.

Memorabilia from the 2012 presidential campaign or his first House race in 1998? Will he hang a poster of his favorite band, Rage Against the Machine?

headline: Russia: Librarian Is Accused of Allowing Access to Banned Ukrainian Books
abstract: The director of the library, Natalia Sharina, was placed under house arrest and could face as much as five years in prison.
lead_paragraph: The director of a Ukrainian-language library in Moscow was placed under house arrest on Monday by a Russian court that accused her of allowing public access to banned literature. The director, Natalia Sharina, could face as much as five years in prison for what Russian law enforcement agencies said was the dissemination of books by a Ukrainian nationalist writer, Dmytro Korchynsky, that are banned in Russia for promoting anti-Russian propaganda. Ms. Sharina denied the charges, saying the banned books were “planted during the searches,” a claim that was repeated by staff members. “Books cannot constitute extremism, because in my opinion extremism is an action,” she said in the courtroom, the Kommersant newspaper reported. Ms. Sharina’s lawyers have appealed the decision, the Interfax news agency said, and Human Rights Watch called for her immediate release in a statement.

headline: Colorado: Suspect Killed in Rampage Is Identified

lead_paragraph: The authorities in Colorado Springs have identified the man they say killed three people in a shooting rampage on Saturday before being shot to death in a gunfight with the police. The El Paso County Sheriff’s Office said Monday that the assailant was Noah Jacob Harpham, 32, left, a local resident. The Colorado Springs Gazette reported that witnesses had said the assailant had a rifle in one hand and a revolver in the other when he killed a bicyclist on Saturday. He then walked less than a mile and fatally shot two women who were chatting on a porch. The victims were identified as Andrew Alan Myers, 35; Jennifer Michelle Vasquez, 42; and Christina Rose Baccus-Gallela, 34. Four Colorado Springs police officers were placed on administrative leave while the shooting is investigated.

headline: The Evolution of Simplicity
abstract: These are busy and complicated times, and today’s simplicity movements are different from those in the past.
lead_paragraph: In this country we’re raised to go for the gusto, to try new things and savor the smorgasbord of life’s possibilities. As Oliver Wendell Holmes put it, “The chief work of civilization is just that it makes the means of living more complex. Because more complex and intense intellectual efforts mean a fuller and richer life. That means more life. Life is an end to itself and the only question as to whether it is worth living is whether you have enough of it.”

headline: France, Paradise Lost
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: A once expansive vision has shrunk to mean self-interest.
lead_paragraph: Paris — WHEN I moved to France 12 years ago, it was like arriving in an unfriendly paradise. Sure, hardly anyone spoke to me. But there was national paid maternity leave and free preschool. Practically everyone seemed to agree on the need for strict gun laws, and access to birth control and abortion. Not only did the whole country have health insurance; most undocumented immigrants could get medical and dental care free. (Cruelly, their thermal bath cures weren’t covered.)

headline: The Facebook Intifada
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Palestinians', 'Terrorism', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Hate Crimes']
abstract: Social media companies try to control hate and violent incitement on their sites, but are they doing enough?
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — THREE weeks ago, my father was riding on a public bus in Jerusalem’s Armon Hanatziv neighborhood when terrorists from East Jerusalem shot him in the head and stabbed him multiple times. Afterward, as he lay unconscious in the intensive care unit of Hadassah Hospital in Jerusalem, fighting for his life, one question was on my mind: What inspired the two young Palestinian men to savagely attack my father and a busload of passengers?

Were I a traditional analyst, I might have wondered to myself: “Is there ambivalence here? Perhaps she doesn’t want to come back?”

headline: Avoiding Taxes, Legally, Offshore
abstract: A new book looks at the baroque — and sometimes absurd — world of offshore tax havens.
lead_paragraph: The collapse of Enron, with its web of offshore companies, got Paolo Woods talking with a photo editor. As big as the story was, the editor told him, he was hard pressed to figure out just how to illustrate something rooted in a thicket of secretive corporations that — on paper, at least — were based in tax havens. Nondescript post office boxes were not exactly the stuff of great images.

abstract: Or do you stay true to your teams no matter how tough a season they are having?
lead_paragraph: Both the New York Mets and the Kansas City Royals picked up many new fans this postseason. That makes sense. People like to root for winning teams — or, at least, teams that have a chance to win a championship. If next season doesn’t go as well, those fans might find a different team to root for.

headline: ‘Islam and the Future of Tolerance’ and ‘Not in God’s Name’
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Religion and Belief', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Two books discuss the nature of religious extremism and potential paths to reform.
lead_paragraph: Civilization has a civility problem. This I learned long before Donald Trump. In 2005, the prominent “new atheist” Richard Dawkins shouted his disapproval at me — from the audience — during my TED talk at Oxford University. More recently, the novelist Salman Rushdie chastised me on Twitter for suggesting that even atheists worship something. Many of Rushdie’s followers, worshiping their own wisdom, responded to my tweet with vitriol. Defending the value of doubt through crude certitude is a sign of our times.

headline: Steve Deace and the Power of Conservative Media
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Radio', 'Endorsements', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: When the radio host speaks for angry Republicans in Iowa — and beyond — the 2016 candidates have no choice but to listen.
lead_paragraph: Talk of alpha and beta males is common in the suburban Des Moines studio of the nationally syndicated conservative talk-show host Steve Deace. Almost daily, he assails the wimpy betas purporting to rule today’s Republican Party — the feckless politicians who, under siege, are giving ground to alpha fighters like him. Such chatter includes references to ‘‘manginas’’ and ‘‘growing a pair,’’ yet does not seem to put off the women in Deace’s audience; after all, being politically incorrect has become a conservative badge of honor in 2015.

headline: Mary Karr Thinks You Shouldn’t Google Yourself
abstract: The memoirist believes in exposing the truth without talking about anyone’s penis.
lead_paragraph: In your book ‘‘The Art of Memoir,’’ you write that one of the side effects of being a memoirist is that strangers ‘‘skip the small talk and confide the most turbulent patches of their lives,’’ which to me wasn’t so surprising, but what you wrote about it was: ‘‘I have never not been moved by such a tale.’’ Small talk is boring. Politics are boring. The weather is boring. The minute somebody says to you, ‘‘I’ve never told anybody this before,’’ they’ve got your attention. I’m not a particularly nice person, but I’ve got to say, it makes me feel less lonely in the world when people confide in me.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — Seeking to reassure investors, Royal Dutch Shell on Tuesday said its $70 billion acquisition of the BG Group would allow it to realize $3.5 billion in savings, shed $30 billion in uncompetitive assets, and expand its operations in the fast-growing liquefied natural gas industry.

headline: Hamptons’ True Colors Show in Autumn Off-Season
abstract: Come fall, when the crowds and cars and high-season glamour fade, turkeys, like so many other things in the Hamptons, come into their own.
lead_paragraph: On a windswept morning in late October, a dozen wild turkeys crashed through the oak trees and landed unceremoniously on the patch of moss, grass and leaves that my husband and I call a lawn. I was on my way out the door, looking forward to a drive on the back roads near our house in Springs, a wooded hamlet in the town of East Hampton. The sight of the birds stopped me in my tracks. The screen door slipped from my hand. The slam rang out like a gunshot. A cloud of crows burst from the trees, and the turkeys, like the fantastical airships in a Philip Pullman novel, sailed across the fence and were gone.

headline: Travel Tips From the Well-Traveled Jamie Colby
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'News and News Media', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'AIRPORTS']
abstract: Ms. Colby is now a pro at keeping up her exercise routine on the road, saving time at airports and relying on apps to make travel a bit easier.
lead_paragraph: As a television journalist specializing in news, Jamie Colby, 54, has traveled the world covering major events like the tsunami in Asia and the papal conclave at the Vatican, but nothing prepared her for being the host of “Strange Inheritance” on Fox Business Network. The second season of the series, debuting on Nov. 11, took her from her home in New York City to 20 states and one country, Britain, to speak with people saddled with unusual inheritances like a military tank collection in California, a frontier fort in Texas and a 17th-century shipwreck in Florida.

lead_paragraph: BEIJING — President Xi Jinping of China announced on Tuesday that the Communist Party and the national government had set a 6.5 percent target for annual economic growth from 2016 to 2020.

headline: A Triumphant De Keersmaeker Takes Paris Opera by Storm
abstract: The choreographer Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker took the Paris Ballet by storm with a triple bill.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Four musicians, dressed in black, walk on to the stage and sit with their instruments. Four female dancers, dressed in black, walk on to the stage and stand at the periphery in a rough semi-circle. The dancers look at each other, look at the musicians. Nothing happens. Then the dancers suddenly whip into quick turns toward the center of the stage, stand in a close line, and do little slinky, side-to-side walks. The music starts — Bartok’s String Quartet No. 4 — and they flop unceremoniously to the floor, legs splayed gracelessly, white underwear revealed.

headline: 1915: State Rejects Women’s Suffrage
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Women’s suffrage was defeated in a vote in New Jersey in 1915.
lead_paragraph: Woman suffrage was defeated yesterday in New Jersey by a majority of about fifty thousand. Despite President Wilson’s recent declaration in favor of the women and his trip to his old home, Princeton, to cast his vote for their cause, every county in the State cast a majority against the suffrage amendment. The defeat was overwhelming. The women conceded it early in the evening, but they stuck boldly to their battle flag and said they would carry the fight into another campaign, in which they felt confident they would drive their foes to cover. — The New York Herald, European Edition, November 4, 1915

headline: Brace for the Nonstop Football League
abstract: Envisioning a day when prime-time college or pro football telecasts are available every day of the season.
lead_paragraph: With November arrived, Tuesday and Wednesday prime-time football begins — tonight in college action it’s the Northern Illinois Huskies versus the Toledo Rockets. Next month bowl mania kicks off, followed by the N.F.L. postseason: It’s pretty much wall-to-wall cleats and pads. This raises a question many might prefer not be raised: How soon till there is a nationally telecast football game every single day from school back in session till the Super Bowl? That is to say, how long till a Nonstop Football League?

headline: Quarry to Table Design
abstract: A Dutch furniture designer is applying his classic geometric shapes to stone.
lead_paragraph: The furniture designer Lex Pott is well regarded in his native Holland for his clever reinterpretation of basic geometric shapes: mirrors of overlapping triangles, shelves made from segmented circles. Next month, he will try to win over an American audience with the Future Perfect’s exhibition of his new stone pieces at Design Miami, including a table with a base of jagged Belgian bluestone that pierces the top and an elegant shelving unit made of different-colored marble slabs.

headline: ‘Vic Invades’
abstract: This short documentary profiles the extreme sport of “UrbExing,” in which people infiltrate skyscrapers and subways for adventure — and the perfect photograph.
lead_paragraph: I first encountered the mysterious subject of this Op-Doc video, Victor Thomas, via his Instagram account, where he is known as “Vic Invades.” His photos showed someone dangling his feet over the edge of a massive skyscraper, limbs hanging precariously above the incredible vista of New York City far below. The images were striking – both beautiful and dangerous.

headline: Charles Koch Defends Big-Money Campaign Contributions
abstract: “I expect something in return,” Charles G. Koch said of his political donations. “I would love to have the government stop this corporate welfare. That’s what I want. I want the government to, to let companies, or require that companies only profit by helping make other people’s lives better.”
lead_paragraph: Charles G. Koch, the billionaire conservative businessman and philanthropist, defended the flow of giant donations into political campaigns, saying in an interview on Tuesday that he hoped that money from wealthy contributors would help persuade candidates to end corporate welfare.

headline: Life Pulls Back in Afghan Capital, as Danger Rises and Troops Recede
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Terrorism', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Helicopters', 'Restaurants', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Since the end of the huge NATO combat mission, restaurants have closed, night life has dwindled, and a city once awash in Western money feels largely shut down.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — If there had been grumbling before about the deafening intrusion of low-flying American helicopters in the Afghan capital, the discontent has surely multiplied along with the number of flights: packs of them now, coming two, four, six at a time, starting around 7 a.m., then again at midday and at dusk.

headline: German Court Deems Ex-Guard at Auschwitz, 93, Fit to Stand Trial
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Concentration Camps', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: The man faces charges of accessory to the murder of at least 170,000 people, as Germany presses on with efforts to bring elderly Nazis to justice for their role in the Holocaust.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A German court has determined that a 93-year-old man who served as an SS sergeant at the Auschwitz death camp is fit to stand trial on charges of accessory to the murder of at least 170,000 people during his tenure there, as the country presses on with efforts to bring older Nazis to justice for their role in the Holocaust.

headline: Deal for Candy Crush Maker Favors Hope Over Experience
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Activision is buying King Digital for $5.9 billion. With few potential cost savings, this looks as much an excuse to use excess cash as a sound bet on future hits.

The London-based maker of the sweet-matching mobile game is selling out to Activision Blizzard for $5.9 billion, below the price of last year’s initial public offering.

headline: 1965: Cracking Down on Beatniks
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Police in Rome threaten to crack down on beatniks in 1965.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Rome police today [Nov.3] threatened a major crackdown on the unwashed, unshaven, unruly beatnik bands which have made Rome’s stately Spanish Steps their rallying point. Foreigners in the ranks of the Spanish Steps loafers may be expelled from the country and Italian youths copying the shaggy style may be sent to the barber first and then back to their families, police warned. Climaxing a summer-long series of small incidents there, the Spanish Steps were the stage yesterday of a violent free-for-all tussle between the beatniks, soldiers and police. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 4, 1965

headline: Stadium Food, for Foodies
abstract: Moving from Cracker Jack to crab fries, sports arenas around the U.S. are collectively raising their concessions game.
lead_paragraph: Sports stadiums across America are upping the ante on their culinary offerings. At Seattle’s CenturyLink Field, Seahawks fans are feasting on fries with crab sauce and locally sourced sausages from the Pike Place Market butcher shop Uli’s. At Portland’s Moda Center, home of the N.B.A.’s Trail Blazers, on draft is Widmer Brothers’ Upheaval IPA (the arena pours 70 percent craft beers), which pairs well with Bunk Sandwiches’ New Orleans-style muffuletta. At Philadelphia’s Lincoln Financial Field, Eagles enthusiasts are eating gourmet pizzas by the James Beard Award-winner Marc Vetri. But leading the pack is the 49ers’ new $1.3 billion Levi’s Stadium in Santa Clara, Calif. About 75 percent of the food is local, and 26 vegan items are on offer, including a vegetarian take on a pulled pork sandwich with smoked jackfruit.

headline: Beyond the Honeycrisp Apple
abstract: Fruit breeders have been creating varieties with flashy names like Cosmic Crisp and SnapDragon, leaving Red Delicious and McIntosh behind and hoping to knock off recent favorites.
lead_paragraph: ROCK ISLAND, Wash. — Take one bite of a Cosmic Crisp — dramatically dark, richly flavored and explosively crisp and juicy — and it’s easy to see why it is already being hailed as the most promising and important apple of the future.

headline: Prix Goncourt Goes to Mathias Énard
abstract: France’s top literary award was awarded on Tuesday to “La Boussole,” which tackles the interactions between the Western and Islamic worlds.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — France’s top literary award, the Goncourt Prize, was awarded on Tuesday to the novelist Mathias Énard for “La Boussole,” or “The Compass.” Set during a long night of opium-fueled conversation, it is one of several books on this year’s short list to tackle the often fraught interactions between the Western and Islamic worlds.

headline: Demand Creates Its Own Supply
abstract: You don’t Say.
lead_paragraph: One of the intellectually horrifying things about the response to economic crisis was the way many economists, some of them famous, reinvented old fallacies in the belief that they were saying something profound. In particular, quite a few economists seemed utterly unaware that Say’s Law – the proposition that supply creates its own demand, that shortfalls in aggregate demand were impossible – had been refuted three generations ago.

headline: Readers Respond to Success Academy’s ‘Got to Go’ Student List
abstract: An article about the creation of a “Got to Go” list of students at a Success Academy charter school prompted more than 1,200 comments with varied reactions.
lead_paragraph: Readers were divided in response to an article about the creation of a “Got to Go” list of students at a Success Academy charter school, part of New York City’s largest charter network. Last December, the principal at Success Academy Fort Greene, in Brooklyn, singled out 16 students he said were disruptive and hoped to see leave. Although the principal was quickly chastised, nine of the students later left, and the list seemed to validate claims that the network achieves its high test scores by weeding out weak or difficult students.

headline: The Conspiracy Consensus
abstract: Trump isn’t different.
lead_paragraph: So, are we supposed to be shocked over Donald Trump claiming that Janet Yellen is keeping rates low to help Obama? Folks, this is a widely held position in the Republican Party; Paul Ryan and John Taylor accused Ben Bernanke years ago of doing something dastardly by preventing the fiscal crisis they insist would and should have happened under Obama. If Trump’s remarks seem startling, it’s only because the press has soft-pedaled the conspiracy theorizing of seemingly respectable Republicans.

headline: Singapore Treats at Chomp Chomp in Greenwich Village
abstract: With the chef Simpson Wong’s ambitious hawker food menu, it’s like going from stall to stall without leaving your seat.

headline: Cassette Brings French-Catalonian Flavors to Greenpoint
abstract: Also: Dominique Bistro opens in the West Village; Chelsea Market adds kiosks; and I Trulli eliminates tipping.
lead_paragraph: Cassette In their new venture, Henry Rich and the chef Joe Pasqualetto move from the rustic Italian they feature at Rucola in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, to southwestern French, with some Catalonian flavors. Vegetables dominate in dishes like roasted peppers with white anchovies, potatoes with salsa verde, roasted acorn squash with red rice, and pasta with tomatoes, toasted garlic and salt cod. Desserts include crème Catalan, the Spanish take on crème brûlée. The wines of the region are well represented and well priced, with about a dozen under $50. Perry Chen, a founder of Kickstarter, which happens to be just around the corner, is also a partner. Unlike the cozy, cluttered Rucola, this restaurant is airy and spacious, with big windows: 113 Franklin Street (Kent Street), Greenpoint, Brooklyn, 347-682-4111, cassettebk.com.

headline: Australia Deploys Sheepdogs to Save a Penguin Colony
abstract: The population of little penguins on an island in Australia has bounced back thanks to the vigilance of a few sheepdogs.
lead_paragraph: “Massacred,” read the banner headline in the local newspaper — just the single word, as if describing an act of war. Below it was a photo of dead penguins and other birds, the latest casualties in Australia’s long history of imported species’ decimating native wildlife.

headline: Clothes That Match the Wallpaper
abstract: The indie brand Calico Wallpaper has teamed up with Print All Over Me and the Brooklyn concept store Swords-Smith on an inaugural capsule collection.
lead_paragraph: Comparing someone’s outfit to wallpaper isn’t normally a compliment — but that may change today, as Calico Wallpaper launches a collaboration. With the custom clothier Print All Over Me, the cultish indie brand’s stylish, nature-inspired patterns have been translated into a limited-edition capsule collection, sold exclusively by the Brooklyn concept shop Swords-Smith. It’s the second time Calico and Print All Over Me have teamed up, though it’s the first with any fanfare: As Nick Cope, the co-founder of Calico alongside his wife Rachel, explains, “We had them unofficially design our tradeshow uniforms that harmonized with our booth” at this year’s Design Week NYC back in May. And as for Swords-Smith, the shop isn’t just shilling the goods; its founders (also a married couple, Briana Swords and R Smith) were integral in developing the concept. “I loved Calico’s wallpaper,” Swords says. “Every time I saw it, I thought to myself, ‘I would love this on a dress.’”

headline: Vatican’s Financial Troubles Run Deep, According to New Book
abstract: “Merchants in the Temple,” a new book by Gianluigi Nuzzi, describes a nest of greed, cronyism and mismanagement at the Vatican.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Pope John Paul I, who died in 1978, still holds more than 110,000 euros, or about $120,000, in a Vatican bank account. The Vatican pension fund is running an €800-million deficit. The Vatican’s real estate holdings total €2.7 billion, seven times more than what is listed on its balance sheets. And the Vatican’s governing body had agreed to push Philip Morris cigarettes, for a fee.

headline: Jon Stewart Signs Production Deal With HBO

headline: More White People Die From Suicide and Substance Abuse: Why?
keywords: ['Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Gina Kolata considers why the death rates for middle-aged white Americans are rising.
lead_paragraph: The big mystery is why? Why would the death rate for middle-aged non-Hispanic whites be increasing after decades of decline while rates for middle-aged blacks and Hispanics continue to fall? And why didn’t other rich countries have the same mortality rate increase for people in midlife?

headline: Romania Places the Heart of a Queen in Her Castle
abstract: Queen Marie, who died in 1938, had her heart placed in a small silver coffin, which was moved from a museum in Bucharest, Romania, to the room in her castle where she died.
lead_paragraph: BUCHAREST, Romania — It has been a busy few years for royal remains. In 2012, King Richard III’s bones were found under a parking lot in Leicester, England, and reburied in March. In September, the Russian authorities exhumed the bodies of Czar Nicholas II and Empress Alexandra for new DNA tests. Last week, the Russians said the body of the czar’s father, Alexander III, would be dug up for testing, too.

headline: What Is the Locker-Room Policy for Transgender Students at Your Child’s School?
abstract: The Education Department has said that requiring a transgender student to change behind a curtain violates Title IX. How are bathrooms, locker rooms and showers used at your child’s school? What are the rules set around bathrooms and locker rooms, and how have the conversations around that gone where you live?
lead_paragraph: Federal education authorities found Monday that an Illinois school district violated antidiscrimination laws when it did not allow a transgender student who identifies as a girl and participates on a girls’ sports team to change and shower in the girls’ locker room without restrictions. Instead, the student, who identifies as female but was born male, is required to change beyond privacy curtains in the girls’ locker room and to shower separately.

headline: In Milan, Massimo Piombo Opens a Shop for the Fashion Obsessive
abstract: An elegant new men’s wear store in Milan has three levels: “Glamour,” “Bizarre” and “Obsession.”
lead_paragraph: Massimo Piombo, a fixation of fashion editors, if not a household name, can make the elegant seem esoteric and the esoteric elegant. He has had many micro-achievements. Among them, he says, was being at the forefront of bringing the pajama shirt out of the bedroom and into the working world.

headline: Familial Ties to Slavery, Bound by Vintage First-Person Accounts
abstract: Descendants of authors of slave narratives gathered for a discussion at the State University of New York at Buffalo.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — The Michigan Street Baptist Church, built here in the 1840s, was a haven for fugitives on the Underground Railroad, and a place of worship for illustrious citizens like Mary Burnett Talbert, a founder of the movement that led to the creation of the N.A.A.C.P.

headline: A Design Show Fit for Beetlejuice
abstract: Surreal, avant-garde works make up the new Art et Industrie retrospective.
lead_paragraph: Art et Industrie, founded in 1977, was an influential avant-garde design movement beloved by the likes of Jean-Michel Basquiat, who frequented the group’s openings in SoHo. Years later, the gallerist Hugues Magen, newly arrived from Paris, was similarly struck: “I was educated in Europe, with all of the standards that this implies, and was confronted in New York with Art et Industrie,” recalls Magen, a former principal dancer with the Dance Theatre of Harlem. “I was mesmerized and challenged, in front of something for which I had very little reference, and I was inspired by seeing liberty in such a way that I was not accustomed to in terms of design.”

headline: Donald Trump Pitches New Book (and a Campaign, Too)
abstract: Trump the Campaign and Trump the Marketing Machine are always difficult to disentangle. But whatever thin buffer had kept them separated the last few months evaporated entirely on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Inside the pink marbled atrium of the Trump Tower on Tuesday, Donald J. Trump, the salesman, signed copies of his new book by the armload, gleefully demanding to know precisely how long the line of buyers had become on 56th Street. “Is it all the way to Madison Avenue?” he asked an aide.

headline: Catholicism For the Time Being
keywords: ['Christians and Christianity', 'Crosses and Crucifixes', 'Pilgrimages', 'Priests', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: When muddling through is the better part of valor.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, with my latest broadside on matters Catholics filed and published, I drove with my family up into northwestern Connecticut — just for the drive, no particular destination in mind. We ended up stopping for mass at a shrine near Litchfield, built in imitation and honor of Lourdes, that I’d visited occasionally many years earlier with my parents. The place was mostly unchanged: A big expanse of land, gray and somewhat forbidding on a cloudy day with the trees half-gone toward winter; a grotto where they have outdoor masses in warmer weather; a long stations of the cross ascending a wooded hill to a lifesize Calvary; and various gift shops and outbuildings scattered around the grounds. One of the outbuildings doubles as a chapel, and that’s where the All Saints Day mass was held: In a crowded, close, carpeted space, with a mostly-gray haired congregation (we were some of the youngest people there) dressed in suburban- Catholic casual and packed into too-small chairs on three sides of the altar.

headline: White House on Keystone Project
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Keystone Pipeline System']

lead_paragraph: Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary, suggested that politics had driven the request by TransCanada to suspend the review of the proposed Keystone XL pipeline.

headline: Does Anyone Own the Cornrow?
keywords: ['Hair', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Models (Professional)', 'Women and Girls', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: For some people, it’s an important part of black culture. For others, it’s just a hairstyle.
lead_paragraph: There’s no way to sugarcoat this: I always experience a flash of annoyance when I see white girls wearing cornrows. Maybe it’s because the hairstyle is being marketed as “new and trendy.” Or it could be that I, as a black woman, know it’s not a style white girls wore when I was growing up, and that they often mocked me for wearing it.

lead_paragraph: A senior Morgan Stanley deal maker is leaving the firm to join a longtime client, Comcast, as a senior executive in charge of corporate development.

headline: VW Reveals It Misstated Emissions of Gas Cars
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Diesel Power', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Automobiles', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The company said it had underreported the carbon dioxide emitted by 800,000 diesel- and some gasoline-powered cars, and would set aside $2.2 billion to cover the cost of the problem.
lead_paragraph: Volkswagen’s pollution problems took a costly new turn on Tuesday when the company said it had understated emissions of carbon dioxide, a greenhouse gas, for about 800,000 of its vehicles sold in Europe, and overstated the cars’ fuel economy.

headline: Influential, Late-’70s Paintings, Revisited
abstract: Paintings in a new show of Troy Brauntuch’s early work come on loan from the collections of Larry Gagosian, Robert Longo and more.
lead_paragraph: “You’re in, you’re out, you’re up, you’re down,” the painter Troy Brauntuch says, with his trademark disarming self-deprecation. “Privately, one always goes on.” Nearly 40 years ago, Brauntuch had a flash of big-shot fame: he was one of five artists (alongside Jack Goldstein, Sherrie Levine, Robert Longo and Philip Smith) included in the influential 1977 group show “Pictures,” curated at Artists Space by Douglas Crimp. The show came to represent the brewing movement of image-based artists — those who “had a broader perspective of how we read images, and really entered the picture again, and what that means,” Brauntuch says. “Pictures” operated as a bellwether, in stark contrast to then-fashionable Minimalism and abstraction. “We came out of a time when ‘art’ was not what we were doing, which is why we were doing what we were doing.” His years in New York in the late ’70s and 1980s were spent running up the ladder alongside his friends, like Cindy Sherman, Matt Mullican, David Salle, Goldstein and Longo, whose careers exploded onto the superstar level. He counted Richard Prince and Dike Blair among his golfing buddies, too. “We played religiously,” Brauntuch says. “We also played in a poker game for decades.”

lead_paragraph: To clap or not to clap? Even seasoned concertgoers can be unsure of what to do between pieces when religious music is on the program. On Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall, the soprano Christine Brewer addressed the awkwardness head-on when she turned to the audience members at “Prayer” and, in a genial tone, encouraged them to relax.

To create a setting worthy of the enterprise, Gagosian directors Valentina Castellani and Stefan Ratibor sought the expertise of a longtime collaborator: the architect Annabelle Selldorf.

lead_paragraph: BEIJING — President Xi Jinping of China and Taiwan’s president, Ma Ying-jeou, will meet on Saturday in Singapore, the first such meeting since before the Chinese Communist revolution of 1949 and the retreat of the Chinese Nationalists across the Taiwan Strait.

headline: Smaller Overseas Entrepreneurs Find China Too Frustrating

All he needed to start production was $250,000 of specially designed molding equipment from Israel.

lead_paragraph: Michael D. Hammond, co-founder of Gateway, a computer manufacturer that was started in an Iowa farmhouse and became known for shipping products in boxes with a spotted cow design, died on Thursday at his home in Sioux City, Iowa. He was 53.

headline: China Burns Much More Coal Than Reported, Complicating Climate Talks
abstract: China has been using up to 17 percent more coal a year than reported. By some estimates, that means almost a billion more tons of carbon dioxide released annually.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China, the world’s leading emitter of greenhouse gases from coal, has been burning up to 17 percent more coal a year than the government previously disclosed, according to newly released data. The finding could complicate the already difficult efforts to limit global warming.

lead_paragraph: Fashion events come in as many styles as fashion, but you can always count on Champagne and, at one of New York’s most touted annual parties, on chicken potpie. At the CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund, 12 years strong, potpie — a favorite of Anna Wintour, the editor in chief of Vogue and one of the forces behind the young designer prize — remains immobile on the menu.

lead_paragraph: After guiding the Mets to their first pennant in 15 years, Manager Terry Collins will be rewarded with a two-year contract extension that will be officially announced at a news conference on Wednesday, according to a person in baseball with knowledge of the situation. If Collins finishes out the extension, he will have managed more games than anyone else in Mets history.

headline: Review: Resettling the Meaning of Home in ‘Brooklyn,’ With Saoirse Ronan
abstract: This film about a familiar American story, the immigrant who arrives with dreams of the future and pangs over leaving home, explores the question: Where do we come from?
lead_paragraph: Many American families cherish faded memories of the Old Neighborhood and the Old Country, places that help supply both a sense of identity and a story of progress — complementary answers to the question “Where do we come from?”

headline: An Artistic Homage to a Classic Work of Philosophy
abstract: For a new collaboration with yoox.com, the performance artist and photographer Vanessa Beecroft mined inspiration from Walter Benjamin.
lead_paragraph: In 1936, the German critic Walter Benjamin published “The Work of Art in the Age of Mechanical Reproduction,” a seminal essay that’s arguably even more influential in 2015 than it was eight decades ago. Now, Benjamin’s observations on authorship, authenticity and capital have found their way into Vanessa Beecroft’s photographic series for yoox.com, the Italian e-commerce retailer.

headline: Review: Michel Houellebecq’s ‘Submission’ Imagines France as a Muslim State
abstract: In this novel, set in 2022, an Islamic party sweeps into power and the country undergoes a radical transformation.
lead_paragraph: Published in France on Jan. 7, the day of the terrorist attacks on the satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo, Michel Houellebecq’s new book, “Submission” — a novel set in 2022 in which an Islamic party sweeps into power in France and Islamic law is embraced — became an instant best seller there and the center of a heated debate over the lines between satire and Islamophobia, free-expression and hate-mongering.

headline: Review: ‘In Jackson Heights,’ an Ode to the Immigrant Experience
abstract: Frederick Wiseman’s documentary about this Queens neighborhood advances the idea that it is people — in streets and stores, in barbershops and laundromats — who make a city great.
lead_paragraph: All of creation converges in “In Jackson Heights,” a thrilling, transporting love letter from Frederick Wiseman to New York and its multi-everything glory. Set in the Queens neighborhood of its title — where people from across the globe are staking a claim on America while speaking Spanish, Tibetan and Punjabi — Mr. Wiseman’s latest documentary is a movingly principled, political look at a dynamic neighborhood in which older waves of pioneers make room for new, amid creeping gentrification. It’s an immigration story, so it goes without saying that it is also about New York and the United States — that “teeming nation of nations,” to steal a phrase from Walt Whitman.

headline: Review: Jacques Rivette’s 1971 Film, ‘Out 1: Noli Me Tangere’
abstract: This newly restored, nearly 13-hour French movie, with English subtitles, is having its New York theatrical premiere.
lead_paragraph: Within what is an intense but relatively narrow circle of cinephiles, Jacques Rivette’s 1971 film, “Out 1: Noli Me Tangere” (the subtitle is Latin for “touch me not”), is considered, as more than one writer has put it, a kind of filmic holy grail. The nearly 13-hour work, a cinematic soak both sprawling and intimate, has been almost impossible to view in the more than 40 years since its production. The movie was screened in New York in 2006 by the Museum of the Moving Image, but the two-week engagement at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, beginning on Wednesday, is its New York theatrical premiere.

headline: Ticky Burden, Former All-American and Knick Who Fell Into Crime, Dies at 62
abstract: Luther Burden starred for the University of Utah and played for the Knicks in the 1970s. He was convicted of robbing a Long Island bank in 1980.
lead_paragraph: Luther Burden, better known as Ticky, a sharpshooting guard who played briefly for the Knicks in the 1970s but whose life took an ignominious turn when he was convicted of robbing a Long Island bank in 1980, died on Thursday in Winston-Salem, N.C. He was 62.

headline: Clemson Tops First Set of College Football Playoff Rankings

headline: John Kerry Confronts Human Rights as He Zips Through Central Asia
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The secretary of state’s four-day tour of the five “Stans” of the former Soviet Union has been an experiment in both power-balancing and sleep deprivation.
lead_paragraph: ASHGABAT, Turkmenistan — Secretary of State John Kerry seems unlikely to make it to North Korea in his 15 remaining months in office. But on Tuesday he got the next best thing: A two-hour visit to another of the world’s most-sealed-off autocratic states, where the leader recently unveiled a 69-foot-high gold statue of himself on horseback, to go along with the regularly produced videos of his sporting prowess.

headline: Buoyed by Poll, Hillary Clinton Has Day Full of Optimism in Iowa
abstract: With a new poll in the state showing her ahead of Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, even the weather agreed with Mrs. Clinton.
lead_paragraph: CORALVILLE, Iowa — With a new poll showing the fickle Iowa electorate warming to her candidacy, even the weather agreed with Hillary Rodham Clinton on Tuesday.

headline: Elon Musk Says Never Mind the Hiccups, Tesla Is on Track

headline: Matt Bevin, Republican, Wins Governor’s Race in Kentucky
abstract: Mr. Bevin, a political novice, surprised some Republicans who thought he was too far outside the mainstream to defeat the Democrat, Attorney General Jack Conway.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Matt Bevin, a Republican political novice, wealthy Louisville businessman and Tea Party favorite, was elected Kentucky’s next governor on Tuesday and swept fellow Republicans into statewide office with him. The stunning victory heralds a new era in a state where Democrats have held the governor’s mansion for all but four of the last 44 years.

headline: A Conversation With Michael D. Colacino

lead_paragraph: Mr. Colacino, 58, is the president of Savills Studley, a commercial real estate services company specializing in tenant representation, largely in the office sector. He has been with Studley since 1991 and has been president since 2002; the company, which is based in New York, merged with Savills of London last year.

headline: Review: ‘Veritas,’ a Play About Harvard’s Gay Underground Put on Trial
abstract: At the Cave at St. George’s Church in Manhattan, a troupe called the Representatives depicts the secret tribunals of gay students in 1920.
lead_paragraph: To get to “Veritas” — a tidy site-specific production at the Cave at St. George’s Church from a troupe called the Representatives — you enter through a door below street level, an apt evocation of the play’s depiction of a gay underground at Harvard in 1920. You are offered wine and directed to a corner where a man leads you to the first of two intimate rooms where the show is staged.

headline: Lawyers Offer Contrasting Views of Sheldon Silver as His Corruption Trial Starts
abstract: The prosecution said Mr. Silver, a former State Assembly speaker, had sold his office, while his lawyers argued he was a force for good.

And throughout that reign, prosecutors said on Tuesday, Mr. Silver capitulated to greed, taking illicit payments and “selling his office.”

headline: HBO Documentary Successfully Examines Enigmatic Life of Kareem Abdul-Jabbar
abstract: The film effectively introduces Abdul-Jabbar to a generation that did not witness his 20-year N.B.A. career or possess direct knowledge of the context.
lead_paragraph: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar has been part of our sports culture for a half century while seemingly urging himself to stand apart from it. He did his work on the basketball court but did not feel the need to submit to the public confessional. He came to national renown as a 7-foot teenager when he was mocked for his height and felt stung by racism, even from the high school coach he so admired, Jack Donohue.

headline: Colin Welland, Oscar-Winning Writer of ‘Chariots of Fire,’ Dies at 81

Now, after completing high school and earning degrees in history and law, Ahmed Hussen is about to be sworn in as a member of Parliament — one of 46 nonwhite candidates elected to the House of Commons on Oct. 19, most of them immigrants.

keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'International Relations', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: Stabilizing or reducing carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere is a distant prospect, so the world must continue to adapt to a changing climate.

But any post-meeting celebration will be tempered by two sobering scientific realities that will weaken the effectiveness of even the most ambitious emissions reduction plans that are being discussed.

headline: How A.L.S. Rescued My Father
keywords: ['AMYOTROPHIC LATERAL SCLEROSIS', 'Death and Dying', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: The prospect of death changed him, and he finally allowed his friends and family to enter his life.
lead_paragraph: I laid my hand on his cold collarbone and — as the sun set behind my old school, which could be glimpsed from the bedroom window — he started to die. The vibrating pulses below his neck’s paper-thin skin ebbed. His breathing grew shallow until it disappeared entirely, like ripples on water that slowly level out.

headline: ‘The Crime and the Silence,’ by Anna Bikont
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: A Polish journalist revisits the massacre of Jews in Jedwabne and the town’s long denial of responsibility.
lead_paragraph: On July 10, 1941, in Jedwabne, a town of roughly 3,000 inhabitants in northeastern Poland, a mob of Catholics murdered most of their Jewish neighbors. Estimates of the number of victims vary, from about 300 men, women and children to as many as 1,600. Whatever the correct figure, very few Jews survived. Using axes, clubs and knives, the mob first killed some 40 Jewish men. The remaining Jews — men, women and children, many of them infants — were herded into a wooden barn on the outskirts of the town. Then, as the jeering crowd watched, the murderers barred the doors, poured gasoline on the structure and lit the fire. Everyone inside died. Plunder of Jewish homes followed. Peasants from neighboring villages, who had begun arriving in Jedwabne at dawn on the day of the massacre, joined in the fun.

headline: Jay Winik’s ‘1944: FDR and the Year That Changed History’
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: The people and politics leading to President Roosevelt’s belated decision to help rescue Jews in Europe.
lead_paragraph: In 2001, Jay Winik scored a commercial and critical success with his best seller “April 1865,” a vivid account of the final month of the Civil War, which Winik convincingly argued was a crucial turning point in American history. Robert E. Lee and Ulys­ses S. Grant, among others, play major roles in “April 1865,” but Abraham Lincoln towers above all of them.

headline: ‘Killing a King’ Examines Assassination of Yitzhak Rabin
abstract: Rabin was assassinated 20 years ago at a crucial point in the peace process.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, on Nov. 4, 1995, a man who was trying to beat swords into plowshares was shot as he left a peace rally. Yitzhak Rabin, the Israeli prime minister who signed a groundbreaking agreement with the Palestinians just a little more than two years earlier, was assassinated in Tel Aviv by a young right-wing law student who decided he had a divinely sanctioned duty to kill the premier.

headline: Stand More at Work, Sit More at Home
abstract: New findings subtly underscore that, when it comes to health habits and exercise, we humans have a surprising capacity to be our own worst enemies.

headline: Suicide Bombing Kills at Least 4 Egyptian Police Officers in Sinai
abstract: The Islamic State’s local affiliate, called Sinai Province, claimed responsibility for the attack in a statement distributed on social media accounts.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — At least four police officers were killed on Wednesday morning when a suicide bomber detonated an explosives-packed vehicle next to a police club in northern Sinai, according to the Egyptian state news media. The Islamic State’s local affiliate, called Sinai Province, claimed responsibility for the bombing in a statement distributed on social media accounts.

Gov. Gary R. Herbert of Utah hailed the investment as a model for financing public projects, but questions have emerged about the success of the program,Nathaniel Popper reports in DealBook.

abstract: You may not have known that Burberry had three clothing lines for men and for women — but don’t worry, it will soon have just one.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, in a briefing just before Burberry unveiled its latest holiday ad campaign, Christopher Bailey, chief executive and chief creative officer of the brand, also announced what he suggested was a gift to consumers: the news that the three Burberry women’s and men’s wear lines would begin a consolidation process, so that by the end of 2016, there will be a single brand on offer in stores.

headline: At Paul Ryan’s Invitation, Image of Hastert Takes an ‘Appropriate’ Leave From Speaker’s Lobby
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A portrait of Representative Frederick H. Gillett, a Massachusetts Republican who served as speaker of the House for six years in the early 1920s, was chosen to replace that of former Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, who recently pleaded guilty to violating banking laws.
lead_paragraph: Some facts about Representative Frederick H. Gillett: A Massachusetts Republican, he served as speaker of the House for six years in the early 1920s. He proposed an anti-polygamy amendment to the Constitution. He served in the Senate after the House, then apparently engaged in “literary pursuits.”

headline: 2016 Legislative Calendars Leave Plenty of Room for Campaigning
abstract: The House schedule for next year will contain just 25 full four-day or five-day work weeks, and the Senate will have a similarly abridged schedule, largely because of time off for political conventions and campaigning.
lead_paragraph: Rank-and-file House Republicans have been demanding a greater role in legislating — and more amendments — which means longer debates and workdays at the Capitol. And Speaker Paul D. Ryan seems prepared to oblige. But election years also present their own special scheduling imperatives, given the need for lawmakers to defend their seats.

headline: Remains of Nearly 2,750 Korean Wartime Laborers Found in Japan, South Says
keywords: ['World War II (1939-45)', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Historians estimate that at least 1.2 million Koreans were coerced, or sometimes duped, into toiling as part of Japan’s war efforts in Japan, China and elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Summing up a search that has been underway for more than a decade, a South Korean government commission said on Wednesday that the remains of nearly 2,750 people believed to be Koreans who were forced to work in Japan in the World War II era have been found.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Rhymes With ‘Rock’
abstract: Keep your anatomical innuendos out of family game night.
lead_paragraph: Lori writes: During a family game night, my husband drew a card that said, ‘‘Find two things that rhyme with ‘rock.’ ’’ He searched the house and returned with a sock and a tube of caulk. I immediately disputed the caulk, but he insisted it rhymes, shouting a mispronunciation of the word over and over in front of our 9-year-old.

headline: How Much Can We Spend to Keep Our Dog Alive?
abstract: Is it fair to expend limited resources on one animal’s life when there is so much suffering in the world?
lead_paragraph: About 18 months ago, my husband and I adopted a dog who was seized as part of a cruelty/neglect investigation. He has serious skin issues and was recently diagnosed with lymphoma. Like most dogs, despite all he has been through, he has a sweet doggy spirit. He also has a team of specialists — a dermatologist, an oncologist and his regular vet. At the moment, he is comfortable and happy. When the time comes (most likely in the next year), we will see him through to a gentle death. We have the resources to take care of him, but he is expensive — think car payment, not mortgage payment. He doesn’t look like a regular dog, and people know he has a medical routine. There is a lot of unsolicited judgment, mostly in three camps: those who think we should devote the same amount of resources to charitable animal-related organizations and not an individual dog, people who think it is wrong to ‘‘put a dog through chemo’’ and people who think it’s morally wrong to exert so much effort on an animal. We mostly just love our dog. What do you think? C. S., Portland, Ore.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Magic-Flight Launch Box
abstract: Unlike iridescent pipes and cumbersome bongs, a vape embodies discretion.
lead_paragraph: For a year or two, I smoked pot out of a chimney-­shaped wooden pipe. It came with a lighter, which was wrapped in a sort of braided-­leather papoose. Papoose and pipe were handmade by a shaman-­like fellow I met on the side of a highway in the Pacific Northwest. His wares were solid, but the smoke was harsh. So, not long ago, I switched to a vaporizer, or ‘‘vape,’’ the Magic-­Flight Launch Box.

headline: Kenya Excels in Running but Lags in Antidoping
abstract: Even as Kenyan athletes again captured the men’s and women’s races at the New York marathon, Kenya had a nonfunctioning antidoping agency, according to World Anti-Doping Agency officials.
lead_paragraph: In case you haven’t noticed, Kenya’s runners are good. Lately, they are better than ever.

headline: A Slice of Heaven in Pittsburgh
abstract: In his farewell column, Mark Bittman visits Pittsburgh to learn how to make pizza easy again.
lead_paragraph: Somehow, over the past few years, Neapolitan pizza — gooey, thin, soft-crusted, mozzarella-and-tomato-only — has become the ideal. In a way it’s understandable; pizza had strayed so far from its roots that the classical model was bound to come back.

headline: How We Judge Those Who Served, or Didn’t, in Vietnam
abstract: A Vietnam-era veteran says presidential candidates should not be judged harshly just because they did not serve during that war.
lead_paragraph: The first Democratic presidential debate once again raised the issue of military service during the Vietnam War. Senator Bernie Sanders was asked how he could be commander-in-chief, given that he applied for conscientious objector status during that war. (Though his application was rejected he was not drafted and did not serve.)

headline: New Passport in Britain Puts Women in 2nd Class
abstract: A redesign of the document was intended to celebrate creativity and innovation in the country over the past five centuries, but critics point out it features seven men and only two women.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s newly designed passport was meant to celebrate the country’s creativity and innovation over the last five centuries, and officials have called it the “latest step in an evolutionary process” for passport security.

headline: A Canada Ready to Share Again
abstract: Justin Trudeau’s election offers promise in helping solve both the refugee crisis and the challenges of First Nations at home.
lead_paragraph: Toronto — The resounding demand for change that saw the Liberal leader Justin Trudeau swept into the Canadian prime minister’s office, and Stephen Harper out of it, also introduced other auspicious changes, setting the country on a different but familiar path. The 338-seat House of Commons now has more female representatives than ever before, and there are 46 members from minority groups (though African-Canadians are still underrepresented). The country’s first lawmaker born in Afghanistan was elected. The 10 members from Canada’s indigenous population of about 1.4 million is also a record.

headline: Let’s Finally Close Guantánamo
abstract: The prison has cost the United States billions of dollars and is one of the best propaganda tools that terrorists have today.
lead_paragraph: INSTEAD of blocking President Obama’s efforts to close the costly Guantánamo Bay detention facility, Congress should be working with him to finally shut it down.

headline: Kicked Off a Plane? Here’s How to Handle It
abstract: A Spirit Airlines flight attendant recently ejected several passengers from a flight. What can get you kicked off a plane and what do you do if it happens to you?
lead_paragraph: Seven passengers were removed from a Spirit Airlines flight on Monday before it left Los Angeles, bound for Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport. The incident appears to have started with a double-booked seat and escalated when other passengers questioned the conduct of the flight crew. The fliers, all African-American, and at least one fellow passenger using Twitter  have accused the airline of racism.

headline: Nilaja Sun Serves Up the Characters in Her One-Woman ‘Pike St.’
abstract: Ms. Sun makes a long-awaited return with a focus on a family whose daughter has a mystery illness.
lead_paragraph: The golden age of the chameleonic solo show seems to have passed, and with it the days when there seemed to be a virtuoso new work by Eric Bogosian, Anna Deavere Smith, Danny Hoch, John Leguizamo or Sarah Jones opening every few months. But there is good news for fans of this fertile theatrical genre: One of its most gifted stars, Nilaja Sun, is making a long-awaited return with “Pike St.,” a one-woman show that evokes a collection of characters on the Lower East Side, including a family dealing with a teenage daughter whose mysterious sickness has rendered her unable to move or breathe on her own.

headline: 1915: Panel in Defense of Armenians
keywords: ['Armenians', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'World War I (1914-18)']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: An American committee is organized on behalf of Armenians in 1915.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Responding to a pressing appeal from Mr. Morgenthau, United States Ambassador in Constantinople, an American committee has been organized on behalf of the Armenians. Among its members are such men as Mr. Charles R. Crane, Mr. Samuel T. Dutton and Mr. Oscar Straus. The committee has just published a report giving conclusive evidence in regard to the atrocities against the Armenians on the part of the Turks. Witnesses of these horrors hold the Germans largely responsible for them because of tacit assent. — The New York Herald, European Edition, November 5, 1915

headline: Heartland of Darkness
abstract: White America breaks bad.
lead_paragraph: This new paper by Angus Deaton and Anne Case on mortality among middle-aged whites has been getting a lot of attention, and rightly so. As a number of people have pointed out, the closest parallel to America’s rising death rates — driven by poisonings, suicide, and chronic liver diseases — is the collapse in Russian life expectancy after the fall of Communism. (No, we’re not doing as badly as that, but still.) What the data look like is a society gripped by despair, with a surge of unhealthy behaviors and an epidemic of drugs, very much including alcohol.

headline: An Easy Way to Use WhatsApp
abstract: The WhatsApp site offers instructions for emailing the contents of a conversation in a file to yourself — which could then be printed.
lead_paragraph: Q. My daughter has been living in South America for the last year and we communicate daily via WhatsApp on our iPhones. Our text history is a wonderful diary of her experiences there and I would like to be able to save them to my computer and print them out for us to enjoy in the future. Is there a simple way to do this?

headline: Punk Is Beautiful: Dickie Hammond (1965-2015)
abstract: Dickie Hammond’s guitar playing reminded me that I should play music for as long as I could, no matter what.
lead_paragraph: Dickie Hammond, one of British punk rock’s most gifted and revered guitarists, died last week. He was 50. Facebook and British and European blogs are filling up with tributes to Dickie — a “legend,” a “lord” and a “lovely bloke” — some of them calling him the best punk guitarist of all time. None of this is likely to make the obit pages outside North England.

headline: Forty-Two Minutes With Jeb Bush on the Campaign Bus

lead_paragraph: RYE, N.H. — Jeb Bush needs a boost. He’s getting a bus.

abstract: A British government study has recommended that the awards at financial services companies be linked to the recruitment of more women for senior posts.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The annual bonuses of financial services executives in Britain should be tied to targets to bring more women into senior roles, according to the preliminary findings of a government commission’s review of gender diversity in the sector.

headline: Angelina Jolie Pitt Is Behind Closed Doors in ‘By the Sea’
abstract: She talks about directing her husband and switching hats between her roles as actress, screenwriter and director for her new film.
lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, CALIF. — During the filming of “By the Sea,” Angelina Jolie Pitt and Brad Pitt — who play a depressed former dancer and her blocked novelist husband — had a go-to method for lightening an often somber mood on the set. “There were a lot of jokes about how nobody is ever going to want to be our neighbor again,” said Ms. Jolie Pitt, referring to how their characters often spy through a peephole on two lovers in the hotel room next door.

lead_paragraph: Children are much more likely than not to grow up in a household in which their parents work, and in nearly half of all two-parent families today, both parents work full time, a sharp increase from previous decades.

headline: France to Lift Ban on Gay Men Donating Blood
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Blood Donation', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Sexually Transmitted Diseases']
abstract: Starting in the spring, gay and bisexual men will have to wait one year before they may donate blood.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — France will lift a ban on blood donations by gay and bisexual men starting next year, officials announced Wednesday, joining a growing list of countries that have loosened or scrapped such restrictions, which many see as outdated vestiges of the 1980s AIDS crisis.
