headline: Public Companies Trying to Mimic Private Firms
abstract: Some companies go private to free themselves of meddling investors. But there’s another way: Ignore them.
lead_paragraph: It was one of the biggest rebukes of the public markets in recent memory — and it may not be the last.

headline: What to Watch in New York’s Fall Art Auctions
abstract: The big auction season is upon us. Here’s what you should know.
lead_paragraph: It has been a banner year for the international art auction houses. Last November, the big fall auctions in New York saw sales at Christie’s and Sotheby’s top $2 billion in two weeks. In May, Christie’s sold $1 billion worth of art in just three days. Included in that total was a 1955 Picasso, “Les Femmes d’Alger (Version ‘O’),” which went for $179.4 million with fees — a record for any artwork at auction.

headline: Reader Contest: The Best Parenting Advice in Six Words
abstract: What’s your best advice for parents in exactly 6 words?
lead_paragraph: Made a threat? Carry it through.

headline: 1940: Vichy Gives Assurances to U.S.
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: An early American intervention in Martinique is discounted in 1940.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The chances of early American intervention in Martinique were discounted today [Nov. 4] by Gaston Henry-Haye, French Ambassador, after he had delivered a note from the Vichy government to the State Department denying any intention of turning over French possessions and bases to the Germans.

headline: Digital Transformation Going Mainstream in 2016, IDC Predicts
abstract: The technology research firm IDC predicts the pace of digital transformation of business is going to accelerate and increasingly hit every industry.
lead_paragraph: It is the time of year when the big technology research shops gaze into the near future to identify trends that will have the most impact on corporate America and the tech industry over the next few years.

headline: Patricia Riggen, Director of ‘The 33,’ on Shooting in a Mine
abstract: Ms. Riggen took her film about trapped Chilean miners, starring Antonio Banderas, Lou Diamond Phillips and Juliette Binoche, deep underground.
lead_paragraph: On the first day of shooting “The 33,” the Mexican director Patricia Riggen sat in her chair in the cave that served as the movie’s set. “And bicckk! A stone falls on top of my head,” she recalled. “Fortunately, I had my hard hat on. But it makes me realize where I am and what it means to be there.”

headline: In ‘The Hot Rock,’ Gems on View Before Their Time
abstract: Robert Redford and Zero Mostel are among the cast members in this 1972 caper comedy screening at Film Forum.
lead_paragraph: It’s never been clear why “The Hot Rock,” the New York caper comedy directed by Peter Yates, didn’t get more love at its 1972 release. (Maybe because the city was simply an unfunny tableau of urban decline, not yet the object of nostalgic affection it would become.) Even so, the film, about unpolished jewel thieves trying to snatch a spectacular diamond for an interested buyer, is an embarrassment of riches: It featured William Goldman’s script, adapted from the Donald E. Westlake novel, as well as a top-shelf cast — Robert Redford playing straight man to George Segal, Paul Sand and Ron Leibman, all eclipsed by vintage late-period Zero Mostel. And the city was virtually a featured character itself.

headline: Lizt Alfonso Dance Cuba Blends Dance Traditions
abstract: The troupe is known for its fiery mix of ballet, flamenco, cha-cha, rumba, bolero and salsa dance.
lead_paragraph: It’s always a hot night in Havana wherever and whenever Lizt Alfonso Dance Cuba performs. In her “Cuba Vibra!,” Ms. Alfonso’s Havana-based company, in only 95 minutes, will celebrate the development of Cuban music and dance from the 1950s to the present with the aid of 18 dancers and an onstage big band. The troupe, founded by Ms. Alfonso in 1991 as an all-female group, now includes men.

headline: A Beloved Bakery in Midwood
abstract: Isaac’s Bake Shop is famous in Midwood’s Jewish community, but also picks up customers tired of waiting at a celebrated pizza place nearby.
lead_paragraph: Isaac’s Bake Shop is famous in Midwood’s Jewish community, but also picks up customers tired of waiting at a celebrated pizza place nearby.

headline: Q. & A. Why Are More Companies Passing on Going Public?
abstract: Researchers at U.C.L.A., Harvard and N.Y.U. found that corporate executives may have started to figure out that being publicly traded is a hindrance.
lead_paragraph: The United States stock market is thought to have played a heroic role in the country’s history. Over the decades, thousands of public companies have raised many billions of dollars in the markets — money that has propelled economic growth, innovation and employment. Without the public markets, corporate America would not have had a vast, cheap and powerful pool of capital.

headline: Classical Playlist: Vaughan Williams and a Piano ‘Nutcracker’
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: VAUGHAN WILLIAMS: ‘A Sea Symphony’Katherine Broderick, soprano; Roderick Williams, baritone; Hallé Choir, Hallé Youth Choir, Schola Cantorum of Oxford, Ad Solem; Hallé Orchestra; Mark Elder, conductor(Hallé)Manchester’s Hallé Orchestra continues its unbroken streak of valuable releases with this towering account of Ralph Vaughan Williams’s first symphony. Written at the crest of the fashion for seafaring works that swept Britain at the start of the 20th century, and given its premiere just a month after Mahler’s Eighth, it’s a full choral symphony lasting over an hour, a work that astonishes with ambition both compositional and (with texts by Walt Whitman) literary and philosophical. Mark Elder makes clear Vaughan Williams’s debts to Charles Stanford and Elgar, Wagner and Ravel, carrying them along in a reading of tidal power, patient yet inexorable. (David Allen)

headline: ‘Secret Space Escapes’ Re-enacts Near Disasters on Past Missions
abstract: This new documentary series on the Science Channel explores a variety of situations that could have turned catastrophic.
lead_paragraph: We’re all familiar with America’s worst spacecraft moments, those that took a disastrous, fatal turn. But less well known are the “almosts,” the difficulties astronauts faced that could have been catastrophic.

headline: Britain Announces Plan to Update Surveillance Laws
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Privacy', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Computer Security', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The government promised tougher scrutiny over monitoring by spy agencies but said it wanted technology firms to store data about Internet use for a year.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Stirring a fraught debate about the balance between security and privacy, the British government on Wednesday proposed tougher scrutiny over snooping by spy agencies, but also said it wanted technology companies to store data about every Briton’s Internet use for a year.

headline: Bali Travelers Stranded as Volcano Grounds Flights
abstract: More than 700 flights have been canceled or delayed since Mount Rinjani began erupting, and officials said Bali’s international airport would be closed until at least Thursday.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — A volcanic eruption has stranded thousands of airline passengers on the Indonesian island of Bali and led to the cancellation of hundreds of flights in and out of the popular resort destination, with no relief in sight until at least Thursday.

headline: Statins May Dampen Response to Flu Vaccine
abstract: People taking statins had a less robust immune response to flu vaccine and were more likely to get a respiratory illness than those not taking statins.
lead_paragraph: Statins, the cholesterol lowering drugs, may weaken the effect of the flu vaccine, two new studies suggest.

headline: A Brooklyn Bakery Appeals to Observant Jews and Pizza Fans
keywords: ['Kosher Foods and Products', 'Bakeries and Baked Products']
abstract: Most customers of Isaac’s Bake Shop in Midwood are drawn to its kosher fare, but it has a following among people tired of waiting to order at Di Fara Pizza across the street.
lead_paragraph: Isaac’s Bake Shop knows firsthand the power of the adage “location, location, location.” The humble kosher bakery happens to be directly across the street from Di Fara Pizza, one of the few destinations in Midwood that draws international tour guides. Di Fara is also known for its interminable waiting times. Thanks to the influx of hungry customers roaming up and down Avenue J looking for an in-the-meantime nibble, Isaac’s has developed an unexpected following among those unaware of or indifferent to the laws of kashrut.

headline: Christian Gerhaher at Park Avenue Armory, and Julia Bullock at the Met
abstract: Mr. Gerhaher and his pianist, Gerold Huber, will perform Haydn, Beethoven and Schoenberg on Nov. 10, the same night as Ms. Bullock’s museum recital.
lead_paragraph: Among chamber music fans, the baritone Christian Gerhaher is considered the uncontested heir to Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau at the helm of the German lied tradition. On Tuesday, Nov. 10, he and his longtime pianist, Gerold Huber, return to the elegant Board of Officers Room at the Park Avenue Armory, which they inaugurated with an all-Schumann recital two years ago. This time, they bring their probing musicianship to the Viennese tradition with a program spanning songs by Haydn, Beethoven, Schoenberg and Berg. (7:30 p.m., parkavenuearmory.org.)

headline: Cargo Plane Crashes in South Sudan
abstract: Shortly after takeoff from Juba's airport, a cargo plane crashed into the banks of the White Nile River. Officials said three survived, but at least 25 have been reported killed.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after takeoff from Juba's airport, a cargo plane crashed into the banks of the White Nile River. Officials said three survived, but at least 25 have been reported killed.

headline: ‘Procession: The Art of Norman Lewis’ Is a Full Retrospective of This Artist’s Career
abstract: The show, opening on Nov. 13 at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts in Philadelphia, offers more than 90 paintings and works on paper.
lead_paragraph: Last year, the art of Norman Lewis (1909-79) shared an exhibition at the Jewish Museum with that of another marginalized Abstract Expressionist, Lee Krasner (1908-84). Now the first full retrospective of Lewis’s art since his death opens on Friday, Nov. 13, at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts in Philadelphia.

headline: Takeaways from Tuesday’s Election
abstract: It was a big night for Republicans, turnout matters, and other things you need to know.
lead_paragraph: It was a big night for Republicans, turnout matters, and other things you need to know.

headline: House Tour | Thomas Flohr
abstract: The VistaJet chairman built a seven-story chalet in the Swiss Alps — fit for James Bond, and complete with a hidden grotto.
lead_paragraph: The VistaJet chairman built a seven-story chalet in the Swiss Alps — fit for James Bond, and complete with a hidden grotto.

headline: The Man Who Hates E.T.F.s
keywords: ['Exchange Traded Funds', 'Mutual Funds', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Executive Compensation']
abstract: Peter S. Kraus, chief of AllianceBernstein, is convinced that exchange-traded funds are a mounting peril to the markets. And he isn’t shy about telling E.T.F. brokers that to their faces.
lead_paragraph: Bearded and tanned, Peter S. Kraus, the chief executive of AllianceBernstein, strode with assurance into a Midtown Manhattan conference room full of financial advisers from a large investment bank.

headline: New Music From Nate Wooley, Alicia Hall Moran and Adam Larson
abstract: Other new works include an album from the Swedish songwriter Anna Von Hausswolff and a new children’s compilation titled “This Record Belongs To ___.”
lead_paragraph: (DANCE TO) THE EARLY MUSIC

headline: Prime Minister Ponta of Romania Resigns
abstract: Prime Minister Victor Ponta of Romania said he is resigning in the wake of public discontent after a fire killed 32 people in a Bucharest nightclub.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Victor Ponta of Romania said he is resigning in the wake of public discontent after a fire killed 32 people in a Bucharest nightclub.

headline: Britons Perturbed by a Troubling Shortage of Curry Chefs
abstract: Curry is so important to the British palate that it has its own committee in Parliament, but curry advocates say immigration restrictions are causing staff shortages.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — William Makepeace Thackeray, a 19th-century English satirist, was born in Calcutta and once penned an ode to curry. “ ’Tis, when done,” he wrote, “a dish for Emperors to feed upon.”

headline: Officer’s Death Stuns Illinois Town a Second Time
keywords: ['Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: More than two months after Lt. Charles Gliniewicz was found dead, officials said he took his own life, fearing he was about to be caught for stealing money from the town.
lead_paragraph: The shooting death of a police lieutenant made national news and brought a stretch of northern Illinois to a tense standstill with roadblocks, thudding helicopters and officers tramping with dogs through woods and over farmland, searching for the killers. The lieutenant, Charles J. Gliniewicz, was hailed as a hero, and some conservatives seized on this and other shootings as evidence that critics of the police were fueling a wave of violence against law enforcement.

headline: The Beatles’ Video Collection ‘1’: Baby, You Can Film My Song
abstract: The Beatles turned to videos when touring became difficult. Those early films and other footage of the band are in a new DVD collection called “1.”
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 23, 1965, the Beatles entered Twickenham Film Studios, on the outskirts of London, for a marathon session. But the biggest band in the world wasn’t recording music — it was making promotional films for five of its singles.

headline: A Jim Henson Thanksgiving, 47 Years in the Making
abstract: A “musical monsters” project from the days before “Sesame Street” is revived for television.
lead_paragraph: In 1968, a pre-famous Jim Henson and his frequent writing partner, Jerry Juhl, collaborated on a treatment for a one-hour Thanksgiving special called “The Musical Monsters of Turkey Hollow.” The outline called for Mr. Henson’s puppets to exist in real-world environs, shot on location in and around an unspecified New England town. The title characters, “small, shaggy monsters” of extraterrestrial origin, would communicate via “a rather unique musical sound” — to be created on an electronic synthesizer by the pioneering musician Raymond Scott.

headline: December Interest Rate Increase Is ‘a Live Possibility,’ Janet Yellen Says
abstract: Janet Yellen, the chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, told a House committee that the economy was “performing well” and that an interest rate increase “may be appropriate.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve could raise its benchmark interest rate in December as long as economic growth continues, two senior Fed officials said on Wednesday, hammering that message in repeated public remarks.

headline: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: A Fall-Themed Veggie Burger
abstract: Create a fall-themed veggie burger with acorn squash, cranberries and toasted almonds to star on your Thanksgiving table.
lead_paragraph: Bailey Rae, a food writer in Nashville, created a fall-themed veggie burger to star on her Thanksgiving table. The dish requires some prep time to bake, scoop and, well, squash, the acorn squash and caramelize the onions, but once those steps are out of the way, this is an easy dish to add to your Thanksgiving menu.

headline: Enlisting Veterans to Remedy the Shortage of Farmers
abstract: Veterans need work and agriculture needs farmers. Now, with the help of nonprofits that are connecting the two, those who once served in the military are producing food.
lead_paragraph: American military veterans need work, and American agriculture needs farmers. So why not, figuratively, convert those who wielded swords into those guiding plowshares?

headline: A Flawed Marijuana Legalization Effort Fails in Ohio [Updated]
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Law and Legislation', 'Marijuana', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: The proposal would have granted a monopoly on commercial marijuana cultivation to a small group of investors, which is a terrible idea.
lead_paragraph: Ohio voters did the right thing on Tuesday by overwhelmingly rejecting a deeply flawed marijuana legalization ballot initiative. The proposal would have amended the state’s constitution to grant a monopoly on commercial cultivation of cannabis to a small group of investors, which is a terrible idea.

headline: Roosting Chickens and Fed-Bashing
abstract: Why hedgies talk doom.
lead_paragraph: So I look at Business Insider and see that Stanley Druckenmiller is issuing dire warnings that terrible things will happen unless the Fed hikes rates now now now. I guess this is supposed to be news. But wait; haven’t I heard this before? Why, yes: two and half years ago he warned that a crash worse than 2008 was coming unless we slash Social Security now now now.

headline: Another Setback for World Trade Center Transit Hub: Leaking Water
keywords: ['World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Building (Construction)', 'Shopping Centers and Malls']
abstract: The leak is among the problems that have stalled the opening of the high-end shopping complex, which was supposed to be operating by now, to the first half of 2016.
lead_paragraph: Everywhere, the shopping season is about to begin. Everywhere, that is, except at “the most complete retail destination in New York City, the most alluring retail landmark in the world,” as the luxury Westfield World Trade Center mall describes itself.

headline: Afghan Businessman Convicted in Kabul Bank Fraud Is Still Free to Make Money
abstract: Khalilullah Frozi, sentenced to 15 years for his role in defrauding Kabul Bank of nearly $1 billion, has partnered with the Afghan government on a development project.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — In a big day for development here, a notable Afghan businessman stood with top government officials on Wednesday as he signed the contract for a new township: 8,800 homes across 33 acres of prime real estate in the heart of the capital, with an initial investment of at least $95 million.

headline: Migrants Rescued Near Greece
abstract: Greek authorities reported a deadly boating accident near the island of Lesbos involving migrants from Turkey, The Associated Press said. Rescue workers were able to save most on board.
lead_paragraph: Greek authorities reported a deadly boating accident near the island of Lesbos involving migrants from Turkey, The Associated Press said. Rescue workers were able to save most on board.

headline: Expectations Mount for Trustees in Higher Education
abstract: Unlike in years past, positions on a college’s or university’s board of trustees now require much more than a checkbook and a rubber stamp.
lead_paragraph: Rick White is a financial consultant in Boulder, Colo., but his heart is often 2,000 miles to the east, at Haverford College, the school on the Main Line outside Philadelphia that he graduated from in 1981. When he was tapped to be on its governing board, he was like a sub coming off the bench in a crucial game, ready to go all in.

headline: Eight Edgy, Elegant Enamel Earrings
abstract: A bit Memphis, a touch mod, these graphic combinations of color and shape feel totally on the mark.
lead_paragraph: A bit Memphis, a touch mod, these graphic combinations of color and shape feel totally on the mark.

headline: Trudeau Becomes Prime Minister of Canada
abstract: Justin Trudeau, the leader of the majority Liberal Party, was sworn in on Wednesday as the 23rd prime minister of Canada.
lead_paragraph: Justin Trudeau, the leader of the majority Liberal Party, was sworn in on Wednesday as the 23rd prime minister of Canada.

headline: Navigating the Tax Rules on Charitable Gifts
abstract: In time for year-end tax planning, a primer on avoiding common pitfalls when making charitable donations.
lead_paragraph: Congress has been tightening the rules on charitable gifts for more than a decade, and following those rules is critical to getting the maximum deduction for gifts. Below, in time for year-end tax planning, are some common charitable giving pitfalls and how to navigate around them.

headline: Margaret Cho Wants to Talk About Sex Work
abstract: The outspoken comedian tweets her way into sex work activism.
lead_paragraph: It was the tweet heard round the sex-worker world. At 6:12 p.m. on Oct. 29, Margaret Cho, the 46-year-old comedian, disturbed the Twittersphere with an economical 109 characters: “Sex work is simply work. For me it was honest work. I was a sex worker when I was young. It was hard but well paid. There’s no shame in it.”

headline: Steve Coleman, Toward a Sound That Defies Walls
abstract: Having traveled the world to inhale traditions and rhythms, Steve Colman alights for the first time at the Village Vanguard, performing with two different groups.
lead_paragraph: The saxophonist and bandleader Steve Coleman is fascinated by tradition but doesn’t seem to believe that any tradition is self-contained. Starting from his early training in the Chicago and New York jazz scenes during the late ’70s and early ’80s, he eventually created a music that could encompass everything he learned: Charlie Parker and James Brown; rhythmic practices from Africa and India and Brazil; ancient or esoteric theories about numbers, form, symmetry and multiplicity. He’s played and taught all over the world but never led a band at the Village Vanguard. That soon changes. On the first two nights of his engagement, he’ll play with a new chamber-like group, Natal Eclipse: horns, bass, piano (Craig Taborn), voice (Jen Shyu) and no drums. Then he’ll present the standard version of his long-running band, Five Elements — a great evolving machine — and through the weekend he’ll add a second drummer, the great Marcus Gilmore, to that group. Don’t miss it. (8:30 and 10:30 p.m., Tuesday, Nov. 10, through Sunday, Nov. 15, villagevanguard.com.)

headline: Justin Trudeau Is Sworn In as Prime Minister of Canada
abstract: Ending nearly a decade of Conservative government, Mr. Trudeau, the Liberal Party leader, took the oath of office at Rideau Hall in Ottawa on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Justin Trudeau, the leader of the Liberal Party, was sworn in as prime minister of Canada on Wednesday morning, ending nearly a decade of Conservative dominance.

headline: Lumber Liquidators Names John M. Presley as Chief
abstract: Mr. Presley, a longtime director, will remain on the board and take the helm of the company on Nov. 16.
lead_paragraph: The discount flooring retailer Lumber Liquidators selected a new chief executive on Wednesday as the company struggled to recover from a major safety scandal that has badly damaged its stock price and sales.

headline: Terry Collins Gets a Reward, and Sandy Alderson Gets a Scare
abstract: A Mets official said General Manager Sandy Alderson had not eaten breakfast and began to feel lightheaded while sitting in front of the television lights at a news conference.
lead_paragraph: The Mets held a postseason news conference Wednesday that, for the first time in years, was celebratory in nature. Manager Terry Collins wore a teal dress shirt and black slacks and a satisfied expression. Sitting next to him, General Manager Sandy Alderson announced that the Mets had agreed to give Collins a two-year contract extension, a reward for leading the team to its first pennant in 15 years.

headline: A $1,000 Day in New York City for $100
abstract: A budget doesn’t hamper our Frugal Traveler on a romp through downtown, from a beloved West Village cheese shop to the top of the city’s tallest tower.
lead_paragraph: A budget doesn’t hamper our Frugal Traveler on a romp through downtown, from a beloved West Village cheese shop to the top of the city’s tallest tower.

headline: Honda and Takata Officials React
abstract: Executives gave statements regarding Honda's decision not to use Takata's technology in its vehicles after the United States fined Takata for faulty airbags.
lead_paragraph: Executives gave statements regarding Honda's decision not to use Takata's technology in its vehicles after the United States fined Takata for faulty airbags.

headline: Activist Investors Get a Welcome Seat at the Table
abstract: As corporate America shifts its negative view of activists, more companies are adopting their tactics and even hiring them as consultants.
lead_paragraph: For decades, corporate America rejected activist investors, accusing them of being corporate raiders out to make a quick buck. But these days, some of America’s biggest companies are trying to think more like them.

headline: Risking Your Neck to Run With the Unicorns
keywords: ['Venture Capital', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Start-ups', 'Initial Public Offerings']
abstract: Tech start-ups are making deals to stretch their private valuations to $1 billion. But those trade-offs may end up hurting employees and early investors.
lead_paragraph: In the world of Wall Street, where numbers are everything, one number is especially coveted: one billion. Technology start-ups that achieve $1 billion in valuation before going public — so-called unicorns — can attract the attention of prominent venture capital firms and draw résumés from top talent across the country.

headline: An Anticorruption Plea in Kenya: ‘Please, Just Steal a Little’
abstract: Even for Kenyans who have seen countless corruption scandals, graft coming to light now is almost too outrageous to believe.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — When it comes to honesty, politicians here don’t usually win many awards.

headline: Britain, Concerned About Russian Crash, Halts Sinai Flights
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Prime Minister David Cameron announced the suspension of all flights between Britain and the Egyptian resort of Sharm el Sheikh.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British government on Wednesday suspended flights between Britain and the Egyptian resort of Sharm el Sheikh over concerns that a chartered Russian jetliner might have been brought down in the Sinai Peninsula by a bomb on board.

headline: Review: Christian Tetzlaff Sharpens Mendelssohn’s Edge
abstract: Accompanied by the Orchestra of St. Luke’s at Carnegie Hall, this soloist added bite to the Mendelssohn Violin Concerto.
lead_paragraph: A moment arose on Thursday night at Carnegie Hall when I thought that Christian Tetzlaff was going to play the Mendelssohn Violin Concerto straight.

headline: Thomas Flohr’s Fortress in St. Moritz
abstract: With a business that caters to modern-day 007 aspirants, the VistaJet chairman Thomas Flohr has created a house to match: a seven-story chalet in the Swiss Alps.
lead_paragraph: With a business that caters to modern-day 007 aspirants, the VistaJet chairman Thomas Flohr has created a house to match: a seven-story chalet in the Swiss Alps.

headline: One Man’s Mountaintop Fortress — and Playground
abstract: By day, the VistaJet founder Thomas Flohr is attempting to revolutionize private aviation. But during his off hours, he gets to play secret agent at home in St. Moritz.
lead_paragraph: High above the Swiss ski resort of St. Moritz, where the royal and the merely rich break for caviar and champagne between downhill runs, is Thomas Flohr’s James Bond-inspired home, Ches’Aivla (Eagle’s Nest in the local language, Romansh). A seven-story, 35,000-square-foot structure built into the Suvretta mountainside, it has a cinema, library, wine cellar, spa, squash court, billiard room, bowling alley and pizzeria and is filled with important contemporary art and a stream of mostly female staff. Parked in the ‘‘garage gallery’’ is a pristine silver Aston Martin DB5 (‘‘like the one in ‘Goldfinger,’ ’’ Flohr says, brightly). Part of the home office is leather-padded like M’s at the MI6 headquarters in London, and there’s a midcentury rosewood and chrome desk that was used in ‘‘From Russia With Love’’ and ‘‘You Only Live Twice.’’ On the wall hangs a rusted steel map of the world with the capitals and major cities identified by tiny lights, ‘‘like when you have Dr. No in those meetings and they divide the world and look at the map,’’ he says.

headline: Saying No to a Cash Buffet in Start-Up World
abstract: Some companies refuse the big money, hold tight to their independence and build themselves through resilience and discipline.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — To fashion cognoscenti, Everlane is perhaps best known for its almost monastically plain button-down shirts and pants, stripped of excess.

headline: Deutsche Bank to Pay $258 Million and Fire 6 in Settlement
abstract: It is the latest in a string of settlements over sanctions violations as regulators take aim at banks for doing business with blacklisted countries.
lead_paragraph: Deutsche Bank agreed on Wednesday to pay $258 million and fire six employees to resolve investigations by state and federal banking regulators into its dealings with countries like Iran and Syria in violation of United States sanctions laws.

headline: Marco Rubio Confronts New Scrutiny Over Use of Party Credit Card
abstract: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida said that he would “soon” release additional records that would detail expenditures from a Republican Party credit card used years ago, brushing aside continued criticism about his personal finances.
lead_paragraph: A decade after he began using a Republican Party credit card for personal purchases like paving stones at his home, Senator Marco Rubio on Wednesday pledged to disclose new spending records from that account as he sought to inoculate himself against what could be his biggest liability as a presidential candidate: how he manages his finances.

lead_paragraph: The Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Rodham Clinton discussed gun violence during a speech in Iowa on Tuesday.

abstract: The concept of pay-for-performance has attained a sense of inevitability. But under the tax code, it encourages risky behavior.
lead_paragraph: Every religion has a creation myth.

headline: ‘The Bloggess’ Conjures Thousands of Cringes With One Tweet
abstract: Jenny Lawson, an author with a strong online following, said, ‘We’re all just weirdos’ after her post inspired hundreds of confessions of mortifying moments.
lead_paragraph: After a decade of blogging, writing a best-selling memoir and dispatching clever tweets, the author Jenny Lawson is skilled in the art of self-deprecating humor.

abstract: Marisol Touraine, France's health minister, says the country will end a taboo and a form of discrimination as it prepares to allow gay men to donate blood.
lead_paragraph: Marisol Touraine, France's health minister, says the country will end a taboo and a form of discrimination as it prepares to allow gay men to donate blood.

headline: Readers React to Rising Death Rates of Middle-Aged White Americans
abstract: An article about an increase in mortality rates drew almost 1,900 comments from readers.
lead_paragraph: A front-page report on a study that found death rates rising among white, middle-aged Americans, tapped into deep roots of angst, compassion and frustration among readers. The article shot to the top of the most-emailed list, and attracted nearly 1,900 comments.

headline: Quentin Tarantino Says ‘All Cops Are Not Murderers’
abstract: Quentin Tarantino says his remarks about polices officers were misinterpreted.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Quentin Tarantino has broken his silence regarding a growing police boycott of his coming film, “The Hateful Eight,” telling The Los Angeles Times that his public remarks about police violence had been misinterpreted.

headline: Police Kill California Student After Campus Stabbing of 4
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Colleges and Universities', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks']
abstract: A student wielding a hunting knife stabbed four people Wednesday on the campus of the University of California, Merced, before he was shot by university police officers, law enforcement officials said.
lead_paragraph: A student wielding a hunting knife stabbed four people at the start of a class on Wednesday on the campus of the University of California, Merced, before he was shot and killed by university police officers, law enforcement officials said.

headline: Holocaust Film That Roiled Cannes Gets First DVD Release in Germany
keywords: ['Cannes International Film Festival', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Movies']
abstract: “Night and Fog,” which sparked an uproar when it was removed from the official Cannes lineup in 1956, is released in Germany on DVD for the first time.
lead_paragraph: “Night and Fog,” a 1955 Holocaust documentary that caused an uproar at the Cannes Film Festival in 1956, has been released for the first time on DVD in Germany.

headline: As Doors Close, Syrian Refugees Despair
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: Propelled by fear and desperation, Syrian refugees have faced one hurdle after another.
lead_paragraph: Propelled by fear and desperation, Syrian refugees have faced one hurdle after another.

headline: Yellen Speaks to Legislators
abstract: Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, told the House Financial Services Committee that the economy was “performing well” and suggested that the Fed could raise interest rates.
lead_paragraph: Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, told the House Financial Services Committee that the economy was “performing well” and suggested that the Fed could raise interest rates.

headline: Making a Picky Eater Project Last a Lifetime
abstract: 10 tips to turn a Picky Eater Project into long-lasting change.
lead_paragraph: Six weeks ago we started the Picky Eater Project, introducing a few key ideas we thought could change the eating preferences of Brooke, a sixth grader, and Hunter, a third grader, whose meal requirements (along with their parents Marlo and Corey’s willingness to cater to them) were taking over the family dinner hour.

headline: When a Photographer Is His Own Camera
abstract: Inside a converted delivery truck, Ian Ruhter manually creates stunning landscapes over the course of many hours.
lead_paragraph: For the photographer Ian Ruhter, whose first New York show opens tomorrow at Danziger Gallery, success has come from climbing into his work. “The game-changing moment came when I realized I could be the camera. I could be the mechanics of it,” Ruhter says. From inside the lens of a delivery truck converted into a camera, Ruhter becomes the machine’s very manual settings: the shutter and the processor, and also the “film,” which he makes from scratch on sheets of aluminum up to five feet wide. (Light-sensitive collodion plates, once wet, need to be exposed and developed in a matter of minutes, but the whole set-up takes about a day for a single image.) “It takes so much time,” he says, of choosing not to “jump out of a car and take a selfie” at a lookout. “It really makes me sit there and be part of the environment, and suck it up and enjoy.”

headline: One Downside of an Up Economy: Employee Turnover
abstract: As job options multiply, worker retention has risen to the top of the list of employers’ concerns. To many companies, “engagement” is the answer.
lead_paragraph: Most employees — no matter how many years they have been with a company or how much talent and hard work they bring to the table — feel disposable. And most employers do little to discourage that feeling.

headline: Graying Firms Wrestle With Making Room for Younger Lawyers
keywords: ['Legal Profession', 'Millennial Generation', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Baby Boomers']
abstract: The millennial generation is pushing up against current law firm leaders, many of whom are not in much of a mind to budge.
lead_paragraph: Even the law firms nimble enough to overcome the economic turbulence in recent years are not feeling invincible these days. The revenue looks good because costly litigation and specialized legal work are flourishing. But a generational divide is percolating just under the surface.

headline: Ted Cruz Has a Chance to Win. Here’s the Path.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: A victory in Iowa, which is plausible, could help him emerge as the sole leader of a conservative wing that is flexing its muscles this cycle.
lead_paragraph: When Ted Cruz announced his run for the presidency, the big question was whether he had only a small chance to win or no chance at all. Since then, a lot has gone right for him.

headline: Sylvie Guillem Prepares to End Her Ballet Career
abstract: The dancer is finishing up her nine-month around-the-world tour, which will include a stop in New York.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — “I am not nice,” the ballerina Sylvie Guillem said. Seated in her dressing room in the Teatro Arcimboldi here, Ms. Guillem burst out laughing. “That has gotten me into a lot of trouble.”

It had all the trappings of a Hollywood branding soiree, announced by a neon sign hovering overhead: “Welcome to the Rebelution.”

headline: Time Warner May Have Left Door Ajar for a Fox Return
abstract: Time Warner’s stock trades below the 2014 offer price from 21st Century Fox and at a discount to peers, making it vulnerable to a fresh takeover approach.
lead_paragraph: Time Warner may have left its henhouse gate open to Fox. Its chief executive, Jeffrey L. Bewkes, last year thwarted an $80 billion takeover bid from Rupert Murdoch’s rival media company with some bold projections. Mr. Bewkes is now backing down from those claims and could be vulnerable to a fresh approach.

headline: Activists May Be Less Myopic Than Their Reputation Suggests
abstract: While activists have been criticized for short-term “quarterly capitalism,” they may hold shares longer than many institutional or retail investors.
lead_paragraph: Are activist investors short-term traders or in it for the long term? It is the question of the moment as nearly $200 billion has poured into the coffers of activists with names like Icahn, Ackman and Peltz, among others. Last year, as a group they put some 200 companies in their cross hairs and replaced 19 chief executives, according to the law firm Sidley Austin, putting pressure on virtually every board in the country to pay attention to this vocal class of shareholders.

Asif Kapadia, the director of “Amy,” and James Gay-Rees, the producer, will be producers on the Oasis project, which doesn’t yet have a title or release date.

headline: Supreme Court Justices Fear Loss of Control Over Redistricting Cases

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At a Supreme Court  argument on Wednesday about procedures in redistricting cases, the justices appeared to be trying to reconcile two conflicting impulses. They did not want to close the door entirely on challenges to gerrymandering, but they also did not want to be required to rule on them.

headline: In Heat of August 1945, Mao and Chiang Met for the Last Time
abstract: In August 1945, Mao Zedong flew from his mountain redoubt in Yan’an to Chongqing, the headquarters of Chiang Kai-shek’s Nationalists and China’s sweltering wartime capital.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In August 1945, Mao Zedong flew from his mountain redoubt in Yan’an to Chongqing, the headquarters of Chiang Kai-shek’s Nationalists and China’s sweltering wartime capital. It was to be the last meeting between leaders of the Communists and the Nationalists, the rival factions then contending for control of China.

headline: Why Buffett’s Salad Oil Magic May Not Repeat for Ackman
abstract: It can be dangerous to compare current investment opportunities to home runs from the annals of business history.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Gramm is the author of the forthcoming book “Dear Chairman: Boardroom Battles and the Rise of Shareholder Activism” (HarperBusiness), which has a chapter about the Great Salad Oil Swindle. He is a hedge fund manager who teaches value investing at Columbia Business School.

lead_paragraph: Airline passengers were stranded at airports on the Indonesian island of Bali because of volcanic ash from the eruption of Mount Rinjani on the neighboring island of Lombok.

headline: Houellebecq’s Islam, Houellebecq’s West
abstract: Notes on the French novelist’s dystopia.
lead_paragraph: Like many people who pretend to parle a little francais but get tired after reading a page, I’ve only just now read the newly-translated “Submission,” Michel Houellebecq’s dystopian vision of a near-future French republic that succumbs willingly to a vaguely Tariq Ramadan-esque form of political Islam. When I say “dystopian,” the casual reader may infer — as many people did when the book first appeared, literally at the same moment as the “Charlie Hebdo” massacre — that the dystopia is the Islamicized France, that Houellebecq is trying to do for Islamism or “Eurabia” what Orwell once did for Stalinism. But if you’ve read the keener reviews (or Houellebecq’s previous novels) you probably understand that no, actually, the dystopia is the contemporary West, and the Islamified future that Houellebecq’s story ushers in is portrayed as a kind of civilizational step forward, or if you prefer a necessary regression back to health.

headline: Ryan McGinley’s Upstate New York
abstract: For his new shows, the artist braved the elements to capture otherworldly outdoor portraits. He shares images from the series, as well as his favorite haunts in the area.
lead_paragraph: Since 2004, Ryan McGinley has taken summer road trips across America with a gang of models — excursions that have yielded some of his best-known work. But his next two shows at Team Gallery (running semi-concurrently at both gallery locations in SoHo and Venice, Calif.), reveal a dramatic shift in thematic focus. Whereas McGinley’s road trip series resulted in youthful, sometimes forlorn-feeling images of nude forms set against the backdrop of landscapes that varied according to geographic location, this most recent collection of photographs was shot entirely in upstate New York.

lead_paragraph: Gusting into his ground floor studio on Walker Street in TriBeCa, William Ivey Long paused for an instant to point out a suite of artworks by his former friend and neighbor Louise Bourgeois, among them an eerie six-eyed figure traced somewhat tentatively in red over black.

headline: ‘Trumbo’ Recalls the Hunters and the Hunted of Hollywood
abstract: Jay Roach’s film recounts the ordeal of the screenwriter Dalton Trumbo, one of the “Hollywood 10” who defied the House Un-American Activities Committee in 1947.
lead_paragraph: James Dalton Trumbo, the storied screenwriter of “Spartacus” and “Roman Holiday,” would use many names. Pseudonyms were a necessity for Trumbo (1905-1976), one of the “Hollywood 10” who defied the House Un-American Activities Committee in 1947 during its witch hunt for Communists.

headline: Foo Fighters, Recruited by Viral Video, Play Unplanned Concert in Italy
abstract: More than 1,000 musicians had performed a cover of the band’s “Learn to Fly” in a video that gained millions of viewers.
lead_paragraph: To lure the Foo Fighters to his hometown, Cesena, in northern Italy, Fabio Zaffagnini organized 1,000 musicians to play one of their hit songs, recording a video that was widely shared online in July.

headline: Witness Describes Aftermath of Stabbings
abstract: A student described security response to the stabbing of five people on the campus of the University of California, Merced.
lead_paragraph: A student described security response to the stabbing of five people on the campus of the University of California, Merced.

headline: Groenlandia se desvanece entre ríos helados
abstract: Groenlandia se está derritiendo. Ahora, un grupo de científicos busca predecir que tan rápido subirán los niveles del mar.
lead_paragraph: Groenlandia se está derritiendo. Ahora, un grupo de científicos busca predecir que tan rápido subirán los niveles del mar.

headline: Senate Report Says Pentagon Paid Sports Leagues for Patriotic Events
abstract: A Senate report found that the Defense Department signed $6.8 million worth of contracts with teams from the N.F.L., Major League Baseball and other sports leagues that amounted to “paid-for patriotism.”
lead_paragraph: Ceremonial first pitches. Luxury box seats. An athlete’s airport greeting for a returning service member. And at least one appearance by the cheerleaders of the Indianapolis Colts.

headline: Expedia to Acquire HomeAway for $3.9 Billion
abstract: The company is adding the Airbnb rival to its travel-booking brands, which include Orbitz, Travelocity, Hotels.com, Hotwire and Trivago.
lead_paragraph: Expedia said it had agreed to acquire HomeAway, adding vacation rentals to its wide swath of online travel booking options.

headline: Review: ‘Killing a King,’ on the Murder That Claimed a Peace Process
abstract: Dan Ephron’s detailed account of the death of Yitzhak Rabin includes his assessment that it achieved the outcome the assassin intended.
lead_paragraph: When contemplating the history of Israel, it is tempting to dream in counterfactuals. It is also an almost certain formula for madness. The idea that Israel generates so many wistful what-ifs is itself a sign of the country’s fraught and fragile existence. No one would mourn what might have been if all of us could agree on what should be.

headline: Mercedes-Benz Recalls 126,000 Vehicles Over Problems With Airbags
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The automaker said airbags in 126,000 model-year 2008-10 vehicles might either inflate at improper times or not deploy during a crash.
lead_paragraph: Mercedes-Benz has joined the ranks of automakers troubled by airbag malfunctions, recalling about 126,000 vehicles in the United States, according to a report from the automaker posted this week on the website of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing: Russian Plane Crash, Houston, Facebook
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: For Performa, One Artist Stages a Debate — Among His Own Paintings
abstract: Wyatt Kahn’s Central Park puppet show features a rousing contemporary-art confab among versions of his works that have been brought to life.
lead_paragraph: One of the surprises on the lineup of this year’s Performa biennial, a self-reflexive puppet show by Wyatt Kahn, thrusts the artist — who identifies primarily as a painter rather than a performer — and his studio practice into the performance spotlight. “Her invitation came with carte blanche,” Kahn says, referring to the Performa director and curator RoseLee Goldberg. “So I pitched her a puppet show. I was thrilled when she said yes.”

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Review: John Pizzarelli and Jessica Molaskey, Feeling Deeply, at Café Carlyle
abstract: This couple’s show, “My Generation,” includes songs from Paul McCartney, Paul Simon and Billy Joel.
lead_paragraph: It was nearly 30 years ago that Paul Simon’s album “Graceland” introduced “The Boy in the Bubble,” a prescient song about our perilous, technologized world of “lasers in the jungle” and “the bomb in the baby carriage” with a fragmented expression of apocalyptic dread that still feels remarkably contemporary. And to hear Jessica Molaskey perform it on Tuesday evening with her husband, John Pizzarelli, on guitar at Café Carlyle was to be brought up short by the song’s telegraphic sense of alarm. Just like that bomb, the images explode in your mind.

headline: Doctor at Sheldon Silver Trial Tells of Elaborate Arrangement, Years in Making
abstract: A plan involving mesothelioma patients’ being referred to a law firm, the heart of the corruption case against Mr. Silver, came into focus as Dr. Robert N. Taub of Columbia University testified.
lead_paragraph: In New York’s ornate Capitol building in Albany, a plan two years in the making was taking root. Everyone would benefit: Victims of mesothelioma, a rare but deadly form of cancer caused by exposure to asbestos, would be sent to a reputable law firm; the firm would pick up new clients; and a well-regarded cancer research clinic would receive funds.

headline: ‘Defensive Medicine’ May Lower Malpractice Risks
abstract: Doctors who ordered the most tests were least likely to be sued by patients.
lead_paragraph: Some doctors practice “defensive medicine,” ordering extra tests and procedures believing this will ward off malpractice suits. A new study suggests that it does.

headline: Putting the Cool in Cool-Weather Style
abstract: Parkas, boots, sweaters and gloves to help you take the perfect “weekend upstate” selfie.
lead_paragraph: Parkas, boots, sweaters and gloves to help you take the perfect “weekend upstate” selfie.

headline: U.S. Offers Account to Encourage Retirement Saving
abstract: MyRA is aimed at people who have no retirement plan at work and lets them have money deducted from their paychecks or make electronic transfers.
lead_paragraph: After an extended test period, the federal government is widely promoting its new savings plan called myRA, which is aimed at people who do not have a retirement plan at work.

headline: Quintessential Britain, Accessories and Other Shopping Events
abstract: Plus: Del Toro’s concept shop, a holiday pop-up from Cuyana, Hike Nike NYC, and sample sales from Adam Lippes and Thakoon.
lead_paragraph: Cheerio! From Thursday to Sunday, 20 British companies will celebrate home on Madison Avenue with quintessentially British in-store programming. At Jimmy Choo, you can sip tea in Wedgwood china while shopping for glamorous footwear like the Dolly 100 silver glitter pump with fox-fur pompoms ($995), while Anya Hindmarch will offer free embossing on bespoke purchases, including keepsake boxes ($510 for a large size). Jimmy Choo is at 716 Madison Avenue; Anya Hindmarch is at 795 Madison Avenue.

headline: Indian Muslim, Accused of Stealing a Cow, Is Beaten to Death by a Hindu Mob
keywords: ['Hinduism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Cattle']
abstract: It was the fourth time in six weeks that Hindus had killed Muslims they suspected of slaughtering, stealing or smuggling cows, which are seen as revered religious symbols.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Amid a politically charged national debate over religious intolerance, a Muslim man was beaten to death on Monday by a mob of Hindus who suspected him of stealing a cow, a revered symbol in the Hindu religion. It was the fourth time in six weeks that Hindus had killed Muslims they suspected of slaughtering, stealing or smuggling cows.

headline: Donald Trump Is Said to Have Reached Out to the Megadonor Sheldon Adelson
abstract: This summer, Mr. Trump called Mr. Adelson, who spent more than $20 million backing Newt Gingrich’s presidential campaign in 2012, to talk about the state of the race, according to a person told of the discussion.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has mockingly accused Sheldon Adelson, a casino developer and one of the biggest Republican megadonors, of wanting a “puppet” to back when it was reported that Mr. Adelson was considering throwing his support to Senator Marco Rubio.

headline: Charles Herbert, Mid-Century Child Star on TV and in Movies, Dies at 66
abstract: Mr. Herbert, a top earner in his youth, appeared in more than 20 films (including “The Fly” and “Houseboat”) and 50 television episodes (including “The Twilight Zone”).
lead_paragraph: Charles Herbert, who was 4 years old when he was discovered by a Hollywood talent scout on a bus while out shopping with his mother and went on to become a top-earning child actor of the 1950s and ’60s, died on Oct. 31 in Las Vegas. He was 66.

headline: Actors Studio to Stage Play by María Irene Fornés
abstract: Starting Thursday, the Actors Studio will have free performances of “Mud,” by the Cuban playwright María Irene Fornés.
lead_paragraph: The Actors Studio in New York City will stage a half dozen free performances of “Mud,” a provocative play by the Cuban-born American playwright and director María Irene Fornés that deals with such themes as illiteracy, hunger and poverty, the non-profit organization announced Wednesday.

headline: Buffalo’s Next Top Start-Ups
abstract: The 43North business idea contest, which recently held its second annual competition, is America’s largest, with $5 million in total prize money.
lead_paragraph: The 43North business idea contest, which recently held its second annual competition, is America’s largest, with $5 million in total prize money.

headline: Buffalo Entices Start-Ups to Relocate With $5 Million Contest
keywords: ['Entrepreneurship', 'Contests and Prizes', 'Venture Capital', 'Relocation of Business', 'Grants (Corporate and Foundation)']
abstract: Buffalo is one of a number of struggling cities and regions experimenting with prize contests to draw entrepreneurs, although the question of their effectiveness remains unanswered.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — Until two weeks ago, Ace Callwood had never set foot in this chilly, postindustrial city, but he committed, sight unseen, to move his fledgling technology business and its four employees here. The lure that drew him was cash: a guaranteed investment of at least $250,000 and a shot at as much as $1 million.

headline: Bitcoin Basics
abstract: Bitcoin is both a virtual currency and an online payment system, one that some people believe will transform the global financial system.
lead_paragraph: Bitcoin is both a virtual currency and an online payment system — one that some people believe will transform the global financial system. But the details of this new technology have remained a mystery to most.

headline: Brett Gardner’s Wrist Injury Led to Drop-Off, Coach Says
abstract: The Yankees’ new hitting coach, Alan Cockrell, said Gardner battled a wrist injury for a significant part of the season after being hit by a pitch.
lead_paragraph: When the Yankees were shut out by the Houston Astros in the American League wild-card game, the crowd at Yankee Stadium saved its most vociferous boos for one of its favorite players, Brett Gardner, the Yankees’ only homegrown starter.

headline: Highway Bill Debate Tests Paul Ryan’s Promise for a More Open House
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Law and Legislation', 'Bridges and Tunnels']
abstract: Representatives debating a $325 billion bill funding highways and transportation infrastructure proposed more amendments than in recent years — except on how to pay for programs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Vicky Hartzler, Republican of Missouri, wanted an amendment that would prohibit the use of federal highway money for “landscaping and beautification.”

headline: Iran President Pushes Back Over Anti-U.S. Crackdown
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'United States International Relations', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: President Hassan Rouhani suggested that at least some of the arrests made by Revolutionary Guards agents on sedition accusations were groundless.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — President Hassan Rouhani of Iran on Wednesday criticized the recent arrests of journalists and others by the Revolutionary Guard Corps, which has accused detainees of being part of seditious plots hatched by the United States.

headline: Thursday’s Matchup: Browns (2-6) at Bengals (7-0)
abstract: The only thing standing between Cincinnati and an 8-0 start is a matchup against Cleveland on Thursday, but given the Browns’ tough start and rash of injuries, the team does not appear to present much of a challenge.
lead_paragraph: 8:25 p.m. Eastern, NFL Network

headline: State Dept. Denies Request for Delay on Pipeline Review
abstract: The State Department on Wednesday notified TransCanada, the company seeking to build the Keystone XL oil pipeline, that it would not grant a request to suspend its review of the project.
lead_paragraph: The State Department on Wednesday notified TransCanada, the company seeking to build the Keystone XL oil pipeline, that it would not grant a request to suspend its review of the project. “A lot of work has gone into this to date, and the secretary wants that work to continue,” John Kirby, the department spokesman, said, referring to Secretary of State John Kerry. In a letter to Mr. Kerry, TransCanada said a delay would allow time for a review by Nebraska. Environmental groups said the request is a bid to avert President Obama’s expected rejection of the pipeline. TransCanada said on Wednesday that it respected the State Department’s decision and would continue pressing to show that the pipeline is “in the national interest of the United States.”

headline: Bitcoin Surges, Emerging From a Lull in Interest
abstract: Despite its use for illegal activities, Bitcoin is being closely studied by conventional banks and financial firms. The online currency has rallied over 100 percent in the last month.
lead_paragraph: After a long period of quiet, the price of the virtual currency Bitcoin is surging again as signs of interest from China and Wall Street have helped kick off a new speculative frenzy.

headline: Officials Debate Whether ‘Ferguson Effect’ Is Real
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: Chuck Rosenberg, the acting chief of the D.E.A., waded into the question of whether the police have become more reluctant to confront suspicious people.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A rift widened Wednesday within the Obama administration over the politically charged question of whether a surge in crime in some cities reflects the reluctance of the police to confront suspicious people because of increased public scrutiny of their behavior.

headline: In Houston, Hate Trumped Fairness
abstract: Fearmongering and demagogy derailed a sensible equal rights ordinance that would have protected gay and transgender residents.
lead_paragraph: Sometime in the near future, a transgender teenager in Texas will attempt suicide — and maybe succeed — because vilifying people for their gender identity remains politically acceptable in America.

headline: Suicide of a Dishonest Officer
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: Sometimes bad people simply do bad things. Not everything in real life fits neatly into a narrative.
lead_paragraph: There is no way to fully process the betrayal by Charles Joseph Gliniewicz, a police lieutenant in Illinois who an investigator said Wednesday had committed a “carefully staged suicide” after years of stealing money from a local youth group that he ran.

headline: Cavaliers, Taking Cue From LeBron James’s Sleeves, Go on Tear to Beat Knicks
abstract: James, frustrated in the first half, tore the sleeves of his jersey, and he finished with 23 points to help Cleveland rally past Carmelo Anthony and the Knicks.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Carmelo Anthony and LeBron James go way back. They knew each other in high school. They entered the N.B.A. together as lottery picks in 2003. They became friends.

headline: Ex-Prosecutor Details Robert Durst Case in New Book, but Some Fear It Could Aid Defense
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: In “He Killed Them All,” Jeanine Pirro, a former Westchester County district attorney, describes her pursuit of justice in the Durst case, but details in the account have faced questions.
lead_paragraph: Just when the story of Robert A. Durst, the New York real estate scion who is a suspect in two murders, could not get any stranger, a new book arrives from a former Westchester County district attorney, Jeanine Pirro, describing her quest for justice in his case.

headline: Airbnb and Uber Mobilize Vast User Base to Sway Policy
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Mobile Applications', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: Leading companies in the sharing economy, like Airbnb and Uber, are turning their millions of users into an enormous political operation to fight back against unfavorable policies.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Over the last few years, so-called sharing companies like Airbnb and Uber — online platforms that allow strangers to pay one another for a room or a ride — have established footholds in thousands of communities well before local regulators have figured out how to deal with them.

headline: Highlights From the Trial of Sheldon Silver
abstract: Sheldon Silver, an assemblyman who rose from the Lower East Side of Manhattan to become one of New York State’s most powerful politicians, was found guilty on Monday in a federal corruption trial.
lead_paragraph: Sheldon Silver, an assemblyman who rose from the Lower East Side of Manhattan to become one of New York State’s most powerful politicians, was found guilty on Monday in a federal corruption trial.

headline: Trump ‘SNL’ Petitions Arrive at 30 Rock
abstract: Petitions from Latino and immigration groups calling on NBC to drop Donald J. Trump as the “Saturday Night Live” host this week were delivered to its offices.
lead_paragraph: Petitions from Latino and immigration groups calling on NBC to drop Donald J. Trump as the “Saturday Night Live” host this week were delivered to its offices.

headline: Donald Trump’s Scheduled Appearance on ‘Saturday Night Live’ Draws Protest
abstract: In an event organized by the League of United Latin American Citizens, about two dozen protesters demanded that NBC rescind an invitation that Mr. Trump had accepted to host the show this week.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has appeared unconcerned with the possibility of angering Latinos since declaring during the announcement of his presidential campaign in June that Mexico was sending rapists to the United States.

headline: Memphis Is Powerful. The Problem: Its League Isn’t.
abstract: The rules of the college football playoff system lend an advantage to schools in the five power conferences.
lead_paragraph: Three tigers enter a room before the evening circus. They appear equally fierce. Two are sent to the big tent. The third? His pedigree is called into question, and he is sent off to a sideshow.

headline: Puerto Rico’s Debt Crisis and the 1975 Law Complicating Matters
abstract: The Tower Amendment, a law passed to ease a constitutional dispute in 1975, has made solving Puerto Rico’s debt crisis even more difficult.
lead_paragraph: To appreciate why it is proving so hard for Washington to help debt-burdened Puerto Rico, it helps to go back to 1975, the year New York City went broke, and consider the role played in that crisis by a prominent Republican senator from Texas named John Tower.

headline: N.F.L. Says Teams Will Have to Return Improper Military Payments
keywords: ['Football', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: In a letter to Sen. John McCain and Sen. Jeff Flake, Commissioner Roger Goodell said that the N.F.L. was conducting an audit of all contracts between the league’s 32 teams and various branches of the military.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. said that any of its teams found to have been paid by a branch of the military for promotional purposes would have to return the money.

headline: Budget Could Be the Last of the Big Deals for President Obama
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Federal Taxes (US)']
abstract: The truce with Republicans in Congress will do little to change the way Washington functions or to enhance the president’s legacy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama and Republicans in Congress are enjoying a rare season of peace and productivity, eschewing debt defaults, government shutdowns and budgetary brinkmanship as they move long-stalled legislation. But for the White House, the suspension of dysfunction has a darker side: the demise of dreams.

headline: Charges for 2 Connecticut Students Said to Have Dressed Like Columbine Killers
abstract: Two Litchfield High School students were arrested on Wednesday after they were said to have worn costumes and threatened to harm other students.
lead_paragraph: Two high school students in western Connecticut were arrested on Wednesday after they were said to have worn Halloween costumes that looked like the gunmen responsible for the Columbine mass killings in 1999 and threatened to harm other students, the authorities said.

headline: Divine Being
abstract: Samuel A. Donaldson summons a divine being.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — When you’re solving a themed crossword, how long would you say it takes you to “guess” or solve the theme before you finish the puzzle? I see many comments from people who claim not to see themes, and it seems to me that these solvers are missing some of the fun of deciphering a crossword puzzle.

headline: ‘Empire’ Season 2, Episode 6: ‘A High Hope for a Low Heaven’
abstract: Lyon Dynasty faces attacks from outsiders while Andre weakens Empire from within.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday’s “Empire,” a kidnapping mystery was resolved almost as quickly as it unfurled. Hakeem got snatched by three gang members with matching longhorn back tattoos, but they only held him for an afternoon and asked for a modest $40,000 ransom for his safe return. The ordeal leaves the youngest Lyon shaken, and a smack from the butt of a gun renders him temporarily hearing-impaired and unable to perform. Hakeem’s unearned bravado frequently makes him insufferable, so the vulnerability he radiates throughout the crisis and its aftermath is rewarding, whetever the cost, though he still manages to treat his family poorly throughout.

headline: San Francisco’s First Female Sheriff Plans to Improve Ties in Criminal Justice System
abstract: Vicki Hennessy, who will succeed a sheriff known for his scandals, said she would take a more inclusive approach in working with federal immigration officials.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — San Francisco elected its first female sheriff on Tuesday: Vicki Hennessy, a city native who pledged to work with the whole criminal justice system — including the police, the district attorney’s office and federal immigration officials — to build better relationships.

headline: One Is Dead After Plane Crashes Off Queens Coast
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: An eyewitness called 911 around 8 p.m. and reported seeing an aircraft go down in the water near the western tip of the Rockaway Peninsula.
lead_paragraph: Search crews found the body of a man amid the debris from a small plane that crashed off the coast of the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens on Wednesday night, the authorities said.

headline: Official Cites Past Arrests for Driver in Fatal Brooklyn Bus Crash
abstract: The driver, Paul Roper, 48, appeared in court on Wednesday to face charges of leaving the scene of an accident, a felony, among lesser counts.
lead_paragraph: The bus driver with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority who was charged in connection with a crash that killed a 70-year-old woman on Tuesday in Brooklyn had been arrested three times over the last decade, a law enforcement official said.

headline: Brooklyn Man, 35, Is Fatally Shot in His Building’s Hallway
abstract: The girlfriend of Hector Diaz, who had previously chased away intruders, said he went downstairs to check out a noise when she heard a gunshot.
lead_paragraph: A Brooklyn man died on Wednesday after he was shot in the head in the hallway of his apartment building, the police said.

headline: Kentucky’s Next Governor, Matt Bevin, Rode In on Outsider Status
abstract: Now that Matt Bevin, a Republican who has said he is “not beholden to any party per se,” is the governor-elect of Kentucky, members of both parties wonder what sort of leader he will be.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE — Matt Bevin, Kentucky’s new Republican governor-elect, likes to catch his opponents off guard. So on a Friday in September, while driving by the state Democratic Party headquarters — where a sign declared “We Can’t Trust Matt Bevin” — he decided, spur-of-the-moment, to pop in.

headline: Thomas Gilbert Jr. Is Fit for Trial in Wealthy Father’s Death, Psychologist Says
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Although two court-appointed psychiatrists have found Mr. Gilbert too mentally ill to be tried on murder charges, a forensic psychologist reached a starkly different conclusion.
lead_paragraph: Although two court-appointed psychiatrists have found Thomas Gilbert Jr. too mentally ill to be tried on charges he killed his wealthy father, a forensic psychologist hired by the Manhattan district attorney’s office said in court on Wednesday that he had reached a starkly different conclusion.

headline: Elder Bush Says His Son Was Served Badly by Aides
abstract: President George Bush’s biography gives voice to sentiments many suspected he has privately harbored for years.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After years of holding back, former President George Bush has finally broken his public silence about some of the key figures in his son’s administration, issuing scathing critiques of Vice President Dick Cheney and Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld.

headline: M.L.B. Decision on Nationals’ Rights Fees Is Overturned
abstract: A New York State Supreme Court judge said a committee’s decision to award the franchise five years of annual rights fees from a regional network had been compromised by a conflict of interest.
lead_paragraph: A Major League Baseball committee’s decision to award the Washington Nationals five years of annual rights fees from the Mid-Atlantic Sports Network, which would have peaked at about $66 million in 2016, was thrown out Wednesday by a New York State Supreme Court judge.

headline: CUNY Faculty Members Arrested After Staging Protest
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: As part of a demand for salary increases, the City University of New York faculty members blocked the entrance to the Midtown Manhattan building housing the administration’s offices.
lead_paragraph: Several dozen City University of New York faculty members were arrested on Wednesday when they blocked the entrance to the Midtown Manhattan building housing the administration’s offices as part of a demand for salary increases.

headline: Protesters to NBC: Dump Trump
abstract: Demonstrators outside NBC’s headquarters in New York asked the network to cancel Donald Trump's appearance on “Saturday Night Live” this weekend.
lead_paragraph: Demonstrators outside NBC’s headquarters in New York asked the network to cancel Donald Trump's appearance on “Saturday Night Live” this weekend.

headline: A Love for Music and Singing, Undiminished by Parkinson’s
abstract: Early retirement because of Parkinson’s disease drastically changed Jorge Escalante’s financial situation, but his singing has not been silenced.
lead_paragraph: Songs by scores of popular musicians — Jethro Tull, the Rolling Stones and Queen, most notably — streamed from the radio in Jorge Escalante’s childhood home in San Juan de Miraflores, Peru. Although the lyrics were foreign and incomprehensible, he was besotted by the music.

headline: Worries of Market Chill at Sotheby’s Auction of Ex-Chief’s Collection
abstract: The auction brought $377 million with fees, just squeaking past the $375 million low estimate. The art world was looking to the Sotheby’s sale as an important test of the overall market.
lead_paragraph: The stakes were higher than ever at Sotheby’s on Wednesday night, marking the start of a fall season of global art buying as well as one of the biggest gambles for the auction house, which had put $500 million behind a sale of A. Alfred Taubman’s collection.

headline: What to Watch Thursday
abstract: Amazon’s pilot season, a Mexican crooner in hot water, and Stephen Colbert takes on the Norwegian writer Karl Ove Knausgaard.
lead_paragraph: Election Day was Tuesday, you say, viewers? Not at Amazon Video, where you can help decide which pilots to develop without the agony of watching debates. Those who’d rather not exercise their streaming rights can partake of the mayhem known as “Larrymania” or navel gaze with the Norwegian writer Karl Ove Knausgaard.

headline: Death Among Middle-Aged Whites
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Alcohol Abuse', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'United States Economy', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: The health and financial implications are disturbing for America’s “lost generation.”
lead_paragraph: Two Princeton economists startled other Americans — and themselves — when they uncovered a trend that had escaped the medical and scientific world: Between 1999 and 2013, white middle-aged men and women in the United States, especially those with only a high school education, began dying at a sharply increased rate, largely a result of problems with legal and illegal drugs, alcohol-related liver disease and suicide. The health and financial implications are disturbing for the country, and for what the two economists called a “lost generation.”

headline: Teachers for the Needy
abstract: The Woodrow Wilson Foundation writes, “Exemplary teachers can help students overcome the disadvantages they face as a result of family income.”

headline: Democrats Undermine Efforts to Protect Retirement Savers
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Retirement', 'Individual Retirement Accounts', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Financial Brokers']
abstract: Americans need protection from advisers who steer them into high-priced products and strategies.
lead_paragraph: Forty-seven House Democrats are threatening to derail the  Obama administration’s effort  to protect Americans from retirement advisers who put their own interest in earning commissions above their clients’ need for expert advice.

headline: Why America Invented Ahmad Chalabi
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: He enabled Washington to sustain a fantasy future for Iraq.
lead_paragraph: WITH his death, the Iraqi politician Ahmad Chalabi is once again in the news. Detractors rage about his supply of fabricated intelligence on Iraqi weapons of mass destruction that supposedly tricked Washington into war. Supporters claim he was a heroic dissident who was never given the chance to transform his troubled country into paradise.

headline: What We Owe the MythBusters
abstract: The hit TV show, ending a 14-season run next year, transformed the way Americans view science and engineering. We’ll miss it.
lead_paragraph: WHEN the reality TV show “MythBusters” debuted on the Discovery Channel in 2003, its producers weren’t on a mission to transform science and education in America. They just wanted to entertain. In each episode, the hosts would try to debunk or confirm a few classic urban legends. Could a penny dropped off the Empire State Building really kill a person? Could eating a poppy-seed bagel actually make you test positive for heroin? The producers cast two San Francisco-based special-effects artists, Jamie Hyneman and Adam Savage, as hosts. The show was a surprise hit — pulling in as many as 20 million viewers a season — and it helped changed our culture.

headline: Drugs, Greed and a Dead Boy
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Books and Literature', 'Children and Childhood', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']

lead_paragraph: Andrew Francesco was a rambunctious, athletic and joyful child, but also a handful. When he was 5 years old, a psychiatrist prescribed Ritalin. As he grew older, he disrupted classes and was given a growing number of potent antipsychotic and other medications.

headline: What My Mother Wanted Us to Pack
abstract: She left her daughters five suitcases, and a final, unspoken, piece of advice.
lead_paragraph: After our mother died last year at age 91, my four sisters and I gathered to clear out her apartment. We didn’t imagine the work would be onerous, since our mother — a modest, orderly person determined never to be a burden to her kids — had consciously downsized over the years as she and my father moved from their suburban home to a three-bedroom condo and then to a small apartment in a “senior residence.”

headline: Alabama Is Rolling in Cash, With Tide Lifting All Boats
abstract: Over the past decade, the success of Alabama’s football program has become a powerful engine for the university’s economic and academic growth.
lead_paragraph: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — Bill Battle is near the 30-yard line with his fellow alumni, gripping hands and flashing a lighthouse smile, reassuring one and all that all is right in the University of Alabama athletics department, which he runs. Near the edge of the field, Molly Brautigan and fellow sorority sisters laugh and plot their postgame festivities.

headline: Should Prostitution Be Legal?
abstract: Does legalizing prostitution make women less vulnerable to abuse by criminals? Or, will decriminalization lead to higher rates of human trafficking without solving the issues of abuse and exploitation?
lead_paragraph: This summer Amnesty International passed a resolution supporting the decriminalization of sex work. The organization decided that decriminalization is the best way to defend sex workers’ human rights and lessen the risk of abuse they face. But will making prostitution legal only increase the demand for sex workers, without actually protecting them from the violent abuse and exploitation that is common in the industry?

headline: Before, During and After: Strategies From Our News Q’s Feature for Reading Nonfiction

lead_paragraph: Every weekday on this blog we take an important or interesting news or feature story from the week and turn it into what we call News Q’s — a quick series of questions and activities designed to help students both understand the story and connect it to their own lives.
