headline: How to Help
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Children and Childhood', 'Philanthropy']
abstract: A list of organizations that provide aid to refugee children like Hana, Oleg and Chuol.
lead_paragraph: Every day in 2014, an average of 42,500 people left their homes looking for protection and safety elsewhere, and the number of refugees in the world has quadrupled in the past five years, to close to 60 million. More than 50 percent of those refugees are children, the highest figure for child refugees in more than a decade. Chuol, Hana and Oleg — the children featured in the New York Times Magazine article “The Displaced” — are three young refugees who were forced to leave everything behind because of violence, conflict and persecution.

headline: The Displaced: Oleg
abstract: At 11, he is living in the ruins of his former life.
lead_paragraph: Oleg Teryokhin was living with his mother and father in Nikishino, a rural village of fewer than 1,000 coal miners, farmers and their families in eastern Ukraine, when fighting broke out in April 2014. Hastily formed separatist militias, goaded and armed by Moscow, rose up in a rebellion against a new, pro-Western government in Kiev. In the first months of the conflict, the fighting was far from Nikishino, and Oleg, then 10, spent the early summer tearing about the village on his bicycle, zipping past its old brick cottages and apricot orchards. Then, in July, scorched scraps of clothing and bits of paper with foreign writing blew through the village — debris from the crash of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, the passenger jet that was shot down, killing hundreds of people whose bodies lay in fields just south of the village. When Oleg carried some of these items home, his mother, Galina, was horrified that the conflict had come so close.

headline: The Displaced: Chuol
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: At 9, without his parents, he was forced to flee to the swamps.
lead_paragraph: Chuol was only 5 in 2011, the year South Sudan, after decades of war, became the world’s newest nation. He was living with his parents, grandparents and other relatives in a village near the city of Leer, not yet old enough to understand the hope and joy sweeping through the small East African country.

headline: The Displaced: Introduction
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Children and Childhood', 'Virtual Reality (Computers)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder']
abstract: Nearly 60 million people are currently displaced from their homes by war and persecution — more than at any time since World War II. Half are children. This multimedia journey in text, photographs and virtual reality tells the stories of three of them.
lead_paragraph: I have two photos on my desk. The first shows a child, a girl of about 10. She is standing behind an enormous pile of her family’s belongings, which have been tightly packed for a long journey. Her face is blank with uncertainty, but she strikes a bossy pose — one hand on her hip, the other planted firmly against the bundles. Her companions are an older woman, probably her mother, and a little boy — her younger brother? Both look directly at the photographer, Henri Cartier-Bresson, who took this picture in Dessau, as scores of Germans displaced during World War II began returning home. It is 1945. Where has this girl been, and what has she seen?

headline: The Displaced: Hana
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: At 12, she has lived one-quarter of her life in a debilitating state of suspension as a Syrian refugee in Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: At 4:45 in the morning on a Saturday in early August, stars were still bright in the sky above a refugee settlement in rural Lebanon where Hana Abdullah, a 12-year-old girl from Syria, now lives. The morning call to prayer floated down a dusty road and wound its way around the mostly silent tents. At 5 o’clock, Hana was still sleeping on her bamboo mat by the edge of her family’s tent, her arms folded, her hands under her head. Her baby brother and three of her four sisters slept nearby. Many mornings Hana was up at 4 o’clock. She worked in the nearby fields of Lebanon’s Bekaa Valley, picking fruits or vegetables, and everyone started early. But today the truck that would take her there was late. Now came its familiar rumble, next the crunching of gravel: She stirred, her mouth twitched, her eyelids fluttered. Then she was up, vertical in one swift movement, stretching, pulling on a hat from a stash of her belongings. She grabbed lunch — a tomato, and a pita she folded around a potato — and ducked outside to wait on one of the benches in front of her tent.

headline: Virtual Reality: A New Way to Tell Stories
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Magazines', 'Virtual Reality (Computers)']
abstract: Until now, virtual reality has been seen mostly as a revolutionary new platform for video games. But it has the potential to transform journalism as well.
lead_paragraph: One hundred nineteen years ago, the inaugural issue of this magazine published the first photographs ever to appear in The New York Times, beginning on the cover with three small halftone images of the former presidential candidates Stephen Douglas, John Bell and John Breckinridge. Elsewhere in the magazine, readers found images of X-rays, then a nascent technology, showing a hand and a foot. Now, more than 6,000 Sundays later, the magazine is proud to introduce another visual innovation: In conjunction with this week’s cover story on the global refugee crisis, we are unveiling The New York Times’s first contribution to the new field of virtual-­reality journalism.

lead_paragraph: When The Huffington Post put up a Facebook video on Friday of Gov. Chris Christie speaking about his mother’s addiction to cigarettes and his friend’s death from addiction, it wasn’t with the expectancy that it would become one of the most watched videos on its Facebook account. Mr. Christie, of New Jersey, has been talking about drug overhaul since 2010, and he frequently touches on the subject on the campaign trail, as have other candidates, like Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Review: In ‘Spectre,’ Daniel Craig Is Back as James Bond, No Surprise
abstract: There’s nothing unexpected in Spectre, the 24th “official” title in the series, which is presumably as planned.
lead_paragraph: Does it mean something that James Bond drinks a dirty martini in “Spectre,” the latest in the seemingly unkillable franchise? It’s too soon to know, though true Bondologists will be parsing this new drink’s significance shortly. As more of an amateur in all-things Bond, I had hoped a dirty bomb would go boom or that the actress Léa Seydoux would do something unspeakable to Daniel Craig, given that the pre-credit sequence features female nudes writhing alongside an octopus with busy arms. Part of the bankable pleasure of the series, after all, is that every so often, among the usual guns and girls, the unexpected happens — a bikini stops the film, a villain revs it up, Bond surprises.

headline: An Arts Explosion Takes Shanghai
abstract: Museums and galleries are turning the once-industrial West Bund into a cultural hub.
lead_paragraph: In Shanghai, the historic Bund grabs much of the spotlight — the stretch of former banks and trading houses along the Huangpu River, built a century ago in a kaleidoscope of architectural styles, is a monument to the grandeur of another era. It can also be downright suffocating on weekends, with tourists jostling for selfie positions.

headline: Equality, Then What? New Plays Explore Modern Gay Life
abstract: Several works explore topics concerning domesticity rather than the fight for marriage and other rights.
lead_paragraph: In 2011, when the New York State Legislature announced the passage of a marriage equality bill, Mark Gerrard and his partner, Tom Broecker, raced to celebrate outside the Stonewall Inn. In the middle of the laughter and the merriment and the dancing, Mr. Gerrard recalled a moment of uncertainty. “So now we’re supposed to get married?” he thought. “Now we’re supposed to want to get married?”

headline: From Army of One to Band of Tweeters
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Social Media', 'Iraq War (2003-11)']
abstract: Social media’s hold on soldiers’ attention is damaging the combat cohesion needed in battle.
lead_paragraph: IT was the end of a long combat patrol near a district called Adhamiyah, in northwest Baghdad, in the fall of 2008. It started like most daily missions but ended with a hidden enemy throwing a grenade at a vehicle convoy, missing it but hitting a young Iraqi child instead. As the company commander, I met the soldiers at the site and after a few hours followed them back to our base. I left the men, went to stow my equipment and brief other officers.

headline: ISIS Claims It Struck Police in Bangladesh

headline: A Post-Peronist President at Last?
abstract: The coming runoff in Argentina’s presidential election finds the nation in a mood for change.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — The last time Argentina was scheduled to hold a presidential runoff election was 12 years ago. That occasion was very unusual in that the winning candidate, intimidated by the thin margin of his victory, decided to quit the field. Rather than risk losing in the second round of voting, he chose to step down, leaving the presidency to the candidate who had been the runner-up in the first round.

headline: Twenty Designers on the Art That Inspires Them

For a new sale on the site Paddle8, 20 American designers — including Michael Kors, Thom Browne, Francisco Costa and Diane von Furstenberg — have each picked one piece of art that has influenced their work; the proceeds of the sale will go to benefit the CFDA and its programs. (The Alice + Olivia designer Stacey Bendet Eisner has even donated a Francesco Clemente painting.) Click through the slide show here to see the work that inspires each designer — and why.

headline: Video Review: Cadillac’s ATS-V, a Socially Refined Muscle Car
abstract: As capable as Mercedes-Benz AMG and BMW M cars, ATS-V is letter-perfect in its driving dynamics. Now, if Cadillac can get enthusiasts to understand that.
lead_paragraph: LETTERS can be so meaningful. M affixed to a BMW or AMG on a Mercedes-Benz seduces performance enthusiasts. The V, found on Cadillac, is the last of them alphabetically but possibly Speed Racer’s first consonant of choice. Seriously. The ATS-V sedan and coupe, built to take on C63, M3 and M4, is the real deal for taming tarmac. If only Cadillac had street cred.

headline: A Picturesque Destination With a Grisly Past

headline: Stephen Curry’s Champion Warriors Pick Up Where They Left Off

lead_paragraph: In a showdown of unbeatens, the Warriors improved to 5-0, beating the Clippers, 112-108, Wednesday night. Draymond Green is hitting some 3s and Festus Ezeli is blocking some shots, but Golden State’s fast start is mostly due to superhuman performances by Stephen Curry.

headline: Aung San Suu Kyi Seems to Have Myanmar’s Countryside in Her Corner
abstract: As the Burmese prepare to vote in parliamentary elections on Sunday, the ruling party’s efforts to win over the people appear to have come up short.
lead_paragraph: KWUN CHAN KONE, Myanmar — This village at the end of a long, bumpy dirt road in the Irrawaddy Delta would seem a natural stronghold for the former generals who rule Myanmar.

headline: A Brief Guide to Myanmar’s Elections
abstract: What are the prospects for Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, and how much control does the military retain?
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, more than 30 million voters across Myanmar can cast their ballots in the country’s first relatively free elections in 25 years. The nationwide vote is a milestone in the Southeast Asian nation’s transformation from isolated military dictatorship to a more open society, seeking to attract foreign investment and tourists.

headline: Expedia Expands Into Airbnb’s Market With HomeAway Deal
abstract: HomeAway lacks the urban clout of its better-known rival, but moving in with its new parent will help.
lead_paragraph: Expedia has found a back door into Airbnb’s home turf.

headline: New Inductees at Toy Hall of Fame Join the Ball, the Box and the Barbie Doll

lead_paragraph: Shane Rhinewald tells people he works in a history museum.

headline: Resistance to Authority in Greece as Pessimism Takes Hold
abstract: Greeks no longer believe, if they ever did, in the functionality of politics, the mayor of Athens said.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Yiorgos Kaminis has the privilege and misfortune of being the mayor of Athens, the suffering heart of bankrupt Greece, marked by both the majesty of the Parthenon and a relentless wave of graffiti hooligans, whose work he does not have the money to scrape off.

headline: A Wrong Turn for Guatemalan Democracy
abstract: After six months of protests, the country has a new president. But is it on a path toward real reform?
lead_paragraph: Haverford, Pa. — GIVEN how dramatic Guatemala’s politics have been of late, it’s fitting that an actor, Jimmy Morales, would cruise to victory over a former first lady, Sandra Torres, in last week’s presidential elections.

headline: 1915: Spurious Night Clubs to Close
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Shady night clubs are given their notice in 1915.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The doom of the many spurious night clubs, which have become very numerous in London and other English cities, is now practically sealed. These clubs have been the cause of a succession of scandals, and Lord Curzon, moving the second reading of the Night Clubs Bill in the House of Lords yesterday, said that officers have, in some instances, been drugged and afterwards blackmailed in these resorts. ‘‘The Night Clubs Bill,’’ he said, ‘‘is designed to put an end to a great scandal — namely, the rapid and unarrested growth of what are commonly called night clubs, which are really haunts of temptation and dens of iniquity.’’ — The New York Herald, European Edition, November 6, 1915

headline: What to Do This Weekend
abstract: Here’s a range of things our editors recommend, “Choose Your Own Adventure”-style.

headline: Are These Twins Identical?
abstract: A study found that one-third of parents of twins were unsure or incorrect about their twins’ genetic identity, and many doctors don’t do much better.

headline: Edie Campbell on the Influence of Seoul
abstract: The Campbell sisters took a quick trip to South Korea to celebrate their mother, the British architect Sophie Hicks.
lead_paragraph: In between modeling during New York and London fashion weeks this September, I took a 48-hour break to fly to Seoul. My younger sister, Olympia, and I went for the opening party of a new store my mum, the British architect Sophie Hicks, had designed and built for the Stockholm-based fashion brand Acne Studios. Initially, it seemed a strange fit: a small piece of Scandinavia in South Korea.

headline: Natural History Museum’s Expansion: Part Dr. Seuss, Part Jurassic Park

headline: Inquiry Opens Into Shooting Death of Boy, 6, in Louisiana Police Chase
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The Louisiana State Police said marshals in the city of Marksville were trying to arrest the boy’s father when the chase began and shots were fired.

headline: Marco Rubio Lashes Back at Donald Trump Over Credit Card Flap

headline: Decoding Keith Haring’s Early Works
abstract: “Bombs and Dogs,” presented by Jeffrey Deitch and Suzanne Geiss, focuses on the artist’s output from 1980 to 1984.
lead_paragraph: The art dealer and curator Jeffrey Deitch is most fascinated by both bookends of an artist’s career — not just the late works, which are typically profound and full of reflection, but the first compositions, too. “In the early periods, you get the exuberance, the promise,” he explains. “Sometimes you don’t get the refinement, yet you feel this sincerity.”

headline: Serena Williams Thwarts Phone Theft, Complete With Highlight Video
abstract: Ms. Williams posted a story of foiling a man who tried to steal her phone, though surveillance video told a slightly less dramatic story.
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams is a world-class athlete and is seen as a living embodiment of the phrase “girl power,” but it appears that a man who seemed to try to steal her phone on Tuesday was due for a reminder. Even so, surveillance video suggests the encounter was not quite as dramatic as Ms. Williams’s widely shared tale on Facebook.

headline: Why Your Kids Love Snapchat, and Why You Should Let Them
keywords: ['Instant Messaging', 'Mobile Applications', 'Parenting', 'Social Media', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Text Messaging']
abstract: No perfectly curated lives, no friend counts. no “likes.” Snapchat is all about interaction.
lead_paragraph: In the picture that sprang to life on my phone, the girl’s hair was an unruly nest. Her eyes were crusty slits as she squinted, unsmiling, at the camera. She was still in bed, blankets askew. It is not a glamorous shot.

headline: ‘American Horror Story’ Season 5, Episode 5: We Have Two Selves
abstract: This week’s episode featured one of the season’s most deplorable images and one of its best performances.
lead_paragraph: The Hotel Cortez is pretty sick. There’s the gratuitous depravity, of course, but what I really mean is that a virus is running rampant. The Countess calls it “our precious virus,” a sort of vampirism that, yes, keeps one young and beautiful, but also spreads death and destruction.

headline: Wine Gift Options Abound for Thanksgiving
abstract: A box of chocolates or some hand towels are nice, but if your hosts enjoy wine, what better gift than a well-chosen bottle?
lead_paragraph: A good Thanksgiving guest has one responsibility and one elective. The responsibility is to carry out with good will whatever tasks, if any, have been assigned. The elective (and let’s face it, good manners would call this a responsibility, too) is to bring a little something for the hosts.

headline: The Naturally Alchemical Power of Gold Makeup
abstract: Dabbed on lids, brushed on brows or painted on lips, metallic makeup lends a supernatural sexiness.
lead_paragraph: Gold makeup plays a part in some of the most irresistible female archetypes — the sun-kissed blonde bombshell, the ancient queen, the glittering disco diva. Think of Brigitte Bardot and her honey-bronzed skin, Cleopatra and her gold-leaf eyes and gilded-to-the-hilt Studio 54 girls like Veruschka, Jerry Hall and Grace Jones. It’s no surprise that Ian Fleming, a master of male fantasy, dreamed up Auric Goldfinger, a villain who kills his bodacious victim by drenching her skin in gold paint. Watching ‘‘golden girl’’ Shirley Eaton’s metallic naked body glowing on pristine white sheets in the 1964 Bond movie, one feels like dying a golden death might not be such a bad thing.

headline: ‘You Us We All’ Creates a Baroque Vision of Modern Life

lead_paragraph: Early in the new opera “You Us We All,” two fashionable women of the 17th century, wearing elaborate wigs, gowns and corsets, sing about boredom while twilight gathers over modern-day Los Angeles. “I forgetith how glorious the sunset is at thy infinity pool,” one sings forlornly in pseudo-antique English, sipping a martini, her voice underscored by a Baroque ensemble.

headline: Review: ‘The Secret World Inside You’ Explores the Microbial Human
abstract: This exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History looks at the trillions of organisms crawling on and in the body.
lead_paragraph: There are trillions of them, crawling on you, and in you. This is the disturbing news that comes early in “The Secret World Inside You,” an exhibition that opens on Saturday at the American Museum of Natural History. “Your body is teeming with bacteria, viruses and other microbes,” a small video screen announces. The screen stands near the entrance, in a cosmic sea of tiny suspended lights, as sonorous space music pours forth in a sonic ooze.

lead_paragraph: In a photograph on the wall of Grandchamps, a Haitian restaurant near the eastern edge of Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, a woman in a sundress and long earrings carries a plate of seemingly just-gathered string beans. The image is bucolic and sternly glamorous at once, a reminder to the chef, Shawn Brockman (who happens to be the woman’s son-in-law) that she has trusted him with her recipes and he had better watch what he’s doing.

Jay Dardenne, one of Mr. Vitter’s Republican rivals in the primary, endorsed the Democrat in the runoff election, State Representative John Bel Edwards.

headline: Review: Aziz Ansari, in ‘Master of None,’ Negotiates Technology and Social Mores
abstract: This new 10-episode series on Netflix follows a struggling actor working his way through a world overloaded with choices.
lead_paragraph: In the best episode of Netflix’s “Master of None” — I think, it’s hard to pick just one — Dev (Aziz Ansari) wants tacos, but doesn’t know where to go. So he whips out his laptop and smartphone, consults Google, Eater and Yelp, finds lists and reviews, dozens of them, New York City’s trendiest tortillas, dissected and annotated by social media. Finally he settles on a food truck said to have the most delicious tacos in the city.

headline: Two Former Traders Found Guilty in Libor Manipulation Case

headline: Claims for Cryotherapy Treatment Get New Scrutiny After a Death
keywords: ['Cryotherapy', 'Spas', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: A woman’s death in Nevada in October placed attention on the growing practice of full-body cryotherapy, which its enthusiasts say has many benefits.

And suddenly you are encased in gas, below the neck, in a tank that is minus 300 degrees Fahrenheit — colder than the coldest naturally occurring temperature recorded on Earth.

A Cuban-born outfielder who made his major league debut in 2012, Cespedes has been around long enough for most of the baseball world to be plenty familiar with him, but he was suddenly on his way to 35 home runs and a contract worth the gross domestic product of a midsize country.

headline: Poll Finds Global Consensus on a Need to Tackle Climate Change

abstract: A Pew poll in 40 countries found that in all but one, a majority of respondents support limiting greenhouse gas emissions, though intensity of concern varies.

headline: Taking a Break, John Kasich Practices His Golf Swing
abstract: Gov. John Kasich took a few minutes to hit a few golf balls after a speech in New Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: PORTSMOUTH, N.H. — Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio had a few minutes Thursday between the end of his remarks to the Portsmith Rotary Club at the country club here and when his lunch arrived. So, taking advantage of a gorgeous fall day, he walked to the driving range and took four swings. He was quite pleased with his shots, exclaiming to his staff after every swing how true he had hit the ball.

headline: Dewey Jury’s Deadlock Exposes a System’s Flaws
abstract: One reason for the mistrial in the Dewey & LeBoeuf criminal case may have been the requirement for a unanimous decision.
lead_paragraph: When the founding fathers enshrined a right to an impartial trial by jury in the Sixth Amendment, it’s hard to imagine they were anticipating the jury in the Dewey & LeBoeuf criminal case.

headline: Natalia Osipova and Sergei Polunin to Unite at Sadler’s Wells
abstract: The theater also announced details of its spring-summer 2016 lineup, but it was Ms. Osipova and Mr. Polunin who generated the most excitement when they confirmed that they are a couple offstage.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Natalia Osipova and Sergei Polunin, two of ballet’s biggest stars, will perform together in a program of new work by Russell Maliphant, Sidi Larbi Cherkaoui and Arthur Pita at Sadler’s Wells next year. The theater announced the new partnership at a news conference on Thursday, along with details of its spring-summer 2016 lineup, which includes a program of all-female choreography for English National Ballet; a new piece by Javier de Frutos for the BalletBoyz; a work for dancers and horses by Bartabas; a new piece by Crystal Pite, and a “multi-installation” event by the lighting designers Lucy Carter and Michael Hulls and the composer Nitin Sawhney.

headline: Human Cost Rises as Old Bridges, Dams and Roads Go Unrepaired
keywords: ['Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Transportation', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Levees and Dams', 'Bridges and Tunnels', 'Railroad Accidents and Safety', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Hundreds of deaths, illnesses and injuries every year can be linked to the failure of transportation infrastructure and other systems like pipelines, experts say.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A routine trip to run errands almost cost Katherine Dean her life. In February, just as Ms. Dean, of suburban Maryland, drove underneath a bridge on the Capital Beltway, a large chunk of concrete fell from the structure, crushing the hood of her car and smashing the windshield.

headline: The George Bushes: A Father’s Critique of His Son’s Advisers
abstract: Readers argue that George W. Bush prided himself on being “the decider” and is responsible for those he chose to advise him.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Death Toll in Pakistan Factory Collapse Rises to 20
abstract: Rescue workers stepped up efforts to find survivors a day after the collapse of a factory on the outskirts of Lahore.
lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan — Rescue workers on Thursday intensified their search for survivors in the collapse of a factory near Lahore the day before after pulling out 108 survivors over two days, Pakistani officials said.

headline: U.S. to Share Criminal Records With Native American Police
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Native Americans', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The Justice Department will allow 10 tribes in eight states to share state and federal records, plugging a bureaucratic hole that had allowed offenders at reservations to buy guns.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department moved Thursday to fix what it described as “an information gap” that has allowed offenders living on Native American reservations to buy guns illegally and for years has blocked tribal police from access to important criminal records.

headline: Pandora and Sony/ATV in Deal on Songwriter Payments
keywords: ['Music', 'Royalties', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: The direct licensing deal will give Sony/ATV, the biggest music publisher, about 25 percent higher rates than it gets through Ascap and BMI.
lead_paragraph: Pandora Media and the publisher Sony/ATV have often been bitter opponents in the music industry’s streaming wars. But on Thursday they announced a direct licensing deal that gives both sides benefits while the music world braces for possible changes in government regulation of songwriting rights.

headline: Where to Find the Best Jeans in New York
abstract: Three stores, from Lower Manhattan to Brooklyn, serve the man who is very serious about his denim.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, among the truly committed, truly discerning jeans shopper, a beau ideal has taken hold: raw selvage denim in styles that evoke the rugged workpants of yesteryear. Think Marlon Brando in “The Wild One” (or his jeans, anyway).

headline: Ride-Sharing Apps Bring Back Car-Pooling
keywords: ['Car-Pooling and Ride-Sharing', 'Commuting', 'Mobile Applications', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Transit Systems']
abstract: Long the province of suburban parents and shift workers headed to the same factory, car-pooling is getting an urban makeover.
lead_paragraph: JACK DeMANCHE’S commute to work was like many in the Boston area — long. But that was before Mr. DeManche, a digital strategist for an advertising agency, began sharing a ride with other commuters with the service Bridj.

headline: Ayumi Tanaka’s “Wish You Were Here”
abstract: The artist’s dreamlike photo collages are based on memories of her childhood in a small Japanese village.
lead_paragraph: The artist’s dreamlike photo collages are based on memories of her childhood in a small Japanese village.

headline: Goldman Sachs Rolls Out New Policies to Retain Junior Bankers
keywords: ['Hiring and Promotion', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Working Hours', 'Work-Life Balance']
abstract: With moves like accelerating promotions and minimizing busy work, the company is trying to entice young employees to stay for the long haul.
lead_paragraph: In an effort to appease young investment bankers over the last few years, Goldman Sachs increased their salaries and gave them Saturdays off.

headline: N.F.L. Week 9 Previews and Picks
abstract: The undefeated Carolina Panthers will try to pick up a signature win against the Green Bay Packers.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a look at the best games of N.F.L. Week 9, and who we think will win them.

headline: Dreamlike Photo Collages, Created From Memory
abstract: The artist Ayumi Tanaka’s careful, nostalgic compositions are inspired by half-remembered moments from her childhood in a Japanese village.
lead_paragraph: Encountering the photographer Ayumi Tanaka’s series “Wish You Were Here” feels like stepping into her subconscious: Though the images and themes might not be yours, the feelings they evoke are familiar. Tanaka constructs three-dimensional dioramas, composed of overlapping multiple layers of photo collages, assembled and photographed to illustrate the “landscapes of my memory,” as she puts it: images that might serve as jumping-off points for all sorts of fairy-tales. The artist constructs her collages with family photos taken when she was growing up in a small village in the mountains of Japan; more recent personal snapshots; self-portraits; and pictures of everyday objects taken from the Internet that become symbols evocative of her childhood memories. The artist herself takes on a poetic tone when discussing her work. “At times in my day-to-day life, I find myself stumbling over reminders of days gone by. Partly formed memories rise up from a forgotten abyss within, surrounding me like a powerful fragrance and rocking my emotions to the core,” she says. “In these moments, I am seized with the desire to gather and collect, to retrieve what has been lost and weave it into something whole.”

headline: Former Goldman Employee Pleads Guilty in Leak Case
abstract: A day earlier, a former Federal Reserve Bank of New York employee pleaded guilty to an identical charge in the same case.
lead_paragraph: Highlighting the hazards of Wall Street’s revolving door with regulatory agencies, a former employee of Goldman Sachs pleaded guilty on Thursday for obtaining documents leaked to him by a former colleague at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

headline: ‘Why Would I Join a Party That Doesn’t Really Like Me?’: Readers on Asian-Americans and the Republican Party
keywords: ['Asian-Americans', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Education', 'Governors (US)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Indian-Americans', 'Minorities', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In response to a recent column, many Asian-American readers said the Republican Party’s rhetoric on immigration, education and poverty led them to support Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Many Asian-American readers said the Republican Party’s rhetoric on immigration, education and poverty were top reasons they largely support Democrats for public office, in response to a column by Thomas Edsall.

headline: Scientists Engineer a Plant to Reject Its Own Pollen
abstract: Preventing self-pollination may strengthen genetic diversity and provide better yields, researchers suggest.
lead_paragraph: Field poppies do not self-pollinate, a strategy that helps keep the species’ gene pool diverse. Now, researchers at the University of Birmingham in England have successfully transferred two genes from a poppy plant to a self-fertilizing plant called thale cress. The genetically modified thale cress rejects its own pollen and that of close relatives, the researchers report in the journal Science. The experiment may help researchers breed plants that are stronger than their parents and provide better yields.

headline: Why Barclays May Want to Mull a Move to the U.S.
abstract: HSBC caused an uproar by suggesting it might move its headquarters to Hong Kong. But it makes more sense for its London-based peer Barclays to move to New York.
lead_paragraph: HSBC has caused a scene by suggesting it might move its headquarters from London. But it is rival Barclays that really ought to consider a domicile switch.

headline: Ex-Player’s Suit Challenges N.C.A.A.’s Transfer Rules
keywords: ['Football (College)', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Scholarships and Fellowships', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A football player who lost his scholarship says rules requiring players to sit out a year if they switch colleges violate antitrust law.
lead_paragraph: A former college football player has filed suit against the N.C.A.A., charging that the association’s transfer rules and limits on scholarships violate United States antitrust laws. The lawsuit, filed in a federal court in Indianapolis on Thursday on behalf of the former Weber State cornerback Devin Pugh, seeks to allow players to transfer freely between colleges and to abolish the cap on football scholarships — currently 85.

headline: Four New Ways to Make Fancy Drinks at Home
abstract: Paris's Experimental Cocktail Club shares tips and recipes from its new book.
lead_paragraph: Paris's Experimental Cocktail Club shares tips and recipes from its new book.

headline: 1940: Roosevelt Wins Third Term
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: President Franklin D. Roosevelt wins re-election in 1940.
lead_paragraph: President Franklin D. Roosevelt won re-election yesterday to become the first President ever honored by a third term in the 151 years since the first inauguration of George Washington. The President and his running mate, Henry A. Wallace, rolled up an overwhelming margin in the electoral college over their Republican opponents, Wendell L. Willkie and Charles L. McNary. However, this plurality fell short of the one that President Roosevelt and John N. Garner attained in the 1936 landslide. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 6, 1940

lead_paragraph: Greece and Elsewhere: Pictures of the Day

headline: Marvel’s Iceman Cometh Out
abstract: A remarkable moment for a longtime X-Men character was a year in the making, the comic publisher’s editor in chief says.
lead_paragraph: “If I knew then, what I know now” is a familiar, wistful refrain. What would we tell our younger selves if we could? In “Uncanny X-Men” No. 600, which was published Wednesday by Marvel Entertainment, readers get to see the mutant hero Iceman have a conversation with his past self thanks to time travel (because, you know, comics). But it is the younger Iceman that forces the older to acknowledge a truth: He, Bobby Drake, is gay.

headline: Nov. 5, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Greece, Serbia, Myanmar and the West Bank.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Greece, Serbia, Myanmar and the West Bank.

headline: Doctor in Sheldon Silver’s Corruption Trial Denies Improper Relationship
abstract: Dr. Robert N. Taub, whose testimony many believed would be damaging in the corruption trial for Mr. Silver, a former New York Assembly speaker, denied he had an explicit financial relationship.
lead_paragraph: The bonds of friendship between Dr. Robert N. Taub and Sheldon Silver were evident, from small favors — Mr. Silver once gave Dr. Taub handmade matzo, and helped the doctor’s son find a job — to larger ones.

headline: Bilingual Etiquette for In-Laws
abstract: Plus: one’s obligation to food-challenged co-workers; responding to the self-invited guest; and wearing a ring with a history.
lead_paragraph: Our son lives across the country from us. We visit twice a year. My daughter-in-law, who was raised abroad but speaks perfect English, wants my granddaughter, 4, to be bilingual. She has only spoken to her in her native language from the day she was born. This doesn’t change when we visit. We sit clueless for long stretches while they talk. The same thing happens to my son, who barely speaks their language. We don’t object to our granddaughter learning another language, but we don’t want to feel so left out. Do you agree that this behavior is totally rude?

headline: Sotheby’s Day Auction of Taubman Collection at $42.7 Million
abstract: Thursday’s sale left the auction house feeling encouraged enough to announce that it was on track to cover the $500 million it had guaranteed in selling the collection of its former chairman, A. Alfred Taubman.
lead_paragraph: Daytime auctions don’t usually make big news. But at Sotheby’s Taubman Modern and Contemporary Art sale on Thursday afternoon, the results, which totaled $42.7 million with fees, left the auction house feeling encouraged enough to announce that it was on track to cover the $500 million it had guaranteed in selling the collection of its former chairman, A. Alfred Taubman. With 123 scheduled lots, the estimate for the sale was $30.2 million to $43.4 million.

headline: A Very Mod Ballet at the Guggenheim Gala
abstract: For tonight’s event, the choreographer Tom Gold has reinterpreted a 1973 composition by Minsa Craig.
lead_paragraph: What do the painter Alberto Burri and the author Jacqueline Susann have in common? At first glance, not much. But leave it to the Guggenheim to mash up the incongruous for the sake of art — or in this case, for the Guggenheim International Gala, which for the last three years has been lent some extra oomph by Dior. Currently, the Guggenheim’s main floorspace is devoted to a retrospective of work by Burri, the Italian iconoclast whose postwar rejection of pictorial tradition influenced Arte Povera and Neo-Dada. The entertainment at tonight’s gala will come via Tom Gold, the former New York City Ballet principal now leading his own company, who has unearthed “November Steps,” an overlooked ballet by Burri’s wife Minsa Craig. “To me, it looked like Martha Graham and Merce Cunningham en pointe in Andy Warhol’s factory,” Gold says. “Or ‘Valley of the Dolls!’”

headline: Review: ‘Sam Phillips: The Man Who Invented Rock ’n’ Roll,’ by Peter Guralnick
abstract: Guralnick’s biography explores how Phillips passionately shaped a mix of black and white voices at Sun Records in Memphis, from Elvis Presley to Jerry Lee Lewis to Howlin’ Wolf.
lead_paragraph: Sam Phillips, the founder of Sun Records in Memphis, is frequently remembered for a single sound bite: “If I could find a white man who had the Negro sound and the Negro feel, I could make a billion dollars!” He seems cynical at best, racist at worst.

headline: Flannel Escapes Its Grunge Past
abstract: Men’s wear designers have gone back to the flannel shirt, but not in a way that evokes Seattle in the ’90s.
lead_paragraph: Men’s wear designers have gone back to the flannel shirt, but not in a way that evokes Seattle in the ’90s.

headline: Living With Cancer: The Lure of Alternative Remedies
abstract: Sick people need all sorts of strategies, alongside medical ones, to deal with disease.
lead_paragraph: When I get tired of being told to juice carrots, I remember that the essayist Anatole Broyard took tap-dancing lessons as he underwent treatment for prostate cancer. Sick people need all sorts of strategies, alongside medical ones, to deal with disease.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day in the Asia-Pacific region.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: ‘Four Marilyns’ Is Back on the Auction Block
abstract: This Warhol portrait from 1962, which was sold at Phillips in 2013 and then sold eight months later, will be part of Christie’s sale on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Those perusing catalogs for the coming art auctions may have done a double take when viewing Christie’s cover for its postwar and contemporary art sale on Tuesday, featuring Warhol’s 1962 acrylic and silk-screen “Four Marilyns.”

headline: A Vote in Houston Leaves the N.F.L. in a Bind
abstract: After voters repealed an anti-discrimination ordinance, the N.F.L. said it would stick with plans to host the 2017 Super Bowl in Houston, and the N.C.A.A. said it would keep the 2016 Final Four there.
lead_paragraph: In this age of always-on media attention, there are few more effective ways to silence most professional athletes than to ask a pointed political question. Schooled to carefully manage their public personas, many players will studiously sidestep anything with a whiff of controversy.

headline: Review: In ‘The Seedbed,’ an Uneasy Marital Truce Frays Over Dinner
abstract: The psychological drama by Bryan Delany is having its world premiere at the New Jersey Repertory Company in Long Branch.
lead_paragraph: A biblical proverb glimmers behind a meaningful title in “The Seedbed,” a new psychological drama now having its world premiere at the New Jersey Repertory Company in Long Branch.

headline: Review: ‘Miss You Already,’ on Female Friends and Crying
abstract: Toni Collette and Drew Barrymore star in Catherine Hardwicke’s drama about longtime friends drawn together and torn apart by one’s illness.
lead_paragraph: As Jess (Drew Barrymore) is going into labor, she flashes back through her long friendship with Milly (Toni Collette), who should be with her but isn’t. “Miss You Already” will eventually account for Milly’s absence, and in the course of doing so it will illuminate the intimate, difficult bond between the two women, who met as 10-year-old schoolgirls and have been nearly inseparable ever since.

headline: With ESPN Gains, Disney Profit Rose 12 Percent in Fiscal Year
abstract: For its fourth quarter, Disney had a per-share profit of $1.20 a share, a 35 percent increase.
lead_paragraph: Wither ESPN? Not this time.

headline: Ben Carson Appeals to Black Voters, but His Campaign Doesn’t, Yet
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Mr. Carson has a unique possibility of drawing blacks to vote in the Republican primary, but his campaign has yet to hire a staff member dedicated to turning out black voters.
lead_paragraph: WEST MEMPHIS, Ark. — Sam Hawkins Jr. said he came to a rally here last week for the Republican presidential candidate Ben Carson because he finds Mr. Carson’s social conservatism appealing, relishes his newness to politics and believes that President Obama “sold out for the vote” in supporting same-sex marriage.

headline: Review: BalletCollective Plays With Wildfire
abstract: The dance troupe’s “Invisible Divide,” at the Skirball Center at New York University, included two world premieres.
lead_paragraph: BalletCollective’s program “Invisible Divide” leaves a number of burning images in the mind, chiefly ones that revealingly illustrate modern masculinity. Thanks to the choreographer Troy Schumacher, the three male dancers — Harrison Coll (who has moments worthy of James Dean), David Prottas and Taylor Stanley — register with powerful individuality. The way they do so in the contexts both of women and of one another is arresting, fresh, exploratory.

headline: Don McCullin at War
abstract: The legendary photographer counsels those seeking conflict: look close to home at the social wars being waged every day.
lead_paragraph: The legendary photographer counsels those seeking conflict: look close to home at the social wars being waged every day.

headline: An H.C. Westermann Retrospective Melds Humor and Provocation
abstract: An overview at Venus reveals the playful and often satirical dimension Mr. Westermann brought to his paintings, woodcut prints, constructions and illustrated letters.
lead_paragraph: “Homage to American Art (Dedicated to Elie Nadelman)” is one of 38 sculptures in “See America First,” a terrific exhibition of works by the great American visionary H. C. Westermann (1922–1981) at Venus (formerly Venus Over Manhattan). From a wooden hook attached to a post anchored to a neatly dovetailed wooden pedestal hangs an object with the handle and shaft of a shovel but, instead of a conventional blade, a wooden sphere the size of a bowling ball. It’s hard to imagine what sort of useful work could be done with this curious tool, made in 1966.

headline: Jared Bark’s Black-and-White Photo Booth Creations
abstract: Mr. Bark made a photo booth his studio for several years, experimenting with the possibilities of the strips of pictures.
lead_paragraph: From 1969 to 1976, the artist Jared Bark all but exhausted the aesthetic possibilities of the common photo booth.

abstract: The artist’s show at Zieher Smith & Horton harnesses a Rift headset and her near abstract paintings.

headline: PaJaMa, Whose Photographs Breathed Eroticism
abstract: This exhibition explores the work of this stylish collaborative, who made the most of anything at hand in the 1930s and ’40s.

headline: Jasper Cropsey Paintings on Display at His Hudson Valley Home
abstract: Many of Jasper Cropsey’s paintings are on display in Hastings-on-Hudson at Ever Rest, his final home, and at the nearby Gallery of Art, which is devoted to his work.
lead_paragraph: Paintings by the Hudson River School artist Jasper Cropsey reside in the White House, the National Gallery of Art, the Metropolitan Museum of Art and museums at Yale and Princeton, but the best place to commune with Cropsey’s glorious 19th-century landscapes is in an oasis in Hastings-on-Hudson.

headline: Lively Debate and Discussion at Festival Albertine
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Cartoons and Cartoonists', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Events at the Albertine bookshop and the Irish Arts Center touch on topics including feminism, climate change, poetry and graphic novels.
lead_paragraph: These days, a good chat about current events or an earful of cultural commentary is readily available on podcasts and online. But Twitter messages and Facebook posts often fail to satisfy the Miser’s thirst to join the conversation.

headline: Furniture Designers With Fates Tied to the Nazis
abstract: Prewar artisans in Germany designed playful furniture pieces. Then World War II began.
lead_paragraph: The Lampedo gallery in Lower Manhattan has assembled 30 pieces of playful furniture with some unsettling back stories for the exhibition “Berlin Deko — German Furniture 1910-1930.” The items in this show, on view through Nov. 21, have been arranged to create a kind of off-kilter living room, with jagged black shards painted and mounted on the walls, floors and ceiling.

headline: The Lindberghs, From Triumph to Tragedy, an Exhibition at Morven
abstract: The show, “Charles and Anne Morrow Lindbergh: Couple of an Age,” opens on Nov. 13 at the Morven Museum & Garden in Princeton, N.J.
lead_paragraph: As soon as Charles Lindbergh completed his trans-Atlantic flight on May 21, 1927, souvenir hunters started tearing apart his plane and trailing after him. Manufacturers put his image on lingerie, crayon boxes, calendars, cigar wrappers, pocket mirrors, board games, tapestries and bookends.

lead_paragraph: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Adam Rapoport, Bon Appétit’s Editor, on 5 Favorite Things
abstract: Saint Laurent sneakers and black Acne jeans are couple of things that make his list.
lead_paragraph: Adam Rapoport, editor in chief of Bon Appétit, is more likely to be found in designer sneakers than kitchen clogs. Even so, he promises he makes a mean stuffing (“I literally use Jimmy Dean sausage,” he said. “It’s my mom’s classic and very right-down-the-middle American.” ) and perfect mashed potatoes, which he’ll serve on Thanksgiving. But first, he dishes up five of his favorite things.

abstract: Damien and Jacqueline Harrison, of the landscape design firm Harrison Green, share their tips for maintaining greenery when outdoor gardens aren’t an option.
lead_paragraph: Damien and Jacqueline Harrison, of the landscape design firm Harrison Green, share their tips for maintaining greenery when outdoor gardens aren’t an option.

headline: At the Armoury, Classics Are Always In Style
abstract: Do you want the latest thing? You’ve come to the wrong place. A visit to a classic tailoring emporium in TriBeCa.
lead_paragraph: For nearly two years, Jake Grantham, the manager of the Armoury, an elegant clothing shop in TriBeCa, has been introducing, or reintroducing, classical tailoring to a range of men looking for something that is at once new and old.

headline: James Corden on His Latest Modeling Gig
abstract: The late-night host discusses the love affair between fashion and comedy, and his appearance in a Burberry holiday campaign.
lead_paragraph: Seven months after strutting the runway for Burberry during its Los Angeles fashion show, and five months after hosting the Council of Fashion Designers of America awards in New York, James Corden, the host of the “The Late Late Show,” is once again having a fashion moment: starring alongside Elton John and Naomi Campbell in the new Burberry holiday campaign directed by Christopher Bailey, the chief executive and chief creative officer of the brand. How did a portly British comedian become the latest “it” boy of the style set? In a phone call from Los Angeles, he talked through the story.

headline: A Take on Seurat, Unseen Since the ’70s
abstract: “Enrico Baj” at Luxembourg & Dayan includes the artist’s interpretation of the pointillist work.
lead_paragraph: “Years ago,” says Roberta Cerini Baj, the widow of the Italian neo-avant garde artist Enrico Baj, “I remember that my daughter, Marianna, told Enrico, ‘When you see paintings in the house, you treat them like friends. When you see them outside of it, in an exhibition, they look totally different.’ And usually, this is true” — though not in the case of Luxembourg & Dayan’s current gathering of her husband’s pieces. The intimate gallery, which is wallpapered and homey, is filled with 50 works by the late artist. Among them is “The Double Grande Jatte,” her husband’s homage to and spin on Georges Seurat’s exercise in pointillism, “A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte.” Its inclusion represents a reunion for Roberta, who last saw “The Double Grande Jatte” when it was on display at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago, in 1971. “I found it so fresh here,” she remarks. “When he was making it, we were in an apartment in Milan and there was a door between the living room and the studio,” and the 20-foot-long mural ran parallel to the door jambs. “It was in front of us all of the time and at the end, Enrico said, ‘I understand now why Seurat died so young, from getting bored of making all of those points.’” A quip, sure, but fitting for someone consumed by the need for change.

headline: Cats, Monsters and Detonations at the Park Avenue Armory’s Print Fair
abstract: The International Fine Art Print Dealers Association Print Fair offers prints from a range of eras and of production techniques. Here are highlights.

abstract: Readers respond to recent reviews of “Doomed to Succeed: The U.S.-Israel Relationship From Truman to Obama,” Ben Bernanke’s “The Courage to Act” and more.

headline: R.H. Quaytman’s Variations on Klee’s Angel
abstract: Pieces from, and inspired by, R.H. Quaytman’s show for the Tel Aviv Museum of Art make up her current exhibition at Miguel Abreu gallery.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, the New York artist R. H. Quaytman was invited to do a show at the Tel Aviv Museum of Art. She traveled to Israel to research themes for a new body of work, and found one in a piece of 20th-century Modernist art: Paul Klee’s 1920 monoprint “Angelus Novus,” a jewel in the collection of the Israel Museum in Jerusalem.

headline: Classical & Opera Listings for Nov. 6-12
abstract: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Review: ‘A Wonderful Life’ an Adaptation of a Frank Capra Film
abstract: The Goodspeed Opera House’s adaptation of Frank Capra’s classic Christmastime film, “It’s a Wonderful Life,” sets the original’s existential struggle to music.
lead_paragraph: “A Wonderful Life” has wonderful leading performances, and they alone are a reason to consider visiting the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam to see this musical stage adaptation.

headline: Review: For New York Philharmonic, an All-Mozart Program
abstract: Conducted by Alan Gilbert, Wednesday’s program at David Geffen Hall was a little more inventive than earlier concerts, yet delight proved elusive.
lead_paragraph: “Perfection, revelation, incarnation, grace, redemption.” Those are just some of the qualities that two centuries of thinkers have associated with Mozart, writes the musicologist Scott Burnham in his book “Mozart’s Grace.”

headline: ‘Soldier, Spectre, Shaman,’ an Alternate History at MoMA
abstract: The exhibition, drawn from the museum’s permanent collection, includes 30 or so artists, mostly European, who insisted on the primacy of the figure.
lead_paragraph: In 1936, the first director of the Museum of Modern Art mapped out the art of his time in a famous chart, the first taste of the museum’s persistent narrative of Modernism. The doctrine goes something like this: Western art of the early 20th century develops in a single direction, toward abstraction. Artists working toward that goal were the true radicals. Those who held onto representation were aesthetic conservatives (whatever their actual politics).Conveniently enough, the artists who broke most definitively with figuration, and who made abstract painting and sculpture into the One True Art, were living in New York — the city that, in the words of the art historian Serge Guilbaut, “stole the idea of Modern art” from Paris after World War II.

headline: Review: ‘The Peanuts Movie’ Curses the Red Baron in 3 Dimensions
abstract: The question with this revival of a franchise revered by nostalgic baby boomers is whether it will resonate with today’s 7-year-olds.
lead_paragraph: “The Peanuts Movie” may be simultaneously the most charming and the most daring experiment in human genetics ever conducted. At issue is whether the character summaries and back stories of fictional pop-culture figures can be passed from one generation to the next solely through DNA.

headline: Review: In ‘Opus,’ the Troupe Circa Melds With the Debussy String Quartet
abstract: This performance combined acrobatics with three Shostakovich string quartets as part of the Next Wave Festival.
lead_paragraph: The grimly somber slow movement of Shostakovich’s String Quartet No. 8 might seem an unlikely musical backdrop for a troupe of acrobats. But the 14 members of the Australian ensemble Circa who performed “Opus” on Wednesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music are more like acrobatic dancers. Or dancing acrobats. Either way, they are amazing.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Carlo Crivelli, an Overlooked Renaissance Master, in Boston
abstract: A Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum show features 26 paintings by this Venice-born artist who devoted his talents mostly to religious commissions.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — If your admiration for Italian Renaissance painting is more culturally received than deeply felt, “Ornament and Illusion: Carlo Crivelli of Venice” at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum is the show to see. It is the first exhibition in an American museum devoted to Crivelli, a great but neglected Early Renaissance master, and his fabulously fraught panel paintings, with their charged emotional moods, exquisitely detailed and richly appointed settings, gleaming trompe l’oeil jewels and tracts of gold gilt. There are only 26 paintings here, but they form a thrilling, seductive and edifying experience.

headline: Review: Orquesta Buena Vista Social Club Bids Adiós, With Notes of Loss
abstract: A feeling of departure weighed heavily on the group’s sold-out concert at the Beacon Theater, its last scheduled stop in the continental United States on its “Adiós Tour.”
lead_paragraph: Last year, Orquesta Buena Vista Social Club began one long, final spin around the globe, under the banner of its official “Adiós Tour.” The operative word there is “adiós,” and it carries more than the usual implications of a band bidding its audience farewell. A feeling of departure weighed heavily, often dispiritingly, on the ensemble’s sold-out concert on Wednesday, its second of two nights at the Beacon Theater, and its last scheduled stop in the continental United States.
