headline: Oscar Munoz, United’s Chief, to Return in First Quarter
abstract: Appointed in September after the dismissal of Jeff Smisek, Mr. Munoz suffered a heart attack last month, but says he is on the mend.
lead_paragraph: United Airlines said on Thursday that its president and chief executive, Oscar Munoz, would return sometime in the first quarter after suffering a heart attack last month.

headline: Review: In ‘Fight or Flight,’ Whine, Women and Songwriter
abstract: The French film actor Mathieu Amalric makes his American stage debut in this play adapted from an Éric Reinhardt novel.
lead_paragraph: Mathieu Amalric can loll on the floor — shirt unbuttoned, feet bare, face stubbly, cigarette smoldering away — and not appear ridiculous. This is a particular gift of the French, and Mr. Amalric, a film actor making his American stage debut with “Fight or Flight (Le Moral des Ménages),” presented by French Institute Alliance Française, has it all wrapped up in a pleasantly scruffy package.

headline: As Refugees Flee, Thousands of Children Have No Country to Call Their Own
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Children and Childhood', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: A United Nations report estimates that 70,000 stateless children are born annually, in regions as disparate as Southeast Asia, the Caribbean and even the heart of Europe.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Two years old, Yazan al-Najjar is a boy without a country.

headline: Boy, 9, Was Pawn in Gang War, Chicago Police Say
abstract: Tyshawn Lee, was reportedly singled out because his father was connected to one of two street gangs, though it was unclear whether it was an act of retaliation.
lead_paragraph: A 9-year-old boy who was shot to death in a Chicago alley, in one of the most notorious crimes in the city’s recent history, was the target of the shooting, not a bystander who became an accidental victim, officials said Thursday.

headline: Theater Listings for Nov. 6-12
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Review: ‘Sand Dollars,’ Unrequited Love in the Dominican Republic
abstract: Geraldine Chaplin falls for a much younger woman while on a Caribbean vacation.
lead_paragraph: A coldhearted prude might be tempted to describe “Sand Dollars,” an empathetic portrait of the relationship between Anne (Geraldine Chaplin), a forlorn older woman of means, and Noelí (Yanet Mojica), a lithe 20-year-old beauty in the Dominican Republic, as a condemnation of sexual tourism. But Ms. Chaplin, in one of her most touching screen performances, imbues Anne with a world-weary melancholy that makes your heart sink. She is in love, despite her better judgment. And her paramour loves her back — a little.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Nov. 6-12
abstract: What if a blue jay could also be a D.J.?
lead_paragraph: What if a blue jay could also be a D.J.?

headline: F.D.A. Approves Genvoya, a New One-Pill Treatment for H.I.V.
abstract: The pill is expected to be less likely to cause kidney damage or loss of bone density, which have become problems for people with H.I.V. who survive into old age.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration approved a new one-pill H.I.V. treatment on Thursday with a new, apparently safer form of tenofovir, a powerful H.I.V. inhibitor. The new pill, called Genvoya, from Gilead Sciences , joins several other one-pill treatments, including Atripla, Complera, Triumeq and Stribild. It contains the same four drugs as Stribild, but with the tenofovir disoproxil fumarate replaced by tenofovir alafenamide. The new form of the inhibitor, Gilead said, enters cells where H.I.V. replicates more efficiently, resulting in 91 percent less tenofovir in the bloodstream. That should make the pill less likely to cause kidney damage or loss of bone density, which have become major problems among people with H.I.V. who survive into old age.

headline: Spare Times for Nov. 6-12
abstract: Information on events for possible inclusion in Spare Times should be sent to weekend@nytimes.com by Friday at 5 p.m. for publication that week. Longer versions of Around Town and For Children listings are in a searchable guide at nytimes.com/events.
lead_paragraph: Information on events for possible inclusion in Spare Times should be sent to weekend@nytimes.com by Friday at 5 p.m. for publication that week. Longer versions of Around Town and For Children listings are in a searchable guide at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Review: In ‘Theeb,’ a Bedouin Boy’s Brutal Coming-of-Age
abstract: Naji Abu Nowar’s drama, set in 1916, follows a young orphan, alone and unarmed in the Arabic equivalent of the Wild West.
lead_paragraph: If you were a preadolescent boy stranded in the desert with a sinister grown-up stranger on whom you depended for your survival, what would you do? That question, posed in the spellbinding Jordanian adventure film “Theeb,” drives a story set in the farthest reaches of the Ottoman Empire in 1916. The man, who is seriously wounded, and the boy play cat and mouse as they help each other stay alive in a do-or-die struggle.

headline: Review: Bryan Cranston in ‘Trumbo,’ as a Screenwriter in a Hollywood Under Siege
abstract: Directed by Jay Roach, the film tells the personal story of one of the Hollywood 10.
lead_paragraph: In “Trumbo,” an ill-conceived take on one of the most famous targets of the Hollywood blacklist, the writer Dalton Trumbo clenches a cigarette holder that juts in the air like a sword. Given that he’s played by Bryan Cranston (“Breaking Bad”), you have hopes that Trumbo will soon be making like Errol Flynn and dashing and slashing through the movie, giving it verve, excitement. The real Trumbo (1905-1976) was a pistol. A baker-intellectual turned industry insider, he was funny, barbed and wildly prolific, with screen credits that range from “Kitty Foyle” to “Spartacus.” He was also a Communist, which for many made him a traitor, the Devil, no more than a terrorist.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Brooklyn’
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Brooklyn.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Brooklyn.”

headline: Exxon Mobil and the G.O.P.: Fossil Fools
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: The leading Republican presidential candidates are promoting the very junk science that was hatched, in part, in Exxon’s board room.
lead_paragraph: Well before one hottest-year-ever was followed by yet another record-breaker, before Arctic ice vanished in real time and Pope Francis made a plea to save our troubled home, the world’s largest private oil company discovered that its chief product could cause global havoc.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Spotlight’
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Spotlight.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Spotlight.”

headline: Movie Review: ‘Spectre’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Spectre.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Spectre.”

headline: This Week’s Movies | Nov. 6, 2015
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Spectre,” “Spotlight” and “Brooklyn.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Spectre,” “Spotlight” and “Brooklyn.”

headline: Chris Christie and Mike Huckabee, in Blow to Their Campaigns, Are Cut From Main Debate Stage
abstract: Fox Business Network, the host of the next Republican presidential debate next week in Milwaukee, announced the qualifiers for the main stage, and Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey did not quite make the cut.
lead_paragraph: When the Republican presidential hopefuls take the stage in Milwaukee on Tuesday night for their fourth debate, familiar faces will be missing from the prime-time lineup — Mike Huckabee and Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey.

headline: Review: In ‘The Hallow,’ Evil Lurks in the Irish Woods
abstract: The title of Corin Hardy’s horror film refers not to a place, but to the vicious supernatural beings who inhabit a forest paradise.
lead_paragraph: The title of “The Hallow” refers not to a place, but to the vicious supernatural beings who inhabit a lush Irish forest. Into this initially peaceful paradise come Adam and Claire (Joseph Mawle and Bojana Novakovic) and their new baby, following the money offered to Adam, a tree expert, by a logging company wishing to survey its latest acquisition.

headline: Congress Split on Tapping Fed or Banks to Fund Roads
keywords: ['Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Senate planned to raise money by paring back a bank dividend members see as obsolete, but the House wants to drain the Federal Reserve’s rainy-day fund instead. Critics say both ideas are wrongheaded.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The banking industry scored a surprise victory on Thursday when the House voted to pay for part of a new highway bill by draining a rainy-day fund at the Federal Reserve rather than cutting federal payments to some of the nation’s largest banks.

headline: Art and Real Estate Collide at Events in the Bronx and at the Brooklyn Museum
abstract: Critics of recent and planned events say it is unseemly for members of the art world to support development efforts that would appear to result in gentrification.
lead_paragraph: A major museum is scheduled to host a real estate conference addressing questions like “Where is the bleeding edge of neighborhood transformation?” and “What opportunities for value-add exist in the seemingly picked-over areas?”

headline: Review: ‘The House That Jack Built,’ a Gritty, Busy Tale of the City
abstract: Written by Joseph Vasquez, the Bronx-born filmmaker who died in 1995, this kitchen sink drama overflows with street flavor.
lead_paragraph: Poor Jack (E. J. Bonilla) — so many things on his plate. His drug-dealing business at the corner bodega, which enabled him to buy the building where his family lives, is threatened by rival dealers; the marriage of his brother (Leo Minaya) is in trouble; he wants his sister (Rosal Colón), a lesbian, to stop seeing her girlfriend (and hopes to “cure” her by having a buddy sleep with her); his pregnant girlfriend (Melissa Fumero) won’t stop asking about marriage; and his alcoholic father (John Herrera) keeps bickering with his mother (Saundra Santiago). But we know that Jack is decent, because he beats up a drug addict pimping out his own daughter.

headline: Union for Reform Judaism Adopts Transgender Rights Policy
abstract: The largest Jewish group in North America said the move was part of its effort to bring in people who have been “on the margins of society.”
lead_paragraph: The largest Jewish group in North America adopted a broad transgender rights policy on Thursday, not only stating its own commitment to equality, but also urging synagogues and other Jewish groups to be advocates for transgender rights and to take steps like training their staffs on accommodating transgender people.

headline: Howard Green, Who Found a Way to Grow Skin and Saved Lives, Dies at 90
abstract: From a failed experiment, Dr. Green discovered how to regenerate skin that could be grafted onto burn victims, and inspired future stem cell research.
lead_paragraph: On July 1, 1983, two young brothers and a friend were exploring a derelict house in their Casper, Wyo., neighborhood when they stumbled on several seductive cans of paint in a cupboard. Mischievously, they splashed the paint on the walls and, inevitably, on themselves.

headline: Review: ‘In the Basement,’ What Lies Beneath in Austria
abstract: Ulrich Seidl gives viewers a tour of the private hobbies practiced in the unseen, unfortunately decorated spaces of Austrian homes.
lead_paragraph: Ulrich Seidl’s raw portrayals of ordinary people have been criticized as unflattering and wallowing in abjection. But occasionally, as in his newest, “In the Basement,” the director can make you wonder whether the problem doesn’t lie with his films but with everyone else’s. This often hilarious movie descends into the unseen spaces of Austrian homes — literally and figuratively — and creates a stage for their residents’ fantasies of sex, violence and power.

headline: The Push for Legal Marijuana Spreads
keywords: ['Marijuana', 'Editorials', 'States (US)', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Hashish', 'Medical Marijuana', 'Law and Legislation', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: An advance in Mexico and a change promised for Canada should be followed by a more sensible drug policy in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Support for making marijuana legal is increasing around the world, and that is a good thing. Earlier this week, the Mexican Supreme Court opened the door to legalizing the drug by giving four plaintiffs the right to grow cannabis for personal use.

headline: Review: In ‘Lost in the Sun,’ a Motherless Teenager Teams Up With a Petty Crook
abstract: Starring Josh Duhamel and Josh Wiggins, this film follows the open-road adventure of a somewhat unlikely pair.
lead_paragraph: Remove the charm and the Depression-era aura from “Paper Moon” and you have “Lost in the Sun,” a road movie that goes nowhere particularly interesting.

headline: Michael Keaton Discusses ‘Spotlight’
abstract: The actor Michael Keaton discusses playing the Boston Globe journalist Walter "Robby" Robinson in “Spotlight.”
lead_paragraph: The actor Michael Keaton discusses playing the Boston Globe journalist Walter "Robby" Robinson in “Spotlight.”

headline: Melissa Mathison, the Screenwriter Behind a Classic, ‘E.T.,’ Dies at 65
abstract: Ms. Mathison, who shared a screenplay credit on “The Black Stallion” (1979), met Steven Spielberg, the director of “E.T.,” in Tunisia, where he started to persuade her to write the script.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Mathison, who wrote the screenplay for “E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial,” the science-fiction fable that became one of Hollywood’s signature depictions of the anxieties and longings of childhood and cemented the reputation of Steven Spielberg as a leading director of artful, popular movies, died on Wednesday in Los Angeles. She was 65.

headline: Lawsuit Accuses Brooklyn Charter School of Failing to Provide Special Education Services
abstract: The suit, filed on behalf of five students at Achievement First Crown Heights, says the children were denied services and punished unfairly.
lead_paragraph: Special education students at a Brooklyn charter school did not get mandated services and were punished for behavior that arose from their disabilities, according to a lawsuit filed in federal court on Thursday.

headline: ‘Graphic Appeal’ Explores Image Transfers at Heckscher Museum of Art
abstract: The works on display at the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington are made by transferring an image from one medium to another, usually from a block, a plate or a screen to a sheet of paper.
lead_paragraph: Some are serene landscapes. Others are vibrant abstracts. A few, like a whimsical depiction of flying slices of pizza, are mischievous illustrations. The works in “Graphic Appeal: Modern Prints From the Collection” at the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington cover a range of subjects and styles, but they have one thing in common: They were made by transferring an image from one medium to another, usually from a block, a plate or a screen to a sheet of paper.

headline: Former Manhattan Prosecutor Avoids Jail in Assault on Woman in Bar
abstract: Eli Cherkasky, 35, was ordered to perform 10 days of community service and complete counseling for alcohol abuse after being found guilty of attacking a 32-year-old woman last year.
lead_paragraph: A former prosecutor in the Manhattan district attorney’s office who was found guilty of assaulting a woman at a bar avoided jail when a judge ordered him on Thursday to perform 10 days of community service and to complete counseling for alcohol abuse.

headline: News Corp., Time Inc. and Tribune All Report Flat or Falling Quarterly Revenue
abstract: The three media companies acknowledged difficulties and planned cost cuts, but sounded a note of optimism.
lead_paragraph: When News Corporation, Time Inc. and Tribune Publishing were spun out of their respective corporate parents in recent years, it was said to be as much for the sake of the media companies themselves as for the bottom lines of the more lucrative businesses they left behind.

headline: Connecticut School Seeks to Expel 2 Accused of Wearing Columbine Costumes
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Threats and Threatening Messages', 'Halloween', 'Costumes', 'School Discipline (Students)', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)']
abstract: Some residents in Litchfield said the threats played on widespread fears in a town that is less than an hour from Newtown, where a school massacre took place three years ago.
lead_paragraph: LITCHFIELD, Conn. — Questions about when a menacing costume verges on a criminal threat swirled around this rural town after two high school sophomores were arrested and accused this week of dressing as the Columbine killers for Halloween and threatening to hurt other students.

headline: Spain’s News Media Are Squeezed by Government and Debt
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Newspapers']
abstract: The industry has faced a perfect storm of constraints, prompting worries about free expression at a time of multiplying scandals in Spain.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Newspapers almost everywhere have struggled to adjust to digital technology and declining advertising revenues.

headline: Restaurant Review: Mokomiya, a Ramen Shop in White Plains
abstract: Unlike most Japanese restaurants in the area, Mokomiya, which opened in May, does not try to appeal to suburban aesthetics or palates.
lead_paragraph: At Mokomiya, staff members call out in unison when you walk through the door: “Irasshaimase” (“Welcome,” in Japanese). Japanese-language newspapers sit in a pile at the entrance; Japanese is spoken at many of the tables.

headline: In Rio, Pacification Without Peace
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Attacks on Police', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: In Complexo do Alemão, one of Rio de Janeiro’s largest favelas, surging violence has claimed the lives of children and police officers, calling into question the government’s police pacification strategy.
lead_paragraph: In Complexo do Alemão, one of Rio de Janeiro’s largest favelas, surging violence has claimed the lives of children and police officers, calling into question the government’s police pacification strategy.

headline: ‘Bond, James Bond,’ Through the Years
abstract: The Bond movie franchise has lived on for more than a half-century. Here’s what critics of The New York Times had to say about the films starring 007 No. 1, Sean Connery.
lead_paragraph: There have been bumps in the road — moguls on the slopes — but yes, the Bond franchise has lived on, lucratively and babe-lusciously, for more than a half-century. Here’s what critics of The New York Times had to say about the films starring 007 No. 1, Sean Connery. Bosley Crowther picked up the pen for the first five.

headline: Legislators Could Upend Finance Laws in Wisconsin
abstract: State lawmakers are expected to consider campaign finance provisions that would allow practices that previously made Gov. Scott Walker a target of investigation.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — For months, it was the biggest political story in Wisconsin: a secret criminal investigation into whether Gov. Scott Walker’s campaign in a 2012 recall election had illegally coordinated fund-raising and spending with several conservative groups. But in July, the state’s conservative-leaning Supreme Court ordered the investigation ended, ruling that state campaign finance law included unconstitutionally vague language.

headline: Witness in Sheldon Silver Trial Reveals Greed Masquerading as Altruism
abstract: The case of Mr. Silver — seen as a critique of New York’s government — sheds light on the motivations and interests of the former Assembly speaker and his friends.
lead_paragraph: “Not that I am aware of,” said Victor Franco, a legislative budget director, unhappily summoned as a witness in the federal corruption trial of Sheldon Silver, the former speaker of the New York State Assembly.

headline: Authorities Assess Toll of Burst Dam in Brazil
keywords: ['Levees and Dams', 'Floods', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Mines and Mining', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Water']
abstract: The episode stunned a country that relies heavily on dams to produce electricity and on mining to generate export revenue.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — A dam from an open-pit mining complex burst on Thursday in southeastern Brazil, flooding a nearby community and enveloping homes and cars in sludge. Rescue teams descending from helicopters scoured the site for survivors.

headline: Macquarie Sets Up Brazil Infrastructure Fund
abstract: The Australian bank’s new fund comes as opportunities are seen for foreign investors in infrastructure projects.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The Macquarie Group, the Australian investment bank, has raised over 600 million reais, or $159 million, from Brazilian investors and is nearing a first close for its debut Brazil infrastructure fund, according to a person briefed on the bank’s plans.

headline: A Cell Therapy Untested in Humans Saves a Baby With Cancer
abstract: The case is significant because it indicates that cell therapies might not have to be customized for each patient.
lead_paragraph: A baby girl who was close to dying from cancer has been rescued by a cell therapy envisioned as a “one size fits all” treatment that had never been tested in people, doctors reported on Thursday.

headline: Review: In ‘The Nightingale,’ the Beauties of Rural China
abstract: Philippe Muyl’s film follows a big-city girl, her grandfather and his pet bird on a visit to the countryside.
lead_paragraph: The virtues of understatement and restraint are vividly apparent in Philippe Muyl’s “The Nightingale,” a gentle tale that could easily lapse into mawkish sentiment but largely steers clear of doing so.

headline: Nationals Keep Making Errors but Stumble Into a Winner in Dusty Baker
abstract: Washington, which floundered during the season and in its initial effort to replace the fired manager Matt Williams, finally turned to a proven commodity.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With great fanfare and no small amount of trepidation, the Washington Nationals, a laughingstock for the last few days, finally introduced a new manager on Thursday: the affable Dusty Baker.

headline: George Barris, California King of Customized Cars, Dies at 89
abstract: The man behind the Batmobile, immortalized in a Tom Wolfe essay, was a pioneer and master of car customization.
lead_paragraph: George Barris, one of the pioneer car customizers immortalized in Tom Wolfe’s essay “The Kandy-Kolored Tangerine-Flake Streamline Baby” and the designer of the Batmobile, the Munster Koach and other specialty cars for television and film, died on Thursday at his home in Encino, Calif. He was 89.

headline: F.D.A. Approves Genvoya, One-Pill Treatment for H.I.V.
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration approved a new one-pill H.I.V. treatment on Thursday with a new, apparently safer form of tenofovir, a powerful H.I.V. inhibitor.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration approved a new one-pill H.I.V. treatment on Thursday with a new, apparently safer form of tenofovir, a powerful H.I.V. inhibitor. The pill, called Genvoya, from Gilead Sciences, joins other one-pill treatments like Atripla, Complera, Triumeq and Stribild. The new form of the inhibitor, Gilead said, more efficiently enters cells where H.I.V. replicates, resulting in 91 percent less tenofovir in the bloodstream. That should make the pill less likely to cause kidney damage or loss of bone density, which have become major problems among people with H.I.V. who survive into old age.

headline: Restaurant Review: Abril Cocina in Maplewood
abstract: Abril Cocina’s corn tacos are made on the premises daily, and the sweet and smoky essence of the ground corn permeates every dish in which it appears.
lead_paragraph: Rancho La Puerta, a spa nestled in a valley near Mount Kuchumaa in Mexico, just south of the border, seems like paradise for many Americans. It does to me as well, mostly because of the meals it serves. The handmade tortillas, fresh-roasted corn, sauces and salsas are the kind of light, rarefied Mexican fusion food that is scarce in the New York area.

headline: Chief Executive of United Will Return Early Next Year
abstract: United Airlines said on Thursday that its president and chief executive, Oscar Munoz, would return in the first quarter after suffering a heart attack last month.
lead_paragraph: United Airlines said on Thursday that its president and chief executive, Oscar Munoz, would return in the first quarter after suffering a heart attack last month. Four days after Mr. Munoz was hospitalized, United named its general counsel, Brett J. Hart, as acting chief. At the time, United provided no information about when Mr. Munoz might return. Mr. Munoz was appointed in September after United dismissed its previous chief, Jeff Smisek, during a corruption investigation into the airline’s trading favors with the chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

headline: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: Festive Eggplant Rolls
abstract: If you’re looking to wow your crowd this Thanksgiving, consider these festive eggplant rolls.
lead_paragraph: If you’re looking to wow your crowd this Thanksgiving, consider these festive eggplant rolls. Courtesy of reader Christine Vartanian Datian of Las Vegas, these decadent rolls of Japanese eggplant strips, ricotta and walnuts are colorful and tasty, with an added crunch.

headline: Why Health Care Start-Ups Like Theranos Need Investing Expertise
keywords: ['Biotechnology and Bioengineering', 'Boards of Directors', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Start-ups', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: Bryan Roberts, a venture capitalist at Venrock who invests in health and biotech-related start-ups, explains the dangers of putting money into such technologies.
lead_paragraph: The Silicon Valley start-ups that often grab headlines are typically in the Internet and consumer technology world. But there’s another part of start-up land that is also highly active: health-related technology, which includes biotech, health care services and medical devices.

headline: A Centennial Celebration for Brooklyn’s Only Saint
abstract: Raphael Hawaweeny, an Eastern Orthodox priest from Syria, built churches, fought for his faith and sometimes got arrested.
lead_paragraph: Brooklyn has just one saint, and his name is Raphael Hawaweeny.

headline: Review: ‘Of Men and War’ Chronicles the Trauma of Combat Veterans
abstract: This documentary, filmed almost entirely in a California therapy center, follows a dozen war veterans racked with emotional suffering.
lead_paragraph: “Of Men and War” opens with a quotation from Erich Maria Remarque’s 1929 novel, “All Quiet on the Western Front,” but there’s no quiet to be had for any of its damaged subjects. Filmed almost entirely inside the Pathway Home in California, a residential therapy center for veterans, this devastatingly raw documentary shows that for some the fighting may stop, but the suffering continues.

headline: Restaurant Review: Bin 300 World Bistro Serves Italian Fare in Wolcott
abstract: Appearances aside, Bin 300 is, with a few exceptions, pure Italian. It counts more than a dozen pasta and risotto dishes among its regular offerings, and that is merely scratching the surface.
lead_paragraph: In the dark, earthen tones of its ocher walls and faux-brick paneling, Bin 300 World Bistro in Wolcott exudes something of the ambience of Amsterdam’s famous brown cafes. That is no easy feat, as structurally the space for the restaurant, which opened in 2007, still bears traces of its earlier inhabitant, an A & W Drive-In.

headline: Review: In ‘Palio,’ Sights and Sounds of This Sienese Horse Race
abstract: Cosima Spender’s documentary focuses on the 2013 race and the competition between two jockeys.
lead_paragraph: Chariots don’t careen around the Colosseum anymore, but the Italian city of Siena still holds a competition from the Middle Ages that evokes a gladiatorial spirit. The Palio, a horse race first recorded in 1238, is a Tuscan feast of civic pride, medieval pageantry and Machiavellian strategies.

headline: First President George Bush Swings at Son’s Aides, Rattling Clan
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Assertions in a new biography of the 41st president have exposed rifts in the Bush political dynasty. They have also complicated the efforts of another Bush, Jeb, to capture the White House.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Former President George Bush’s unusually sharp indictment of his son’s presidential advisers touched off a round of recriminations on Thursday that exposed rifts within America’s leading political dynasty and complicated its efforts to recapture the White House.

headline: Using Only Local Talent, Athletic Bilbao Goes a Long Way
abstract: While soccer clubs like Manchester United pay millions to import the game’s biggest stars, Athletic Bilbao looks no farther than its home in the Basque Country of northern Spain.
lead_paragraph: BILBAO, Spain — The buzzword at the best soccer clubs in Europe these days is global, as in global brand or global footprint or global reach. Bayern Munich wants to be known in Asia and Australia. Barcelona wants to be known in the Middle East. Everyone wants to be known in Africa and the United States.

headline: Time Inc.’s Record of the 20th Century, in Thousands of Boxes, Is Moving
abstract: As the company prepares to move to Lower Manhattan, it is donating its archive, containing a wealth of documents and artifacts of the 20th century, to the New-York Historical Society.
lead_paragraph: America’s attic is moving uptown.

headline: A Peek Inside the Boxes
abstract: Time Inc. has donated its company archive to the New-York Historical Society. Among the 7,500 linear feet of files are these intriguing objects.
lead_paragraph: Time Inc. has donated its company archive to the New-York Historical Society. Among the 7,500 linear feet of files are these intriguing objects.

headline: Canada: Interim Chief for Conservatives
abstract: Rona Ambrose, 46, of Alberta, is widely seen as less partisan than many of her Conservative colleagues.
lead_paragraph: Following its election defeat last month and the resignation of Prime Minister Stephen Harper, the caucus of the Conservative Party of Canada elected Rona Ambrose, 46, of Alberta, as its interim leader on Thursday. Ms. Ambrose, who was first elected to Parliament in 2004, has been the minister of eight departments, including the department responsible for environmental matters. She is widely seen as less partisan than many of her Conservative colleagues. Under the party rules, Ms. Ambrose will not be able to run in the coming party race to select a permanent replacement for Mr. Harper. But as leader of the opposition, she will get a pay raise as well as an official residence. Mr. Harper will continue to represent his Calgary, Alberta, constituency as a member of Parliament.

headline: Review: ‘Peggy Guggenheim: Art Addict,’ Portrait of an Heiress With a Cause
abstract: Lisa Immordino Vreeland’s documentary tracks Guggenheim, the collector and gallerist, on her European travels and her mission to promote Modern art.
lead_paragraph: “Peggy Guggenheim: Art Addict,” Lisa Immordino Vreeland’s sleek, entertaining portrait of the collector and gallerist who assembled one of the great troves of Modern art, cannot be accused of hagiography. From curators to historians to biographers, art world denizens describe Guggenheim’s flaws and failings: She had no formal training; she used art to promote herself; she was a narcissist. And that’s just in the first five minutes.

headline: Battling Depression, and Getting a Clearer View of His Future
abstract: William Medonis was feeling the weight of mental illness when his brother’s death set him back further. Now, with improved self-esteem and a new pair of glasses, he is getting his life back on track.
lead_paragraph: It was shortly after he found his brother’s body inside the small apartment they shared in New Rochelle, N.Y., that depression, so severe it had already made him give up on school and his job, made William Medonis want to give up on his own life.

headline: Review: ‘Sembène!,’ a Documentary About the Senegalese Auteur
abstract: The film focuses on the life and legacy of the director Ousmane Sembène, who showed a fearlessness in a country with no cinematic tradition.

headline: Review: ‘On Your Feet!’ Rides the Rhythm of the Estefans
abstract: This musical about Emilio and Gloria Estefan tracks their career and marriage, including the accident that threatened her life.
lead_paragraph: The recipe may be familiar, but the flavor is fresh in “On Your Feet!,” the half-formulaic, half-original and undeniably crowd-pleasing musical about the lives of Emilio and Gloria Estefan that opened on Thursday at the Marquis Theater.

lead_paragraph: Robert P. DeVecchi, who helped resettle dispossessed people around the world as director, president and, ultimately, chief executive of the International Rescue Committee, died on Oct. 26 at his home in Southport, Conn. He was 85.

headline: Austerity’s Grim Legacy
keywords: ['Recession and Depression', 'United States Economy', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The deficit fetishism that led to government cutbacks has been more destructive in the long run than even its critics anticipated.
lead_paragraph: When economic crisis struck in 2008, policy makers by and large did the right thing. The Federal Reserve and other central banks realized that supporting the financial system took priority over conventional notions of monetary prudence. The Obama administration and its counterparts realized that in a slumping economy budget deficits were helpful, not harmful. And the money-printing and borrowing worked: A repeat of the Great Depression, which seemed all too possible at the time, was avoided.

headline: In Iran, a Deal and Then a Crackdown
abstract: Hard-liners are sending a message to moderates by rounding up journalists and activists.
lead_paragraph: The anti-American backlash in Iran since the nuclear deal was signed has gotten so bad that one Iranian-American businessman in Tehran now likens it to a witch hunt. As alarming as that is, the crackdown will probably get worse.

headline: In the Dry West, Waiting for Congress
abstract: Battles over water along a western river have been resolved by the combatants but they need Congress to sign off on their deal.
lead_paragraph: Klamath Falls, Ore. — DROUGHT in the West is an ugly thing. Rivers trickle away to nothing, fires rage, crops fail, ranchers go broke, tribal people watch fish die. As Westerners fight over the little water left, tempers crack, lawsuits fly and bitterness coats whole communities like fine dust.

One must be a neurosurgeon who chased his mother with a hammer as a child; a senator whose father was beaten toothless in prison and fled Cuba with $100 sewn into his underwear; or a former secretary of state whose mother went without food as a first grader.

headline: Meeting With Taiwan Reflects Limits of China’s Checkbook
abstract: Even as China has assumed the role of a global power, its one-note focus on economic relations has sometimes backfired.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — For the past eight years, the Chinese government has showered its former enemies in Taiwan with economic gifts: direct flights, commercial deals, even an undersea water pipeline. Trade is up more than 50 percent, and mainland tourists, once barred from traveling to the island, now arrive in droves, nearly four million last year alone.

lead_paragraph: A South Bronx warehouse near the Third Avenue Bridge was transformed into a backdrop for a pop-up art show two nights before Halloween. Outside, fires burned in trash cans for warmth. Inside, there was a sculpture fashioned from bullet-riddled cars.

keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Social Media', 'Cooperatives', 'Condominiums', 'Libel and Slander', 'Computers and the Internet']

lead_paragraph: Complaining about the co-op or condominium board is practically a blood sport in New York, an unfortunate side effect of living under the rule of elected volunteers. Usually, disputes go no further than a heated exchange at the annual meeting. Much like a family feud, the dirty laundry is rarely aired in public. But thanks to the Internet, that is changing.

headline: Driving Alaska’s Dalton Highway
abstract: Finding that there can be solace in solitude in a 400-mile drive on one of America’s loneliest roads.
lead_paragraph: On the Dalton Highway, most conversations concern the Dalton Highway. Though there aren’t many people on the road, they inevitably talk about the road. My first conversation, during a three-day drive along the isolated freeway in Alaska, was with a man named Steven Duffy who was working as a waiter at the Yukon River Camp, a lonesome rest stop marooned among the spruce trees four hours north of Fairbanks.

headline: Review: Finding Beauty in a Wrenching ‘Lulu’ at the Met
abstract: The South African artist’s version of Alban Berg’s bleak, confounding story is worthy of its landmark stature: visually stunning and superbly performed.
lead_paragraph: The South African artist William Kentridge is now two for two at the Metropolitan Opera. In 2010, in a momentous company debut, he directed a dazzling, frenetic production of Shostakovich’s wildly satirical opera “The Nose,” based on a Gogol short story. The staging, which involved inventive projections and animated drawings by Mr. Kentridge, was not just the talk of the opera world. It made the Met the center of the New York contemporary art scene for the duration of the run.

headline: Sex, Death and Mushrooms
keywords: ['Mushrooms', 'Fungi', 'Sex', 'Death and Dying', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Food']
abstract: Contemplating mortality during a fungus-hunting expedition in a forest moving toward winter.
lead_paragraph: The forest air is sweet and winy with decay. It’s raining hard. I wipe drops of cold water from the tip of my nose, open an umbrella and ready myself for a walk with my old friend Nick, emeritus professor of the history of science and amateur mycologist. For the last 15 years I’ve accompanied him on autumn mushroom hunts; today we’re visiting Thetford Forest, in Suffolk. Both of us carry trugs, traditional English wooden baskets of willow and sweet chestnut, to hold what we will find. Perhaps tiny fungi with hairlike stalks, or lumpy shelves on the trunks of rotting trees, or pale masses like discarded round pillows, or splayed red starfish arms emerging from the ground.

headline: A Long Engagement
abstract: In the country formerly known as Burma, a marriage that never was.
lead_paragraph: I first learned of my would-be betrothal to a man named Stephen in 1993, when I was 21. My parents had just returned to the States from a trip to the territory of my mother’s people, the Karen; their home is the country I will always call Burma, though it had been renamed Myanmar by its military-backed government. A 29-year-old soldier engaged in resistance against the junta, this Karen man was also a self-taught programmer and engineer — and he appeared to have dazzled my parents. ‘‘I promised you in marriage to him,’’ my mother informed me, only half in jest.

headline: How to Make a Time Capsule
abstract: Include a touch of social criticism. Keep above ground.
lead_paragraph: ‘‘Be anti-tech when it comes to what you put inside,’’ says William E. Jarvis, a founder of the International Time Capsule Society. You don’t want your message to the future formatted irretrievably on an obsolete technology like a floppy disk. Include stable items that will not damage everything else by corroding (electronics), exploding (beer bottles) or decomposing (flora and fauna). Put in objects that show evidence of human touch. ‘‘Suppose you wanted to include a book of erotica,’’ Jarvis says. ‘‘Make it a used one, so that the person who finds it can tell which pages have been thumbed more.’’

headline: ‘My Life’
abstract: Selected by Natasha Trethewey.
lead_paragraph: The subtlest changes in syntax can work in a poem to evoke a feeling of strangeness. Here, the inversion in the first line places the emphasis not on the sentence’s noun, the “I,” but on the comparison to the biblical story. And the alliteration and cadences of the lines evoke the actual feeling of tumbling — “How heel over head was I hurled down.” That inversion of heel and head enlivens a common phrase, making the poem an experience in language.

headline: Gary Danielson of CBS on L.S.U.-Alabama and Going Pro Early
abstract: The commentator, who will be at Saturday night’s game in Tuscaloosa, spoke about the rise of the Tigers’ and the Crimson Tide’s conference and rivalry.

abstract: The country has become a fulcrum of the refugees’ path toward Western and Northern Europe, shifting the course as conditions change and borders tighten or close.

abstract: The new patrol officers, whose training emphasizes public service, are being held up as a tangible sign of change in a corrupt criminal justice system.

headline: Of Mice and Apartment Sales
abstract: Rodents seek shelter from the cold in city apartments. Spotting one is unnerving, but the predicament takes on new urgency if you’re planning to sell.
lead_paragraph: Each fall, rodents, seeking shelter from the cold, take up residence in apartments across New York City — gnawing on electrical wires and leaving droppings in kitchen cupboards. Spotting one of these uninvited guests scurrying under the refrigerator is unnerving enough, but the predicament takes on new urgency if you’re planning to put your apartment on the market.

headline: In Tunisia, a Mission of Justice and a Moment of Reckoning

lead_paragraph: TUNIS — FOR Sihem Bensedrine, it sometimes seems as though the Arab Spring revolution never happened. As the head of Tunisia’s Truth and Dignity Commission, she is in charge of guiding the country through a process of transitional justice for the crimes of past regimes, a sharp turnaround after nearly 60 years of dictatorship.

lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton has in the past week tried to keep the news media glare focused squarely on the Republican candidates. She has delivered her standard stump speech in Iowa, flown with her head down on a commercial flight to Chicago and remained relatively under the radar, even while attending star-studded fund-raisers hosted by Christina Aguilera and Rob Reiner.

headline: Daily Report: A $1 Billion Bet on Artificial Intelligence in Silicon Valley
abstract: Interest and investment in artificial intelligence is back with a vengeance in Silicon Valley, attracting companies such as Toyota to make big bets in the space.
lead_paragraph: Artificial intelligence has waxed and waned as a topic of interest in Silicon Valley over the decades. Now there is a fever pitch over it, with behemoths including Apple, Alphabet’s Google and Facebook increasingly playing in the space. Numerous start-ups have also sprung up around machine learning.

headline: Hike They Shouldn’t
abstract: One month changes little.
lead_paragraph: Does today’s good job report mean that the Fed will raise rates next month? Probably yes. Does it mean that the Fed should raise rates? Definitely not. The arguments against an early rate rise remain compelling, and shouldn’t be abandoned based on one month’s data.

headline: This Artist’s Work Takes a Village — Literally
abstract: Liza Lou often seeks community participation to help assemble her works; a new show features her largest sculpture to date.
lead_paragraph: Anything can happen when the artist Liza Lou, who frequently seeks out community participation, gathers a group to help her assemble artworks for her exhibitions. “I’ve had situations where people meet each other and end up getting married,” she says — an observation she’s quick to qualify. “I don’t want to publicly promise that if you work on my project, you’ll end up married. But it’s self-selecting. The people who come tend to be interested in art. It can bring out some quirkiness.”

headline: The Long Shadow of China’s One-Child Policy
abstract: The government edict may now be a thing of the past, but its impact will stretch far into the future.
lead_paragraph: If you get stuck in a crowd in China — it’s not hard to do in a country of nearly 1.4 billion — you may hear someone mutter, “Ren tai duo!”: “Too many people!” It’s a common but misleading complaint. The real demographic crisis that prompted the Chinese government’s decision last week to end its one-child policy is more palpable on the quiet Shanghai lane where I live with my family: There is a dearth of young people.

headline: An Old Paris Hotel, in the Hands of a Graffiti Artist
abstract: André Saraiva teamed up with the writers Glenn O’Brien and Olivier Zahm to reimagine the famous Hôtel Grand Amour.
lead_paragraph: For nearly a decade, the tiny Hôtel Amour in Paris lured a certain clientele with its disco balls, black walls and phallic furniture. ‘‘There’s never room anymore,’’ says André Saraiva, the graffiti artist, nightlife impresario and co-owner. But with his new Hôtel Grand Amour, a Napoleon III-style building in the 10th Arrondissement with 44 rooms, some featuring libraries ‘‘curated’’ by the fashion writers Glenn O’Brien and Olivier Zahm, and art by the likes of Keith Haring and Petra Collins, he hopes to remedy that. There’s also a spa, a cafe, an upscale brasserie and a cocktail lounge inspired by the Ritz’s Bar Hemingway. ‘‘You could literally never leave,’’ says Saraiva.

headline: 1890: Irish Ether Drinkers
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The peasantry in the North of Ireland take to drinking ether in 1890.
lead_paragraph: A special investigation of the ether drinking in the North of Ireland led to the conclusion that the ether drinking area may be roughly said to embrace the mountainous and barren districts of the counties of Londonderry, Tyrone, Armagh and Antrim, the former two being the principal localities. Ether seems to be a great surprise to the temperance advocates of to-day, to those who wage war on alcoholic stimulants. Curiously enough, it originated with the great teetotal movement of fifty years ago.

headline: The Venetian Ghetto’s Hidden Gems
abstract: You would never know that behind the entirely nondescript facade of the city’s old Jewish quarter are five exquisite synagogues, each with its own particular style.
lead_paragraph: In the context of Jewish history, the word ‘‘ghetto’’ carries with it an unmistakable fatalism. But long before the Holocaust, the term had a different set of connotations. The Jewish quarters of the great European capitals — Paris’s Marais, Frankfurt’s Judengasse, Amsterdam’s Jodenbuurt — were testaments to the diversity and richness of Jewish life. Often sites of mandated segregation ridden with poverty and plague, they also fostered cultural exchange and intellectual vitality. Nowhere was this more apparent than in Venice, which established one of Europe’s first Jewish ghettos in 1516 in the Cannaregio district, on a small island where the city's cannons had previously been cast: the foundry, or ‘‘geto.’’

headline: Mass Atrocities Looming in Burundi?
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Leaders of Burundi are using language that recalls the run-up to the genocide in Rwanda next door. The international community needs to act urgently to avert what may be a humanitarian catastrophe.
lead_paragraph: There’s evidence that we may be on the brink of a humanitarian calamity in Burundi, a small central African nation that has seen waves of killings in its history. It has been unstable for months, but now the authorities are using language that recalls the run-up to the 1994 genocide in Rwanda, right next door. A few officials are blowing the whistle — including Samantha Power, who chronicled genocide in her brilliant book and yesterday as ambassador to the U.N. put out a statement on the crisis. But we need a much stronger reaction, immediately, from top U.N. officials including Ban Ki-moon and from African leaders.

lead_paragraph: THE SENSE OF STYLE: The Thinking Person’s Guide to Writing in the 21st Century, by Steven Pinker. (Penguin, $17.) headline: Bridget O’Neill and Justin Simons: A Couple Fostering Love (and Children)
abstract: In their early twenties, the couple fostered 13 children over three years. Now they are on to the next chapter.
lead_paragraph: By switching up the order in which normal courtships unfold, Bridget O’Neill and Justin Simons got an advance look at what sort of long-term couple they might make. Not to mention what type of parents they would be.

headline: Isol’s ‘The Menino,’ and More
abstract: Three books feature exuberant little ones who stretch — but never break — their mysterious bond with parents.
lead_paragraph: A few years after the fact, my youngest daughter asked, “How’d you get milk to come out of your boobs?” My first answer was a stilted, “Uhh.” I was embarrassed to have such a loose grip on my own biology. “I don’t really know.” She proposed a miniature cow inside my rib cage. She waded fearlessly into the unknown. When everything is strange and new, minor mysteries (popcorn, tuning forks) carry the same weight as the nonminor mysteries (biology, birth, death and the sometimes lonely in-between). Three new books rely on the supple child mind to help us see the familiar as something wholly new and surprising. Like the farsighted reader who requires distance to see clearly, these books make room for mystery in order to understand the wondrously complex and totally basic bond between children and their parents.

lead_paragraph: Inside the Library Services Center in Queens, a 238-foot conveyor belt sorts about 30,000 items for the New York and Brooklyn Public Libraries.

headline: ‘Crenshaw,’ by Katherine Applegate
abstract: His family on the verge of homelessness, a boy summons an imaginary friend.
lead_paragraph: A 400-pound gorilla casts a large shadow. In 2013, Katherine Applegate won the Newbery Medal for “The One and Only Ivan,” the story of a gorilla kept in a strip-mall circus. Ivan, the gorilla, frees himself and a young elephant by communicating with humans through finger-painting. “Ivan” was a winning tale for many ­reasons: It was based, loosely, on a true story; it addressed the issue of animal cruelty honestly, but in a manner that children could handle; it was technically original, telling the story from Ivan’s perspective, in short chapters that read like prose poems. But the primary reason “Ivan” has become such a beloved book is Ivan himself. His frank wisdom about life, both human and animal, provokes laughter and thought; his aspirations — to become an artist, and to liberate himself through art — feel universal.
