lead_paragraph: SPECIAL rules apply to older people who contribute to tax-favored health savings accounts as they near age 65 and become eligible for federal Medicare coverage.

headline: Libraries in New York and Seattle Area Staging a Battle of the Sorters
abstract: Public libraries in New York have one hour to defend the city’s title as home to “the world’s fastest library-sorting system” and to break a 2-2 tie with a team from Seattle.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Salvatore Magaddino will crank up the “Rocky” theme song and deliver a pep talk. His crew will then have one hour to defend the city’s title as home to “the world’s fastest library-sorting system” (at least according to the trophy) and to break its 2-2 tie with a squad from the King County Library System, which serves the area around Seattle.

headline: 1940: Japanese Fear Poll Result
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Japan regards the re-election of President Roosevelt as ominous in 1940.
lead_paragraph: TOKIO — The re-election of President Roosevelt for a third term is regarded by Japanese in all circles as of ominous portent so far as American-Japanese relations are concerned. Japanese were hoping Wendell L. Willkie would be elected, not because they believed American pressure on Japan would be greatly relaxed, but because they considered a change might bring about a betterment, while they regarded a continuance of the Roosevelt policy as presaging further aggravation of relations with the United States.

headline: FIFA’s Sepp Blatter Being Treated for ‘Stress-Related’ Medical Issue
abstract: Blatter’s lawyer said the FIFA president was in a hospital for a ‘checkup’ but was expected to return home shortly.
lead_paragraph: The suspended FIFA president Sepp Blatter was treated at a hospital on Friday but was expected to be released shortly, his lawyer said. An adviser to Mr. Blatter said the incident was “related to stress.”

headline: ‘Fuzzy Mud,’ by Louis Sachar
abstract: When friends find a pool of toxic ooze, their town is quarantined and a cover-up exposed.
lead_paragraph: Adults have it rough in children’s literature. Mothers vanish, fathers get slain, grim teen societies herd all the grown-ups into their own boring corners of the planet. It’s not that children’s authors dislike adults, exactly. It’s more an issue of plotting: Stories are more interesting when protagonists have the ability to change the world around them, for good or for bad — and kids will be the first to tell you that they become pretty powerless whenever adults are on the scene.

headline: If Jobs Report Heralds a Solid Upturn, Democrats’ Fortunes May Also Rise
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Interest Rates', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Wages and Salaries', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A more tangible economic upswing could help Democrats keep the White House after the Obama administration’s long struggle with slow economic recovery.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Friday’s surprisingly robust jobs report cheered Democrats hoping to retain the White House and capture the Senate next year, but it heralded a new atmosphere of uncertainty by flashing a green light to the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates, which could undermine economic growth.

headline: ‘The Trouble in Me’ and ‘Orbiting Jupiter’
abstract: The teenage protagonists of these young adult novels take up with disturbed older boys, with mixed results.
lead_paragraph: Jack Gantos and his publisher encourage you to think of “The Trouble in Me” as a prequel to his celebrated memoir “Hole in My Life” — and I encourage you to ignore them. The books are so different in tone, in what they strive for and what they achieve, that they could meet at a party, get drunk and go home together without ever knowing that they’re cousins. Instead, let’s consider Gantos’s novel as spiritual kin to another new Y.A. novel from a highly decorated pro: Gary D. Schmidt’s “Orbiting Jupiter.” Here are two books about the perilous moment in a boy’s life when he is so desperate to define himself — so open to influence — that just getting to know a troubled older kid is like walking into a storm.

headline: The Return of London’s Fog
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: The city’s famous air pollution is coming back. So why won’t politicians do anything?
lead_paragraph: Cambridge, England — IN January, researchers at King’s College London announced that pollution levels on Oxford Street, in central London, had exceeded limits set for the entire year in just the first four days of 2015. Similarly alarming numbers have been recorded for other streets in the city — and yet the mayor, Boris Johnson, has delayed implementation of stricter air-quality measures until 2020.

headline: An Early Whiff of Dogs or Hogs May Lessen Asthma Risk
abstract: Exposure to dogs or farm animals in early childhood significantly reduces the risk for asthma, a large study has found.
lead_paragraph: Exposure to dogs or farm animals in early childhood significantly reduces the risk for asthma, a large study has found.

headline: Fashion
abstract: New books by Amy Odell, Cintra Wilson, Andrew Wilson and Gioia Diliberto.
lead_paragraph: TALES FROM THE BACK ROWAn Outsider’s View From Inside the Fashion Industry By Amy Odell231 pp. Simon & Schuster, $25.

headline: ‘Hotel’ and ‘Vertigo,’ by Joanna Walsh
abstract: A memoir and a story collection explore guarded and uprooted lives.
lead_paragraph: I recently encountered a new nonfiction term: “the constructed I.” A quick consideration of any classic nonfiction text — one by Joan Didion, say — yields that the “I” in essays, journalism and memoirs is usually a partial invention. A nonfiction writer artfully sculptures an “I” narrator, similar to the way fiction writers sculpture their narrators. But what happens when a narrator is too constructed? When does artfulness ossify into artifice?

headline: Ban Before Reading
abstract: How it feels to have your book suspended from a high school’s English curriculum.
lead_paragraph: Friends and family congratulated me, book sales bounced a little and a 10-year-old title was suddenly under discussion by people who had never read it. I had been awarded literary recognition of a peculiar kind, one that brought me no euphoria. Along with six other books opposed by conservative parents in a wealthy school district near Dallas, my book “The Working Poor: Invisible in America,” a nonideological portrayal of lives near the bottom, was suspended from the English curriculum at Highland Park High School, where it had been used in advanced placement classes.

headline: Activision Plans Its Own Studio to Showcase Its Games
abstract: Activision Blizzard said a newly formed studios unit would develop and produce movies and TV shows based on about 1,000 titles in its company library.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Activision Blizzard, a gaming company that this week disclosed plans to acquire King Digital Entertainment for $5.9 billion, said it already had a next step in mind: the creation of an internal film and television studio.

headline: ‘The Reproach of Hunger,’ by David Rieff
abstract: An examination of conventional wisdom about world hunger’s causes, and its future.
lead_paragraph: Hunger is probably the most salient consequence of poverty. This salience has some rationale: Hunger makes food a priority, and poor people spend about half of their income on it. But hunger is, nevertheless, a symptom of poverty, not a problem to be tackled in isolation — the solution to hunger may not have much to do with the supply of food. In this rambling book, David Rieff never quite recognizes this fundamental point. Positing that the 2008 spike in global food prices marked the start of structurally higher prices, his discussion revolves around whether we should look for the solution of extra food production in technocratic philanthropy, global agribusiness or revolutionary politics. Arriving at an answer that none look promising, he asks, “Where does this leave us?”

headline: ‘Kid Moses,’ by Mark R. Thornton
abstract: A homeless Tanzanian boy leaves Dar es Salaam for the unknown wilderness in this debut novel.
lead_paragraph: In the English-speaking world, “safari” evokes gaggles of sunburned tourists in pith helmets, gawking at lions and ­elephants from the safety of open-topped all-terrain vehicles before ending the day with gin and tonics and Instagrams of acacia trees silhouetted against fiery African sunsets. In Swahili, “safari” just means a trip, a plain old trip of any variety.

headline: Putin, Reimagined
abstract: Authors with Russian roots discuss why Putin might appeal to novelists.
lead_paragraph: This week, we look at two new books about Vladimir Putin and Russia under his rule (“The New Tsar” and “Winter Is Coming.”). Putin has also inspired fiction writers, appearing as himself (or in thin disguise) in books by Charles Cumming, Martin Cruz Smith and others. I asked authors with Russian roots why Putin might appeal to novelists.

headline: ‘Becoming Nicole,’ by Amy Ellis Nutt
abstract: A family rises to the challenge when their son insists he is a girl.
lead_paragraph: “Becoming Nicole: The Transformation of an American Family,” by Amy Ellis Nutt, generously traces the parameters of parental love. It tells the story of Wayne and Kelly Maines, a good-hearted, hard-working American couple, neither rich nor poor, neither fabulous nor downtrodden, who after years of trying to conceive a baby are finally given the opportunity to adopt: infant boys, identical twins, the children of Kelly’s second cousin. The Maineses name the babies Jonas and Wyatt, and immediately the low expectations that come with unmet yearning give way to the more self-centered aspirations that accompany getting what you want. Fantasies of imprinting upon these inchoate beings a storybook childhood preoccupy both parents, but especially Wayne, who sees in fatherhood a chance at passing down the rites and traditions of American manhood. Still in the hospital, Wayne cradles the babies and murmurs to them as if reciting a prayer: My boys, my boys. “We’re going to have so much fun together,” he whispers in the twins’ ears. “We’re going to go hunting and fishing and I will teach you everything I know.”

headline: Sonia Manzano’s ‘Becoming Maria’ and Margarita Engle’s ‘Enchanted Air’
abstract: Look for your life: Two Latina writers explore the experience of finding their own way among multiple cultures.
lead_paragraph: From the very first sentence, Margarita Engle’s memoir “Enchanted Air” takes wing. “When my parents met, it was love at first sight,” Engle writes. “They were standing on the terrace of an art school in an elegant palace now known as the Museo Romántico, the Romantic Museum.” Since her Cuban mother and American father did not speak the same language, they “communicated by passing drawings back and forth, like children in the back of a classroom. . . . Sketches, signs and gestures had to substitute for words.”

headline: ‘Dream On, Amber’ and ‘Full Cicada Moon’
abstract: In two books, biracial girls face an absent father, a cross-country move and the bigotry of those around them.
lead_paragraph: Children’s literature has been engulfed in a conversation on the lack of books featuring minority characters. This call for diversity has been accompanied by uncomfortable yet necessary debates about what constitutes quality representation, and few people agree on that. Two new novels about biracial girls illustrate the range of approaches authors can take to these issues.

headline: Philip C. Stead’s ‘Lenny & Lucy,’ and More
abstract: Imaginary sidekicks help their picture-book friends through tight spots and tough times.
lead_paragraph: “It is through fantasy that children achieve catharsis,” Maurice Sendak said when he accepted the Caldecott Medal for “Where the Wild Things Are” in 1964. “It is the best means they have for taming Wild Things.” In four new picture books about imaginary friends, conjured companions of all kinds help children confront the beastly parts of life. In these books, the children’s situations change when they meet real-life friends, but reassuringly, their chimerical pals never disappear.

headline: ‘The Hired Girl,’ by Laura Amy Schlitz
abstract: Escaping a brutal home, this protagonist models herself on inspiring fictional characters.
lead_paragraph: Surrounded by a brutish father and brothers and aching for her dead mother, 14-year-old Joan Skraggs runs away from her family’s Pennsylvania farm, makes her way to Baltimore, and is rescued from a park bench by a well-dressed young man. She presents herself as Janet Lovelace, age 18, and becomes “the hired girl,” a servant to the Rosenbachs — a prosperous Jewish family who own a department store. It’s 1911, the tail end of the Gilded Age, and world wars have yet to break out. Janet keeps a diary, and the reader quickly gleans that her notions of life come from three books: “Jane Eyre,” “Dombey and Son” and “Ivanhoe.” “I plan to go on as bravely as a heroine in a novel,” she writes. “In my new life I’m not going to be vulgar. Even though I’m going to be a servant I’m going to cultivate my finer feelings. I will better myself and write with truth and refinement.”

headline: ‘The Rest of Us Just Live Here,’ by Patrick Ness
abstract: A novel plays with Y.A. formulas, keeping the supernaturally special teenagers in the background.
lead_paragraph: At my typical public high school in an average-size town, I was surrounded by a lot of kids just like me — that is to say, no one had any special powers. There were no vampires. No witches. No werewolves or shape shifters or zombie fighters. No one was on a mission to save the world from the forces of evil. Mostly, we were learning to drive cars, trying to pass calculus, angling for the first glimmerings of what adult relationships might hold. We were teenagers, for all the beauty and mundanity in that. It was horrible, fantastic, brutal, magical and sometimes utterly boring. It was, in a word, life.

headline: Rick Riordan’s ‘Magnus Chase and the Gods of Asgard’
abstract: A novel from the author of the Percy Jackson series uses a boy’s adventure to enter the world of Norse mythology.
lead_paragraph: The line between cynical repetition and elegant variation is as fine in adventure stories as it is in — well, as it is in that line the members of Spinal Tap sapiently discovered between clever and stupid. Rick Riordan, after the well-earned triumph of his two Percy Jackson series, tales of an all-American boy who discovers that he is the son of a Greek god, now embarks, with “Magnus Chase and the Gods of Asgard: The Sword of Summer,” on an entirely new series, this one about a not-quite-all-American boy who discovers he is the son of . . . a Norse god. The boys are certainly different ­— Magnus, our new hero, a Kurt Cobain look-alike, starts out homeless and a petty thief in Boston, where Percy was at boarding school.

headline: ‘Everything, Everything,’ by Nicola Yoon
abstract: A girl whose compromised immune system has kept her isolated decides to take a risk for love in this young adult novel.
lead_paragraph: Even if you knew love could kill you, what would you risk to experience it — just once? Just for a little while?

headline: ‘Out of Darkness,’ by Ashley Hope Pérez
abstract: Racism, love and friendship power a story that begins with a girl’s pain and ends in a town’s tragedy.
lead_paragraph: The novels that burn into our minds as young adults often involve horror of some kind. A mere mention of “All Quiet on the Western Front” or “I Am the Cheese,” and I’m right back to brooding again in the ocean-deep emotions of my adolescence. What is that urge, the desire to soak in anguish and injustice as we come of age? Whatever it is, Ashley Hope Pérez’s new novel, “Out of Darkness,” fills the need. Her layered tale of color lines, love and struggle in an East Texas oil town is a pit-in-the-stomach family drama that goes down like it should, with pain and fascination, like a mix of sugary medicine and artisanal moonshine. I actually had to close the book at one point to seek respite with Facebook. And puppies.

headline: ‘The League of Unexceptional Children,’ by Gitty Daneshvari
abstract: A middle-grade novel invents a spy network of children so ordinary they can carry out their mission without being noticed.
lead_paragraph: The cloak of American exceptionalism wears some permanent stains down its front — like slavery and the denial of civil rights. And fresh stains, too, like exaggerated income inequality. Likewise, the reality of the elite, exceptional American child is hardly as pristine as many parents imagine. Our “gifted and talented” Mandarin-speaking, travel-team-­captaining, polished-in-selfies youth are often characterized by narcissism, the pursuit of achievement at any cost, toxic stress and greed: grade greed, accomplishment greed, résumé greed. Precocious superstardom is not always happy. And regular, average childhood is not necessarily a problem that needs fixing.

headline: ‘Vasilisa the Beautiful’ Retold by Anthea Bell, and More
abstract: Three illustrated books for a broad range of ages find ways to shine new light on classic fairy tales.
lead_paragraph: Fairy tale retellings: Climb up a pile of these revamped, remixed and rehabilitated classics and we reach high enough to wake the giant. And yet, no matter how much we empower the princess, humanize the witch and emasculate the prince, or how earnestly we whack and whittle these tales to reflect us, we seem only to make the original tales stronger.

headline: ‘A Step Toward Falling,’ by Cammie McGovern
abstract: After an assault, four high school students, two with mental disabilities, become linked by universal emotions and challenges.
lead_paragraph: Cammie McGovern’s “A Step Toward Falling” opens with two high school seniors, Emily and Lucas, taking on 40 hours of community service at a center for young adults with disabilities. Emily and Lucas will serve as models for “a typical peer’s approach to friendship and dating” in a class called Boundaries and Relationships. They are not there by choice.

headline: ‘The Snow Rabbit,’ by Camille Garoche, and More
abstract: From toys left to their own devices to an enchanted hare to a zooful of playfellows, flights of flakes lead to flights of fancy.
lead_paragraph: What is the secret to snow’s alchemy — its power to transform any ordinary street into its own world? Backyards, driveways and rooftops take cover under white and everything is changed. Snow means gloves and boots and anticipation. It doubles your speed downhill, then cushions your fall at the bottom. It makes it much harder for school buses to reach their destination. But as three new books show, our captivation lies in something more than the break from routine and the opportunity for daredevil stunts. We make snowmen, we make angels, we build fortresses and we leave our footsteps wherever we go. After it snows, we sculpture the world around us, carving out stages upon which our imaginations perform.

headline: Steve Sheinkin’s ‘Most Dangerous’
abstract: An account of Daniel Ellsberg and his release of the Pentagon Papers introduces young readers to the Vietnam War.
lead_paragraph: About 70 pages into his gripping new history for young readers, “Most Dangerous: Daniel Ellsberg and the Secret History of the Vietnam War,” Steve Sheinkin seems to switch genres, describing a scene that could have been taken from “The Walking Dead”: a trailer full of corpses, its floor “streaked with blood and brains.” Arms and legs were falling off the rotting trunks, which made it difficult to count how many bodies were in the trailer. The stench was unbearable. So the bodies were hosed down and the trailer tipped to its side, letting, as one witness put it, a “rivulet of blood-colored water” flow outside. A delegation of American military officers passed by, stepping over the blood “to avoid ruining the shine on their boots.”

headline: Inside the List
abstract: “Depraved Heart,” Patricia Cornwell’s 23rd mystery about the medical examiner Kay Scarpetta, enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 3.
lead_paragraph: Fight or Flight: “Depraved Heart,” Patricia Cornwell’s 23rd mystery about the medical examiner Kay Scarpetta — Kirkus Reviews called it “terse and tangled, messy and body-fluid-y and altogether satisfying” — enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 3. In a profile last year, The Telegraph noted that Cornwell has “the coiled-up, fight-or-flight air of a lynx about to spring,” a trait evident on her website’s home page, where a video shows her coolly handling an MP5 submachine gun. “I can’t imagine writing about a certain type of rifle or a type of shotgun or a certain handgun for anything, and not having any experience with it,” she explains in the video. Cornwell has been known to take her research to extremes: She spent six years in a forensics lab to learn Scarpetta’s job and went on to scuba dive, fly a helicopter and stab sides of beef wrapped in wool, all in the name of getting things right. “People now have such short attention spans that I have to try really hard to keep the suspense going, so they don’t have a reason to put down my book and read 20,000 tweets instead,” Cornwell told The Telegraph. “Crime novels are a great excuse to get people together and to . . . examine issues that affect us all,” she added. “The crime is just the party to get the people to show up.”

headline: Don Brown’s ‘Aaron and Alexander,’ and More
abstract: From conflict to confederation, three new picture books conjure portions of the past.
lead_paragraph: Once a lion and a man were walking, and they saw a great bronze sculpture on a pedestal. A bronze man was locked in battle with a fearsome bronze lion. The bronze man had pinned the bronze lion to the base of the pedestal and was clearly about to win the fight. The man said to the lion, “What a battle that must have been, can you imagine that, a man beating a lion?” The lion said to the man, “No, I can’t, but I can imagine that men are much better at making bronze ­sculptures.”

headline: ‘The Blackthorn Key’ and ‘The Doldrums’
abstract: An orphan searches for a killer, and a sheltered kid leaves home to find missing grandparents.
lead_paragraph: When Christopher Rowe, the central character of Kevin Sands’s “The Blackthorn Key,” is taken from a miserable life at an orphanage and apprenticed to the gentle, absent-minded apothecary Master Benedict Blackthorn, he displays both curiosity and intelligence. Other than an unfortunate incident involving gunpowder and a stuffed bear, his master is happy with him. But soon apothecaries start turning up dead all over London. After Christopher’s master is pulled into the gruesome affair, the boy tries to learn who is behind the murders. His loyal and often unappreciated best friend, Tom, accompanies him on a quest that tests both boys’ mettle, their ability to solve complicated riddles and the strength of their ­friendship.

headline: Facts & Figures: What Law Enforcement Agencies Think About Marijuana
abstract: Very few consider it the biggest drug threat they face.
lead_paragraph: A recent Drug Enforcement Administration survey asked law enforcement agencies to name the “greatest drug threat” in their area. Marijuana was the least common choice, with only 6 percent of agencies identifying it as the biggest threat.

headline: Financial Advice for Women, From Women
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Financial Planners', 'Personal Finances', 'Savings', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: A spate of new robo-adviser financial sites aimed at women look to empower them to build net worth, rather than offer household budgeting advice.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a long time since a talking teenage Barbie doll uttered the words, “Math class is tough!” That was 1992, and the uproar that ensued caused Mattel to banish the words from Barbie’s vocabulary.

headline: The End of Chapter 11 Bankruptcy Protection
abstract: There are reasons to think that the famous financial reorganization law won’t work much longer in its current form.
lead_paragraph: Is Chapter 11 doomed? There are reasons to think that the famous financial reorganization law won’t work much longer in its current form.

headline: Prodded by Climate Campaigners and Aided by Cheap Oil, Obama Kills Keystone
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Keystone Pipeline System', 'Natural Gas', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Pipelines']
abstract: The Keystone pipeline campaign wins Obama’s rejection, aided by cheap oil.
lead_paragraph: Congratulations are due to Bill McKibben, Jim Hansen and the tens of thousands of other climate campaigners who turned an obscure cross-border pipeline proposal into an effective national political campaign.

headline: Obamacare Not as Egalitarian as It Appears
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: The health law has been a success in several respects but is also a reminder that reducing inequality is a formidable challenge.
lead_paragraph: The Affordable Care Act has generated an enormous amount of partisan rancor, but with more access to data, it is worth taking stock of how it has actually been working.

headline: Grimes Performs at Guggenheim Gala
abstract: Mark Ronson, Lake Bell, Raf Simons and others at a Guggenheim gala.
lead_paragraph: Operating on the theory that one party is good, but two parties are better (especially where fund-raisers are concerned), the Guggenheim threw open its doors for the first of two parties on Wednesday, both honoring the artists Monir Shahroudy Farmanfarmaian, Doris Salcedo and On Kawara (the last in memoriam).

headline: The Limits of the ‘Tobacco Strategy’ on Climate Change
abstract: Creating identifiable villains like Exxon Mobil should help in the battle of public opinion, but it could also lead to further polarization.
lead_paragraph: For years, activists and scholars have contended that groups who reject the scientific consensus on climate change are employing tactics once used to create doubt about the dangers of smoking.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Out of Breath Solved!
abstract: Readers solve the case of a 74-year-old mechanic who became strangely short of breath whenever he worked under cars.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday we challenged Well readers to solve a case of a 74-year-old mechanic who became strangely short of breath whenever he worked under cars. I also asked for the test that revealed the diagnosis. While a remarkable number of you figured out the diagnosis, it wasn’t until late last night that I finally got an answer that included both the right diagnosis and the right test.

headline: Supreme Court to Hear New Case on Contraception and Religion
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The case concerns nonprofit groups like schools and hospitals that are affiliated with religious organizations, and rules for insurance coverage for contraceptives.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday once again entered the conflict between religious freedom and access to contraception, taking up a case about whether some religious employers must provide free insurance coverage for birth control.

headline: Some Older Patients Are Treated Not Wisely, but Too Much
abstract: Older adults with diabetes and other chronic conditions should be treated less aggressively than they commonly are, some experts say.
lead_paragraph: Over many years, the 77-year-old patient has managed to control his Type 2 diabetes. Thanks in part to daily doses of a drug that reduces blood sugar, his hemoglobin A1c (an average measure of recent blood glucose control) is a very low 6.5 percent.

headline: Hundreds of Nude Photos Jolt Colorado School
abstract: The authorities were debating whether to file child pornography charges, including felony charges, in the sexting case at Cañon City High School.
lead_paragraph: CAÑON CITY, Colo. — At least 100 students at a high school in Cañon City traded naked pictures of themselves, the authorities said Friday, part of a large sexting ring.

headline: Watch Three Doves Do Battle With A Hawk
abstract: Is QE for the birds?
lead_paragraph: Or that’s what I guess will happen at the IMF Annual Research Conference at 4:15; the final session, including yours truly, will be webcast here.

headline: Winners: The Best Parenting Advice in Six Words
abstract: The winners in the “Best Parenting Advice in Six Words” contest include the funny, the practical and the sweet.
lead_paragraph: We called for The Best Parenting Advice in Six Words. You responded, with more than 250 comments, and as many tweets and Facebook posts. From the bounty of pithy brilliance, I invited Larry Smith, the founder of Smith Magazine and editor of “The Best Advice in Six Words,” along with the other books in the “Six Words” series, to choose his favorite. He did more, as the very best contest judges will, creating categories to fit and bestowing accolades wherever possible. His choices, and his ultimate favorite:

headline: An Artful Ode to an Undersung Chemist
abstract: Tavares Strachan’s new show at Anthony Meier in San Francisco uses multimedia installations to examine the life of Rosalind Franklin.
lead_paragraph: As a child growing up in Nassau in the ’80s, the installation artist Tavares Strachan got most of his information about the world by a means that’s now all but obsolete: encyclopedias. “There were so many inaccuracies, and there were so many things left out, because the process of creating encyclopedias is all about editing and curating, really,” Strachan says. He became fascinated by the figures forgotten by history — like Matthew Alexander Henson, the African-American explorer who led Robert Peary to the North Pole in 1909. (Strachan took inspiration from Henson when he represented the Bahamas at the Venice Biennale in 2013.)

headline: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: Lentil-Stuffed Delicata Squash With Cashew Raita
abstract: A reader sent in a recipe for a fall dish with spice and “abundant umami” to suit a wide-range of palates.
lead_paragraph: Delicata is a light yellow squash with green stripes and a creamy, rich texture. One of the best things about delicata is that it’s much easier to clean, cut and cook than butternut or other winter squash varieties.

headline: Obama the Job Killer Redux
abstract: Funny about that private sector.
lead_paragraph: Philip Bump at the WaPo makes the same point I made a couple of days ago about the Obama job record: private sector job creation under the “job-killing” president has far outpaced anything that happened under Bush, while public-sector employment has declined. This doesn’t mean that Obama’s record is great. It does, however, mean that Republican claims that Obama’s left-wing policies, or something, are the big problem are very much at odds with the evidence.

headline: Older Quarterbacks Form a New Story in the N.F.L.
abstract: Over half of all passing yards this season have come from quarterbacks who are on the “wrong” side of 30.
lead_paragraph: In 2011 and 2012, the landscape of the N.F.L. appeared to be changing, with the game turning into one dominated by the young quarterbacks who had just entered the league.

headline: Rooftop Rock
abstract: The Annie O Music Series, a curated showcase of musical acts, takes place 21 stories above the city at the Standard Hotel.
lead_paragraph: The Annie O Music Series, a curated showcase of musical acts, takes place 21 stories above the city at the Standard Hotel.

headline: Penthouse Underground: A Musical Series at the Standard Hotel on the Bowery
abstract: Far above the downtown scene, the penthouse of the Standard Hotel in the East Village is home to a semiregular music series, curated by Annie Ohayon.
lead_paragraph: As a photographer, I find that every climb to the highest point in my neighborhood — the East Village — has been not only a study of light, geography and the ever-changing skyline, but also a musical adventure.

headline: Walter Maria de Silva, VW Chief Designer, to Retire
abstract: VW portrayed the departure of Walter Maria de Silva as a personal decision unrelated to the company’s emissions scandal.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Volkswagen’s chief designer will retire at the end of November, the company said on Friday, a move that coincides with organizational changes caused by the emissions cheating scandal.

headline: Veteran Republican Operative Is Joining Marco Rubio’s Campaign
abstract: Joe Pounder, a founder of the Republican opposition research firm America Rising who is known as an indefatigable researcher, will join Senator Marco Rubio’s campaign communications team as soon as next week.
lead_paragraph: For months, Senator Marco Rubio has operated with a lean staff. But he is making a major addition to his communications team, with a veteran and respected Republican operative who was involved with his 2010 run for the Senate from Florida.

headline: An App for Booking Babysitters
abstract: The new child-care-finding app, Chime, vets its babysitters with in-person interviews and parent ratings and reviews.
lead_paragraph: For teenagers, babysitting is often the first thing that comes to mind when brainstorming ways to earn a little extra spending money. But digitally savvy adolescents will not be surprised to find they have extra competition these days.

headline: GoFundMe Gone Wild
abstract: How raising money for personal causes has spun out of control.
lead_paragraph: As someone with the keen observational skills of Mr. Magoo, it took me a long time to notice a problem social-media acquaintances had been talking about for months.

headline: What I Love | Zhang Hongtu
abstract: The artist Zhang Hongtu’s 1,875-square-foot studio sits behind his narrow brick house in Woodside, Queens.
lead_paragraph: The artist Zhang Hongtu’s 1,875-square-foot studio sits behind his narrow brick house in Woodside, Queens.

headline: The Resident Golf Pro of Stuyvesant Town
abstract: Bernie Rothenberg, 98, has installed himself as the resident golf pro for a modest village green outside his Stuyvesant Town apartment building.
lead_paragraph: Bernie Rothenberg, 98, pulled eight colored balls from his jacket pockets and gripped a pitching wedge in his weathered hands.

headline: Transforming Daddy Issues Into Art
abstract: Camille Henrot’s new show at Metro Pictures uses humor and absurdity to explore a variety of ways authority can be abused.
lead_paragraph: Joe Jackson, James Joyce, Darth Vader, Lucius Malfoy and Brutus all have one thing in common: They’re “Bad Dads,” according to the French multimedia artist Camille Henrot, whose new show of interactive sculptures and drawings opens at Metro Pictures this week. Henrot’s definition of the term extends beyond the biological to include any authority figure that abuses power — a parent, sure, but also the government, the police or even the Internet. In preparing for her upcoming show, Henrot wondered what strategies people might use to “balance this dependent relationship.” One strategy: to call a hotline.

headline: The Big Bang of Art and Tech in New York
abstract: As noted in “Silicon City,” a coming New-York Historical Society exhibition, collaborations in the 1960s presaged a greater convergence today.
lead_paragraph: What happens when you put artists and technologists together? Forty-nine years ago last month, Robert Rauschenberg and a Bell Telephone Laboratories engineer named Billy Kluver answered that question with a tennis match.

headline: College Football Games to Watch on Saturday
abstract: L.S.U.-Alabama, T.C.U.-Oklahoma State and Clemson-Florida State could bring clarity to the playoff picture.
lead_paragraph: Saturday

headline: The Coolest Cats of the Lower East Side
abstract: At Koneko, a new cat cafe in downtown Manhattan, just who is rescuing whom?
lead_paragraph: At Koneko, a new cat cafe in downtown Manhattan, just who is rescuing whom?

headline: Rite Aid and Walgreens in Murky Deal to Clear Antitrust Hurdle
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Walgreens is left holding all the cards in its deal with Rite Aid when it comes to sales and acquisitions.
lead_paragraph: Walgreens Boots Alliance is in a buying mood, having just agreed to buy Rite Aid for $9.4 billion. The question is whether antitrust authorities in the United States will permit the deal to go forward.

headline: More Jobs, Same Worries
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: The jobs report for October was unexpectedly good. But that doesn’t mean the Fed should raise interest rates.
lead_paragraph: Last month, when the employment report for September was worse than expected, I wrote that the best response was to withhold judgment until more data came in.

headline: Weinstein Brothers Renew Their Contracts
abstract: The brothers’ existing contracts at their namesake company had been set to expire on Dec. 31. They will remain as co-chief executives.
lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Bob and Harvey Weinstein have renewed their contracts as co-chief executives of the Weinstein Company, Harvey Weinstein said in an interview here on Friday.

headline: Resisting Bomb Theory, Egypt Finds Itself Increasingly Alone
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Terrorism', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: As Britain, the United States and Russia take steps to protect their citizens, Egypt’s public statements recalled the 1999 crash of an EgyptAir flight near Nantucket.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Six days after the crash of a Russian charter flight from the Egyptian resort area of Sharm el Sheikh, the government of Egypt is finding itself increasingly isolated in its resistance to the possibility that a terrorist’s bomb brought down the plane.

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: Mary-Louise Parker
abstract: The actress and author shares the titles she’d most want to take with her on a desert island.
lead_paragraph: For his bookshop installation, One Grand, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is the actress Mary-Louise Parker, whose first book, “Dear Mr. You,” is out next week. She shares her list exclusively with T.

headline: Zhang Hongtu’s Art Studio in Woodside, Queens
abstract: The artist works in a 1,875-square-foot space behind his home.
lead_paragraph: Like many artists, Zhang Hongtu considers his studio his home away from home. And conveniently, it’s just a few steps from his narrow detached brick house in Woodside, Queens — out the back door and through a small courtyard — to work every day.

headline: How Politics Shaped General Relativity
keywords: ['Science and Technology', 'Physics', 'Research', 'Space and Astronomy', 'World War I (1914-18)', 'Gravitation and Gravity', 'International Relations']
abstract: Even abstract scientific research can be derailed (or propelled) by human conflict.
lead_paragraph: ON four Thursdays in November 1915 — one lecture each week — Albert Einstein rose to the podium at the Prussian Academy of Sciences to deliver updates on what he came to call his “general theory of relativity.” He was working at a frenzied pace, adjusting details between each presentation. By the end of the month, he had arrived at a form for his equations that physicists still use today. Elegant and crisp, they are brief enough to tweet.

headline: For Landscape Architect Kate Orff, Sunday Morning Means Having to Say ‘Sorry!’
abstract: Ms. Orff, new director of Columbia’s graduate Urban Design Program, plays table games with her younger son before outdoor activities in or near Forest Hills Gardens.
lead_paragraph: Kate Orff, a landscape architect, first captured the public’s attention in 2010 with her passionate promotion of a plan proposed by her firm, Scape, to bring oysters back to New York Harbor (the bivalves filter water and form reefs that can buffer against storm surges). After Hurricane Sandy, the idea became part of a $60 million federally funded program to build a breakwater seeded with oysters off Staten Island’s South Shore. Ms. Orff, 43, is also the director of the Urban Design Program at Columbia University’s Graduate School of Architecture, Planning and Preservation. She lives with her husband, Oded Horodniceanu, 42, a contractor and engineer, and their children, Adi, 8, and Matias, 4, in Forest Hills, Queens, in a rowhouse community called Arbor Close — the landscape designed, fittingly, by the Olmsted Brothers.

lead_paragraph: Brazil and Elsewhere: Pictures of the Day

headline: In Search of Dim Sum With ‘The Good Wife’ Actress Sarah Steele

lead_paragraph: Sarah Steele and her boyfriend, Raviv Ullman, recently made a pact: They were going to expand their horizons. They were going to get out of their Brooklyn neighborhood, try different bars, try different restaurants, like the Vegetarian Dim Sum House in Chinatown, where they had dinner a few months ago.

abstract: Eating habits are changing across the country and food companies are struggling to keep up.
lead_paragraph: IT’S easy to make fun of people in big cities for their obsession with gluten, or chia seeds, or cleanses.

headline: Germany Considers Tightening the Rules for Syrian Refugees
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The announcement followed weeks of mounting doubt about whether Germany has the capacity to handle almost 800,000 refugees who have arrived this year.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The German government is considering restoring controls on Syrian refugees arriving here after fleeing war in their homeland, and will significantly tighten rules allowing refugees to bring their families here, the Interior Ministry said on Friday.

headline: Twitter Fans Speak Out Against the Heart
abstract: The change may reflect an identity crisis for the social network known for the 140-character message.
lead_paragraph: I don’t ♥ Twitter’s decision to abandon the ★.

headline: Oxford Students Want Statue of Cecil Rhodes Removed
abstract: Student protesters rallied at Oxford University’s Oriel College, calling for the removal of a statue of Cecil Rhodes, a British imperialist.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of student protesters rallied at Oxford University’s Oriel College on Friday, calling for the removal of a statue of Cecil John Rhodes, a past pupil and benefactor of the school who made his fortune in diamonds while helping Britain seize control of southern Africa in the late 19th century.

headline: Luxury Condos in a Former NoLIta Orphanage
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Restoration and Renovation']
abstract: St. Patrick’s Old Cathedral School in NoLIta is being converted to condos and townhouses, with prices starting at $7.74 million.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 200 years, St. Patrick’s Old Cathedral School on Prince and Mott Streets educated local children, absorbing each successive immigrant generation — German, Irish, Italian and, later, Hispanics and Chinese — into its fold. Now, like so many New York City landmarks that were once part of the public realm, the building is being converted to condominiums and townhouses, with prices starting at $7.74 million.

headline: Is the Economy Overheating? Here’s Why It’s So Hard to Say
abstract: Wage growth seems to be increasing, a sign of a labor market at full capacity, with inflation likely to follow. But there is more to the story.
lead_paragraph: Let me tell you a story of the battle between the “inflation targeters” and the “accelerationists.” You’ll want to hear this bit of economic history because you want to know whether the Fed might raise interest rates after the latest rosy employment report.

headline: Cuba’s Secret Bedrooms
abstract: Carlos Otero Blanco has seen parts of Cuba that are off-limits to most people: bedrooms. The scenes tell tales of everyday life.
lead_paragraph: Carlos Otero Blanco has seen parts of Cuba that are off-limits to most people: bedrooms. The scenes tell tales of everyday life.

headline: Ode to a Pile Driver
abstract: In Downtown Brooklyn, where the sounds of a building boom fill the air, one person’s deafening noise is another’s sweet industrial symphony.
lead_paragraph: In Downtown Brooklyn, where the sounds of a building boom fill the air, one person’s deafening noise is another’s sweet industrial symphony.

lead_paragraph: Broadway’s latest crossover star, T Bone Burnett, has made a career of hopping across genres.

headline: Seeking Truffles, and Wanting More, at Il Tartufo in Manhattan
abstract: Eataly, the Italian food mall in Manhattan, just opened the truffle-themed pop-up restaurant, which will serve weekday lunch.
lead_paragraph: A pointer on truffle hunting: Never use a pig. “Dogs are better, because the dogs also hunt the truffle, but they don’t eat the truffle,” said Dino Borri, director of purchasing at Eataly, the Italian food mall near Madison Square in Manhattan. “The pigs eat everything,” he said.

headline: Some Surprising Relics at the Tenement Museum
abstract: The collection includes thousands of household items preserved in the crowded apartments of the Lower East Side, including curry powder nearly a century old and jars of morphine-laced medicine.
lead_paragraph: “I think most people associate the historic immigrant experience first with Ellis Island,” said David Favaloro, a curator at the Tenement Museum on the Lower East Side, “and then specifically with this neighborhood.” The museum occupies a building at 97 Orchard Street, a five-floor walk-up that was home to some 7,000 immigrants (of mostly German and Irish descent) from 1863 to 1935, when it lost its residential designation amid a modernization of the city’s anarchic fire codes.

headline: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
abstract: Book signings, a pheasant hunt, primary deadlines and demonstrations in Rockefeller Center in this week in political pictures.

headline: The Vault Apps That Keep Sexts a Secret
abstract: Students at a Colorado high school could face charges after using “photo vault” apps to keep illicit photos secret. But plenty of adults use the apps, too. Here’s how they work.
lead_paragraph: When students were caught participating in an illicit photo ring that was operating out of a high school in Cañon City, Colo., parents and school officials there were quick to say that kind of thing was surely happening all over the country.

headline: Oil Supply Picture Has Changed Since Keystone Was Proposed
abstract: Seven years ago, production in the United States was falling, some thought permanently, and Mexico’s industry was also in decline.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — When the Obama administration began considering the Keystone XL pipeline seven years ago, oil production in the United States was falling and most analysts thought it would never recover. At the same time, Mexican oil production was also in decline, meaning that domestic refineries would soon need another source of crude.

headline: Broadway Central Hotel’s Heyday Before a Fatal Collapse
abstract: Before the Manhattan hotel's walls buckled, it was the site of some spectacular moments and some spectacularly sordid ones.
lead_paragraph: Q. I vaguely remember the fatal collapse of a welfare hotel around 1973. Can you tell me about the hotel?

abstract: The Manhattan district attorney is giving grants, from criminal penalties against three international banks, for public and private criminal justice programs in New York and around the nation.
lead_paragraph: These days, the programs being announced by the Manhattan district attorney sound more like the projects of a major philanthropic foundation than those of a local prosecutor’s office.

headline: Consulting Firm With Clinton Ties Denies Influencing State Department Policy

lead_paragraph: The head of a consulting firm founded by one of Bill Clinton’s closest aides pushed back against allegations by Senator Charles E. Grassley, the Iowa Republican who is chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, that the firm had undue influence on Hillary Rodham Clinton’s diplomatic work.

headline: ‘Getting On,’ Played With Crudity and Grace
abstract: Starting its third and final season, this HBO series features Laurie Metcalf as a doctor in an extended-care unit for patients with serious disease or the infirmities of old age.
lead_paragraph: In the extended-care ward that is the setting for HBO’s series “Getting On,” some patients are entering the final phase of life. They’re generally sent off with a combination of dignity and abasement. That same seemingly contradictory combination will certainly mark the send-off for the series itself, which begins its third and final season on Sunday night.

headline: Autoworkers at Ford Tentatively Approve New Contract
abstract: Voting continued on a contract at General Motors, but passage is expected there as well.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The United Automobile Workers union reached a tentative agreement on Friday on a new contract for more than 52,000 workers at Ford Motor Company.

lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: ‘Flesh and Bone,’ a Ballet Drama With Strippers
abstract: This Starz series features Sarah Hay as a newcomer ballerina with a shady second job, and Ben Daniels as the dance company’s artistic director.
lead_paragraph: “Flesh and Bone” quickly dashes any hopes (or assuages any fears) you might have that it will be a serious drama about the world of ballet. As the opening credits roll, Karen O sings a droning cover of the 1980s hit “Obsession” (“Who do you want me to be/To make you sleep with me”) over a grainy montage featuring dancers and a lot of flying red chalk. It already feels as if we were back in the soft core heyday of Zalman King, with David Duchovny about to walk on screen to narrate an episode of “Red Shoe Diaries.”

headline: Review: ‘Agent X,’ With Sharon Stone and a Spy
abstract: Ms. Stone plays a new vice president who learns that her real job involves handling a secret superagent (Jeff Hephner).
lead_paragraph: The one notable thing about “Agent X,” a new spy series that’s cheap and thin even by the standards of TNT (where it begins on Sunday), is that it stars Sharon Stone in her first full-time television role. (She’s done short arcs on shows like “The Practice” and “Law & Order: SVU.”)

lead_paragraph: There were only a few hiccups in the opening of Koneko, the new cat cafe on Clinton Street on the Lower East Side.

headline: In ‘Spotlight,’ the Artless Look of the Boston Journalist
abstract: The costume designer of “Spotlight” calls the journalist look “an unthought-about uniform.” It says, “You don’t really care, you’ve got other things to think about.” So there.
lead_paragraph: “Spotlight,” a movie about The Boston Globe’s reporting on the sexual abuse of children in the Roman Catholic Church that opens in theaters on Friday, has caught the attention of critics.

headline: Review: Deafheaven Moves in Three Directions
abstract: This at least nominally extreme metal band did a concert full of musical references at Webster Hall.
lead_paragraph: There is a fantasy about tradition around extreme metal, and the fantasy is that the only kind of worthwhile tradition is natural, singular and binding. The palpitating drummers and corrosive screamers of black metal: This is who they are. They woke up like that. They’ll be like that tomorrow, too. They know what they play and they know what they think. The certainty has an absolute value.

headline: Review: A ‘Comedy of Errors’ That Never Stands Still
abstract: The Mobile Shakespeare Unit’s streamlined tale of two sets of separated twins comes to the Public Theater.
lead_paragraph: Here’s an equation for fans of theatrical problem solving: What happens when you multiply two men by four hats? The answer, it would seem, is infinite possibilities for confusion, consternation and resolution.

headline: Development, de Blasio-Style
abstract: The perception that the current mayor too easily capitulates to real estate interests, that he cares little about the hazards of extreme density and lacks any vision for urban planning, is very real.
lead_paragraph: When Lynn Ellsworth moved to New York in the 1970s, before she went on to get a doctorate in economics, she lived in a boardinghouse on the Upper West Side, with a dozen or so young women who were students at Barnard and Parsons. The system was vibrant and efficient; this was high-density living in a low-density neighborhood. At some point during more recent years, the buildings on her old block in the West 80s were converted into single-family townhouses. In the intervening period, during the 1990s, Ms. Ellsworth moved to TriBeCa, where the frenetically paced construction of expensive high-rise condominiums — high-density urbanism of a far less romantic kind — has been troublesome and disorienting.

headline: 2 Teenage Inmates Charged in Attack on Rikers Island Officer
abstract: Darnell Green, 19, and William Whitfield, 18, are accused of choking and slicing Officer Ray Calderon, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Two teenage inmates were arraigned in Criminal Court on Friday on charges that they attacked a correction officer at Rikers Island by choking him and slicing his face and wrist with a sharp weapon.

headline: Review: Zubin Mehta Leads Israel Philharmonic in ‘Resurrection’
abstract: The conductor steered the orchestra through the gamut of sonic dynamics in a Mahler symphony that testified to Carnegie Hall’s remarkable acoustics.
lead_paragraph: It was good to see Zubin Mehta looking hale on Thursday evening as he conducted the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra at Carnegie Hall. Mr. Mehta, 79, who has been music director of that orchestra since 1977 and held the same position at the New York Philharmonic from 1978 to 1991, had knee surgery a few months ago, and pictures of him conducting while seated raised alarm among some not fully in the know.

headline: Review: Peter Evans Teaches His Trumpet a New Vocabulary
abstract: In a solo improvisation nearly an hour long at Roulette on Wednesday night, Mr. Evans drew astounding sounds from his instrument.
lead_paragraph: The first notes Peter Evans produced on his trumpet at Roulette on Wednesday resembled tiny yelps and sobs. Soft, frayed and separated by inhospitable patches of silence, they announced themselves almost apologetically: aware, perhaps, of how short they fell of traditional expectations of how music — or a trumpet — should sound.

headline: No to Keystone, Yes to the Planet
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Oil Sands', 'Keystone Pipeline System']
abstract: President Obama’s rejection of the pipeline speaks to the crux of the battle against global warming: More fossil fuels need to stay in the ground.
lead_paragraph: Nearly every mainstream climate scientist has said that a big portion of the fossil fuels now in the ground must remain there if the world is to avoid the worst consequences of global warming. That simple fact lay at the heart of President Obama’s decision on Friday to say no to the Keystone XL oil pipeline from Canada.

headline: ‘A Fine Dessert’: Judging a Book by the Smile of a Slave
abstract: Emily Jenkins and Sophie Blackall’s children’s book has met growing criticism because of a sequence that depicts slavery in 1810.
lead_paragraph: Diversity has been a burning topic in children’s publishing in recent years, as editors, authors and librarians have debated how to tell more inclusive and accurate stories about America’s past and present.

headline: Governor-Elect Pledges to Take Clerks’ Names Off Kentucky Licenses
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Marriages']
abstract: That way, said Matt Bevin, the incoming Republican governor, an objection by same-sex marriage opponents would be removed.
lead_paragraph: Two months after a county clerk in Kentucky became a national figure and was jailed for refusing to grant marriage licenses bearing her name to same-sex couples, the state’s governor-elect said Friday that soon after taking office, he would order new licenses that do not have clerks’ names, a change that would address one objection raised by opponents of same-sex marriage.

headline: In Protesting Against Israel, Youth in Gaza Also Defy Hamas
abstract: The Islamist group, which governs Gaza, said it could not allow violence against Israel because it had agreed to a truce that ended last summer’s war.
lead_paragraph: El BUREIJ, Gaza Strip — The Palestinian youths huddled in the prohibited zone along the fence separating Gaza from Israel on Friday, cloaked by thick smoke pluming from flaming tires as they hurled rocks at Israeli jeeps. A tear gas canister came thudding down over their heads, and one teenager dashed over to pick it up and throw it into a puddle on a rainy afternoon.

headline: Keystone XL Decision by Obama Takes Weight Off Trudeau
keywords: ['Keystone Pipeline System', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Environment', 'United States Politics and Government', 'International Relations']
abstract: The official Canadian position was support for the Keystone XL project, but the new prime minister appeared to be unenthusiastic about it.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Officially, Canada is disappointed. But the Obama administration ’s decision on Friday to reject the Keystone XL pipeline, which would have linked Alberta’s oil sands to the Gulf of Mexico, also appeared to bring Canada’s new Liberal government a sense of relief.

headline: Getting Clean for His Son, From a Drug He Couldn’t Shake
abstract: After an arrest at 22, Donta James swore off dealing drugs but tried some of the crack cocaine he had peddled. He was hooked for more than 15 years.
lead_paragraph: It was not until after his arrest and decision to stop dealing drugs that Donta James became addicted to the very thing he had been peddling: crack cocaine.
