headline: Cuomo Struggles to Maintain Momentum in Upstate Employment
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Relocation of Business']
abstract: Even as Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has trumpeted new job opportunities and new jobs secured, several major employers have recently announced plans to lay off hundreds.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Since his election in 2010, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has portrayed himself as a transformative champion of upstate New York, coaxing companies to settle here or expand, and promptly cheering when they pledge to create new jobs.

headline: Valeant’s Chief Forced to Sell Company Shares He Pledged Against Loans
abstract: Valeant Pharmaceuticals disclosed that Goldman Sachs sold nearly 1.3 million shares in the drug maker, which were being held as collateral for a loan extended to Valeant’s chief executive.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, Valeant Pharmaceuticals has been under pressure from sources raising questions about its drug-pricing tactics and criticizing its ties to a mail-order pharmacy chain that helped increase sales of its expensive treatments.

headline: A Plane Crash Won’t Weaken Putin’s Resolve in Syria
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters']
abstract: Russians have been through worse.
lead_paragraph: For days, unnamed Western intelligence officials and Western heads of state have been implying that a bomb could very well have downed the Russian Metrojet plane carrying 224 Russians to St. Petersburg after a sunny vacation in Sharm el Sheikh. By Friday, French news media were reporting that a “sudden and brutal event” heard on the plane’s black box recordings was the likely culprit. Even the Kremlin, which has been vociferously denying the terrorism connection, canceled all Russian flights to Egypt and began making arrangements to airlift tens of thousands of Russian tourists still in the country.

headline: White House Is Irked Again by Comments About Police
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: The White House chided the acting director of the Drug Enforcement Administration for saying that increased police scrutiny might be forcing officers to be less aggressive when enforcing laws.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House on Friday singled out another senior federal law enforcement official for criticism for having suggested “without any evidence” that crime is on the rise because police officers have become less aggressive in the face of heightened public scrutiny of police behavior.

headline: A Tough Year for Hedge Funds? Not That Real Estate Has Noticed
keywords: ['Hedge Funds', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: Larry Robbins, head of Glenview Capital Management, is said to have bought a $37.9 million penthouse in Manhattan, a move that shows that despite a rough year, hedge fund managers aren’t hurting.
lead_paragraph: A Manhattan penthouse on the Upper East Side with sweeping views of both the Hudson River and the East River was sold this summer for $37.9 million. The person behind the purchase was hidden behind a limited liability company with the cryptic name CRE Acquisition.

headline: Mayor de Blasio, Amid Criticism, Tries to Keep Press Under Control
abstract: City Hall reporters object to restrictions on what questions can be asked.
lead_paragraph: Relished by some mayors and resented by others, the ritual has endured for decades in New York’s City Hall: an open and unscripted question-and-answer session between the mayor and the press.

headline: Spotty Intelligence Prompts U.S. Caution in Assessing Jet Crash in Egypt
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: Intelligence gathered thus far is seen by American officials as inconclusive and claims of responsibility as less than credible.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States has spent billions over the past 14 years improving its ability to gather intelligence across the globe, much of that money intended to ensure that acts of airborne terrorism like the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, never happen again.

headline: Exxon Inquiry Both Mirrors and Contrasts With Tobacco Industry Case
abstract: The tobacco industry largely hid evidence of the addictiveness of tobacco, while Exxon published peer-reviewed climate change research even as it raised doubts on the underlying science.
lead_paragraph: The New York attorney general’s decision to investigate Exxon Mobil over whether the company lied to the public and investors about the risks of climate change has raised questions about possible similarities to the Justice Department’s successful suit against the tobacco industry in 1997.

headline: New Setback for Chris Christie Just as Hope Was High
abstract: Mr. Christie’s demotion to the so-called undercard debate highlighted his transformation from dominant to underdog.
lead_paragraph: Chris Christie’s presidential campaign seemed, at long last, to be gaining altitude: His poll numbers were rising in New Hampshire, and he had given a forceful performance at last week’s Republican debate in Colorado. A video of Mr. Christie speaking off the cuff about drug addiction, flashing the unguarded persona that made him a political celebrity in the first place, was widely shared online.

headline: Netanyahu May Try to Mend Fences in First U.S. Visit Since Iran Deal
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Jews and Judaism', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The campaign by the prime minister and pro-Israel groups against the nuclear accord with Iran has left raw feelings.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Democratic members of Congress felt the wrath of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and pro-Israel groups almost immediately after announcing their support for the nuclear deal with Iran.

headline: Though Not on Ballot, Narendra Modi Is at Center of Vote in India
abstract: Narendra Modi, the Indian prime minister, has staked his prestige on helping his party gain control in the populous but poor state of Bihar.
lead_paragraph: PATNA, India — For months now, few goals have been more important to Prime Minister Narendra Modi than winning this month’s elections in Bihar, a farming state tucked up against the border of Nepal in east India.

headline: Where Homeless Meets Crazy
abstract: On the streets of Chicago and Chennai, India, mental illness is experienced differently.
lead_paragraph: IN every corner of the world, there are people who are flagrantly ill, people who mutter to invisible others and box at the air. But because the cultural texture is different in different settings, the experience of madness can be quite different, too. That is true even of such a blunt assault on human feeling as homelessness.

headline: Ben Carson Turns Heat on Reporters in Feisty News Conference
abstract: In a mocking and unexpectedly theatrical appearance, Mr. Carson delivered a public scolding of the news media that has begun to question his celebrated biography.
lead_paragraph: Ben Carson was feisty. He was mocking. He was unyielding. And he was unexpectedly theatrical.

headline: When Gold Isn’t Worth the Price
keywords: ['Mines and Mining', 'Jewels and Jewelry', 'Environment', 'Clean Water Act', 'Metals and Minerals', 'Gold', 'Conflict Minerals and Resources', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Diamonds', 'Copper, Brass and Bronze']
abstract: The jewelry trade must not profit from mines that ruin the natural world.
lead_paragraph: THERE are few places in the world more beautiful than the landscape of salmon-rich rivers that flow into Bristol Bay, Alaska. I arrived there seven years ago not as a sportsman or ecotourist, as most visitors do, but as a chief executive fearful that the company I led would be seen as complicit in the destruction of this remarkable place.

headline: A Kenyan Runner Maps His Way Home
keywords: ['Track and Field', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Kelvin Serem comes from a family of subsistence farmers in Kenya, but he won a scholarship to a private school in New Jersey in 2011 and now attends Lafayette College as a student-athlete, all while supporting a school he helped have built in his home village.
lead_paragraph: EASTON, Pa. — A sliver of a long-distance runner glides all but unnoticed through the undulating streets of this eastern Pennsylvanian city. He keeps a metronomic pace, checks his wristwatch, tries to clear his head. His mind races faster than his feet.

headline: Martin St. Louis Still Leads Rangers, but Now He Towers Over Them
abstract: The diminutive and prolific St. Louis, who recently retired after a 16-season N.H.L. career, coaches his three sons and other children who play for the Mid Fairfield Junior Rangers in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: STAMFORD, Conn. — Whether perched behind the bench clutching a paper cup of black coffee or tutoring 7-year-old skaters in the art of on-ice tag, Martin St. Louis approaches his new role with the same intensity that won him two N.H.L. scoring titles and a Stanley Cup.

headline: China’s Pacific Overtures
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Chinese navy is flexing its muscles in the South China Sea, but a belligerent response from the U.S. is exactly the wrong tack.
lead_paragraph: THE dangerous game of chicken now being played out in the South China Sea, with American warships sailing provocatively close to a clutch of new-made Chinese islands, is only the beginning of what looks to be a lengthy and epic tussle.

headline: Mets Gamble With $15.8 Million Offer to Daniel Murphy, Who Faces a Bigger Gamble
abstract: A playoff hero and a World Series goat, Murphy is likely, but not certain, to make more if he rejects the one-year deal and becomes a free agent.
lead_paragraph: Even the most casual baseball fan who watched the postseason could easily see what most trained experts have long known. Daniel Murphy, the Mets’ second baseman, can be a terrific hitter, but he also has glaring limitations in the field.

headline: How the U.S. and Israel Can Move Forward
abstract: President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu must find ways to work together toward a defense agreement, as well as on Syria and Iran.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s visit to the White House on Monday will be his first meeting with President Obama in over a year, an unusual lapse in direct personal contact between the leaders of two allied states. Their broken relationship, caused in large measure by the Israeli prime minister’s vitriolic but failed campaign to kill the nuclear deal with Iran, make the circumstances awkward. But it is in the strategic interests of both countries to find a way to work together more constructively.

headline: The Fallacy of the Latest Contraception Case
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Birth Control and Family Planning']
abstract: In a secular society, religious freedom demands respect and accommodation, not veto power over government actions.
lead_paragraph: Now that the Supreme Court has agreed to hear the latest challenge to the Affordable Care Act’s guarantee of insurance coverage for birth control, it is worth reiterating what the conflict at the core of these cases is really about.

headline: Not What’s Expected
abstract: A Saturday brain-twister from Barry C. Silk.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — If there are any beginning solvers reading today, I’d love to hear from you on a subject that I think about every now and then: At what point do you push yourself beyond the early week puzzles and dip a cruciverbal toe into the challenges of the Saturday puzzle?

headline: Friday Night Music: Elephant Revival, The Pasture
abstract: More transcendental folk.
lead_paragraph: A bit late; blame Amtrak.

headline: Panthers Prosper as Quarterback Cam Newton Grows
abstract: Newton, a 6-foot-5, 245-pound force, led the Panthers to a victory over the Colts on Monday. For a franchise that has never started a season with seven wins in a row, this is all new ground.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Mud, dirt and torn-up patches of sod lay in a heap outside Bank of America Stadium on Wednesday — the remains of the field after Monday night’s game between the Carolina Panthers and the Indianapolis Colts, which was played in a monsoon.

headline: Beneath Washington Square, Forgotten Tombs Begin to Yield Their Secrets
abstract: Construction on a new water main in Lower Manhattan uncovered two forgotten burial vaults, whose contents and histories are still unknown to archaeologists.
lead_paragraph: One was named William. Another was 21 years old.

headline: Porzingis Tantalizes but Knicks Lose Their Third in a Row
abstract: The Knicks fell flat in the fourth quarter of their 99-92 loss to the Bucks, but Kristaps Porzingis had his second double-double in his last three games.
lead_paragraph: It had already been an eventful week for Kristaps Porzingis. On Monday, he absorbed the full force of Carmelo Anthony’s 220-pound frame on the side of his neck. Two days later, Porzingis got his first up-close look at LeBron James when the Knicks visited the Cleveland Cavaliers.

headline: University Returns $1 Million Grant to Coca-Cola
keywords: ['Diet and Nutrition', 'Grants (Corporate and Foundation)', 'Medicine and Health', 'Obesity', 'Soft Drinks']
abstract: The University of Colorado School of Medicine is giving back $1 million that was used to establish an advocacy group that played down the link between soft drinks and weight.
lead_paragraph: The University of Colorado School of Medicine announced Friday that it was returning a $1 million gift from Coca-Cola after it was revealed that the money had been used to establish an advocacy group that played down the link between soft drinks and obesity.

headline: ‘The Knick’ Season 2, Episode 4: Fever Cabinet
abstract: This week’s “The Knick" featured one quick, horrifying, drolly macabre moment.
lead_paragraph: Opal Edwards was up and Cornelia Showalter was down in this week’s episode of “The Knick,” in which Zaraah Abrahams, as Opal, Algernon Edwards’s heretofore secret wife, is quickly establishing herself as one of the show’s strongest characters.

headline: Lakers Taste First Win; the Nets Can’t Relate
abstract: Billy King, the Nets’ general manager, insisted that he was still “upbeat and positive” about the team, which had lost its first five games.
lead_paragraph: Billy King tilted his shoulder against a wall early Friday night as a group of assembled reporters lobbed questions about the Nets’ troublesome start to the season.

headline: Plane Bombings and Attempted Bombings
abstract: An overview of bomb attacks aboard aircraft.
lead_paragraph: An overview of bomb attacks aboard aircraft.

headline: 2 Louisiana Officers Charged With Second-Degree Murder in Killing of Boy, 6
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The police officers were arrested in the shooting death of Jeremy Mardis during the pursuit of the boy’s father in an S.U.V.
lead_paragraph: Two police officers have been arrested on charges of second-degree murder in connection with the shooting death of a 6-year-old boy during a pursuit of his father in a sport utility vehicle in central Louisiana, the state police said Friday.

headline: On ‘20/20’, Woman Charged in Fiancé’s Kayak Death Denies She Killed Him
abstract: Angelika Graswald, 35, who is charged with murder in the drowning of Victor Viafore last April, spoke with ABC’s “20/20” from jail.
lead_paragraph: In barely a whisper, Angelika Graswald, the woman accused of killing her fiancé while they were kayaking on the Hudson River, told ABC’s “20/20” that she “loved him” and “didn’t do anything to kill him.”

headline: Bernie Sanders Courts Black Voters at South Carolina Forum
abstract: Mr. Sanders and his rivals for the Democratic presidential nomination, Hillary Rodham Clinton and Martin O’Malley, sought to differentiate themselves in back-to-back interviews.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders used a Democratic primary forum in South Carolina on Friday to try to reach out to black voters and make the argument that he is the candidate best suited to address the needs of a demographic that overwhelmingly favors Hillary Rodham Clinton, his chief rival for the nomination.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Trump, Donald Trump, on “Saturday Night Live”; “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory” vs. “Boyhood”; and that other dude — Bond, James Bond — on iTunes.
lead_paragraph: It’s the weekend, relieved viewers, which means “Saturday Night Live,” which means Trump, Donald Trump. Need an all-afternoon break? Give the kids some TV candy with “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory,” then steal “Boyhood” for yourself. And for the price of a Ben Franklin, you can curl up with old-school Bond, James Bond, in the privacy of your home and leave the “Spectre” lines to everyone else.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 7, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “In Guinea, we never had this apocalyptic transmission like in Liberia and Sierra Leone; we never had bodies in the streets.”

headline: Corrections: November 7, 2015
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, November 7, 2015
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK

headline: Leaders of China and Taiwan Talk of Peace Across the Strait
abstract: The meeting in Singapore between Xi Jinping and Ma Ying-jeou comes amid increasing wariness among Taiwan voters of Beijing’s embrace.
lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — President Xi Jinping of China met with President Ma Ying-jeou of Taiwan on Saturday in the first-ever encounter between leaders of the neighbors and longtime rivals, an act both sides described as a breakthrough gesture meant to promote peace and mutual prosperity.

headline: Xi Again Defends China’s Claim to South China Sea Islands
abstract: In a speech in Singapore before he met the president of Taiwan, China’s president asked countries “outside the region” to respect stability in the area.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — President Xi Jinping of China said in a speech on Saturday morning in Singapore that islands in the South China Sea “have been China’s territory since ancient times,” and that countries from outside the region should respect the need of Asian nations for a “peaceful and stable environment” so the nations could develop rapidly.

headline: Should You Treat Muscle Pain With Ice or Heat?
abstract: Cold therapy is usually recommended in the immediate aftermath of an acute injury, but both heat and cold may help with lingering muscle pain.
lead_paragraph: Q. What determines whether one should use heat or ice to treat muscle and joint pain, especially after exercise?

headline: The Case for Melancholy
abstract: A writer wonders: Whatever happened to experiencing the grace of deeply tinted blue moods, which require reflection and mental steeping, like tea?
lead_paragraph: Everywhere you look these days you see something on how to be happy — how to manifest abundance, desires and success, find your bliss.

headline: Margaret Trudeau’s Comeback
abstract: Once a tabloid mainstay, the former first lady of Canada makes a mindful return.
lead_paragraph: Once a tabloid mainstay, the former first lady of Canada makes a mindful return.

headline: The Quiet Comeback of Margaret Trudeau
abstract: Once tabloid fodder for partying with rock stars and Andy Warhol, Margaret Trudeau is back in the spotlight as her son Justin becomes Canada’s prime minister.
lead_paragraph: Ottawa — On Wednesday, Justin Trudeau took the oath of office as the new prime minister of Canada, accompanied by his wife and three small children — and a woman in a dark blue coat that many people in the country may not have seen much of in recent years but who remains an indelible character in Canadian political history: his mother.

headline: The Week on Instagram
abstract: Photos posted on @nytimes this week took followers from a remote Australian island to one of America’s loneliest highways.
lead_paragraph: Photos posted on @nytimes this week took followers from a remote Australian island to one of America’s loneliest highways.

headline: Crime Down in Karachi, Paramilitary in Pakistan Shifts Focus
abstract: The Sindh Rangers, a paramilitary force, have curbed violence in Karachi, but they are now targeting political parties at odds with the nation’s military establishment.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — Paramilitary troops have become ubiquitous around this sprawling Pakistani port city. They watch over police officers at traffic circles, their convoys patrol thoroughfares, their raids drive daily headlines.

headline: Sierra Leone Declared Free of Ebola Transmissions
abstract: The news marks a joyous but tense moment in Sierra Leone, where Ebola has crippled the nation’s economy and officials worry the virus could re-emerge at any moment.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — After a nerve-racking countdown, Sierra Leone celebrated a national milestone on Saturday that government officials hoped would help the country finally leave behind a grim chapter in its history: It was officially declared free of Ebola transmissions.

headline: Off-Season Hamptons: What to Do
abstract: In the fall, off-season Hamptons is a quieter place, teeming with very noticeable wildlife. Here are just a few places you might want to check out.
lead_paragraph: In the fall, off-season Hamptons is a quieter place, a little ghostly, decidedly small-townish and teeming with very noticeable wildlife. It includes hiking trails, stretches of shoreline with vastly different personalities and some offbeat restaurants and dive bars. Here are just a few places you might want to check out.

headline: Before Elections in Myanmar, Citizens Express Desire for Change
abstract: On Sunday, Myanmar will hold its first relatively free elections in 25 years, and readers on Facebook talked about what they hoped, and feared, would come from the vote.
lead_paragraph: Myanmar will hold its first relatively free elections in 25 years on Sunday. Ahead of the vote, we asked people in Myanmar via Facebook to tell us what they hope, and fear, will come from the elections. We also asked readers to tell us which campaign issues were the most important to them.

headline: Real Estate Shell Companies Scheme to Defraud Owners Out of Their Homes
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Mortgages']
abstract: Relying on the secrecy of limited liability companies, white-collar thieves are targeting pockets of New York City for fraudulent deed transfers, leaving the victims groping for redress.
lead_paragraph: Partially paralyzed and reliant on a wheelchair, Ozella Campbell spends a lot of time watching television. It was under those circumstances in February 2014 that she saw a commercial urging her to call MyHouseIsADump.com, a company that offered to buy houses in as-is condition, in cash, and to close the purchase within seven days.

headline: Police Chiefs, Looking to Diversify Forces, Face Structural Hurdles
abstract: Though many are eager to hire minorities, well-intended policies that were not meant to discriminate have created obstacles in cities across the nation.
lead_paragraph: INKSTER, Mich. — When William T. Riley III became the police chief of this small city west of Detroit this summer, he found a department that bore little resemblance to the city it served.

headline: Route Decision Led to U.S. Helicopter Crash in Nepal, Marines Say
keywords: ['Helicopters', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Earthquakes', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters']
abstract: In its findings on the crash in May of the earthquake rescue flight, the military said the aircraft was flying over unfamiliar terrain.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The crash of a United States Marines helicopter in Nepal in May that killed 13 people during earthquake rescue operations was most likely caused by the crew’s decision to fly the most direct route to Kathmandu, the capital, the Marines said Saturday.

headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: Airbnb Takes San Francisco
abstract: Voters’ defeat of a measure that would have imposed restrictions on Airbnb rentals spurs a discussion on the company’s approach to setting up shop in a city.
lead_paragraph: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: Cooking With the Door Open
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Condominiums', 'Smells and Odors', 'Heating', 'Affordable Housing', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: This week’s subjects include odors from the apartment next door; problems with the heat; and rules in middle-income developments.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: New Mystery Surfaces 4 Decades After Pablo Neruda’s Death
abstract: A government statement said it was “highly probable” that suspicions of foul play in the Chilean poet’s demise were correct. But an official inquiry was still continuing.
lead_paragraph: Many Chileans have long suspected foul play in the death of the poet Pablo Neruda, who died 12 days after the 1973 coup led by Gen. Augusto Pinochet. Now, the government of Chile has said it is “highly probable” that those suspicions are correct.

headline: Cheese-Eating Job Creators
abstract: Sacre bleu!
lead_paragraph: It’s been obvious for a while that Jeb! is toast. Last week, however, he became French toast: after making a crack about French work weeks that was completely wrong, he … apologized for the mistake. Fool! As National Review made clear, real men don’t admit to, let alone apologize for, errors:

headline: Slippery Rock’s Tie to Michigan Is All in the Name
abstract: At a program that has no shortage of traditions, Michigan fans have been cheering the Rock, a Division II school in the Pennsylvania State Athletic Conference, for more than a half-century.
lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — During the second quarter of Michigan’s game against Michigan State on Oct. 17 — a matchup that would be decided in the Spartans’ favor by an agonizingly botched punt — an out-of-town score whose relevance was not immediately apparent was shown on Michigan Stadium’s main video board: Slippery Rock 35, Mercyhurst 24.

headline: Cuban Revolutionaries Hope Their Legacy Won’t Fade Away
abstract: Memories of overthrowing a dictatorship remain strong among the elders of Santiago de Cuba, the city where the fight began, but the younger generation is ready to move on.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO DE CUBA — In the photograph, the friends stand stripped to their undershirts in the blistering heat, clutching shovels, their faces cast in sepia. The men, hiding in the folds of the Sierra Maestra mountains of Cuba, were fighters in the throes of revolution.

headline: Afghan Mullah Leading Stoning Inquiry Condones Practice
keywords: ['Shariah (Islamic Law)', 'ADULTERY', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', "Women's Rights", 'Women and Girls', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: A mullah’s theological support for the sort of stoning he is being sent to investigate is emblematic of the national conundrum over the role of Shariah law.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — After men believed to be Taliban fighters forced a 19-year-old named Rukhshana into a freshly dug pit and methodically stoned her to death for adultery, a video of the killing surfaced on the Internet and incited outrage.

headline: Microsoft’s Stock Math: Fewer Shares, Pricier Shares
abstract: Microsoft’s stock finally returned to a nominal level not seen since before the 2000 tech collapse. But without share buybacks, it might not look quite so good.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft has been on a roll. Late last month, it did something it hadn’t pulled off since Bill Gates was chief: Its share price reached a new high.

headline: F.B.I. to Help Russia Investigate Plane Crash in Egypt
abstract: Some American officials said that the Russians want help analyzing forensic evidence from the charter plane that broke apart over the Sinai Peninsula, killing 224 people.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. has agreed to help the Russian government with its investigation into the deadly crash of a Russian charter plane in the Sinai Peninsula in Egypt, senior American officials said on Saturday.

headline: Rising Left Bloc in Portugal Could Threaten Austerity Drive
abstract: Left-wing parties are weighing forming a coalition, which could bring down Prime Minister Pedro Passos Coelho’s government just weeks into its new term.
lead_paragraph: LISBON — Last month’s elections in Portugal were meant to deliver a clear verdict on the center-right coalition of Prime Minister Pedro Passos Coelho, whose austerity program has been held up as a model by creditors and countries like Germany that have advocated belt-tightening in Europe.

headline: Variety: Diagramless
abstract: Fred Piscop offers us a creative diagramless puzzle.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — I would go into a long speech about this ART-themed diagramless puzzle by Fred Piscop, but … {Entire puzzle community rushes forward at once to grab their long-awaited diagramless puzzle, trampling Deb to death in the process.}

headline: Once, Twice, Three Times a Lemon
abstract: A driver spends thousands on a series of used engines that each break down in hours, and then he is stranded again by the seller’s customer service.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes the Haggler is really glad he does not own a car. This is one of those times:

headline: Gaps in Egyptian Airport Security Face Scrutiny After Crash
keywords: ['Airport Security', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: Inconsistencies in airport security in Egypt are now under a spotlight as evidence from the crash of a Russian charter jet points to the possibility of a bombing.
lead_paragraph: SHARM EL SHEIKH, Egypt — The airport is surrounded by a wall topped with barbed wire. Armed sentries are stationed at its entrance, and passengers pass through two security screenings before reaching departure gates; before a recent flight, there were no fewer than eight uniformed guards standing around the checkpoint.

headline: German City by the Danube Is Tested by a Different Kind of Flood
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: This picturesque Bavarian city embodies Germany’s commitment to welcoming a surging flow of migrants. But it also reflects lingering conflicts over strategy between the Bavarian state and the Merkel government.
lead_paragraph: PASSAU, Germany — The first time it happened, Wolfgang Wagner thought it was funny. He was driving to work when the police stopped him. An officer asked him to open the back of his van.

headline: A Tasting of Chinese Wines
abstract: The wine critic Eric Asimov samples five wines and finds them drinkable, with promise for the industry’s future there.
lead_paragraph: When I mentioned to a colleague that I was going to try a few Chinese wines, he looked at me sadly and said, “I’m sorry.”

headline: As U.S. Escalates Air War on ISIS, Allies Slip Away
abstract: Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates have shifted most of their aircraft away from Syria as they fight Houthi rebels in Yemen.
lead_paragraph: AL UDEID AIR BASE, Qatar — As the United States prepares to intensify airstrikes against the Islamic State in Syria, the Arab allies who with great fanfare sent warplanes on the initial missions there a year ago have largely vanished from the campaign.

headline: China’s Winemakers Seek Their Own Napa Valley
abstract: Wines produced in a rocky, arid region on the edge of the Gobi Desert have won prestigious awards, and foreign investors have taken notice.
lead_paragraph: YINCHUAN, China — On a fall evening in a fluorescent-lit classroom at Tsinghua University in Beijing, a dozen students listened intently. The speaker, Emma Gao, held a glass to the light and asked them to study the swirling liquid inside. Tsinghua is known as the “M.I.T. of China,” but this was no freshman seminar in fluid mechanics. It was a gathering of the student wine club.

headline: For Mets, One Fateful Pitch Was Two Years in the Making
abstract: Jeurys Familia had success this year with the quick pitch, a tactic he learned from the veteran LaTroy Hawkins in 2013. But in Game 1 of the World Series, Familia tried it on the wrong hitter.
lead_paragraph: The roots of one of the most agonizing pitches in Mets history date to February 2013. LaTroy Hawkins, then in the autumn of a 21-year career, arrived at camp in Port St. Lucie, Fla., as a savvy and analytical veteran.

headline: Coming Full Circle to Help Her Elders
abstract: A career filled with tough cases transforms a lawyer into a champion for the elderly, just like her mother.
lead_paragraph: In the midst of my raging adolescence in 1979, my mother was devoting most of her time to a Jewish nursing home in Baltimore where she was the board president.

headline: Detroit Businesswomen Team Up to Get Rape Kits Tested
abstract: Discovered forgotten in storage, the thousands of unprocessed kits overwhelmed the prosecutor’s office, but the community has stepped in to help.
lead_paragraph: In 2009, a Wayne County assistant prosecuting attorney noticed thousands of rape kits stacked on the shelves of a Detroit Police Department storage facility. The kits are used to collect and store DNA evidence obtained from sexual assault survivors. These particular kits had been in storage for up to 30 years, and their contents had never been processed or properly investigated.

headline: Giants’ Punter Reclaims Spotlight After Winding Road From L.S.U.
abstract: Brad Wing is used to being the center of attention, and in his two years at Louisiana State, and subsequent two years in the N.F.L., he has remained committed to that.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — In Australia, Brad Wing explained recently, kickers are a big deal. They are not called kickers; they are called scorers. In Australian rules football, the nation’s most popular sport, the men who kick the ball typically play full-forward, a focal position, where they call the plays, direct the offense and become sort of like, well, a quarterback.

headline: Afghan President Calls Off Business Deal With Banker Convicted of Fraud
abstract: President Ashraf Ghani canceled his government’s partnership with Khalilullah Frozi, who was supposed to be in prison for defrauding Kabul Bank.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Facing a public outcry, the Afghan president, Ashraf Ghani, has called off his government’s recent business partnership with a felon who was supposed to be in prison for defrauding the country’s biggest private bank.

headline: The Cyberthreat Under the Street
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)']
abstract: In the worry over cybersecurity, we can forget that the physical cables that carry data are at risk.
lead_paragraph: WITHIN the last year there have been 16 so-called fiber cuts in the San Francisco Bay Area. According to the F.B.I., someone or some group has been going through manholes to sever fiber optic cables that supply telecommunications to large sections of the region, which is home to technology companies, academic institutions and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, overseer of the nation’s nuclear weapons.

headline: Sex, Lies and Houston
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Discrimination', 'Referendums', 'Bathrooms and Toilets']
abstract: I know the pain of being reduced to a cruel caricature. Don’t you?
lead_paragraph: I USED to be a child molester.

headline: The Pakistan Nuclear Nightmare
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The country hasn’t gotten the same attention as Iran, but the Obama administration is now addressing the issue with greater urgency and imagination.
lead_paragraph: With as many as 120 warheads, Pakistan could in a decade become the world’s third-ranked nuclear power, behind the United States and Russia, but ahead of China, France and Britain. Its arsenal is growing faster than any other country’s, and it has become even more lethal in recent years with the addition of small tactical nuclear weapons that can hit India and longer-range nuclear missiles that can reach farther.

headline: The Dying of the Whites
keywords: ['Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Age, Chronological', 'Minorities', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Alcohol Abuse', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Medicine and Health', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Religion and Belief', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: What white mortality rates tell us about the crisis of the working class.

headline: How Doctors Helped Drive the Addiction Crisis
abstract: Opioid painkillers are deadly, overprescribed and often ineffective.
lead_paragraph: THERE has been an alarming and steady increase in the mortality rate of middle-aged white Americans since 1999, according to a study published last week. This increase — half a percent annually — contrasts starkly with decreasing death rates in all other age and ethnic groups and with middle-aged people in other developed countries.

headline: Poppy Bush Finally Gives Junior a Spanking
abstract: Do not go gentle, man, into that good night.
lead_paragraph: WESTEROS — I VISITED HBO’s “Game of Thrones” set in Belfast last week, and after watching Daenerys Targaryen in firelight for a couple hours, I learned how to say “I have to go to the bathroom” in Dothraki.

headline: Turkey’s Troubling ISIS Game
abstract: Islamic State militants are now embroiled in the age-old conflict of Turks and Kurds.
lead_paragraph: SANLIURFA, Turkey — ABOVE a restaurant specializing in sheep’s head soup, with steaming tureens of broth in the window, two young Syrian journalists took up residence in this ancient town in southeastern Turkey. They had fled Raqqa, the stronghold in Syria of the Islamic State, or ISIS, and devoted their time to denouncing the crimes of the barbarous jihadi group. Today, their second-floor apartment is a crime scene, with a red police seal on the door.

headline: David Linde
abstract: The film producer on reading Joyce, watching BBC shows and listening to his college-age sons’ music.
lead_paragraph: David Linde, a longtime film producer and executive formerly with Universal Studios, was recently named chief executive of Participant Media, a film and television production company that mines current events and social issues for subject matter.

headline: What Scented Candles Say to an Economist
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Shopping and Retail', 'United States Economy', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Pop-up shops can reveal business confidence better than official data.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — ECONOMISTS pay too little attention to what is happening around them. Our record at forecasting economic growth has not recovered from the failure to predict the 2008 crash, yet the profession has not done enough to improve things.

headline: The Price of Denialism
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Philosophy', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Science and Technology', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change']
abstract: Science will sometimes be off the mark. That doesn’t mean it can be ignored.
lead_paragraph: We’ve all heard the phrase “you’re entitled to your own opinion, but not your own facts.” Opinions are the sorts of things about which we can take a poll. They are sometimes well-informed, but rarely expected to be anything other than subjective. Facts, on the other hand, are “out there” in the world, separate from us, so it makes little sense to ask people what they think of them. As the comedian John Oliver so aptly put it in commenting on a recent Gallup poll that found that one in four Americans disbelieve in climate change: “You don’t need people’s opinion on a fact. You might as well have a poll asking: ‘Which number is bigger, 15 or 5?’ Or ‘Do owls exist’ or ‘Are there hats?’”

headline: Sweet Home Mississippi
abstract: When an Englishman relocates to the rural South, he learns to love his adopted home and embrace its glorious contradictions.
lead_paragraph: PLUTO, MISS. — TO move from Lower Manhattan to rural Mississippi is probably the most extreme culture shock available in this country. To do it as an Englishman adds an extra twist. But I fell in love with an old farmhouse while visiting a friend in the Mississippi Delta, bought it for next to nothing, in New York terms, and persuaded my girlfriend, Mariah, to move there with me.

headline: The Doctor Who Saved 100,000 Eyes
abstract: Nicholas Kristof travels to Nepal to meet an ophthalmologist who may have cured more people of blindness than anyone in history.
lead_paragraph: Nicholas Kristof travels to Nepal to meet an ophthalmologist who may have cured more people of blindness than anyone in history.

headline: In 5 Minutes, He Lets the Blind See
abstract: A Nepali ophthalmologist who pioneered a $25 operation to remove cataracts has restored sight to more than 100,000 people.
lead_paragraph: HETAUDA, Nepal — WATCHING the doctor perform is like observing miracles.

keywords: ['Editorials', 'Corporations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Consumer Protection', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION']
abstract: Corporations have stacked the deck in setting up a system that protects them in most cases of consumer grievances.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, America’s corporations have created a private system for handling disputes that benefits them greatly while denying consumers their day in court.

headline: In Seattle, a Campaign Finance Plan That Voters Control
abstract: A $30 million experiment in campaign financing deserves the nation’s close attention.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Seattle voters advanced the city’s reputation for progressivism when they approved a bold and unusual campaign finance reform plan. The plan will draw on real estate taxes to give every registered voter $100 in “democracy vouchers” to spend on candidates in the next city elections.

headline: I Am Paying for Your Expensive Medicine
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: We need to evaluate whether new drugs are really worthwhile, because the costs are widely, although perhaps invisibly, shared.
lead_paragraph: YOU may not know it, but you could be on the hook to pay at least $124 this year for a drug you probably don’t take.

headline: Casualties of War
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Euthanasia and Assisted Suicide', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: As Holocaust survivors, my parents insisted on being in control of their own deaths.
lead_paragraph: It has been 15 years since my mother called and asked, “Do you have some time at the end of July or the beginning of August? Your father and I have decided to kill ourselves and we would like you to come and find our bodies.”

headline: Volkswagen May Offer Cash to Ease Owners’ Ire
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Diesel Power', 'Air Pollution', 'Automobiles', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: In an effort to recover some good will, Volkswagen is expected to offer cash to the owners of diesel cars.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Volkswagen is expected to offer cash to the owners of diesel cars in the United States this coming week as it steps up an effort to recover some of the good will it lost after admitting in September that the vehicles were programmed to cheat on emissions tests.

headline: While Time Marches On, a Referee Jogs, Sprints or Dashes
abstract: Joe Gaeta, an 88-year-old football official on Long Island, more than keeps up with his peers, many of whom are decades younger.
lead_paragraph: BAY SHORE, N.Y. — On a recent Sunday on Long Island, Joe Gaeta sprinted nearly 10 miles over the course of a four-and-a-half-hour workday. Wearing an exercise tracking device, Gaeta put in the kind of day that has become rather routine for him over the last quarter-century: He officiated four Police Athletic League youth football games, jogging across the gridiron more than three dozen times to back up a fellow official’s call. He dashed 100 yards on three occasions to follow long scoring plays and sprinted to the end zone a dozen other times to chase touchdown jaunts of more than 40 yards.

headline: And the 2016 Nominees May Be . . .
abstract: Readers offer their predictions for both parties for the 2016 elections.

headline: Hillary in History
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Women and Girls', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Whether she wins or not, Hillary Clinton — the wife of a former president, with the longest résumé in the room — is a perfect transitional figure.
lead_paragraph: IT’S officially one year until the presidential election. Amazing how time flies, isn’t it? Once again we’re watching debates featuring what appears to be the entire supporting cast of “Ben-Hur.” Once again we’re asking ourselves why Iowa always gets to be first. Once again we’re wondering whether Hillary Clinton will make history by becoming the first woman president.

headline: Thomas S. Marvel, Architect of the Tropical, Dies at 80
abstract: An American who went to the Caribbean and stayed forever.
lead_paragraph: Thomas S. Marvel, an architect whose regional style of modernism left an imprint on dozens of public buildings, churches and houses across the Caribbean, died on Tuesday at his home in San Juan, P.R. He was 80.

abstract: In his 20th and final season in the N.B.A., Bryant has said he does not want opposing teams to honor him with tributes or gifts when the Lakers come to town.
lead_paragraph: Do Kobe Bryant a favor and spare him the pregame testimonials, the gold-plated plaques, the sporty cars and easy chairs. Just deposit his check, give him the ball and get in his way.

Putin of Russia who helped design the government’s takeover of independent media in that country. Mr. Lesin was found in a high-end hotel here on Thursday morning.

headline: Mississippi Flag, a Rebel Holdout, Is in a New Fight
keywords: ['Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Referendums', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: With the closing of the polls on Tuesday night, what could turn out to be the last battle over the Confederate battle flag in Mississippi has begun in earnest.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Miss. — In single strokes after the massacre of nine black churchgoers in Charleston in June, Confederate battle flags were taken from statehouse grounds in South Carolina and Alabama, pulled from shelves at major retailers like Walmart and declared unwelcome, if to limited effect, at Nascar races.

lead_paragraph: Adnan Syed, whose conviction in the murder of his high school ex-girlfriend was the subject of the popular “Serial” podcast, has been granted a hearing that will allow him to introduce new evidence.

headline: Palestinians Channel Their Grief Through a Song for Solidarity
abstract: In Gaza on Saturday, Palestinians gathered to sing “My Homeland,” a longtime anthem, in communities across the territory as part of a social media campaign.
lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — “My Homeland” was once a triumphant military song, played with drums and trumpets, long the anthem of Palestinians. It has since transformed into a lament of a tumultuous region.

headline: A Dancer Is Driven to Succeed After a Homeless Childhood

lead_paragraph: For Sonya Ortiz, being a soloist in Martha Graham’s dance company for teenagers and dancing at Radio City Music Hall for the Garden of Dreams Foundation were milestones, but her greatest achievement was getting into college.

headline: Drought Adds Wrinkle to ‘Rain Room’ Exhibit in California
abstract: An artwork that lets visitors walk through a downpour without getting wet, a hit in New York in 2013, has taken on new meaning with its arrival at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For Southern Californians struggling through the worst drought in the history of the state, relief may finally be here — or at least a sprinkle of relief. Rain has arrived, but it is confined to a 2,500-square-foot windowless room in a museum exhibition on the Miracle Mile, open to a handful of people who are let in for precisely 15 minutes to experience it in all its soaking, spritzing glory.

headline: Passer Recovers and Puts Clemson in One Championship Game
abstract: After a shabby first half, Tigers star quarterback Deshaun Watson went on to rush for a career-high 107 yards and a touchdown, leading Clemson to clinch the Atlantic Coast Conference Atlantic Division.
lead_paragraph: CLEMSON, S.C. — Clemson faced a third-and-3 at the Florida State 7-yard line late in the first half when the Tigers’ star quarterback, Deshaun Watson, took the snap, stepped back and spiked the ball into the ground, thinking he had to stop the clock.

headline: Cricket Exhibition at Citi Field Gets a Boost From Sachin Tendulkar
abstract: Tendulkar was one of two team captains, along with Shane Warne of Australia, leading renowned players from around the world in a three-match series meant to promote cricket in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Just about every big-name cricket player of the last 25 years was at Citi Field on Saturday for an exhibition match. But the thousands of mostly South Asian-Americans who fought traffic or rode the crowded, slow-moving 7 trains to the stadium were mainly there to see one man: Sachin Tendulkar.

headline: A Colorado Town Unfamiliar With Attention Deals With a Flood of It
abstract: After a sexting ring was discovered at a high school in Cañon City, Colo., some residents responded by taking the glut of attention in stride as news media coverage continues in the town.
lead_paragraph: CAÑON CITY, Colo. — The last time this tiny town with the big sexting scandal made national news headlines was probably after the forest fire that burned most of an iconic tourist attraction nearby, the Royal Gorge Bridge and Park. The time before that might have been a shooting, residents said. They could not remember any recent escapes from the high-security prisons that surround them and employ many of the townspeople, but they also could not remember any good news that had put the town in the national eye.

headline: Mourners Gather to Remember Two Victims of Halloween Crash in the Bronx

lead_paragraph: Two coffins sat side by side on the stage at Harvest Fields Community Church in the Bronx as mourners gathered on Saturday to remember a beloved military veteran and his granddaughter who were struck and killed by a car while trick-or-treating on Halloween.

headline: Neediest Cases: Sonya Goes to College
abstract: Despite spending her youth in and out of shelters, Sonya Ortiz not only graduated from high school but is attending college. With a little help, she is now pursuing her dreams.

headline: Marco Rubio’s Use of Party Credit Card Reinforces a Picture of Messy Finances
abstract: Mr. Rubio’s campaign released statements for his Republican Party of Florida-issued American Express card, hoping to at last quiet accusations that he used party money to pay for trips, meals and gifts for him and his family.
lead_paragraph: Newly released credit card statements from the years when Senator Marco Rubio was a young Florida legislator on the fast track to leadership show a pattern of falling behind on payments while mingling personal and political spending, disclosures that reinforce the image of a politician who has long struggled with messy finances, at home and in his career.

headline: The Best Moments in College Football This Week

headline: 1965: African-American Seeks Cabinet Post
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Robert C. Weaver voices his desire to run the Department of Urban Development in 1965.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It has become an axiom in the Johnson era that if a man wants a high government post, the last thing he does is say so. And a newspaper story saying that an official desires a cabinet job, or is under consideration, is regarded as the surest path to early retirement. Consequently, it raised eyebrows in official Washington today [Nov. 8] when Robert C. Weaver, the highest- ranking Negro in the government, answered ‘‘yes,’’ when asked whether he wanted the cabinet post of secretary of the new Department of Housing and Urban Development. The department, still headless, comes into being at 12:01 a.m. tomorrow. President Johnson hasn’t indicated his choice for the new cabinet post, and won’t until early next year, according to a White House announcement over the weekend. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 9, 1965

headline: 1940: Robbing Nazi Prisoner Is Legal Under British Law
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The robbing of a Nazi prisoner is declared legal in 1940.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Delving 192 years back into musty English jurisprudence, an attorney quoted today [Nov. 8] a decision of the Kings Bench division in the reign of William III that a British subject is ‘‘entitled to what he can take from the King’s enemies.’’ The attorney obtained freedom for a member of the Home Guard, who had been charged with the theft of a German pistol, six rounds of ammunition and a flying helmet from a Nazi airman who had bailed out over Chatham, Kent. These articles were alleged to be ‘‘the property of his majesty,’’ but Gerald Thesiger, defending Harry Foulds, member of the Home Guard, cited the judgment of a prize court of 1748. That court had held that a subject was entitled to whatever he could take from the King’s enemies and that such property had never been vested in the crown. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 9, 1940

headline: Backed by Nail Salon Owners, a New York Legislator Now Fights Reforms
keywords: ['Beauty Salons', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Nails (Body Part)', 'Korean-Americans', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: Assemblyman Ron Kim, who was instrumental in creating a law to protect workers, has since received tens of thousands of dollars in political donations from salon owners and industry groups.
lead_paragraph: In a packed hall in the Bronx a few months ago, Ron Kim, a New York State assemblyman, stood clutching a ceremonial pen in his left hand, the other extended into the crowd as labor advocates, politicians and immigrant rights workers thronged to shake it. Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo had just used the pen to sign into law a bill protecting nail salon workers from labor abuses and potentially dangerous chemicals. It was a measure that Mr. Kim, who represents the mostly Asian enclave of Flushing, Queens, had spent a painstaking summer helping to craft.

headline: Yitzhak Navon, 94, Israeli Ex-President, Dies; Part of Founding Generation
abstract: The scion of an old Jerusalem family, Mr. Navon served as Israel’s fifth president and was one of the fading generation of Israeli state builders.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Yitzhak Navon, who took part in the founding of Israel, served as its fifth president, from 1978 to 1983, in a largely ceremonial role, and then returned to politics as a Labor Party legislator and minister of education, died late Friday night at his home here. He was 94.

headline: TED Prize Goes to Archaeologist Who Combats Looting With Satellite Technology
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Satellites', 'TED Conference', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']
abstract: An archaeologist’s quest to track illicit digs at ancient sites, part of a global effort to stop such activity, has received a $1 million TED prize.
lead_paragraph: Her laptop brims with satellite images pitted with thousands of black dots, evidence of excavations across Egypt where looters have tunneled in search of mummies, jewelry and other valuables prized by collectors, advertised in auction catalogs and trafficked on eBay, a criminal global black market estimated in the billions of dollars.

headline: French Artist Kills Off Chinese Alter Ego, but Some Knew of Ruse
abstract: Though the French-born Alexandre Ouairy recently revealed he had been exhibiting under the pseudonym Tao Hongjing for the past decade, his assumed identity hasn’t helped him that profoundly.
lead_paragraph: Last week, a French artist living in Shanghai named Alexandre Ouairy received a wave of press attention for revealing that he had been exhibiting under the Chinese pseudonym Tao Hongjing for the past decade. According to news reports, he had assumed the pseudonym a decade ago, based on a suggestion by his gallerist, in order to cash in on the market there for Chinese contemporary art, a goldmine unavailable to an artist of French descent living in China. Now, on the eve of two solo shows — at Red Gate Gallery in Beijing and Shun Gallery in Shanghai — Mr. Ouairy was finally coming clean, acknowledging that the whole masquerade had been a “conceptual art project.”

headline: Review: ‘A Wild Swan,’ Michael Cunningham’s Scabrous Antidote to Happily Ever After
abstract: The author recasts familiar fairy-tale outcomes from the perspective of a louche cynic.
lead_paragraph: Anyone familiar with the work of Michael Cunningham knows that he holds the notion of happy endings in bittersweet regard. He said as much to The New Yorker this summer: “‘And they lived happily ever after’ struck me as insufficient, and a bit of a cop-out. Happy all the time? Forever?”

headline: Review: ‘Chang(e)’ Explores a Woman’s Self-Immolation
abstract: Soomi Kim and Suzi Takahashi recount the life and death of Kathy Change, a political protester who died in 1996, in a work at Here Arts Center.
lead_paragraph: In the final moments of “Chang(e),” a docudrama at Here Arts Center, an artist and activist,Kathy Change, sets herself afire. This is not a spoiler. Self-immolation is how the real Kathy Change extinguished her life, in front of a peace sign sculpture on the campus of the University of Pennsylvania, one morning in 1996.

headline: Review: Eric Yves Garcia’s ‘Pour Spirits,’ a Taste of Musical Role-Playing

Is it a tribute to “spirits,” as in alcohol? Is “pour” to be taken as a pun on “poor” to elicit sympathy?

headline: Review: Volmir Cordeiro, Assuming an Aspiring Celebrity’s Identity
abstract: In his solo piece “Inês” at Danspace, the Brazilian dancer inhabits the personality of a would-be player in a “Real Housewives” show, with stars in her eyes.
lead_paragraph: Volmir Cordeiro, carefully placing one long leg in front of the other like a spindly supermodel, took deliberate steps to the front of the stage where he planted himself to talk about Inês, a 57-year-old with an all-too-common affliction: an insatiable need to be famous.

headline: Babies (Aww …)
abstract: Aww, look … Pawel Fludzinski is back. That’s nice.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY POST — Aww … look how cute! It’s a delightful puzzle by Pawel Fludzinski to start off our solving week.

headline: Review: Robin Rhode Takes Schoenberg’s ‘Erwartung’ to the Street (Broadway, No Less)
abstract: In “Arnold Schönberg’s ‘Erwartung’: A Performance by Robin Rhode,” part of Performa 15, Carole Sidney Louis sang of desperation.
lead_paragraph: Like many, I’ve walked through Times Square and experienced something I can only properly call despair. But I tip my hat to the lady who was drifting, crouching, shrieking and generally existing just past the verge of a nervous breakdown between 42nd and 43rd Streets on Broadway early Saturday evening. Even at my worst, she had me beat.

headline: Review: Axiom Displays Its New-Music Range at Alice Tully Hall
abstract: The conductor Jeffrey Milarsky led members of this Juilliard School group in a program of contemporary works.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Adès’s quartet “Catch” seems like a parody of chamber dynamics, a mini-drama featuring an insecure musician, ego clashes and temporary defections. The humorous piece, written in 1991, when Mr. Adès was a student, is scored for piano, violin, cello and clarinet: The first three instruments cajole the clarinetist into joining the proceedings.

headline: A Selfless Caretaker, First as a Daughter, Now as a Mother
abstract: Celeste Lawton was so occupied with her sick mother’s needs that she ended up leaving high school. Now she’s working hard to provide for her own daughter.
lead_paragraph: At 13, Celeste Lawton was sticking needles in her mother’s arms: Melody Banks needed insulin injections to combat her diabetes, and there was no one else to help when the nurse was off duty.

headline: Boxing Is a Brutal, Fading Sport. Could Football Be Next?
abstract: Brain injuries have turned boxing into a sport many see as too brutal. Perhaps football will fall into the same category for the same reason one day.
lead_paragraph: The sweet science. That was the lofty sobriquet assigned to boxing long ago by devoted followers with a romantic flair. But there came a time when the fight game’s hold on the American spirit began to loosen, when it stood widely condemned as plain brutal.

headline: A Diminished Kobe Bryant Still Finds a Warm Welcome at the Garden

headline: Giants Escape With Win and Credit Jason Pierre-Paul With Helping

In the late afternoon, the rain that had threatened to flood the area halted, and an hour before kickoff, any likely possibility that the winner would not be competing for a playoff spot in December was eliminated.

headline: 9-Year-Old Girl Is Killed by a Pit Bull on Long Island

lead_paragraph: MONROVIA, Liberia — There’s a saying in Liberia: When wartime comes, the foot will help the body. On Sunday, Liberians lined up at the ELWA hospital compound were invoking this favorite phrase to help explain the confounding sight of their fellow countrymen running in a marathon.

lead_paragraph: Nearly 16 hours after beginning his shift behind the wheel of a yellow cab, a driver struck and killed an 88-year-old woman as she crossed an Upper Manhattan street with the right of way early Sunday morning, a police official said.

United was not about to make life easy for the Red Bulls, refusing to play pretty soccer against one of the more entertaining, attacking teams in Major League Soccer.

lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump, who has taken well-documented liberties with facts from his own life story and from his campaign for president, sought repeatedly on Sunday to cast doubt on the honesty of Ben Carson, his surging Republican rival.

keywords: ['Radio', 'Music', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Disc Jockeys']

headline: Review: ‘Allegiance,’ a Musical History Lesson About Interned Japanese-Americans
abstract: This Broadway musical with George Takei and Lea Salonga sets out to illuminate a dark passage in American history.
lead_paragraph: “Allegiance,” a new musical about the internment of Japanese-Americans in camps during World War II, could be said to suffer from a problem of divided loyalties, and I’m not referring to its characters. The show wants to illuminate a dark passage in American history with complexity and honesty, but the first requirement of any Broadway musical is to entertain. While well-intentioned and polished, “Allegiance” struggles to balance both ambitions, and doesn’t always find an equilibrium.

headline: Review: ‘Hir’ Sorts Through a Family in Transition

headline: ‘The Walking Dead’ Recap: Season 6, Episode 5, ‘Now’
abstract: The Alexandrians struggled to face the facts, but many issues remain unresolved.
lead_paragraph: Toward the end of this week’s “The Walking Dead,” Maggie, dejected and wandering through a sewer of waterlogged walkers and broken dreams, collapsed into an emotional heap of Glenn-grief, self-recrimination and anguished uncertainty.

headline: ‘The Leftovers’ Season 2, Episode 6 Recap: Her Eye Is on the Sparrow
abstract: The show’s greatest strength may be its ability to convey so much narrative information so naturally.
lead_paragraph: “The Leftovers” excels at many things, but its greatest strength may be its ability to convey so much narrative information so naturally. This week’s episode, “Lens” — which deftly explains a ton of back story and demystifies previously cryptic details — is a master class in how that’s done. By the end of the hour, we know why there are numerical markers on the streets of Miracle (they’re part of the audio tour); we know why Jerry keeps killing goats (because he killed one on that fateful Oct. 14, and many think that’s what made Miracle immune from departures); we know that Erika was planning to leave John; and we know why she buried that bird, and why (well, sort of) it emerged from that shoebox alive.

headline: ‘Homeland’ Season 5, Episode 6: Everyone Seems Off-Kilter

headline: The Best of Week 9 in the N.F.L.
abstract: The top performers and key injuries in the league this week.
lead_paragraph: Antonio Brown set Steelers marks with 284 receiving yards and 17 catches, including a 57-yarder on the game’s final drive that set up a winning field goal. “I really don’t know what to say but ‘wow,’ ” said Raiders safety Charles Woodson, who spent most of the day futilely chasing Brown around Heinz Field. Brown and DeAngelo Williams, who ran for 170 yards and two scores and had 55 receiving yards, combined for 531 of Pittsburgh’s 597 yards of offense.

headline: Being Dishonest About Ugliness
keywords: ['Beauty (Concept)', 'Parenting', 'Books and Literature', 'Children and Childhood', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: We should stop pretending to children that looks do not matter. Some ugly ducklings never turn into swans.
lead_paragraph: ADULTS often tangle themselves in knots when discussing physical appearance with children. We try to iron out differences by insisting they don’t matter, attribute a greater moral fortitude to the plain or leap in defensively when someone is described as not conventionally attractive, or — worse — ugly or fat. After all, there are better, kinder words to use, or other characteristics to focus on.

headline: Despair, American Style
keywords: ['Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Age, Chronological', 'United States Economy', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Searching for economic and cultural reasons why middle-aged white Americans are dying sooner.
lead_paragraph: A couple of weeks ago President Obama mocked Republicans who are “down on America,” and reinforced his message by doing a pretty good Grumpy Cat impression. He had a point: With job growth at rates not seen since the 1990s, with the percentage of Americans covered by health insurance hitting record highs, the doom-and-gloom predictions of his political enemies look ever more at odds with reality.

headline: An Island Refuge, Surrounded by Bloody Civil War, in South Sudan
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Civilian Casualties', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Child Soldiers']
abstract: Tens of thousands of desperate civilians have sought safety in a swamp that is full of dangers, but none that compare to the atrocities they fled.
lead_paragraph: UNITY STATE, South Sudan — The swamp is so large it can be seen from space. During the rainy season, it stretches over an area the size of France, a forbidding maze of reeds and crocodiles that long warded off even the most intrepid of explorers searching for the source of the Nile, whose waters flood these clay plains.

headline: Cuba’s Secret Bedrooms
abstract: Carlos Otero Blanco has seen parts of Cuba that are off-limits to most people: bedrooms. The scenes tell tales of everyday life.
lead_paragraph: Carlos Otero Blanco has seen parts of his native Cuba that are off-limits to most people. He does not need a security clearance, just a smile and small talk. Given the pushback he sometimes gets, it might just be easier to photograph the Council of State.

headline: F.C.C. Sides With Hot Spots, and Hospitality Industry Feels a Chill
keywords: ['Wireless Communications', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The commission is cracking down on convention centers that electronically block Wi-Fi hot spots to push guests to pay high rates for Internet access.
lead_paragraph: Fed up with Internet charges that can range into six figures, more meeting planners are instead using mobile hot spots to connect at conferences and conventions. But their efforts have at times been stymied, when the venues have electronically blocked the transmissions.

headline: Democratic Group Called iVote Pushes Automatic Voter Registration
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Drivers Licenses', 'States (US)', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)']
abstract: Former aides to President Obama and President Bill Clinton have pledged to spend up to $10 million in an effort to get states to register anyone getting a driver’s license.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Republicans across the country mount an aggressive effort to tighten voting laws, a group of former aides to President Obama and President Bill Clinton is pledging to counter by spending up to $10 million on a push to make voter registration automatic whenever someone gets a driver’s license.

headline: How to Upgrade Your Thanksgiving Road Trip
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Automobiles', 'Families and Family Life', 'Road Trips', 'Thanksgiving Day']
abstract: From a plug-in espresso machine to an organizer for toys and gadgets, accessories to make your trip go smoother.
lead_paragraph: While talk of Thanksgiving travel often centers around the cost and tribulations of flying, during the holiday weekend more Americans actually hit the road.  AAA estimated that nearly 90 percent of Thanksgiving travelers in 2014 would go by automobile, with about 46 million people driving 50 miles or more from home. This year, why not make the journey more enjoyable? After all, you could spend hours sitting in traffic. Or maybe dinner at your cousin’s house wasn’t as tasty, er, filling, as you had hoped. Everyone knows to bring along the usual accessories, like phone chargers and tablet mounts. But certain extras can help shift a ho-hum road trip into the next gear. Below, a guide.

headline: Would You Want to Hang Out at a Cat Cafe?
abstract: What is the appeal of visiting a cafe where cats are available for adoption?
lead_paragraph: What do you know about so-called cat cafes? Do you like cats? What about other animals?

headline: Jon Meacham’s ‘Destiny and Power: The American Odyssey of George Herbert Walker Bush’
abstract: Jon Meacham recounts and celebrates the life of George H. W. Bush.
lead_paragraph: George H. W. Bush is unusual among modern American presidents in that after he left the White House in 1993 he never produced his own full-scale autobiography. True, he co-wrote a book about his administration’s foreign policy with Brent Scowcroft, his national security adviser, and then allowed a collection of his letters and diary excerpts to be published. But he showed no interest in writing the kind of doorstopper others have given us, nothing on the order of “RN: The Memoirs of Richard Nixon,” “Ronald Reagan: An American Life” or Bill Clinton’s “My Life.” Even Hillary Clinton, who may yet be president and thus get her own chance to add to the genre, has already written two thick memoirs, either of which, if you accidentally dropped it on your foot, might leave you limping.

abstract: On Mondays, we publish a Times photo without a caption, headline or other information about its origins. Join the conversation by commenting on what you see and why. A live discussion is offered that day from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. Eastern.

headline: Law Firm Loathed by Tech Expands to Industry’s Home Turf

abstract: A class action firm that routinely targets tech companies is opening an office in San Francisco, not far from many of the companies it has sued.

lead_paragraph: With a month to go before Congress must finish its 12 spending bills or face another case of shutdown fever, the Senate returns on Monday to focus on one of the least contentious of the measures — legislation funding veterans and military construction programs.

headline: Taiwan Debates Its President’s Meeting With Xi Jinping of China
abstract: Tsai Ing-wen, the leader of Taiwan’s main opposition party and the front-runner in the presidential race, said the meeting left many people in Taiwan disappointed or even angry.
lead_paragraph: While Chinese commentary was resoundingly positive about Saturday’s meeting between President Xi Jinping of China and President Ma Ying-jeou of Taiwan, reactions in Taiwan to the historic encounter were decidedly mixed.

headline: Obama and Netanyahu to Meet After a Tense Year
abstract: After months of long-distance jousting over the Iran nuclear deal, President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel will discuss the issue at the White House on Monday to try to put their feuding behind them.
lead_paragraph: After months of long-distance jousting over the Iran nuclear deal, President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel will meet on Monday for the first time in more than a year and try to put their feuding behind them.

headline: Good Talks Needed to Combat HPV Vaccine Myth
abstract: The low immunization rate with the vaccine, tied in part to the touchy issue of sex, has measurably negative consequences.
lead_paragraph: When people hear about vaccine deniers — anti-vaxxers, to some — they most often think about parents who are refusing to vaccinate their children. But there’s another type of vaccine refusal, and it’s important that we not ignore that. Doctors sometimes promote the use of some vaccines with less enthusiasm than others. Sometimes, they don’t talk about them at all.

headline: Bernie Sanders Takes His Turn Questioning the Questioners
abstract: As they increase their criticism of the news media, Republicans are finding an ally in Senator Bernie Sanders, a Democrat, who bristled on the Sunday talk shows about questions he thought were too focused on politics.

headline: In a Corner of New York City That Goes ‘Back Into the 70s,’ Gunman Kills One and Wounds Two
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: The early morning altercation started inside a McDonald’s on Eighth Avenue, between 34th and 35th Streets, that has a reputation as a throwback to a seedier era in New York.
lead_paragraph: Sandwiched between the gleaming towers rising over the West Side of Midtown Manhattan and the bright lights of 42nd Street, a corridor of brown brick buildings along Eighth Avenue shrouds the remnants of an earlier era of New York City street life. The drug-addled loll on corners. The pornography seekers slink out of shops.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — The chairman of the insurer Standard Life will join Barclays in January as deputy chairman and senior independent director, the British bank said on Monday.

headline: Jordanian Police Officer Kills Five, Including Two Americans

lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — At least five people, including two American trainers, were killed on Monday at an Amman training compound by a Jordanian police officer who fired on them before he was shot to death, the government said.

abstract: Seventy years ago, department store shoppers in Philadelphia got the first look at Richard James’s new plaything.
lead_paragraph: The Slinky, which first appeared in the Gimbels department store in Philadelphia 70 years ago this month, didn’t start out as a toy.
