headline: How a Small Indie Magazine Gets Fashion’s Hottest Tell-Alls
abstract: It’s by the fashion world, for the fashion world. And, with Raf Simons, it has its third smash issue.
lead_paragraph: When Raf Simons left Christian Dior just over two weeks ago — a designer departure felt round the world — he did so with the usual anodyne joint news release containing generic quotes in which he and Dior management expressed their mutual appreciation and respect. That, they said, was the end of it; no one involved was giving any further interviews.

headline: Google Offers Free Software in Bid to Gain an Edge in Machine Learning
abstract: Google is making much of its machine-learning technology freely available as open-source software. The move is intended to accelerate innovation in the field and enrich Google.
lead_paragraph: A race is underway toward the future of computer technology with advances in a branch of artificial intelligence known as machine learning. Machine-learning software is trained to handle vast amounts of data, and then learns as it goes, often on its own.

headline: 1940: De Gaulle Strikes in Africa
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Gen. Charles de Gaulle and his troops land in Gabon in 1940.
lead_paragraph: VICHY — The situation in French Africa became more tense today [Nov. 9] as reports reached here that ‘‘Free French’’ forces headed by Gen. Charles de Gaulle and Gen. de Larminat, after conquering Lambaréné, in the interior of Gabon, French Equatorial Africa, had effected a landing near Libreville, the most important seaport of Gabon. British light naval units supported the landing, it was reported here. The Vichy government asserted yesterday that Libreville would remain loyal to the government of Premier Marshal Henri Pétain. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 10, 1940

headline: Match Is Seeking $3.1 Billion Value in I.P.O.
abstract: The owner of the online dating brands OkCupid and Tinder sets a price range of $12 to $14 a share.
lead_paragraph: The Match Group is seeking a valuation of about $3.1 billion as it prepares for an initial public offering.

headline: Drugs Pervade Sport in Russia, World Anti-Doping Agency Report Finds
abstract: The report, by the World Anti-Doping Agency, implicates athletes, coaches, trainers, doctors and various Russian institutions.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Members of Russia’s secret service intimidated workers at a drug-testing lab to cover up top athletes’ positive results. They impersonated lab engineers during the Winter Olympics in Sochi last year. A lab once destroyed more than 1,400 samples.

headline: Daily Report: Using the Web to Transform Public Radio
keywords: ['Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Public Broadcasting', 'Radio', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: The digital shift was supposed to destroy public radio, with so much streaming music available through the web. But some stations have found a way to turn the change to their advantage.
lead_paragraph: Video — not to mention online music streaming — was supposed to kill the radio star. Instead, some longtime radio stations have found a way to transform and use all the new Internet outlets to thrive, Nick Wingfield writes.

headline: Sunday TV Recaps: ‘Homeland,’ ‘The Walking Dead,’ ‘The Affair’ and ‘The Leftovers’
abstract: Recaps of select Sunday night series.
lead_paragraph: Recaps of select Sunday night series.

headline: Darth Jar Jar and the Wisdom of Fans
abstract: How the online fanbeast and its theories could save certain creators from themselves.
lead_paragraph: During what was a relatively slow time for political news last week, up to and including the Ben Carson West Point “controversy,” the nerdier reaches of the political internet (but I repeat myself) spent a lot of time on two “Star Wars”-related conversations. First, the elaborate theory, first spun out by a Reddit user, that the hated Jar Jar Binks was originally supposed to be a Yoda-style Force master, a Dark Side adept cloaking his powers in bungling and clowning, until the backlash against his character persuaded George Lucas to bury the idea. Second, the controversial defenses of the Empire being spun out by Sonny Bunch (standing on the shoulders of Jonathan Last), and contested by Jedi apologists and rebel sympathizers on the left, center and right alike — up to and including one Senator Ted Cruz.

headline: Creditors Withhold 2 Billion Euro Bailout Payment From Greece
abstract: As Greece tries to secure the next installment from its $92 billion package, Greek officials and foreign creditors remain at odds over whether Athens has met economic overhaul targets.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Greece’s international bailout program has hit snags, delaying release of the next payout of rescue money.

headline: Conviction Offers Guide to Future ‘Spoofing’ Cases
keywords: ['Securities and Commodities Violations', 'High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)']
abstract: The successful prosecution of Michael Coscia shows the potential power of the spoofing provision to reshape how high-frequency trading firms operate.
lead_paragraph: The recent conviction of Michael Coscia in the Federal District Court in Chicago in the first prosecution for “spoofing” provides more clarity to high-frequency trading firms about how they can operate. The message is to tread carefully when a strategy depends on using orders that will be quickly canceled because the government may claim they are an effort to manipulate the market by fooling others into trading.

headline: As China and Europe Age, Path to More Children Lies Beyond Bedroom
keywords: ['Birth Rates', 'Population', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Children and Childhood', 'Workplace Environment']
abstract: Simply allowing more offspring will not necessarily lead to a higher fertility rate, experts say, that is achieved by greater gender equality, more trust within society and higher immigration.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — China’s decision to allow more families to have a second child is an effort to confront a problem that is facing much of Europe, too — aging populations and not enough babies. But reversing a demographic slide involves a complicated set of incentives that have more to do with social mores than with government policies, experts say.

headline: Ben Carson Backers Ramp Up Counterattack, Highlighting His Medical Career
keywords: ['Doctors', 'News and News Media', 'Political Action Committees', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: As part of a strategy to counteract recent negative publicity, Ben Carson’s supporters want to reveal the bedside manner of the candidate who is famous for being the first surgeon to separate twins who were joined at the head.
lead_paragraph: With his biography under the microscope, supporters of Ben Carson are digging in with new plans to highlight the Republican presidential candidate’s most clear-cut credential: his career as a renowned neurosurgeon.

headline: Russia Says Stalled Arms Deal With Iran Is Signed and Active
keywords: ['Arms Trade', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'International Relations']
abstract: Russia said it was moving on a nearly 10-year-old contract with Iran to deliver powerful air defense missiles, though it gave no delivery date or any other details.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia’s most senior arms executive said Monday that a contract to supply Iran with powerful S-300 air defense missiles was now active. But with no delivery date or any other details, the announcement seemed aimed more at warding off an Iranian lawsuit than a major step toward delivery of the weapon system.

headline: Key Figures in the Russian Doping Scandal
abstract: Here is a look at the officials and athletes named in the World Anti-Doping Association’s report on Russian doping.
lead_paragraph: Here is a look at the officials and athletes named in the World Anti-Doping Association’s report on Russian doping.

abstract: The company, whose last private investment round valued it at more than $3 billion, makes products meant to make life easier for software developers.
lead_paragraph: Atlassian, a maker of development and collaboration software for companies, filed on Monday to go public.

headline: University of Missouri Protests Spur a Day of Change
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Football (College)', 'Discrimination']
abstract: After the football team added its clout to protests over racial issues, Timothy Wolfe announced that he was stepping down as president of the four-campus system, and the chancellor, R. Bowen Loftin, said he would move into another job.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, Mo. — Months of student and faculty protests over racial tensions and other issues that all but paralyzed the University of Missouri campus culminated Monday in an extraordinary coup for the demonstrators, as the president of the university system resigned and the chancellor of the flagship campus here said he would step down to a less prominent role at the end of the year.

headline: Thanksgiving: What We Believe
abstract: There is no more welcoming, inclusive holiday on the American calendar, and this year we extend that feeling to the food itself.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. Beginning today, that email will also appear on nytimes.com. To receive the email, register here.

headline: The Crispr Quandary
abstract: A new gene-editing tool might create an ethical morass — or it might make revising nature seem natural.
lead_paragraph: One day in March 2011, Emmanuelle Charpentier, a geneticist who was studying flesh-eating bacteria, approached Jennifer Doudna, an award-winning scientist, at a microbiology conference in Puerto Rico. Charpentier, a more junior researcher, hoped to persuade Doudna, the head of a formidably large lab at the University of California, Berkeley, to collaborate. While walking the cobblestone streets of Old San Juan, the two women fell to talking. Charpentier had recently grown interested in a particular gene, known as Crispr, that seemed to help flesh-eating bacteria fight off invasive viruses. By understanding that gene, as well as the protein that enabled it, called Cas9, Charpentier hoped to find a way to cure patients infected with the bacteria by stripping it of its protective immune system.

headline: World Anti-Doping Agency Report on Russian Doping Program
abstract: The report described a pervasive doping culture among Russia’s sports programs and implicated athletes, coaches, trainers, doctors and various Russian institutions.
lead_paragraph: The report described a pervasive doping culture among Russia’s sports programs and implicated athletes, coaches, trainers, doctors and various Russian institutions.

headline: 1965: Pacifist Sets Fire to Himself
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: An antiwar demonstrator sets fire to himself in front of the United Nations in 1965.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — A young student who once tried to become a Trappist monk set himself on fire in front of the United Nations here today [Nov. 9] screaming that he was against all wars. Police said Roger Laporte, 22, identified as a student and part-time volunteer for the Catholic Worker Movement, a pacifist organization, was in critical condition in Bellevue Hospital with burns over his entire body. Last rites were administered after Mr. Laporte expressed repentance over his violation of the Roman Catholic Church’s strict religious credo against suicide. It was the second incident of its kind in a week. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 10, 1965

headline: In Ancient Times, Salamanders Bared Their Fangs
abstract: Amphibian fossils discovered in Brazil suggest the Pangaean supercontinent held extensive southern tropics.
lead_paragraph: Researchers have discovered amphibian fossils in northeastern Brazil that date back 278 million years, to the time of the supercontinent Pangaea. Until now, little was known about animal life in the southern tropical regions of the continent.

headline: Unesco Rejects Kosovo Membership in a Victory for Serbia
abstract: Serbia had lobbied hard against Kosovo’s candidacy for the United Nations’ cultural agency, which had been supported by the major Western countries.
lead_paragraph: BELGRADE, Serbia — Unesco, the United Nations’ cultural agency, narrowly denied Kosovo membership on Monday, handing a sizable political victory to Serbia, which had fought a fierce battle against the bid for months.

headline: The True Heart of French Seaside Chic
abstract: Let the partiers keep the Riviera. Just a few hundred miles to the west sits the alluring little island of Île de Ré, and its unspoiled pastures and vineyards.
lead_paragraph: Let the partiers keep the Riviera. Just a few hundred miles to the west sits the alluring little island of Île de Ré, and its unspoiled pastures and vineyards.

headline: A.D.H.D. Rates Rise Around Globe, but Sympathy Often Lags
abstract: Debates about the validity of A.D.H.D. and the drugs used to treat it — the same that have long polarized Americans — are now playing out all over the world.
lead_paragraph: Last year, Sinan Sonmezler of Istanbul refused to keep going to school. His eighth-grade classmates called him “weird” and “stupid,” and his teachers rebuked him for his tendency to stare out the window during class. The school director told his parents he was “lazy.”

headline: Lapsing Faculties
abstract: Help a forgetful high-school teacher remember the day of the week — a short math puzzle by Math Circles presenter Marc Roth.
lead_paragraph: This week’s puzzle is an original suggested by Marc Roth, a math teacher at the Woodside Learning Center and presenter at Math Circles in the San Francisco Bay Area. Let’s try —

headline: Locking in Votes and Doling Out ‘Dogs’: How Roberts Assigns Opinions
abstract: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. pays keen attention to strategy, a study says, noting that the swing justice, Anthony M. Kennedy, is given a large number of big cases.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the chief justice is in the majority, he gets to decide who will write the Supreme Court’s opinion. This is, Justice Felix Frankfurter once wrote, “perhaps the most delicate judgment demanded of the chief justice.”

headline: Animals Rely on Hair to Keep Clean, Study Finds
abstract: In insects and mammals alike, hairs trap dirt particles but also help remove them.
lead_paragraph: The honeybee and the squirrel have the same number of hairs: about three million. A moth has 10 billion hairs, while the human head has only 100,000.

headline: Gansevoort Street, With Up-and-Down History, Could Grow Taller Again
abstract: In the meatpacking district, a historic block where tenements were once chopped in half may soon be altered to include buildings that rise four, six and eight stories.
lead_paragraph: Despite what you might have heard, the cobblestones of the meatpacking district still run red. But now it is with flecks of beef tartare and hibiscus cocktails, the crimson soles of Louboutins and what looks like a blob of plasma but is actually red paint from one of the half-dozen artists’ stalls that followed the Whitney Museum downtown.

headline: The Gold Bug Bites Texas Politicians
abstract: A new law allows Texas to establish its own gold bullion depository. But that might not be such a good idea.
lead_paragraph: Fantasies of secession danced like tumbleweed when Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas signed an odd new law in June authorizing the state to be the first in the nation to create its own gold bullion depository. The goal, Mr. Abbott’s office announced, is to “repatriate $1 billion in gold bullion from the Federal Reserve in New York.” That’s repatriate, as in moving 6,643 gold bars from one country to another.

headline: When to Ignore a Promise to ‘Never Put Me in a Home’
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Elderly', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Living Wills and Health Care Proxies', 'Nursing Homes']
abstract: Directives about how people want to be cared for at the end of their lives are often ignored, overlooked, lost — or even incomprehensible.
lead_paragraph: Our new patient, 88 years old, had been demented for years. She was admitted to the hospital with a deep, malodorous and infected pressure sore stretching from the top of her right shoulder down to the middle of her spine.

headline: Human Trafficking at Sea: Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: The reporter Ian Urbina gives readers a taste of his experience reporting on illicit activities in the sea near the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes even open secrets are worth exploring. During the year I spent reporting on lawlessness at sea, many sources mentioned so-called manning agencies that trick seafarers into working on the world’s ships, especially fishing vessels.

headline: American Prisoner in Yemen Said to Face Death Sentence
abstract: Sharif Mobley, who was arrested in 2010 in a sweep of suspected militants tied to Al Qaeda, told his lawyers that he could be sentenced even amid the country’s civil war.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Lawyers for an American held prisoner in Yemen’s capital said that their client could be sentenced to death on murder charges at his next hearing scheduled for Wednesday, despite the difficulty of conducting a trial during Yemen’s civil war.

headline: With a Mobile Website Like an App, Flipkart Takes a Swipe at Apple
keywords: ['Chrome (Browser)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Mobile Applications', 'Mobile Commerce and Payments', 'Smartphones', 'Start-ups', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: Flipkart worked with Google to create a new mobile website that was unveiled on Monday in a move to improve the mobile web experience and steer away from apps.
lead_paragraph: India’s e-commerce start-up Flipkart has worked with Google to make a new mobile website that could eliminate the need for apps, in a move that takes a swipe at Apple’s grip on the mobile experience.

headline: Weyerhaeuser’s Big Acquisition Looks Good on Paper
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Wood and Wood Products', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: A 14 percent premium for Plum Creek, a timberland REIT, is modest but fair. Weyerhaeuser’s long transformation looks nearly complete.
lead_paragraph: Weyerhaeuser’s new $23 billion woodland monster looks good on paper. Weyerhaeuser, the forestry giant, is paying a 14 percent premium for a $7 billion rival, Plum Creek Timber. That’s modest but fair, given the expected cost savings and a planned $2.5 billion stock buyback for both sets of shareholders.

headline: One Paris Boutique Takes Inspiration From the Catskills
abstract: Beginning next week, Colette will feature a collection of goods, art, music and literature from the region.
lead_paragraph: For several years, Sarah Andelman, the founder and creative director of the cult Paris boutique Colette, has been a regular visitor to the Catskills, where she and her family have owned a house for the past decade. In 2011, she got married in Woodstock, and she now spends many of her holidays and summers in the region. “I think I feel a little guilty spending so much time upstate,” she recently told T in an email from the house, where she and her family had come from Paris to celebrate Halloween.

headline: Supreme Court Sides With Police Officer Who Shot Man in Car Chase
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: In the case, a majority of the Supreme Court ruled that the officer had qualified immunity after he shot a suspect fleeing in a car from an overpass in Texas.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday ruled for a police officer who shot and killed a fleeing suspect from a highway overpass. The court’s decision was unsigned and issued without full briefing and oral argument, an indication that the majority found the case to be easy.

headline: Fecal Transplants Made (Somewhat) More Palatable
abstract: The controversial procedure seems to cure some patients of dangerous C. difficile infections. Now there’s a simpler option, in pill form.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Catherine Duff, then 57, tearfully described eight debilitating bouts of antibiotic-resistant Clostridium difficile infection to a government panel in Washington. She grew better, she said, only after treating the gastrointestinal infection at home with her husband’s feces, a blender and an enema bag.

headline: As Golf Returns to the Olympics, a Brazilian Golfer Hopes to Return to Rio, Too
abstract: Candy Hannemann wants to play in the 2016 Games in her hometown, despite years away from the highest level of the sport.
lead_paragraph: Candy Hannemann had been sidelined from the L.P.G.A. Tour for several years because of wrist operations when she learned that golf would return to the 2016 Olympic Games.

headline: Obama and Netanyahu Seek to Move Past Rift Over Iran Nuclear Deal
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Palestinians']
abstract: In their first encounter since their feud over the Iran nuclear deal, President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel spoke of their shared goals.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel sought on Monday to move beyond their bitter rupture over the Iran nuclear deal, turning the page on a season of poisonous relations during a White House meeting that focused on collaboration over acrimony.

headline: Review: In ‘tiger tiger,’ a Quest for Answers in a Mauling
abstract: Jessica Almasy’s play, at Dixon Place, shifts from an interview with a guilty tiger to a look at the teenagers who survived an attack.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Almasy’s “tiger tiger (on the nature of violence)” at Dixon Place burns loudly and hotly, though not especially brightly. Based glancingly on a Christmas Day mauling at the San Francisco Zoo in 2007 that left a teenager dead, at first it seems to be about the need to assign meaning to catastrophe. Then it doesn’t seem to be about much of anything at all.

headline: Trial of Vincent Asaro Highlights Loss of Mafia’s Code of Silence
keywords: ['Organized Crime', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Robberies and Thefts']
abstract: Mr. Asaro is accused of crimes including murder and the 1978 Lufthansa robbery, but unlike other suspects, he did not make a deal with the government.
lead_paragraph: After he had helped pull off one of the biggest cash robberies in American history — the Lufthansa heist of 1978 — and stashed millions of dollars, along with burlap sacks of gold chains, crates of watches, and diamonds and emeralds, in his cousin’s basement, Vincent Asaro thought first about the code: Protect the family.

headline: N.Y.C.F.C. Hires Patrick Vieira as Coach
abstract: The French World Cup winner, plucked from a developmental role with Manchester City, will take over at N.Y.C.F.C. on Jan. 1, the team said.
lead_paragraph: New York City F.C. named the French World Cup winner Patrick Vieira as its coach Monday, plucking him from a developmental role with its parent club, Manchester City, to try to improve on a disappointing first season in Major League Soccer.

headline: Campbell Rethinks Its Soup Recipe as Consumer Tastes Change
abstract: Hoping to bolster sales, Campbell Soup is updating its classic chicken noodle soup, as well as the way it does business.
lead_paragraph: CAMDEN, N.J. — Food companies tinker with the signature products in their portfolios at their own risk — and few products are as classic as Campbell’s chicken noodle soup.

headline: Placing a Cap on Americans’ Consumption of Added Sugar
abstract: The goal of new F.D.A. guidelines is to limit added sugar to no more than 10 percent of daily calories. For an adult, that means no more than 12.5 teaspoons a day.
lead_paragraph: Health experts have been nudging Americans to kick the sugar habit for years, and now it’s official: The Food and Drug Administration is recommending a daily cap on sugar for the first time.

headline: Can a Trip Ever Be ‘Authentic’?
abstract: In a globalized age — when a McAloo Tikki is just as Indian as the Taj Mahal — has the very word lost its meaning?
lead_paragraph: In a globalized age — when a McAloo Tikki is just as Indian as the Taj Mahal — has the very word lost its meaning?

headline: VW Looks at Cost Cuts and Offers Money to Diesel Car Owners
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Diesel Power', 'Air Pollution', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Automobiles', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)']
abstract: The company will meet with worker representatives about how to cut costs following the emissions scandal. VW is also offering up to $1,000 to owners.
lead_paragraph: Volkswagen said on Monday that it would begin talks with worker representatives about how to cut costs, in the latest sign that the company’s crisis over cheating on emissions tests is taking a heavy toll.

headline: Ben Carson Moves Into a Tie With Donald Trump in South Carolina Poll
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Monmouth University’s poll of South Carolina voters in August showed Donald J. Trump leading Ben Carson, 30 percent to 15 percent. Its most recent survey has Mr. Carson ahead of Mr. Trump, 28 percent to 27 percent.
lead_paragraph: Ben Carson’s surge in the polls has made its way to South Carolina, where a new poll from Monmouth University shows him deadlocked with Donald J. Trump as the leading Republican presidential candidate in the state.

headline: University of Missouri President Resigns
abstract: Timothy M. Wolfe announced on Monday his resignation as the president of the University of Missouri, after months of student and faculty protests over racial tensions.
lead_paragraph: Timothy M. Wolfe announced on Monday his resignation as the president of the University of Missouri, after months of student and faculty protests over racial tensions.

headline: 3 Things to Know About the Sprint Blood Pressure Trial
abstract: New data from a major study called Sprint has shaken some of the basic assumptions about the treatment of high blood pressure.
lead_paragraph: New data from a major study called Sprint, released Monday, has shaken some of the basic assumptions about the treatment of high blood pressure. The trial found that lowering systolic blood pressure from currently recommended levels of 140 to 150 to below 120 could prevent heart attacks and strokes and potentially save many lives.

headline: New Treatment Slows an Epidemic of Sleeping Sickness
abstract: Cases of the disease declined among Ugandans after researchers began treating cattle.
lead_paragraph: Cases of human sleeping sickness have fallen greatly in parts of rural Uganda where cattle were given an experimental dual treatment that killed both the parasites that cause the disease and the flies that carry them, researchers in Scotland said Monday.

headline: Kath Mainland Stepping Down as Head of Edinburgh Fringe
abstract: Moving on to lead the Melbourne Festival.
lead_paragraph: With her short hair, multiple ear piercings and penchant for wearing a leather jacket, Kath Mainland gives off an aura of hipness that has long seemed appropriate for her role in helping to oversee the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, the enormous arts festival that pops up annually in the Scottish capital and includes a lot of scrappy productions. But after seven years as chief executive of the Edinburgh Festival Fringe Society, the organizational force behind the event, Ms. Mainland is leaving. Beginning in February she will take over as executive director of the Melbourne Festival.

headline: Data on Benefits of Lower Blood Pressure Brings Clarity for Doctors and Patients
abstract: Patients who lowered their systolic blood pressure to under 120 were 25 percent less likely to have heart attacks, heart failure or strokes, or to die from heart disease.
lead_paragraph: When the federal government announced in September that it had abruptly halted a large blood pressure study because its results were so compelling, doctors were left in frustrating limbo.

headline: Truth and Lies: The Orwellian World of Politics
abstract: Readers ask about trust and the absence of “solid policy proposals.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Killer Whales to Take Final Bows at SeaWorld San Diego
keywords: ['AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Whales and Whaling', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: The orca performances will be replaced with an “informative” experience with a “conservation message inspiring people to act.” Other parks are not affected.
lead_paragraph: SeaWorld said on Monday that it planned to phase out next year its San Diego killer whale performance, a central point for criticism of how its animals are treated.

headline: Astronauts Needed: NASA Wants to Make Mars Your Corner Office
keywords: ['Space and Astronomy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: NASA will be posting job openings for astronauts in December as it prepares to resume manned space flight.
lead_paragraph: Many childhood dreams come to nothing, but here is a chance to make one come true: For the first time in four years, NASA is looking for more astronauts.

headline: Obama Starts Personal Facebook Page
abstract: A White House team is working with the president on his social media presence.
lead_paragraph: The leader of the free world now has a personal Facebook page, and more than 45,000 people clicked “like” on it in the first hour it was live on Monday.

headline: Catalan Legislators Raise Stakes in Push for Secession From Spain
abstract: In the latest step to break with Spain, legislators approved a resolution for creating separate Catalan institutions, including a tax agency and social security system.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA — Catalan separatist lawmakers intensified their standoff with Spain’s central government in Madrid on Monday, approving a resolution that lays out a path for the region to “disconnect” from the rest of Spain by creating its own institutions, including a separate Catalan tax agency and social security system.

headline: Cuban Peers Dispute Ted Cruz’s Father’s Story of Fighting for Castro
abstract: The family narrative that has provided such inspirational fire and biographical heft to Mr. Cruz’s campaign is, his father’s former comrades and friends say, an embroidered one.
lead_paragraph: MATANZAS, Cuba — Since he was a boy, Senator Ted Cruz has said, all he wanted to do was “fight for liberty” — a yearning that he says was first kindled when he heard his father’s tales of fighting as a rebel leader in Cuba in the 1950s, throwing firebombs, running guns and surviving torture.

headline: Wood You Can Wear
abstract: Hand-carved jewelry — with gold, diamonds and gemstones — makes a statement while maintaining a natural delicacy.
lead_paragraph: Hand-carved jewelry — with gold, diamonds and gemstones — makes a statement while maintaining a natural delicacy.

headline: Afghan Fighters Loyal to ISIS Beheaded 7 Hostages, Officials Say
abstract: The bodies of seven ethnic Hazara civilians were found Saturday after the Taliban had pushed back the militants and a group of allied dissidents, officials said.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghan militants claiming loyalty to the Islamic State were found to have beheaded seven ethnic Hazara civilians who had been abducted in the southern Afghan province of Zabul, officials said on Monday, as infighting among Taliban splinter factions intensified.

headline: Delayed Opening for Mamet’s ‘China Doll’
abstract: The play began previews on Oct. 21; it had been scheduled to open Nov. 19, but instead will now open Dec. 4, and “new material is going in this week,” the lead producer said.
lead_paragraph: The producers of “China Doll,” a new play written by David Mamet and starring Al Pacino, said on Monday that the play requires more work than they had expected and so they are delaying the official opening by two weeks.

headline: Judge Deals a Blow to N.S.A. Data Collection Program
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'USA Freedom Act', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Constitutional Amendments']
abstract: A federal judge ordered the National Security Agency to stop collecting records for one Verizon customer, just weeks before the program was scheduled to be shut down and replaced.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Monday partly blocked the National Security Agency’s program that systematically collects Americans’ domestic phone records in bulk just weeks before the agency was scheduled to shut it down and replace it. The judge said the program was most likely unconstitutional.

headline: Starbucks’s Red Holiday Cups Inspire Outcry Online
abstract: The protests were so loud that Starbucks sought to clarify its decision to remove Christmas-holiday symbols on its cups.
lead_paragraph: For some reason, Starbucks keeps trying to coax its customers to share a bit more over their coffee cups.

headline: Target Keeps Thanksgiving Opening at 6 p.m. on the Holiday
keywords: ['Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Thanksgiving Day']
abstract: The retailer will open at 6 p.m. on Thanksgiving Day for the second year, the first time in years that it did not move up its opening times.
lead_paragraph: Target doesn’t want Americans to miss Thanksgiving dinner — but with its stores opening at 6 p.m. that day for a second year running, shoppers may still have to choose between sales and dessert.

headline: Chris Stapleton Rides C.M.A.’s to a Big Week on the Album Chart
abstract: Chris Stapleton’s debut album, “Traveller,” was No. 1 on the Billboard album chart
lead_paragraph: Never say that television time doesn’t sell records.

headline: Canadian Pacific Said to Weigh Deal for Norfolk Southern
abstract: The preliminary discussions may lead to a new round of consolidation within the railroad industry.
lead_paragraph: If at first Canadian Pacific could not succeed in buying a fellow railroad operator, it looks prepared to try again with another target.

headline: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: Stuffing Muffins
abstract: Turn your stuffing into muffins for a festive flare to the popular side dish.
lead_paragraph: Stuffing is a traditional Thanksgiving accompaniment to the turkey, but turning stuffing into muffins helps it hold its own on the holiday table — with or without the bird.

headline: Review: Donny Deutsch’s ‘Donny!,’ a Crass, Infuriating Talk Show Host
abstract: It’s hard to know where the real Donny leaves off and the fictional one begins in this USA comedy.
lead_paragraph: Don’t watch “Donny!” because it might make you laugh. Then you’ll hate yourself for liking a sitcom that stars an advertising executive, and a moderately annoying one at that.

headline: Bond Giant Pimco Calls Gross’s Lawsuit ‘Legally Groundless’
abstract: Pimco said the suit “is only the latest step in Mr. Gross’s effort to resurrect a personal reputation damaged by his own unacceptable behavior.”
lead_paragraph: Pimco, the bond investment giant, responded on Monday to a $200 million lawsuit filed by its former star portfolio manager, William H. Gross, by asking that his claim be dismissed as “legally groundless.”

headline: Russian Artist Sets Security Service’s Door on Fire
abstract: In his latest act of protest, Pyotr Pavlensky set fire to the entrance of Russia’s Federal Security Service and was charged with vandalism.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The artist’s brush was a cigarette lighter, his paint a can of gasoline and the canvas, as it has always been for Pyotr Pavlensky, a symbol of the Russian state.

headline: 1890: The Electric Chair, ‘Far Worse Than Hanging’
abstract: Mark Bulik looks at the first mention of “electric chair” in the New York Times.
lead_paragraph: It was supposed to be a humane alternative to the noose. On March 22, 1890, The Times reported on a New York Court of Appeals ruling that a new invention, the electric chair, did not constitute cruel punishment. It would be used to execute a convicted wife killer, William Kemmler.

headline: Ackman Defends Fund’s Valeant Losses and Digs at ‘Snide Comments’
abstract: The billionaire, whose firm is among the worst-performing hedge funds this year, used an investor conference call to take a swipe at the media.
lead_paragraph: The billionaire investor William A. Ackman, whose firm is among the worst-performing hedge funds this year, used an investor conference call on Monday to take a swipe at the media and those on Wall Street who he said relished “betting against” him.

headline: Artificial Patients, Real Learning
keywords: ['Mannequins (Dummies)', '3-D Printers', 'Medicine and Health', 'Doctors', '3-D Devices and Effects', 'Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Hospitals']
abstract: Rubber and plastic dummies that have skin and internal organs with a realistic feel are providing blood-and-guts training for operations.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The patient’s blood pressure had reportedly crashed in the ambulance; a gunshot wound had damaged the heart. In the operating room, a medical resident, Dr. Dan Hashimoto, slid a knife into the patient’s chest and sliced horizontally, from the sternum across the torso.

headline: Hollywood in the Operating Room
abstract: Surgeons at Massachusetts General Hospital have four minutes to save this gunshot wound victim. So how do residents learn such a risky procedure? With a little help from Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: Surgeons at Massachusetts General Hospital have four minutes to save this gunshot wound victim. So how do residents learn such a risky procedure? With a little help from Hollywood.

headline: Mariners Saw the Hall of Fame Version of Ken Griffey Jr.
abstract: Griffey’s great numbers mostly came in his first 11 major league seasons, which were played in Seattle. After that, he was little more than a journeyman.
lead_paragraph: Consider these two major league ballplayers.

headline: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch
abstract: The United States men’s national team opens qualifying for the 2018 World Cup on Friday night with a game against St. Vincent and the Grenadines in St. Louis.
lead_paragraph: Put away your favorite club’s jersey and get your flags out: it’s international break time again.

headline: Deal Talks Start Early, but Mets’ Sandy Alderson Will Miss Meetings
abstract: Alderson will not be among the executives at the livelier-than-usual general manager meetings because he is having an undisclosed medical procedure. The Mets will have three representatives, though.
lead_paragraph: BOCA RATON, Fla. — The general manager meetings are usually a somewhat sleepy cousin to baseball’s winter meetings, but that could change this year.

headline: With a Presidential Boost, ‘Hamilton’ Tops Broadway Box Office
abstract: The musical played nine performances, one of them a fund-raiser for the Democratic Party.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has been quite clear about how much he likes the new musical “Hamilton.” And last week, he managed to boost its grosses past those of Broadway’s longtime leader, “The Lion King.”

headline: The Killer App: Storytelling
abstract: As MediaStorm celebrates 10 years, its founder looks ahead to the challenges and opportunities facing photographers in the online world.
lead_paragraph: As MediaStorm celebrates 10 years, its founder looks ahead to the challenges and opportunities facing photographers in the online world.

abstract: After the resignation of President Timothy M. Wolfe, students and faculty agreed that a new approach is needed to combat the rising number of racist incidents at the University of Missouri.
lead_paragraph: After the resignation of President Timothy M. Wolfe, students and faculty agreed that a new approach is needed to combat the rising number of racist incidents at the University of Missouri.

headline: Review: In ‘Hotels of North America,’ Rick Moody Examines the Middle-Aged Male in Free Fall
abstract: In Mr. Moody’s latest novel, a hotel critic covers a lot more ground than just accommodations.
lead_paragraph: One drawback of American journalism is that newspapers and magazines don’t have hotel critics. Into this cultural void steps Reginald Edward Morse, the hero of Rick Moody’s new novel, “Hotels of North America.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Myanmar and Elsewhere
abstract: Myanmar and Elsewhere — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Myanmar and Elsewhere — Pictures of the Day

headline: Prosecution Witness in Lufthansa Trial Is Scrutinized in Closing Arguments
abstract: Gaspare Valenti had testified that he committed crimes with Vincent Asaro, including the 1978 Lufthansa heist, as Mr. Asaro rose through the Mafia ranks.
lead_paragraph: It was not so much Vincent Asaro but his cousin Gaspare Valenti, the key prosecution witness against him, who was under scrutiny as closing arguments in Mr. Asaro’s trial on racketeering charges concluded on Monday.

headline: Breakthrough Prize Looks to Stars to Shine on Science
abstract: The idea behind the Breakthrough Prize is that if scientists are viewed as celebrities, then more young students will aspire to be scientists.
lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Movie stars. Red carpet. Awards.

headline: Nov. 9, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Myanmar, Brazil, the United States and Germany.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Myanmar, Brazil, the United States and Germany.

headline: Facts & Figures: Where People Worry About Climate Change
abstract: People in countries with high levels of carbon emissions are actually less concerned about climate change than people in low-emission countries.
lead_paragraph: Americans are less likely than people in Latin America and Sub-Saharan Africa to believe climate change is a very serious problem, according to a recent Pew report. Forty-five percent of people in the United States see climate change as very serious, compared with 86 percent in Brazil and 79 percent in Burkina Faso.

headline: A Vagabond Teahouse Pours Camaraderie, One Free Cup at a Time
keywords: ['Food Trucks and Vendors', 'Tea', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Giuseppe Spadafora shows up in a city or town with his bus and begins offering tea to passers-by, hoping to engage in conversation and form relationships.
lead_paragraph: Giuseppe Spadafora opened a side door of his white Ford bus, spread a light blue carpet on a sidewalk near McCarren Park in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, and placed a small wooden sandwich board next to it reading “Free Tea.”

headline: Chloë Sevigny’s Wild Gucci Dress
abstract: The actress’s look at the LACMA gala was covered in animals, flowers and fruit.
lead_paragraph: The Star: Chloë Sevigny

headline: Review: In ‘Ballet (New York),’ Nondancers Try Their Jetés
abstract: Commissioned by Performa 15 and choreographed by Jérôme Bel, the show was cast with 13 New Yorkers of various ages and backgrounds.

headline: Donald Trump’s Not-So-Fond Farewell on ‘Saturday Night Live’
abstract: The Republican candidate looked as if he needed a friend during a part of the show that is usually warm and fuzzy.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s appearance on “Saturday Night Live” last weekend was memorable for a few things, none having much to do with his comedic skills.

headline: Review: ‘Dead and Breathing,’ About the Right to Die
abstract: An long-ailing woman who would like to die has a proposal for her nurse in Chisa Hutchinson’s play, at the National Black Theater.
lead_paragraph: Carolyn Whitlock, the long-ailing woman at the center of Chisa Hutchinson’s play “Dead and Breathing,” at the National Black Theater, has wealth in abundance. What’s lacking is the ease she expects it to bring her.

headline: Egypt Extends Detention of a Journalist, Hossam Bahgat
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: The journalist was interrogated Sunday about his article on an alleged coup plot by military officers and then was moved to a secret detention center.
lead_paragraph: SHARM EL SHEIKH, Egypt — Egyptian military prosecutors on Monday extended the detention of Hossam Bahgat, an investigative journalist and the founder of Egypt’s leading human rights organization, in a sign that the government is moving to bring him to trial on charges of publishing false news harmful to national security.

headline: Verbatim: Would Jeb Bush Kill Baby Hitler? ‘Hell Yeah.’
abstract: Jeb Bush says he would, indeed, kill baby Hitler.
lead_paragraph: — Jeb Bush, in an interview with The Huffington Post, on whether he would kill a baby Hitler if he could go back in time. The question was inspired by a New York Times Magazine survey.

headline: ISIS Ally in Egypt Emerges as Key Suspect in Russian Jet Crash
abstract: Officials say they believe it increasingly likely that a group known as the Sinai Province of the Islamic State planted a bomb on the Russian airliner that crashed in Egypt, killing 224 people.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Within months of the military takeover here two years ago, a little-known group calling itself Ansar Beit al-Maqdis managed to penetrate rings of checkpoints and heavy security to carry out a string of startling attacks, assassinating a senior police official at his home near here and blowing up a security headquarters here and in Mansoura, Egypt.

headline: Hannah Rothschild Adds Novelist to Her Résumé
abstract: Ms. Rothschild, a member of the venerable banking family and chairwoman of the National Gallery, discusses the beginnings of her first novel.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — There wasn’t a minion in sight at the Rothschild offices here, and Hannah Rothschild — author, filmmaker, chairwoman of the National Gallery — was looking dubiously at the coffee-making apparatus on a table in a small boardroom. “I think this machine works,” she said.

headline: Lindsey Graham to Make His Voice Heard During Debate, on Social Media
abstract: Senator Lindsey Graham has been left out of Tuesday’s Republican debates, but he will weigh in on Sidewire, a social media platform, to offer his own responses to questions.
lead_paragraph: With poll numbers that barely register, Senator Lindsey Graham will not be participating in either of Tuesday night’s Republican presidential debates, leaving the stages without the witty wisecracks that have become one of his claims to fame.

headline: An Artful Homage to Roller Disco
abstract: Mark Bradford’s “Deimos” was created using wheels from the roller skates Hauser & Wirth inherited from the Roxy, a previous tenant of its building.
lead_paragraph: When Hauser & Wirth moved into its Dieter Roth-designed West 18th Street space two years ago, the gallery inherited an unexpected treasure trove: hundreds of roller skates left over from the former tenant, the famous Roxy roller disco. With the opening of Mark Bradford’s new exhibition, “Be Strong Boquan,” this past weekend, the history of the building comes back to life. Immediately upon entering the show, visitors encounter “Deimos,” a video installation depicting dozens of the little orange wheels from the Roxy’s skates, spinning from one end of the frame to the other. T premieres the video exclusively here (in the gallery, it’s displayed across three screens on one very long wall).

headline: Hillary Clinton on Familiar Ground in Registering for the New Hampshire Primary
abstract: For the fourth time in her career — twice as a political spouse and now twice as a presidential candidate — Hillary Rodham Clinton placed the Clinton surname on the ballot for New Hampshire’s primary.
lead_paragraph: CONCORD, N.H. — For the fourth time in her career — as a political spouse and as a presidential candidate — Hillary Rodham Clinton made her way into the crowded and crusty office of New Hampshire’s secretary of state as the Clinton surname was placed on the ballot for the state’s primary, the first in the nation.

headline: Gov. Christie Doesn’t Want Your Vote
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Elections, Governors', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: New Jersey wants to make voting easier, so why did the governor veto a bill that would do exactly that?
lead_paragraph: New Jersey’s voter-turnout rate is among the lowest in the country. During the 2014 midterm elections, 30.4 percent of the state’s eligible voters went to the polls. Last week, only 21 percent of voters came out — the worst showing for a general election in state history.

headline: A New L.A. Wellness Destination Deals in Affordable Luxury
abstract: In a city known for exclusive and expensive holistic therapies, reasonably priced massage appeals to the masses.
lead_paragraph: In a city where ayahuasca ceremonies and crystal healings are as openly discussed as traffic and the weather, healing and wellness in Los Angeles can feel velvet rope-exclusive. Not everyone can afford to go six days off-the-grid or devote an entire weekend to juicing — and even those who do have the time and the means may find themselves at the very bottom of of a Kabbalistic intuitive counselor’s waitlist.

headline: Martin O’Malley Receives Support From Obama’s Finance Circle
abstract: Five people who served on President Obama’s national finance committee in his 2008 campaign are circulating a letter seeking to rally support for Martin O’Malley, who has been struggling to gain traction in the Democratic presidential race.
lead_paragraph: Five people who served on President Obama’s national finance committee during his first presidential campaign are circulating a letter seeking to rally support for Martin O’Malley, the former governor of Maryland who has been struggling to gain traction in the Democratic presidential race.

headline: Mike Bartlett Turns to Shakespeare to Voice His ‘King Charles III’
abstract: Mr. Bartlett discusses the use of language to transform his protagonists from cardboard figures of ridicule into full-blown characters of tragedy and pathos.
lead_paragraph: How do you write a play about the British royal family without making its members seem risible, banal or irrelevant? Except for Queen Elizabeth, who orbits in her own special universe, today’s royals often appear to be trapped in a dreary reality show whose ostensible dramas (Who did Kate wear? What did Charles say?) are anything but dramatic.

headline: Laminate Maker Ark Is Accused of Selling Tainted Flooring
keywords: ['Wood and Wood Products', 'Floors and Flooring', 'Formaldehyde', 'Consumer Protection', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: A hedge fund manager who accused Lumber Liquidators of selling wood with high levels of formaldehyde is making the same claims against Ark Floors, an importer of Chinese wood products.
lead_paragraph: As Lumber Liquidators continues to struggle after a safety crisis over its Chinese-made laminate flooring, a much smaller flooring company has been drawn into the spotlight.

headline: Students Celebrate University of Missouri President’s Resignation
abstract: Students and faculty members at the University of Missouri in Columbia erupted in cheers at word of Timothy M. Wolfe’s resignation as president of the university system on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Students and faculty members at the University of Missouri in Columbia erupted in cheers at word of Timothy M. Wolfe’s resignation as president of the university system on Monday.

headline: The Stonehenge Landscape
abstract: To many visitors, Stonehenge is not much more than some big stones and not as impressive as they imagined. But the story is not just Stonehenge.
lead_paragraph: To many visitors, Stonehenge is not much more than some big stones and not as impressive as they imagined. But the story is not just Stonehenge.

headline: Stonehenge Begins to Yield Its Secrets
abstract: Discoveries over the last decade have revealed more about the everyday lives of the people for whom the giant monuments held meaning.
lead_paragraph: AMESBURY, England — About 6,300 years ago, a tree here toppled over.

headline: Panel: What Today’s News Tells Us About the 2016 Election
abstract: David Leonhardt, the editor of The Upshot, looks at which of the current political stories matter for next year’s election.
lead_paragraph: We are a year out from the 2016 United States presidential vote, but it is clear that election madness is already in full swing. With such a long lead time, it’s hard to tell: Who will be in? Who will be out? And above all, which of the current political stories matter for next year’s election — and which don’t?

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: In ‘Mediterranea,’ Two Migrants Speak for Many
abstract: The release of Jonas Carpignano’s film about two young men who made the harrowing journey from North Africa to Europe is well timed.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As Europe faces its largest migrant crisis since World War II — more than 780,000 people from the Middle East and Africa have arrived this year, according to the United Nations’ refugee agency — it can be easy to forget that there is a story behind each decision to attempt the difficult journey.

headline: A Teenage Son’s Kind Acts, Revealed as He Is Laid to Rest
abstract: When their son Miles Kirkland Thomas suddenly died, Jamar Thomas and Tanza Kirkland were not just unprepared for the emotional toll. There was also the cost of his funeral.
lead_paragraph: They knew that their son, Miles Kirkland Thomas, had used his time and talents to be supportive to others. They knew he made the varsity football team as a freshman. He volunteered with an organization called Health for Youths at a local police precinct house. He always saw the good in people.

headline: A Design Gallery That Wants a Strong Reaction
abstract: The first American outpost of Carpenters Workshop Gallery opens tomorrow in the Fifth Avenue space formerly occupied by Takashimaya.
lead_paragraph: There are tough acts to follow — and then there’s Takashimaya, the Japanese department store that reigned over Fifth Avenue until it closed in 2010. The store itself hasn’t returned, but its instantly recognizable postmodern building has undergone a face-lift at the hands of David Chipperfield and even found a new tenant grand enough to fill its duplex penthouse: Carpenters Workshop Gallery, opening tomorrow.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing: University of Missouri, Myanmar, Doping
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Digital Dig Unpacks Atlanta Dive Bar Rich in History
abstract: Academics are digitally documenting the ephemera on the walls of Manuel’s Tavern, a beloved haunt with an outsize role in the region’s political history.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The artist and documentary filmmaker Ruth Dusseault calls the stuff that has found its way onto the walls of Manuel’s Tavern, a beloved Eisenhower-era dive bar here, an “organic archive” and a “60-year installation piece.”

headline: Goodbyes to the Lord of the Dance and Mademoiselle Non
abstract: Michael Flatley and Sylvie Guillem begin their farewell appearances in New York this week.

headline: U.S. Soccer, Resolving Lawsuit, Will Limit Headers for Youth Players
abstract: The new guidelines resolve a proposed class-action lawsuit over head injuries and will prohibit some players 10 and under from heading the ball.
lead_paragraph: The United States Soccer Federation unveiled a series of safety initiatives Monday aimed at addressing head injuries in the sport, including a policy that sets strict limits on youth players heading the ball. The new guidelines, which resolve a proposed class-action lawsuit filed against U.S. Soccer and others last year, will prohibit players age 10 and younger from heading the ball and will reduce headers in practice for those from age 11 to 13.

headline: Skelos Case Hearing Offers Hint of Possible Defense Strategy
abstract: During arguments, a lawyer for State Senator Dean G. Skelos said that witnesses would testify about “certain aspects” of his son Adam Skelos’s life.
lead_paragraph: When the corruption trial of State Senator Dean G. Skelos and his son Adam begins next week, there will probably be snippets of salacious talk from both men, on a father’s influence and on undermining the governor in budget negotiations.

headline: Scuffle Between Nevada Casino Company and Union Pulls In Deutsche Bank
abstract: The Culinary Workers Union said Station Casinos failed to disclosed settlements made by a part owner, Deutsche Bank, this year to settle investigations into its capital market activities.
lead_paragraph: The long-running fight between culinary workers and a casino owner in Las Vegas is about to go another round. And the workers are hoping the regulatory troubles faced by a German bank might give them the advantage they have been looking for.

headline: Panel to Examine Tolls for New Tappan Zee Bridge
abstract: The executive director of the New York State Thruway Authority said that rates would not increase in 2016, but that the new group would issue toll recommendations for the replacement.
lead_paragraph: The New York State Thruway Authority announced on Monday that a new task force would examine whether to raise tolls for the crossing that is being built to replace the Tappan Zee Bridge.

headline: With $170.4 Million Sale at Auction, Modigliani Work Joins Rarefied Nine-Figure Club
abstract: The price tag for the single work was a far cry from the roughly $4,700 in today’s dollars that Modigliani sought for the entire contents of his Paris studio in 1918-19.
lead_paragraph: In an overheated art market where anything seems possible, a painting of an outstretched nude woman by the early-20th-century artist Amedeo Modigliani sold on Monday night for $170.4 million with fees to Liu Yiqian, a former taxi driver turned billionaire art collector, in a packed sales room at Christie’s. It was the second-highest price paid for an artwork at auction.

headline: Hoping for His Backing, Jeb Bush Meets With a Cautious Scott Walker
abstract: Mr. Bush, who would rather avoid Mr. Walker’s presidential trajectory but would love to have his support, held an event with the Wisconsin governor on Monday.

abstract: Thirty-six hours after Tigers football players became involved in a dispute with the university system president, Timothy M. Wolfe, over the tepid response to racial incidents, Wolfe was history.
lead_paragraph: Well, that was fast.

abstract: When world powers gather in Vienna this weekend to discuss a possible postwar political deal for Syria, one of the main points of contention will be to determine which opposition groups are legitimate and which are terrorists.
lead_paragraph: When world powers gather in Vienna this weekend to discuss a possible postwar political deal for Syria, one of the main points of contention will be to determine whom to include among opposition groups in future negotiations — and the West may back groups that are less than “moderate,” Britain’s top diplomat said on Monday.

headline: Manhattan Man Charged in Wife’s Killing Is Barred From Talking to Anyone but Lawyer

lead_paragraph: A judge denied bail on Monday to a Manhattan man accused of strangling his estranged wife six years ago and covering up the crime, then took the unusual step of barring the defendant from speaking to anyone except his lawyer — a move intended to prevent him from sending messages to witnesses.

headline: A Rebuke to India’s Prime Minister Narendra Modi
abstract: His party’s loss in Bihar is a clear message to stop divisive politics and start delivering on promises of economic development.
lead_paragraph: During a national election in India last year, Narendra Modi promised “development for all.” As prime minister, he has yet to deliver big economic improvements, but in the meantime, members of his government and political party have shredded his promise of inclusion by inflaming sectarian tensions. Now, voters in the country’s third most populous state have sent Mr. Modi a message: Put an end to the hatemongering.

headline: Brookie Maxwell, an Artist and Curator, Dies at 59
abstract: Ms. Maxwell, a painter, sculptor and curator, immersed herself in social causes and viewed art as a spiritual haven for homeless children.
lead_paragraph: Brookie Maxwell, a painter, sculptor and curator who immersed herself in social causes and viewed art as a spiritual haven for homeless children, died on Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 59.

headline: Appeals Court Deals Blow to Obama’s Immigration Plans

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court said Monday that President Obama could not move forward with his plans to overhaul immigration rules by providing up to five million people with work permits and protection from deportation.

headline: Bill Ackman’s Enigmatic Approach to Valeant Pharmaceuticals
abstract: Bill Ackman has led something of a crusade on moral grounds against Herbalife, a nutritional supplements company, but he seems unperturbed by Valeant’s rapacious re-pricing of old drugs.
lead_paragraph: William A. Ackman, the activist investor, has described his billion-dollar bet and continuing crusade against the nutritional supplements company Herbalife as a “moral obligation.” In at least one presentation, he nearly cried onstage and said that if his Herbalife trade was successful, he would give the profits to charity because he would consider them “blood money.”

headline: Letter from Capitol Hill: Allow Government Officials to Read Full Torture Report
abstract: The executive summary of the report on C.I.A. torture was publicly released in December 2014, but the complete 6,700-page report was confined to executive branch safes. Senators Dianne Feinstein and Patrick J. Leahy wrote this letter imploring the heads of the Justice Department and the F.B.I. to allow more government officials to read the report.
lead_paragraph: The executive summary of the report on C.I.A. torture was publicly released in December 2014, but the complete 6,700-page report was confined to executive branch safes. headline: Classified Report on the C.I.A.’s Secret Prisons Is Caught in Limbo
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Terrorism', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Torture', 'Interrogations']
abstract: Nearly a year after the Senate released a declassified summary of a report on the C.I.A.’s secret prison program, the full document is the subject of battles in the courts and in Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Senate security officer stepped out of the December chill last year and delivered envelopes marked “Top Secret” to the Pentagon, the C.I.A., the State Department and the Justice Department. Inside each packet was a disc containing a 6,700-page classified report on the C.I.A.’s secret prison program and a letter from Senator Dianne Feinstein, urging officials to read the report to ensure that the lessons were not lost to time.

headline: Years Later, Bittersweet Victory for Alysia Montaño

Knowing the World Anti-Doping Agency was releasing the findings of its extraordinary inquiry into doping and corruption in Russian track and field, she devoured the details of the report in bed as soon as she awoke.

headline: Preparing for Jets, Bills’ Rex Ryan Finds Way to Needle Them

lead_paragraph: Wojciech Fangor, one of the most distinctive painters to emerge from postwar Poland, died on Oct. 25 in Warsaw. He was 92.

headline: Russia: Official Says Delayed Deal to Sell Iran Missiles Remains in Force
keywords: ['Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'International Relations', 'Arms Trade']
abstract: An announcement by Sergei V. Chemezov, Russia’s chief arms trade executive, provided no delivery date or any other details.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s most senior arms executive said Monday that a contract to supply Iran with powerful S-300 air defense missiles was now active. But with no delivery date or any other details, the announcement seemed aimed more at warding off an Iranian lawsuit than a major step toward delivery of the weapon system. Sergei V. Chemezov, Russia’s chief arms trade executive, made the announcement at an air show in Dubai, Russian news agencies reported. “The contract to deliver the S-300 was not only signed by both sides, but has already come into force,” Mr. Chemezov was quoted as saying by the RIA Novosti news agency. The initial contract to deliver the weapons was signed in 2007, before the current international arms embargo against Iran was established. But the deal was canceled in 2010 by Dmitri A. Medvedev, then Russia’s president, under pressure from the United States and Israel. In response, Iran filed a lawsuit claiming breach of contract that could cost Moscow as much as five times the $800 million value of the original deal. President Vladimir V. Putin reversed Mr. Medvedev’s decision in April, as a nuclear deal between Iran and the world powers began to appear likely. But the system still has not been delivered. The hitch, military experts say, is that Russia wants to keep the unfulfilled contract as a bargaining chip in its relations with the West, perhaps with an eye to ending economic sanctions imposed over its actions in Ukraine.

headline: Lamar Alexander Seeks Path to Change in Senate

headline: Review: In ‘Lost Girls,’ Derailed Blue-Collar Lives, With Zingers
abstract: The playwright John Pollono is a deft practitioner of the sort of twist-in-the-tale narratives that are mostly associated with O. Henry and W. Somerset Maugham.
lead_paragraph: So you’re driving along through what you think is a drearily familiar landscape, when suddenly there’s a bend in the road. All at once, in a single click of perception, everything looks slightly but revealingly different, and not just where you are now, but also where you’ve been. The view in the rearview mirror has changed.

headline: Off the Field, Charting the X’s and O’s of a Protest Movement
keywords: ['Football (College)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'College Athletics', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Strikes', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']

headline: ‘Fargo’ Season 2, Episode 5: The Butcher of Luverne
abstract: The Gerhardt children are unprepared for the horrors they encounter, and the Blumquists can’t get on the same page.
lead_paragraph: Children make mistakes. And as they get older, they still make mistakes — maybe not as many, but bigger and more dangerous ones. They rebel. They test their boundaries. They slip around (or smash through) the guardrails their parents have set up for their protection. For Charlie and Simone Gerhardt, the children of criminals, growing up comes with a deep moral confusion and a nefarious sense of duty. Will they be ready to run the family business? (Is that something they even want?) And what sort of twisted values are their elders instilling in them to prepare them for it?

headline: ‘Blindspot’ Season 1, Episode 8: Hot-Button Issues
abstract: This week’s episode name-checked police shootings and gay football players.
lead_paragraph: Characters on NBC’s “Blindspot” often remark on how prescient the tattoo artist or artists who inked up Jane were. “How did he/she/they know we would be in this specific place at this exact time and find this obscure clue?” Another sort of prescience took over Monday night’s episode: The tattoos are also freakishly good at steering the plot toward hot-button real-life issues.

headline: Your Kids Will Live Longer Than You Thought
abstract: How most of us think about mortality rates is wrong. That’s good news if you are an infant, not so much if you run the Social Security Trust Fund.
lead_paragraph: According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, life expectancy at birth in the United States was 78.8 years in 2013 — 76.4 years for men, 81.2 years for women. But I have good news. Those statistics don’t mean what you probably think they mean.

headline: Smart African Politics: Candidates Debating Under a Tree
abstract: Studies in Sierra Leone confirm that debates by candidates for parliament not only introduce the candidates to voters; they make voting more issue-oriented.
lead_paragraph: Political debates are good even when they’re bad. Even when candidates are cringe-worthy, they’re cringe-worthy in public view. And voters learn about all the candidates, not just new ones. In the United States, for example, Hillary Clinton has been center stage in political life for 24 years. Donald Trump is the very definition of “overexposed.” Still, the debates tell us new things about them — their positions, temperament, grace under pressure (or lack thereof), charisma and political skill.

headline: Defeating My Anxiety
keywords: ['Anxiety and Stress', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Religion and Belief', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation']
abstract: It took two months, three therapies and a tiny amount of clonazepam.
lead_paragraph: When the stock market crashed in 2008, my wife and I were 70. And we saw half of our retirement funds disappear. Before the crash, we felt secure in the belief that we had enough money to last as long as we lived; after the crash, we feared that we would not, and I worried about it a great deal. I had a hard time going to sleep and an even harder time going back to sleep after getting up to go to the bathroom in the middle of the night. I came to hate going into that bathroom because I knew my demons resided there and would invade my consciousness immediately.

lead_paragraph: As New York City officials encourage older tenants to take advantage of an underused program that freezes their rents, they have also been cutting off participants who fail to renew on time, advocates say.

headline: Afghans Arriving in Germany Find the Welcome Is Wearing Thin
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Smuggling', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Germany’s tougher stance toward migrants from Afghanistan is emerging as a big test of Europe’s willingness to absorb people from the world’s most troubled regions.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A growing sense that Afghanistan is slipping into greater chaos and will not stabilize anytime soon is driving rising numbers of Afghans to flee for Europe, hopeful that they will enjoy the same welcome given to Syrians and Iraqis seeking safety from war and terror.

headline: What to Look For in Republican Debate
abstract: Fox Business Network pledged to host a policy-driven debate, but that may be easier said than done. Here’s what to watch for in Milwaukee.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday night’s Republican presidential debate in Milwaukee will bring the eight leading contenders together at a time when two are confronting questions about their pasts, one faces mounting doubts about his seriousness, and another who began the race as a favorite is under intense pressure to show he can be as forceful as he was cracked up to be. Yet their ability to address those problems could actually depend on whether Fox Business Network, the host of the debate, fails to deliver on its promises for a policy-driven evening focused on sober economic issues.

headline: The Killer App: Storytelling
abstract: As MediaStorm celebrates 10 years, its founder looks ahead to the challenges and opportunities facing photographers in the online world.
lead_paragraph: Brian Storm was raised in the Detroit area and attended the College of the Ozarks on a baseball scholarship. While obtaining a graduate degree at the University of Missouri’s School of Journalism in 1993, he discovered computers and began making interactive CD-ROM disks. He started a company, MediaStorm, but put it on hold while working for MSNBC and Corbis over the next decade.He relaunched MediaStorm in 2005 as a film-production company and interactive design studio, which this month celebrates its 10th anniversary. He spoke with James Estrin about the future of photography and multimedia. Their conversation has been edited.

headline: ‘Nabokov in America,’ by Robert Roper
abstract: Roper’s book argues that Nabokov’s American period, from 1940 to 1960, was beneficial to the author in every way.
lead_paragraph: Who would have thought there’d be more to say about Vladimir Nabokov? This most scholarly and mandarin of writers, an incontestable master of his craft, has been parsed and chronicled to death — the subject of Brian Boyd’s two-­volume biography as well as Stacy Schiff’s portrait of a marriage (“Véra: Mrs. Vladimir Nabokov”), not to mention thousands of critical studies. So my first thought when I set eyes on Robert Roper’s “Nabokov in America: On the Road to ‘Lolita’ ” was, “Is this book necessary?”

headline: In ‘Letters to Véra,’ Vladimir Nabokov Writes to His Wife
abstract: Nabokov’s letters to Véra suggest a sky-filling ­adoration and a helpless dependency.
lead_paragraph: My sun, my soul, my song, my bird, my sweetheart, my pink sky, my sunny rainbow, my little music, my inexpressible delight, my softness, my tenderness, my lightness, my dear life, my dear eyes. . . . These endearments and salutations (backed up by a crowded menagerie of surrogates: Goosikins, Poochums, Tigercubkin, Puppykin) suggest a sky-filling ­adoration and, more than that, a helpless dependency. As early as Vladimir Nabokov’s second letter to Véra Slonim, after a couple of months of chaste acquaintanceship, he lays it all before her: “I cannot write a word without hearing how you will pronounce it — and can’t recall a single trifle I’ve lived through without regret — so sharp! — that we haven’t lived through it together. . . . You came into my life . . . as one comes to a kingdom where all the rivers have been waiting for your reflection, all the roads, for your steps.”
