lead_paragraph: When he was handed the chairman’s gavel of the Senate Armed Services Committee this year, Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, said changes to the way the Pentagon spent its money and to its overall structure would be his top priorities.

headline: Hillary Clinton to Release Plan to Address Veterans Affairs Scandal
abstract: Mrs. Clinton will roll out her proposals to help veterans and to improve the treatment they receive at the Department of Veterans Affairs as she fields Republican attacks on her previous comments about the problems that have plagued the department.
lead_paragraph: WINDHAM, N.H. — On Monday, just after she officially registered as a Democratic candidate in New Hampshire, Hillary Rodham Clinton declared, “This election is about our veterans.”

headline: Donald Trump Sees a Bump in Attention After ‘S.N.L.’ Appearance
abstract: According to a digital marketing firm, Donald J. Trump experienced a large increase in engagement across websites, social media and video platforms the day after being on the show.
lead_paragraph: Few candidates for president have been as deft at garnering free media attention as Donald J. Trump. His appearance on “Saturday Night Live” is the latest example.

headline: Seeing Voting Rights Under Siege, Philip Glass Rewrites an Opera
abstract: When Mr. Glass and Christopher Hampton wrote “Appomattox,” it was mostly about the Civil War. Now the second act grapples with more recent history.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Each new chapter of American history has a way of casting what came before it in a different light. So when the composer Philip Glass and the playwright Christopher Hampton decided to revive “Appomattox,” the opera about the Civil War that they wrote a decade ago, they found that the changing civil rights landscape cried out for a rewrite.

headline: In Ireland, Milk Chocolate Reigns
abstract: Ireland is a place where milk chocolate is a source of intense pride, with respected chocolatiers like Butlers, Skelligs, Lily O’Brien’s and Cadbury.
lead_paragraph: Everyone we met in Ireland told us that our trip last year couldn’t have been better timed. We were there in early summer. The countryside was at its ripest green, the characteristic clouds and rain were nowhere to be seen, and the crowds of summer tourists hadn’t yet arrived. But never mind the weather and the sights. We were there for the chocolate. Well, actually, I was there for the milk chocolate. My husband, Mahir, who proclaims his allegiance to dark, was my grumbling recruit.

headline: The Cult of the ‘Amateur’
keywords: ['English Language', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: In American life, work is confused with play and political inexperience in a presidential candidate is considered a virtue.
lead_paragraph: Late in October, the retired brain surgeon Ben Carson took the stage at a Christian college in Colorado and pitched himself as president. ‘‘I love it when people come up to me and they say: ‘B-b-b-b-but-but you’ve never been elected to any public office! You can’t possibly know how to do anything!’ Well, let me tell you something. The ark was built by amateurs. The Titanic was built by professionals.’’ Carson touched his fingertips together and smiled softly to himself. The crowd went nuts. Outside, one Carson supporter pinpointed the surgeon’s appeal: ‘‘People are sick of politicians.’’

headline: You, Only Better
abstract: Is “biohacking” just a fad? Or can data-driven diets help us become an improved, happier species?
lead_paragraph: Dave Asprey does not like infomercials. He didn’t want our conversation to feel like one, he said, raising both hands in a gesture of innocence, like a magician showing there was nothing up his sleeve. But once he planted the suggestion, it wouldn’t go away. There was the register of his voice, oscillating between breathy and enthusiastic, and the complete absence of qualifiers to soften his bold claims. And then there were the wares clustered on the table in front of him. He had laid out cups of his signature product, Bulletproof Coffee, which is made with grass-fed butter and Brain Octane, a trademarked oil extracted from coconuts. Next to the cups lay Bulletproof-branded protein bars in chocolate and vanilla. ‘‘I am not plugging my stuff,’’ he said with a semi-embarrassed laugh. ‘‘I’m just talking about how things work.’’

headline: A Visit to the Strange, Secretive World of David Bowie’s ‘Lazarus’
abstract: The Belgian director Ivo van Hove, Michael C. Hall and Cristin Milioti talk, and avoid talking, about this new musical.
lead_paragraph: On a recent weekday morning, the Belgian director Ivo van Hove sat at a corner table in the bar of the Standard Hotel. A bound script of “Lazarus,” his latest stage project, nestled on the table beside his Americano.

headline: Economists, Biologists and Skrillex on How to Predict the Future
keywords: ['Social Conditions and Trends', 'Global Warming', 'Income Inequality', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Synthetic Biology', 'Color', 'Insurance', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Music']
abstract: Industry experts weigh in on what they can — and cannot — know about how their fields will change over time.
lead_paragraph: Lots of people pretend they’ve got tomorrow figured out: tech gurus, politicians, C.E.O.s and (yes) journalists. But if we’re honest with ourselves, the view ahead of us has never been murkier. That’s because the problems that most haunt our world today — climate change and pollution, inequality and war — are problems for which technology, long our spur to envisioning better futures, looks more like a cause than a solution. Our future is hard to imagine because we have trouble imagining how we can possibly act to improve it.

headline: Poll Watch: Overseas Elections Offer Warnings for U.S. Pollsters
abstract: Pre-election polls in numerous countries this year have widely missed their marks, often by underestimating support for candidates on the ideological fringes.
lead_paragraph: Pre-election polls in numerous countries this year have widely missed their marks, often by underestimating support for candidates on the ideological fringes. The polling failures in countries like Britain, Poland and Israel point to technical issues that could well foreshadow polling problems in the United States, many analysts believe.

lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Liu Yiqian, a former taxi driver turned billionaire art collector, confirmed on Tuesday that he was the buyer of the painting of a nude woman by Amedeo Modigliani that sold for  $170.4 million at Christie’s New York on Monday night.

lead_paragraph: The Department of Homeland Security denies a temporary worker visa.

abstract: Congress set up the H-1B visa program to help American companies hire foreigners with specialized skills. But in recent years, many H-1B visas have gone to temporary immigrants who lacked special skills and displaced American workers from jobs.
lead_paragraph: Congress set up the H-1B visa program to help American companies hire foreigners with specialized skills. But in recent years, many H-1B visas have gone to temporary immigrants who lacked special skills and displaced American workers from jobs.

abstract: Paul D. Ryan is among the members of the “cot club,” who retire to their offices each night the House is in session for fiscal, practical and political reasons.

keywords: ['Juvenile Delinquency', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']

headline: Emma Roberts Shares Her Beauty Routine
abstract: The “Scream Queens” star can’t live without her face oil, and other go-to products.
lead_paragraph: Emma Roberts, 24, plays the lead character Chanel Oberlin, a terrifying sorority co-president who lords over her minions (the Chanels) on the hit fall show “Scream Queens.” In real life, Ms. Roberts, who was born in the Hudson Valley but grew up in the Hollywood Hills, is quite a bit more approachable and a beauty product junkie to boot. Here, the actress and Aerie model shares her beauty favorites.

abstract: Now there are complaints of not enough parity; no one’s ever satisfied.
lead_paragraph: Midway through the N.F.L. season is often the juncture at which sportstalk obsesses about parity driving every team toward .500. Instead, in this midway point there are three 8-0 teams and 16 losing clubs. No one’s ever satisfied — there are complaints of not enough parity.

headline: Where Humans and Computers Agree in College Football
abstract: The official playoff ranking last week resembled a computer composite much more than it resembled rankings from the media or coaches.
lead_paragraph: Cover your ears, Bowl Championship Series haters. Many computer rankings, which rely on statistics and algorithms to rate teams, tracked closely with how the committee’s 12 flesh-and-blood experts ended up listing the teams in the season’s first College Football Playoff ranking last Tuesday night.

headline: Ex-British Soldier, 66, Is Arrested in Bloody Sunday Massacre
abstract: The suspect, whom the authorities did not identify, was questioned about the 1972 killings of unarmed civilian marchers by British soldiers in Northern Ireland.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The police in Northern Ireland arrested a 66-year-old man on Tuesday in connection with Bloody Sunday, the infamous massacre of unarmed civilian marchers by British soldiers in Londonderry on Jan. 30, 1972. It was the first time anyone has been arrested in the massacre, for which the British government formally apologized in 2010.

headline: China’s Crackdown on Financial Markets Gets Top-Level Support

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — President Xi Jinping of China called for more measures to protect stock market investors after meeting with financial regulators, the state news media said on Tuesday, signaling top-level support for a national campaign to crack down on market manipulation and to increase transparency.

lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: TAG Heuer, Intel and Google Raise the Stakes in Smartwatches
abstract: The TAG Connected brings digital functionality to Swiss watchmaking. Should you buy in?
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t quite the frenzy of the Balmain x H&M event last week, but by noon on Monday, there were lines outside the TAG Heuer store on Fifth Avenue stretching at least partway down the block, as watch aficionados awaited their first glance at what has been thought of as the first real luxury competitor to the Apple Watch: the TAG Heuer Connected, a Swiss-engineered smartwatch with an Intel chip and a Google platform.

headline: 1915: Japan Crowns Emperor
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Japan celebrates its new emperor in 1915.
lead_paragraph: With all the strangely picturesque ceremony customary to the occasion, the coronation of Emperor Yoshihito of Japan took place yesterday at Kyoto, the Holy City. Strictly speaking, by reason of the fact that in Japan the sovereign has no crown nor does he receive any anointment, the ceremony was not so much that of a coronation as of the consecration of the new Emperor by a solemn ritual homage paid by him to his ancestors. The festivities in connection with the celebration of the Emperor’s accession to the throne last a month and began on Saturday with the departure from Tokyo of the sovereign and his suite for Kyoto, where on Sunday he deposited in the sacred pavilion called the Shunko-Den the sword, mirror and jewels bequeathed by the first Emperor of the Meiji dynasty. — The New York Herald, European Edition, November 11, 1915

headline: Ben Carson Fans in Iowa Stand by Their Man and Against the News Media
abstract: His supporters are shrugging off accusations that he made up elements of his biography, calling them reflective of news media bias.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — As he faces a swirl of questions about whether elements of his compelling biography are true, Ben Carson is finding stubborn allies: his many fans in Iowa, who are shrugging off accusations that he made things up, calling them reflective of news media bias.

headline: American Ambassador Builds Diplomatic Bridges With British Teenagers
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Gun Control', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: Matthew Barzun, the American ambassador to Britain, has talked with some 10,000 teenagers at schools across the country to learn what they really think about the United States.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Matthew Barzun, the American ambassador to the Court of St. James’s, stood before a buzzing, boisterous audience of several hundred teenagers in a poor borough on the southern edge of greater London and asked them what frustrated or concerned them the most about the United States.

lead_paragraph: A 90-year-old man died on Tuesday after he was found unconscious by emergency workers responding to a fire in his apartment in Queens, the authorities said.

headline: Helmut Schmidt, Assertive West German Chancellor, Dies at 96
abstract: Mr. Schmidt, elected in 1974, often appeared to disregard diplomacy, but he pushed his country into a forceful international role during the waning Cold War years.
lead_paragraph: Helmut Schmidt, the former West German chancellor who marshaled personal dynamism, managerial brilliance and often acid-tongued impatience to push his country into an assertive international role as the Cold War dragged on into the 1970s, died on Tuesday at his home in Hamburg. He was 96.

headline: Court Rules Against French Comedian Dieudonné in Free-Speech Case
keywords: ['ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Comedy and Humor']
abstract: Europe’s human rights court rejected an appeal by Dieudonné M’Bala M’Bala, saying laws on freedom of expression do not protect anti-Semitic comments or Holocaust denial.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In 2008, the French comedian Dieudonné M’bala M’bala finished a performance in Paris by inviting a Holocaust denier onstage to receive a prize from an actor dressed in striped pajamas resembling a concentration camp uniform, with a yellow star bearing the word “Jew.”

headline: Facebook to Appeal a Belgian Court’s Ruling on Data Privacy
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media']
abstract: The social media giant was told by a court in Brussels that it must stop collecting online data about people in Belgium who are not its users.
lead_paragraph: Facebook intends to appeal a privacy ruling in Belgium that forces the social media giant to stop collecting digital information about people who are not its users.

headline: Vito J. Lopez, Ex-New York Assemblyman Tainted by Scandal, Dies at 74
abstract: Mr. Lopez, a former community organizer and legislator, was a power broker in New York City and Albany until he was brought down by a sexual harassment scandal.
lead_paragraph: Vito J. Lopez, a former community organizer and New York assemblyman who parlayed a small antipoverty center in Brooklyn into a political machine that made him a power broker in New York City and Albany until he was brought down by a sexual harassment scandal, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 74.

headline: Now for the Positive: Jay Cutler Becomes Bears’ Top Passer
abstract: The much maligned Cutler set the Bears’ franchise record for touchdown passes on Monday night, connecting for Nos. 138 and 139.
lead_paragraph: When you think about Jay Cutler, you might think about ... well, what do you think about?

headline: ‘Jane the Virgin’ Season 2, Episode 5: Who Will She Choose?
abstract: This show has done a superb job navigating the love triangle plot.
lead_paragraph: “Jane the Virgin” has done a superb job navigating the love triangle, a common television plot device that is often done poorly, as when series allow it to overtake the main narrative or spend too long building multiple “will-they/won’t they-“ scenarios. Yet “Jane the Virgin” has deftly managed its triangle in a way that remains engaging and new, and doesn’t make viewers sick of the love between either Jane and Michael or Jane and Rafael.

headline: 1940: Italians Flee in Greece
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Italian troops retreat in Greece in 1940.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — The Italian lines in the Epirus sector have broken and the Fascist troops are in full retreat there, at the extreme left, or southern, end of the Greek front, according to the latest reports reaching here tonight [Nov. 10]. The Italians are retreating in disorder and are abandoning quantities of war material, it was stated in the reports. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 11, 1940

headline: Why Tuberculosis Is Back
abstract: Chronic underfunding of relief efforts has enabled a preventable disease to become the world’s biggest infectious killer.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — New data from the World Health Organization shows that we have allowed a preventable, curable disease to become the world’s biggest communicable killer. The millenniums-old lung disease tuberculosis now outranks even H.I.V./AIDS in the number of lives it claims. The fact is that we’ve been very successful at curing people of TB since the 1950s — so why is this illness still such a scourge?

headline: The Designer Who Doesn’t Want You to Sit Down
abstract: The prodigious and visionary Patricia Urquiola tackles the ultimate frontier of bad design: the American office.
lead_paragraph: The Spanish industrial designer Patricia Urquiola tackles the ultimate frontier of bad design: the American office.

headline: Miami City Ballet Returns for Joyce Season
abstract: The Joyce Theater’s spring and summer season, announced on Tuesday, also includes Dorrance Dance, the Stephen Petronio Company, Pennsylvania Ballet and a Cuba Festival.
lead_paragraph: Miami City Ballet will give a season in New York for the first time since 2009. Alessandra Ferri and Herman Cornejo team up for a program of contemporary ballet pieces with the pianist Bruce Levingston. These are some of the highlights of the Joyce Theater’s offerings for its spring and summer season, announced on Tuesday, which also includes the tap ensemble Dorrance Dance, the Stephen Petronio Company, Pennsylvania Ballet and a Cuba Festival.

headline: Escaping Reality With Brazil’s Globo TV
abstract: A media giant enthralls a country’s TV-addicted viewers with empty soap operas and inane commentary on the news.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Last year, The Economist published an article about TV Globo, Brazil’s largest broadcast network. It reported that “91 million people, just under half the population, tune in to it each day: The sort of audience that, in the United States, is to be had only once a year, and only for the one network that has won the rights that year to broadcast American football’s Super Bowl championship game.”

headline: Cuffing Season Is Here: Till Spring Do Us Part
abstract: It’s the time of the year when temperatures drop, going outside becomes a hassle, and having someone to snuggle with becomes a priority.
lead_paragraph: Camille Sanches, a Columbia University sophomore, was eating lunch with friends when another girl stopped by with some news: A guy had asked her out on a date.

headline: A Bleak Future in Eastern Ukraine’s Frozen Zone
abstract: The experiences of the few young professionals who have remained in the region reflect a sharp decline in living standards and a building sense of hopelessness.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — The 28-year-old accountant with a bob of chestnut hair would dash from work to meet her wide circle of friends at bars, restaurants and dinner parties. “It’s not how you spend your time, but who you spend it with,” Irina Filatova, the accountant, said of her humming social life.

headline: Opening Eyes
abstract: On my Win a Trip journey with Nicholas Kristof, I saw the miracles performed by Dr. Sanduk Ruit and Dr. Geoffrey Tabin at their cataract surgery camp in Nepal.
lead_paragraph: On my 2015 win-a-trip journey with Nicholas Kristof through India and Nepal, I spent most of the time reporting on issues related to extreme poverty, malnutrition and human rights abuses. As I wrote these columns, I battled feelings of futility and hopelessness. I was determined to change hearts and minds through human-centered stories, but I was afraid that the scale of the problems I was witnessing would engulf any efforts made to combat them.

headline: Scott Campbell Wants to Tattoo You
abstract: A Q. and A. with the famed tattoo artist who will soon be giving free tattoos — surprise tattoos — to anyone who dares.
lead_paragraph: As the best man at Justin Theroux and Jennifer Aniston’s wedding; the husband of the actress and filmmaker Lake Bell; and the tattoo artist who has inked the likes of Sting, Marc Jacobs, Robert Downey Jr. and Courtney Love, the New York tattoo artist turned fine artist Scott Campbell has enjoyed a degree of media attention not usually afforded the anonymous skin-scribblers of the East Village.

headline: A Pre-emptive Strike From Marco Rubio, Using Jeb Bush’s Words
abstract: Marco Rubio’s campaign unveiled an advertisement that shows former Gov. Jeb Bush showering his longtime Florida friend with praise, in a preview of what the senator may use should Mr. Bush go on the offensive in Tuesday night’s debate.
lead_paragraph: Senator Marco Rubio is ready for an onslaught of attacks from Jeb Bush, and ahead of Tuesday night’s Republican presidential debate he offered a preview of the comeback that he may use should Mr. Bush go on the offensive.

headline: Prosecutors Allege Persistent Heating Oil Fraud in New York City
abstract: Indictments that were unsealed on Tuesday charge nine companies and 44 people with defrauding a broad array of customers of fuel they believed had been delivered.
lead_paragraph: In a city of glittering office towers and computerized transactions, of records kept in the cloud and fuels that send less soot into the sky, the authorities say old-fashioned corruption of the most brazen kind still poisons the heating oil industry.

headline: Tasting and Testing a Genetically Modified, Non-Browning Apple
abstract: A non-browning apple passes the backpack and blender test—but will the genetic modification win parental approval?
lead_paragraph: Innovations in biotech crops aren’t known for getting children excited, but there is a new fruit trait on its way to the market that families may appreciate and children may actually notice. It’s a genetically modified apple that doesn’t turn brown when it is bruised or sliced. My children and I had a chance to try some last week. We beat them up and put them through a battery of tests to see how child-friendly and tasty they really are — a snack and a science lesson in one.

headline: Obama to Appeal Immigration Ruling to Supreme Court
abstract: The federal appeals court ruling blocked the president’s plan to provide work permits to millions of undocumented immigrants while shielding most of them from deportation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will ask the Supreme Court to clear the way for his far-reaching overhaul of the nation’s immigration system, administration lawyers said Tuesday, setting up a battle in the nation’s highest court over whether nearly five million undocumented immigrants can legally live and work in the United States.

headline: A History of Racism at the University of Missouri
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Timothy Wolfe’s tone-deaf style made matters worse, but racism has been an issue at the system’s flagship campus for years.
lead_paragraph: Timothy Wolfe’s resignation on Monday from the presidency of the University of Missouri system will not resolve the racial tensions that forced him from office. His tone-deaf style certainly inflamed the problem at the flagship campus in Columbia. But racist acts and utterances aimed at black students and black faculty have been an issue there for many years.

headline: Hindu Nationalist Killed in Clashes at Indian Celebration of Muslim Ruler
abstract: The death of the protester, coming after right-wing Hindus had pressured the government to cancel the event, is part of a string of escalating sectarian violence.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Tension between Hindus and Muslims flared anew in India on Tuesday when a Hindu nationalist in the southern state of Karnataka died from injuries he suffered while protesting a celebration honoring an 18th-century Muslim ruler.

headline: New York Regulator Seeks Proposals to Improve Cybersecurity
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Security and Warning Systems']
abstract: The Department of Financial Services in New York calls for financial companies to name chief information security officers.
lead_paragraph: New York’s financial industry regulator is seeking suggestions from other regulators on proposed regulations to shore up digital security defenses in the industry.

headline: Obama Turns to Diplomacy and Military in Syria, and Is Met With Doubts
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The goal is to press Russia, Iran and other players toward a cease-fire and a timeline for a transition of power, a strategy that even some in the administration doubt will work.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For the first time in the four-year Syrian civil war, President Obama is beginning to execute a combined diplomatic and military approach to force President Bashar al-Assad to leave office and end the carnage.

headline: Raymond Kelly, Former New York Police Commissioner, Joins K2
abstract: He will become vice chairman of the investigations company.
lead_paragraph: Since leaving his role as the longest-serving commissioner of the New York Police Department two years ago, Raymond W. Kelly has hardly retired.

headline: Modern Vessels With an Ancient Feel
abstract: With his whitewashed water jugs, the Los Angeles-based ceramist Eric Roinestad nods to the past.
lead_paragraph: The stoneware vessels crafted by the Los Angeles-based ceramist Eric Roinestad evoke the persevering elegance of water jugs pulled from the volcanic soil of Pompeii. Yet while the objects nod to the past, with their whitewashed bisque palette and smooth matte surfaces, they are clearly of their time. After giving these substantial pieces, which range between 14 and 20 inches tall, a flat wash, Roinestad fires them and then sands them to let some of the clay show through the glaze, giving the vases the feel of having been hauled, gently, from the ashes of time.

headline: Myanmar Military Still Big Power Despite Opposition Victory
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Elections', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Nobel Prizes']
abstract: Vestiges of Myanmar’s police state, alive and well, will wield enormous influence even with the lopsided election triumph by Aung San Suu Kyi’s party.
lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — Amid the mold-covered facades of downtown Yangon are police stations, a five-story building housing the Special Branch state security agency and government offices where citizens are required to register out-of-town houseguests.

headline: Volkswagen Hires Expert in Self-Driving Cars From Apple
keywords: ['Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Air Pollution', 'Diesel Power', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The move indicates that the German carmaker will continue to invest in advanced technologies despite the burdens of its emissions cheating crisis.
lead_paragraph: Volkswagen has hired an expert in self-driving car technology from Apple, sending a signal that it will continue to invest in leading-edge technologies despite the financial burden created by its emissions cheating crisis.

headline: Beware the Beer Belly
abstract: A new analysis of data from a large national study has found that carrying fat around the middle greatly raises the risk for heart disease and death, even for those of normal weight.
lead_paragraph: A beer belly is a dangerous thing.

headline: Arrest of Jose Reyes May Test Baseball’s New Domestic Violence Policy
abstract: Reyes, a shortstop for the Rockies, was arrested in Hawaii last month, and Rob Manfred, the baseball commissioner, said he had begun an inquiry.
lead_paragraph: BOCA RATON, Fla. — Colorado Rockies shortstop Jose Reyes, who was arrested in Hawaii recently on charges of assaulting his wife, may become the first player to face discipline under Major League Baseball’s new domestic violence policy.

headline: Jams
abstract: Jonathan Waxman reboots the restaurant that helped bring nouvelle California cuisine to New York.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Waxman reboots the restaurant that helped bring nouvelle California cuisine to New York.

headline: Jams Gets a Reboot in Midtown
abstract: Jonathan Waxman’s revival of a 1980s haunt trudges ahead in zombie-like fashion.
lead_paragraph: By the early 1980s, New Yorkers knew that something major was happening in the kitchens of California. They had heard about the revolution, but most of them hadn’t tasted it until Jonathan Waxman opened Jams in 1984. Here was a report from the West Coast front lines brought by a chef fresh from Michael’s in Santa Monica and, before that, Chez Panisse in Berkeley.

headline: New Tour Reveals Vietnam’s Many Sides
abstract: A new tour to Vietnam from Adventure Life combines cultural and outdoor activities in urban and rural settings.
lead_paragraph: A new tour to Vietnam from Adventure Life combines cultural and outdoor activities in urban and rural settings. Highlights of the 12-day trip include trekking through remote Hmong villages, exploring Hanoi and spending two nights on a junk cruising around the towering limestone islands in Ha Long Bay, above. On the way back to Hanoi from Ha Long, travelers will visit the porcelain ceramics factory at Bat Trang and take a rickshaw ride along the bank of the Perfume River to the Hue Imperial City. On some days, guests will be able to choose among cycling, rock climbing or a trek to the massive Son Doong Cave in Phong Nha-Ke Bang National Park, open to the public only since 2013.

headline: Tale of Gowanus Canal’s Three-Eyed Fish May Be Too Good to Be True
keywords: ['Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Hoaxes and Pranks']
abstract: Over the weekend, the news site Gothamist posted a video seeming to show an abnormal catfish caught in the Superfund site, though some scientists were skeptical.
lead_paragraph: A lot of strange things lurk in the murky, tainted depths of the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn. But a three-eyed catfish is very unlikely to be one of them.

headline: A ‘Star Wars’ Fan Dies After Getting His Last Wish
abstract: Thousands of fans rallied around the #ForceForDaniel hashtag to support Daniel Fleetwood. Last week he saw “Star Wars: The Force Awakens.” This week, he died from cancer.
lead_paragraph: After learning that he was losing his two-year battle with cancer, Daniel Fleetwood, a longtime “Star Wars” fan, had one last wish: to see an early version of the newest film.

headline: In the South of France, a Sophisticated Ease
abstract: Exaggerated tailoring and classic stripes take new shape by the sea.
lead_paragraph: Exaggerated tailoring and classic stripes take new shape by the sea.

headline: Justice Department Opposes United-Delta Swap for Newark Landing Slots
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: The agency says that an agreement between the airlines to swap takeoff and landing spots between Newark and Kennedy airports would harm competition.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department said on Tuesday that it would seek to block United Airlines from further expanding its hold at Newark Liberty International Airport because the carrier already has a near monopoly there.

headline: Readers Respond: Kicked Off a Plane
abstract: Hundreds of commenters weighed in on our story about passengers being kicked off an airplane. Here are a few of the most interesting responses.
lead_paragraph: Last week, several airplane passengers in Los Angeles who had boarded their Spirit Airlines flight to Dallas got kicked off the plane after an exchange over a seat that had been double-booked. (The passengers say the decision was racially motivated; the carrier says it’s looking into the matter.)

headline: Atmospheric Greenhouse Gas Levels Hit Record, Report Says
abstract: The World Meteorological Organization announced that concentrations of carbon dioxide, methane and nitrous oxide reached record levels in 2014.
lead_paragraph: Global concentrations of carbon dioxide in Earth’s atmosphere surpassed 400 parts per million for a monthly average this past spring, breaching a symbolic barrier set by climate scientists and policy makers, according to a report released Monday.

headline: Prosecutors Announce More Charges in Hacking of JPMorgan Chase
abstract: A superseding indictment says three men hacked into banks, brokers and financial information publishing companies.
lead_paragraph: Billing it as the largest hacking case ever uncovered, federal prosecutors in Manhattan on Tuesday described a global, multiyear scheme to steal information on 100 million customers of a dozen companies in the United States and use the data to advance stock manipulation activities, illicit online gambling and fraud.

headline: In Russia, Doping Accusations Are Taken in Stride
abstract: The accusations that a Kremlin-backed program eased doping by elite track-and-field athletes were sweeping, but outrage was hard to find in Russia.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The sweeping accusations that a Kremlin-backed program facilitated doping by elite Russian track-and-field athletes in the Olympics and other top sports events earned a collective shrug Tuesday from the Russian public and even, to some extent, from the officials who oversaw the debacle.

headline: Neel Kashkari, Ex-Treasury Official, Named Minneapolis Fed President
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Neel Kashkari is the third new president of a regional reserve bank named this year, and all three previously worked at Goldman Sachs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Neel T. Kashkari, who oversaw the government’s bailout of the banking industry as a Treasury official in the George W. Bush and Obama administrations, was named the next president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis on Tuesday.

headline: Fashion by the Sea
abstract: Exaggerated tailoring and classic stripes inspire a more sophisticated ease.
lead_paragraph: Exaggerated tailoring and classic stripes inspire a more sophisticated ease.

headline: Valeant Chief Says Issues Stem From Fast Growth
abstract: J. Michael Pearson, the pharmaceutical company’s chief executive, said in a conference call with investors that the company was strong, despite recent issues.
lead_paragraph: J. Michael Pearson, the embattled chief executive of Valeant Pharmaceuticals International, sought on Tuesday to reassure investors that the once highflying company still had a solid future despite a steep fall in its stock price and growing questions about its business model and debt levels.

headline: Aziz Ansari on Acting, Race and Hollywood
abstract: It can be hard to find minority performers for film and television roles, but we can’t keep using white actors in brownface.
lead_paragraph: Fisher Stevens was cooking dinner when I got him on the phone. I had wanted to talk to him for years because, as I recount in my new Netflix series, “Master of None,” this actor played a strange role in my relationship to television and film.

headline: Cuomo to Raise Minimum Wage to $15 for All New York State Employees
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said that he would act unilaterally for employees on the state’s payroll, placing New York’s public workers far ahead of other states on minimum wage.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Tuesday that he would unilaterally establish a $15 minimum wage for all state workers, making New York the first state to set such a high wage for its public employees.

headline: How to Watch the G.O.P. Debate
abstract: The so-called undercard debate is at 7 p.m. Eastern, and the prime-time event at 9. Here are your options for watching, listening and keeping up.
lead_paragraph: Republican presidential candidates will get another opportunity to share their views on the economy on Tuesday night in Milwaukee, when Fox Business Network and The Wall Street Journal host the party’s fourth debate this cycle.

headline: Deployment Solace From an Earlier Generation of Military Spouses
abstract: “We managed fine, honey, and you will too.”
lead_paragraph: When my husband, a Navy helicopter pilot, deployed a little over a month ago, I drove our two children home in relative silence, wondering how we would handle the better part of the next year. I found my answer — my solace — in an unlikely place: love letters that aren’t mine.

headline: Meatballs and Instruction Manuals: Indiana Braces for Ikea.
abstract: Ikea officials announce plans to open a store in Fishers, Ind., in the fall of 2017.
lead_paragraph: Lingonberries, Swedish meatballs and the frustrations of furniture assembly manuals are coming to central Indiana: Ikea, the Swedish home furnishings retailer, announced plans on Tuesday to open a new store outside Indianapolis.

headline: Einat Admony’s New Restaurant Set to Open
abstract: Combina will feature the chef’s trademark Israeli-Middle Eastern fare; Arepa Factory opens in the East Village; Quality Meats expands; and more.
lead_paragraph: Combina The chef Einat Admony’s latest restaurant, a wide room with an open kitchen and bar and an expanse of windows, will feature her trademark Israeli-Middle Eastern fare, but often with a bright Spanish inflection. The haloumi (cheese) comes dressed with chimichurri; a burger is made with merguez, the North African sausage; fried eggplant comes on a tostada; and there are salt cod doughnuts. “Not fritters, real doughnuts,” Ms. Admony said. The drinks list includes sherries, ciders, vermouths and homemade limoncello made with Moroccan-style preserved lemons. Joining her as chef in this venture is Molly Breidenthal. Lacking basement storage, the owners installed shelving all around to hold ingredients. (Opens Saturday): 330 West Broadway (Grand Street), 212-226-1248.

headline: University of Missouri Professor Who Confronted Photographer Quits Journalism Post
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Freedom of the Press', 'News and News Media', 'Journalism Schools']
abstract: Melissa Click was seen on video calling for “some muscle” to remove a journalist from a public demonstration.
lead_paragraph: After a University of Missouri professor was seen on video calling for “some muscle” to remove a journalist from a public demonstration, the professor cut her ties to the university’s journalism school on Tuesday as protest organizers — and the professor herself — joined college officials in stating that journalists had a right to be present.

headline: Liberty Global and Discovery Communications Take Stakes in Lions Gate
abstract: With the investments, John Malone strengthens his ties to the home of “Mad Men” and the “Hunger Games” franchise.
lead_paragraph: John C. Malone, the media and telecommunications billionaire, has never been one to shy away from making deals. And in a year when he helped orchestrate one of the biggest cable transactions in recent years, he has struck another play.

headline: Senate Passes Military Bill That Bans Transfers of Guantánamo Detainees
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Detainees']
abstract: A spokesman said President Obama would sign the annual military bill despite provisions that will make it extremely difficult for him to close the terrorist detention center in Cuba.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Tuesday approved an annual military policy bill, and the White House spokesman said President Obama would sign it despite provisions that will make it extremely difficult for him to fulfill his promise of closing the terrorist detention center at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

headline: Reese Witherspoon, Caitlyn Jenner and Others Honored by Glamour
abstract: Activists, celebrities, athletes and businesswomen were celebrated at the magazine’s annual Women of the Year awards.
lead_paragraph: Activists, celebrities, athletes and businesswomen were celebrated at the magazine’s annual Women of the Year awards.

headline: Portugal’s Government Ousted in Challenge to Austerity
abstract: The prime minister, Pedro Passos Coelho, had been held up as a model proponent of the belt-tightening prescriptions pushed by European Union officials.
lead_paragraph: An alliance of left-wing Portuguese lawmakers on Tuesday brought down the government of Prime Minister Pedro Passos Coelho, turning the country’s politics on its head just weeks after inconclusive elections and offering up a strong new challenge to the austerity policies that have divided Europe.

headline: Caitlyn Jenner, Reese Witherspoon and Others Honor Women With Glamour
abstract: Activists, celebrities, athletes and businesswomen were celebrated at the magazine’s annual Women of the Year awards.
lead_paragraph: At the Glamour Women of the Year awards on Monday night, the dresses were designer and the heels hard to walk in, but the speeches were fiery and progressive.

headline: Helmut Schmidt, West Germany’s Assertive and Popular Chancellor
abstract: Mr. Schmidt, elected in 1974, pushed his country into a forceful international role during the waning Cold War years. He died Tuesday at 96.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Schmidt, elected in 1974, pushed his country into a forceful international role during the waning Cold War years. He died Tuesday at 96.

headline: Have You Encountered Racial Conflict on Campus?
abstract: New York Times journalists would like to hear about readers’ experiences with racial conflict on college campuses.
lead_paragraph: New York Times journalists would like to hear about readers’ experiences with racial conflict on college campuses.

headline: Why People Actually Like the Denver Airport
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'AIRPORTS', 'Airport Security', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: Since taking over at the Denver airport in 2008, Kim Day has helped to transform it into the envy of airports around the country.
lead_paragraph: Airports are an inevitable part of the lives of most travelers. But few would say that they have a passion for them. Kim Day, the chief executive of Denver International Airport, is an exception. In a previous life, Ms. Day, 61, was an architect, and she says that shaped her career running airports. “I see the world, and airports, differently than most people,” she told the audience at the Skift Global Forum, a travel conference held last month in Brooklyn. “I can’t walk into a space without critiquing it and wanting to rearrange the furniture. And I plan every vacation around buildings and spaces around the world that I want to see.”

headline: Caution Needed on Push Into Repo Lending
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: As big investment banks pull back, some lenders are bulking up in repo, a form of short-term collateralized lending that may carry hidden risks.
lead_paragraph: Regional lenders like Wells Fargo, Nordea and the Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group have been bulking up in repo, a form of short-term collateralized lending that principally helps nonbank financial groups fund themselves and their clients. It’s not a wholly positive trend.

headline: Montreal to Dump Raw Sewage as It Makes Repairs
abstract: The controversial sewage diversion may last as long as seven days. The mayor said the city had no choice.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — The mayor of Montreal, Denis Coderre, said Tuesday that the city would begin dumping about 2.1 billion gallons of raw sewage into the St. Lawrence River early Wednesday morning.

headline: Romania’s President Picks Dacian Ciolos as New Prime Minister
keywords: ['Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: Mr. Ciolos, an expert on agriculture, is considered to be a capable manager whose appointment could help calm the political unrest that has roiled the country.
lead_paragraph: BUCHAREST, Romania — Romania’s president on Tuesday nominated an expert on agriculture to replace Prime Minister Victor Ponta, who was ousted last week after major demonstrations by protesters angered by graft and lethargy in the government.

headline: No Charges Against Rio Police in Fatal Shooting of 10-Year-Old Boy
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Poverty']
abstract: An inquiry said the officers involved in the fatal shooting, which prompted a public outcry in Rio’s violence-plagued favelas, were acting in self-defense.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Just seven months ago, this city was stunned by images of the lifeless body of Eduardo de Jesus, a 10-year-old boy fatally shot by a police officer on the doorstep of his home. The authorities promised justice to Eduardo’s parents. Protests flared in Complexo do Alemão, the maze of cinder block homes where Eduardo lived.

headline: No Rio, Pacificação Sem Paz
abstract: No Alemão, uma das maiores favelas do Rio, a vaga de violência custa a vida de crianças e policiais, colocando em causa a estratégia das Unidades de Polícia Pacificadora.
lead_paragraph: No Alemão, uma das maiores favelas do Rio, a vaga de violência custa a vida de crianças e policiais, colocando em causa a estratégia das Unidades de Polícia Pacificadora.

abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany praised the former West German chancellor Helmut Schmidt, who died on Tuesday, citing his service and sense of duty.
lead_paragraph: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany praised the former West German chancellor Helmut Schmidt, who died on Tuesday, citing his service and sense of duty.

headline: Hedda Hopper Bold Brand of Fashion
abstract: Who knew better than Hedda Hopper the value of an eye-popping look?
lead_paragraph: Who knew better than Hedda Hopper the value of an eye-popping look?

headline: For Gossip Columnist Hedda Hopper, Flamboyance Was Her Brand
abstract: The gossip columnist, played by Helen Mirren in the new film “Trumbo,” was a savvy self-marketer, one of the first public figures to use wardrobe and artifice to turn herself into a viable American icon.
lead_paragraph: “The geniuses who conduct the motion picture business killed glamour,” Hedda Hopper once lamented.

headline: Netflix to Finance Film by “Snowpiercer” Director
abstract: The Korean director Bong Joon-ho announced the deal, for his adventure film “Okja,” which will be co-produced by Plan B Entertainment.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Netflix will provide financing for the Korean director Bong Joon-ho’s adventure film “Okja,” which will be co-produced by Plan B Entertainment, Mr. Bong said in a statement. The film, about the travels of a girl and a friendly beast, is expected to cost about $50 million, and will feature Jake Gyllenhaal, Tilda Swinton, Bill Nighy and others.

headline: 2 Accused of Being Russian Soldiers Appear in Court in Ukraine
abstract: The men, who confessed to being members of Russia’s military while recovering from wounds in captivity, told a Ukrainian court that they were unemployed, not soldiers.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A Ukrainian court on Tuesday opened preliminary hearings in the trial of two Russian men captured in combat in eastern Ukraine and suspected of serving as active-duty members of the Russian military.

headline: Commissioner Hopeful of 2016 Spring Training Game in Cuba
abstract: The last time a major league team played in Cuba was 1999, when the Baltimore Orioles faced Cuba’s national team in Havana.
lead_paragraph: BOCA RATON, Fla. — Commissioner Rob Manfred expressed hope Tuesday that a Major League Baseball team would play exhibition games in Cuba during spring training next year, saying that “it would be a good thing for baseball.”

headline: Attack of the Seagulls? Nope. Appendicitis Felled Pianist.
abstract: The pianist Paul Lewis said rumors of a seagull attack forcing him to cancel concerts were false, and attributes his absence to a burst appendix.
lead_paragraph: It had nothing to do with the seagull attack.

headline: Korean War Memorial Group Finds More Aid in Korea Than in U.S.
keywords: ['Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Korean War', 'National Mall (Washington, DC)', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The foundation does not have the money it needs to maintain the memorial on the National Mall, and what it does have came from South Korean corporations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Korean War Veterans Memorial on the National Mall is often considered one of the most striking of the war memorials, with the seven-foot-tall stainless steel statues of soldiers anticipating combat, and its dark gray granite wall etched with images of those who supported the troops.

headline: New York Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Rules Suspended on Wednesday
abstract: Because of Veterans Day, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Because of Veterans Day, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Wednesday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: From Hotel to Hospital: The Perils of Reporting in Pakistan
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Poisoning and Poisons']
abstract: Rod Nordland, the Kabul bureau chief, recounts a banal poisoning episode in one of the world’s cloak-and-dagger capitals.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The last time I worried about being the victim of a poison gas attack was in Baghdad, back when we still believed in the WMD fairy tale. The last place I ever expected a poison gas attack was in a five-star hotel here in Pakistan’s capital.

headline: Lois Colley, Westchester County Socialite, Was Murdered, Police Say
abstract: Ms. Colley, 83, whose body was discovered at her home in North Salem, N.Y., on Monday night, died from blunt force trauma, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A prominent socialite and the wife of a millionaire McDonald’s franchise owner was found dead in her Westchester County home this week, and the New York State Police said on Tuesday that they believed she was murdered.

headline: Former Prison for Women to Become a Place That Serves Them
abstract: Plans call for conversion of the former Bayview Correctional Facility in Manhattan to the Women’s Building, largely for nonprofit groups.
lead_paragraph: Over the years, as West Chelsea went from gritty to glamorous, Bayview Correctional Facility, a notorious women’s prison, became an increasingly odd fit.

headline: Fantasy Football Week 10: Waiver Wire Picks
abstract: Jaguars quarterback Blake Bortles and Bills running back Karlos Williams are options if you need to fill out your bench.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a look at the players worth adding to your fantasy football roster this week:

headline: Supreme Court Hears Case for Tyson Foods Class-Action Lawsuit
abstract: Thousands of workers at an Iowa pork processing plant are seeking to band together in a single lawsuit seeking overtime pay.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Facing a Supreme Court generally hostile to class actions, thousands of workers at an Iowa pork processing plant may nevertheless have found a narrow path toward victory at an argument on Tuesday, one that would allow them to band together in a single lawsuit seeking overtime pay.

headline: Rehabilitating a Prison
abstract: A former women’s prison in Chelsea is being converted into offices, by developers who will rent mainly to nonprofit organizations focused on providing services for women.
lead_paragraph: A former women’s prison in Chelsea is being converted into offices, by developers who will rent mainly to nonprofit organizations focused on providing services for women.

headline: Survey Finds Corporations Looking to Reduce Outside Legal Spending
abstract: Nearly half of the 258 corporate law departments surveyed intend to cut their spending with outside legal firms as they take a harder look at costs and risks.
lead_paragraph: Close to half the corporate law departments that responded to a recent survey plan to cut spending on outside legal work, according to Altman-Weil, a legal consulting firm that surveyed 258 corporate law departments. Instead, corporate counsel offices plan to parcel out more work among their own employees and to contract lawyers.

headline: Mayor de Blasio’s Group Abandons Plans for Inequality Forum in Iowa
abstract: The Progressive Agenda Committee, founded by Mayor Bill de Blasio, said the forum had become unnecessary, because inequality had already moved to the center of the 2016 presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: The liberal advocacy group founded by Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York has abandoned its plans to hold a forum in Iowa focused on income inequality, bringing an abrupt and anticlimactic end to his initial efforts at shaping the economic debate in the 2016 presidential campaign.

headline: New York’s Funniest Stand-Up Finalists Gear Up for a Serious Smackdown
abstract: Hoping to benefit from the exposure, 10 comedians — nine men and just one woman — will face off in the final round on Sunday at the New York Comedy Festival.
lead_paragraph: It’s a maxim that stand-up comedy, like many artistic pursuits, is a marathon, not a sprint: There aren’t many lightning victories, just one long slog. But after taking part in the New York’s Funniest Stand-Up semifinals last month, Randy Syphax seemed to think that the competition gave comics an incentive to pick up the pace. “Nights like this definitely feel like someone shot a gun,” he said.

headline: Review: How to Pet a Dog and Other Gnawing Issues in ‘Going Deep With David Rees’
abstract: The humorist’s show, first seen last year on the National Geographic Channel, begins a new season Wednesday on Esquire.
lead_paragraph: “Don’t overthink it” is usually pretty good advice; the list of things that can be made worse or less enjoyable by too much analysis is endless. But “Going Deep With David Rees” turns overthinking into an art form.

abstract: The lawsuit filed against Facebook and its directors over directors’ compensation.
lead_paragraph: The lawsuit filed against Facebook and its directors over directors’ compensation.

abstract: Stephanie Clifford provides a back-scene look at her reporting on the Vincent Asaro trial in Brooklyn’s Federal District Court.

lead_paragraph: The exact nature of Sheldon Silver’s lucrative outside legal work had long been one of the best-kept secrets in New York politics.

headline: How Much to Pay a Director? There’s No Clear Answer
abstract: Tired of high chief executive compensation? You’re probably not going to like the latest issue du jour: rising director pay.

headline: When Ted Cruz’s Father Campaigned for Fidel Castro
abstract: After leaving Cuba for Texas in 1957, Rafael Cruz spoke out in support of the Castro-led rebellion, only to reject it two years later after becoming disillusioned with its leftist leanings.
lead_paragraph: Long before he headlined Republican dinners and wooed donors on behalf of his son, Ted, Rafael Cruz – now an evangelical pastor and a major draw for Tea Party audiences – campaigned across Texas for none other than Fidel Castro.

abstract: Photos from Afghanistan, Syria, Greece and Myanmar.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Afghanistan, Syria, Greece and Myanmar.

headline: WADA Acts on Doping Report, Revoking Accreditation of Russian Lab
abstract: After the move, the lab’s director, Grigory Rodchenkov, was said to have resigned, all in the wake of the report, which outlined systemic doping in Russian athletics.
lead_paragraph: In an interview Tuesday, the president of the World Anti-Doping Agency defended his handling of the Russian athletics scandal, even as his organization moved to revoke the accreditation of a Moscow lab at the heart of the scandal.

headline: Eike Batista Banned for 5 Years From Serving as a Corporate Officer
abstract: The fallen Brazilian mogul also faces a criminal case, which has been suspended.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO — The fallen businessman Eike Batista lost another legal battle Tuesday as Brazil’s markets regulator banned him from serving as an officer of a publicly traded company for the next five years.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Deborah Sontag, Sam Dolnick and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: A Festive Vegan Torte
abstract: What do you do when Americans, French, omnivores and vegans gather at the Thanksgiving table? Please them all with this festive torte of sweet potatoes, chick peas and lentils.
lead_paragraph: As a transplanted American living in Paris, Ann Schreifels had the task of hosting Thanksgiving, a holiday the locals didn’t celebrate, in a city that is arguably the culinary capital of the world, to a guest list that included meat eaters and vegans.

headline: Russian Airplane Crash Shakes Egypt’s Tourism
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Terrorism', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The downing of the Russian Metrojet is the latest blow to Egypt’s tourism, which has been reeling since the 2011 uprising.
lead_paragraph: The Oct. 31 downing of the Russian airliner Metrojet over the Sinai Peninsula of Egypt, which killed all 224 passengers and crew aboard, represents the latest blow to Egyptian tourism, which has been reeling since the 2011 Egyptian uprising that ousted President Hosni Mubarak.

headline: Hillary Clinton Pledges to Make Better Treatment of Veterans a Priority
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton called the Department of Veterans Affairs an “archaic system” that was “built for the past, not the future,” as she unveiled a multipronged set of proposals Tuesday to expand care and medical services to the country’s 21.8 million veterans.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton on Tuesday called the Department of Veterans Affairs an “archaic system” that was “built for the past, not the future,” as she unveiled a multipronged set of proposals to expand care and medical services to the country’s 21.8 million veterans.

headline: Review: Flora Crockett, a Forgotten Abstract Painter
abstract: About two dozen of Ms. Crockett’s sparkling late paintings, from 1966 to 1973, form a surprising exhibition at Meredith Ward Fine Art.
lead_paragraph: The paintings of the American abstractionist Flora Crockett have not been exhibited in New York since a group show at the Overseas Press Club of America in 1965. That was the year she turned 73 and began her most productive period as a painter.

headline: On ‘Mr. Misunderstood,’ Eric Church Pays Homage to His Influences
abstract: Mr. Church’s new album, a surprise release last week, has shades of the Allman Brothers and scraped-up Southern rock, along with bluesy country gospel.
lead_paragraph: Eric Church is the sort of singer who sings earnestly about other singers, whose songs posit music as a magical sun shower to bathe in blissfully. In his songs, music is fuel for love, for anguish and, naturally, for other music.

headline: A Beloved L.A. Surf Hangout Gets a Second Act
abstract: Venice's Rose Café, reopened with chef Jason Neroni, features work from the artist Craig Stecyk.
lead_paragraph: When the Rose Café — a longtime artist hangout in Venice Beach — closed its doors earlier this year, many of its fans feared a big change was underway. But for its next incarnation, open now, the new owner Bill Chait wanted to honor the space’s history and reflect the neighborhood’s culture. So he called on Jeffrey Deitch, the New York-based art dealer and curator who just a few years earlier had served as the director of the Museum of Contemporary Art Los Angeles. “We talked to Ed Ruscha, and Ed Moses, and reached out at some point to John Baldessari, and ended up talking to Craig,” Chait says, referring to the artist Craig Stecyk, who decorated the new space. “Craig knew a lot of these artists and obviously had been very involved in the Venice surf and skateboard scene, and so I think what he’s doing was very sort of trying to enhance the history of the Rose.”

headline: Oy or Yo? Sculpture With Something to Say Lands at Brooklyn Bridge
abstract: The new sculpture by the artist Deborah Kass yells “YO” if you are looking at it from Manhattan or “OY” if you are gazing out from Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The rude interjection is a staple of New York life. Now, the landscape of the city will itself heckle residents and tourists, with a brash new sculpture in Brooklyn Bridge Park that yells “YO” if you are looking at it from Manhattan or “OY” if you are gazing out from Brooklyn.

headline: Review: With ‘Charles Francis Chan Jr.’s Exotic Oriental Murder Mystery,’ Lloyd Suh Takes on a Legacy
abstract: This play is adapted from “The Mysterious Affair at Styles,” Agatha Christie’s first Hercule Poirot novel.
lead_paragraph: Ah. So.

headline: Review: ‘Ride the Cyclone,’ About Teenagers, and Angst, in Purgatory
abstract: Members of a school choir meet their deaths on a roller coaster and must compete for redemption in this musical at the Chicago Shakespeare Theater.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — “Ride the Cyclone,” an unceasingly delightful new musical having its premiere at the Chicago Shakespeare Theater, does bring a smidgen of sad news. Apparently the rivalries, insecurities and peer-fearing angst of the teenage years survive even beyond the grave.

headline: Gordon Parks’s Harlem Argument
abstract: A look at Gordon Parks’s first photo essay for Life shows how editors’ choices of words and pictures can manipulate meaning.
lead_paragraph: A look at Gordon Parks’s first photo essay for Life shows how editors’ choices of words and pictures can manipulate meaning.

headline: Review: ‘Mad Libs Live!,’ a Musical With a Few Missing Pieces
abstract: As in the word game, the audience is asked to help fill in the blanks — a license to go a little lowbrow — in this show at New World Stages.
lead_paragraph: Poop was popular at the matinee I attended. So was Donald Trump. That figures: Playing Mad Libs, the fill-in-the-blank word game, always has been license to go a little lowbrow.

lead_paragraph: The New York State attorney general on Tuesday ordered the two biggest daily fantasy sports companies, DraftKings and FanDuel, to stop accepting bets from New York residents, saying their games constituted illegal gambling under state law.

headline: Review: ‘My Life on the Road,’ Gloria Steinem’s Journey as a Traveling Feminist
abstract: In her first book in more than 20 years, Ms. Steinem looks back at nearly five decades as itinerant feminist organizer and standard-bearer.
lead_paragraph: As a young journalist in the early 1960s, Gloria Steinem famously went undercover as a Playboy bunny. In the early pages of her new book, “My Life on the Road,” Ms. Steinem, now 81, claims another unlikely job description.

headline: When Buying Gift Cards, Know Your Audience (and Their Age)
abstract: Gift cards are popular to give during the holidays. New research and experts offer insights into what types of cards to buy for friends and relatives, and how to get the best deal.
lead_paragraph: Shoppers stumped about what holiday gifts to give friends or relatives often fall back on gift cards. When choosing such a card, it may be wise to take the recipient’s age into account, a new analysis finds.

abstract: The language has been an integral part of life for Mr. Hoffman and Ms. Toren, who star in a New Yiddish Rep production of the Arthur Miller play.

abstract: Two Palestinian cousins accused of a stabbing were apparently inspired by a video showing harsh Israeli treatment of a suspect accused of an earlier stabbing.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The younger cousin took his allowance from his father on Tuesday morning and said he was off to school as usual. He and his older cousin decided to skip class instead.

headline: A Conversation With Martin Cohen
abstract: Mr. Cohen, 66, is executive chairman of Cohen & Steers, a publicly traded investment company known for its real estate investment trust mutual funds.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Cohen, 66, is the executive chairman and a founder of Cohen & Steers, a publicly traded investment company known for its real estate investment trust, or REIT, mutual funds. The company, which Mr. Cohen started in New York in 1986 with Robert Steers, was among the first to specialize in listed real estate. It manages around $50 billion in assets, which now also include infrastructure, natural resource and commodity equities.

lead_paragraph: Preet Bharara, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, announced charges in the the largest hacking case ever uncovered.

headline: The Fight for $15 Comes to the Republican Debate
abstract: Protesters will call for higher wages and unions on Tuesday night. It’s time for Republicans to listen.
lead_paragraph: When an estimated one thousand Fight for $15 protesters gather on Tuesday night at the Milwaukee auditorium where the Republican presidential debate is being held, it will mark the end of a long day of strikes and protests in some 400 cities nationwide.

headline: Designing Arthur Miller: Simple Gestures, Big Ideas
abstract: On the centennial of Mr. Miller’s birth, a look at how designers are capturing the powerful spirit of his plays with simplicity and brawn.
lead_paragraph: A compelling silhouette appears on the cover of a new digital edition of the playwright Arthur Miller’s “Playing for Time,” about a women’s orchestra in Auschwitz. (The script was produced as a 1980 television movie starring Vanessa Redgrave.) Against a somber purple background, white pages of a score spill from a skinny music stand. It takes a second to notice the swastika at the base.

lead_paragraph: The McDonald’s Corporation will increase its spending to buy back shares and for heftier dividends for shareholders, Steve Easterbrook, its chief executive, said on Tuesday.

lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Redpoint eventures, a joint effort between Redpoint Ventures and e.ventures of Silicon Valley, has added Romero Rodrigues, one of Brazil’s best-known Internet entrepreneurs, as a full-time general partner.

headline: Nevada: Lack of Oxygen Is Cited in Death in Cryotherapy Tank
abstract: The woman who died at a cryotherapy center in Henderson while giving herself a cold-air treatment died from lack of oxygen, the Clark County coroner’s office said.
lead_paragraph: The woman who died at a cryotherapy center in Henderson while giving herself a cold-air treatment died from lack of oxygen, the Clark County coroner’s office said Tuesday. The woman, Chelsea Ake-Salvacion, 24, was an employee at Rejuvenice, which allowed customers to spend up to three minutes encased in capsules cooled to minus 240 degrees. She was found dead in one of the chambers on Oct. 20, prompting questions about safety in the growing industry. The coroner’s office said nitrogen used to cool the chamber had displaced the oxygen Ms. Ake-Salvacion needed to breathe, and ruled her death an accident.

headline: Seeking a Better Life While Trying to Forget the ‘Long, Terrible Years’ of the Holocaust
abstract: Facing anti-Semitism in Ukraine, Dora and Motel Shkolnick obtained visas to come to the United States in 1973 with hopes of creating a better future for their children.
lead_paragraph: Rain tapped lightly on the windows of Dora and Motel Shkolnick’s one-bedroom apartment in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn. Inside, Mr. Shkolnick, 96, and Mrs. Shkolnick, 91, sat at a dining room table and shared warm pastries she had baked.

headline: Thanksgiving for All
abstract: How to plan and cook Thanksgiving.
lead_paragraph: There is no more inclusive holiday on the American calendar than Thanksgiving — and perhaps no more ambitious for the home cook. From turkey to the trimmings, Sam Sifton, Melissa Clark, Julia Moskin, Eric Asimov and the editors of The New York Times Food department tell you everything you need to know to plan the menu, prepare the food and serve it all with style and grace.

headline: SABMiller Is Said Near Deal to Sell MillerCoors
abstract: Selling its 58 percent stake in MillerCoors to Molson Coors Brewing Company may be the linchpin for SABMiller’s sale to Anheuser-Busch InBev for about $104 billion.
lead_paragraph: Molson Coors Brewing Company is close to an agreement to buy the rest of MillerCoors from SABMiller, a person briefed on the deal said.

lead_paragraph: Pat Eddery, one of the greatest jockeys of the postwar era, with three victories in the Epsom Derby and four in the Arc de Triomphe to his credit, as well as two Breeders’ Cup races in the United States, died on Tuesday. He was 63.

headline: Torn Asunder in 1943 Battle, Twins Are Reunited Under Florida Soil
abstract: During World War II, the Reilly brothers, who grew up in Queens, were part of a unit that stormed the small Japanese-held island called Tarawa Atoll. It would be their last hour together.
lead_paragraph: James P. Reilly and Michael J. Reilly, fraternal twins born on Nov. 9, 1923, remained close throughout their abbreviated life together. As allies and co-conspirators, they were always within each other’s orbit, attending the same public schools in Queens, playing sports together and jointly enlisting in the Marines.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel made a direct appeal on Tuesday to Democrats still troubled by the public feud over the nuclear deal with Iran, appearing at a leading liberal think tank aligned with President Obama to declare that support for his country in the United States must remain a bipartisan proposition.

headline: Los Angeles Police Urged to Review Use of Force After ‘Alarming’ Rise in Shootings
abstract: The number of shootings by the police so far this year has nearly doubled, prompting the call from the civilian board that oversees the force.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Citing an “alarming” rise in shootings by police over the last year, the civilian board that oversees the Los Angeles police called on Tuesday for an extensive review of the department’s policies on the use of force.

headline: René Girard, French Theorist of the Social Sciences, Dies at 91

lead_paragraph: René Girard, whose explorations of literature and myth helped establish influential theories about how people are motivated to want things, died on Nov. 4 at his home in Stanford, Calif. He was 91.

headline: Kevin Durant Is Mr. Popular in an Opponent’s Town

Durant wore a camouflage jacket (which did little good) and large headphones that he had draped around his neck.

lead_paragraph: The West Virginia Supreme Court said Tuesday that a man could withdraw a guilty plea he made in 2002 for a robbery and rape because prosecutors had withheld DNA testing results suggesting that he was probably innocent.

lead_paragraph: RAYMUN, Jordan — He was a fierce Jordanian nationalist, following his father and uncles into the military from this village loyal to King Abdullah II. He was also a deeply conservative Muslim, at the mosque most days by 3 a.m. to lead the first and most challenging of the five daily prayers.

headline: Old Rush Participants
abstract: In which the oddness of a David Steinberg puzzle is embraced.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — This one by David Steinberg kept its secrets from me for the longest time and it was worth it. I say this because it’s very easy to put your nose up in the air and critique a puzzle that has … let’s just call it “odd” fill and cluing, shall we? … but it’s a downright hoot when you find out toward the end of the solve that the oddness was deliberate and to a purpose.

headline: Fatal Crash in a Brooklyn Creek, Seen Only on Camera

lead_paragraph: The car traveling at high speed down Gerritsen Avenue in Brooklyn early Monday morning smashed through a wood construction fence, through a yard and into thin air. It crashed into the water of Shell Bank Creek, by the Belt Parkway, and sank.

headline: ‘Scream Queens’ Season 1, Episode 8: Snuffed Out
abstract: Another one bites the dust.
lead_paragraph: You knew she had to go sooner or later – she was that kind of character; not fringe, but not really major either – and on Tuesday night’s “Scream Queens” the chapter’s candle blogger was, as it were, snuffed out. She was never given much to do in the show, but I’ll miss her waxy obsessiveness anyway.

headline: In Republican Debate, Candidates Battle Sharply on Immigration
abstract: Gov. John Kasich of Ohio and former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida tried to gain political momentum by heaping scorn on Donald J. Trump’s plan to deport unauthorized immigrants.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — After weeks of personal sniping, the Republican presidential candidates clashed sharply over immigration and other policies in their debate here on Tuesday, with Gov. John Kasich of Ohio and former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida trying to energize their campaigns by heaping scorn on Donald J. Trump’s plan to deport unauthorized immigrants.

headline: Canada: Montreal to Dump Sewage Into River During Repair Work
abstract: The mayor said the city would dump about 2.1 billion gallons of raw sewage into the St. Lawrence River.
lead_paragraph: The mayor of Montreal, Denis Coderre, said Tuesday that the city would begin dumping about 2.1 billion gallons of raw sewage into the St. Lawrence River early Wednesday. The diversion, which may continue for up to seven days, will allow workers to repair and alter a major collector sewer. “If we could have avoided this choice, we would have done it,” Mr. Coderre told reporters. After initially approving the city’s plan, the former Conservative federal government banned the city from diverting the sewage in the midst of the recent election campaign. The Conservatives were routed by the Liberal Party last month. The new Liberal government said Monday that the diversion could go ahead, provided that the city addressed concerns raised by a panel of scientists. That review found that while dumping the sewage was not ideal, it was preferable to the potential consequences of a sewer failure.

headline: Fox Business Network’s Debate Is a Step Up, in Some Ways

headline: A Criminal Record and a Fair Shot at a Job
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Law and Legislation', 'Ex-Convicts']
abstract: An arrest should not be a life sentence of joblessness. Ban the box to lower rates of recidivism, and give Americans the fresh start they need.
lead_paragraph: Nineteen states and 100 cities and counties forbid public agencies — and in some cases, private businesses — to ask job applicants about criminal convictions until later in the application process, when they have had a fair chance to prove their qualifications. Last week, President Obama added the weight of the federal government to this movement when he ordered federal agencies to stop asking most people about convictions at the outset.

headline: The Misuse of Interpol’s Database
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Fugitives', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing']
abstract: Stronger safeguards are needed to prevent governments from using the agency’s list of fugitives to persecute dissidents.
lead_paragraph: Fugitive alerts issued by Interpol, the international law enforcement clearinghouse, can make it hard for fugitives to slip across borders. But the group’s “red notice” database, which can be reviewed by authorities across the world to identify people facing prosecution, is frequently used by authoritarian governments to control and persecute dissidents, human rights activists and journalists.

headline: Voters, You Can Have Everything!
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: There’s no end to the promises of the presidential candidates.
lead_paragraph: I confess, as much as I am troubled by Donald Trump’s anti-immigrant, anti-free-trade tirades, I do find The Donald’s campaign strategy truly interesting. He’s not, as people say, an “anti-politician.” He’s actually caricaturing politicians. And like any great caricaturist, Trump identifies his subject’s most salient features and then exaggerates them.

headline: How Much Do Black Lives Matter to the Presidential Campaign?
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'School Discipline (Students)']
abstract: The argument between Democrats and Republicans over law and disorder is a crucial dividing line.
lead_paragraph: The onslaught of confrontations between blacks and the police, as well as intense coverage on TV and online of college campus protests and of the Black Lives Matter movement, have decisively affected the Democratic Party’s position on a core issue: the use of force to maintain public order.

headline: Hope and a Laptop for College
abstract: The Neediest Cases Fund helps a young college-bound mother.
lead_paragraph: Someday, Jada Williams hopes to become a veterinarian. “I’ve always loved animals,” she said. “They always seem to make me happy.” But the path toward attaining that goal has not been an easy one.

headline: Obama Should Let Fossil Fuels Lie
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Federal Lands', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Keystone Pipeline System', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']
abstract: The president can act to stop new extraction on our public lands without the approval of Congress.
lead_paragraph: PRESIDENT OBAMA’S rejection of the proposed Keystone XL pipeline last week had the ring of a great victory for the environment. But even as he declared the United States a “global leader” in the transition to cleaner energy, he revealed a challenge that neither he nor his administration has confronted: “If we’re going to prevent large parts of this earth from becoming not only inhospitable but uninhabitable in our lifetimes,” the president said, “we’re going to have to keep some fossil fuels in the ground, rather than burn them and release more dangerous pollution into the sky.”
