headline: Saying Goodbye to Seattle’s Gum Wall
abstract: After accumulating for 20 years in a deeply encrusted display, about 2,200 pounds of gum is being removed from the gum wall near Pike Place Market in Seattle.
lead_paragraph: After accumulating for 20 years in a deeply encrusted display, about 2,200 pounds of gum is being removed from the gum wall near Pike Place Market in Seattle.

headline: Saying Goodbye a Little Longer as Seattle Scrapes Off Its Gum Wall
abstract: About 2,200 pounds of gum, chewed and stuck to a brick wall near Pike Place Market, captivates and repulses visitors, but it has also endangered the wall itself.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — William Ward sells a lot of gum. He works at a newspaper stand just around the corner from a bizarre attraction called the gum wall near Pike Place Market just off the waterfront here, and people show up unprepared. He also sells a lot of hand sanitizer.

headline: Even Famous Female Economists Get No Respect
abstract: A look at the disparate treatment of economics power couples suggests that gender bias is alive and well.
lead_paragraph: Men’s voices tend to dominate economic debate, although perhaps this is shaped by how we talk about the contributions of female economists. This is easiest to see in how we discuss the work of economist power couples.

headline: Share Your Story
abstract: We invite you to share your experiences ​confronting issues of race in your life.
lead_paragraph: We invite you to share your experiences ​confronting issues of race in your life.

headline: ‘A Conversation With Police on Race’
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Police', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination']
abstract: In this short documentary, former officers share their thoughts on policing and race in America.
lead_paragraph: Over the past year or so, our nation has been embroiled in a difficult conversation about our history of police brutality and racial profiling. Stories of young black men shot by officers, and footage of police behavior before many of those deaths, have raised hard questions about institutional racism and misconduct within our police force. They have sparked protests, investigations and policy changes.

headline: A City Choking on Cars Hopes Commuters Will Return to Two Wheels
abstract: Facing pollution and traffic concerns, Beijing is proposing steps to encourage bicycling, re-embracing what has long been an integral part of China’s culture.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In the early morning haze, Sun Jian pedaled his bicycle along a bustling ring road in Beijing, dodging buses and cars as he weaved his way through multiple lines of traffic.

headline: Drinking In the Beauty of Picasso’s Sculptures at MoMA
abstract: How conservators pieced together a once-in-a-lifetime show.
lead_paragraph: At the moment, Lynda Zycherman, the Museum of Modern Art’s sculpture conservator, is in her element. She’s supervising what might be called the care and feeding of the 120 objects in the Modern’s extraordinary “Picasso Sculpture,” an array that traces the artist’s breathtaking inventiveness in bronze, wood, clay, plaster, sheet metal and stones through six decades.

headline: Both Parties Have Equal Chance to Win White House
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Though the two parties face radically different nomination battles, the presidential race should be a tossup between the Democrats and Republicans.
lead_paragraph: It’s a mismatch — and an even match.

headline: A Five-Bedroom House in a Cotswold Cottage Style in Victoria
abstract: With mountain and sea views from its back deck, the home is on the market for $1.291 million.
lead_paragraph: With mountain and sea views from its back deck, the home is on the market for $1.291 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... British Columbia
abstract: Victoria, a city of roughly 80,000 in a greater metropolitan area of about 345,000 on Vancouver Island, has had a robust single-family housing market in the last several years.
lead_paragraph: A COTSWOLD COTTAGE-STYLE HOME IN VICTORIA, BRITISH COLUMBIA

headline: App Smart | Apple TV Apps
abstract: New devices for the televisionlike Apple TV can now run apps, including shopping apps like Gilt and games like Asphalt 8.
lead_paragraph: New devices for the televisionlike Apple TV can now run apps, including shopping apps like Gilt and games like Asphalt 8.

headline: Video Feature: Playing to the Strengths of the New Apple TV
keywords: ['Television Sets and Media Devices', 'Mobile Applications', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Television']
abstract: Gaming, shopping, video and utility apps that have the potential to make your television truly “smart.”
lead_paragraph: The new Apple TV has been out for only about two weeks, but there are already hundreds of apps available for downloading to the set-top box. The apps have the potential to make your television truly “smart,” so it’s time to experiment with the best gaming, shopping, video and utility apps and see how they transform the set in your living room.

headline: Airbnb Pledges to Work With Cities and Pay ‘Fair Share’ of Taxes
abstract: After helping defeat Proposition F in San Francisco, which would have limited the home-sharing service, the company has pledged to cooperate with local governments.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A week ago, Airbnb  fired off a warning shot to cities that it would fight back if municipal officials proposed rules that might curtail its home-sharing service.

headline: A Software Firm That Wines and Dines the Restaurant Industry
abstract: The start-up Dine Market initially faced an uphill fight convincing restaurateurs its app could save them thousands of dollars on food and supplies.
lead_paragraph: Celebrity chefs and other food maestros who oversee four- and five-star restaurants are a discerning and confident lot who typically don’t like anyone outside interfering with — let alone offering advice on — how they buy ingredients for their menus.

headline: A Typical American Life, a Very American Death
keywords: ['Dating and Relationships', 'Gun Control', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Raluca Iosif moved to my neighborhood from Romania harboring dreams of a typical American life; instead, she was shot to death by her ex-boyfriend.
lead_paragraph: Last month, after working a long shift at the hospital, I walked to a restaurant in my neighborhood to have dinner with a male friend. The weather was unseasonably warm, so we ate outside. As we sat talking, our conversation was interrupted by something that sounded like a car backfiring. We paused, made a joke about the crowd at the nearby grocery store, and continued our meal. On my walk home, I didn’t notice the flashing lights at the end of my street.

headline: 1940: Czechs and Poles Drop Feuds
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Two governments-in-exile pledge co-operation against Germany in 1940.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Laying the groundwork for a possible new order in central Europe, the Polish government and the provisional government of Czecho-Slovakia buried their past quarrels and jointly declared today [Nov. 11] their intention at the end of the war to enter into a closer economic and political association. The two governments-in-exile expressed the hope that they would be joined by other countries in the same part of Europe, and that free people throughout the world would help their cause by combating the German menace to the full extent of their power. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 12, 1940

headline: Ranking George Washington, the General
abstract: On this Veterans Day, we look back at how the nation’s first president became the highest-ranking military officer in American history.
lead_paragraph: The 1918 truce that halted fighting in World War I went into effect at the 11th hour of the 11th day of the 11th month. Today, that is commemorated in the U.S. as Veterans Day.

headline: They’re With the Band
abstract: A book by the photographer Baron Wolman shows the playful energy and style of the classic groupies of the late 1960s.
lead_paragraph: A book by the photographer Baron Wolman shows the playful energy and style of the classic groupies of the late 1960s.

headline: Ex-Allies of Christie Didn’t Receive Evidence in Lane Closings Case, Lawyers Say
abstract: The lawyers filed complaints to the United States District Court in Newark in response to the May indictments of Bill Baroni and Bridget Anne Kelly.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for two former allies of Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey have complained to a federal court that prosecutors and the governor’s lawyers had not provided emails and other documents related to the scheme to snarl traffic at the entrance to the George Washington Bridge in Fort Lee.

headline: Rankings Indicate Big 12 Could Miss College Football Playoff Again
abstract: With four playoff spots and five power conferences, at least one is going to be left out each year.
lead_paragraph: With the release of the season’s second college football playoff rankings, the pecking order at the top continues to clarify. If No. 1 Clemson wins the Atlantic Coast Conference, No. 2 Alabama the Southeastern Conference and No. 3 Ohio State the Big Ten, and if No. 4 Notre Dame wins the rest of its independent schedule, they are likely to be the four teams in the playoff.

headline: ‘Incident at Vichy,’ a Revival of Arthur Miller’s Harrowing Wartime Drama
abstract: This play at the Signature Theater centers on a group of mostly Jewish detainees in Vichy France who struggle with denial, choices and fundamental questions of identity.
lead_paragraph: Guilt is as inescapable as oxygen in the works of Arthur Miller, whose centennial is being celebrated this season with a formidable assortment of revivals, including Broadway productions of “A View From the Bridge” and “The Crucible.” But seldom did he dissect the nature of moral responsibility as rigorously as he did is in his lesser-known “Incident at Vichy” (1964), which opens Sunday, Nov. 15, in a Signature Theater production. Set in France during World War II, the play centers on a group of male detainees, most of them Jewish, who have been rounded up by German and French officers for interrogation. As the men try to figure out why they have been brought together, their conversation widens to embrace the most fundamental questions of identity, both ethnic and ethical. Michael Wilson (“The Orphans’ Home Cycle”) directs a cast that includes Richard Thomas and Jonathan Hadary. (Through Dec. 13, Pershing Square Signature Center, Manhattan; 212-244-7529, signaturetheater.org.)

headline: Macy’s Lowers Its Guidance on Sales Slump
abstract: The retailer said it would have to mark down inventory to make way for new styles, which could put pressure on other chains to follow.
lead_paragraph: A slump in tourist spending and warmer weather hit Macy’s business in the third quarter, driving sales lower and prompting the department store chain to lower its guidance for the year.

headline: Jean Butler Brings Her Irish Dance to St. Mark’s Church
abstract: Ms. Butler, a creator of “Riverdance,” performs with the cellist Neil Martin.
lead_paragraph: This tale of two Irish dance stars began with a six-minute performance at the Eurovision Song Contest in Dublin in 1994. They were the central couple backed up by a rousing ensemble: Jean Butler, a poised redhead, and Michael Flatley, a flamboyant blond in a shiny teal blouse who would later become the self-proclaimed Lord of the Dance. Together, they created and starred in “Riverdance,” the international megahit spawned by that TV appearance.

headline: At University of Missouri, Black Students See a Campus Riven by Race
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination', 'Cyberharassment', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Many black students say that racial tensions were already woven into the fabric of everyday life at the University of Missouri, well before the recent cascade of events.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, Mo. — At first, Briana Gray just chalked up the comments and questions from her new roommate at the University of Missouri to innocent ignorance: How do you style your hair? What do you put in it?

headline: A Philharmonic Menu of Young Composers
abstract: Performing at the fashionable National Sawdust space, the orchestra will take up works by Kate Soper, Adam Schoenberg and more.
lead_paragraph: American composers 40 and under are the focus of the New York Philharmonic’s latest Contact! new-music concert, on Monday, Nov. 16. The first Contact! to be hosted at the recently opened performance space National Sawdust, in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, the event features chamber works by Kate Soper, Adam Schoenberg, Nathan Heidelberger and Caroline Mallonée. Mario Davidovsky, born in Argentina but a resident of the United States for the past half-century, represents an older generation with his sextet “Flashbacks.” (7:30 p.m., 80 North Sixth Street, 646-779-8455, nationalsawdust.org.)

headline: ‘The Art of More,’ on Crackle, Reveals the Ugly Side of Pretty Things
abstract: This scripted series, available for streaming on Nov. 19, traces the underbelly of the art world.
lead_paragraph: Sex, blood, dirty money. “Smuggled, stolen and forged art is a $10 billion business,” intones a voice more Bensonhurst than Beekman Place. “The big collectors are more than willing to look the other way.” That’s where Graham Connor (Christian Cooke) — a former soldier in Iraq turned antiquities thief who has maneuvered his way into a top Manhattan auction house — comes in. “I get them to look my way,” he says in “The Art of More,” a new series streaming Thursday, Nov. 19, on Crackle.

headline: In ‘Fat City,’ Boxing Has a Starring Role
abstract: This restored 1972 film features Jeff Bridges and Stacy Keach as boxers at different points in their careers.
lead_paragraph: Another “Rocky” movie, this one called “Creed,” is just days away from release, but before the manipulative hero-making of that franchise, there was John Huston’s “Fat City,” a whole different kind of boxing movie. A new restoration of it begins a one-week run on Friday, Nov. 20, at Film Forum, and Leonard Gardner, who wrote both the screenplay and the novel it was based on, is scheduled to be on hand at the opening night showing at 7 to introduce this 1972 movie. The film was an early showcase for Stacy Keach and Jeff Bridges, Mr. Bridges playing a young boxer just starting out, Mr. Keach a somewhat older one who tries a comeback. In his review in The New York Times, Vincent Canby had high praise for the acting and for the script, “full of the kind of dialogue that movies usually can’t afford, that defines time, place, mood and character while seemingly going nowhere.” (At 209 West Houston Street, South Village; 212-727-8110, filmforum.org.)

headline: Living In Easton, Conn.
abstract: Easton is home to at least 20 farms of varying sizes, from part-time specialty operations to large-scale agritourism attractions.
lead_paragraph: Easton is home to at least 20 farms of varying sizes, from part-time specialty operations to large-scale agritourism attractions.

headline: Easton, Conn.: Embracing a Farming Culture
abstract: The Fairfield County suburb is home to at least 20 farms of varying sizes, from part-time specialty operations to large-scale agritourism attractions.
lead_paragraph: Patti and Allan Popp didn’t move to the rural town of Easton, Conn., to take up farming. They were simply searching for more privacy than they had at their previous home in Stratford. Ms. Popp happened to fall in love with a 1740 house in foreclosure along one of Easton’s main routes, Sport Hill Road.

headline: Coltrane’s ‘A Love Supreme,’ Rereleased and Celebrated at Lincoln Center
abstract: For that worshiped album’s 50th-anniversary celebration, a complete masters version is due out Nov. 20. And the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra will perform its arrangement of the suite.
lead_paragraph: The saxophonist John Coltrane released his most revered album, “A Love Supreme,” on the Impulse! label in 1965, and from the start it was understood as something special: a four-part suite that drew Coltrane’s magnificent quartet into deep, devotional focus. The album has been reissued in a deluxe edition before, but a boxed set due out on Friday, Nov. 20, “A Love Supreme: The Complete Masters,” offers the deepest dive yet, with alternate takes, studio chatter, photo reproductions and a new essay by Ashley Kahn, who once wrote a book on the subject.

headline: Coney Island Culture, at the Brooklyn Museum
abstract: The exhibit “Coney Island: Visions of an American Dreamland, 1861-2008” presents works from artists like Diane Arbus and Joseph Stella.
lead_paragraph: It is a microcosm of American popular culture in all its ersatz glory, the anti-Disneyland, a realm of tawdry spectacle and mindless distraction catering to the basic instincts of hoi polloi. It is, of course, Coney Island, whose history and culture are chronicled in “Coney Island: Visions of an American Dreamland, 1861-2008,” opening Friday, Nov. 20, at the Brooklyn Museum.

headline: Le1f Speaks Out, Like His Fearless Models, on ‘Riot Boi’
abstract: The rapper talks about a range of influences he drew on — Amanda Blank, M.I.A., Dev Hynes and others — in addressing misogyny, homophobia and more in his first full-length album.
lead_paragraph: On his first full-length album, “Riot Boi,” the New York rapper Le1f is playful, painfully clever, aloof, outraged and deadly serious, often in the span of a few lines. “Rats and roaches running all over the hood in the daytime,” he begins on Track 1, “but I still don’t see none of that in their raps, their rhymes or their headlines.” Topical issues covered across the 12 songs include homophobia, misogyny, transgender rights and Black Lives Matter. “You just wanna ignore it all, don’t you?” Le1f scoffs. “Basic.”

headline: Empathy Card Contest: And the Winner Is . . .
abstract: Hundreds of Well readers helped us come up with the right thing to say to a friend in a need.
lead_paragraph: Last week, we introduced Well readers to Emily McDowell, a writer and graphic artist, and her line of empathy cards, a series of greeting cards that helps provide support during times of serious illness and loss.

headline: Is Fat Stigma Making Us Miserable?
abstract: The teasing, judgment and unsolicited advice directed at overweight people may cause the greatest psychological harm.
lead_paragraph: Being overweight doesn’t necessarily make a person distraught, researchers are learning. Rather, it’s the teasing, judgment and unsolicited advice directed at overweight people that can cause the greatest psychological harm.

headline: Facebook’s Notify App Funnels Custom Updates Onto Phone Screens
abstract: Facebook is introducing a new iPhone app that lets users sign up for custom notifications from a selection of about 70 news outlets and information providers.
lead_paragraph: In this age of data overload, information providers and social networks are competing to provide just the highlights that you want, when you want them. News outlets send alerts with breaking news and editors’ picks of top stories. Twitter curates top tweets, organized by subject, into collections it calls Moments. Weather apps warn you of rain minutes before the droplets arrive.

headline: There’s ‘Kung Fu,’ and, in ‘Into the Badlands,’ There’s Hong Kong Kung Fu
abstract: The AMC show’s creators talk about the difficulties of making a martial arts series for American TV, and the ghost of David Carradine’s “Kung Fu.”
lead_paragraph: WEST HOLLYWOOD, CALIF. — In AMC’s new martial arts series, “Into the Badlands,” Daniel Wu plays Sunny, a motorcycle-riding, katana-wielding assassin whose loyalty to his flinty-eyed master is matched only by his prodigious kill count (400 and climbing).

headline: Lauren Pritchard on Her Musical Childhood and Her New Show, ‘Songbird’
abstract: This singer-songwriter is also touring for a recent EP, “Comeback Queen.”
lead_paragraph: One grandfather played ukulele at family gatherings while she was growing up in Jackson, Tenn., and the other was a Hank Williams fan, so perhaps it’s unsurprising that Lauren Pritchard was evolving as a singer-songwriter before she was 10.

headline: Podcast: Beware Fine Print
abstract: Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Michael Corkery share insight into their report on arbitration and the way it circumvents justice for millions of Americans.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Michael Corkery share insight into their report on arbitration and the way it circumvents justice for millions of Americans.

headline: A Lesson in Journalism at the University of Missouri
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: A veteran journalist decries an ugly moment in the protests at the University of Missouri.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: 1965: Rhodesia Claims Independence
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Rhodesia declares independence from British rule in 1965.
lead_paragraph: SALISBURY — Rhodesia today [Nov. 11] declared its independence in the most momentous defiance of Britain since America threw off colonial rule nearly 200 years ago. The white-ruled colony in the heart of Africa immediately found itself outlawed in a largely hostile world. Britain imposed economic sanctions and called for a meeting of the United Nations Security Council to recruit world-wide support. In Pretoria, South African Premier Dr. Hendrik Verwoerd declared that his country would continue normal relations with Rhodesia, thus becoming the first government to recognize the ‘‘rebel’’ nation. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 12, 1965

headline: Great Midweek Recipes
abstract: Delicious recipes for dinner tonight, for celebrating Diwali and for your Thanksgiving feast.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. Beginning today, that email will also appear on nytimes.com. To receive the email, register here.

headline: Another Setback for Immigration Action
keywords: ['Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals', 'Deportation', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Immigration Detention', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama’s effort to overhaul the immigration system has lost in court again.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s effort to overhaul the immigration system through executive action has lost in court again. On Monday a federal appeals-court panel, in a 2-1 vote, blocked the administration from moving forward with programs to shield up to 5 million people from deportation.

headline: Review: In ‘The Bachelors,’ Three Men Are Mired in Frat-Boy Misogyny
abstract: Caroline V. McGraw’s dark comedy is set in a former fraternity house whose denizens work for a living but otherwise behave in disconcerting ways.
lead_paragraph: It’s Friday night on fraternity row in the unnamed college town of Caroline V. McGraw’s “The Bachelors.” But by the end of this unlikely comedy, presented by Lesser America and Rattlestick Playwrights Theater, no one feels much like a party.

headline: Cruz vs. Rubio: The Overture
keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: How last night’s Republican debate laid the groundwork for clashes yet to come.
lead_paragraph: The most interesting story out of last night’s Republican debate is probably the one written up by McKay Coppins here: In several different moments we watched a preview of the way that Ted Cruz intends to go after Marco Rubio if and when the field begins to winnow and the two of them rise toward the top. Coppins cites a couple of Cruz lines on immigration and sugar subsidies that were clearly implied digs at Rubio; I would add Cruz’s stress on how his own tax and spending plan adds up (it doesn’t, really, but compared to Rubio’s it does) and his attempt to position himself in between Rubio and Paul when the two clashed on foreign policy. Add them all together and you have a clear blueprint for an anti-Rubio offensive: Attack sharply on immigration, find his Floridian weakness on corporate welfare, claim the mantle of fiscal hawkishness at home and cast Rubio as a little too Wilsonian abroad.

headline: New Marco Rubio Backer Bankrolls Ad and Writes It, Too
abstract: In the ad from Baby Got Pac, a “super PAC” supporting Marco Rubio, a narrator cites statements from Democrats in which they have openly fretted about the Republican Florida senator’s candidacy.
lead_paragraph: Senator Marco Rubio’s newest financial backer not only bankrolls his own super PAC, but also writes its TV ads.

headline: Unicredit of Italy to Cut 18,200 Jobs as Part of Overhaul
abstract: UniCredit is the latest European lender to announce a major reorganization as banks face slow growth and strict regulatory requirements.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — UniCredit, Italy’s largest bank by assets, said on Wednesday that it would eliminate up to 18,200 jobs and accelerate its cost-cutting over the next three years as part of a revamping of its operations that it hopes will help it avoid the need for a capital increase.

headline: Weighing Benefits of Windows 10 Upgrade
keywords: ['Android (Operating System)', 'Windows (Operating System)', 'iPhone', 'Text Messaging', 'iPad', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: A look at how the new features in Microsoft’s latest operating system compare with version 8.1, and what to do if you’re getting text messages on your iPad but not your iPhone.
lead_paragraph: Q. Should I update to Windows 10 now that I’ve gotten used to Windows 8.1? How big a change is it?

headline: What It Takes to Save a Mockingjay
abstract: “The Hunger Games” roars to its conclusion next Friday with “Mockingjay Part 2.” But the franchise has faced setbacks all along. Here’s an inside look.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The pressure is on. The endgame is near. There will be blood, brutality, death and scary lizard mutants smashing through a sewer. The final film installment of Suzanne Collins’s best-selling trilogy, “The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 2,” will reach American screens on Friday, Nov. 20, and millions of fans worldwide will scrutinize the movie for its fidelity to the books; the portrayal (by Jennifer Lawrence) of its intrepid, taciturn heroine Katniss Everdeen; and its evocation of the civil war that rends Panem, the totalitarian state built from the ashes of North America at some unspecified time in the future.

headline: 10 Years With Times Video
abstract: Erik Olsen, senior video journalist, talks about a decade of filmmaking with The Times.
lead_paragraph: Erik Olsen, senior video journalist, talks about a decade of filmmaking with The Times.

headline: Stephen Colbert to Follow 2016 Super Bowl
abstract: CBS announced on Wednesday that a live episode of Mr. Colbert’s “The Late Show” would run after Super Bowl 50 on Feb. 7, 2016.
lead_paragraph: CBS is handing the coveted post-Super Bowl programming block to its newest late-night host, Stephen Colbert.

headline: Bottles Upon Bottles of Wine at Heights Chateau
abstract: The wine shop on a stretch between Brooklyn Heights and Cobble Hill is an oenophile’s apothecary.
lead_paragraph: The wine shop on a stretch between Brooklyn Heights and Cobble Hill is an oenophile’s apothecary.

headline: At Heights Chateau, a Welcoming Home for Wine Lovers
abstract: When it opened in 1986, its stretch of Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn Heights was known for dive bars, but the wine shop slowly built a relationship with local residents.
lead_paragraph: On a recent brisk Saturday afternoon, at the point where the tail of Atlantic Avenue dips toward New York Harbor, wine and spirits buyers ducked into Heights Chateau to assemble their weekend libations. Behind an antique-looking facade, the store is an oenophile’s apothecary.

headline: At Paradise Cove, Where Less is More
abstract: America’s most glamorous trailer park, Paradise Cove in Malibu, has million-dollar views, hip residents and a location on one of the world’s most iconic beaches.
lead_paragraph: America’s most glamorous trailer park, Paradise Cove in Malibu, has million-dollar views, hip residents and a location on one of the world’s most iconic beaches.

headline: Justin Bieber Announces 58-Date ‘Purpose’ Tour
abstract: The singer’s all-grown-up album, “Purpose,” comes out on Friday, and he’ll kick off a North American tour in March in Seattle.
lead_paragraph: Justin Bieber’s all-grown-up album, “Purpose,” comes out on Friday, and all the final pieces are falling into place for his meticulously crafted, apology-filled comeback. After a steady stream of convincing singles, including “Where Are Ü Now,” made with Diplo and Skrillex, and “What Do You Mean?”, Mr. Bieber’s first No. 1 on the Billboard Hot 100, he has announced a 58-date North American tour for 2016, promoted by AEG Live.

headline: America’s Most Glamorous Trailer Park
keywords: ['Mobile Homes and Trailers', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: In Malibu, Paradise Cove has million-dollar views, hip residents and a location on one of the world’s most iconic beaches.
lead_paragraph: In 1979, David Carter, then a 30-year-old surfer, decided to move from Maui, where he’d spent a few years chasing waves and making surfboards, to Southern California. He and his wife were in search of that real estate oxymoron: an affordable place close to the ocean where they could raise their two sons. On the advice of friends, they went to visit a curious little subdivision called Paradise Cove, a private waterfront community of 265 trailers in Malibu.

headline: Steelers’ Antonio Brown Has Been Only as Good as His Quarterback
abstract: Brown, whose numbers with Ben Roethlisberger are much better than with Michael Vick, is not the only star receiver to be impacted by poor quarterback play.
lead_paragraph: N.F.L. wide receivers are some of the most athletic people on the planet. Speed, leaping ability and the ability to change directions quickly are hallmarks of the position.

headline: Silicon Valley Tries to Alter Your Perception of Cannabis
abstract: As marijuana laws are being loosened across the country, start-ups are using technology to transform what has traditionally been a face-to-face market.
lead_paragraph: One morning in September, I logged on to the website of HelloMD, a medical start-up that promises to connect patients with doctors instantly over the Internet. I filled out my personal details, explained my ailment — I often get heartburn — and entered in my credit card number to cover the $50 consultation fee.

headline: Podcast: Beware the Fine Print
abstract: Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Michael Corkery share insight into their report on arbitration and the way it circumvents justice for millions of Americans.
lead_paragraph: Arbitration clauses. They sound innocuous enough. But, in a three part-series about clauses buried in tens of millions of contracts, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Michael Corkery (along with another reporter, Robert Gebeloff) reported on the way these clauses have deprived Americans of one of their most fundamental constitutional rights: their day in court.

headline: Daily Report: Breezes Could Become Headwinds in Silicon Valley
abstract: Despite strong earnings by big tech players, some smaller start-ups are starting to worry, and make cutbacks, as valuations of hot companies shrink.
lead_paragraph: For months now, the scorching tech industry has shown signs of feeling a slight breeze. As early as September, for example, Nicole Perlroth reported that some security start-ups, used to easily raising new money, were being asked something almost novel: Where are the profits?

headline: Bridget Anne Kelly Court Filings
abstract: Lawyers for Bridget Anne Kelly filed discovery motions.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Bridget Anne Kelly filed discovery motions.

headline: Bill Baroni Court Filings
abstract: Lawyers for Bill Baroni filed motions seeking evidence and a change of venue.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Bill Baroni filed motions seeking evidence and a change of venue.

headline: The Victoria’s Secret Fashion Show
abstract: Top models, such as Gigi Hadid and Kendall Jenner, donned feathers and jewels on the runway at the Victoria’s Secret fashion show.
lead_paragraph: Top models, such as Gigi Hadid and Kendall Jenner, donned feathers and jewels on the runway at the Victoria’s Secret fashion show.

headline: Borrowing From Solar and Chip Tech to Make Diamonds Faster and Cheaper
abstract: A group of engineers and scientists will announce that it has developed an approach to making diamonds that uses technology derived in part from making silicon chips and solar cells.
lead_paragraph: Just a decade ago, Silicon Valley had high hopes of becoming a vibrant manufacturing center by making solar panels. But price competition from abroad, particularly from China, quickly dashed those dreams.

headline: In the Studio With Marques’Almeida
abstract: T visits Portuguese design duo Marta Marques and Paulo Almeida at work in Hackney, London.
lead_paragraph: T visits Portuguese design duo Marta Marques and Paulo Almeida at work in Hackney, London.

headline: Review: Michael Flatley’s New Show Has Unicorns, Rainbows and Some Footwork, Too
abstract: “Lord of the Dance: Dangerous Games” is your last chance to watch Mr. Flatley dancing. And with him, you’ll get flames, fog-banks and explosions.
lead_paragraph: The main reason to see Michael Flatley’s “Lord of the Dance: Dangerous Games,” which opened on Tuesday at the Lyric Theater, is to watch Michael Flatley dancing. It’s your last chance. This Irish-American step-dancing star, now 57, has announced that he will retire from performing at the end of this eight-week run. The trouble is, to see Michael Flatley dancing, you have sit through a Michael Flatley show.

headline: A Debate With Bernanke Over the Fed’s Easy Money Policies
abstract: The Federal Reserve’s decisions may have inflated the price of financial assets, but Ben Bernanke says they kept a bad financial situation from getting worse.
lead_paragraph: By the end of our recent conversation, Ben S. Bernanke, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve, and I had a gentleman’s bet. I believe the easy money policies he pushed for and put in place while serving as Fed chairman starting in 2008 (and that remain in place under his successor, Janet L. Yellen) will lead inevitably to a near-term financial crisis; he thinks that idea is beyond ridiculous.

headline: Inside the Denim-Filled Studio of Marques’Almeida
abstract: Since winning the LVMH prize, Marta Marques and Paulo Almeida have focused their energy on growing their brand. T visits them at work in Hackney, London.

headline: 7 on Business Trip Among Dead in Akron Plane Crash
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: Pebb Enterprises, a Florida real estate company, said two of its executives and five other employees had died in the crash, along with two crew members.
lead_paragraph: A Florida company confirmed Wednesday that seven of its employees were on a private jet that crashed into an apartment building in Akron, Ohio, on Tuesday, bringing the death toll to nine.

headline: To Win a Free I.V.F. Cycle, Contestants Share Losses, Grief and Hope. Is it Worth It?
keywords: ['Contests and Prizes', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'In Vitro Fertilization', 'Infertility', 'Parenting']
abstract: Contestants in this contest win by revealing how much they’ve lost.
lead_paragraph: “Please,” the woman says, staring directly into the camera at the end of a video that lays bare her infertility, her attempts, her losses, her hopes, her dreams, her fears. “Vote for me.”

headline: Confrontation Brews as Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio Vie for Conservative Vote
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Crop Controls and Subsidies', 'Debates (Political)']
abstract: Both senators are courting the most conservative voters in subtle but unmistakable ways, and the most glaring difference between them is immigration.
lead_paragraph: After a Republican presidential debate in which sober policy discussions edged out the loud personality clashes that have dominated so far, the campaign’s focus narrowed on Wednesday into a battle for the party’s most conservative voters.

headline: Saks Fifth Avenue
abstract: The landmark store opened in 1924.
lead_paragraph: The landmark store opened in 1924.

headline: Shelley Poem, 200 Years Later, Returns to Oxford
abstract: The poem, written in 1811 by Percy Bysshe Shelley during his first year as an Oxford student, has been acquired by the Bodleian Libraries there and placed on public display.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A poem written by Percy Bysshe Shelley during his first year as an Oxford student has been acquired by the Bodleian Libraries there and placed on public display.

headline: With Los Angeles in Play, Cities and Teams Update N.F.L. on Plans
abstract: Officials from Oakland, San Diego and St. Louis made a case for keeping their teams from moving on Wednesday, the same day Disney’s chief executive joined the Chargers-Raiders’ stadium project.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. season is just past the halfway mark, but team owners are already preparing for the biggest decision of the new year: whether to allow one or two teams to move to Los Angeles in 2016.

headline: Michael Leonard, Whose Songs From Failed Musicals Endured, Dies at 84
abstract: The composer and arranger’s tunes for “The Yearling” were covered by Barbra Streisand, Nancy Wilson and many others.
lead_paragraph: Michael Leonard, a composer and arranger whose songs, especially from the 1965 musical “The Yearling,” lived on as standards for singers like Barbra Streisand and Nancy Wilson, died on Oct. 31 at his home in Manhattan. He was 84.

headline: Republican Debate Draws 13 Million Viewers as Ratings Slip
abstract: The viewership was the most ever for Fox Business Network, with its moderators Neil Cavuto, Maria Bartiromo and Gerard Baker, but less than previous debates in the 2016 presidential race.
lead_paragraph: More than 13 million people tuned in to Fox Business Network to watch the fourth Republican presidential debate on Tuesday night in Milwaukee, according to Nielsen ratings data provided on Wednesday by the business news network.

headline: Waiting for the Republican Shakeout
abstract: Some conservative analysts predict that the G.O.P.’s “somewhat” conservative voters will restore rationality to the overpopulated primary field.
lead_paragraph: Watching Tuesday’s Republican presidential debate, with the eight prime-time contenders talking over and past one another, the question arises: Should the party show a few of these candidates the door?

headline: Goose Barnacle Caters to Its Brooklyn Neighbors
abstract: The store draws men who want to pass the taste muster, but don’t want to draw looks.
lead_paragraph: The other afternoon, a sharp-looking guy opened the door of Goose Barnacle and asked for help. The old-style door — the heavy wooden kind where one side bolts into the ceiling and floor — was only half open, and therefore not wide enough for what he was pushing, which was a stroller.

headline: Why Has Trust in the News Media Declined?
abstract: Why do so many people say they distrust journalists, and what does that mean?

headline: Buffalo Bills at New York Jets: Who Has the Edge?
abstract: Coach Rex Ryan travels to play the Jets, his former team, in a prime-time matchup with playoff implications
lead_paragraph: 8:25 p.m. Eastern, NFL Network

headline: On the Road in Syria, Struggle All Around
abstract: The police are gone, and militias have flourished, snarling traffic with checkpoints.
lead_paragraph: RMEILAN, Syria — After boiling crude oil from the ground near here all day in a metal tank to refine it into diesel, Ali Mohammed braved the fumes to bang the tank’s drain open with a shovel. He stepped back as the dregs oozed into the dirt and burst into flames.

headline: Shia LaBeouf Offers View of Himself Viewing His Movies
abstract: Mr. LaBeouf, an actor known for his erratic behavior, invited the public to watch all 29 of his films with him at the Angelika Film Center in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Shia LaBeouf, an actor whose erratic behavior often veers into the realm of bizarre performance art, has invited us all to watch him watch his movies — all 29 of them, in reverse chronological order.

headline: Amundi Raises $1.6 Billion in I.P.O. in Paris
abstract: The French asset manager was created in 2010 by a merger of the asset management operations of two French banks, Crédit Agricole and Société Générale.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Amundi, one of the largest asset managers in Europe, said on Wednesday that it had raised 1.5 billion euros, or about $1.6 billion, in its initial public offering of stock in Paris.

headline: South Africa Court Sentences 8 Ex-Policemen in Immigrant’s Murder
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: Each was sentenced to 15 years in the death of an immigrant man working as a taxi driver who sustained blunt force injuries in 2013 after being dragged behind a police van and beaten.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A South African judge on Wednesday sentenced eight former police officers to prison for the murder of a taxi driver from Mozambique who was handcuffed to the back of a police van, dragged about a third of a mile and then placed in a police holding cell, where he was beaten.

headline: Philosophers (and Welders) React to Marco Rubio’s Debate Comments
keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Philosophy', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Welding and Welders']
abstract: Philosophers say the discipline prepares them for a range of useful career choices, while welders say their skill is always in demand and touches most parts of the economy.

headline: Effort to Revive City Opera Includes a ‘Tosca’ Staging
abstract: A group plans to mount this Puccini work amid a battle to claim the bankrupt company’s name.
lead_paragraph: If the death of New York City Opera was tragic, attempts to revive it have sometimes entered the farcical territory of opera buffa: a bidding contest for its name that yielded no sale, a legal battle and a skirmish over a bequest from a patron who died just as the company did.

headline: A Landscape of Blooms, in Dorset
abstract: Charlie McCormick takes a modern approach to a traditional English country garden.
lead_paragraph: Charlie McCormick takes a modern approach to a traditional English country garden.

headline: Egyptian President Makes First Visit to Sharm El Sheikh Since Russian Crash
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: An unannounced trip by President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi came as Egypt continued to face criticism in the investigation of the fatal crash of a Russian plane last month.
lead_paragraph: SHARM EL SHEIKH, Egypt — The Egyptian president, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, made an unannounced, and somewhat belated, visit to this seaside town on Wednesday, saying he was here to “reassure people” after a Russian plane that took off from the local airport broke apart in midair over the Sinai Peninsula late last month.

headline: An English Garden for All Seasons
abstract: In Dorset, Charlie McCormick has created an embroidered tapestry of blooms that lasts well into fall.
lead_paragraph: In Dorset, Charlie McCormick has created an embroidered tapestry of blooms that lasts well into fall.

headline: Anheuser-Busch InBev Deal for SABMiller Pays Off for Molson
abstract: By helping ease antitrust pressure on SABMiller’s $106 billion sale to Anheuser-Busch InBev, Molson Coors avoids paying a premium.
lead_paragraph: Molson Coors Brewing is getting a tasty chaser from its rivals’ mega-deal.

headline: Donald Trump’s ‘Deportation Force’
keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'Deportation', 'Foreign Workers', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Immigration Detention', 'Migrant Labor (Agriculture)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Mr. Trump said he could expel unauthorized immigrants because President Eisenhower did it. But it wouldn’t be as simple as he makes it sound.
lead_paragraph: Some of Donald Trump’s rivals mocked him at the Republican presidential debate on Tuesday night for saying he could deport 11 million unauthorized immigrants.

headline: European and African Leaders Near Deal on Returning Migrants
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: The draft deal being hashed out at a summit meeting in Malta was partly aimed at sending more African migrants who do not qualify for asylum back to their homelands.
lead_paragraph: VALLETTA, Malta — The European Union was closing in on a deal Wednesday to return more migrants to Africa, but there was skepticism that the plan would meet the goal of reducing the numbers of refugees arriving in Germany, Scandinavia and other destinations.

headline: Promised Bipartisanship, Obama Adviser Found Disappointment
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Ray LaHood, a Republican who served as transportation secretary, says the president gave up too easily on his promise to reach across the aisle.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama first won the White House, he recruited Ray LaHood, a Republican congressman, to join his cabinet. The appointment, Mr. Obama said, “reflects that bipartisan spirit” that would distinguish his presidency.

headline: Israelis Condemn E.U. Labeling Move
keywords: ['Labeling and Labels (Product)', 'Israeli Settlements', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Palestinians']
abstract: Officials from Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization disagreed on whether the European Union should label goods from Israeli settlements, and a factory manager spoke out against the move.
lead_paragraph: Officials from Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization disagreed on whether the European Union should label goods from Israeli settlements, and a factory manager spoke out against the move.

headline: Expansion of T-Mobile Data Plans Comes With Higher Prices
keywords: ['Cellular Telephones', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: T-Mobile has quietly increased some of its data plan prices even as it offers higher data limits. Some customers may pay less and get more data; others will pay more for more data than they will use.
lead_paragraph: The phone carrier T-Mobile USA made lots of noise this week about allowing many subscribers to stream content from some video services over their cellular connections without burning through their data allotments — so much noise that it was easy to overlook that T-Mobile also raised prices on many of its data plans.

headline: Donald Trump Insists That Wages Are ‘Too High’
abstract: Donald J. Trump on Wednesday morning repeated a statement he made the night before in the Republican presidential debate: that wages are “too high” in the United States, so he opposes raising the minimum wage.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump on Wednesday morning repeated a statement he made the night before in the Republican presidential debate: that wages are “too high” in the United States, an argument he made to explain his opposition to raising the minimum wage.

headline: VW’s Emissions-Test Trickery May Not Be Illegal in Europe
keywords: ['Diesel Power', 'Air Pollution', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Automobiles', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Unlike in the United States, automakers have the discretion to change their engines’ performance settings before emissions tests.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Four years ago, European auto regulators identified and debated a loophole in their pollution testing rules that could render vehicle emissions tests ineffectual, but it was ultimately left in place, internal documents show.

headline: In Iowa, Jeb Bush Tries to Capitalize on Latest Debate Performance
abstract: Campaigning the day after his best debate performance so far, Jeb Bush tried to convey that he had slowed his slide in the polls and even turned momentum in his favor.
lead_paragraph: JOHNSTON, Iowa — It wasn’t quite a victory lap. Call it more of a coffee klatch lap.

headline: Elizabeth, N.J., Explosion Kills One and Injures 15
abstract: Everyone living in the house was accounted for by midafternoon, officials said, and workers were inspecting the building to determine an exact cause.
lead_paragraph: A man in his 20s was killed and 15 people were injured in an explosion at a two-story duplex in Elizabeth, N.J., on Wednesday morning, city officials said. Investigators believe it was related to gas.

headline: The Flat Tax Goes Mainstream
keywords: ['Income Tax', 'Presidential Election of 1996', 'Presidential Election of 2000', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Sales and Excise Taxes', 'Sexual Harassment']
abstract: Among Republican candidates, the once-fringe idea is now downright popular — even though it’s totally unfair.
lead_paragraph: Remember when the flat tax was a fringe idea? Competitors and others derided it when Steve Forbes made it the center of his 1996 presidential campaign. Though Mr. Forbes won the Arizona and Delaware primaries, he did poorly in Iowa and New Hampshire and dropped out of the race in March of that year. He did even worse in 2000, finishing third in the Delaware primary and ending his campaign soon after.

headline: Cuomo Signs 2 Bills to Speed Up Medical Marijuana Distribution
abstract: The measures direct the New York State Health Department to form a program creating an “expedited pathway” to patients whose lack of access to the drug could harm them.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — In a surprising move, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo signed two bills on Wednesday to establish an “emergency medical marijuana” program for qualified patients, two months before the planned debut of a statewide program providing for the medical use of the drug.

headline: Review: ‘W/ Bob & David’ Resumes a ‘Mr. Show’ Vibe
abstract: Bob Odenkirk and David Cross reunite for a Netflix series that picks up where their 1990s program left off.
lead_paragraph: The great television resurrection machine has been busy lately. Fox is bringing back “The X-Files” next year. Showtime is reviving “Twin Peaks.” Netflix brought back “Arrested Development,” is making a sequel to the family comedy “Full House” and is reportedly planning the return of “Gilmore Girls.” Death, for a TV show, is an increasingly temporary state, as long as enough mourners are lighting the candles.

headline: The Modern Princess, On and Off the Runway
abstract: Inspired by young girls’ fantasies (and a hint of irony), designers have begun to think pink.
lead_paragraph: Inspired by young girls’ fantasies (and a hint of irony), designers have begun to think pink.

headline: Review: ‘Aquaria,’ a Dark Debut Album by Boots
abstract: Boots, a.k.a. Jordy Asher, is a songwriter, singer, rapper, instrumentalist and producer known for his work with Beyoncé and FKA twigs.
lead_paragraph: “Aquaria”

headline: When a Child’s Project Shows a Parental Hand at Work
abstract: It’s become an act of parental dereliction to let a child turn in a project that looks like a child’s work.
lead_paragraph: When my younger son, Finn, was in third grade, his class staged a wax museum as the culmination of a biography project. Each student researched a historical figure they admired, prepared a monologue about that person’s life and historical significance, and on the day of the wax museum presentation, dressed up like their chosen hero. As no academic project is complete without the requisite trifold poster, each student also had to create an illustrated, informative display.

headline: El País Columnist Says Dismissal Tied to His Criticism of Media Independence
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Newspapers']
abstract: Miguel Ángel Aguilar said his column in El País, Spain’s leading newspaper, was canceled after he was quoted questioning its editorial independence in an article in The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — A veteran journalist said on Wednesday that El País, Spain’s leading newspaper, had ended his column after he questioned editorial independence in Spain in an article in The New York Times about the growing financial and government pressures on the Spanish news media that also discussed recent newsroom tensions at El País and other publications.

headline: To Reach the Truly Rich, Television Ads Won’t Do
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Television', 'Automobiles', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: The images of wealth and luxury seen in TV commercials are aimed mostly at those who aspire to wealthy lifestyles, not those who actually enjoy them.
lead_paragraph: Private jets. Grand estates. Fast cars. High fashion.

headline: Investing in Racehorses, Despite the Long Odds
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Personal Finances', 'Horses', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'American Pharoah (Race Horse)']
abstract: Through partnerships, some owners without deep pockets have found success with prize-winning thoroughbreds.
lead_paragraph: One morning this past summer, Ahmed Zayat was in a stall at Del Mar racetrack in California alongside the 2015 Triple Crown winner American Pharoah.

headline: Stronger Dollar Emboldens More Americans to Seek European Dream Home
abstract: The dollar’s climb against the euro, combined with listless prices in some European markets, has led to a sharp rise in Americans seeking a second home on the Continent.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA — With the exchange rate against the euro persistently not in his favor and his retirement still 20 years away, Dr. Kenneth Bermudez had decided to delay his dream of owning a villa in Tuscany, Italy.

headline: ‘Supersavers’ Focus on the Goal
abstract: Disciplined savers commit to an amount they think will support them in retirement — yet they still manage to indulge themselves at times.
lead_paragraph: During the 2007-8 financial crisis, Chris Reining said, he panicked. His state of anxiety wasn’t brought on by the collapse of the United States stock market or the global economic crisis that followed. It was prompted by his office mates in Madison, Wis.

headline: Making an Adviser Relationship Work
abstract: A client can become dissatisfied with a financial adviser over such issues as personal rapport and communication, not just investment returns.
lead_paragraph: In spring 2001, after losing about $75,000 in the dot-com crash, Jerrie Champlin and her husband, Robert Baranowski, decided it was time for professional help.

headline: For Investors, ‘Portfolio Insurance’ Against Market Declines
abstract: Individuals have access to more strategies to help protect their investments from both short- and long-term threats.
lead_paragraph: Whenever the stock market shows a bad hand, as it did in the third quarter, nearly all stock investors hope they have something akin to an ace in the hole.

headline: Plan Your Digital Legacy, and Update Often
keywords: ['Wills and Estates', 'Data Storage', 'Smartphones', 'Personal Finances', 'Computer Security', 'Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Recording all usernames and passwords for your email, social media and online bank accounts, and the like, will help protect your assets when you die, and simplify the process of executing your will.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Magliochetti, 38, always feared dying without an estate plan. In his 20s, he prepared a will. But after consulting with his money manager, Mr. Magliochetti took an even more unusual step: He listed his digital assets, which include digitized family movies and social media accounts, as well as some assets that are more esoteric, like digital currencies and domain names.

headline: India’s Rising Tides and Temperatures
abstract: Ghoramara and its sister islands in the Bay of Bengal are vanishing, their shoreline borders shifting, shrinking and sinking with rising temperatures and tides.
lead_paragraph: Ghoramara and its sister islands in the Bay of Bengal are vanishing, their shoreline borders shifting, shrinking and sinking with rising temperatures and tides.

headline: Giving Up the Affluent Suburbs for City Living
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Suburbs', 'Condominiums', 'Retirement', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Personal Finances', 'Luxury Goods and Services']
abstract: A rising number of wealthy suburbanites are abandoning their empty-nest suburban estates for high-end city residences — and developers are ready for them.
lead_paragraph: Pete Fader often looks eagerly out the window of his office in West Philadelphia, where he is a marketing professor at the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania, at the rising One Riverside, a 22-story luxury condominium building across the Schuylkill.

headline: Estate Planning for the Never-Married
abstract: More Americans are staying single and childless. Without an immediate family, to whom do you leave your assets?
lead_paragraph: When Adam Cooperman opened a technology consulting firm in New York City eight years ago at age 33, he also prepared a will and other legal and medical documents. “If I have all these professional matters, I should probably have my personal affairs in order, as well,” he explained.

headline: Stormy Markets Today May Offer Steady Growth Tomorrow
abstract: Investment advisers say depressed assets like emerging-market stocks and commodities could offer high returns in the long term, even if they are risky now.
lead_paragraph: There are times when a cautious investor can take risks that a rough-and-ready speculator cannot.

headline: Irrational Game Aims to Steer Consumers Toward Rational Choices
keywords: ['Consumer Behavior', 'Cards and Card Games', 'Personal Finances', 'Credit Cards']
abstract: Dan Ariely, a psychology and behavioral economics professor at Duke, hopes his new card game, which offers miniature social-science experiments, will spur conversation about decision making.
lead_paragraph: In his 2008 best-selling book, “Predictably Irrational,” Dan Ariely, a Duke University professor of psychology and behavioral economics, proposed the idea of a “self-control credit card.”

headline: The Metal Chair, Elevated
abstract: Furniture on display at three art shows offers new (and surprisingly inviting) twists on the material.
lead_paragraph: Two major design fairs are on the horizon: the Salon Art + Design in New York this week and Design Miami at the beginning of December. But before they open, a trio of New York shows are making a case for investing in industrial metal furniture this fall. At Friedman Benda, Paul Cocksedge debuted a room of furniture cast entirely of metal. The London-based designer achieved seamless joints using an experimental sealing technique that uses freezing in place of welding. A haven for self-reflection, Cocksedge’s circular tables and mirrored bookshelves possess unexpected warmth — perhaps it’s the touch of brass?

headline: Jeb Bush Says He’s ‘a Better Bet’ (Than Marco Rubio) to Beat Hillary Clinton
abstract: While they largely steered clear of each other in the debate Tuesday, Mr. Bush sounded a more aggressive note against Mr. Rubio the day after, saying he had the proven record needed to beat Hillary Rodham Clinton.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTIC, Iowa — Though Jeb Bush stood alongside Senator Marco Rubio of Florida on Tuesday night at the Republican debate, he largely steered clear of his former-mentee-turned-political-rival.

headline: An Old Chinatown Lounge Gets a New Life
abstract: Tropical, a 14-year-old lounge on Elizabeth Street, has surged in popularity since new owners took over several months ago.
lead_paragraph: Looking to wade through the squalor of an after-hours party but lack the endurance for all-nighters? That’s the subtext of Tropical, a gucky 14-year-old lounge that has surged in popularity since new owners took over recently.

headline: Republican Debate on Fox Business Draws 13.5 Million
abstract: Tuesday’s debate was a high point for Fox Business Network, which worked to distinguish it from the previous debate on CNBC.
lead_paragraph: Fox Business Network has long stood in the shadow of its much larger and louder sibling, Fox News Channel, and its outsize personalities like Bill O’Reilly. And in the financial world, the network consistently trails its competitor CNBC in television ratings.

headline: Review: In ‘Dear Mr. You,’ Mary-Louise Parker Writes to Men, With Lust and Rue
abstract: The actress presents aspects of herself in an epistolary book that is not a memoir but candidly speaks volumes about its author.
lead_paragraph: Mary-Louise Parker, the luminous, bright-eyed actress, makes her literary debut with the equivalent of a one-woman show. Even though “Dear Mr. You” is nominally about men, there’s no question about who has the starring role. This book is enchantingly arranged as a set of letters to men who have mattered to Ms. Parker, many of them alive only in her memory or imagination. But the narrator has endless ways of upstaging them, and why not? They exist in “Dear Mr. You” only to define who Mary-Louise Parker is and how she got that way.

headline: Take Two: George Saunders and Carly Rae Jepsen
abstract: George Saunders and Carly Rae Jepsen go ballistic while considering a levitating light and the most expensive socks ever made.
lead_paragraph: George Saunders and Carly Rae Jepsen go ballistic while considering a levitating light and the most expensive socks ever made.

headline: Velvet Suits Are a Holiday Alternative to Sparkly Dresses
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Jewels and Jewelry']
abstract: Plus: Fort Gansevoort, a space for artisans, also serves barbecue; Live the Process and Moon Juice team up on workout wear and Annie Costello Brown offers dangly cutout earrings.
lead_paragraph: Plus: Fort Gansevoort, a space for artisans, also serves barbecue; Live the Process and Moon Juice team up on workout wear and Annie Costello Brown offers dangly cutout earrings.

headline: Ruth Bell’s Breakout Fashion Season
abstract: Ms. Bell was one of the star models from the spring 2016 shows.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Bell was one of the star models from the spring 2016 shows.

headline: First Draft Focus: In Memory of the Fallen
keywords: ['Cemeteries', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans', 'Veterans Day (US)']
abstract: President Obama participated in a wreath-laying ceremony Wednesday in honor of Veterans Day at Arlington National Cemetery.

headline: Tarantino’s ‘The Hateful Eight’ Resurrects Nearly Obsolete Technology
abstract: The film will be released in a special roadshow version — with overture, intermission and additional footage — on 100 screens in 70-millimeter projection.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When Quentin Tarantino’s “The Hateful Eight” is released in a special roadshow version (with overture, intermission and additional footage) on Dec. 25, it will represent a feat worthy of the heist in the director’s “Jackie Brown.”

headline: Model Ruth Bell’s Star-Is-Born Tale Comes With a Set of Clippers
abstract: “Having no hair is the easiest and best decision I’ve made in my life so far,” the model says.
lead_paragraph: Ruth Bell, 19, of Deal, England, wears her hair clipped close to her skull and bleached the color of creamed butter. Seen from behind, it gives her the aspect of a baby chick; from the front, coupled with her soft seaside accent, of a holdover from the Victorian era, a fever patient bravely accepting her cropping cure.

headline: Serbia to Give $5.4 Million to Bosnian Town, Site of 1995 Massacre
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Foreign Aid', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Characterized as a gesture of good will, the donation was aimed at fostering development in Srebrenica, where 8,000 Muslims were massacred by Bosnian Serb forces.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Serbia’s prime minister said Wednesday that his country was donating about $5.4 million to foster economic development in the Bosnian town of Srebrenica, where about 8,000 Muslim men and boys were massacred by Bosnian Serb forces in 1995.

headline: Yankees Acquire Twins’ Aaron Hicks in Quest for Younger Lineup
abstract: In what may be a prelude to a bigger trade, the Yankees sent the backup catcher John Ryan Murphy to the Twins for center fielder Aaron Hicks.
lead_paragraph: BOCA RATON, Fla. — When the Yankees were in Minnesota in late July, Twins center fielder Aaron Hicks ranged far into the spacious gaps to run down deep drives by Jacoby Ellsbury and Brian McCann. The next night, he belted a long home run off C. C. Sabathia in the first inning.

headline: At Doc NYC, Women’s (Film) Work
abstract: The Doc NYC festival has programmed documentaries by women as all three of its spotlighted features: opening night, closing night and centerpiece.
lead_paragraph: Thom Powers, the artistic director of Doc NYC, the largest festival of documentary films in the country, said he didn’t realize what he had done until after this year’s lineup of 104 features was released. Someone else had to point out to him that his opening night, closing night and centerpiece selections were all directed or co-directed by women.

headline: IAC/InterActiveCorp Offers to Buy Angie’s List
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The move comes after one of the biggest shareholders in Angie’s List urged the company to consider selling itself.
lead_paragraph: The Internet conglomerate IAC/InterActiveCorp offered on Wednesday to buy Angie’s List, the repository of online reviews for home repairs and other services, for about $512 million, taking its offer public after being rebuffed.

headline: Review: ‘Book of Hanging Gardens,’ Sung by Christian Gerhaher
abstract: Mr. Gerhaher, the German baritone, performed Schoenberg’s atonal song cycle at the Park Avenue Armory.
lead_paragraph: Schoenberg’s “The Book of Hanging Gardens” is an atonal song cycle based on poems by Stefan George that obsessively dissect a love affair in 15 feverish, labile verses. The German baritone Christian Gerhaher, who gave a vulnerable and intense performance of the work in the Park Avenue Armory’s Board of Officers Room on Tuesday, has said that the cycle is “like Christmas, 15 times over.” In a book of conversations published in Germany earlier this year, Mr. Gerhaher notes how Schoenberg creates an entirely new set of colors for every emotional nuance, likening each stanza to a gift to the listener.

headline: Review: On ‘Free TC,’ Ty Dolla Sign Delivers Off-the-Cuff R&B
abstract: Ty Dolla Sign here serves much the same function that R. Kelly did in his mid-1990s to mid-2000s peak, making hip-hop carnality and attitude central to the genre.
lead_paragraph: “Free TC”

headline: Review: ‘Aria,’ by Sullivan Fortner, Full of Assurance
abstract: A pianist who recently won the Cole Porter Fellowship in Jazz, Mr. Fortner has released an album of brightly swinging jazz.
lead_paragraph: “Aria”

headline: Glenn O’Brien Reinvents Himself (Yet Again)
abstract: The former GQ Style Guy takes the reins at Maxim magazine, and hosts a new fashion and art show on Apple TV.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t supposed to end this way. Glenn O’Brien, GQ magazine’s Style Guy columnist, bolted in a huff in May after 16 years.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Review: ‘Madam Phung’s Last Journey’ Follows a Gender-Bending Troupe
abstract: Nguyen Thi Tham wrote and directed this documentary about transgender performers in Vietnam.
lead_paragraph: The subject of “Madam Phung’s Last Journey” describes herself and the carnival family in orbit around her as neither male nor female but half and half — citizens who have no place within the strictures of Vietnam’s official society and few opportunities for legitimate employment.

headline: Mexico’s Governing Party Vows to Stop Using Neuromarketing to Study Voters
abstract: The leader of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, says it will stick to campaign tools like polls and political intuition in its future campaigns.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The leader of Mexico’s governing party has said it will stop hiring neuroscience consultants to register voters’ brain waves and read their facial expressions, responding to a political outcry over its use of the tools of neuromarketing to shape its campaign and governing messages.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Africa, the West Bank and Elsewhere

lead_paragraph: The West Bank and Elsewhere: Pictures of the Day

lead_paragraph: Photos from the West Bank, South Africa, Syria and the United States.

headline: Review: ‘Rock in the Red Zone’ Goes Beyond Music in a War-Torn Israeli Town
abstract: This documentary by Laura Bialis rambles as it delves into the relationship between strife and creativity.
lead_paragraph: Long before the director inserts scenes from her own wedding video into “Rock in the Red Zone,” it’s apparent that she’s grown quite close to her subject. A lack of critical distance isn’t always fatal to a documentary. But here, that segment is just one more piece in an often scattershot project.
