headline: The G.O.P. Tax Debate: Low or Lower; Flat or Flatter?
abstract: A closer look at the Republican presidential candidates and their tax proposals.
lead_paragraph: At Tuesday’s Republican debate, candidates discussed two main questions about taxes: Should they be lower than they are now, or should they be way lower? And should there be fewer tax rates, or just one single rate for everyone, rich and poor?

headline: Young Caribbean Team Braces for Daunting Task in World Cup Qualifier
abstract: St. Vincent and the Grenadines, a team of part-time players, will face the United States in St. Louis.
lead_paragraph: If Jurgen Klinsmann, the German coach of the United States national men’s soccer team, thinks he is at his lowest ebb, Cornelius Huggins can offer him a startling reality check.

headline: Nephews of Venezuela’s First Lady Face Drug Charges
abstract: The two men, relatives of the wife of President Nicolás Maduro, were arrested in Haiti and turned over to United States officials, a person close to the investigation said.
lead_paragraph: Two nephews of the wife of President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela were arrested this week in Haiti and flown to the United States where they will face drug trafficking charges, according to a person with knowledge of the matter.

headline: More Young Women Waiting to Leave Home
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Census', 'Families and Family Life', 'Youth', 'Population', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Cultural shifts and economic factors are keeping millennial women home in numbers not seen since 1940, an analysis of Census Bureau data suggests.
lead_paragraph: The share of young women living at home with their parents or other relatives has reached its highest level since the statistics were first gathered, according to an analysis of Census Bureau data.

headline: Review: Chamber Music Society, Bilingual in ‘Channel Crossing’
abstract: English composers, then French, featured in a concert at Lincoln Center that included the Amphion String Quartet.
lead_paragraph: “Channel Crossing,” the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center called its program at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday evening, and the society’s artistic directors, David Finckel and Wu Han, supplied information about the English Channel in an introductory note. At its narrowest, the channel is some 20 miles wide, they wrote; for the hardiest, it’s a seven-hour swim.

headline: 106 Indictments Handed Down in Waco Twin Peaks Biker Shootout
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Gangs', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'District Attorneys']
abstract: A deadly shootout in Texas resulted in more than 100 felony indictments, and prosecutors say more are likely as the investigation continues.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN — A biker shootout in Waco, Tex., that left nine people dead and nearly 20 wounded in May has resulted in 106 felony indictments, and Central Texas prosecutors say more indictments are likely in the protracted investigation.

headline: Mizzou, Yale and Free Speech
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Discrimination', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Minorities', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: On university campuses, First Amendment rights are colliding with inclusivity.
lead_paragraph: On university campuses across the country, from Mizzou to Yale, we have two noble forces colliding with explosive force.

headline: A Flurry of Holiday Pop-Up Stores and Other Shopping Events
abstract: Plus: A Tiffany partnership with Dover Street Market; and sample sales for Lulu Frost and Charlotte Olympia.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, the Dannijo designers Danielle and Jodie Snyder will open a holiday pop-up they’re calling “Conversation Pieces” near their showroom. There you’ll find jewelry designs like an oxidized silver-plate bib necklace with Swarovski crystals ($520) along with lingerie by Morgan Lane and vintage clothing from A Current Affair. At 68 Gansevoort Street.

headline: Bob Dole Endorses Jeb Bush, and Knocks Ted Cruz
abstract: Bob Dole endorsed Jeb Bush for president, saying he believed the former Florida governor was the best qualified candidate, and also making clear that he still held a grudge against Senator Ted Cruz of Texas.
lead_paragraph: Former Senator Bob Dole of Kansas endorsed Jeb Bush for president on Wednesday, saying he believed that the former Florida governor was the best qualified candidate — and also making clear that he still held a grudge against Senator Ted Cruz of Texas.

headline: T-Mobile Video Plan Could Test F.C.C.’s New Net Neutrality Rules
keywords: ['Net Neutrality', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: The plan from T-Mobile USA to allow unlimited streaming of some video services may become the first test of the government’s rules to prevent favoritism on the Internet.
lead_paragraph: A new plan from T-Mobile USA to allow unlimited streaming of some video services may become the first test of the federal government’s rules to prevent favoritism on the Internet.

headline: Republican Voters Slowly Begin to Rally Around Candidates
abstract: In Iowa and New Hampshire, Republicans who had been undecided before Tuesday night’s debate suggested that more and more voters were coming off the fence.
lead_paragraph: DAVENPORT, Iowa — At a Marco Rubio rally the day after the Republicans’ fourth debate, Scott Bell pressed through a crowd to deliver a direct message to the Florida senator. “I’m all in,” he told Mr. Rubio.

headline: Review: The Violinist Leila Josefowicz at Carnegie Hall
abstract: Ms. Josefowicz performed with the pianist John Novacek at Zankel Hall on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: From child prodigy to go-to star for major commissions, the reinvention of the violinist Leila Josefowicz, just 38, is complete. Glance at her menu for the season and see a feast of new music: a garnish of Sibelius topping the meat of concertos by Thomas Adès, John Adams, Oliver Knussen and Sean Shepherd.

headline: Review: Kyle Abraham, Sleekly Protesting Racial Injustice
abstract: Abraham.In.Motion presents works inspired by jazz and hip-hop at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: Race and music are potent tools for Kyle Abraham, a Pittsburgh-born choreographer and dancer who grew up enmeshed in hip-hop culture. In his newest work, “Absent Matter,” Mr. Abraham takes inspiration from jazz and hip-hop to focus on racial injustice. It’s a timely — and, for a dance, a huge — subject. Yet despite his status as a 2013 MacArthur Fellow, Mr. Abraham is not fully formed enough as a choreographer to tackle it.

headline: Friends or Friendly? Sheldon Silver’s Trial Focuses on Ties to Doctor
abstract: How jurors in the corruption trial of Mr. Silver, the former New York State Assembly speaker, perceive the connection between him and Dr. Robert N. Taub could be crucial in determining his fate.
lead_paragraph: Their relationship seemed to pass the tests of friendship. Sheldon Silver and Dr. Robert N. Taub had mutual friends; their families had met, and even stayed at the same hotel during Passover celebrations.

headline: ‘No Easy Answers’ in Murder Charge Against 8-Year-Old
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Children and Childhood', 'Juvenile Delinquency', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Mandatory Sentencing']
abstract: The charges against a boy in the killing of a 1-year-old girl in Alabama prompted questions about juvenile justice and how the authorities should approach these rare cases.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — With its unadorned language and matter-of-fact tone, the announcement on Tuesday by the authorities in Birmingham, Ala., at first read like nearly any other law enforcement statement about a homicide investigation.

headline: Home Health Aide Becomes a Guardian and, He Hopes, a Father
abstract: When Marco Muñoz began taking care of Jose Hernandez, a boy with severe autism and developmental disabilities, they developed a special bond.
lead_paragraph: As Marco Muñoz speaks, recalling the past few years of his life, Jose Hernandez slips one of his shoes onto Mr. Muñoz’s hand. It is an odd yet effective gesture that signals to Mr. Muñoz that Jose wants to go for a walk.

headline: Apple Plans Peer-to-Peer Payment Service
abstract: The company is in talks with banks about a service that would let people use their iPhones to send money to one another as easily as they send messages.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple is working on a person-to-person payments service that may give iPhone owners another reason to use their Apple Wallets.

headline: Racial Discrimination Protests Ignite at Colleges Across the U.S.
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Students say they have been inspired by the Black Lives Matter movement and the protests at the University of Missouri to demand their universities provide a safe space for students of color.
lead_paragraph: The passion that ousted the heads of the University of Missouri after protests over racial discrimination on campus is spreading to other colleges across the country, turning traditional fall semesters into a period of intense focus on racial misunderstanding and whether activism stifles free speech.

headline: FanDuel and DraftKings Prepare for Court Fight in New York
abstract: The two daily fantasy sports operators said they would pursue legal options to stay in operation in the state, which is vital to their businesses, despite a demand by its attorney general to halt.
lead_paragraph: The two largest daily fantasy sports operators acknowledged Wednesday that New York State was vital to the future of their businesses and said they would pursue all legal options to remain in operation there despite a demand by the state attorney general that they stop allowing residents to play because their games constituted illegal gambling under state law.

headline: André Glucksmann, French Philosopher Who Renounced Marxism, Dies at 78
abstract: After publishing his most influential work, “The Master Thinkers,” Mr. Glucksmann became one of France’s most prominent public intellectuals.
lead_paragraph: André Glucksmann, one of the most prominent of the French “New Philosophers,” a group of former radicals who broke with Marxism in the 1970s and became an intellectual counterweight to France’s political left, died on Tuesday in Paris. He was 78.

headline: Review: Andrea Burns at Feinstein’s/54 Below
abstract: Ms. Burns, who plays Gloria Estefan’s mother in “On Your Feet,” is an entertainer at ease in the place where Broadway tradition merges with Latin American pop.
lead_paragraph: Andrea Burns, who plays Gloria Estefan’s mother in the musical “On Your Feet!,” knows who she is: a Latina fish out of water who grew up in Miami, obsessed with Broadway. Ebullient and playful, Ms. Burns, 44, brought a breath of tropical air to Feinstein’s/54 Below on Monday evening. She compared her parents’ 46-year relationship to a union between Jerry Seinfeld and Sofia Vergara. The person onstage had a little of both. “I happen to be part Jewish,” she added. “I have the guilt.”

headline: Betsy Drake, 92, Actress Who Starred With (and Wed) Cary Grant, Dies
abstract: Ms. Drake, a stage actress at the time, bumped into Grant on the Queen Mary, eloped with him and appeared with him in “Every Girl Should Be Married” and “Room for One More.”
lead_paragraph: Betsy Drake, a film actress who starred alongside Cary Grant after bumping into him on the Queen Mary, eloping with him and remaining married to him longer than any of his other wives, died on Oct. 27 at her home in London. She was 92.

headline: G.O.P. Fight Now a Battle Over What Defines a Conservative
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Illegal Immigration', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The debate opened a new season of the campaign shaped by the glaring policy fissures that are dividing Republicans, from immigration and bank regulation to taxes and national security.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — For months, the Republican presidential race has been animated by the party’s inchoate anger about the state of the country and an equally undefined hope that a candidate would emerge who could usher in an era of civic renewal. But the debate here and its aftermath marked an abrupt transition from vague promises about making America “great again,” in Donald J. Trump’s phrase, to a new season of the campaign shaped more by the glaring policy fissures that are dividing Republicans over what exactly to do about the nation’s problems.

keywords: ['Hudson River Tunnels Project', 'Bridges and Tunnels', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)']

headline: Israeli Opposition Leader Withholds Judgment on Netanyahu’s U.S. Visit
abstract: Labor Party leader Isaac Herzog said it was unclear whether Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s visit to Washington was a success.
lead_paragraph: Isaac Herzog, head of the political opposition in Israel, reserved judgment on Wednesday about Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s visit this week to Washington, saying the outcome was unclear despite what appeared to be an improved atmosphere created by the trip.

headline: Labour Leader Jeremy Corbyn Pledges Loyalty to Queen, if Not to Tradition
abstract: Jeremy Corbyn, the new leader of Britain’s opposition party, again risked the wrath of royalists when he swore an oath of loyalty to Queen Elizabeth II, but apparently not on bended knee.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A lifelong republican and veteran leftist, Jeremy Corbyn, the new leader of Britain’s opposition Labour Party, caused consternation among traditionalists in September when he failed to sing the national anthem, “God Save the Queen,” at a ceremony to commemorate World War II.

keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']

lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — A veteran United Nations official who earned his diplomatic credibility in the Israeli-Palestinian crisis will take over the United Nations refugee agency amid the world’s worst migrant crisis in decades.

headline: Shock and Few Leads After Murder of Lois Colley, Society Matriarch
abstract: Residents of wealthy North Salem, N.Y., reacted in horror to the death of Lois Colley, a mainstay of the local fox-hunting club.
lead_paragraph: NORTH SALEM, N.Y. — This pastoral playground in the northeast corner of Westchester County, laced with horse paddocks and stone walls, has long been a draw for the wealthy and well-connected. Among those who call it home are David Letterman, the composer Alan Menken and the financier Steven Rattner. Michael R. Bloomberg, who has many homes, also owns an estate here.

abstract: The Jets committed tens of millions of dollars to defensive backs in free agency, but now injuries and poor play are plaguing their secondary.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Once, there was a house.

keywords: ['Capitol Building (Washington, DC)', 'Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The guardians of the United States Capitol, with the serendipitous convenience of a modest renovation underway in the Rayburn House Office Building, have quietly removed the Mississippi state flag with its Confederate battle insignia from a well-traveled hallway.

headline: Joe’s Crab Shack to Test No-Tipping Policy
abstract: The seafood chain will raise menu prices and give its servers set wages at 18 locations, in one of the largest trials yet of the policy.
lead_paragraph: Following in the footsteps of the Danny Meyer restaurant group, Joe’s Crab Shack, a Houston-based chain with more than 130 locations nationwide, announced on Wednesday that it would test a no-tipping system in one of the largest trials yet of the policy.

headline: Giants’ Pass Rush Has High Hopes for Matchup With Tom Brady
abstract: The Giants’ blueprint for success against the Patriots in the past was always getting to and disrupting Brady. But their pass rush has suffered mightily this season.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Cullen Jenkins is a 12-year N.F.L. veteran, an anchor on the Giants’ defensive line, and lavish praise for opposing quarterbacks does not often pass through his teeth four days before a big game.

headline: Greensboro Puts Focus on Reducing Racial Bias
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Racial Profiling', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Traffic and Parking Violations']
abstract: The police chief of the city has ordered his officers to stop pulling over motorists for minor infractions involving vehicle flaws like broken taillights.
lead_paragraph: The police chief in Greensboro, N.C., has ordered his officers to stop pulling over motorists for minor infractions involving vehicle flaws like broken taillights, an action he called a first step toward eliminating “alarming” racial disparities in traffic stops.

headline: Jacqueline Berrien, Head of E.E.O.C., Is Dead at 53
abstract: Ms. Berrien was a civil rights lawyer who was President Obama’s chairwoman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission from 2010 to 2014.
lead_paragraph: Jacqueline Berrien, a civil rights lawyer who was President Obama’s chairwoman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, died on Monday in Baltimore. She was 53.

headline: Scott Gomez Brings His Playoff Experience to the Blues
abstract: Scott Gomez, 35, has something the St. Louis Blues have lacked — a record of going deep into the Stanley Cup playoffs.
lead_paragraph: Scott Gomez was the first St. Louis Blues player to step on the ice at Madison Square Garden for practice Wednesday.

headline: Carol Doda, Pioneer of Topless Entertainment, Dies at 78
abstract: Ms. Doda, who started a topless revolution as a 26-year-old go-go dancer in 1964, had injected her breasts with enough silicone to expand her bra size to 44DD from 34B.
lead_paragraph: Carol Doda, who was widely credited with triggering a nationwide topless revolution as a 26-year-old go-go dancer in 1964, died on Monday in San Francisco. She was 78.

headline: Richard Horowitz, Timpanist and Craftsman of Conductors’ Batons, Dies at 91
abstract: Mr. Horowitz, who spent 66 years and some 10,000 performances with the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra, had stumbled into a second career making the directors’ sticks.
lead_paragraph: In a Queens boiler room, armed with little more than a champagne cork and a length of wood, Richard Horowitz helped bring to life some of the foremost symphonic music in the world.

headline: Review: ‘Shear Madness,’ Where Getting a Haircut Is Murder
abstract: This interactive comedy-mystery opens in New York, following its decades-long run in Boston.
lead_paragraph: Only $30 for a woman’s haircut at a Manhattan salon? That’s what they charge at Shear Madness, a wacky little shop that’s just opened on West 50th Street, though it looks as if it had been there forever. The walls are baby blue, the floor is linoleum, and isn’t that a ficus tree in the corner, over near the exposed brick?

headline: M.L.B. Considers Adjusting Rules on Slides and Replays
abstract: The organization is weighing whether the slide that wiped out Mets shortstop Ruben Tejada’s season will be outlawed.
lead_paragraph: BOCA RATON, Fla. — Whether the slide that wiped out Mets shortstop Ruben Tejada’s season will be outlawed when he returns next season remains uncertain.

headline: Review: ‘Henry IV,’ Donmar Warehouse’s All-Female Version
abstract: Directed by Phyllida Lloyd and starring Harriet Walter, this production of two condensed Shakespeare plays reveals the desperation behind the bravado.
lead_paragraph: Leave it to an army of sharp-witted women to point out just how much Shakespeare’s “Henry IV” plays are — how shall we put this? — manhood-measuring contests. As embodied by a rousing all-female cast in this seriously entertaining Donmar Warehouse production, which opened on Wednesday night at St. Ann’s Warehouse in Brooklyn, Shakespeare’s soldiers, nobles and carousers seem to be forever engaged in vociferous argument as to who has the bigger ….

headline: Between Here and the Sun
abstract: A nod to an adorable zoo attraction, by David Kwong.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — This puzzle is a totally adorable salute to a very cute animal and I nearly failed miserably at it.

headline: Square Sticks to the Script as It Prepares for Its I.P.O.
abstract: The payment start-up’s chief, Jack Dorsey, also runs Twitter, a fact that Square has played down in meetings with investors before its initial public offering planned for next week.
lead_paragraph: The hundreds of investors who attended Square’s initial public offering marketing lunch on Wednesday could have asked management the tough questions.

headline: Why Germans Loved Helmut Schmidt
abstract: The former chancellor was steely, ornery — and he smoked like a chimney. So why did the country adore him?
lead_paragraph: Hamburg, Germany — HELMUT SCHMIDT, the former German chancellor and renowned postwar statesman who died Tuesday at 96, would have hated to read the adulatory obituaries that have poured forth over the last 24 hours. Henry A. Kissinger, one of his closest friends, once said he hoped Mr. Schmidt would survive him, because “a world without him would be very empty.”

headline: Repeat Train Thief Steals Bus at Port Authority, Police Say
abstract: Darius McCollum, who has been arrested more than two dozen times for taking subway trains and buses for joy rides, took a Greyhound bus in Midtown Manhattan, the police said.
lead_paragraph: Darius McCollum, known for his obsession with buses and trains and his proclivity for taking them for joy rides, has been no stranger to law enforcement in New York City.

headline: Researchers Say There May Be Undiscovered Tomb at Great Pyramid of Giza
abstract: A team using scanning technology said temperature variations could indicate the presence of a tomb in the 4,500-year-old structure.
lead_paragraph: Researchers in Egypt using advanced scanning techniques to study the Pyramids said this week that they had detected “thermal anomalies” within the Great Pyramid of Giza that could indicate the presence of an undiscovered tomb.

headline: Northern Ireland: Ex-Soldier Is Released on Bail in Bloody Sunday Investigation
abstract: The former soldier, 66, who was arrested in connection with the 1972 Bloody Sunday massacre has not been charged.
lead_paragraph: A former British soldier who was arrested Tuesday in connection with the 1972 Bloody Sunday massacre of unarmed civilians in Londonderry has been released on bail, the Police Service of Northern Ireland announced Wednesday. The former soldier, 66, has not been charged. A 2010 inquiry found that the British government was responsible for the massacre, and it prompted the police to open a criminal investigation. This was the first arrest in the case.

headline: Knicks Are Finally Healthy, Besides Heartbreak at Buzzer
abstract: In Arron Afflalo’s season debut, Kristaps Porzingis appeared to sink a winning 3-pointer at the buzzer, but the officials waved the shot off.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Nine games into his N.B.A. career, with four double-doubles to his credit and greats like Magic Johnson already hinting at future greatness to come, the 7-foot wonder Kristaps Porzingis is the subject of good-natured ribbing by his Knicks teammates.

headline: Senate Approves Research Into Combat Effects on Mental Health
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Research into veterans’ suicide received a lift on Tuesday with Senate passage of a measure requiring an independent research program on the effects of combat service on suicide rates and other mental health issues among troops and veterans.
lead_paragraph: Research into veterans’ suicide received a lift on Tuesday with Senate passage of a measure requiring an independent research program on the effects of combat service on suicide rates and other mental health issues among troops and veterans. A report by The New York Times in September found that monitoring of suicide was not coordinated between the Department of Veterans Affairs and Department of Defense, and many veterans fell through the cracks because the effect of combat exposure was poorly tracked.   After more than decade of war, neither department has the data to show whether troops exposed to combat have a higher risk of suicide, and how that risk changes over time. Because of this, veterans say suicide prevention programs do not fit their needs. “We simply don’t know enough about the effects of combat on mental health issues among service members and veterans both during and after service,” said the amendment’s sponsor, Senator Michael Bennet of Colorado. The measure passed as part of the Military Construction and Veterans Affairs and Related Agencies Appropriations Act for fiscal year 2016.

headline: In India, Many Voters May See Corruption as the Lesser Evil
abstract: The victory in Bihar State by opposition parties calling themselves secular was partly a response to the right-wing Hindu character of Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s party.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — What do Indians despise more: communal conflict or corruption?

headline: Kurds, Backed by U.S. Air Power, Try to Regain Sinjar From ISIS
keywords: ['Kurds', 'Yazidi (Religious Sect)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The move also sought to cut a major jihadist supply line between Syria and the Iraqi city of Mosul.
lead_paragraph: MOUNT SINJAR, Iraq — Kurdish forces aided by thousands of lightly armed Yazidi fighters began a long-awaited offensive early Thursday to reclaim Mount Sinjar and an accompanying town from the Islamic State, which seized the northern Iraqi territory last year and murdered, raped and enslaved thousands of Yazidis.

headline: Hawaii Confronts Dengue Outbreak as 33 Are Infected
abstract: Health officials warned that the entire Big Island is at risk for the spread of the mosquito-borne tropical illness.
lead_paragraph: Health officials in Hawaii have confirmed at least 33 cases of dengue fever, a mosquito-borne tropical illness not usually found there, and warned that the entire Big Island is at risk for its spread.

abstract: The ease of creating roads through the desert could limit the effectiveness of the offensive to cut off a key ISIS supply route.
lead_paragraph: The ease of creating roads through the desert could limit the effectiveness of the offensive to cut off a key ISIS supply route.

headline: Obesity Rises Despite All Efforts to Fight It, U.S. Health Officials Say
abstract: Despite years of efforts to reduce obesity, federal health officials reported Thursday that the share of Americans who were obese increased slightly.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Despite years of efforts to reduce obesity in America, including a major push by Michelle Obama, federal health officials reported Thursday that the share of Americans who were obese had not declined in recent years, and had edged up slightly.

headline: Macy’s Sounds a Holiday Alarm, and Retailers Brace for Heavy Discounting
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Holidays and Special Occasions', 'Mobile Commerce and Payments', 'Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)']
abstract: Aggressive discounting from Macy’s, one of the country’s biggest merchants, is bad news for retailers this holiday season, which is shaping up to be highly discount-driven.
lead_paragraph: When Macy’s, a store closely associated with Christmas, says there is trouble brewing ahead of the holidays, it is enough to send the world of shopping into a tailspin.

headline: Sale Offers a Reason for Relief at Sotheby’s
abstract: If art buyers were feeling a bit of auction fatigue going into Sotheby’s contemporary art evening sale — the sixth auction in seven days — they did not show it in their bidding for several major works.
lead_paragraph: If art buyers were feeling a bit of auction fatigue going into Sotheby’s contemporary art evening sale on Wednesday — the sixth auction in seven days — they did not show it in their bidding for several major works.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, November 12, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “It can be exhausting feeling like you’re speaking for your entire race.”

headline: 2 Arrested in Laser Strike on Helicopter
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)', 'Helicopters']

headline: The Stealth Attack on Abortion Access
abstract: Some states are subsidizing medically questionable crisis pregnancy centers, while moving to strip funding from comprehensive health care providers.
lead_paragraph: A YEAR ago, a mother and self-described “God-fearing woman” called me after she had an abortion. She said that earlier, when she found herself unexpectedly pregnant, she drove straight to what she thought was a comprehensive health care provider near her home in Columbus, Ohio. When she asked about abortion, the staff told her she shouldn’t murder her child. Ohio requires an ultrasound before an abortion, so the woman listened to the staff’s condemnations, taking them to heart, crying. She told me later, “I didn’t know where else to go.”

headline: Who Is Entitled to Be Heard?
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Discrimination', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Censorship', 'Cyberharassment', 'Threats and Threatening Messages']
abstract: At Yale and Missouri, both sides are talking past each other.
lead_paragraph: SOME of the most potent threats to free speech these days come not from our government or corporations, but from our citizenry. Pitched battles being waged at Yale and the University of Missouri pit speech versus speech in a contest of who and what is entitled to be heard. These are only the latest examples: In recent years speakers have been disinvited, campus events disrupted and activists threatened for speaking their minds.

headline: Judicial Energy and the Supreme Court
abstract: Will the Supreme Court reverse an appeals court decision blocking a program to shield undocumented parents of American-born children from deportation?
lead_paragraph: Terry Eastland, a Reagan-era conservative activist who now edits The Weekly Standard, wrote a book back in 1992 that he called “Energy in the Executive: The Case for the Strong Presidency.” He took to task both President Ronald Reagan, for whom he had worked in the Justice Department, and the first President Bush for having failed to use all possible levers of presidential power to advance the conservative agenda.

headline: An Antidote to Cynicism in Canada

headline: Poll Shows Hillary Clinton Maintaining Lead Over Bernie Sanders

lead_paragraph: Despite a month of sharpened attacks, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont has failed to significantly dent Hillary Rodham Clinton’s lead in the Democratic presidential race, according to a New York Times/CBS News survey released on Thursday.

headline: Retracing a Mother’s Path of Escape Along a Wintry Merrimack
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Canoes and Canoeing', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: Two adventurers revisit the river route in New Hampshire that Hannah Duston used in 1697 to flee from a group of Abenaki Indians.
lead_paragraph: A thick curtain of snow fell over the Merrimack River, obscuring the far bank. While my friend Chris Pierce and I searched for a place to launch our canoe, the flurries drifted away. Paddling carefully on the swollen expanse of the Merrimack, we passed a small island fringed with ice, and thus entered a forgotten chapter in American history.

headline: Choose Your Own Adventure: A Conversation With Jennifer Egan and George Saunders
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Science Fiction', 'Language and Languages', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: Two fiction writers known for their mind-bending imaginations discuss the business of envisioning the future.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Egan: I want to start by talking about how we define writing about the future. Some things that I think of as futuristic, when I’ve looked at them again for this conversation, I’m not sure they really are. So I guess my question would be: What leads you into territory that feels futuristic? How do you end up there? And what makes it the future?

headline: Letter of Recommendation: The ‘Death in … ’ Books
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Bears', 'Falls']
abstract: They are more than just macabre litanies of accidents, murders and mishaps in America’s most treasured national parks.
lead_paragraph: This summer, two female bears, each with a set of twin cubs, took up residence along a tree-lined trail in Denver. Hikers in the park had proved themselves prone to snapping selfies with bears, sometimes by creeping within 10 feet of them, so in response, the city pre-emptively shut down the trail. This story circulated online as evidence of human stupidity’s direct correlation with modern technol­ogy’s advancement, but I thought that was unfair. People have been making mistakes in nature for a long, long time.

headline: Review: In Angelina Jolie Pitt’s ‘By the Sea,’ an Unhappy Ménage and Tear-Streaked Mascara
abstract: The film stars Ms. Jolie Pitt and Brad Pitt as a troubled married couple staying in the South of France in the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: Meta with a vengeance, “By the Sea” stars Angelina Jolie Pitt and Brad Pitt as itinerant married artists who are suffering, beautifully, through a rough patch. Any resemblance to real life is strictly coincidental and completely intentional. At first luxurious blush it’s a jet-setting marital melodrama, one of those he-said, she-said (and wept) encounter sessions decked with designer shades, to-die-for digs and millionaire tears. More interestingly, the movie, which Ms. Jolie Pitt wrote and directed, is a knowing or at least a ticklishly amusing demonstration of celebrity and its relay of gazes from one of the most looked-at women in the world. Take, watch, she seems to say, this is my body.

headline: Nancy Pelosi Made Rare Visit to Tibet, China Says
abstract: Chinese leaders allowed her to make a tightly controlled visit to the region, which is under Beijing rule and usually off limits to foreign officials and journalists.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Nancy Pelosi, the Democratic leader of the House of Representatives, visited Lhasa, the capital of Tibet, this week and met with the Communist Party chief of the region, according to a Foreign Ministry spokesman and a report published on Thursday by the official Tibet Daily.

headline: 1915: Winston Churchill Resigns
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Churchill resigns in 1915.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Mr. Winston Churchill, the Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster, who was First Lord of the Admiralty until the formation of the Coalition Ministry, has resigned office and will rejoin his regiment in France. Mr. Churchill, in tendering his resignation, said that his chief reason for resigning was that Mr. Asquith, who had promised six weeks ago to make him a member of the new War Council, had not seen his way to do so. Mr. Churchill, therefore, declined to remain any longer in well-paid inactivity. — The New York Herald, European Edition, November 13, 1915

headline: A Mother’s Hoarding, a Daughter’s Art
abstract: Stephanie Calvert had been deeply ashamed of her mother’s habit. But her mother’s accident led her to reexamine their past.
lead_paragraph: When a bicycle accident left her mother with severe brain damage, Stephanie Calvert began to reexamine what had been a difficult relationship. Her mother had been a hoarder — when the family moved to an isolated schoolhouse in Thatcher, Colo., she filled it with clothes, papers and other objects. Ms. Calvert was deeply embarrassed by her mother’s habit — she became depressed and “wanted to leave as soon as I could and move far away.”

headline: Coordinated European Raids Target Ring Supporting Terrorist Groups
abstract: The authorities arrested 15 people in four countries believed to be seeking to overthrow the Kurdish government in northern Iraq and to recruit Islamic State militants.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The authorities arrested 15 people in four European countries on Thursday, breaking up what officials called a terrorist network that sought to overthrow the Kurdish government in northern Iraq and to recruit militants to fight in Iraq and Syria.

headline: Adele Cries to Her Music, Too
abstract: The British singer discusses the challenge of following up the success of “21,” how motherhood has changed her and why she avoids being a celebrity.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “I’m not going to cry,” Adele said. She was practicing with her band at Music Bank rehearsal studios, an unglamorous warehouse space in South London, and had just finished “When We Were Young,” one of the torchiest ballads on her new album, “25.” It’s a song about running into an old flame that confesses, “I still care” and then, tentatively, asks, “Do you still care?”

lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Home buyers in Rio de Janeiro used to get into intense bidding wars as they tried to secure even a modest apartment in one of the city’s exclusive beachfront districts. Not anymore.

headline: Daily Report: Imagining the Road Ahead
abstract: ScanLAB Projects, a London design studio, has taken 3D scanning to an artistic level by trying to scan the inner life of self-driving cars.
lead_paragraph: If predictions about the future are true, many of us will soon be riding around in self-driving cars. But a crucial part of making that prediction a reality is making sure that the car can see — or sense — the world around it.

headline: 1965: Russians Send Probe to Venus
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The Soviet Union launches a spaceship to Venus in 1965
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Soviet Union took another stab at inter-planetary space exploration today [Nov. 12] — a field in which it has been unsuccessful for four years — with the launching of what is called the ‘‘Venus-2’’ spaceship to the earth’s cloud- covered ‘‘sister planet.’’ The 2,123-pound craft got off to a good start on its three- and-a-half-month flight to Venus, and then Tass, the government news agency, announced that it had been launched. Venus-1 was launched on Feb. 12, 1961, but its radios went dead about two weeks later. After that first failure, Soviet space engineers failed on at least four more occasions, according to American sources, to send rockets toward Venus. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 13, 1965

headline: In Victoria, British Columbia, Where to Go on Trounce Alley

keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Social Media', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']

headline: Review: Stacy Schiff’s ‘The Witches,’ a Reign of Terror in 17th-Century Salem
abstract: Ms. Schiff goes back to the original story of Salem, Massachusetts, offering a minutely detailed chronicle of nine harrowing months in 1692.
lead_paragraph: The feverish Salem witch hunts of 1692 have become a metaphor not just for anti-Communist mania in the 1950s but for the larger strain of what the historian Richard Hofstadter has described as “the paranoid style in American politics,” and for all manner of conspiratorial hate-and-fear mongering, inquisitional madness and communal hysteria.

headline: The Danger of Knowing ‘Just Enough’ Spanish
abstract: Good medical care relies on understanding, and understanding is all about language.
lead_paragraph: I speak just enough Spanish to be dangerous.

headline: How a Company Can Be Both Downgraded and Upgraded

lead_paragraph: The ratings agency Fitch downgraded the Chesapeake Energy Corporation’s issuer default rating last week to BB- from BB. At the same time, Fitch upgraded the rating on the company’s bank loan to BB+ from BB.

headline: With Aung San Suu Kyi’s Rise, China and Myanmar Face New Relationship
abstract: Whether China can work well with the country under a newly elected government is an open question.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Even though China has long supported the generals who have wielded most of the power in Myanmar, the government in Beijing prepared this year for the possible election victory of the opposition leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, by inviting her to the capital to meet with President Xi Jinping.

headline: Pistons’ Andre Drummond Hits the Boards and Makes a Huge Leap
abstract: Drummond has always been a great rebounder, but he is off to a historically great start and his numbers are striking.
lead_paragraph: Andre Drummond pulled down 17 rebounds on Wednesday night, the eighth-highest total by any N.B.A. player this season. Yet his rebounding average for the year dropped.

headline: Why Jeffrey Lacker Is Worried About Inflation
keywords: ['Interest Rates', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'United States Economy', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond has been trying to raise interest rates for a while; he may finally get his way.
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Lacker, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, was the only member of the Fed’s policy-making committee who voted to raise interest rates in September, and again in October. Mr. Lacker has long expressed skepticism about the benefits of the Fed’s stimulus campaign, and he has been concerned that inflation will begin to rise more quickly as the economy gains strength.

headline: In Obama Era, G.O.P. Bolsters Grip in the States
keywords: ['States (US)', 'Local Government', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'State Legislatures', 'Elections, State Legislature']
abstract: Democratic control of state and local elected offices has waned since 2009, hollowing out the party’s roster of potential candidates for major races.
lead_paragraph: LEXINGTON, Ky. — Young, telegenic and news media savvy, State Auditor Adam Edelen looked like a shoo-in for re-election when Democrats gathered in a horse barn here for a buffet dinner late last month. Most figured he would go on to challenge Senator Rand Paul, whose Republican presidential bid is faltering even as he seeks re-election.

headline: Bright Lights, Strange Shapes and Talk of U.F.O.’s
abstract: When strange things appear in the sky, many people can’t help but turn their thoughts to extraterrestrials. But there’s usually a more down-to-earth explanation.
lead_paragraph: When strange things appear in the sky, many people can’t help but turn their thoughts to extraterrestrials. But there’s usually a more down-to-earth explanation.

headline: ‘American Horror Story’ Season 5, Episode 6: Impersonation of Love
abstract: It was hard to care about a romance introduced so abruptly.
lead_paragraph: What does it mean to fall in love in the world of “American Horror Story”? When the body count is this high, is there any room for such sentiment?

headline: How Period Trackers Have Changed Girl Culture
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Menstruation', 'Mobile Applications', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Period trackers are among the most popular apps and helping change girl culture by making girls more open about their periods.
lead_paragraph: My 18-year-old daughter knows exactly when it will be that time of the month. Since June, she’s been plugging the dates of her menstrual cycle into a popular period tracking app called Clue, and has it programmed to send her an alert every month, two days before her next period is due.

headline: Palestinian Dies as Undercover Israelis Raid a Hospital
abstract: Video emerged showing Israeli forces disguised in traditional Arab outfits as they burst in to make an arrest. One man was killed.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — About two dozen men wearing bulky jackets, woolen caps, hoodies and checkered kaffiyehs barged into a hospital in the West Bank city of Hebron before dawn on Thursday, pushing what appeared to be a very pregnant woman in a wheelchair.

headline: Cola, a New Start-up, Introduces Ways to Do More in Text Messages
abstract: The company is trying to make it easier to accomplish tasks inside text messaging and to give other app makers the programming hooks that allow them to expand the abilities of text messages even further.
lead_paragraph: For better or worse, text messaging is the app people spend more time using than any other on their smartphones. A new start-up, Cola, believes it can make it a bit better.

headline: Bringing iPhone-style Medical Research to the Android World
keywords: ['Android (Operating System)', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Medicine and Health', 'Mobile Applications', 'Research']
abstract: A new software initiative will enable Android smartphones to be used for large-scale medical research projects. Apple did that for iPhones earlier this year.
lead_paragraph: Since Apple introduced its ResearchKit software in March, scientists at leading medical schools across the country have written apps to study asthma, Parkinson’s disease, autism, epilepsy, melanoma, breast cancer and other ailments. Medical experts are hopeful that using smartphones to gather health data from millions of people, with their consent, can open a window to new insights into diseases, treatments and lifestyle effects.

headline: When Headlines Play Down Dads, All Parents Lose
abstract: The “who does more at home” story distracts us from real policy issues while supporting the status quo.
lead_paragraph: Female readers, did you gravitate toward certain articles about a recent Pew Report (Raising Kids and Running a Household: How Working Parents Share the Load)? Maybe you clicked on a headline like Equal division of labor at home for working parents? Not exactly (CNN), or “Who does more at home when both parents work? Depends on which one you ask” (Pew Fact Tank), or lingered knowingly over the paragraphs in the many articles that described how mothers do more: more to manage children’s schedules and activities, more chores, more coping with sick days. Much of the reporting included a wry poke at the “fun” statistic: More fathers than mothers say they share equally in the work.

headline: The House of Lords: The Constitutional Dinosaur Britain Can’t Kill
abstract: Britain’s unelected second chamber is an absurd anachronism in a modern democracy. Apparently, we like it that way.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Imagine President Obama introducing a controversial welfare proposal that quickly became the contentious subject of many columns and talk shows — but was approved, nonetheless, by Congress.

headline: Charges Against Nephews of Venezuela’s First Lady
abstract: The two men, Efraín Antonio Campo Flores and Francisco Flores de Freitas, are accused of conspiring to ship cocaine to the United States, to be sold in New York.
lead_paragraph: The two men, Efraín Antonio Campo Flores and Francisco Flores de Freitas, are accused of conspiring to ship cocaine to the United States, to be sold in New York.

headline: De Blasio Attends Flight 587 Memorial, and This Time, He Isn’t Late
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio arrived early to a service for the jet that crashed in the Rockaways in 2001, taking a small step toward repairing his reputation for tardiness.
lead_paragraph: The announcement on his public schedule was simple enough: Mayor Bill de Blasio was to deliver remarks on Thursday at the annual memorial service for Flight 587, the American Airlines jet that crashed in the Rockaways.

headline: Fantasy Football Week 10: Bills at Jets
abstract: Fantasy football analysis for Thursday night’s game between the Buffalo Bills and the Jets.
lead_paragraph: Fantasy football analysis for Thursday night’s game between the Buffalo Bills and the Jets. Check back Friday for analysis on Sunday’s games and Monday’s matchup between the Houston Texans and the Cincinnati Bengals. You can also follow the Sablich brothers on Twitter at @5thDownFantasy.

lead_paragraph: Kurdish-led forces gained control over a major jihadist supply line between Syria and the Iraqi city of Mosul as part of a broader offensive to reclaim the town of Sinjar.

headline: 2 Said to Be Venezuelan First Lady’s Nephews Charged in Drug Plot
abstract: The two men were identified in an indictment unsealed in Manhattan as Efraín Antonio Campo Flores and Franqui Francisco Flores de Freitas, said to be nephews of Cilia Flores.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors in New York on Thursday charged two men — identified by a person briefed on the case as nephews of the wife of President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela — with conspiring to ship cocaine to the United States.

headline: Marco Canora Gives Hearth a Healthy Tuneup
abstract: The chef at the East Village restaurant will introduce a new menu in January, with a manifesto that explains his new approach.
lead_paragraph: The chef Marco Canora has adopted a pro-fat, anti-processed-food, back-to-basics regimen over the last few years that has transformed his health and the way he views food. Now he wants his East Village restaurant, Hearth, to follow suit.

headline: Review: ‘The 33’ Recalls a Chilean Mine Disaster and the Men Who Endured It
abstract: In this stirring and suspenseful story, trapped miners wait underground to be rescued, grappling with fear and bonding as brothers.
lead_paragraph: The ordeal of the 33 Chilean miners trapped deep inside the earth after the collapse of a mine shaft in August 2010 was both an intensely local story and a global phenomenon. As family members waited in a makeshift camp near the mine’s opening, viewers across the world followed the progress of the rescue efforts thanks to round-the-clock news media attention. We breathed sighs of relief and wept tears of joy when the men finally emerged, after more than two months in subterranean heat and darkness. And then, as is our habit, we moved on.

headline: With a Hush, an American Lexus Plant Goes to Work
abstract: Starting the new Lexus plant in Georgetown, Ky., meant introducing autoworkers to the brand’s methods, some of which call for a quiet assembly line.
lead_paragraph: Last month, a switch was flipped at a sprawling auto factory in Georgetown, Ky., and with it, Toyota started building Lexus cars in the United States for the first time.

headline: Russia Says Leak of Secret Nuclear Weapon Design Was an Accident
abstract: Portrayed as an accidental disclosure, the Russian news media’s reporting of a nuclear-armed drone submarine appeared to be a deliberate tactic by the Kremlin.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Kremlin’s chief spokesman has confirmed that a report broadcast on Russian television this week revealed the design of a secret nuclear weapon delivery system: a drone submarine that could attack coastlines.

headline: Transgender, and Facing Prison or Deportation
abstract: Immigration Equality and the Legal Aid Society discuss the plight of transgender people.

headline: Paul Ryan Stays Close to Home While Others Junketeer
keywords: ['Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Law and Legislation', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Watchdog groups are calling on the speaker to suspend privately-funded foreign junkets for lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: Representative Paul Ryan, the new Speaker of the House, is by now a famous homebody who emphatically prefers family life to the back slapping, nice-to-see-you routine of lawmakers, even when they travel to exotic places abroad in the name of fact finding. In the last 15 years, Mr. Ryan, unlike many colleagues, has accepted only two privately financed trips overseas. The distinction might have been encouraging  for Washington’s leading ethics watchdog groups last week in their call for the speaker to suspend the increasingly controversial foreign junkets paid for by private interests intent on swaying American lawmakers.

headline: ‘Empire’ Season 2, Episode 7: ‘True Love Never’
abstract: Everyone mostly stayed put this week, and it was unnerving.
lead_paragraph: In an “Empire” season that has drawn its strength from the dizzying unpredictability of its moves, Episode 7 felt like a bit of a come down. Everyone mostly stayed put this week, and it was unnerving. The show’s sole constant is deceiving appearances. In a week light on kidnapping, theft, murder and backstabbing, is the calm just a temporary comfort to snatch out from under us later?

headline: The Third Trail
abstract: I just finished hiking 2,700 miles. No, it wasn’t the Pacific Crest Trail, nor the Appalachian Trail.
lead_paragraph: I just finished hiking 2,700 miles. No, it wasn’t on one of those two trails. Not the Pacific Crest Trail of Reese Witherspoon’s movie Wild, nor Robert Redford’s Appalachian Trail from A Walk in the Woods.

headline: Elvis Costello’s ‘Unfaithful Music and Disappearing Ink’
abstract: Known for his compact pop lyrics, Elvis Costello spares little in this memoir.
lead_paragraph: “Life takes much longer than the average pop song,” Elvis Costello writes in his uneven and bloated autobiography, in which life takes much, much longer. You wouldn’t guess from this audiobook’s 18½ hours (“Swann’s Way” read by Simon Vance is a mere 17½) that Costello shot to fame with songs that could condense a great deal of feeling and literate expression into bursts of little more than three minutes.

lead_paragraph: Volkswagen, trying to get to the bottom of its emissions-cheating scandal, on Thursday pressured employees to tell what they know, announcing an amnesty program for informants that will expire at the end of the month.

headline: Being An Inflation Hawk Means Never Having To Say You’re Sorry
abstract: Because nobody will mention your past predictions.
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Lacker, president of the Richmond Fed, is worried about inflation unless the Fed tightens quickly, ignoring the worriers. Here’s what he just said:

headline: A Tinder Turn Toward the Indifferent
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Wines', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Veganism', 'Grandparents']
abstract: Plus: a dress doused in red wine; concerns over vegan-only dietary demands; and respecting the wishes of a new mother.
lead_paragraph: I am newly single and enjoy meeting women on Tinder. It’s often difficult to know if a Tinder match is worth meeting in the real world until after you have invested time chatting with the woman via the app. The number of matches can be overwhelming, making it a challenge to juggle multiple conversations. Sometimes these chats fizzle on their own. But often I’m given a phone number just as my interest wanes. How should I deal with this?

headline: ISIS Claims Responsibility for Blasts That Killed Dozens in Beirut
keywords: ['Bombs and Explosives', 'Terrorism', 'Shiite Muslims', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The bombings, near a Palestinian refugee camp that has absorbed many Syrians, killed at least 43 people, according to the Lebanese Health Ministry.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A fiery double suicide bombing terrorized a mostly Shiite residential area of southern Beirut on Thursday, ripping through a busy shopping district at rush hour. The Lebanese Health Ministry said at least 43 people had been killed and more than 200 wounded in the worst attack to strike the city in years.

lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz continued to pound Senator Marco Rubio over his immigration record on Thursday, escalating the tension between the two rivals for the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: Tito King’s Kitchen and Bago Join a Filipino Feast in the East Village
abstract: Two new restaurants with modest, occasionally boundary-crossing delights set up shop around the neighborhood’s Little Manila.
lead_paragraph: Bonito flakes wave like tattered flags, great shreds of them over a heap of ground pork still agitated from the frying pan, riled up by fermented black beans and fish sauce. Japanese Kewpie mayonnaise brings scattered sweet high notes and a deeper tang than its Western cousins. Under it all, French fries lie in wait, with charred tips.

headline: Apple Apologizes to Black Students Ejected From Store in Australia

headline: Further Speculations on White Mortality
abstract: More on the mysteries surrounding (now-revised) estimates on rising white mortality.
lead_paragraph: I wrote my column last weekend on the much-discussed Anne Case/Angus Deaton paper on rising white mortality rates, and since then there’s been an important emendation to their data from Columbia’s Andrew Gelman: In a nutshell, Gelman argues that a finer-grained look at the numbers suggests that 1) the overall white mortality rate has re-stabilized, rather than continuing to rise, since the mid-2000s, that 2) the mortality increase was actually more notable for thirtysomethings and early fortysomethings than for the 45-54 cohort, and that 3) it’s white women whose mortality rates have kept on increasing over the last decade, even as white men have seen their mortality rates fall a little once again.

headline: Missy Elliott Releases New Video
abstract: A decade after her last album, Missy Elliott releases a video of a new single.
lead_paragraph: A decade after her last album, Missy Elliott released a music video for her new single, “WTF (Where They From)” on Thursday morning.

headline: More Virtual Reality Videos to Watch
abstract: A not-so-definitive list of other immersive, 360-degree shorts to view with your Google Cardboard.
lead_paragraph: Last weekend, The New York Times delivered 1.2 million Google Cardboard viewers to home-delivery subscribers and asked them to watch our new virtual-reality film, “The Displaced,” about three refugee children growing up in Lebanon, South Sudan and Ukraine. This is the first in a series of virtual-reality films the magazine intends to produce. (We also experimented with V.R. before this with a short film about the “Walking New York” issue.) V.R. is still an emerging medium but there have already been a number of important projects from a variety of creators that indicate the potential of this technology. Below are a few of our favorites.

headline: The Web of Deals That John Malone Weaves

lead_paragraph: The media mogul John C. Malone is never one to shy away from complicated deals. Two announcements from his companies on Thursday — involving tracking stocks, spinoffs and tax efficiencies – exemplify how he can spin an intricate web of investments.

headline: 1953 | Immersive Technology Debuts, in the Movie Ads

lead_paragraph: This month, Times readers were introduced to virtual reality as a new means of storytelling.

headline: A Refugee Crisis in Lebanon Hides in Plain Sight

lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — At first glance, evening on Beirut’s neon-lit, bustling Hamra Street looks much as it did a few years ago. But slow down and look around.

headline: Making a Museum Out of a Mountain
abstract: In picture-perfect South Tyrol on the Austrian border of Italy, the legendary mountaineer Reinhold Messner has created six eccentric museums devoted to his lifelong passion. Naturally, to get to each one is a hike.
lead_paragraph: The only hiking I’ve ever known or half-enjoyed has involved flat terrain, a swimmable body of water as a destination and at least one parent to whine to along the way. But in September, I found myself 5,000 feet up a mountain, lost, alone, without a working cellphone, not even close to where I was supposed to be going, and completely happy. As I gnawed my way up the Dolomite peak of Kronplatz mountain, I had to stop every 100 yards and catch my breath. It hadn’t even occurred to me that the trek would be difficult or that I should bring water. But whatever panic and thirst and lung-burn I experienced was mitigated by the frosted clover and edelweiss and enzian, which I could see the sun thawing in real time as I walked. The air smelled sweetly of manure and cut grass; the tinkle of cowbells and the call of actual cuckoo birds echoed through the valleys.

headline: U.S. Smoking Rate Declines, but Poor Remain at Higher Risk
abstract: About a third of Americans insured by Medicaid in 2014 were cigarette smokers. The figure for the privately insured? 13 percent.

lead_paragraph: BOCA RATON, Fla. — A few hours before the start of the 2009 World Series between the Yankees and the Philadelphia Phillies, Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman picked up the phone and called Dave Dombrowski, his counterpart with the Detroit Tigers. He wanted to see who might be available in a trade over the winter.

headline: French Photographer Wins Prix Pictet
abstract: Valérie Belin has won the sixth Prix Pictet for photography, for her series “Still life, 2014.”
lead_paragraph: The French photographer Valérie Belin has won the sixth Prix Pictet for photography, for her series “Still life, 2014.” The award was announced by Kofi Annan, the former secretary general of the United Nations and the honorary president of the prize, on Thursday at the Musée d’Art Moderne in Paris, at the opening reception for an exhibition of work by the 12 finalists.

headline: After a Mass Extinction, Only the Small Survive
keywords: ['Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Fossils', 'Paleontology', 'Fish and Other Marine Life']
abstract: A study of fossils from before and after a mass extinction 359 million years ago found that animals that flourished after the event were smaller on average.
lead_paragraph: From sharks to giraffes, many of Earth’s biggest and most magnificent species are threatened with extinction. A new study of the fossil record indicates that once large vertebrates disappear, evolution cannot quickly restore them — for tens of millions of years, most animals remain small.

headline: Huge Valeant Stake Exposes Rift at Sequoia Fund

lead_paragraph: For more than four decades, the Sequoia Fund has been the envy of Wall Street, one of the rare funds to consistently beat the market. Known for its close ties to Warren E. Buffett, the fund at its peak managed more than $9 billion. It was in such demand that it closed to new investors in 2013, a move that enhanced its mystique.

headline: At Paris Photo, a Wide-Ranging Mix
abstract: Beginning today, 147 galleries and 27 art-book dealers and publishers gather for the world’s largest photography fair. A rundown of what to expect.
lead_paragraph: Beginning today, 147 galleries and 27 art-book dealers and publishers will gather in Paris’s enormous, glass-domed Grand Palais for Paris Photo, the world’s largest photography fair. With it come a slew of satellite events, including the independent publishing fair Offprint Paris, a Martin Scorsese exhibition at La Cinémathèque Française and the photographer Alex Prager’s first solo show in France at the Galerie Des Galeries. And inside Paris Photo itself, visitors often lose their bearings and entire days wandering among the endless rows of stalls. With that in mind, here are a few highlights from the fair.

headline: Letters: On Fiction and Fracking
abstract: Readers respond to a recent interview with Matt Ridley, a review of Anthony Marra’s “The Tsar of Love and Techno” and more.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In ‘Star Wars and the Power of Costume,’ You Are What You Wear
abstract: An exhibition opening in Times Square drives home how the costumes made each character indelible.
lead_paragraph: However you feel about nudity in movies, walking through the new exhibition at Discovery Times Square will certainly lead you to one realization: A naked actor is a wasted opportunity. The right costume in the right circumstance can be as important a storytelling device as any line of dialogue or special-effects gimmick. It can become practically a character in and of itself.

headline: The Secrets in Greenland’s Ice Sheet
abstract: By studying the largest glaciers on earth, scientists hope to determine whether we’ll have time to respond to climate change or whether it’s already too late.
lead_paragraph: At one point several hundred thousand years ago, snow began falling over the center of the earth’s largest island. The snow did not melt, and in the years that followed, storms brought even more. All around Greenland, the arctic temperatures remained low enough for the snow to last past spring and summer. It piled up, year after year, century after century, millennium after millennium. Eventually, the snow became the Greenland ice sheet, a blanket of ice so huge that it covered 650,000 square miles and reached a thickness of 10,000 feet in places. Meanwhile, in Antarctica, a similar process was well underway. There, as snow fell upon snow for years without end, the ice sheet spread out over a much vaster area: 5.4 million square miles, an expanse far larger than the lower 48 states. By the start of the modern era, when power plants and electric lights began illuminating the streets of Manhattan, about 75 percent of the world’s freshwater had been frozen into the ice sheets that lay over these lands at opposite ends of the earth.

headline: Thanksgiving Wine 2015
abstract: Bottles to enhance this year’s holiday feast.

headline: Fret-Free Wine Options for Thanksgiving

lead_paragraph: Nothing ought to be simpler than selecting wines for Thanksgiving, right? You pick a few bottles that you like, open them and everybody’s happy.

headline: McDonald’s C.E.O. on All Day Breakfast, Hourly Wages and Wall Street

lead_paragraph: A little more than eight months after he took the helm as chief executive of the McDonald’s Corporation, Steve Easterbrook spent this week in New York trying to persuade investors that the company is pulling itself out of a prolonged slump. Below is an edited transcript of a brief interview with The New York Times.

lead_paragraph: Out Magazine, noting the advances of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people since 2008, has named President Obama its Ally of the Year, making him the first sitting American president to pose for the cover of a gay magazine.

lead_paragraph: Two of Broadway’s biggest stars, Patti LuPone and Christine Ebersole, will portray competing cosmetics industry executives in a new musical, “War Paint,” scheduled to premiere in Chicago next summer.

headline: The Illustrated Interview: Richard Branson
abstract: The British entrepreneur, whose multibillion-dollar empire includes the world’s first commercial spaceline, sketches his responses to a brief questionnaire.

headline: Amid Unrest in Missouri, University System Picks Michael Middleton as Interim Chief
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Discrimination', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks']
abstract: The Missouri state university system named Mr. Middleton as interim president to lead the four-school system as it responds to recent racially charged campus clashes.
lead_paragraph: The Missouri state university system on Thursday named as interim president an African-American who said he understood the complexity and nuance of the recent racially charged campus clashes, adding that while some people will hold his race against him, it probably also played a role in his getting the job.

headline: An Unlikely Union: Tiffany and Dover Street Market
abstract: The store’s president, Adrian Joffe, and the jewelry house’s design director, Francesca Amfitheatrof, discuss their new limited-edition collection.
lead_paragraph: On a rainy afternoon earlier this week, with the Flatiron district in near-gridlock, Adrian Joffe, the president and C.E.O. of Comme des Garçons and Dover Street Market, went for tea at Tiffany & Company. The occasion was Dover Street’s new collaboration with the brand — and its new design director, Francesca Amfitheatrof.

headline: U.N. Security Council Seeks to Head Off Mass Atrocities in Burundi
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The Security Council called for a bolstered international presence in the East African nation but stopped short of sanctions against those who incite violence.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Spurred by fears of mass atrocities, the United Nations Security Council on Thursday unanimously passed a resolution that calls for a bolstered international presence in Burundi but stops short of sanctions against those who incite violence.

headline: Vincent Asaro, Accused in Lufthansa Heist, Is Found Not Guilty
keywords: ['Organized Crime', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: A federal jury in Brooklyn cleared Mr. Asaro, 80, on all counts in a trial for charges related to the 1978 Lufthansa robbery, along with other acts of racketeering and extortion.
lead_paragraph: Vincent Asaro, the reputed mobster charged in connection with the notorious 1978 Lufthansa robbery, walked out of federal court in Brooklyn on Thursday a free man after a jury cleared him of racketeering and other charges.

headline: Anheuser-Busch InBev’s Plan to Finance Beer Deal
abstract: Data suggests that the brewer is avoiding about $300 million of outlays to lenders by self-arranging $75 billion of debt to buy SABMiller.
lead_paragraph: It’s rare that a big nonfinancial company arranges its own debt – and $75 billion worth is a first. That, though, is what Anheuser-Busch InBev has done with the five-part loan package backing its deal to buy SABMiller for more than $100 billion, which was formally announced on Wednesday.

headline: Ohio Man Arrested After Social Posts Urging Killing of Military Members
abstract: The case against Terrence J. McNeil, 25, centers on posts on social media seen as promoting specific acts of violence in the name of the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal authorities arrested an Ohio hospital worker on a terrorism-related charge Thursday, accusing him of declaring his support for the Islamic State on social media and calling for the killing of United States service members.

headline: 5 New Apple Varieties
abstract: ­Junami, Kanzi, RubyFrost, Opal and SnapDragon are a handful of the newest kind.
lead_paragraph: ­Junami, Kanzi, RubyFrost, Opal and SnapDragon are a handful of the newest kind.

headline: Arguments From Irrelevant Authority
abstract: Fame is no indication of expertise.
lead_paragraph: One curious aspect of economic debate these past five years or so has been the extent to which people demanding fiscal austerity and/or higher interest rates rely on what I think of as spurious authority figures — people who are well-known for some reason that has nothing at all to do with expertise in the subject at hand. I remember being told that the deficit must be a terrible threat because Admiral Mullen, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said so; so, are we going to rely on Janet Yellen to set naval strategy?

headline: N.F.L. Week 10 Previews and Picks
abstract: The Cardinals will play the Seahawks in a matchup that last season marked a turning point for both teams.

headline: 75 Years After Steinbeck Sailed, a Boat Is Readied to Go Back to Sea
keywords: ['Boats and Boating', 'Books and Literature', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Fishing, Commercial']
abstract: John Gregg knows $1 million was too much to pay for a 78-year-old wooden fishing boat, but he’s spending an additional $2 million to refit it as a science and education vessel.
lead_paragraph: PORT TOWNSEND, Wash. — Rule 1 in the world of working wooden boats, since the days of dugout canoes and fishing skiffs, has been that when they are no longer of use or they are lost at sea, people build new ones and move on. Sentimentality and fussy restoration are rarely in the tool kit.

headline: Massachusetts Regulator Says Real Estate Affiliate Faked Proxy Votes
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Private Equity']
abstract: The vote was crucial to the sale of American Realty businesses to the private equity giant Apollo Global Management, a deal that later collapsed.
lead_paragraph: Massachusetts’ securities regulator is taking aim at an affiliate of American Realty Capital, accusing it of faking proxy votes for a September shareholder meeting that was crucial to the planned $378 million sale of American Realty businesses to the private equity giant Apollo Global Management.

headline: John Steinbeck, Afloat
abstract: Boats and water figure prominently in John Steinbeck’s writing. Here are a few examples.
lead_paragraph: Boats and water figure prominently in John Steinbeck’s writing. They often appear as characters, like in “The Log From the Sea of Cortez,” but also as metaphors for mobility and transformation. Here are examples of Steinbeck’s nautical passages, literal and otherwise.

headline: Kevin Barry’s ‘Beatlebone’ Wins Goldsmiths Prize
abstract: The prize, established in 2013, honors inventive fiction.
lead_paragraph: The Irish writer Kevin Barry won the Goldsmiths Prize on Wednesday for his second novel, “Beatlebone,” which imagines John Lennon visiting a small island off the west coast of Ireland in 1978. The prize, established in 2013, honors British and Irish writers for “fiction that breaks the mold or opens up new possibilities for the novel form,” and comes with an award of £10,000, or about $15,000.

headline: Goldman Sachs Names 425 New Managing Directors
abstract: Nearly one-third of the newly promoted employees are millennials, and one-quarter are women.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a third of the Goldman Sachs Group’s 425 newly minted managing directors are millennials, or people born after 1980. Forty percent were hired as analysts. Roughly 21 percent are former summer interns.

headline: France Says Climate Talks Must Produce Binding Deal
abstract: President François Hollande was responding to remarks by Secretary of State John Kerry, who said that any agreement reached at the climate conference was “not going to be a treaty.”
lead_paragraph: PARIS — French officials said on Thursday that any agreement at the coming climate conference in Paris would have to be legally binding, expressing alarm at comments by the American secretary of state that suggested the opposite.

headline: When Office Chaos Threatens to Overshadow Customer Service
keywords: ['Workplace Environment', 'Customer Relations', 'Executives and Management (Theory)', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: A front desk coordinator at a fast-growing software company asks how to jump-start an effective planning system.
lead_paragraph: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: After a week of debate over whether Ben Carson really won a scholarship to West Point, Republicans have refocused the question of military service on Hillary Rodham Clinton, expressing doubts about her claim that she tried to join the Marines in the 1970s.

keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Minimum Wage', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Productivity', 'Tips and Tipping', 'Unemployment', 'Wages and Salaries']

lead_paragraph: For almost 40 years, Sophie Gimbel influenced American fashion as the head of the Saks custom department.

headline: Myanmar Generals Set the Stage for Their Own Exit
abstract: The military let the vote take place unimpeded, and while that posture could change, all signs point to a peaceful transfer of power to the National League for Democracy.
lead_paragraph: NAYPYIDAW, Myanmar — This capital, built from scratch by Myanmar’s former dictators, is filled with soldiers, police officers and civil servants. But even here, where most people work for the government, they voted to throw it out of power.

headline: Ai Weiwei Debuts His First Jewelry Collection
abstract: The artist discusses his new line, out this week, which is based on his work with rebars gathered after the 2008 Sichuan earthquake.
lead_paragraph: Ai Weiwei is not the type of artist you expect to work small. His most celebrated installations have been created on an epic scale: works made from 99 tons of steel, say, or 8 million sunflower seeds. So the news that the 58-year-old Chinese artist and activist has been secretly working on a collection of jewelry, which launched in London this week, might come as something of a surprise. Is he going in a new direction?

headline: Review: In ‘James White,’ Facing Adulthood With Uncertainty
abstract: The title character, played by Christopher Abbott, grapples with his future while caring for his ailing mother in this Josh Mond film.
lead_paragraph: “James White” burrows so deeply into the consciousness of its title character, a flailing young Manhattanite played by Christopher Abbott (“Girls”), that his self-loathing and panic feel contagious. Who hasn’t, at a certain point in life, faced a sink-or-swim moment when a promising future suddenly began to seem out of reach? James combats the terror of grown-up responsibility with copious amounts of booze and late-night carousing in which he picks fights in bars and behaves like a brat. But Mr. Abbott’s performance makes you aware that James’s bad behavior stems from fear; deep down he has a warm heart.

headline: In Return to St. John’s, Chris Mullin Gets a Little Help From His Friends
abstract: Mullin, the team’s first-year coach, had no coaching or recruiting experience, so he tapped the services of some longtime basketball buddies.
lead_paragraph: The first call came for Barry Rohrssen while Kentucky’s charter jet sat on the tarmac in Cleveland in the wee hours of March 29. The Wildcats had just outlasted Notre Dame to advance to the Final Four in men’s basketball. Text messages poured into his phone like rain pelting a sidewalk. More than 120 still sit there today, unread, tiny red tokens reminding Rohrssen, a Kentucky assistant coach, of the feeling of being on top of the college basketball world.

headline: Agatha Christie’s Mr. Quin Finds New Life as an App
abstract: A new app is released based on Agatha Christie’s ghoulish short story series “The Mysterious Mr Quin.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON– Eighty-five years after its first publication, Agatha Christie’s ghoulish short story series “The Mysterious Mr. Quin” is getting new life — as an app.

headline: Review: In ‘You Us We All,’ a Symbolic Hope Writes to Pop Divas
abstract: This operatic modern masque, written, directed and designed by Andrew Ondrejcak, with music by Shara Worden, is at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: The amusing Twitter account named Kim Kierkegaardashian mashes up the anguished writings of Soren Kierkegaard with the daffy public statements of Kim Kardashian: “When the child must be weaned, the mother too is not without sorrow, but you and your toddler can still wear matching outfits.”

lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “By the Sea,” “The 33” and “James White.”
