lead_paragraph: In January 2012, Sheldon Silver, then the New York Assembly speaker, and a large real estate company signed a deal that promised to be beneficial to him.

headline: Uterus Transplants May Soon Help Some Infertile Women in the U.S. Become Pregnant
abstract: Surgeons at the Cleveland Clinic are set to become the first in the United States to transplant a uterus.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Six doctors swarmed around the body of the deceased organ donor and quickly started to operate.

headline: Masterpieces of Japanese Art at the Met
abstract: This lavish show includes 160 objects from one of the most comprehensive collections of Japanese art in the West.
lead_paragraph: Has there ever been a more beautiful autumn than the one now on the wane in New York City, with our parks still looking like cloth-of-gold, and flocks of southbound geese calling over our rivers? We know there were just such seasons in centuries past in Japan. Artists tell us so. In a 16th-century hanging scroll, the painter Shikibu Terutada depicts fall leaves and flowers as last-chance blasts of color. In the 18th century, Maruyama Okyo fills an all-but-empty folding screen with the image of a single goose descending to withered reeds.

headline: Uzbekistan Releases Political Prisoner After 21 Years
abstract: The prisoner, Murod Juraev, had been imprisoned since Sept. 18, 1994, and was sometimes called the world’s longest-serving political prisoner by rights groups.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — An Uzbek detainee sometimes called the world’s longest-serving political prisoner by rights groups was released on Thursday, having spent 21 years behind bars on various pretexts and trumped-up charges.

headline: A New Place to Celebrate Cool California Design
abstract: From the owners of Reform Gallery comes the Landing, which opens Saturday with an exhibition of work by the artist J. B. Blunk.
lead_paragraph: Running a gallery can be “a little bit like an adoption agency,” says Gerard O’Brien. “You want to find the right home for these things because they have intrinsic value.” For more than a decade, his salon-style showroom, Reform Gallery, has been an insider resource for furniture by the post-G.I. Bill generation of West Coast artists, with pieces from the wire sculptor Ruth Asawa to the potter Doyle Lane. “California has always been this incredible place for makers,” O’Brien says, sitting on a loading dock in Paul Tuttle’s iconic leather “Z” chair, which was designed in Santa Barbara and produced in-state. “It was the land where you could come dream and make those dreams come true.”

headline: Lois Greenfield: Moving Still
abstract: Images from the dance photographer’s new book, out this month.
lead_paragraph: Images from the dance photographer’s new book, out this month.

headline: G.O.P. Candidates Target Immigration Policy as Litmus Test in Presidential Race
abstract: The long-distance skirmishing illustrated the degree to which several Republican candidates see immigration as the most potent weapon in the presidential contest.
lead_paragraph: A long-simmering debate over immigration in the Republican presidential contest boiled over on Thursday, as Senator Ted Cruz accused his colleague, Senator Marco Rubio, of “trying to jam this amnesty down the American people’s throats.”

headline: Eleven Wedding Gifts for Holiday Entertaining

lead_paragraph: Accessories to help newlyweds set the mood for a joyful dinner.

headline: Review: ‘Our Guy, Cy: The Songs of Cy Coleman’ Pays Tribute to a Man and His Musicals
abstract: Randy Graff, Cady Huffman and Judy Kaye, three alumnae of Coleman shows, perform an affectionate tribute, directed by Will Nunziata, at Feinstein’s/54 Below.
lead_paragraph: The songs of Cy Coleman are not given to navel-gazing introspection. Their characters are too busy elbowing their way through the show business jungle. Rolling with the punches and coming up bruised but exuberant.

headline: Skills and Strategies | Annotating to Engage, Analyze, Connect and Create
abstract: Annotation is not just a classroom exercise, but something we all do all the time. With these ideas we hope to expand students’ notions of what annotation can be and inspire them to experiment with new ways of doing it — in class and out.
lead_paragraph: What do your students think annotation looks like? For many, it probably begins and ends with the image of an assigned novel bristling with yellow Post-its.

headline: Artur Mas Loses Bid to Remain Leader in Catalonia
abstract: The vote by Catalan lawmakers throws into chaos the region’s three-year drive for independence from Spain.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Catalonia’s three-year drive for independence was thrown into turmoil on Thursday when Catalan lawmakers voted against reinstating Artur Mas — the politician who has led the push to secede from Spain — as head of the regional government.

headline: Everyone Is Upset, or Not Upset, About Christmas
abstract: The fight over the “War on Christmas” starts earlier every year.

headline: Regional Newspapers Weigh In on Syria Talks
abstract: Editorial opinion in the region is divided over whether international talks this weekend in Vienna have any chance of reaching a postwar political deal to end the civil war in Syria.
lead_paragraph: Diplomats from around the world will try again in Vienna this weekend to find a way to end the four-year-old civil war in Syria. Judging by editorial opinion in the region, though, the region is sharply divided over whether the talks have any chance of success.

headline: Christopher Chiappa’s Latest Obsession: The Amazing Egg
abstract: Eggs by the hundreds, gargantuan stoves and the ephemera of Frank Stella.
lead_paragraph: Fried eggs sliding down the walls, spreading in the corners, sprawling across the floor. No, you haven’t walked into some restaurant kitchen run amok or a twisted rendition of Dr. Seuss. This is “Livestrong,” an installation by Christopher Chiappa, his third solo show at Kate Werble Gallery on Vandam Street, which opens Saturday.

abstract: The museum, once the home of an oil and rail magnate and his much younger wife, is relining its music room with these luxurious pieces.

headline: 19th-Century Parks Drawings for New York City Are Destined for Display
abstract: The drawings, representing designs by Frederick Law Olmsted, Calvert Vaux and others, were retrieved after being put up for sale through Christie’s.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, New York City officials learned that a slightly moldy trove of 128 construction plans for local parks was slated for sale through Christie’s. The city requested that the sale be called off, and since then those 19th-century drawings have been repaired and returned to the government. The city is now planning to put them on display.

headline: In Swan Song, Arne Duncan Extols School Progress Under His Tenure
abstract: The departing education secretary visited a once-failing high school in Boston to highlight the progress that has been made under the administration’s signature school reform program.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — With the Obama administration’s signature school reform program coming to an end and battered by politics, the secretary of education, Arne Duncan, came to a once-failing high school in one of this city’s most troubled neighborhoods on Thursday to highlight the progress that has been made here and across the country.

headline: Hillary Clinton Unveils $30 Billion Plan to Help Coal Towns
keywords: ['Environment', 'Mines and Mining', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton, seeking to balance support for environmental regulations with the effect those rules could have on workers, unveiled a $30 billion plan to help miners and communities where coal plants close.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton, seeking to balance support for new environmental regulations with the effect those rules could have on workers, unveiled a $30 billion plan on Thursday to help coal miners adjust to their changing landscape.

headline: A Mail-Art Performance and Other Treats at Performa 15
abstract: The artist Brian Fuata will interact with items from the archive of Ray Johnson, a mail-art pioneer, and Rainer Ganahl will sell off books to explore Walter Benjamin’s thoughts on owning a library.
lead_paragraph: The Miser has an ambivalent relationship with performance art. Some pieces can come off as esoteric or nonsensical; others can be profound, even moving. (Just ask the teary-eyed spectators who attended Marina Abramovic’s Museum of Modern Art retrospective five years ago.) At Performa 15, a three-week biennial devoted to the art form, not everything will stick. But with about 30 artists taking part, it shouldn’t be difficult to find something to love.

headline: Review: Aji 10 Latin Cuisine & Pisco Bar in Norwalk
abstract: At Aji 10 Latin Cuisine & Pisco Bar in Norwalk, the “modern Latin-Nikkei” menu sprinkles Latin-style dishes with tastes of Japan.
lead_paragraph: In keeping with its name, Aji 10 Latin Cuisine & Pisco Bar in Norwalk offers an array of Peruvian and other Latin dishes. But the restaurant also offers a sprinkling of tempura and sushi rolls — part of a menu it describes as “modern Latin-Nikkei cuisine” which draws from Peru’s influential Japanese immigrant community.

lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

lead_paragraph: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Recalling the Outlaw Eye of Dash Snow
abstract: The artists Dan Colen, Hanna Liden and Nate Lowman, and Blair Hansen, director of the Dash Snow Archive, discuss the subject of “Dash Snow: Freeze Means Run.”
lead_paragraph: GREENWICH, Conn. — For a press-wary paranoiac, the artist Dash Snow towed around an immense burden of public myth during his short lifetime. By the time he died from an overdose in 2009 at the age of 27, he had come to stand almost single-handedly for a downtown New York art and party scene that arose just before 9/11 and flourished in the anxious years afterward, known for its drug-fueled excess and adolescent rebellion in the face of a city rapidly becoming more homogeneous, wealth-obsessed and heavily policed. That Mr. Snow came from art-world privilege — he was an estranged member of the de Menil collecting family — made the narrative that grew up around him all the more loaded. He was resented, glorified, dismissed and envied, often in the space of a single conversation, regarded as a genuinely troubled, politically aware poet of early 21st-century anomie or a heavily tattooed epigone of a counterculture that lost its steam long before his arrival.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: A Five-Artist Exhibition Goes Sci-Fi at Mitchell Algus
abstract: The show, “The Description of a New World, Called the Blazing-World,” includes work by Cajsa von Zeipel and Anna Uddenberg, among others.
lead_paragraph: More than the sum of its parts, this five-artist show exudes a tantalizing sci-fi vibe. Its title, “The Description of a New World, Called the Blazing-World,” is taken from that of a utopian tale by the 17th-century writer and philosopher Margaret Cavendish.

headline: Eva and Franco Mattes, the Art of Deletion
abstract: An Internet “content moderator” might sound like an innocent job, but an exhibition by Eva and Franco Mattes explains how these anonymous workers change the content of the Internet.

headline: Mead, a Beverage From the Middle Ages, Makes a Comeback
abstract: New Jersey’s lone legal maker of the fermented honey drink adds a modern twist to a Middle Ages favorite.
lead_paragraph: In an alley behind a shopping mall in Vauxhall, a modern version of a fermented beverage popular in the Middle Ages is being produced, sampled and sold: mead.

headline: Review: Here’s Looking at ‘Ingrid Bergman — In Her Own Words’
abstract: This documentary by Stig Bjorkman blends Bergman’s copious documentation of her own life with reminiscences from relatives and colleagues.
lead_paragraph: Ingrid Bergman, whose personal life could seem more electrifying than her movies, had the kind of towering self-possession that is a requisite for immortal stars, but also for modern women. Toward the end of her life, when her daughter Isabella Rossellini asked why she had kept so many letters, diaries, photos and other mementos, Bergman responded with consummate movie-star sang-froid: “I always knew I was going to be famous.” (She died in 1982 at 67.) Ms. Rossellini shared this anecdote in The New Yorker in 1989, in a Talk of the Town item in which she described her mother’s trove — letters from Alfred Hitchcock and Ernest Hemingway included — and its meaning.

headline: Review: In ‘Moana With Sound,’ Island Songs and the Crash of Waves
abstract: For this update of a 1926 “docufiction” movie, the original filmmakers’ daughter traveled back to a South Sea island to record songs, dialogue and sound effects.
lead_paragraph: This film is designated as a Critics’ Pick.

headline: Smithsonian’s Renwick Gallery Reopens With a New Focus
abstract: After being shuttered for two years of renovations, the Renwick, part of the Smithsonian American Art Museum, has an updated mission.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Renwick Gallery, housed in an ornate, 156-year-old confection here that was the first American building constructed as a public art museum, begins a new chapter in its history on Friday.

headline: ‘Unorthodox’ Faces Paradox at the Jewish Museum
abstract: This exhibition of works by 55 artists from around the world is engaging and often entertaining but does it live up to its bigger ambitions?

headline: Gene Amdahl, Pioneer of Mainframe Computing, Dies at 92
abstract: Dr. Amdahl played a crucial role in developing the IBM System/360 series, which influenced computer design for years.
lead_paragraph: Gene Amdahl, a trailblazer in the design of IBM’s mainframe computers, which became the central nervous system for businesses large and small throughout the world, died on Tuesday at a nursing home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 92.

headline: Mother of 3 Regains Her Footing After Being Shot
abstract: Yennifez Marte was the unintended victim in a gang-related shooting in 2008. After a long, painful recovery, she has found a new job and permanent housing for her daughters.
lead_paragraph: Balloons began popping, three in quick succession.

lead_paragraph: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Review: ‘Shelter’ Focuses on an Addict and an Immigrant, Both Homeless
abstract: Paul Bettany’s film stars Jennifer Connelly and Anthony Mackie as desperate drifters on the streets of New York.
lead_paragraph: The more tolerable moments in “Shelter,” Paul Bettany’s overwrought cri de coeur about homelessness in New York City, show its characters desperately navigating the city’s overstressed shelter system. These grim scenes, filmed in shades of brown and gray, suggest the combination of fear, exhaustion and uncertainty in people at the mercy of an impersonal bureaucracy that shuffles them from place to place. But the movie never bothers to show you life inside a shelter dormitory or tries to convey a broader vision of the city’s street culture. It is too busy showcasing its star Jennifer Connelly (Mr. Bettany’s wife) in degrading situations.

headline: A New York Times/CBS News Poll on the Democratic Race
abstract: Although her lead over Bernie Sanders has slipped since September, Hillary Rodham Clinton is dominating the race for the Democratic nomination, buoyed by primary voters’ perceptions of her experience and leadership. Mr. Sanders, who trails by double digits, is preferred by those who want change, and he holds distinct advantages on speaking the truth and not being beholden to special interests, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
lead_paragraph: Although her lead over Bernie Sanders has slipped since September, Hillary Rodham Clinton is dominating the race for the Democratic nomination, buoyed by primary voters’ perceptions of her experience and leadership. Mr. Sanders, who trails by double digits, is preferred by those who want change, and he holds distinct advantages on speaking the truth and not being beholden to special interests, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: Poll Shows Hillary Clinton Is Seen as More Likely Than Bernie Sanders to Be Effective
abstract: In a new poll, 62 percent said Mrs. Clinton could bring about real change in Washington, compared with 51 percent for Mr. Sanders.
lead_paragraph: With the Democratic presidential nomination contest all but officially a two-person race, Hillary Rodham Clinton appears vastly better positioned than Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont to persuade party primary voters that she would be more effective at passing her agenda and dealing with international crises, according to a New York Times/CBS News survey released Thursday.

headline: How the New York Times/CBS News Poll Was Conducted
abstract: The latest Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Nov. 6 through 10 with 1,495 adults throughout the United States. Of those, 1,259 said they were registered to vote.
lead_paragraph: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Nov. 6 through 10 with 1,495 adults throughout the United States. Of those, 1,259 said they were registered to vote.

headline: New York’s Week in Pictures: Nov. 13
abstract: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images from the city’s Veterans Day parade and a Bronx funeral.
lead_paragraph: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images from the city’s Veterans Day parade and a Bronx funeral.

headline: Review: In Fellipe Barbosa’s ‘Casa Grande,’ a Teenager Awakens to His Father’s Financial Ruin and More
abstract: This Brazilian film charts a teenage boy’s journey from self-entitlement to a painful understanding of class privilege.
lead_paragraph: Fellipe Barbosa’s “Casa Grande” opens with a shot of a house in Rio de Janeiro, piled high with rooms and viewed from a backyard with a swimming pool and hot tub. The opulence conceals a rot within the household. Dad has been playing fast and loose with his hedge fund, and soon his 17-year-old son, Jean, is taking the bus to school instead of the customary car with driver.

lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

abstract: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.
lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Review: ‘Entertainment’ Features a Comic Who Is Cracking Up
abstract: Gregg Turkington plays a version of his real-life stand-up persona, performing gigs at seedy clubs in the California desert, in Rick Alverson’s film.
lead_paragraph: Watching “Entertainment” is a profoundly uncomfortable, some would say repellent, experience that isn’t easily forgotten. Yet I left this barbed portrait of a cracking-up comic with more than a little respect for its fearless director, Rick Alverson, and his trusting star, Gregg Turkington. You can’t deny that they’re a match made in heaven.

headline: At Aeroflot, It’s Patriotism Over Profits as Russia Pressures Industry
abstract: As Russia struggles under sanctions and low oil prices, it is pushing its national airline and others to help support homegrown companies.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — All smiles and cheery banter, the flight attendants greeted travelers on board Russia’s newest passenger jet.

headline: Spare Times for Children Listings for Nov. 13-19
abstract: You can meet all kinds of people at a book festival. Just consider Roy Sullivan and Mary Fields.
lead_paragraph: You can meet all kinds of people at a book festival. Just consider Roy Sullivan and Mary Fields.

headline: Review: ‘Funny Bunny,’ About a Trio of Outsiders
abstract: Alison Bagnall’s film is a portrait of characters in various states of arrested development.

headline: Review: ‘Heist,’ a Sly Thriller That Works Hard
abstract: Scott Mann wrings the best from the material in this movie about mob connections and outrageous crimes.
lead_paragraph: Whatever its flaws, “Heist” is to be commended for repeatedly finding ways to distract us from them. Battling a preposterous plot and second-tier performances that are, at best, serviceable, this roll-along thriller from Scott Mann works its keister off to turn beef jerky into chateaubriand.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘James White’
abstract: Josh Mond narrates the opening sequence from “James White,” featuring Christopher Abbott.
lead_paragraph: Josh Mond narrates the opening sequence from “James White,” featuring Christopher Abbott.

headline: Spare Times for Nov. 13-19
abstract: Holiday Train Shows  New York doesn’t take its toy train exhibitions lightly. Three shows provide a chance to immerse yourself in a miniature landscape with vintage locomotives as classic as a Norman Rockwell holiday scene.
lead_paragraph: Holiday Train Shows  New York doesn’t take its toy train exhibitions lightly. Three shows provide a chance to immerse yourself in a miniature landscape with vintage locomotives as classic as a Norman Rockwell holiday scene.

headline: Josh Mond Narrates a Scene From ‘James White’
abstract: The writer and director discusses his film “James White,” starring Christopher Abbott.
lead_paragraph: A young man dealing with the loss of his estranged father and the continued care of his ailing mother is at the center of “James White,” the directorial debut of Josh Mond. He is part of a filmmaking collaborative called Borderline Films that includes Antonio Campos (“Afterschool”) and Sean Durkin (“Martha Marcy May Marlene”). The film stars Christopher Abbott and Cynthia Nixon and traverses dark, painful terrain.

headline: Review: A Glowing Pizza Oven at Wood & Fire in Pleasantville
abstract: The centerpiece at Wood & Fire, an Italian restaurant in Pleasantville, N.Y., is its Neapolitan pizza oven, but its menu has an array of options, from roasted beet salad to octopus.
lead_paragraph: With patio-warming fire towers at the main entrance and neat stacks of wood lining the passage to the back entrance, Wood & Fire, a new informal dining spot in Pleasantville, could not have a more appropriate name. Inside, a mosaic-paved Neapolitan pizza oven glows hot.

headline: Review: In ‘Love the Coopers,’ a Dysfunctional Family Sits Down to Christmas Dinner
abstract: Diane Keaton and John Goodman play a long-married couple who have big news to deliver to the family once it gathers, in Jessie Nelson’s film.
lead_paragraph: Classic Christmas movies have a magic that can’t be manufactured, but “Love the Coopers” desperately tries to do just that. It employs a familiar conceit — dysfunctional family gathers for holiday meal — and enlists recognizable actors to deliver it, but the result plays like a collection of ideas and jokes borrowed from other movies. The film is occasionally amusing but rarely feels genuine.

headline: Drug Charges for Nephews of Venezuela’s First Lady Could Add to Public Distrust
abstract: Though President Nicolás Maduro’s wife, Cilia Flores, has been accused of nepotism in the past, the recent family scandal could be especially problematic as legislative elections approach.
lead_paragraph: In the eyes of many Venezuelans, Cilia Flores, the wife of President Nicolás Maduro, represents a special kind of family values.

headline: Review: ‘Man Up,’ About a Romance With Obstacles
abstract: The recently divorced Jack (Simon Pegg) mistakes Nancy (Lake Bell) for a blind date in this romantic comedy directed by Ben Palmer.
lead_paragraph: “Man Up,” a destined-for-romance story in the spirit of “You’ve Got Mail” and “Sleepless in Seattle,” has just enough edge to distinguish it from a Lifetime movie. It also has Lake Bell and Simon Pegg, versatile and likable actors who help the mild story considerably.

headline: Review: ‘Song of Lahore’ Chronicles a Pakistani Jazz Ensemble’s American Triumph
abstract: This documentary, by Sharmeen Obaid-Chinoy and Andy Schocken, shows how the Sachal Jazz Ensemble got to play at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: If all of “Song of Lahore” were as exciting as its ending, you’d need an hour afterward to catch your breath. It’s not, yet despite a lackluster start, this documentary redeems itself by the finale.

headline: Review: ‘Steve McQueen: The Man & Le Mans,’ a Documentary
abstract: A look at the making of McQueen’s 1971 movie, “Le Mans,” about that 24-hour sports car race in France.
lead_paragraph: “Steve McQueen: The Man & Le Mans” is a niche documentary about the making of a niche, rather unloved movie. It doesn’t really succeed in conveying McQueen’s great passion for auto racing. In truth, it mostly makes him seem like a jerk — but cinephiles might enjoy it as a case study of moviemaking gone wrong.

headline: Review: ‘Into the Badlands,’ Drama With Martial Arts on AMC
abstract: This post-apocalyptic series from the creators of “Smallville” stars Daniel Wu and looks back to a series from four decades ago.
lead_paragraph: “Into the Badlands,” a futuristic martial-arts saga beginning on Sunday night, is a perfectly average television show. But it’s on AMC, the cable trendsetter, where average has not been the norm. So it will be judged as the most ordinary drama the channel has picked up, and the most lightweight since the days of “Remember WENN” almost 20 years ago.

headline: Review: At PeraBell Food Bar, a Menu That Spans the Globe
abstract: The strategy behind this bistro, located in Riverhead, N.Y., is to offer as many cuisines as possible, including pizza, Thai dishes and Mexican entrees.
lead_paragraph: PeraBell Food Bar, a large bistro that opened in June in Riverhead, certainly aims to please. Its formula, apparently, is to shun any specific personality while leaning on as many currently successful restaurant models as possible.

headline: Nathaniel Marston, ‘One Life to Live’ Actor, Dies at 40
abstract: Mr. Marston was known for playing a character who was brought back after he was killed off.
lead_paragraph: Nathaniel Marston, a television actor who played two characters in succession on the long-running soap opera “One Life to Live,” the second role after fans waged a write-in campaign to bring him back, died on Tuesday from injuries he sustained in a truck accident in October. He was 40.

headline: Review: The Family of Anne Frank, Made Real by Silence
abstract: “The Diary of Anne Frank” reminds us that the Franks weren’t just hallowed historical names but something far more complex: human beings.
lead_paragraph: The book is famous for its words, yet the silences are the most affecting moments in “The Diary of Anne Frank.” In the play, quiet interludes are filled with humor, or fear, or tenderness, and provide the most poignant moments of this worthy production by the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey.

headline: Giants’ Will Beatty Won’t Return This Season
abstract: The Giants’ starting left tackle tore a rotator cuff in his shoulder while rehabilitating a torn pectoral muscle he sustained in May.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Will Beatty, the Giants’ starting left tackle who tore a pectoral muscle lifting weights in May but was expected to give the team a late-season lift when he returned to uniform this month, will be sidelined the remainder of the year with a different injury: a torn rotator cuff in his shoulder. Beatty sustained the new injury while rehabilitating his pectoral muscle.

headline: A Painter of Clouds, Revisited
abstract: An exhibition at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich aims to resurrect the stature of Charles Harold Davis, a 19th-century artist well-known in his time.
lead_paragraph: Last year, while organizing a survey of Connecticut Impressionism at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, Conn., Peter C. Sutton was captivated by the works of Charles Harold Davis. “I thought, ‘Wow, this is a really good painter,’” said Mr. Sutton, the museum’s executive director. “‘Why don’t I know more about him?’”

headline: Fred McNeill, Who Played in Two Super Bowls, Dies at 63
abstract: The Vikings linebacker went on to become a lawyer and a spokesman for former players who suffer from early onset dementia and other cognitive problems, as he did.
lead_paragraph: Fred McNeill, a hard-hitting linebacker who appeared in two Super Bowls with the Minnesota Vikings before becoming a lawyer and a spokesman for former players who suffer from early onset dementia and other cognitive problems, as he did, died on Nov. 3 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 63.

headline: Dean at Claremont McKenna College Resigns Amid Protests
abstract: An email written by the dean of students at the college, which is near Los Angeles, after a newspaper article about the treatment of students of color has led to her resignation.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The dean of students at Claremont McKenna College stepped down Thursday in response to protests over the treatment of students of color.

headline: Citigroup Imports a Branch Style From Operations Abroad
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: The “smart branches,” catering to a more affluent clientele, will be much smaller and offer more personal services.
lead_paragraph: Citigroup, as it begins to retool its retail operations and tries to revamp its image in the United States, is borrowing ideas from its overseas branches.

headline: Fernando del Paso Wins Miguel de Cervantes Prize
abstract: The Mexican writer captured the Spanish-speaking world’s highest literary honor, which is awarded for an author’s entire body of work.
lead_paragraph: The Mexican writer Fernando del Paso, 80, won the 2015 Miguel de Cervantes Prize on Thursday, the highest literary award in the Spanish-speaking world. The annual prize is awarded for an author’s entire body of work.

headline: Tyrone Howard, Man Charged With Killing Officer, Gets Maximum Term in Drug Case
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Attacks on Police', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Mr. Howard’s case has focused attention on the workings of Manhattan drug court, which offers treatment instead of prison to nonviolent addicts who deal drugs to support their habit.
lead_paragraph: The Manhattan judge who sent a career criminal into drug treatment only to see him arrested a few months later on charges that he murdered a police officer defended her decision on Thursday, saying she and another judge had been unfairly pilloried by Mayor Bill de Blasio and his police commissioner.

headline: Iran President Doesn’t Rule Out Normalized U.S. Ties One Day
abstract: The Iranian president’s remarks, in an interview with an Italian newspaper, appeared at odds with those of Iran’s supreme leader, at least in tone.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s president suggested in an interview published Thursday that normalized relations with the United States were possible one day, an assertion that differed markedly from one expressed by his superior, the country’s supreme leader.

headline: Things to Do in Connecticut Nov. 13 to 22, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Secret Service Officer Is Accused of Sending Lewd Photographs
abstract: A Secret Service officer who worked at the White House sent lewd photographs of himself to whom he believed was a 14-year-old girl, according to court papers filed by the federal authorities.
lead_paragraph: A Secret Service officer who worked at the White House sent lewd photographs of himself to whom he believed was a 14-year-old girl, according to court papers filed this week by the federal authorities. The Secret Service has placed the officer, Lee Robert Moore, 37, of Maryland, on leave and revoked his security clearance after his arrest, the agency said in a statement. Unlike agents, Secret Service officers typically wear police-style uniforms and provide security at buildings.

headline: Things to Do on Long Island, Nov. 13 to 22, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: John Kerry Tempers Expectations for Syria Talks
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry indicated Thursday that there was a vast gulf among world leaders on the future of the Syrian president, but a shared commitment to defeating the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Secretary of State John Kerry sought on Thursday to play down expectations for peace talks this weekend on the Syrian civil war, signaling that there remained a vast gulf among world leaders on the future of the Syrian president but a shared commitment to defeating the Islamic State.

headline: Things to Do in New Jersey, Nov. 13 to 22, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Florida: Police Officer Who Killed Stranded Motorist Is Fired
abstract: The plainclothes rookie Palm Beach Gardens police officer who fatally shot a stranded motorist last month was fired Wednesday, the city announced on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The plainclothes rookie Palm Beach Gardens police officer who fatally shot a stranded motorist last month was fired Wednesday, the city announced Thursday. Corey Jones, 31, a housing inspector and musician, died Oct. 18 after his car broke down in the middle of the night off Interstate 95 in Palm Beach County. Palm Beach Gardens Police officer Nouman K. Raja was working a burglary detail when he approached Mr. Jones’s car in an unmarked van. Mr. Raja told the authorities that Mr. Jones confronted him with a gun, so the officer fired six times, striking Mr. Jones three times as he fled. The officer came under criticism for failing to show his badge, and because Mr. Jones had acquired his gun legally. Mr. Raja, who joined the police department in April, was still in his probationary period, making it easier for the city to terminate his employment. The Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Palm Beach Sheriff’s Office are investigating the shooting.

headline: Defense Secretary Dismisses a General on His Staff in a Misconduct Inquiry
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter said on Thursday that he was removing his senior military assistant, Lt. Gen. Ronald F. Lewis, over allegations of misconduct.
lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter said on Thursday that he was removing his senior military assistant, Lt. Gen. Ronald F. Lewis, over allegations of misconduct. A statement announcing the dismissal offered no details, saying only that the matter would be investigated by the Pentagon’s inspector general, but a senior Defense Department official, speaking on the condition of anonymity because he was not authorized to publicly discuss the matter, said the misconduct was sexual. It is rare, if not unheard-of, for a defense secretary to so publicly fire a senior officer on his staff. General Lewis, a former Army chief of public affairs who deployed to Afghanistan and Iraq, has been at Mr. Carter’s side for years, serving him in a number of posts. In the statement, Mr. Carter said: “I expect the highest possible standards of conduct from the men and women in this department, particularly from those serving in the most senior positions. There is no exception.”

headline: Things to Do in the Hudson Valley, Nov. 13 to 22, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Rex Ryan Aims Jab at Opponent and Lands Squarely on N.F.L.
abstract: Just when you think you’ve seen Rex Ryan at his most acute state of tone-deafness, he outdoes himself.
lead_paragraph: Just when you think you’ve seen Rex Ryan at his most acute state of tone-deafness, he outdoes himself.

headline: Anastasia Myskina Thrives as Russia’s Fed Cup Captain
abstract: Missing the sport after her own career came to an abrupt end because of injury, Anastasia Myskina, a self-proclaimed “team person,” leads the Russian team into the final against the Czech Republic.
lead_paragraph: When Russia faces the Czech Republic in the Fed Cup final in front of a hostile Prague crowd this weekend, no one in the stadium will be more nervous than Anastasia Myskina.

headline: U.S. Steps Up Its Attacks on ISIS-Controlled Oil Fields in Syria
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Frustrated by ISIS militants’ ability to keep producing oil despite airstrikes against refineries, the United States has moved to inflict damage that takes longer to fix.
lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — The United States and its allies have sharply increased their airstrikes against the sprawling oil fields that the Islamic State controls in eastern Syria in an effort to disrupt one of the terrorist group’s main sources of revenue, American officials said this week.

headline: Report Ties Kenyan Army to Militants’ Smuggling
abstract: The report by a Kenyan watchdog group accuses the Kenyan military of making money on smuggling alongside the Shabab Islamist militants in Somalia.
lead_paragraph: KAMPALA, Uganda — The Kenyan military, a partner of the United States in eastern Africa and a force in fighting Islamist militants in Somalia, has been making money on smuggling alongside those militants for years, according to a new report.

headline: Family Searches for Answers After a Woman Goes Missing From a Hospital
abstract: Maria Dearmas, 58, went missing for three days after being discharged alone from a hospital that should have known she had schizophrenia and dementia.
lead_paragraph: Around 8:30 on the morning of Nov. 1, the Sunday that the New York City Marathon was being run, an ambulance went to a building on East 111th Street in Manhattan and picked up a woman with bad pains in her belly. Medics took her 14 blocks south, to the emergency room at Metropolitan Hospital Center. The woman, Maria Dearmas, 58, was a frequent visitor to Metropolitan for a range of miseries.

headline: Senate Rules Entangle Bid to Repeal Health Care Law
abstract: A determination by the Senate parliamentarian complicates voting issues surrounding the latest challenge to the president’s signature legislation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act have become snarled in the complex rules of the Senate, raising questions about whether the Republican-controlled Congress can fulfill its pledge to send a repeal measure to President Obama.

headline: Phil Taylor, Motorhead Drummer Who Helped Shape a Genre, Dies at 61
abstract: The “Philthy Animal” was credited with a drumming style that inspired some of the top metal bands of the 1980s and ’90s.
lead_paragraph: Phil Taylor, the drummer who was known as Philthy Animal and whose breakneck playing for the British rock band Motorhead helped give rise to the thrash metal genre, died on Wednesday. He was 61.

headline: Rena Wolner, Who Led 3 Major Paperback Publishers, Dies at 70
abstract: Ms. Wolner, president and publisher of Berkley, Pocket and Avon Books, helped lead the way in negotiating combined hardback and paperback deals with notable authors.
lead_paragraph: Rena Wolner, a former contracts department assistant who became president of three mass-market paperback publishing companies, died on Saturday in Boca Raton, Fla. She was 70.

headline: Guilty Plea in Drug Overdoses at Wesleyan
abstract: Zachary Kramer, 21, a former Wesleyan University student, admitted that he had distributed a party drug that left nearly a dozen students hospitalized last winter.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — A former Wesleyan University student pleaded guilty on Thursday to a federal drug dealing charge, admitting that he had distributed a party drug that left nearly a dozen students hospitalized, two in critical condition, after they overdosed on the drug last winter.

headline: Review: Jean-Yves Thibaudet, Emotional Austerity at Carnegie
abstract: The pianist performed Schumann’s “Scenes From Childhood” and gave a deft interpretation of Ravel’s “Miroirs."
lead_paragraph: Like other ostensibly “simple” piano works, such as Mozart sonatas and Bach’s two-part inventions, Schumann’s “Kinderszenen” (“Scenes From Childhood”) reveals much in terms of technique and expression. But when Jean-Yves Thibaudet performed it at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening, it sounded more like a reminiscence of a humdrum day at the office than a set of tenderly emotive miniatures.

headline: Utah Senator, Crucial Ally for the Pacific Rim Trade Deal, Is Now Its Main Hurdle
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Biotechnology and Bioengineering']
abstract: Senator Orrin G. Hatch objects to language that would limit brand-name drug makers’ monopoly protections abroad for their cutting-edge medicines known as biologics.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Orrin G. Hatch, with his long record of promoting trade, was a natural and crucial Republican ally for President Obama earlier this year, helping him conclude negotiations among 12 Pacific Rim nations on the largest regional trade accord in history.

headline: President Obama Denounces Donald Trump’s Deportation Plan
abstract: Mr. Obama called Mr. Trump’s campaign promise to deploy a “deportation force” to round up millions of immigrants in the country illegally and send them home unrealistic and un-American.
lead_paragraph: President Obama on Thursday denounced Donald J. Trump’s campaign promise to deploy a “deportation force” to round up millions of immigrants in the country illegally and send them home, calling it unrealistic and un-American.

headline: Review: ‘A View From the Bridge’ Bears Witness to the Pain of Fate
abstract: From its opening scene, Ivo van Hove’s revival of Arthur Miller’s play evokes an acute sense of dread and a relentless aura of grim predestination.
lead_paragraph: This must be what Greek tragedy once felt like, when people went to the theater in search of catharsis. Ivo van Hove’s magnificent reconception of Arthur Miller’s “A View From the Bridge,” which opened on Thursday night at the Lyceum Theater, takes you into extreme emotional territory that you seldom dare visit in daily life.

headline: South African Game
abstract: Friday fun with Patrick Berry.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — I had two distinctly different experiences with today’s puzzle by Patrick Berry, and with a constructor as skilled as he is, you never really know if he’s done it on purpose.

headline: Woman Called Dead Is Found to Still Be Alive
abstract: Emergency workers summoned to a shooting scene in Richmond Hill, Queens, pronounced a woman dead, but the police later heard sounds coming from her.
lead_paragraph: Emergency medical workers summoned to a shooting in Queens on Thursday morning pronounced a woman dead. But police officers investigating the scene made another discovery: She was still alive.

headline: Acquittals Are Greeted With Good Cheer in Queens
abstract: Mr. Asaro walked free on Thursday, to the delight of those who admitted they knew him.
lead_paragraph: On the quiet side streets and traffic-clogged main drags of southwestern Queens where John Gotti once reigned and where social clubs were sometimes less than social, Vincent Asaro’s acquittal of crimes decades old was welcome news to those who cared to admit they knew him.

headline: Impressionist and Modern Works Bring Solid Bids at Christie’s Auction
abstract: Impressionist and Modern works have dimmed in the eyes of many major collectors, but despite a lack of fireworks, bidding was solid at the middle range of $3 million to $5 million.
lead_paragraph: Time was when Impressionist and Modern works were the big news of the auction season, the ultimate trophy art. But as the Christie’s sale on Thursday night attests, those stars have dimmed in the eyes of many of the world’s major collectors.

headline: Abdul Karim al-Eryani, 81, Dies; Yemeni Politician Brokered Arab Spring Peace
abstract: A former prime minister and diplomat, Mr. Eryani helped bring about a peaceful change of government in 2011.
lead_paragraph: Abdul Karim al-Eryani, a Yemeni former prime minister and diplomat who helped bring about a peaceful change of Yemen’s government during the Arab Spring of 2011, died on Nov. 8 in Frankfurt, where he had flown for medical treatment. He was 81.

headline: Rangers Build Lead as Henrik Lundqvist Resists Blues’ Barrage
abstract: Lundqvist made 31 saves against the dangerous Blues to help the Rangers win their seventh straight game this season.
lead_paragraph: Seconds after Ryan McDonagh’s power-play goal, Brian Elliott, the second goaltender of the game for the St. Louis Blues, angrily whacked his stick against a post. At the other end of the ice, Henrik Lundqvist perched his arms on his knees, calmly awaiting another onslaught.

headline: Angels’ New General Manager Makes a Big Pickup With Andrelton Simmons

lead_paragraph: As a Yankees executive last off-season, Billy Eppler assisted in the acquisition of a smooth-fielding shortstop who grew up in Curaçao. As the new general manager of the Los Angeles Angels, he has done it again.

keywords: ['Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'Labor and Jobs']

lead_paragraph: Jerry Stritzke, the chief executive of the sporting goods company REI, hosted a question-and-answer session on the website Reddit this week to discuss his decision to keep stores closed on Black Friday. But what was intended as an opportunity to bask in good will over the move transformed into a public airing of grievances by scores of angry employees.

abstract: Donald J. Trump unleashed a torrent of insults on Thursday against his main rival, Ben Carson, comparing him to a child molester in a television interview and suggesting that the people of Iowa are “stupid” if they believe Mr. Carson’s claim that he tried to stab a close relative during his childhood.

abstract: For the millions who grew up as only children, the Communist Party’s move to allow married couples to have two offspring reawakened feelings of isolation.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — By many measures, Wang Hailei, 36, belongs to one of the most privileged generations in Chinese history. Raised without siblings under China’s “one child” policy, he was lavished with attention and pampered with gifts like computer games, martial arts novels and music lessons.

headline: Europe Mislabels Israel
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Labeling and Labels (Product)', 'Israeli Settlements']
abstract: The European Union’s latest attempt to strike back at Israel by relabeling Israeli products is not only unfair, it’s illegal.
lead_paragraph: THIS week the European Commission announced guidelines suggesting that Israeli products from areas that came under its control in 1967 be labeled “Israeli Settlement” products and not “Made in Israel” as they have been until now. The policy carves out a special legal rule for Israel, not only contradicting the European Union’s own official positions on these issues, but also going against rulings of European national courts, and violating basic tenets of the World Trade Organization.

headline: They’re Coming for Your Cigarettes. But That’s O.K.
abstract: Concerns over secondhand smoke easily override arguments over personal freedom.
lead_paragraph: The federal government wants to ban smoking in public housing nationwide. Not just in lobbies, stairwells, laundry rooms and other common areas, but inside apartments, too.

headline: Beat the Press
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: Because it’s open season on journalism — from the left and right — powerful partisan voices have emerged, injecting lies into the public arena.
lead_paragraph: Before it slips away, let’s try to pull some larger meaning from perhaps the most absurd moment of 2015: that professor at one of the nation’s top journalism colleges who threatened to use force against a student journalist for doing the things taught in that school.

headline: A Doping Travesty Russia Cannot Duck
abstract: The old Soviet trick of claiming “everybody does it” won’t work if Russia is punished by international sports officials.
lead_paragraph: A central thrust of Soviet propaganda throughout the Cold War was to portray all Soviet misconduct, however outrageous, as no different from what the West was doing — including the propaganda itself. Accordingly, if the West accused the Kremlin of some gross wrongdoing, it was promptly depicted as another hypocritical attempt to belittle the Soviet Union. To a degree it worked: Many Russians, lacking any direct experience of the West, accepted a moral equivalence between their system and Western democracy — along with an instinctive fear of a world forever scheming against them. Alas, this approach has become an integral part of Vladimir Putin’s Russia.

headline: Republicans’ Lust for Gold
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Gold Standard (Monetary)']
abstract: The party’s presidential candidates are falling in behind — and falling for — hard-money policies.
lead_paragraph: It’s not too hard to understand why everyone seeking the Republican presidential nomination is proposing huge tax cuts for the rich. Just follow the money: Candidates in the G.O.P. primary draw the bulk of their financial support from a few dozen extremely wealthy families. Furthermore, decades of indoctrination have made an essentially religious faith in the virtues of high-end tax cuts — a faith impervious to evidence — a central part of Republican identity.

headline: The G.O.P. at an Immigration Crossroads
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: The Republican Party is about to secure either its future or its demise.
lead_paragraph: It’s no exaggeration to say that the next six months will determine the viability of the Republican Party. The demographics of this country are changing. This will be the last presidential election cycle in which the G.O.P., in its current form, has even a shot at winning the White House. And so the large question Republicans must ask themselves is: Are we as a party willing to champion the new America that is inexorably rising around us, or are we the receding roar of an old America that is never coming back?

headline: Confirm President Obama’s Judges
keywords: ['Editorials', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Appeals Courts (US)', 'Federal Courts (US)']
abstract: Republicans angry at President Obama are blocking votes on qualified nominees, even as a backlog of court cases grows.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 12, 2014, President Obama nominated Luis Felipe Restrepo to a judgeship on the federal Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judge Restrepo, who already sits on the United States District Court in Philadelphia, seemed to secure the support of both Pennsylvania senators — Bob Casey, a Democrat, and Pat Toomey, a Republican.

headline: Kurdish Fighters Retake Iraqi City of Sinjar From ISIS
abstract: Yazidis helped the Kurds gain control of the city, which has been under the brutal domination of the Islamic State for more than 15 months.
lead_paragraph: SINJAR, Iraq — Kurdish and Yazidi fighters retook the northern Iraqi city of Sinjar from Islamic State fighters on Friday morning, facing only pockets of resistance as the jihadists cleared out from a town they had brutally dominated for more than 15 months.

headline: How Important Is It to Be Attractive in Our Society?

Some of us are short or tall, stocky or lanky, with bushy eyebrows, a long nose, crooked teeth or — in the case of the man described below — a tumor on our face. In fact, some of us might even be considered ugly by prevailing norms. But how much does that matter?

headline: What Happens to Childhood When You Start Counting Steps?

In his constant quest for adventure, he “gamified” his own life, as we now might say, but it didn’t require gadgets.

headline: Roughing It Like a ‘Real Vermonter’
abstract: After an accident with a wood splitter, a spouse gets a lesson in local culture.
lead_paragraph: In September, the tall maple in our field began to display some fiery red leaves in its uppermost branches. The color, though, made us think of the cold white winter that was ahead of us, and of the wood we’d need for our stoves. My husband got out the chain saw and started to cut the 20-foot logs that had been delivered behind the house. After he cut them into manageable pieces, we all began splitting them in the log splitter and stacking the wood to dry in the Indian summer sunshine.

headline: ‘Fall Song’
abstract: Selected by Natasha Trethewey.
lead_paragraph: ‘‘I need a song that will keep sky open in my mind,’’ the poem reads. What comes before that — short declarative sentences, lines closed with end punctuation and laced with rhyme — is one kind of song. And when that pattern breaks and the punctuation falls away, there is a different evocation of song, linked but open, like a long ‘‘necklace of days.’’

headline: A Left-Bank Bistro Raises the Bar
abstract: The distinguished Michelin-starred chef Jean-François Piège has opened a 20-seat spot that deserves high marks for exquisite execution.
lead_paragraph: The bistronomy movement in Paris may have its roots in former fringe enclaves of the 11th Arrondissement, but today, its tenets — casual, affordable, market-driven cooking — are fanning out beyond the Right Bank. Clover, the most promising of recent arrivals, sits clear across town in the well-heeled St.-Germain-des-Prés neighborhood, where such modern bistros have been noticeably absent.

headline: Roswell Rudd, in a Celebratory Mood, Reflects on His Winding Path
abstract: Mr. Rudd’s “The Wizard of Roz” concert at Le Poisson Rouge will celebrate his earliest days in jazz and his renaissance.
lead_paragraph: KERHONKSON, N.Y. — Roswell Rudd, the genially intrepid jazz trombonist, has lately found himself recalling a memory from his childhood. It’s a composite blur of the rambling jam sessions his father was fond of hosting in their house, first in western Connecticut and then in upstate New York, during the years after World War II.

headline: How to Survive a Stampede
abstract: Don’t follow the crowd. Know your exits.
lead_paragraph: “Don’t just do what the person next to you does,” says Caesar Saloma, a physics professor at the University of the Philippines who studies the movement of mice escaping confined spaces. In some ways, mice stampede as humans do: Individuals blindly follow one another, clogging some exits and ignoring others. In July, as officials prepared for the Pope’s visit and an outdoor mass for upward of six million people, Saloma was asked to work on the crowd-control plan.

headline: Why Republicans Still Love the Gold Standard
keywords: ['Gold Standard (Monetary)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Bretton Woods Agreement', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Presidential hopefuls like Ted Cruz see the gold standard, which economists argue led to the Great Depression, as a control on big government.
lead_paragraph: In Tuesday’s Republican presidential debate, Senator Ted Cruz reintroduced an idea that had many viewers scratching their heads and nearly all economists pulling out their hair. Mr. Cruz advocated a return to the gold standard — that is, tying the value of a dollar to a set amount of gold — because, he said, it produced prosperity under the Bretton Woods system and it helped “workingmen and -women.”

headline: At the Bloody Dawn of the Vietnam War
keywords: ['Vietnam War', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Those who fought in Vietnam were as great as any previous generation.
lead_paragraph: A FEW weeks ago, an archivist at The New York Times discovered a small trove of photographs I’d taken 50 years ago while covering the first major clash of the Vietnam War between the American and North Vietnamese Armies. Though I had written about the battle for The Times, and later in my book “A Bright Shining Lie,” I’d completely forgotten about the photographs. Seeing them brought back a cascade of memories of one of my most extraordinary days as a young war correspondent.

headline: Mastering the Art of Dinner-on-Demand Services
abstract: A crop of high-tech dinner-on-demand services now available just about anywhere there’s an Internet connection.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to planning, shopping, preparing and cooking healthy dinners for my family, I admit defeat. I’ve tried cooking a dozen dinners on the weekend to freeze for the week. I’ve collected “busy mom” cookbooks, and I’ve tried all the crock-pot cooking my family could stomach. (The last time I made a stew, someone in my family actually cried. O.K., I admit, it was me. My husband and daughter just threw theirs away and ordered pizza.)

abstract: After the win, the question was why the military leaders who controlled Myanmar would voluntarily hand over power. The answer seems to be that they never thought they would.
lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — The dictators and army generals of Myanmar have ceded political power one drop at a time over the past decade, a process they carefully managed.

headline: 1890: A Poet and a Lawyer Duel
keywords: ['Duels and Dueling', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Public Defenders and Court-Appointed Lawyers (Criminal)']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A poet and a lawyer duel in France in 1890.
lead_paragraph: CHARLEROI — The Laguerre-Déroulède duel has been fought, and both principals are now languishing in jail here. They have had such an extraordinary hard time of it, trying to find a place to fight, that all Europe has been watching their movements. First, the French police dogged them, then the Belgian police tracked them about, next the Dutch officers objected to any gore being shed in Holland, and so the weary duellists wandered about in search of a nice quiet place, until they reached hospitable Charleroi. The ending of the combat was characteristic of the two men — one a poet and the other a cool-headed lawyer. It was all business on one side and all poetry on the other.

headline: From All Sides
abstract: Reviewers have recommended several books for their tone in covering the state of Israel.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli prime minister Yitzhak Rabin was assassinated 20 years ago this month. This week, Ilene Prusher reviews “Killing a King,” Dan Ephron’s account of that murder and its continuing impact in the Middle East. Over the past couple of decades, reviewers in these pages have recommended several books for their tone in covering the state of Israel.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: I’LL DRINK TO THAT: A Life in Style, With a Twist, by Betty Halbreich with Rebecca Paley. (Penguin, $16.) As a long-reigning personal shopper at Bergdorf Goodman, Halbreich has counseled clientele on matters far more than the sartorial. Writing with Midwestern pragmatism about her work and a therapist’s empathy for her clients, she details her privileged childhood in Chicago; marriage into a wealthy East Coast family; and professional passion found later in life. As our reviewer, Alexandra Jacobs, put it: “She might be a bird in a gilded cage, but her view of the flowers outside is unobstructed.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: SUBMISSION, by Michel Houellebecq. Translated by Lorin Stein. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25.) In Houellebecq’s morally complex novel, an alienated French professor and a France without faith or values yield to an Islamic government.

headline: Julia Roberts, in ‘Secret in Their Eyes,’ Turns Her Famous Smile to Grief
abstract: The star talks about working with her husband on “Secret in Their Eyes,” gender disparity in Hollywood and her coming movie with George Clooney.
lead_paragraph: Julia Roberts was meant to be a man, at least in her new movie, “Secret in Their Eyes.” Her character in this noirish murder thriller was written as a man who loses his wife. That’s how it was in the original Oscar-winning Argentine drama upon which the film is based. But in the American remake, written and directed by Billy Ray (the screenwriter of “Captain Phillips”) and co-starring Chiwetel Ejiofor and Nicole Kidman, it is Ms. Roberts who loses a family member, this time her daughter. Those script changes, conceived by Ms. Roberts, “had a seismic effect on the movie,” Mr. Ray said, giving audiences a new emotional entry point even as the character’s personality did not otherwise change.

headline: Smoking Returns as a Hot Issue in New York Public Housing
keywords: ['Smoking and Tobacco', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A renewed conversation about limiting smoking in multiple-unit dwellings could at least get things moving toward the right place.
lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg’s initiative to end smoking in bars and restaurants, a ban that went into effect on a Sunday night in March 2003, was easily the greatest success of his mayoralty, one even his most impassioned detractors eventually came to applaud. We may never stop elegizing the meatpacking district’s Florent and the fiery, diminished downtown bohemia the restaurant represented, but few of us miss coughing into a slab of bavette, whether it was because we ourselves were smoking or because the guy next to us, looking like Michel Houellebecq, was lifting a match to his fifth American Spirit. When the smoking prohibition took effect, fatalists predicted the decline of eating out, the end of fun, the death of the city. Revelry persevered.

abstract: The president of the Kurdish autonomous region announced on Friday that Kurdish forces had retaken the Iraqi town of Sinjar as part of an offensive against Islamic State militants.
lead_paragraph: The president of the Kurdish autonomous region announced on Friday that Kurdish forces had retaken the Iraqi town of Sinjar as part of an offensive against Islamic State militants.

headline: 1940: Britain Smashes Italy’s Ships
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The British cripple the Italian Navy in 1940.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In one bold raid delivered Monday night [Nov. 12] by its sea-borne bombers, the British fleet in the Mediterranean crippled at least two and probably three of the Italian Navy’s six battleships and put out of action two cruisers and several auxiliary vessels as they lay comfortably behind shore batteries of the naval stronghold of Taranto, on the heel of the Italian boot. This decisive blow, which immediately tipped the balance of Mediterranean naval strength in favor of the British, was announced to a wildly cheering House of Commons this morning by Prime Minister Winston Churchill. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 14, 1940

abstract: Fantasy football analysis for N.F.L. Week 10 games and complete player rankings.
lead_paragraph: Fantasy football analysis for N.F.L. Week 10 games and Monday’s matchup between the Houston Texans and the Cincinnati Bengals. You can also follow the Sablich brothers on Twitter at @5thDownFantasy and see their complete Week 10 player rankings.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Donald Trump and Ben Carson are duking it out in the Republican debates — and on the hardcover nonfiction best-seller list.
lead_paragraph: No Joy: The Republican debates aren’t the only place Donald Trump and Ben Carson are duking it out these days. They’re also competing on the hardcover nonfiction list, where Carson’s book “A More Perfect Union” (written with his wife, Candy Carson) is No. 4 after five weeks and Trump’s book “Crippled America” makes its debut at No. 5. Both men have been here before, of course, Carson with two previous best sellers and Trump with eight (most notably “Trump: The Art of the Deal,” written with Tony Schwartz, which spent 48 weeks on the hardcover nonfiction list in 1987 and 1988). So what do their books reveal about the candidates? Nothing we didn’t know already from watching them campaign. Carson is genial and bland in advancing his model of Christian conservatism; in his latest book, a paean to the Constitution, each chapter opens with a Bible verse. And Trump is blustery and vain and entertaining. Here he is discussing his book’s cover, which shows him with a stern Sam the Eagle frown: “Some readers may be wondering why the picture we used on the cover of this book is so angry and so mean looking. I had some beautiful pictures taken in which I had a big smile on my face. I looked happy, I looked content, I looked like a very nice person, which in theory I am. My family loved those pictures and wanted me to use one of them. The photographer did a great job. But I decided it wasn’t appropriate. In this book we’re talking about Crippled America — that’s a tough title. Unfortunately, there’s very little that’s nice about it. . . . So I wanted a picture where I wasn’t happy, a picture that reflected the anger and unhappiness that I feel, rather than joy. There’s nothing to be joyful about. Because we are not in a joyous situation right now.”

headline: ‘We That Are Left,’ by Clare Clark
abstract: In the wake of World War I, survivors explore new ways to connect to lost loved ones.
lead_paragraph: There’s an exchange halfway through Clare Clark’s fine new novel that gets to the heart of the book’s concerns. The speakers are Oscar Greenwood, studying physics at Cambridge just when Einstein’s theory of relativity is gaining widespread attention, and Phyllis Melville, a World War I nurse who, post-armistice, is intent on becoming an archaeologist. “Just because we can’t picture something,” Oscar tells her, “doesn’t mean it isn’t true.” “I thought scientists weren’t allowed to say things like that,” she observes. His reply? “These days they are.”

headline: Gloria Steinem’s ‘My Life on the Road’
abstract: Gloria Steinem reviews her peripatetic years as an activist and journalist.
lead_paragraph: For many public intellectuals these days, speaking engagements pay the bills. But listening, according to the feminist icon Gloria Steinem, is even more important. Her new book, “My Life on the Road,” provides a lesson in how to stay relevant when your name is synonymous with a decades-old movement that has fallen in and out of popular favor: Keep moving. And keep asking questions.

headline: Rebecca Hunt’s ‘Everland’
abstract: A novel interweaves two Antarctic expeditions, a century apart.
lead_paragraph: It is 1913, and a British expedition to Antarctica runs into disaster. Three members of the crew — Napps, a natural if overbearing leader; Millet-Bass, a physically imposing veteran of sea and ice; and Dinners, a young man inexperienced in everything to do with exploration life and the Antarctic — set out in a dinghy from the mother ship, Kismet, to explore the island they have named Everland in homage to their patron, Joseph Evelyn. But a storm arises as the men depart and when eventually they wash ashore their task is no longer exploration but survival. Echoes of Captain Scott’s disastrous Antarctic expedition ring through the story of the fictitious Kismet, but are never overplayed, and the Kismet’s venture slips plausibly among the other known sagas of this so-called Heroic Age of exploration.

headline: ‘The German War,’ by Nicholas Stargardt
abstract: A panoramic look at the experience of Germans from all walks of life during World War II.
lead_paragraph: World War II was extraordinary not only for the violence the Third Reich unleashed, but also for the way Hitler’s Germany went down to defeat. Kamikaze-style, suicidal defense will forever be associated with Japan. But it was Nazi Germany that actually immolated itself. While Hitler lived, there could be no negotiation. There would be no surrender, no repeat of the November 1918 armistice. The result was the devastation not only of much of Central Europe, but also of Germany itself. In the course of the war, 5.3 million men would die fighting in Wehrmacht uniform. Close to a million German civilians were killed in air raids and the ethnic cleansing that followed the war. Germany’s casualties far exceeded those of all of Western Europe put together. And the violence escalated as the war went on. The largest number died in the last desperate months, the worst being January 1945, when the Wehrmacht lost 450,000 — more in a matter of weeks than America would suffer in all of its wars of the 20th century.

headline: Robert Reich’s ‘Saving Capitalism’
abstract: Reich argues that capitalism should create broad prosperity, not just vast gains for the wealthy.
lead_paragraph: To understand “Saving Capitalism,” Robert Reich’s sweeping treatise on inequality in America, you must accept a central premise: The free market is fundamentally a human construct and so to debate the appropriateness of government in shaping it is beside the point. Someone is always writing the rules of the market. Reich’s concern is that over the last three decades, the lead authors have been Wall Street, big corporations and the wealthy elite. His fear is that “we are lurching toward a capitalism so top-heavy it cannot be sustained.”

headline: Patricia Cornwell’s ‘Depraved Heart,’ and More
abstract: In Cornwell’s latest novel, the medical examiner Kay Scarpetta is worried about threats to her brilliant, prickly niece.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Kay Scarpetta, who keeps us coming back to Patricia Cornwell’s sprawling crime novels, is one tough broad. As chief medical examiner for the state of Massachusetts, she has no trouble dealing with the gory sights and smells of dead bodies and violent crimes. “A select few of us come into this world not bothered by gruesomeness,” she says. “In fact we’re drawn to it, fascinated, intrigued.” What she can’t handle are threats to the person she loves best in the world, her brilliant, prickly niece, Lucy.

headline: Elizabeth Tallent’s ‘Mendocino Fire’
abstract: Tallent’s stories show how easily love can alter.
lead_paragraph: “How could narrators so prodigal in their empathy originate in the brain of that withholder?” So muses the unnamed woman who speaks to us in Elizabeth Tallent’s story “Narrator,” which comes near the end of her enchanting new collection, “Mendocino Fire.” That “withholder” is a famous writer, sprawled on the steps of the stairwell at a “welcome get-­together” for students in the creative writing program at Berkeley, and she has just watched him be flamboyantly rude to two young female admirers. Having thought highly of his novels, the new student has imagined the great man must have a “radiance” and “generosity of spirit” that are clearly not on offer. She feels betrayed.

headline: ‘The Gold Eaters,’ by Ronald Wright
abstract: A young boy lands in the service of Pizarro in this novel of conquest, culture clash and shifting identity.
lead_paragraph: The action of Ronald Wright’s fast-paced historical novel unfolds in the early 16th century in what is now Peru. His central character, Waman, is a callow boy from the coastal lowland town of Little River. At home, Waman speaks Tallan, an indigenous language that is, thanks to the spread of the Inca empire, giving way to Quechua, the tongue of the increasingly dominant Incas.

headline: ‘Goddess,’ by Kelly Gardiner
abstract: The many lives of a cross-dressing, swashbuckling opera star.
lead_paragraph: The divine creature who plummets “from the painted clouds” to center stage in Kelly Gardiner’s gender-bending picaresque, “Goddess,” is based on an actual historical character. Julie d’Aubigny, a.k.a. Mademoiselle de Maupin, a.k.a. La Travesti, grew up in Versailles on the periphery of Louis XIV’s court, where her father served as secretary to the Sun King’s master of horse. Papa d’Aubigny taught the court pages — and his daughter, who from childhood on dressed “as a chevalier who happened to be born female” — to fence; and Julie became an expert swordsman and equestrian, a seductress of both women and men, a tavern brawler and itinerant singer, and improbably — but what is not improbable in this narrative? — an operatic superstar at the Académie Royale de Musique in Paris. She died in a convent in 1707 at the age of 33.

headline: Memoirs
abstract: New books by Barry Yourgrau, Aspen Matis, Caroline Heller, Alison Pick and Juliet Jacques.
lead_paragraph: MESSOne Man’s Struggle to Clean Up His House and His ActBy Barry Yourgrau276 pp. Norton, $25.95.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: This weekend, begin preparing for Thanksgiving and eat well while doing it.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Here’s the plan for this weekend. Tonight you should make some Screaming Eagle Cheese-Steak Subs (above), a recipe I picked up at Boston College a few years ago and made ridiculous with skirt steak, Cheddar and a thick swab of chipotle mayonnaise.

headline: Finding Alice’s ‘Wonderland’ in Oxford
abstract: Setting out to explore the Oxford, England, of Lewis Carroll, who rooted “Alice in Wonderland” 150 years ago in the place where he lived and worked.
lead_paragraph: Alice leaned back in the rowboat and watched flecks of blue flicker among the branches overhead. She heard the sound of the oars splashing in the water as the boat made its way up the Thames from Oxford, and of her sisters Lorina and Edith giggling, but mostly she heard Mr. Dodgson weaving a tale about another Alice, a little girl who had fallen down a rabbit hole and was now having a wonderful adventure in a wonderful land. When the girls returned to Oxford with Mr. Dodgson and his friend Robinson Duckworth on that July 4, 1862, Alice thought she would ask Mr. Dodgson to write the story down — it was one of his best.

headline: An Artist and a Poet on the Dream of Immortality
abstract: For T magazine’s ongoing series, the artist Shirazeh Houshiary gives form to the poet Monica Youn’s wistful imagining of a celestial body — one that promises immortality just before slipping out of reach.
lead_paragraph: For T magazine’s ongoing series, the artist Shirazeh Houshiary gives form to the poet Monica Youn’s wistful imagining of a celestial body — one that promises immortality just before slipping out of reach.

lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — An Israeli father and son were killed and five other members of their family were wounded in a drive-by shooting near a Jewish settlement in the occupied West Bank on Friday.

abstract: The Brontë Society in England will acquire a previously unknown poem written by a young Charlotte Brontë, found along with a sliver of prose, folded into a book that belonged to the author’s mother, Maria.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Brontë Society in Haworth in northern England will acquire a previously unknown poem written by a young Charlotte Brontë, the society announced this week.

abstract: An I.A.A.F. council voted on Friday to suspend Russia in the wake of sweeping doping allegations against the country’s athletes.
lead_paragraph: In an unprecedented move, Russia was provisionally suspended from track and field on Friday by the sport’s world governing body in the wake of sweeping doping allegations against the country’s athletes, coaches, trainers, doctors and officials.

headline: Hard-Liners in Iran Denounce President Hassan Rouhani in Standoff
abstract: A loose alliance of clerics, politicians and commanders has been insistent that the nuclear deal has changed nothing in relations between the Iran and the United States.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iran’s president was sharply criticized by hard-liners during Friday Prayer and again on television on Friday in what is becoming an increasingly tense standoff over the future of Iran after the signing of the nuclear deal during the summer.

headline: Harvey Stein Captures Street Theater of Midtown Manhattan
abstract: In Mr. Stein’s new collection, “Briefly Seen,” his photographs are meant to make “the streets feel like a place where anything can happen,” he said.
lead_paragraph: Harvey Stein has documented Midtown Manhattan — during parades, the evening rush — since the 1970s. In his new book, “Briefly Seen: New York Street Life,” he captures Midtown as theater: older women in Easter hats; a painted body on a Gay Pride float. But just as often, he does the opposite, unmasking faces, capturing the expressions of people simply trying to make their way through the crowd.

An elevated railway brought uptown swells downtown to a speakeasy at First Avenue and St. Marks Place, where a butcher shop led to a back alley and Scheib’s Place, now Theatre 80 St. Marks and the William Barnacle Tavern. That dissolute era — as well as a murder mystery and diabolical booby trap — is vividly recounted at the Museum of the American Gangster.
