headline: Derek Ridgers’s “The Others”
abstract: The photographer’s latest book includes images from 1980s London.
lead_paragraph: The photographer’s latest book includes images from 1980s London.

headline: Getting Hot and Heavy in the 1980s
abstract: The photographer Derek Ridgers shares images from his new book, “The Others.”
lead_paragraph: The English photographer Derek Ridgers’s latest book doesn’t really pick up where his earlier efforts, “When We Were Young” and “78-87,” left off. Instead, “The Others,” out today, gathers what these much-lauded publications left out: 100 previously unpublished snapshots (pared down from 650) that had been living in Ridgers’s hard-drive folder under the same name. He captured the kids at London hot spots like the Mud Club, Le Beat Route, Heaven, Cha-Cha and Cafe De Paris “because I was there and had the access,” he explains, “but very quickly, I realized I was documenting people who were not going to be looking like that for that long — in some cases, they were only ever going to look like that for one night.” Here, he shares with T a selection of couples caught mid-liplock. “As I felt like I needed to ask permission of my subjects, I would sometimes have to stop them kissing, ask, and then let them get on with it,” he remembers. “No one ever said no and no one ever stopped kissing. They just went right back to it.”

lead_paragraph: When Diego and Wendy Reyes found a vertiginous lot in Colorado with panoramic views of Snowmass Village and the surrounding mountains and forests, it didn’t take them long to decide what they wanted to do with it: build a vacation home there as breathtaking as the scenery.

headline: Sotheby’s to Offer Buyouts to Staff
keywords: ['Auctions', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: “Sotheby’s is not as efficient a company as it could be,” said Tad Smith, Sotheby’s chief executive officer.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, just as the fall auction season was drawing to a close, Sotheby’s offered its employees voluntary buyouts to cut costs.

headline: Scott Campbell Turns Blind Trust Into Tattoos
abstract: At a one-man installation and performance at Milk Gallery, the celebrity tattoo artist inked lottery winners without their input or feedback.
lead_paragraph: It was hard to place the look on John Gachot’s face as he was seated on a draped chair next to a wall in a downtown Manhattan art gallery, his right arm stuffed through a hole the size of a discus for minute after excruciating minute.

headline: Mysterious Ink
abstract: The artist Scott Campbell offered free, anonymous tattoos to a select few visitors to his “Whole Glory” installation at Milk Gallery in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The artist Scott Campbell offered free, anonymous tattoos to a select few visitors to his “Whole Glory” installation at Milk Gallery in Manhattan.

headline: Roasted Sweet Potatoes
abstract: Melissa Clark makes a savory sweet potato dish with horseradish compound butter.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark makes a savory sweet potato dish with horseradish compound butter.

headline: Thanksgiving Vegetables Get Freshened Up
abstract: Professional chefs offer ideas for replacing the same old tired, soggy side dishes on the holiday table. (Article plus video.)
lead_paragraph: Like many other Americans, the chef Michael Anthony grew up accustomed to the soggy green-bean casseroles and marshmallow-topped sweet potatoes on his grandparents’ Thanksgiving table in Indianapolis.

headline: A Restaurant Where Art is on the Menu
abstract: Unclebrother, created by the art dealer Gavin Brown and the artist Rirkrit Tiravanija, is an outgrowth of Tiravanija’s 1992 performance piece “Untitled (Free).”
lead_paragraph: In 1992, the art dealer Gavin Brown helped the artist Rirkrit Tiravanija transform 303 Gallery, then on Greene Street, into an operational kitchen for a part performance, part installation piece titled “Untitled (Free).” The seminal solo show, which found the artist serving up gratis curry and rice out of the converted gallery, represented a critical development in Tiravanija’s practice. It also marked the beginning of his friendship with Brown, who at the time worked as an assistant at the gallery. Now in the collection of MoMA, “Untitled (Free)” — considered a masterwork of relational aesthetics — was the first of many interactive projects realized by the twosome. Their latest scheme: a gallery-meets-kitchen in Hancock, N.Y. Lovingly referred to as Unclebrother (the name is an inside joke), the hybrid restaurant revives the generous spirit of Tiravanija and Brown’s inaugural partnership, but adds in a full-time, brick-and-mortar locale. “It’s the first time he’s had a commercial kitchen, so it’s a departure in that sense,” Brown says. “It’s a natural progression, in a way. It’s about entering into the same place but from a different direction.”

headline: Jay Z’s Tidal Loses Another Executive
abstract: The resignation of the chief investment officer, Vania Schlogel, is at least the third high-level departure at the music streaming service since Jay Z bought it early this year.
lead_paragraph: Since Jay Z  bought Tidal early this year, the music streaming service has been plagued by frequent management changes and the perception both inside and outside the music industry that it was unlikely to succeed in a market dominated by Spotify, Apple and Pandora.

headline: Readers Respond to Alabama 8-Year-Old Accused of Killing a Toddler
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: A story about an 8-year-old boy charged with the murder of a 1-year-old girl sparked intense debate among Times readers.
lead_paragraph: A story this week about an 8-year-old boy in Birmingham, Ala., charged with the murder of a 1-year-old girl who had been left with him while her mother went to a nightclub, sparked intense debate among Times readers about who should be held accountable when a child commits a crime.

headline: Sunday Cycling and Soccer
abstract: Victor Calise, commissioner of the Mayor’s Office for People With Disabilities, started a recent Sunday in the park and ended it with an Italian dinner.
lead_paragraph: Victor Calise, commissioner of the Mayor’s Office for People With Disabilities, started a recent Sunday in the park and ended it with an Italian dinner.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
abstract: Iraq and Elsewhere: Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Iraq and Elsewhere: Pictures of the Day

headline: For Brands Like Toms, It’s All About the Experience
abstract: Companies are opting for creative spaces instead of traditional stores to appeal to shoppers who want to hang out or be a part of something meaningful.
lead_paragraph: When Blake Mycoskie, the founder of the shoe company Toms, began talking with its executives a few years ago about opening retail outlets, he faced an impasse right from the start. It was over the word “store.”

headline: Chinese Overtures to Syngenta at a Time of Susceptibility
abstract: The pesticides company has reportedly rejected a $42 billion bid from China National Chemical Corporation, yet it looks vulnerable to a takeover.
lead_paragraph: China has broken the future of Syngenta, the Swiss pesticides giant, wide open. The company has rejected a $42 billion bid from the China National Chemical Corporation, Bloomberg News reported. But the world’s big agrochemical companies look ripe for consolidation. Syngenta may find itself among the first to be harvested.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This week’s properties include a five-bedroom in Hamilton, N.J., and a four-bedroom in Lloyd Neck, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a five-bedroom in Hamilton, N.J., and a four-bedroom in Lloyd Neck, N.Y.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
abstract: This week’s properties include a five-bedroom in Hamilton, N.J., and a four-bedroom in Lloyd Neck, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in the New York region:

headline: Paris Attacks Kill More Than 100, Police Say; Border Controls Tightened
abstract: The Paris area reeled Friday night from a shooting rampage, explosions and mass hostage-taking that President François Hollande called an unprecedented terrorist attack on France.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Paris area reeled Friday night from a shooting rampage, explosions and mass hostage-taking that President François Hollande called an unprecedented terrorist attack on France. His government announced sharply increased border controls and heightened police powers as it mobilized the military in a national emergency.

headline: How Victor Calise, Disabilities Commissioner, Spends His Sundays
abstract: For Mr. Calise, who has been paralyzed from the waist down since 1994, the effort to make New York City’s public spaces more accessible never stops.
lead_paragraph: When Mayor Bill de Blasio reappointed Victor Calise this year as the commissioner for the Mayor’s Office for People With Disabilities, he remarked on “Victor’s relentless pursuit to make New York City the most accessible place in the world.” Mr. Calise, 43, was raised in Ozone Park, Queens, and has been using a wheelchair since a mountain biking accident in 1994 that left him paralyzed from the waist down. He competed on the United States sled hockey team at the 1998 Paralympics in Japan. Later, he worked with the parks department to help bring the city’s parks, beaches and recreational facilities into compliance with the Americans with Disabilities Act. He lives on the Upper West Side with his wife, Susan, and their daughters, Sophia, 13, and Lola, 10.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Carolyn Ryan, Adeel Hassan and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: James Dyson
abstract: The British entrepreneur shares the titles he’d most want to take with him on a desert island.
lead_paragraph: For his bookshop installation, One Grand, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is the British vacuum-cleaner entrepreneur Sir James Dyson. He shares his list exclusively with T.

headline: Columbia Rises for Opener and Quickly Shines
abstract: The Lions greeted the men’s basketball season on Friday with an 11 a.m. game amid excitement that they can make the N.C.A.A. tournament for the first time since 1968.
lead_paragraph: Many of the teams expected to be a part of the N.C.A.A. tournament field opened the men’s basketball season Friday night in front of capacity crowds. At Duke, students began lining up Thursday night for the team’s home opener against Siena, scheduled for 7 p.m. Friday.

headline: Nov. 13, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Iraq, the Philippines, the West Bank and Indonesia.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Iraq, the Philippines, the West Bank and Indonesia.

headline: Nina Griscom Pushes Her New Handbag Line With a Can-Do Spirit
keywords: ['Handbags and Purses', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'High Society and Socialites']
abstract: The uptown doyenne is back, but she has an uphill battle in the accessories business.
lead_paragraph: “Should I bill this directly to your husband?” the uptown doyenne Nina Griscom asked with a laugh at a recent trunk show for her handbag collection, Nina Griscom for GiGi New York.

headline: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
abstract: Honoring veterans, political rallies, another presidential debate and a Sunshine Summit in this week in political pictures.

headline: Deadly Attacks in Paris
abstract: More than 100 people were killed and others injured in shootings and explosions that rocked the Paris area Friday. A blast at a stadium forced the evacuation of the French president.
lead_paragraph: More than 100 people were killed and others injured in shootings and explosions that rocked the Paris area Friday. A blast at a stadium forced the evacuation of the French president.

headline: Paris Attacks: The Violence, Its Victims and How the Investigation Unfolded
abstract: More than 120 people were killed in shootings across Paris on Nov. 13. Look back at how the attacks and investigation unfolded.

headline: Daniel Murphy Rejects Mets’ Qualifying Offer
abstract: Turning down a one-year, $15.8 million deal makes the 2015 slugging star of the National League playoffs a free agent.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Murphy, the slugging star of the Mets’ charmed sprint through the National League playoffs last month, declined the team’s qualifying offer on Friday and will test the open market in free agency.

headline: Scene of Deadly Attacks in Paris
abstract: More than 100 people were killed Friday in multiple acts of violence in and around Paris.
lead_paragraph: More than 100 people were killed Friday in multiple acts of violence in and around Paris.

headline: Review: Isabel Leonard and Sharon Isbin in a Duet of Voice and Guitar
abstract: These performers offered a concert of Spanish works, along with a premiere by Richard Danielpour, at Zankel Hall on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Most of the opera singers who appear at Carnegie Hall follow the traditional route of singing alongside a pianist. The mezzo-soprano Isabel Leonard chose a more unusual partner for her concert on Thursday evening at Zankel Hall, performing mostly Spanish music with the guitarist Sharon Isbin.

headline: Wary of Mainstream Medicine, Immigrants Seek Remedies From Home
keywords: ['Alternative and Complementary Medicine', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Dietary Supplements and Herbal Remedies', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Emporiums of plant-based medicines offer products for what ails the mind, body and soul, even though scientific studies about their efficacy are inconclusive.
lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon, Ina Vandebroek was poking around the shelves of La 21 Division Botanica on the Grand Concourse in the Bronx. Its narrow aisles were crammed with thousands of votive candles, herbal potions and brightly colored plaster statues of saints.

headline: Immigration: A Hard Line in Politics, but an Applause Line on Broadway
abstract: The issue is sharply divisive in the presidential campaign. But it’s being celebrated on the nation’s most prestigious stages.
lead_paragraph: At the very first out-of-town performance of “On Your Feet!,” the new Broadway musical about Gloria and Emilio Estefan, the pattern was established: The audience erupted in cheers when an angry Mr. Estefan rebuked a hostile record company executive, saying, “You should look very closely at my face, because whether you know it or not … this is what an American looks like.”

headline: Saying He Has Cancer, Missouri Coach Is Resigning
abstract: Pinkel announced on Friday that he has cancer, but his decision to resign comes after he backed his football players’ threatened boycott of a coming game amid racial protests on campus.
lead_paragraph: Saying that he has cancer and wants to focus on his family and his treatment, the head coach of the University of Missouri football team, Gary Pinkel, announced his resignation Friday. The move shocked the college football world after racial protests had put it in the national spotlight and Pinkel had backed his players’ threat to boycott a game.

headline: Daniil Trifonov, New to Rachmaninoff, but a Bold and Youthful Echo
abstract: The 24-year-old Russian pianist-composer is the star attraction of the New York Philharmonic’s Rachmaninoff festival, a focused whirl of animation onstage.
lead_paragraph: David Geffen Hall is nearly empty. An usher roams the aisles. A technician adjusts microphones. A New York Philharmonic woodwind player fiddles with his reeds. Near the stage door sits a piano technician, his work on a Steinway being tested.

headline: Review: Daniil Trifonov Brings Subtlety to Rachmaninoff
abstract: This 24-year-old Russian pianist has begun a three-week New York Philharmonic festival devoted to this composer.
lead_paragraph: For three weeks, on behalf of Rachmaninoff, the New York Philharmonic is putting itself at the disposal of the dazzling 24-year-old Russian pianist Daniil Trifonov. On Wednesday night at David Geffen Hall, Mr. Trifonov was a brilliant, uncommonly poetic soloist in that composer’s Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini and Piano Concerto No. 2. Given the familiarity of these pieces, you might wonder why a Rachmaninoff festival was called for.

headline: Photographers and Filmmakers Using Drones to Reach New Heights
abstract: Long Island high school experimenters and professionals alike are finding that remote-control aerial shots, like of a fisherman’s expression from the ocean side, can expand their perspectives.
lead_paragraph: A group recently congregated in a grassy field at the LongHouse Reserve gardens in East Hampton for a photography workshop, watching intently as a white drone the size of a seagull hovered nearby, its lights flashing and four propellers buzzing. It sounded like a small hive of bees.

headline: Andy White, Drummer on the Beatles’ ‘Love Me Do,’ Dies at 85
abstract: Mr. White, a studio musician renowned for his stylistic flexibility, sat in for the song at the band’s third recording session, while Ringo Starr played the tambourine.
lead_paragraph: Andy White, a studio drummer with a thriving career in London in the 1960s whose best-known work was on the Beatles’ first single, “Love Me Do,” died on Monday at his home in Caldwell, N.J. He was 85.

headline: As Lives Lengthen, Costs Mount
keywords: ['Series', 'Retirement', 'Personal Finances', 'Elderly', 'Income', 'Affordable Housing', 'Social Security (US)', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Some elderly New Yorkers receive too much income to be eligible for assistance, but not enough to pay for the services they need.
lead_paragraph: Frederick Jones and Ping Wong are both over 85; both live on fixed incomes; and both have health problems that limit their mobility. From there, their lives diverge in ways that illuminate the uneven challenges facing New York’s oldest old.

headline: Review: Danish String Quartet Plays at the Rose Studio
abstract: This is the first time that these players have performed the complete quartets of the Danish master Carl Nielsen on a single program.
lead_paragraph: The young players of the superb Danish String Quartet have been performing the four quartets by Denmark’s own Carl Nielsen ever since their student days. Yet these players had never performed all four on a single program until Thursday evening at the intimate Rose Studio, in a concert presented by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center.

headline: Kia Issues a Second Recall of Soul Models in 2 Years
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The recall, which addresses a defect that can cause a loss of steering control, affects cars manufactured in the three latest model years.
lead_paragraph: For the second time in about 17 months, Kia is recalling its Soul model for possible steering loss.

headline: First Draft Focus: Summit in the Sunshine State
abstract: Clockwise from top left: Senator Ted Cruz, Senator Lindsey Graham, Senator Marco Rubio and Mike Huckabee spoke Friday at the Republican Party of Florida’s Sunshine Summit in Orlando.

headline: M.L.B. Picks Tampa Bay Rays to Play Possible Exhibition in Cuba
abstract: Commissioner Rob Manfred picked the team at random from several Major League Baseball franchises eager to compete in Havana during spring training.
lead_paragraph: If a major league baseball team plays a spring training game in Cuba next year, it will be the Tampa Bay Rays.

headline: Review: Sylvie Guillem Says Goodbye, Her Way
abstract: Her farewell show, “Life in Progress,” at City Center, includes works by Akram Khan, Mats Ek, Russell Maliphant and William Forsythe.
lead_paragraph: Sylvie Guillem is a trailblazer, notably in the decisive way she has commandeered her ballet career, but she’s only human. After dancing for nearly four decades, she’s calling it quits. In the charming program note for her farewell performance, “Life in Progress,” Ms. Guillem writes that she gave a friend the final say, or a “license to kill,” if she remained onstage longer than she should. “Frankly,” she writes, “I’d like to spare him this task.”

headline: Andrew Richardson, the Man Who Named a Magazine After Himself
abstract: After a career as a fashion stylist, he is arousing attention with a magazine named after himself, a streetwear line and a boutique, soon to be on both coasts.
lead_paragraph: When Andrew Richardson visited Japan last month, customs officials confiscated copies of his magazine, Richardson, for its sexually explicit photos. About a year ago, his Instagram account was temporarily suspended for showing a part of a woman’s derrière.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Review: ‘Men Are From Mars, Women Are From Venus, Live!’
abstract: Peter Story performs in his one-man show about man-woman relationships, adapted from the book by John Gray.
lead_paragraph: Peter Story brings an awful lot of energy and an engaging delivery to “Men Are From Mars, Women Are From Venus, Live!,” a one-man show at New World Stages, but his efforts don’t always overcome the creakiness of the source material.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing: Paris, Russia, Islamic State
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Review: At Salon Art + Design, What to Check Out
abstract: This fair at the Park Avenue Armory mixes artworks and furniture, showing how architects and interior designers are thinking today.

headline: Professors Dispute Depiction of Harvard Case in Rape Documentary
keywords: ['Movies', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Sex Crimes', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: “The Hunting Ground,” which is to be shown this month on CNN, includes a “false picture” of an assault involving a Harvard law student, they say.
lead_paragraph: The veracity of one of this year’s most talked about documentaries, “The Hunting Ground,” has been attacked by 19 Harvard Law School professors, who say the film’s portrayal of rape on college campus is distorted, specifically when it comes to their school’s handling of one particular case.

headline: Win a Trip 2016
abstract: The Op-Ed columnist Nicholas Kristof invites students to enter a contest for an international reporting trip in 2016.
lead_paragraph: The Op-Ed columnist Nicholas Kristof invites students to enter a contest for an international reporting trip in 2016.

headline: Three Hours of Terror in Paris, Moment by Moment
abstract: Many of the attacks were just minutes apart.
lead_paragraph: Many of the attacks were just minutes apart.

headline: Syria Talks: What Countries Want
abstract: Diplomats from more than a dozen countries are meeting in Vienna on Saturday for talks on ending the Syrian civil war. Here is a rundown of what these countries want in these talks.
lead_paragraph: Diplomats from more than a dozen countries are meeting in Vienna on Saturday for talks on ending the Syrian civil war. Here is a rundown of what these countries want in these talks.

headline: Bill Cunningham | In Living Color
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Autumn (Season)']
abstract: Autumn in New York seemed to reach a crescendo last week, with nature and fashion producing an unbeatable spectrum.
lead_paragraph: Autumn in New York seemed to reach a crescendo last week, with nature and fashion producing an unbeatable spectrum. Urns in Central Park were filled with chrysanthemums, the Conservatory Garden dazzled with its Impressionist floral display and the New York Public Library was trimmed in blossoms — all reflected in the colors of stylish people. The urns on the park’s Bow Bridge, missing for decades, were once again filled with flowers.

headline: Evening Hours | Friends in High Places
abstract: Celebrations of art, politics, public service and more.
lead_paragraph: Celebrations of art, politics, public service and more.

headline: Abortion, Back at the Supreme Court
abstract: The justices face two fundamental issues in a case involving a law whose purpose is to end safe, legal procedures.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, the Supreme Court agreed to hear a case that involves one of the most serious threats to women’s reproductive freedom since Roe v. Wade.

headline: An Oil-Soaked Globe as Production Keeps Climbing and Demand Falls
abstract: The renewed collapse in crude prices is helping to again drive down gasoline prices for American drivers, and a surge in production has led to a global stockpile of three billion barrels.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Such is the state of the oil industry these days that there is sometimes nowhere to put the oil. Off the coast of Texas, a line of roughly 40 tankers has formed, waiting to unload their crude or, in some cases, for a willing buyer to come along. Similar scenes are playing out off the coasts of Singapore and China and in the Persian Gulf.

headline: An Aspiring Actor Refuses to Be Defined by His Past
abstract: Michael Terry survived many troubles and hardships, including being homeless and assaulted by a member of the clergy, but he remains focused on making his dreams come true.
lead_paragraph: To hear Michael Terry tell it, everything about his life seemed difficult. But anything was possible.

headline: Soccer Fans Sing ‘La Marseillaise’
abstract: Soccer fans responded to a series of explosions and shootings in Paris by singing the French national anthem as they were evacuated from the stadium.
lead_paragraph: Soccer fans responded to a series of explosions and shootings in Paris by singing the French national anthem as they were evacuated from the stadium.

headline: The Seduction of Safety, on Campus and Beyond
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Discrimination']
abstract: People who mock the idea of a safe space are the ones who can take their security for granted.
lead_paragraph: I HAVE been searching for safety for most of my life. I experienced a brutal assault when I was young and in that terrible moment, I learned I was vulnerable in unimaginable ways. I have come to crave safety, the idea that I can live free from physical or emotional harm. As an adult, I understand that there is no such thing as safety, that safety is promised to no one, but oh the idea of it remains so lovely, so elusive.

headline: Paris Terror Attacks Leave Awful Realization: Another Massacre
abstract: Ambulances screamed down the boulevards, as a stunned and confused French capital was left to wonder: Why us? Once again?
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The night was chilly but thick with excitement as the big match between France’s national soccer team and archrival Germany was underway at the national stadium in a northern suburb of Paris. President François Hollande watched with the crowd as the French players pushed the ball across midfield.

headline: Kentucky Governor Issues Parting Plea to Successor on Health Care System
keywords: ['Medicaid', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Gov. Steven L. Beshear of Kentucky defended his expansion of Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act, imploring the governor-elect to keep the program.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gov. Steven L. Beshear of Kentucky offered a vivid defense of his expansion of Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act on Friday, imploring Matt Bevin, the Republican governor-elect, to “look at this from a business standpoint, if not from a human standpoint,” and keep the program in place.

headline: Defamation Suits Against Cosby Point to Peril of Belittling Accusers
abstract: Bill Cosby’s lawyers were aggressive enough to fend off rumors about his behavior for years. But the tactic may have backfired in the latest accusations against him.
lead_paragraph: In the last 12 months, dozens of women who for years stayed silent or said little have come forward to accuse the entertainer Bill Cosby of sexually assaulting them, only to find that it was too late to sue him on grounds directly related to the accusations, because of the statute of limitations.

headline: Sharpening Attacks on Marco Rubio, Ted Cruz Urges New Immigration Limits
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Citizenship and Naturalization']
abstract: Mr. Cruz called for a halt to increases in legal immigration “so long as American unemployment remains unacceptably high” but did not detail plans for those in the country illegally.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Escalating a confrontation with Senator Marco Rubio of Florida over immigration policy, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, one of his rivals for the Republican presidential nomination, introduced proposals on Friday outlining his own approach, calling for a halt to increases in legal immigration “so long as American unemployment remains unacceptably high.”

headline: I.M.F. Officials Back Inclusion of Renminbi in Fund’s Currency
abstract: Approval by the International Monetary Fund would be a big step toward China’s campaign to turn its currency into a mainstay of international finance.
lead_paragraph: International Monetary Fund staff members recommended Friday that China’s renminbi be included in the fund’s benchmark basket of currencies, a big step forward for the country’s long campaign to turn its currency into one of the pillars of international finance.

headline: Dismissed Pentagon General Held Wide Influence Behind the Scenes
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter dismissed his senior military assistant, Lt. Gen. Ronald F. Lewis — who held a job little known beyond Washington — for unspecified personal misconduct.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lt. Gen. Ronald F. Lewis held a job that is little known beyond Washington. But his abrupt and public firing on Thursday called attention not only to a senior officer’s potentially career-ending scandal but also to the huge influence over military policy that his position, senior military assistant to the defense secretary, wields.

headline: A Daunting Trip to School for Some Homeless Children
abstract: With its shelter system overburdened, the city has resorted to placing some families in hotels on Staten Island, far from the schools they had been attending.
lead_paragraph: The daily trek to school begins outside a cluster of budget-price hotels in an industrial area in the middle of Staten Island.

headline: Some See Attacks by Donald Trump as Start of His Downfall
abstract: After Mr. Trump posted a video mocking Ben Carson as a liar, the more pressing question seemed to concern whether Mr. Trump will be able to attract a majority of Republican primary voters.
lead_paragraph: First he compared Ben Carson to a “child molester” in a nationally televised interview. Then, at a campaign rally in Iowa, Donald J. Trump asked for someone to come try to stab him in the abdomen, twisting his own belt buckle as if to prove that Mr. Carson’s account of having knifed a friend, as a wild-tempered youth, had to have been a lie.

headline: California’s Prison Experiment
abstract: By scaling back punishments for low-level offenses, the state has shown that crime can drop under such reforms.
lead_paragraph: What happens when you release thousands of prison inmates before the end of their sentences?

headline: ‘Scene of Carnage’ Inside Sold-Out Paris Concert Hall
abstract: People attending a show by an American group, Eagles of Death Metal, described sudden terror when gunmen burst into the Bataclan concert hall.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The band had been playing to the crowd at one of this city’s most popular music venues, the Bataclan, for about an hour. The 150-year-old music hall was sold out for the show by the American group Eagles of Death Metal.

headline: Jack Yufe, a Jew Whose Twin Was a Nazi, Dies at 82
abstract: Mr. Yufe became a celebrity after he and his brother were subjects in a study of nature versus nurture.
lead_paragraph: One day in 1954, Jack Yufe, a store owner from Southern California, stepped off a train in Essen, West Germany, and began searching the crowd at the station. He was looking for someone he had not seen since he was a baby, 21 years earlier.

headline: With a Big Lead, Mrs. Clinton Can Afford to Take Some Risks
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Debates (Political)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Minimum Wage', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Hillary Clinton holds a 19-point lead over Bernie Sanders. She should stop playing it safe and spell out what her proposals mean, in bold detail.
lead_paragraph: As Hillary Rodham Clinton, Bernie Sanders and Martin O’Malley head into their second debate on Saturday, Democratic primary voters favor Mrs. Clinton over Senator Sanders of Vermont by 52 percent to 33 percent, according to a new New York Times/CBS News poll. But a much larger number — 78 percent — expect Mrs. Clinton to be the Democratic nominee.

headline: In Paris, a Night Disrupted by Terror
abstract: Instantly we are scanning Twitter, calling out estimates of the dead.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — IT is a perfectly normal dinner party until someone stands up, checks his phone, and says: I think there’s been an explosion, at the Stade de France.

headline: Tim Valentine, 89, 6-Term Democrat in Congress From North Carolina, Dies
abstract: Mr. Valentine was a moderate Democrat who supported the Voting Rights Act, though race was an underlying issue in his first House campaign.
lead_paragraph: Tim Valentine, who narrowly won the first of six terms in Congress in 1982 by defeating a rival who would have become North Carolina’s first black congressman in decades, died on Tuesday at his home in Rocky Mount, N.C. He was 89.

headline: Bruce B. Dayton, Minnesota Retailer and Arts Patron, Dies at 97
abstract: Mr. Dayton inherited what became the Dayton-Hudson Corporation from his grandfather and father.
lead_paragraph: Bruce B. Dayton, the last of the five brothers whose retailing empire included department stores, some of the nation’s first enclosed shopping malls and the Target discount chain, died on Friday at his home in Orono, Minn., near Minneapolis. He was 97.

headline: Paris Attacks on Social Media
abstract: Scenes from sites of attacks across the Paris area on Friday were shared on social media.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from sites of attacks across the Paris area on Friday were shared on social media.

headline: Panel Backs 1% Raises for New York Police Officers
abstract: The increases awarded to rank-and-file officer, which cover 2010 and 2011, were deemed “an insult” by their union’s president.
lead_paragraph: A state arbitration panel decided on Friday to approve 1 percent raises for rank-and-file New York police officers who have worked for years without a labor pact with the city.

headline: Date Night With the Democrats
abstract: Get ready to settle down Saturday night with Martin, Bernie and Hillary.
lead_paragraph: This weekend’s Democratic debate is going to be a tough sell. Two hours on a Saturday night, and not a single candidate who appears to be certifiably deranged.

headline: Theft of a Boxer’s Championship Belts Devastates His Upstate Hometown
abstract: Residents of Canastota, N.Y. were stunned and angry after four championship belts that belonged to Carmen Basilio, a native who won titles in the 1950s, were stolen from the International Boxing Hall of Fame in town.
lead_paragraph: CANASTOTA, N.Y. — To drivers who take Exit 34 off the New York Thruway, the International Boxing Hall of Fame pops up like a quick jab, welcoming them to this small central New York village about 25 miles east of Syracuse.

headline: Uses Pickup Lines
abstract: A fresh and fun Saturday puzzle by Kameron Austin Smith.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — First of all, this puzzle by Kameron Austin Collins is awesome. It’s not perfect, but it’s fresh and fun and I enjoyed almost every moment of it. And that, to me, more than balances out a less-than-desirable spot or two. That’s what makes a puzzle that is fun to solve.

headline: When Red (Bills) Met Green (Jets), Colorblind Fans Lost
abstract: The all-green uniforms worn by the Jets and the all-red ones of the Bills turned the viewing experience of Thursday’s matchup into headache-inducing misery for colorblind fans.
lead_paragraph: For some fans, the N.F.L. Week 10 game on Thursday night did not become unwatchable when the Jets committed two turnovers in a two-minute span or bungled a late comeback attempt. Or even when the Buffalo Bills punter muffed a snap.

headline: Acquittal of Vincent Asaro Is Latest Setback in Mafia Prosecutions
abstract: Federal prosecutors spent three weeks presenting evidence against the reputed mobster. His fast acquittal could signal a change in public feeling toward Mafia informants.
lead_paragraph: After 12 jurors acquitted the reputed mobster Vincent Asaro on all charges Thursday and left the courtroom, lawyers and trial observers were left asking: What happened?

headline: St. John’s Gives Nervous Chris Mullin First Coaching Victory in His First Try
abstract: Chris Mullin’s first win as a coach was in the books, with a 66-57 victory over Wagner at Carnesecca Arena on Friday.
lead_paragraph: When it was over, and Chris Mullin’s first win as a coach was in the books, he made his way toward the southeast corner of the stands, to kiss the left hand of the man who brought him to St. John’s.

headline: Terror and Confusion in Paris
abstract: On the Boulevard Beaumarchais, there was shock on Friday over a siege at a concert hall that took place a short distance from the attack on Charlie Hebdo in January.
lead_paragraph: On the Boulevard Beaumarchais, there was shock on Friday over a siege at a concert hall that took place a short distance from the attack on Charlie Hebdo in January.

headline: Red Sox Acquire Star Closer Craig Kimbrel
abstract: The San Diego Padres traded Kimbrel, who had 39 saves in 43 chances after joining the team last season from Atlanta, for four of Boston’s minor league prospects.
lead_paragraph: The revival of the San Diego Padres was a flop last season, and the Boston Red Sox are the latest team to poach one of their talented players. In their first major move under baseball operations president Dave Dombrowski, the Red Sox traded four prospects Friday for Craig Kimbrel, a four-time All-Star who is only 27 years old.

headline: More Scrutiny, Better Policing
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Police', 'Cameras', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Law enforcement must embrace innovations like body cameras.
lead_paragraph: THE director of the F.B.I., James B. Comey, recently offered an explanation for a reported uptick of violent crime in some of our cities. “A chill wind,” he said, “has blown through American law enforcement over the last year” — a reference to the so-called Ferguson effect that increased scrutiny on police conduct has led to reduced law enforcement in some urban neighborhoods.

headline: ‘The Knick’ Season 2, Episode 5: Rapid Progress
abstract: If the Knick’s doctors have their way, there won’t be any diseases left for us to worry about a century later.
lead_paragraph: If the small staff of the Knickerbocker Hospital has its way, there won’t be any diseases left for us to worry about a century later. In Friday night’s episode of “The Knick” alone, John Thackery was zeroing in on the causes of addiction while the former (and presumably future) Knick surgeon Bertie Chickering was about to use radiation to treat his mother’s cancer (based on a tip from Algernon Edwards). In the same spirit of constant innovation, Thackery rigged a telephone for use as a metal detector to find shrapnel in the body of a subway worker — a nurse held the receiver to her ear and when she heard static, Thackery pulled out a nail from deep within the man’s body.

headline: LeBron James Springs to Life and Forces Knicks to Relive a Collapse
abstract: The Knicks let their lead slip from their grasp, as the Cavaliers came back once again to win, 90-84, on Friday at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: Seconds remained in the first half when Carmelo Anthony started sizing up Tristan Thompson along the right sideline, near the Knicks’ bench. Hunched over, Anthony braided low, hypnotizing dribbles between his legs, back and forth across his body. Then, midstep, he rose and slung a parabolic 3-pointer that splashed through the net.

headline: Braves Fans Can Put Their Money on the Team
abstract: Liberty Media, which owns the Atlanta Braves, said it would offer a tracking stock specifically for the team.
lead_paragraph: Atlanta Braves fans can now bet on the future of their team, and not just by buying tickets.

headline: Eagles of Death Metal, a Band Known for Wit, Now Mired in Tragedy
abstract: The band whose concert was the site of the worst violence in Paris is a blues-rock outfit with an irreverent side; all its members were reported safe.
lead_paragraph: The band that was playing Friday evening at the Bataclan concert hall in Paris, where about 100 people were killed in one of a wave of attacks on the city, has an inadvertently alarming name: Eagles of Death Metal.

headline: How Paris Terror Attacks Unfolded
abstract: A series of attacks in Paris from the main sports stadium to the Bataclan concert hall spread terror across the city Friday night.
lead_paragraph: A series of attacks in Paris from the main sports stadium to the Bataclan concert hall spread terror across the city Friday night.

headline: Don’t Pit the Healthy Against the Sick
abstract: Readers take issue with an article by Ezekiel J. Emanuel, who is concerned that he is paying for someone else’s medicine.

headline: The Virtues of Arbitration
abstract: The U.S. Chamber Institute for Legal Reform says that “arbitration provides consumers with a fairer, simpler, cheaper and faster way of resolving disputes.”

abstract: The Pakistani Embassy and the co-president of the International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War respond to an editorial.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Columbia? An Ivy League Power?
abstract: Columbia greeted the men’s basketball season Friday with an 11 a.m. game amid excitement that it can make the N.C.A.A. tournament this season.
lead_paragraph: Columbia greeted the men’s basketball season Friday with an 11 a.m. game amid excitement that it can make the N.C.A.A. tournament this season.

headline: Conservationists Decry Slaying of Cambodian Forest Guards, Pointing to China Timber Trade
keywords: ['Corruption (Institutional)', 'Environment', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Logging Industry', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Poaching (Wildlife)']
abstract: Two forest guardians in Cambodia are slain in their hammocks, prompting conservationists to call for a crackdown on illegal logging and violence.
lead_paragraph: One week ago, two members of a four-person team patrolling for illegal loggers and wildlife poachers in the Preah Vihear Protected Forest in northwestern Cambodia were shot and killed in their sleep, as Mongabay reported. Six men suspected in the murders, including a soldier, were arrested early in the week, but have been charged only with illegal logging for the moment as authorities continue to sift for evidence.

headline: CBS Shifts Emphasis of Democratic Debate to Reflect Paris Attacks
abstract: The network’s news team has reworked plans and reformulated questions for the Saturday debate to make them more related to terrorism and national security.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — In the hours after the deadly attacks in Paris, CBS News significantly reworked its plans for the Democratic presidential debate it is hosting here on Saturday night to focus more on issues of terrorism, national security and foreign relations.

headline: What to Watch Saturday
abstract: An early Steve Jobs documentary, a new crime series from France and episodes of “Doctor Who” for sci-fi fans and “Dr. Dee” for animal lovers.
lead_paragraph: Today’s lineup — crime; travel through time, space, dimensions and tundra; home repair; ’70s teenagers; Steve Jobs; and James Taylor — pairs well with popcorn.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 14, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “As I speak, terrorist attacks of an unprecedented scale are taking place in the Paris region. There are several dozen dead, lots more wounded. It’s horrific.”

headline: Corrections: November 14, 2015
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, November 14, 2015.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: News Media Scrambles to Cover Paris Shootings
abstract: American media outlets rushed reporters to Paris, while networks shifted their programming in the wake of the killings.
lead_paragraph: The American news media scrambled on Friday evening and early Saturday to cover the deadly attacks in Paris, an event unfolding thousands of miles away in multiple locations across a city gripped by terror and uncertainty.

headline: Three Teams of Coordinated Attackers Carried Out Assault on Paris, Officials Say; Hollande Blames ISIS
abstract: The assault on Paris was carried out by three teams of attackers — including one who traveled to Europe on a Syrian passport along with the flow of migrants — on behalf of ISIS, officials said.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Three teams of Islamic State attackers acting in unison carried out the terrorist assault in Paris on Friday night, officials said Saturday, including one assailant who may have traveled to Europe on a Syrian passport along with the flow of migrants.

headline: Attacks in Central Paris
abstract: At least 127 people were killed and dozens were wounded in six apparently coordinated attacks.
lead_paragraph: At least 127 people were killed and dozens were wounded in six apparently coordinated attacks.

headline: Meet the Instamom, a Stage Mother for Social Media
abstract: The social network is an express track for parents interested in sharing and sometimes capitalizing on the visual story line of their children’s lives.
lead_paragraph: It was a gorgeous fall day in Dumbo, Brooklyn, and Keira Cannon was holding one of the weekend photo shoots she does with her favorite subject: her son, Princeton.

headline: IBM’s Design-Centered Strategy to Set Free the Squares
abstract: The tech stalwart has been hiring designers by the hundreds, all part of an accelerated approach to product development that is a major departure from the past.
lead_paragraph: Phil Gilbert is a tall man with a shaved head and wire-rimmed glasses. He typically wears cowboy boots and bluejeans to work — hardly unusual these days, except he’s an executive at IBM, a company that still has a button-down suit-and-tie reputation. And in case you don’t get the message from his wardrobe, there’s a huge black-and-white photograph hanging in his office of a young Bob Dylan, hunched over sheet music, making changes to songs in the “Highway 61 Revisited” album. It’s an image, Mr. Gilbert will tell you, that conveys both a rebel spirit and hard work.

headline: A Princess Aboard the Queen Mary 2
keywords: ['Ships and Shipping', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Royal Families', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Princess Anne, daughter of Queen Elizabeth II, pays a royal visit to the Queen Mary 2, while docked in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: “Who are we meeting?” Tony Perrottet, an Australian-born historian, asked one recent Thursday. “Is it a princess? It’s not a queen, is it? It couldn’t be the queen. Am I meant to know this? Was it on the invitation?”

headline: Using High Heels for Self-Defense
keywords: ['Self-Defense', 'Women and Girls', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Sex Crimes', 'Sexual Harassment']
abstract: Some women who wear high heels are taking a self-defense class that teaches them how to fight back when they’re wearing heels if they’re attacked.
lead_paragraph: On a recent rainy evening, about 30 women, most wearing high heels, gathered in a Midtown Manhattan rehearsal space and engaged in a series of brisk maneuvers: hammer fists, elbowing out of chokeholds, fierce kicks.

headline: Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Gloria Steinem on the Unending Fight for Women’s Rights
abstract: The two longtime friends discuss everything from rap names to the moments that spurred them to action.
lead_paragraph: The room went still when the women hugged. All of the staff, bustling in preparation just moments before, paused when Ruth Bader Ginsburg emerged quietly from her private chambers at the Supreme Court last month and embraced her old friend Gloria Steinem.

headline: How to Pick a Meditation App
abstract: A number of new meditation apps promise a journey to mindfulness, but with so many different options, it’s tough to know what to look for.
lead_paragraph: By now you’ve probably read about how meditation may help you manage anxiety, stress and blood pressure, and help you sleep better, be more creative and improve your relationships. While researchers are still debating many of these claims, a number of apps offer guided meditation specifically designed to take you from a first-time meditator to mindfulness guru.

headline: ISIS Claims Responsibility, Calling Paris Attacks ‘First of the Storm’
abstract: The statement was issued online in Arabic, French and English and distributed via supporters on Twitter, according to a group that tracks jihadist propaganda.
lead_paragraph: SINONE, Iraq — The Islamic State claimed responsibility on Saturday for the catastrophic attacks in the French capital, calling them “the first of the storm” and mocking France as a “capital of prostitution and obscenity,” according to statements released in multiple languages on one of the terror group’s encrypted messaging accounts.

headline: The Week on Instagram
abstract: Photos posted on @nytimes this week took followers from the roads of Liberia’s countryside to a boatyard in Washington State
lead_paragraph: Photos posted on @nytimes this week took followers from the roads of Liberia’s countryside to a boatyard in Washington State

headline: Feeling Woozy? It May Be Cyber Sickness
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Headaches', 'Migraine Headaches', 'Motion Sickness', 'Virtual Reality (Computers)']
abstract: A peculiar side effect of screen time is cybersickness, which causes a person to feel woozy from viewing moving digital content.
lead_paragraph: If you are watching computer-generated mayhem in the latest action film or scrolling rapidly on your smartphone, you may start to feel a little off. Maybe it is a dull headache or dizziness or creeping nausea.

headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: Robots vs. Jobs
abstract: A look at a G.O.P. candidate’s thoughts on how robots may replace humans in the work force, and a smartphone from Facebook that sends news alerts to your phone.
lead_paragraph: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: Attacks in Paris Add Urgency to Talks on Ending Syria War
abstract: Top diplomats from more than a dozen countries met to discuss how to end the crisis in Syria, vowing to redouble their efforts to confront terrorism.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — The top diplomats from more than a dozen countries agreed Saturday to press forward on an ambitious timetable to engineer a political transition and cease-fire in Syria, but remained deeply divided on major issues after a round of talks that gained intensity following the terrorist attacks in Paris.

headline: Putting a Stop to a Neighbor’s Slurs
abstract: This week: A co-op board steers clear of a squabble among residents; a business is run out of a residential home; and a wish for a backyard cabana.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Paris Terror Attacks May Prompt More Aggressive U.S. Strategy on ISIS
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: With lethal strikes against Russia, in Lebanon, and now in Paris, the Islamic State shows its chilling reach, and becomes a broader threat.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the Islamic State stormed onto the scene in Syria and Iraq, it seemed focused on seizing territory in its own neighborhood. But in the last two weeks, the so-called soldiers of the caliphate appear to have demonstrated a chilling reach, with terrorist attacks against Russia, in Lebanon and now in France.

headline: France Attacks to Dominate Agenda at G-20 Conference in Turkey
abstract: President Obama landed in Turkey for an annual gathering of presidents and prime ministers that is poised to become an urgent summit meeting on confronting extremism.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will consult about the Paris terrorist attacks with world leaders in Turkey this weekend as the annual gathering of presidents and prime ministers from the world’s largest economies there is poised to become an urgent summit meeting on confronting extremism.

headline: Tens of Thousands March in Seoul, Calling for Ouster of President
abstract: South Korean police fired water cannons and tear gas at protesters, who were brought together by a host of grievances, including President Park Geun-hye’s decision to replace school history textbooks.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The police on Saturday fired water cannons and tear gas at thousands of protesters shouting for President Park Geun-hye’s resignation while marching toward her office in Seoul in the largest antigovernment demonstration here in several years.

headline: As Paris Attacks Unfolded, Players and Fans at Soccer Stadium Remained Unaware
abstract: Coaches for France and Germany decided not to tell their players of the carnage, and most fans in the Stade de France just north of Paris had no cellphone reception.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Shortly after 9:45 p.m. Friday, at halftime of an exhibition soccer match between France and Germany, the players on both teams went to their locker rooms to rest while the coaches, who normally would have been reviewing their strategies, instead received shocking news.

headline: Paris Attacks: What We Know and Don’t Know

headline: The Real Problem With the Economy
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Income Inequality', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Shopping and Retail', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The slumping stock market this week is a blip. What makes it dismaying is the political and economic backdrop.
lead_paragraph: The slumping stock market this week and the weaker-than-expected retail sales report are blips.

headline: Saks and Gimbel’s, a Merchandising Legend
abstract: It was just a country store in Indiana that sold itself into the hearts of shoppers and became a merchandising legend.
lead_paragraph: It was just a country store in Indiana that sold itself into the hearts of shoppers and became a merchandising legend.

headline: Saks Is Shaking Off Retail Gloom With a Fifth Avenue Face-Lift
abstract: As department stores struggle, Saks is trying to restore its glory with a $250 million renovation of its storied Manhattan flagship.
lead_paragraph: Marc Metrick stepped off a freight elevator at Saks Fifth Avenue one recent afternoon and navigated his way past mangled wires and bare concrete beams, his Prada lace-ups crunching on broken glass.

headline: Terror in Paris
abstract: The French remain defiant and united in the wake of a barbaric night of violence.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday morning, after an evening of incomprehensible barbarism against a free and civilized society by armed terrorists, President François Hollande of France declared the attacks an act of war. More than 125 people were slaughtered in multiple venues in Paris — in a concert hall, at several restaurants, near a sports stadium, on the street. Mr. Hollande declared a nationwide state of emergency, imposed checks at all of France’s borders, and called in the army to protect the city.

headline: Amber Guild of Collins: Call Out the Elephant in the Room
abstract: Ms. Guild, president of the brand consultancy Collins, believes that an effective leader must be willing to embrace conflict.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Amber Guild, president of Collins, a brand consultancy, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Israeli Forces Destroy Family Homes of 4 Palestinians Accused in Shootings
abstract: The demolitions on Saturday were the most sweeping use of a recently revived, controversial antiterrorism measure since unrest escalated last month.
lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — Israeli forces on Saturday destroyed the family homes of three Palestinian men charged with carrying out a drive-by shooting last month that killed a couple in front of their four children, and the forces also demolished the home of a man accused of fatally shooting an Israeli in June.

headline: No Dot on ‘i,’ but Pitt Crosses the ‘t’s’ in a Return to Its Signature Script
abstract: Developed by the Panthers’ coach, Johnny Majors, in the early 1970s, the beloved logo that lasted for 24 seasons is back, and Pitt faithful are snapping up anything they can get their hands on that bears it.
lead_paragraph: The Pitt Script, the iconic helmet insignia made famous by University of Pittsburgh legends like Tony Dorsett and Dan Marino, has made a full comeback this fall. The current football team loves it.

headline: Lexie Sachs: A Sentry for the Good Housekeeping Seal
abstract: In a lab, Ms. Sachs tests textiles, paper and plastics for manufacturers who seek the Good Housekeeping magazine seal of approval.
lead_paragraph: Lexie Sachs, 28, senior product analyst at the Good Housekeeping Institute in New York

headline: A Tax-Cutting Move That Pfizer Can Hardly Resist
abstract: The drug maker’s latest move toward shifting its legal tax headquarters abroad has drawn scorn from politicians, but it’s a shareholder-friendly tactic.
lead_paragraph: Give Pfizer, the giant drug maker, points for boldness and persistence: The company has bravely put “tax inversions” back in the headlines.

headline: Immigration Sanctuary Ban Creates Uncertainty in North Carolina
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Police', 'Local Government', 'Immigration Detention', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The police chief of Durham said a new state law would erode trust among undocumented residents, but officials in other so-called sanctuary cities weren’t sure what practical changes might result.
lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.C. — A day after Gov. Pat McCrory signed a bill prohibiting so-called sanctuary city policies in North Carolina, Jose Lopez, the police chief in Durham, was assessing the effect it would have on this city, where, for the last dozen years, police officers have been instructed to limit inquiries about a person’s immigration status.

headline: Jerry Stritzke of REI: If You Can’t Be Outside, Bring the Outside In
keywords: ['Workplace Environment', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)']

headline: Marco Rubio’s History on Immigration Leaves Conservatives Distrustful of Shift
abstract: Anti-immigration passions have roiled the Republican Party through the primary and debate season. And the shifting views of one Republican presidential candidate seen by some as a rising star, Marco Rubio, are under attack.
lead_paragraph: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — Joyce Kaufman sat in her radio studio here the other day and said the first word that comes to mind when she thinks of Marco Rubio. “A chameleon,” she scoffed.

headline: For Gary Pinkel at Missouri, an Evolution Followed by a Revolution
keywords: ['Football (College)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Coaches and Managers']
abstract: Pinkel, the Tigers’ football coach, had to side with his players, but he did not appear to be entirely comfortable in the role of social revolutionary in bringing about the resignations of two key university officials.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, Mo. — Coaching at the high altitude of Division I college football is only partly about football. It requires a deep hike into regions controlled by state politicians and high-rolling boosters and alumni, not to mention an occasional grapple with society’s most intractable problems.

headline: Rising Mortality Rates for Working-Class Whites
keywords: ['Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Addiction (Psychology)', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Readers offer their theories to explain the findings of a new study.
lead_paragraph: Readers offer their theories to explain why middle-aged whites are dying earlier.

headline: The Exploitation of Paris
abstract: In haste, people twist the bloodshed in France to their own purposes.
lead_paragraph: Can’t we wait until we’ve resolved the body count? Until the identities of all of the victims have been determined and their families informed? Until the sirens stop wailing? Until the blood is dry?

headline: How to Watch the Democratic Debate
abstract: Television, radio, the Internet and social media offer ways to tune in as Hillary Rodham Clinton, Bernie Sanders and Martin O’Malley share the stage.
lead_paragraph: While the eyes of the world are on the aftermath of terrorist attacks in Paris, the Democratic presidential debate in Iowa will go on.

headline: Egyptian Leaders Blame a Familiar Foe, Conspiracy, but Citizens Are Dubious
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: Faced with skepticism after a Russian plane crash in Sinai and flooding in Alexandria, Egyptian officials portray Western alarms of terrorism as a plot against Egypt.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt sought on Wednesday to reassure residents of Sharm el Sheikh about the exodus of tourists after the crash of a Russian charter jet after takeoff from the resort’s airport. But to Egyptians worried about putting food on their tables, he offered little comfort.

headline: ISIS Leader in Libya Is Targeted in U.S. Airstrike
keywords: ['Targeted Killings', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The United States has broadened its fight against the Islamic State, targeting the group’s senior leader in Libya on Friday night, the Pentagon announced on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States has broadened its fight against the Islamic State, targeting the group’s senior leader in Libya on Friday night, the Pentagon announced on Saturday.

headline: Many Say High Deductibles Make Their Health Law Insurance All but Useless
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: For many consumers, the sticker shock is coming not on the front end, when they purchase Affordable Care Act plans, but when they get sick and are hit by sky-high deductibles.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Obama administration officials, urging people to sign up for health insurance under the Affordable Care Act, have trumpeted the low premiums available on the law’s new marketplaces.

headline: Lindsey Vonn Is Fearlessly Forging Ahead
abstract: With her career at a crossroads and some personal life goals — like having a family — postponed indefinitely, Vonn has charted a final competitive stage that begins when the World Cup resumes later this month.
lead_paragraph: VAIL, Colo. — This past summer, sitting by herself inside the first house she has ever owned, Lindsey Vonn took stock of the rollicking past decade in the public eye.

headline: To Weld, Perchance, to Dream
abstract: My father was a welder. So I actually did have a choice to make: to weld or to philosophize?
lead_paragraph: It’s not often that one finds oneself uniquely qualified to comment on a matter in the popular media, but when Marco Rubio argued at the Republican debate last week that the country needs “more welders and less philosophers,” I had my moment. My father was a welder, and I am a philosopher. I actually did have a choice to make some decades ago: to weld or to philosophize?

headline: A New Way to Improve College Enrollment
abstract: A unique educational collaboration in Long Beach, Calif., raises college admissions and graduation rates for the poor and underprivileged.
lead_paragraph: AMERICAN public schools do a good job of getting students into college, but a poor job preparing them to succeed once they’re there. While more than two-thirds of high school graduates enroll in college, nearly two-thirds of those arrive on campus unprepared for college-level rigor.

headline: Angus Deaton
abstract: A Nobel laureate on his taste for opera, fly-fishing and scatological jokes.
lead_paragraph: Angus Deaton is a professor of economics at Princeton and winner of this year’s Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science.

headline: Gifts With Meaning
keywords: ['Philanthropy', 'Holidays and Special Occasions', 'Gifts', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: Some ideas for holiday presents, including helping a girl attend school, a refugee stay warm, a blind person regain sight and a doctor save lives.
lead_paragraph: IT’S time for my annual holiday gift guide, the chance to recommend presents more meaningful than a tie or sweater.

headline: Why Free Can Be a Problem on the Internet
abstract: Will “zero-rating” plans like T-Mobile’s new Binge On let telecom companies unfairly influence what services people use?
lead_paragraph: T-Mobile, the wireless company, said last week that it would let customers watch as many movies as they wanted on services like Netflix and HBO as well as all other kinds of video, without having it count against their monthly data plans. Given the growing popularity of streaming video, its plan, called Binge On, should appeal to many consumers. But there are real concerns about whether such promotions could give telecommunications companies the ability to influence what services people use on the Internet, benefiting some businesses and hurting others.

headline: Policing for Profit in St. Louis County
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Traffic and Parking Violations', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Fines (Penalties)']
abstract: A cap on revenue from traffic fines caused towns in St. Louis County to get creative and hand out tickets for untidy window blinds.
lead_paragraph: As many unwary drivers can attest, small-town speed traps have long been a steady source of income for local governments. But “policing for profit” acquired sinister overtones when a Justice Department investigation into the shooting and racial unrest in Ferguson, Mo., drew attention to the fact that some towns in St. Louis County derived 40 percent or more of their revenue by repeatedly nailing citizens with traffic fines and fees for petty violations.

headline: Don’t Let the Aid for 9/11 Responders Expire
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'James Zadroga 9-11 Health and Compensation Act', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Reparations', 'September 11 (2001)']
abstract: Moves to cut compensation for disabled first responders to the 9/11 attacks should be soundly rejected.
lead_paragraph: In a positive signal from Congress, bipartisan majorities in both houses are on record as approving permanent renewal and financing of the emergency health care and compensation programs needed by thousands of first responders to the 9/11 attacks who are suffering illnesses as a result of their labors at the devastated sites.

headline: Men’s Lib!
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Men and Boys', 'Gender', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Women have learned to become more like men. Now men need to learn to become more like women.
lead_paragraph: SO far the gender revolution has been a one-sided effort. Women have entered previously male precincts of economic and political life, and for the most part they have succeeded. They can lead companies, fly fighter jets, even run for president.

headline: Win a Trip in 2016
keywords: ['Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Contests and Prizes', 'Poverty', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: I’m pleased to invite university students to apply for my 2016 win-a-trip journey.
lead_paragraph: I’m pleased to invite university students to apply for my 2016 win-a-trip journey. I’ve been holding my win-a-trip contest since 2006, then taking the winner along with me on a reporting trip to the developing world. My aim is to generate interest in neglected global issues, and frankly it’s also an occasion for me to write about the issues in my column.

headline: A Poet’s Election Victory Over a Former General Speaks of a New Myanmar
abstract: Perhaps no election victory was more eloquent than that of U Tin Thit, a poet and former political prisoner who defeated a former defense minister.
lead_paragraph: KYI DAUNG KAN, Myanmar — It was the poet versus the soldier — and the poet won.

headline: Plan to Export Chimps Tests Law to Protect Species
keywords: ['Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Monkeys and Apes', 'Research', 'ANIMALS']
abstract: A plan to export eight chimps from a research center in Atlanta to a zoo in England is a first test of an endangered species listing that says that only actions that benefit chimpanzees as a species should be allowed.
lead_paragraph: When the Fish and Wildlife Service decided in June to classify all chimpanzees, captive or wild, as endangered, the ruling meant that any biomedical experiment or export of chimps from the United States, whoever owned them, would be subject to a strict permit process under the Endangered Species Act.

headline: To Save Paris, Defeat ISIS
abstract: The only adequate response to the slaughter in France is military and the objective must be to crush ISIS.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — The Paris slaughter claimed by the Islamic State constitutes, as President François Hollande of France declared, an “act of war.” As such, it demands of all NATO states a collective response under Article 5 of the North Atlantic Treaty. This says that, “An armed attack against one or more of them in Europe or North America shall be considered an attack against them all.”

headline: Steely Veteran of the Sea to Make a Voyage Home
abstract: The Peking, a steel windjammer built in 1911 in Germany, is returning from New York City to its home country after the German government allocated 30 million euros to make the journey possible.
lead_paragraph: The Peking has faced gale-force winds and hurricanes. It has seen war and rough seas and rogue waves. Through it all, from its construction in 1911, it survived, and in 1974, it found a port where it could rest.

headline: Players on Fringes of Tennis Chase a Status Symbol to Cherish
abstract: On the Futures circuit, the lowest level that awards ATP ranking points, players try to earn a symbol that they are genuine touring professionals.
lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — The crowd was tiny, but the emotions were quite the contrary. As Korey Lovett finished off his comeback victory in the first round of the Player’s Choice Open here this month, one of his coaches at the University of Alabama, Ryler DeHeart, rushed to congratulate Lovett’s father.

headline: One Small Rankings Point Feels Like a Giant Leap, When It Is the First
abstract: The vast majority of professional tennis players remember exactly when they received theirs. “It’s like a milestone,” Roger Federer said.
lead_paragraph: Jim Courier, a former No. 1, said a tennis player never forgets a first ranking point.

headline: At Metropolitan Opera, Support for Paris Sounds Out With Singing of  France’s National Anthem
abstract: Led by Plácido Domingo, the opera cast and audience sang “La Marseillaise” on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera showed its support for the people of Paris in the wake of the terrorist attacks by opening its Saturday matinee of Puccini’s “Tosca” with Plácido Domingo conducting the orchestra and chorus in the French national anthem, “La Marseillaise.”

headline: The Tricky Terrain of Virtual Reality
keywords: ['Public Editor (Times Column)', 'Virtual Reality (Computers)', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The Times has developed a cutting-edge way to tell stories using virtual reality. Now comes the real challenge: adapting tried-and-true rules to a new medium.
lead_paragraph: The arrival of a small cardboard box with last Sunday’s Times represented, in its unobtrusive way, a collision of cultures.

headline: Kevin Love Is Back With Cavs and More Determined
abstract: After missing most of the playoffs last season with a dislocated left shoulder, Love has since waded into his second season with the Cavaliers, and it is an experiment that continues to captivate the N.B.A.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Love went nearly four months without shooting a basketball after he dislocated his left shoulder in a playoff game against the Boston Celtics last April. He spent much of his rehabilitation at altitude in Utah, where he focused on his conditioning. By early September, he was ready to return to the court.

headline: Challenged by Bullies, but Channeling the Anger
abstract: Julio Mattos, 15, had become sullen and withdrawn, a result, in part, of constant bullying. A local boxing gym has helped him manage his frustrations.
lead_paragraph: On many occasions, Julio Mattos has used some of his allowance to buy pizza slices for homeless people or snacks to feed to stray animals.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Laughable Disguise
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Debates (Political)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: It’s a season of false political fronts. His is especially bogus.
lead_paragraph: THE venerated political strategist David Axelrod once described a presidential campaign as “an M.R.I. for the soul.” It winds up being precisely that.

headline: Half-Century Later, 76ers Again Pursue the Warriors’ Path
abstract: The Golden State Warriors and the Philadelphia 76ers now represent the polar opposites of where a team can be in its development.
lead_paragraph: The Golden State Warriors never lose and the Philadelphia 76ers never win. Two original N.B.A. franchises linked forever when one took the place of the other in Philadelphia, they now represent the polar opposites of where a team can be in its development.

headline: Republican Candidates Urge Aggressive Response After Paris Attacks

lead_paragraph: François Molins, the Paris prosecutor, said that officials had identified one suspect in Friday's attacks as a man born near Paris who had been listed as an extremist since 2010.

headline: Paris Attacks Could Bolster Hillary Clinton’s Support, Focus Group Indicates
