lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — The Paris terrorist attacks, raising questions about American leadership in the world and national security, will most likely bolster Hillary Rodham Clinton’s strengths in Saturday’s debate, according to a focus group of undecided Iowa Democrats.

headline: The Virtue of Contradicting Ourselves
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Research', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: We don’t like flip-floppers, but we should consider voting for them anyway.
lead_paragraph: IF you’re a politician, there may be something worse than being called a liar, a cheater, a jerk or a wimp. In America, you don’t want to be known as a flip-flopper. Jeb Bush and Hillary Rodham Clinton have both been criticized for changing their positions from yes to no on invading Iraq. A decade earlier, flip-flopping was one of the biggest knocks against John Kerry. In a JibJab video gone viral, an animated George W. Bush mocked Mr. Kerry: “You have more waffles than a house of pancakes.”

headline: Attackers in Paris ‘Did Not Give Anybody a Chance’
abstract: Parisians who went out on Friday night to listen to music, watch soccer, or enjoy a meal or drink with friends, quickly became engulfed in a blood-soaked drama.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — François Granier, a wine consultant and rock music fan, thought the concert he was attending Friday night had simply taken a particularly raucous turn.

headline: A Crisis Our Universities Deserve
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'College Athletics', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Campus radicals are often spoiled and self-dramatizing, but they also do have something to protest.
lead_paragraph: BETWEEN the 19th century and the 1950s, the American university was gradually transformed from an institution intended to transmit knowledge into an institution designed to serve technocracy. The religious premises fell away, the classical curriculums were displaced by specialized majors, the humanities ceded pride of place to technical disciplines, and the professor’s role became more and more about research rather than instruction.

headline: Parisians Fear Terror Attacks Will Divide, Not Unite, the City
abstract: Friday’s killings came just 10 months after the massacre at Charlie Hebdo, provoking new concern about France’s ability to manage the deep gulf between Muslims and non-Muslims.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Tony Balet came to work on Saturday with a ribbon pinned on his shirt. It was red, white, blue and black.

headline: Is Mark Zuckerberg Ready for Facebook Parenthood?
abstract: He changed how the rest of us share our kids with the world. It’s almost his turn.
lead_paragraph: IN a Manhattan cafe, I sit near a mother and her young daughter having tea. The daughter looks out the window. The mother takes pictures of her own shoes on a marvelously tiled floor, and of her daughter, who ignores her assiduously. I watch the mother artfully arrange the daughter’s teacup for a shot. I watch the daughter set her jaw. I watch the mother take a photo of the daughter and her teacup. The light is just so. I watch the mother consider her caption and hashtags and post it. I watch the mother scroll through her newsfeed. I watch the daughter stare out the window.

headline: Teaching Peace in Elementary School
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Education (K-12)', 'Children and Childhood', 'Emotions', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Many educators believe that children need to learn emotional intelligence to reach their full academic potential.
lead_paragraph: FOR years, there has been a steady stream of headlines about the soaring mental health needs of college students and their struggles with anxiety and lack of resilience.

headline: America, the Not So Promised Land
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: We conveniently forget that a third of the immigrants who came here a century ago didn’t like what they found — and went back.
lead_paragraph: ONE of the great myths Americans have about their country is that everyone wants to come here. Advocates and enemies of immigration share this assumption, which dates at least as far back as the turn of the 20th century. As reports of “American fever” circulated in Eastern Europe, one Polish economist, Leopold Caro, claimed that entire villages were becoming ghost towns. “Many houses stood empty, and in many others only old women and small children remained behind. In some villages the entire young generation left home.”

headline: As Paris Terror Attacks Unfolded, Social Media Tools Offered Help in Crisis
abstract: Facebook activated its Safety Check tool while Twitter put its new Moments tool to use, highlighting top news tweets about the attacks.

headline: Robert Craft, Stravinsky Adviser and Steward, Dies at 92

lead_paragraph: Robert Craft, an orchestral conductor, scholar and writer who was called an elegant Boswell by his supporters and a calculating Svengali by his detractors for his long professional association with Igor Stravinsky, died on Tuesday at his home in Gulf Stream, Fla. He was 92.

headline: Out for Fun on a Friday Night, Victims Are Mostly Young

headline: Day After Paris Attacks, Familiar Fear Grips a Wary New York

keywords: ['Corporate Taxes', 'Intellectual Property', 'Tax Shelters', 'Taxation', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The country has been accused of acting like a low-tax haven, giving breaks that have attracted international companies. Now Ireland is phasing out some breaks, but adding another.
lead_paragraph: CORK, Ireland — As lord mayor of this quiet seaside city in southern Ireland, Chris O’Leary seems to have a situation most other local politicians can only dream about.

headline: A Baby Dies at Day Care, and a Mother Asks Why She Had to Leave Him So Soon
keywords: ['Day Care Centers', 'Family Leaves', 'Parenting', 'Sudden Infant Death Syndrome']
abstract: I wasn’t just up against the end of my parental leave. I was up against an entire culture.
lead_paragraph: As he did most mornings of the 117 days of his life, the first thing Karl did that Monday morning in July was to give me a smile like sunlight. He lay in the bed for a while, between his dad and me, looking from one of us to the other, working himself up with gurgles of delight. That morning, which started the same as all his others, would be a little different, however: it was his mommy’s first day back at work.

headline: ​Supporting France, Obama Loath to Add Troops to ISIS Fight
keywords: ['Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Even as the president searched for ways to step up the war against the terrorist group, White House officials again ruled out introducing substantial numbers of American ground troops.
lead_paragraph: ANTALYA, Turkey — For President Obama, the short-term response to the terrorist attacks in Paris was straightforward and relatively easy: The American military and intelligence agencies provided information to help French warplanes bomb Islamic State targets on Sunday in the group’s stronghold in northern Syria.

headline: 1940: Worst Nazi Raid Leaves Coventry in Ruin
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A British city devastated after a Nazi raid.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Subjected last night to one of the most furious bombing attacks of the war, the industrial city of Coventry, in the heart of the Midlands, presented today [Nov. 15] scenes of ruin never before equaled in England in this ruthless and devastating conflict. From dusk on Thursday until dawn Coventry was battered and blasted by wave after wave of Nazi planes, which, according to German assertions, dropped 1,000,000 pounds of high explosives and 60,000 pounds of incendiary bombs.

abstract: The Jaguars and Ravens have matching records.
lead_paragraph: Jaguars (2-6) at Ravens (2-6)

abstract: If the Seahawks have any chance of making a late run to snatch the N.F.C. West title away from the Cardinals, it probably needs to win this game.

headline: Rollie Massimino’s Latest Act: A Smaller Stage, but Just as Frenetic
abstract: Massimino, who rose to fame as the leader of the 1985 Villanova team that won the national championship, now coaches at Keiser University, an N.A.I.A. program in Florida.
lead_paragraph: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — Recovering from a collapsed lung, under treatment for small recurrences of the cancer that was surgically removed four years ago, and on medication, Rollie Massimino was under strict doctor’s orders to take it easy for 48 hours and especially to avoid driving his car.

headline: Grief in Paris
abstract: At least 129 people were killed and dozens more were wounded in coordinated attacks.
lead_paragraph: At least 129 people were killed and dozens more were wounded in coordinated attacks.

headline: France Strikes ISIS Targets in Syria in Retaliation for Attacks
abstract: The French Defense Ministry said a raid led by 12 French aircraft had destroyed two Islamic State targets in Raqqa, the group’s self-proclaimed capital.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — France bombed the Syrian city of Raqqa on Sunday night, its most aggressive strike against the Islamic State group it blames for killing 129 people in a string of terrorist attacks across Paris only two days before.

headline: 1965: Anti-Red Law in U.S. Is Voided
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The Supreme Court rules that Communist Party members do not have to register with the government.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court today [Nov. 15] unanimously ruled that Communist party members do not have to register with the government because they might incriminate themselves. The high tribunal declared a requirement that Communist party members register under the 1950 Subversive Activities Control Law, sometimes referred to as the McCarran Act, violates the Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination.

headline: Paris Attacks: What We Know and Don’t Know
abstract: A briefing with the latest information.
lead_paragraph: French warplanes struck Islamic State militants in Syria, two days after Islamic State terrorists killed at least 129 people in Paris. The airstrikes appeared to be focused on Raqqa, the self-proclaimed capital of the Islamic State.

headline: Pope Condemns 'Barbarity' of Paris Attacks
abstract: Pope Francis expressed condolences to all the citizens of France and said that using the name of God to justify violence and hatred was "blasphemy."
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis expressed condolences to all the citizens of France and said that using the name of God to justify violence and hatred was "blasphemy."

headline: Beirut, Also the Site of Deadly Attacks, Feels Forgotten
keywords: ['Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Terrorism']
abstract: A global outpouring of grief followed the Paris assaults, but no such solidarity was expressed a day earlier when 43 civilians were killed in Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Ali Awad, 14, was chopping vegetables when the first bomb struck. Adel Tormous, who would die tackling the second bomber, was sitting at a nearby coffee stand. Khodr Alaa Deen, a registered nurse, was on his way to work his night shift at the teaching hospital of the American University at Beirut, in Lebanon.

headline: Mary-Louise Parker on Life With and Without Men
abstract: With a lifelong love of poetry and abiding love for her late father, Mary-Louise Parker has written a non-memoir that is personal and very revealing.
lead_paragraph: The other day in the Brooklyn Heights duplex Mary-Louise Parker shares with her two children and Mrs. Roosevelt, a cocker spaniel in a red diaper, the actress was stroking one of the oyster shells she keeps in a bowl in her living room.

headline: A Street-Level Search for Women to Put on a Manhattan Pedestal
keywords: ['Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Women and Girls', 'Performance Art', 'Triangle Shirtwaist Factory Fire (1911)']
abstract: Lois Evans, a playwright and performance artist known as LuLu LoLo, has taken the role of Joan of Arc to advance a push to honor Susan B. Anthony and Elizabeth Cady Stanton with a Central Park statue.
lead_paragraph: Joan of Arc’s armor glistened in the noonday sun as she walked slowly through the lunchtime crowds rushing past the Flatiron Building in Manhattan recently. Every now and then, she paused and scanned the sidewalk, slightly tilting her head back as she announced her mission.

headline: Invoking Nazis, Marco Rubio Hits Hillary Clinton for Not Saying U.S. Is at War With ‘Radical Islam’
abstract: Criticizing Mrs. Clinton, Mr. Rubio drew a parallel between members of the Nazi Party who did not commit acts of violence and Muslims who are not violent extremists.
lead_paragraph: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, arguing that the United States is “at war with radical Islam,” sharply criticized Hillary Rodham Clinton for declining to characterize the perpetrators of the Paris attacks in that way, invoking Nazi Germany to make his point.

headline: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Honors Paris
abstract: SNL castmember Cecily Strong pledged her support for Paris in the show’s opening moments.
lead_paragraph: “Saturday Night Live” skipped its usual cold open on Saturday, instead delivering a message of support to Paris after Friday’s attacks.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: From lamb curry to salmon roasted in butter, Sam Sifton has quite a few delicious ideas for dinner.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Let’s put aside Thanksgiving planning for a moment. It’s not just the horrible news out of France. You thought about Thanksgiving yesterday, and will think about it tomorrow, and next weekend will be filled with preparations large and small. For this day, at least, we’re going to concentrate on the short term: dinners for the week ahead.

headline: Efforts to Rein In Arbitration Come Under Well-Financed Attack
keywords: ['ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Debates (Political)', 'Political Advertising']
abstract: As regulators, lawmakers and the Justice Department pushed to restrict arbitration, the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and others pushed back.
lead_paragraph: A television ad during the Republican presidential debate last Tuesday depicted pale bureaucrats rubber-stamping the word “DENIED” on the files of frustrated Americans, beneath a red banner of Senator Elizabeth Warren evoking a Communist apparatchik.

headline: Muslims in Paris Condemn Attacks
abstract: Muslims in the French capital condemned the terrorists that attacked their city, saying they tarnished Islam.
lead_paragraph: Muslims in the French capital condemned the terrorists that attacked their city, saying they tarnished Islam.

headline: Fear and Friends
abstract: If we care about killing innocent people, terrorists win!
lead_paragraph: The news from Paris was horrifying, and deserved a break in the usual round of commentary, but surely nobody who has been paying attention was completely shocked. We know that there are jihadists out there, and even the best efforts at prevention will fail sometimes. We’ll have to see how this fairly elaborate plot went undetected, but really nothing about the story so far suggests that it should fundamentally change how we see the world.

headline: ‘Love the Coopers’ Beats Expectations, but James Bond and Charlie Brown Win the Box Office
abstract: “Love the Coopers” took in roughly $8.4 million, but came in behind “Spectre” and “The Peanuts Movie.”
lead_paragraph: The feel-good comedy “Love the Coopers” seemed to arrive just in time for moviegoers weary of word events, while the ripped-from-the-headlines drama “The 33,” about the 2010 Chilean mining tragedy, may have been a little too real.

headline: Unraveling the Connections Among the Paris Attackers
abstract: As many as six of the assailants in the coordinated Islamic State terrorist assault in Paris were Europeans who had traveled to Syria.
lead_paragraph: As many as six of the assailants in the coordinated Islamic State terrorist assault in Paris were Europeans who had traveled to Syria.

headline: Jeb Bush Says U.S. ‘Should Declare War’ in Fight Against Islamic State
abstract: Mr. Bush, the former Florida governor, warned that the caliphate was gaining strength “every day” and insisted the United States must take the lead in fighting it in Syria and Iraq.
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush said the United States “should declare war” as it responds to the Paris attacks and the rise of ISIS in general.

headline: Cartoon: Heng on Democracy’s First Steps in Myanmar
abstract: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi’s party, the National League for Democracy, won a solid majority in parliamentary elections.
lead_paragraph: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi’s party, the National League for Democracy, won a solid majority in parliamentary elections.

headline: Irish Repertory Theater Set to Honor Brian Friel
abstract: Brian Friel, who died last month, will be honored by the Irish Repertory Theater on Dec. 7.
lead_paragraph: The Irish playwright Brian Friel, who died last month at 86, will be honored in a memorial service on Dec. 7, presented by The Irish Repertory Theater at the Manhattan Theater Club’s Samuel J. Friedman Theater. Additionally, Broadway theaters will dim their lights for Mr. Friel on Dec. 8.

headline: Projection Kicks Off Countdown to Black History and Culture Museum Opening
abstract: A video project by Stanley Nelson and Marcia Smith celebrates the countdown to the opening of a new Smithsonian museum next fall.
lead_paragraph: By this time next year, a new Smithsonian museum dedicated to telling the history of black Americans will be welcoming visitors on the National Mall.

headline: Man Who Gave Psychics $718,000 ‘Just Got Sucked In’
abstract: Two psychics vowed to reunite Niall Rice with the woman he loved. Even after it was discovered that she was dead.
lead_paragraph: He sat in a Denny’s restaurant, drinking coffee between cigarette breaks after a long and sleepless night, answering question after question.

headline: What to Watch Sunday
abstract: If you need an escape from all the news, Anthony Bourdain will take you to a sunny island, and Bob’s Burgers will bring you an early Christmas.
lead_paragraph: If you need an escape from all the news, Anthony Bourdain will take you to a sunny island, and Bob’s Burgers will bring you an early Christmas.

headline: For Once, the Knicks Protect a Fourth-Quarter Lead
abstract: Carmelo Anthony finished with 29 points and 13 rebounds, and Kevin Seraphin scored 12 off the bench, in a 95-87 victory against the Pelicans.
lead_paragraph: Frustrated with his limited role on the Knicks, Kevin Seraphin recently went to Coach Derek Fisher’s office and asked what he could do to earn more playing time. It was a long and frank conversation, Seraphin said, and Fisher essentially told him to focus on his defense and rebounding. Fisher also preached patience: Seraphin’s time would come.

headline: Obama and Putin Discuss ISIS and Syria in Informal Conversation
abstract: The two men, in Turkey for the Group of 20 summit meeting, talked for 35 minutes, though a Russian official said they disagreed on how to deal with with the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: ANTALYA, Turkey — President Obama and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia met face-to-face here on Sunday, broaching once again their longstanding disagreement about how to confront the Islamic State and deal with the civil war in Syria.

headline: Fear Rising Among Refugees in Paris
keywords: ['Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Refugees in central Paris have heightened fears about their security and their future in France following Friday's attacks.
lead_paragraph: Refugees in central Paris have heightened fears about their security and their future in France following Friday's attacks.

headline: Hillary Clinton Botches Wall Street Questions
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Debates (Political)', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: After a good start on national security and terrorism, Hillary Clinton flubbed legitimate questions about her ties to Wall Street on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton should have seen that Wall Street shot coming. Instead, she compounded the damage.

headline: Review: ‘The Latin Explosion: A New America,’ on HBO, Is a Music Civics Lesson
abstract: This documentary looks back on 60 years of Hispanic culture in America through work by artists like Desi Arnaz, Gloria Estefan and Pitbull.
lead_paragraph: The best moments come early in “The Latin Explosion: A New America,” an hourlong HBO documentary on Monday night. Desi Arnaz dancing with his conga and wailing “Babalú.” Rita Moreno laying down the law in “West Side Story.” A series of early rock ’n’ roll one-hit wonders matched with their real names: Sam the Sham, a.k.a. Domingo Samudio; Question Mark (of Question Mark and the Mysterians), a.k.a. Rudy Martinez; Cannibal (of Cannibal and the Headhunters), a.k.a. Frankie Garcia.

headline: Penguins, Known for Dangerous Attack, Are in Peril Themselves
abstract: After a shutout loss to the Devils on Saturday night, the Pittsburgh star Sidney Crosby said, “We didn’t compete.” Recently, that seems to be a trend.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — As usual, the crowd at Prudential Center directed an obscene chant at Pittsburgh center Sidney Crosby, the Penguins’ captain. But this time was different: When the jeers began in the middle of the third period on Saturday night, the Penguins were three goals behind.

headline: Paris Attacks Pose Test for U.S. Presidential Candidates
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Debates (Political)', 'United States International Relations', 'Terrorism', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)']
abstract: The attacks have bolstered the Republican right’s anti-immigration demands and may enhance Hillary Rodham Clinton’s credentials as the candidate with experience.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The tragedy in Paris is roiling American politics, bolstering the Republican right’s anti-immigration demands in the short run and perhaps ultimately enhancing Hillary Rodham Clinton and her credentials as the candidate with experience.

headline: Review: St. Thomas Church Season Honors John Scott
abstract: The Orchestra of St. Luke’s and the St. Thomas Choir performed Mozart’s Requiem and Haydn’s “Mass in Times of Distress” in a concert dedicated to the memory of its music director.
lead_paragraph: When John Scott, the revered organist and choirmaster at St. Thomas Church Fifth Avenue, programmed Mozart’s Requiem to open the church’s concert season on Thursday evening, he could hardly have anticipated that the performance would be dedicated to his memory. But in August, having returned from the first leg of a triumphant European recital tour, Mr. Scott, a vigorous 59, died of a heart attack.

headline: Review: The Mezzo-Soprano Anne Sofie von Otter at the Frick Collection
abstract: Ms. von Otter performed with the lutenist Thomas Dunford and the keyboardist Jonathan Cohen on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Lovely as it was, it had an air of unreality. To have canceled the concert or significantly altered the program on Friday night — a delicious mix of the sublime and the ridiculous, featuring the Swedish mezzo-soprano Anne Sofie von Otter — would have achieved nothing.

headline: Israeli Forces Arrest Palestinian in Drive-By Shooting in West Bank
abstract: The authorities said the suspect’s father had informed the military about his son’s involvement in the hope of preventing the demolition of the family home.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Israeli authorities announced on Sunday the arrest of a Palestinian man suspected of carrying out a deadly drive-by shooting against Israelis in the West Bank, and said the suspect’s father had informed the military about his son’s involvement in the hope of preventing the demolition of their family home.

headline: Watching Missouri From Afar, and Seeing Lesson for All Black Athletes
abstract: Black student-athletes, by taking a rare step to join a fight against racial tensions on campus, reconciled their celebrity with the concerns of fellow black students.
lead_paragraph: More than a week after the president and the chancellor of the University of Missouri were forced to resign, the activism of the football players who helped bring about those changes is being celebrated as an example of what can be achieved when athletes lend their celebrity to a cause. What many found extraordinary about the affair is that athletes stepped out of the sports cocoon.

headline: 15 Sudanese Migrants Killed at Egypt-Israel Border, Officials Say
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Human Trafficking']
abstract: One account said the migrants had been shot by the Egyptian police for trying to cross the border, but another said they had been caught in the middle of a shootout with smugglers.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — At least 15 Sudanese migrants trying to cross from Egypt into Israel were shot and killed at the border early Sunday, possibly by Egyptian police officers, according to security officials and news reports.

headline: More Than 8.5 Million Watched Democratic Debate on CBS
keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'News and News Media', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Ratings (Audience Measurement)', 'Television']
abstract: The television audience on Saturday was substantially smaller than the one last month for the party’s first presidential debate.
lead_paragraph: More than 8.5 million people watched the second Democratic presidential debate on CBS on Saturday night, according to Nielsen data provided by the network.

headline: Review: ‘Prem Ratan Dhan Payo,’ a Bollywood Tale of a Prince-and-Plebe Double
abstract: Sooraj R. Barjatya’s film stars Salman Khan as a decent and playful fellow who intervenes in the power battles of a royal family.
lead_paragraph: The Bollywood movie “Prem Ratan Dhan Payo” is set in contemporary India, though it’s one of palaces and quaint villages and low-rise cities, with the occasional iPhone and Mercedes thrown in for modernity and luxury branding’s sake.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Nov. 16
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Review: ‘Appomattox’ at the Kennedy Center
abstract: The Washington National Opera presents a revised version of Philip Glass and Christopher Hampton’s opera.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Eight years ago, the composer Philip Glass unveiled a new opera, “Appomattox,” at the San Francisco Opera. Set to a libretto by Christopher Hampton, it centered on the gentlemanly negotiations between Generals Grant and Lee at a rural Virginia home that effectively brought the Civil War to a close in 1865. But the appearance of a chorus of civil rights protesters signaled that the opera’s true subject was race relations in America.

headline: Review: Ry Cooder, Ricky Skaggs and the Whites, a Roots-Music Celebration
abstract: Cooder-White-Skaggs conveyed a sense of rare, joyous occasion during Rosanne Cash’s Perspectives series at Carnegie Hall on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Ry Cooder began the first encore at Zankel Hall on Saturday night with a shadowy, droning solo on electric bouzouki, in no hurry to settle on a tempo. After a few moments, Ricky Skaggs joined him on mandolin, and their searching interplay coalesced into a slow processional. Only as Mr. Cooder started singing, with a light husk in his baritone, did the shape of a song become clear.

headline: Review: ‘Spectator’ at the Japan Society
abstract: The performance shifts between dancers onstage and doll-house-scale arrangements in live video, in Shuji Onodera’s work.
lead_paragraph: When a friend heard I was going to a production at the Japan Society, he guessed I would see one of the traditional Japanese genres — Noh, Kabuki, Bunraku — and said at once, “Interesting.” My visit on Friday, however, was for Shuji Onodera’s “Spectator,” which, certainly interesting, was new in Tokyo in 2013.

headline: Paris Attacks Shift Europe’s Migrant Focus to Security
keywords: ['Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Officials across Europe were calling for even stronger border controls, stricter screening of migrants and some way to reduce the flow.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — With hundreds of thousands of migrants pouring across its borders, and economic and political pressure growing to enact tighter controls, Europe has nevertheless stayed fairly steady in its response to the humanitarian emergency.

headline: Review: In ‘Destiny and Power,’ George H.W. Bush Epitomizes a Vanishing G.O.P.
abstract: Subtitled “The American Odyssey of George Herbert Walker Bush,” Jon Meacham’s biography reveals the ambition that lay behind a president often seen as ineffectual.
lead_paragraph: For better or for worse, George Herbert Walker Bush has been enshrined in collective memory as a series of caricatures, all of them evoking ineffectuality. He was the effete Yale man and the blue blood wimp; the awkward statesman who, when called upon to speak, diced the English language into an uneven and mysterious julienne. It didn’t help that his face was generally a fresco of befuddlement. The last thing one would have expected of him was tigerish ambition. Unlike so many politicians who thrust their way into the Oval Office — TheodoreRoosevelt, Lyndon B. Johnson, Bill Clinton — there seemed nothing overtly appetitive about him.

headline: Tic-Tac-Toe Win
abstract: A New York Times debut by Jim Holland.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — If you’re an experienced solver, you will find this debut puzzle by Jim Holland pretty easy. You probably won’t stop writing in entries from the time you start until you write in the last letter.

headline: For Spike Lee, an Honorary Oscar, but Diversity Takes Center Stage
keywords: ['Movies', 'Academy Awards (Oscars)', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Discrimination', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Stung by criticism of its failure to nominate any black actors or directors last season, the Academy used its annual Governors Awards to face the issue head on.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “We can talk, you know, yabba, yabba, yabba, but we need to have some serious discussion about diversity, and get some flave up in this!” Spike Lee admonished members of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, as he accepted an honorary Oscar at a black-tie banquet in Hollywood on Saturday night.

headline: Beneath New York Public Library, Shelving Its Past for High-Tech Research Stacks
abstract: After abandoning a much-criticized plan to move most of its research books to New Jersey, the library is creating a new storage and retrieval system under Bryant Park.
lead_paragraph: As they skate or snack in Bryant Park, visitors might dismiss the stately New York Public Library next door as a dog-eared relic in an age of digital information.

headline: Blacks Are Challenged to Buy From Black-Owned Businesses to Close Gap
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Books and Literature', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Blacks spend less money in black-owned businesses than other racial and ethnic groups spend in businesses owned by members of their groups, including Hispanics and Asians.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Should black people go out of their way to patronize black-owned business?

headline: What Will Come After Paris
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'International Relations']
abstract: No one is really safe from the barbarism of ISIS until the nations involved work together to defeat the murderous scourge.
lead_paragraph: The terrorist attacks in Paris on Friday, along with twin bombings in Beirut on the day before and the downing of a Russian jetliner over the Sinai Peninsula on Oct. 31, show a new phase in the Islamic State’s war against the West, a readiness to strike far beyond areas it controls in Iraq, Syria, and increasingly, Libya.

headline: Blocks From Charlie Hebdo, Area Known for Bonhomie Is Shaken Again
abstract: The 11th Arrondissement, the multicultural district that was the site of at least five attacks on Friday and the Charlie Hebdo attack in January, is known for its “bourgeois bonhomie.”
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The massacre Friday night  by militants wielding assault rifles provoked an eerie and disturbing sense of familiarity for all of France. But that feeling was even more profound for one quickly gentrifying, multicultural neighborhood of Paris known for its “bourgeois bonhomie” — the 11th Arrondissement.

headline: Joel Schumacher, Directing ‘Neighborhood 3,’ Gets an Education
abstract: Mr. Schumacher, who has weathered many industry storms, finds putting on a play is a different kind of thrill.
lead_paragraph: On the first preview night for the Flea Theater premiere of “Neighborhood 3: Requisition of Doom,” the set was not quite finished, the music was temporary and the sound designer was not even due to begin work until after the curtain call. “I have no idea what’s going to happen tonight,” said the director, Joel Schumacher, before the show. But he was not sweating it. “I don’t mind anything, except the Republican debates,” he said breezily.

headline: Layoffs Coming at Weinstein Company, Mostly in Film Division
abstract: As many as 50 of its more than 200 employees will be affected.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Weinstein Company on Sunday confirmed that it will lay off as many as 50 of its more than 200 employees, mostly in its film division. The layoffs were first reported by Variety. Weinstein has been shifting much of its focus toward television, but continues to work on future films, including “The Six Billion Dollar Man,” planned for 2017, and has high-profile films set for release this year. Those include a pair of likely awards contenders, Todd Haynes’s “Carol” and Quentin Tarantino’s “The Hateful Eight.”

headline: Hillary Clinton Takes a More Defined Stance on ISIS
abstract: A day after the second Democratic presidential debate, where the candidates did not offer ideas on confronting extremists, Mrs. Clinton said the United States had to rally its allies, “pulling countries off the sidelines.”
lead_paragraph: AMES, Iowa – The day after a debate in which Democratic presidential candidates tangled over the causes of Islamic State terrorism but not how to confront it, Hillary Rodham Clinton offered a more forward-looking view of American leadership in response to the threat.

headline: 5 Yemeni Guantánamo Inmates Are Sent to United Arab Emirates
abstract: The lower-level detainees had been held for nearly 14 years but never charged with a crime, and their transfers reduce the population at the prison in Cuba to 107.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Department of Defense announced on Sunday that it had transferred five lower-level Yemeni detainees from the Guantánamo Bay prison in Cuba to the United Arab Emirates. The United States had held each for nearly 14 years as wartime prisoners, and none had been charged with a crime.

headline: Tensions in Iran After Nuclear Deal Grow in Hostility
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The reaction of conservatives who opposed the deal has been harsh, as seen in a series of arrests of Iranian journalists and at least one Iranian-American.

headline: In Presidential Campaign, It’s Now Terrorism, Not Taxes

And Marco Rubio, after pushing out a new video about the “clash of civilizations,” revamped his plans for an important Monday appearance before a group of executives on the assumption that terrorism, not tax rates, would be their most pressing concern.

A tiny green light flashed, indicating that the device was charged.

headline: Review: ‘Incident at Vichy,’ an Arthur Miller Tale Set in World War II
abstract: This revival revolves around a group of Jewish men being rounded up in France under German occupation.
lead_paragraph: “We don’t want to alarm people,” says a police captain to a colleague near the beginning of “Incident at Vichy,” Arthur Miller’s 1964 drama about the rounding up of Jews in France under German occupation. The remark resounds with irony, since most of the men surrounding them, who have been pulled off the streets, supposedly so their identity papers can be verified but in fact so they can be revealed as Jews and sent to concentration camps, are practically vibrating with anxiety and subterranean fear.

Cousins was 20 for 25 passing for 324 yards, with no interceptions and a perfect passer rating of 158.3. His scoring throws came on passes of 78 yards, to running back Matt Jones; 16 and 8 yards, to tight end Jordan Reed; and 11 yards, to receiver Jamison Crowder. Cousins did not have a scoring toss of more than 7 yards this season.

We must wait for the nation to embrace the one true religion, he suggested, and gay people must be allowed to repent and convert.

headline: Fearing Fear Itself
abstract: Terrorists won’t bring down Western civilization, and the tradeoffs we make to counter it should not include giving in to the panic they hope to create.

headline: ‘The Blue Touch Paper: A Memoir,’ by David Hare
abstract: The playwright David Hare looks back on his experience and his career.
lead_paragraph: When David Hare was a child, nothing excited him more than getting lost. From the outset of his adult professional life, however, he knew very well where he was — and how to get from there to where he wanted to be. With his singular combination of talent and tenacity, he always found himself at the center of wherever theatrical daring and excellence were recruited. In 1974, with “Knuckle,” Hare broke through to the West End, among the first of his generation of Oxbridge Young Turks to do so. As a resident dramatist, he ascended the food chain of British theater: from disputatious bouts at the Royal Court to the Nottingham Playhouse during Richard Eyre’s brilliant regime and all the way up to the National Theater, where by 1984 he was an associate director, co-creating the influential Joint Stock Company along the way.

headline: Mindy Kaling’s ‘Why Not Me?’
abstract: Kaling discusses life in an image-driven industry, and the perks and pitfalls of making it.
lead_paragraph: “Why Not Me?” is the title of Mindy Kaling’s breezy new book, arriving on the heels of similar volumes by Tina Fey, Lena Dunham, Sarah Silverman, Amy Poehler and, notably, Kaling herself. Soon, Amy Schumer will tender her offering (which recently sold for a reported $8 million to $10 million, and will doubtless sell like hot cakes, if indeed hot cakes sell in the zillions) to the growing canon of ­memoir-slash-essay collections by women comedians and comedy writers. Clearly, there is something about the combination that’s working.
