abstract: The assaults could rekindle a measure pushed by Senator Charles E. Grassley, the Iowa Republican, to prohibit the administration from spending any money to admit Syrian refugees until the intelligence community approves the process.
lead_paragraph: Repercussions from the Paris attacks will ripple through Congress as lawmakers return on Monday and begin to weigh in from the floors of the Senate and the House.

headline: Youth Coding Event Gets a Hand From Minecraft
abstract: On Monday an event meant to make coding attractive to children announced its latest tool, a programming tutorial based on Minecraft.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — For the past two years, schools around the world have participated in an event called the Hour of Code in early December, using a variety of gimmicks to make computer programming interesting and accessible to students.

headline: China Responds to Paris Attacks Through a Domestic Lens
abstract: Along with revulsion, Chinese leaders and many citizens also voiced a more complex mix of expectations and emotions, rooted in rival views of the country’s own problems.
lead_paragraph: Read in Chinese | 点击查看本文中文版

headline: How to Decrease Prices for an Expensive Class of Drugs
abstract: Two professors suggest requiring biologic manufacturers to disclose drug production details in exchange for a longer period of market exclusivity.
lead_paragraph: Competition among generic drug makers pushes drug prices downward. But such competition is weak for a growing and expensive class of drugs called biologics. A big reason has to do with the science that underlies them.

headline: Les attentats à Paris révèlent les limites de Daesh
abstract: Le groupe islamiste n’a pas les moyens de ses ambitions.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, Italie — Comme l’a déclaré le Président François Hollande, la France est bien en guerre contre Daesh. La France considère le groupe Islamiste comme son ennemi numéro un. Elle le combat en première ligne avec les Américains au Moyen-Orient, et comme seule nation occidentale dans le Sahel. Elle a engagé dans cette lutte, commencée au Mali en 2013, un pourcentage de son armée bien supérieur à celui des troupes américaines.

headline: Houston Texans at Cincinnati Bengals Preview
abstract: Cincinnati and Andy Dalton have struggled mightily in recent years against the Texans.
lead_paragraph: Texans (3-5) at Bengals (8-0)

headline: Five Ways Your Smartphone Can Help Your Health
abstract: Your smartphone can help improve your health at the push of a button, or sometimes just by yelling at its voice-activated software.
lead_paragraph: A doctor friend once told me the best thing I could do for my health was to turn off my cellphone. But that was before smartphone makers began building health and safety features into their phones. Here are five healthful tricks your phone can do.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 16, 2015
abstract: On Mondays, we publish a Times photo without a caption, headline or other information about its origins. Join the conversation by commenting on what you see and why. A live discussion is offered that day from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. Eastern.
lead_paragraph: Updated: Nov. 20, 2015

headline: Israeli Soldiers Raid West Bank Refugee Camp, Prompting Deadly Clashes
abstract: Two Palestinians were killed and several others were wounded as residents said that up to 1,000 troops entered the camp between Jerusalem and Ramallah.
lead_paragraph: QALANDIYA REFUGEE CAMP, West Bank — Armed clashes broke out during an Israeli military raid at the Qalandiya refugee camp in the West Bank before dawn on Monday, leaving two Palestinian men dead and several others wounded, according to the Israeli military and Palestinian residents.

headline: Assessing the Fitness of Wearable Tech
abstract: Older adults are among those who could benefit most from fitness trackers, but some experts caution that the devices may have a dark side.
lead_paragraph: Like many people who grew up long before personal computers and cellphones became ubiquitous, I’ve never tried a fitness tracker. I already know I walk about five miles a day, in addition to my daily swim. My weight is stable within a range of two pounds. I prefer to remain accountable only to myself, not to a gadget.

headline: Marriott to Buy Starwood Hotels, Creating World’s Largest Hotel Company
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The $12.2 billion deal, expected to close in the middle of next year, would give the combined company more than 5,500 owned or franchised hotels with 1.1 million rooms around the world.
lead_paragraph: When Marriott International’s $12.2 billion bid for Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide was announced on Monday morning, investors and analysts were surprised.

headline: Police Capture Armed Woman Barricaded Near the White House
abstract: The police had stopped traffic in the area, and had also prevented thousands of people who were trying to walk to work from getting to their offices.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Several blocks near the White House were shut down for most of Monday morning as an armed woman barricaded herself in an office building, adding to tensions in a city already at heightened alert after the terrorist attacks in Paris.

headline: Collaborations 3.0: Lee Daniels’s ‘Empire’ and Hood by Air Make a Fashion Statement
abstract: While it’s not an opportunity to “dress like Cookie,” the clothing line may signal a new stage in pop culture/designer partnerships.
lead_paragraph: These days the high fashion designer/fast fashion collaboration has become so ubiquitous (Balmain x H&M, Lilly Pulitzer for Target, the North Face for J. Crew) that it is starting to feel like a calculated formula guaranteed to milk the most from a marketing budget. So it’s nice to see one based on an entirely different premise: fandom.

headline: Jesse Tyler Ferguson Returns to Broadway in ‘Fully Committed’
abstract: Jesse Tyler Ferguson will star in the one man show “Fully Committed,” a comedy about foodie culture.
lead_paragraph: Jesse Tyler Ferguson plays one half of one of television’s most memorable couples on “Modern Family.” But when he returns to Broadway in April, he’ll be all alone. Mr. Ferguson will star in the one-man show “Fully Committed,” a comedy about foodie culture by Becky Mode, starting April 2 at the Lyceum Theater.

headline: Jazzmeia Horn Wins Thelonious Monk Institute International Jazz Competition
abstract: Jazzmeia Horn, a 23-year-old singer originally from Dallas, is the winner of the 2015 Thelonious Monk Institute International Jazz Competition.
lead_paragraph: The winner of the 2015 Thelonious Monk Institute International Jazz Competition is Jazzmeia Horn. Originally from Dallas, Ms. Horn, 23, is a singer with a smart, steadfast connection to the jazz-vocal tradition, as defined by predecessors like Betty Carter and Sarah Vaughan. Since moving to New York in 2009 to attend the New School for Jazz and Contemporary Music, she has been a regular presence on the club scene, often with her band, the Artistry of Jazz Horn.

headline: 1890: Honduras Slays Her Traitors
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The revolution in Honduras ends violently in 1890.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — The Honduras revolution has ended, and General Sanchez and all his principal leaders have been shot. Yesterday morning General Bogran opened fire on the barrack to which the insurgents had retreated. Sanchez and his comrades, knowing that death awaited them, fought desperately; but it was a hopeless struggle from the start. Bogran’s soldiers charged and soon all the rebels remaining alive were prisoners. Without the formality of a court-martial Sanchez and the leading officers were taken to one of the principal squares in the city, blindfolded and stood in line in the presence of hundreds of citizens. The word was given to the firing party, and a crash of musketry rang the death-knell of the revolution. — The New York Herald, European Edition, November 17, 1890

headline: It’s Easy to Overestimate Effect of Paris Attacks on 2016 Race
abstract: Republicans will almost certainly press their criticism on foreign policy, but forecasts of “game changers” tend to be wrong.
lead_paragraph: Until last week, the threat from terrorism had received little attention from candidates or voters during the 2016 campaign. In one poll, just 3 percent of Americans rated it the most important problem facing the country.

headline: Daily Report: IBM Embraces Its Inner Designer
abstract: Phil Gilbert, head of design at IBM, is trying to get the technology giant to embrace a new concept that could potentially help the company, which has seen two years of declining revenue, rethink its approach.
lead_paragraph: IBM has been associated with many things over the years. But few people would ever connect Big Blue, as IBM is sometimes called, with a progressive attitude toward design.

headline: Will Uterine Transplants Make Male Pregnancy Possible?
abstract: Denise Grady reported that American doctors expect to implant a uterus into women, and considers the implications for men who wish to carry children.
lead_paragraph: A reader writes, “The Times reported last week that surgeons at the Cleveland Clinic expect to become the first in the United States to transplant a uterus into a woman who lacks one, so that she can become pregnant and give birth. Is there any reason doctors could not implant a uterus in a man, so that he could become pregnant?”

headline: Media General Rejects Nexstar Bid, but Will Negotiate
abstract: The company, which operates 71 television stations, said the unsolicited $4.1 billion offer undervalued the company.
lead_paragraph: Media General, which operates 71 television stations in all but two states, has rejected a $4.1 billion bid from the Nexstar Broadcasting Group, saying the unsolicited offer undervalues the company.

headline: 1940: King Inspects Coventry’s Ruins
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: King George VI visits Coventry, in ruins after Nazi airstrikes in 1940.
lead_paragraph: COVENTRY, England — As troops were being rushed to this stricken city, which suffered on Thursday night the worst raid to date in the German aerial war on Great Britain, King George VI and other government leaders visited today [Nov. 16] the injured and homeless and inspected the vast damage to Coventry, a Midlands industrial center, where 200 persons were killed and 800 injured by the Nazi air attack. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 17, 1940

headline: 7 Inspiring Quotes From Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Gloria Steinem
abstract: Here are some noteworthy quotes from the two inspiring women.
lead_paragraph: Here are some noteworthy quotes from the two inspiring women.

headline: Obama Says Strategy to Fight ISIS Will Succeed
keywords: ['Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The president said his strategy for defeating the Islamic State is working and that turning away Syrian refugees based on religion would be un-American.
lead_paragraph: ANTALYA, Turkey — Time after time, the question was essentially the same: Why isn’t your strategy against the Islamic State working?

headline: A Savory Alternative to Traditional Stuffing
abstract: Pilaf of wild rice and toasted quinoa offers a contrast of flavors, textures and ingredients.
lead_paragraph: Call this savory mix of wild rice, quinoa, mushrooms and greens a stuffing or a pilaf. It’s not meant to go inside a turkey but it has the definitive herbal flavors I associate with and insist on when I make any kind of stuffing — sage mainly, but also thyme. They are forever stored in my bank of taste memories; I have looked forward to them every Thanksgiving since my first forkful of the packaged stuffing of my youth.

headline: Devils Look Sharp, Even as They Shun Razors
abstract: With a new coach, a new general manager and more relaxed rules about facial hair, the Devils have gotten off to a strong start, even beating the reigning Stanley Cup champions twice.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Sporting five o’clock shadows and mustaches — forbidden during the regular season by the former general manager Lou Lamoriello — the Devils have won 10 of their last 13 games, including two victories over the Chicago Blackhawks, the Stanley Cup champions.

headline: Giants Receiver Victor Cruz, Gone 13 Months, Will Have Surgery
abstract: A second lengthy rehabilitation of a serious leg injury could mean the end of Cruz’s career with the team.
lead_paragraph: Victor Cruz was running pass routes on Saturday at the Giants’ practice complex hoping to finally be ready to make his season debut in a game on Nov. 29 against Washington.

headline: The Coravin Proves Rob Moose Is Serious About His Wine
abstract: The $300 tool was a gift from his parents. It acts like a hypodermic syringe to draw out wine while fending off oxidation.
lead_paragraph: The light in Rob Moose’s refrigerator won’t turn on. This is intentional: Mr. Moose, a rangy, tumble-haired rock guitarist, violinist and producer who has spent much of the last decade working with the likes of Bon Iver and Sufjan Stevens, taped the switch down.

headline: We’re All About Pie
abstract: Ideas for dinner this week and more Thanksgiving preparations (clean out that fridge!).
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears on nytimes.com. To receive the email, register here.

headline: Jim Webb Joins In on Criticizing Hillary Clinton’s Marines Story
keywords: ['Draft and Recruitment (Military)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Republicans have been mocking Hillary Rodham Clinton since she told voters in New Hampshire last week of her contemplation about joining the military in the 1970s. Similar criticism coming from a Democrat and a decorated veteran is striking.
lead_paragraph: Jim Webb may have abandoned his bid for the Democratic presidential nomination, but the former senator from Virginia is not finished criticizing Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: The Challenges for Volkswagen’s Internal Investigation
abstract: An appeal to employees may be something of a last-ditch effort to ferret out information needed for a credible internal investigation.
lead_paragraph: Step 1 in the playbook for a company accused of misconduct is a promise of complete cooperation with the government. Step 2 is the key, because the company must then conduct a thorough internal investigation that will deliver the information necessary to assure regulators and prosecutors that the problem has been dealt with and those responsible have been identified.

headline: Plea Discussions Sought in Skelos Trial, Prosecutor Says
abstract: It was not disclosed which defendant, either State Senator Dean G. Skelos or his son, Adam, requested to discuss a deal to resolve part or all of an indictment including bribery and extortion charges.
lead_paragraph: A prosecutor at the corruption trial of State Senator Dean G. Skelos and his son told the judge on Monday that one of the defendants had sought to discuss a possible plea deal in the federal bribery and extortion case.

headline: Taking Stock of the $10 Billion Washington Spent on Colombia’s War
keywords: ['Coca (Plant)', 'Cocaine and Crack Cocaine', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Extradition', 'International Relations', 'Nineteen Hundred Nineties', 'Television', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The American ambassador in Bogotá discusses Colombia-U.S. relations, cocaine production and the accuracy of the show “Narcos.”
lead_paragraph: The United States has spent more than $10 billion dollars beefing up Colombia’s security forces, supporting development and backing reform of the judicial system in an effort known as Plan Colombia. After playing an instrumental role in giving the Colombian government the upper hand in its decades-long war against the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, a Marxist guerrilla group, Washington has turned its attention to peacemaking. I talked with Kevin Whitaker, the American ambassador in Bogotá, by email about this evolution and Washington’s decision to sit down with leaders who are under indictment in the United States.

headline: A World’s Leading Puzzle Designer Shares an Early Original
abstract: Can you crack this original creation by the world’s most prolific puzzle inventor?
lead_paragraph: This week’s puzzle is an original suggested by Naoki Inaba, the Japanese puzzle master and one of the world’s most prolific inventors of original puzzles. We’ve seen him before with Area Maze and Predator and Prey; this week he shares one of his earliest designs. Let’s give it a try. Here’s —

headline: Chip Credit Cards Give Retailers Another Grievance Against Banks
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit Cards', 'Debit Cards', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Identity Theft']
abstract: A battle between retailers and the banking industry over credit card technology adds fuel to a feud over what merchants pay for the processing of credit and debit transactions.
lead_paragraph: The employee perched on a stepstool by the checkout at Trader Joe’s in Union Square in Manhattan is like an air traffic controller: Register 6 for one customer. Register 9 for the next.

headline: A Big Week for Long (or Were They Short?) Passes
abstract: Little screen passes turned into big gains in a number of N.F.L. games this week.
lead_paragraph: The modern N.F.L. is defined by the short-passing game. And on Sunday, the short-passing game helped set a record for long plays. It might seem counterintuitive, but some of the longest pass plays of the season came from some of the shortest passes of the day:

headline: Japan’s Economy Feels the Sting of China’s Slowdown
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Dependent on Chinese orders that are dwindling, Japan’s heavy-industry manufacturers are slumping, along with the rest of the Japanese economy.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — In its small way, Tsutomu Nyuwa’s metalworking shop in Yasugi, Japan, has been feeding the economic boom 700 miles away in China.

headline: Supreme Court Won’t Hear Case Over Planned Parenthood Documents
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Archives and Records', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: The justices let stand a ruling shielding the documents, related to an application for federal funding, from a disclosure request by New Hampshire Right to Life, an anti-abortion group.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday let stand an appeals court ruling shielding the documents of a Planned Parenthood affiliate in New Hampshire from an anti-abortion group’s request under the open records law. As is its custom, the Supreme Court gave no reasons for turning down the appeal in the case.

headline: Instamoms, Curating a Photo-Worthy Childhood. Discuss.
abstract: Is “taking over your Instagram account” a coming-of-age ritual anyone wants?
lead_paragraph: “The amateur child models of Instagram are already more famous on the Internet than most of your co-workers. There’s 4-year-old London Scout, with 105,000 followers; 2-year-old Millie-Belle Diamond, with 143,000; 4-year-old Michelle (154,000); Gavin (200,000); and the Mini Style Hacker (260,000). Then there’s the prince of Instagram: Alonso Mateo, with more than 600,000 followers. He recently attended the Dior show at Paris Fashion Week.”

headline: Representative Steve King of Iowa Endorses Ted Cruz
abstract: Representative Steve King of Iowa, a hard-right conservative in the state with the first nominating contest, threw his support behind Senator Ted Cruz of Texas for the Republican nomination, calling him the “answer to my prayers.’’
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES – Representative Steve King of Iowa, a hard-right conservative in the state with the first nominating contest, threw his support behind Senator Ted Cruz for the Republican nomination on Monday, calling him the “answer to my prayers.’’

headline: Finding Cheap Flights and More on Black Friday
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Cruises', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Discount Selling', 'Holidays and Special Occasions']
abstract: In the days following Thanksgiving, scores of travel companies offer discounted hotel rooms, vacation packages, rail passes, rental cars, cruises and flights.
lead_paragraph: As every American knows, after the turkey comes the shopping. And not just for clothes and toys. In the days following Thanksgiving (Black Friday and especially Cyber Monday), scores of travel companies offer discounted hotel rooms, vacation packages, rail passes, rental cars, cruises and flights.

headline: Making Lotus Root Croquettes
abstract: The rock-and-roll chef Kenji Koyama shares his recipe for a classic Japanese dish.
lead_paragraph: The rock-and-roll chef Kenji Koyama shares his recipe for a classic Japanese dish.

headline: Nobel Winner Svetlana Alexievich Books to Be Published by Random House
abstract: The three English translations of Ms. Alexievich’s work will appear in 2016 and 2017.
lead_paragraph: Svetlana Alexievich, the Belarussian journalist and winner of the 2015 Nobel Prize in Literature, is about to expand her reach in the English-reading world.

headline: The Japanese Chef Beloved by Lorde
abstract: Kenji Koyama, of West L.A.'s unassuming year-old restaurant Necco, shares his recipe for lotus root croquettes.
lead_paragraph: Necco, a friendly, health-conscious Japanese small-plates restaurant in West L.A., is the kind of place in which Lorde fuels up on wholesome, unpretentious food when she’s in town. It’s helmed by chef Kenji Koyama, who opened it almost exactly one year ago.

headline: A New Book Looks at the Koch Brothers’ Role in Politics
abstract: Jane Mayer’s “Dark Money: The Hidden History of the Billionaires Behind the Rise of the Radical Right,” explores how conservatives like the Kochs are seeking to reshape American politics.
lead_paragraph: In a 2010 profile of the billionaire industrialist brothers Charles and David Koch, the New Yorker writer Jane Mayer described how, from 2005 to 2008, the brothers had vastly outspent ExxonMobil in financing organizations that fight legislation aimed at curbing climate change. Their company, the conglomerate Koch Industries, was also listed as one of the top 10 air polluters in the country, she wrote.

headline: Carnegie Hall Stands Behind Clive Gillinson After Review of Ronald Perelman’s Complaints
abstract: A legal review found no evidence to support allegations that Mr. Gillinson, its executive and artistic director, had tried to undermine the oversight of Mr. Perelman, its former chairman.
lead_paragraph: Carnegie Hall — whose former chairman, Ronald O. Perelman, stepped down last month after clashing with its executive and artistic director, Clive Gillinson — announced on Monday that a legal review that it commissioned had found no evidence to support allegations that Mr. Gillinson had tried to undermine Mr. Perelman’s oversight responsibilities.

headline: Where Ronda Rousey Goes From Here
abstract: Holly Holm stunned the mixed martial arts world over the weekend by knocking out Rousey, who had dominated her sport, in the second round of their U.F.C. fight.
lead_paragraph: It was Ronda Rousey’s Buster Douglas moment. Those who watched it were stunned. Those who read about it the next morning did a double take. And more than a few people were wondering where it leaves her career.

headline: Defense Rests in Trial of Ex-Coal C.E.O., Calling No Witnesses
abstract: Lawyers for Donald L. Blankenship, accused of conspiring to violate safety standards before 29 people died at the Upper Big Branch mine in 2010, had been expected to call many witnesses.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Donald L. Blankenship, the former coal executive accused of conspiring to violate federal safety standards before 29 people were killed at the Upper Big Branch mine in West Virginia, rested their case on Monday without calling any witnesses.

headline: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch
abstract: France will play England in London on Tuesday, the French team’s first match after the Paris terrorist attacks.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday’s showcase friendly between France and England (3 p.m. Eastern time, Fox Sports 1) has surely morphed into something else by now, part somber memorial service and defiant celebration and group therapy session. The French journalist Philippe Auclair suggested Saturday that English fans join their guests at Wembley in singing the French national anthem, “La Marseillaise,” in solidarity when it is played before kickoff. (England Coach Roy Hodgson has endorsed the idea.) If you want to join in from wherever you are, the lyrics are here. The French probably won’t mind if you fumble a word or two.

headline: Serious Delusions
abstract: Mission accomplished.
lead_paragraph: Greg Sargent mocks pundits declaring that the attacks in Paris will finally convince Republican primary voters that they need to get serious, and deflate the Trump/Carson bubble. This time it will really happen!

headline: Monday Roundup: Paris Praise, Brooks’s Trip and Steinem-Ginsburg
abstract: The public editor on all-out Paris coverage, who paid for a luxury trip, and why an article on two iconic women was published in Styles.
lead_paragraph: The crush of news from Paris brought an impressive, all-hands response from The Times’s newsrooms in New York and around the world over the weekend. While no other subject comes close in importance on this Monday, I’ll include here, as addenda, a couple of other matters that came up over the past few days.

headline: Marriott’s Deal for Starwood Looks Defensive
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The merger would create the world’s biggest hotelier. But the stated $200 million in cost savings will not cover the premium that Marriott is paying.
lead_paragraph: Marriott International’s $12 billion deal to buy its rival Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide opens a financial vacancy.

headline: Thanksgiving, the Julia Child Way
abstract: Her food was good but simple, one guest recalls, as Mrs. Child’s cooking style changed with her return to America.
lead_paragraph: At the height of Julia Child’s fame in the 1970s and ’80s, Thanksgiving guests often felt the need to tell her she should get her home number removed from the public directory. (This was an analog tool called a “telephone book.”)

headline: Donald Trump Repeats Call to Inspect Mosques for Signs of Terrorism
keywords: ['Mosques', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Donald J. Trump, who said last month that he would be open to shutting down mosques as part of the fight against Islamic State militants, reiterated on Monday that the idea should be “studied.” Ben Carson offered similar sentiments about Muslim clerics.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump issued another call for more scrutiny of mosques in the United States as fresh fears of terrorism, spurred by the attacks in Paris, dominated the presidential campaign conversation on Monday.

headline: Taking the (Often Imprecise) Measure of Stress
keywords: ['Anxiety and Stress', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Exercise', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: A number of devices are sold as stress trackers, but it is hard to objectively determine a person’s stress level in the real world.
lead_paragraph: Research has long shown that stress is bad for you, but many people are not even aware when they are feeling stressed.

headline: Early Artworks by Lucian Freud Given to National Portrait Gallery
abstract: Never-before-seen sketchbooks and drawings by Lucian Freud will offset inheritance taxes.
lead_paragraph: London — A rare collection of 162 childhood drawings; 47 sketchbooks from the 1940s to 2011; and letters and book cover designs by the artist Lucian Freud, who died in 2011, have been given to Britain in lieu of 2.9 million British pounds, or $4.41 million in inheritance tax by the Freud estate.

headline: Paris Attacks Give Rise to Fakes and Misinformation
abstract: Whenever there is big news, like Friday’s terror attacks in France, altered images, bogus tweets and odd theories abound.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, as terror attacks unfolded across Paris, rumors were spreading on the Internet even as people remained trapped inside the buildings that were under siege.

headline: AR Capital to Stop Creating Nontraded REITs
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate Investment Trusts']
abstract: The company built by Nicholas Schorsch and William Kahane said “regulatory and market uncertainty” was affecting its ability to raise investor money.
lead_paragraph: AR Capital, the real estate investment company built by Nicholas S. Schorsch and William M. Kahane, said Monday that it would stop creating new investment products and close existing ones to new investors to focus on managing the $19 billion it has in current investments.

headline: Cancellation of College Production of ‘Jesus in India’ Over Casting of White Actors Prompts Debate
abstract: Lloyd Suh, the playwright, argued that the Clarion University production could send a “dehumanizing” message to minority students; Clarion said the actors were being “punished for their race.”
lead_paragraph: The cancellation of a college production of Lloyd Suh’s play “Jesus in India” over the casting of white actors as Indian characters has prompted a war of words over diversity in theater, with Mr. Suh arguing that the production could send a “dehumanizing” message to minority students and the school countering that the student actors on its rural, predominantly white campus were being “punished for their race.”

headline: Measuring How Financial Advisers Handle Uncertainty
abstract: Do they tweak around the edges and adapt when things go bad? Or do they toss everything aside and hope that the next new thing will work better?
lead_paragraph: Remember how you felt during the financial crisis in 2008? People were scared. Even the professionals were uncertain about what might happen. I know, because I was scared, too.

headline: John Kerry Arrives in Paris to Show ‘Shared Resolve’ After Attacks
keywords: ['Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'United States International Relations', 'Terrorism', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: The secretary of state’s trip was not announced in advance because of security concerns, and he was scheduled to meet with President François Hollande on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Secretary of State John Kerry arrived in Paris on Monday evening, the first senior Obama administration official to visit France since the terrorist attacks on Friday shook the capital and prompted Western nations to re-evaluate their strategy for fighting the Islamic State.

headline: After Paris Attacks, C.I.A. Director Rekindles Debate Over Surveillance
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Privacy', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The director, John O. Brennan, criticized “hand-wringing” over spying by governments and said that restrictions on surveillance made it harder to find terrorists.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A diabolical range of recent attacks claimed by the Islamic State — a Russian airliner blown up in Egypt, a double suicide bombing in Beirut and Friday’s ghastly assaults on Paris — has rekindled a debate over the proper limits of government surveillance in an age of terrorist mayhem.

headline: In a Tooth, DNA From Some Very Old Cousins, the Denisovans
keywords: ['Paleontology', 'Denisova Hominid', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Science and Technology', 'Neanderthal Man']
abstract: A fossil found in a Siberian cave yields evidence from a vanished, once-hardy branch of the human tree that lived at least 110,000 years ago.
lead_paragraph: A tooth fossil discovered in a Siberian cave has yielded DNA from a vanished branch of the human tree, mysterious cousins called the Denisovans, scientists said Monday.

headline: Liberty Global to Buy Cable & Wireless for $5.5 Billion
keywords: ['Cellular Telephones', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Wireless Communications', 'Telephones and Telecommunications']
abstract: The deal will expand the presence of the John Malone company across the Caribbean and Latin America.
lead_paragraph: Liberty Global, the European cable and wireless operator controlled by John C. Malone, agreed on Monday to buy the British telecommunications company Cable & Wireless Communications for $5.5 billion.

headline: Jawbone in Rock May Clear Up a Mammal Family Mystery
abstract: Helped by CT scans and 3-D printing, researchers say a rodentlike creature that lived more than 200 million years ago belonged to an ancestral branch.
lead_paragraph: With technologies like CT scans and 3-D printing, a team of scientists reported on Monday that it had solved a mystery about the family tree of mammals that started with a single tooth a century and a half ago.

headline: Danny Meyer’s Team Faces a No-Tipping World
abstract: At the Modern, the first of his restaurants to end gratuities, meetings with the staff address the anxieties.
lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving came early this year to the Modern. Not the holiday of turkey and cranberry sauce, but the custom of family members lovingly and contentiously coming together to talk (and talk) about the things that unite and divide them.

headline: Europe’s Darkened Future
abstract: How a half-decade of grim surprises have made Europe’s future look considerably more difficult than it once did.
lead_paragraph: Before we talk about fighting ISIS, let’s talk about the state of Europe. The first time I wrote about the European encounter with Islam in this newspaper was in December of 2009, around the publication of Christopher Caldwell’s “Reflections on the Revolution in Europe,” and the Swiss referendum banning minarets. In that column I wrote critically about the half-thought-out, deliberately un-democratic immigration policies the continent’s leaders had pursued since the 1960s, but I also expressed skepticism about the scenarios of dhimmitude and “Eurabia” floated, long before Michel Houellebecq’s “Submission,” by certain voices on the American and European right. From where I stood, neither demographic projections nor existing patterns of assimilation nor the continent’s ideological currents seemed to support a vision of a Europe where “Shariah has as much clout as liberalism” by, say, 2045. Instead, I argued that the European future would probably be like the present, only more so:

headline: Museum of Modern Art Returns German Artwork to Heirs of Jewish Collector
abstract: The Ludwig and Rosy Fischer collection was one of the most important collections of Expressionist art assembled in pre-Nazi Germany.
lead_paragraph: A German Expressionist painting by Ernst Ludwig Kirchner at the Museum of Modern Art will be returned to the heirs of the German art collector Max Fischer, the museum announced Monday.

headline: Homework Help, Pixel by Pixel
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'E-Books and Readers', 'E-Learning', 'Education (K-12)', 'Homework', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)']
abstract: Parents often worry that technology interferes with a child’s ability to finish homework, but a number of new tech tools are helping students do their homework faster.
lead_paragraph: Parents often worry that technology interferes with a child’s ability to finish homework, but a number of new tech tools are helping students do their homework faster.

headline: Democrats Question Republican-Led Inquiry Into Hillary Clinton’s Aide
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Members of the Senate Democratic leadership have raised questions about an inquiry led by Senator Charles E. Grassley into Hillary Rodham Clinton’s tenure as secretary of state.
lead_paragraph: Members of the Senate Democratic leadership have raised questions about an inquiry led by Senator Charles E. Grassley into Hillary Rodham Clinton’s tenure as secretary of state, highlighting what one staff member called a “fishy” coincidence: that a former aide to Mr. Grassley now works for the State Department’s inspector general.

headline: Seven Things That Inspire Gaspar Noé
abstract: The director, whose sensational new film “Love” is out now, shares some of the artworks, films and people who have influenced his work.
lead_paragraph: The French-Argentine director Gaspar Noé has built his career on the gleeful exploration of the fringes of human experience. Films like “Irreversible,” “Enter the Void” and the newly released “Love” plumb the depths of the uncanny, the impolite, the explicit — with an unflinching eye toward the human capacities for both care and cruelty. They are sometimes hard to watch, and always hard to forget. “Love” is no exception: Noé’s latest film centers on Murphy, an American living in Paris, and his erotically charged relationships; it features many minutes’ worth of unsimulated onscreen sex. (It was also filmed in 3D, and if there’s anything you’re imagining Noé might exploit that technology to depict, you’re probably right.) Here, Noé shares seven of the artworks, films and people who have influenced his work, from Buñuel to Travis Bickle.

headline: That Perfume You Smell Everywhere Is Santal 33
abstract: Le Labo’s popular scent began as an antidote to mass-market scents — and ironically ended up, to the discerning nose, all over the place.
lead_paragraph: Back in 2011, when the fragrance industry saw a rise in celebrity scents and relied on the allure of glossy marketing, the independent perfumery Le Labo proposed an antidote to the obsession with hype: quietly releasing its fifth fragrance in five years — completely unaware of the impact its new unisex perfume would have on a certain set (and generation) of style-conscious women. Like an under-the-radar It bag prized for its unidentifiable features and nondescript branding, Santal 33 quickly became a sort of cult secret, whispered through wafts of sandalwood and cedar, only detected by those in the know.

headline: For French Team, Playing for Country
abstract: Hugo Lloris, captain of the French national soccer team, spoke about what it would be like to play France’s match with England on Tuesday in London.
lead_paragraph: Hugo Lloris, captain of the French national soccer team, spoke about what it would be like to play France’s match with England on Tuesday in London.

headline: Union President, Randi Weingarten, Defends Hillary Clinton on Charter Schools
abstract: Randi Weingarten, president of the American Federation of Teachers, said Hillary Rodham Clinton had argued for “accountability for all public schools,” including charter schools.
lead_paragraph: Randi Weingarten, the president of the American Federation of Teachers, defended Hillary Rodham Clinton on Monday over critical remarks she made about charter schools, saying the Democratic presidential candidate had voiced a view many hold about such schools.

headline: An African King in Bolivia
abstract: A small-town farmer traces his lineage to a 19th-century African prince who was enslaved and taken to work in the silver mines of Bolivia.
lead_paragraph: A small-town farmer traces his lineage to a 19th-century African prince who was enslaved and taken to work in the silver mines of Bolivia.

headline: Mushroom Essences and More Thanksgiving Helpers
abstract: A guide to manners, where to find turducken, toting with Roy Lichtenstein, mulberry gin and gravy ladles that don’t burn your fingertips.
lead_paragraph: It takes but a whiff of two new mushroom elixirs made in the Périgord region of France to understand their vibrant intensity. Added to pan sauces, turkey jus or a toss of sautéed mushrooms and green beans, they would contribute depth of flavor. Morilles (morels), and cèpes (porcini) are the varieties made by macerating fresh mushrooms in alcohol, then distilling the result, which is 36 proof: Mushroom elixirs by Distillerie du Périgord, 6.8 ounces, $21.98 at Zabar’s. $25 at earthy.com.

headline: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
abstract: France and Elsewhere: Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: France and Elsewhere: Pictures of the Day

headline: Nov. 16, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from France, Belgium, the West Bank and Costa Rica.
lead_paragraph: Photos from France, Belgium, the West Bank and Costa Rica.

headline: Clashes Erupt During Raid in West Bank
abstract: Israeli troops killed two Palestinians after armed clashes broke out during a raid of the Qalandiya refugee camp in the West Bank.
lead_paragraph: Israeli troops killed two Palestinians after armed clashes broke out during a raid of the Qalandiya refugee camp in the West Bank.

headline: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: Twice-Baked Squash
abstract: A recipe created by a food writer living in Barcelona yields holiday version of a twice-baked butternut squash that is pretty and will easily dress up a fall or winter holiday table.
lead_paragraph: Caitlin Galer-Unti, a food writer, thought that baked butternut squash was so nice, she baked it twice.

headline: Chris Stapleton Takes Top Spot on Album Chart Again
abstract: For the second week in a row, “Traveller” by Chris Stapleton tops the album chart months after its release.
lead_paragraph: “Sometimes Cinderella is 37 years old, has a scraggly beard and sounds like a cross between George Jones and Otis Redding.”

headline: Berlin Philharmonic’s Beethoven Marathon at Carnegie Prompts Some Head-Scratching
abstract: The programming may seem an odd choice for its conductor, Simon Rattle, who has imaginatively mixed old and new over the years.
lead_paragraph: Taking on Beethoven’s nine symphonies in a concentrated marathon of concerts has long seemed almost a requisite undertaking for any conductor of stature — the ultimate public statement of artistic gravitas.

headline: What Travelers Can Expect in Paris
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'AIRPORTS']
abstract: If you’re visiting Paris, here’s what you need to know about flights, hotels, getting around and how to help in the wake of the attacks.
lead_paragraph: France was the top destination for international tourists last year, in no small part because of Paris’s allure. The fatal terrorist attacks in the city on Nov. 13 upended lives and a place that tourists hold dear. Below is information on how hotels and air carriers are accommodating travelers who are affected, when cultural sites are reopening, getting around town and the country and how tourists can do their part to help.

headline: Jets Hope Fitzpatrick’s Thumb Will Be Ready for Sunday
abstract: Jets quarterback Fitzpatrick had surgery to repair a torn ligament in his left thumb Friday, and the team hopes he will be ready to start Sunday in Houston.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — After having surgery to repair a torn ligament in his left thumb, Jets quarterback Ryan Fitzpatrick will be ready to start at quarterback Sunday in Houston.

headline: For-Profit College Operator EDMC Will Forgive Student Loans
abstract: As a result of a settlement over its recruitment practices, the Education Management Corporation will forgive loans to about 80,000 students.
lead_paragraph: The for-profit college operator Education Management Corporation will forgive loans to about 80,000 former students nationwide as part of an agreement with state attorneys general resulting from a multiyear investigation of the company’s aggressive recruitment practices.

headline: Prominent Iranian Cartoonist Reported Arrested in Tehran
abstract: The reason for the arrest of the cartoonist, Hadi Heidari, was not clear. It came amid a crackdown against perceived Western infiltration, activists said.
lead_paragraph: A prominent press cartoonist in Iran was arrested at work on Monday by security agents who provided no explanation, according to an Iranian news website and rights activists.

headline: Xian Zhang Takes New Jersey Symphony Podium
abstract: The orchestra’s next music director will be familiar to some concertgoers in the region: the Chinese-American star was an associate conductor at the New York Philharmonic for several years.
lead_paragraph: The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra’s next music director will be familiar to some concertgoers in the region: the orchestra announced Monday that the role would be filled by Xian Zhang, a rising Chinese-American star who was an associate conductor at the New York Philharmonic for several years before concentrating her recent career in Europe.

headline: ‘School of Rock’ and ‘The Color Purple’ Off to Strong Starts on Broadway
abstract: “School of Rock” grossed $928,596 in its first eight preview performances and “The Color Purple” grossed $690,820 in its first six previews.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Lloyd Webber and Alice Walker don’t have all that much in common, but Broadway seems to be smiling on both of them this fall.

headline: Scott Campbell’s “Whole Glory”
abstract: Over four days, the artist gave 23 participants mystery tattoos through a hole in a wall.
lead_paragraph: Over four days, the artist gave 23 participants mystery tattoos through a hole in a wall.

headline: Painful Choices for Peyton Manning and the Broncos
abstract: Manning has a tear of the plantar fascia ligament in his left foot, and after his poor game on Sunday, Denver Coach Gary Kubiak told reporters that he should have kept Manning out.
lead_paragraph: The Denver Broncos and their quarterback Peyton Manning received another reminder on Sunday that Manning’s illustrious career might be nearing an end.

headline: I Got a Mystery Tattoo From Scott Campbell
abstract: The artist’s “Whole Glory” project entailed giving tattoos to 23 participants over four days — through a hole in a wall. I was one of them.
lead_paragraph: This past Saturday morning, I got a tattoo from the artist Scott Campbell of Saved Tattoo. Thirty-six hours later, on Sunday night, we met face-to-face for the first time.

headline: Paris in Mourning
abstract: As France observed a moment of silence on Monday, there were signs of communal grief and heightened security in the capial.
lead_paragraph: As France observed a moment of silence on Monday, there were signs of communal grief and heightened security in the capial.

headline: Prison Town in Colorado Doesn’t Want Guantánamo Detainees
keywords: ['Detainees', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Terrorism', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)']
abstract: Residents and officials in Florence don’t want the notoriety or the visitors who would come with taking transferred Guantánamo inmates.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, Colo. — The Unabomber lives here. So do the men best known as the shoe bomber and the Boston Marathon bomber, as well as a Sept. 11 conspirator and 10,000 other inmates from the infamous to the obscure, sealed behind thick walls and razor-wire fences in the rolling high desert of southern Colorado.

headline: Filings Show Rocky Quarter for Many Hedge Funds
abstract: Some funds added shares of Valeant in a quarter when shares of the drug maker slid sharply.
lead_paragraph: Some of the richest investors on Wall Street on Monday gave the world a glimpse of how they make their money. Or, in the case of the last quarter, how many of them lost money for their clients.

headline: Chris Christie, Taking Law-and-Order Stance, Sidesteps Bridge Scandal in ’16 Race
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie’s focus on terrorism and crime has helped him turn the page on the political retribution scandal that has threatened his bid for the Republican nomination.
lead_paragraph: Chris Christie’s voice was level, even soft, as he recalled his precise movements on Sept. 11, 2001. Addressing a Republican conference in Florida, he wove a tale that linked his background as a federal prosecutor to a current need for American resolve overseas, and to what he characterized as wavering leadership by a “lawless president.”

headline: Amid Many Emotions, No Choice for France but to Play
abstract: The French players accepted the decision to play England in a friendly on Tuesday and understand the larger purpose of the game.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Sitting at a small table in the news conference room at Wembley Stadium on Monday afternoon, Hugo Lloris, the goalkeeper and captain of France’s national soccer team, listened to the question and frowned. Then he hesitated. Then he shrugged. It was clear he wanted to give the right answer, the supportive answer, the answer the French soccer federation would want him to give. But Lloris wanted to be truthful, too.

headline: The Food Police in My Phone
abstract: A new nutrition app gives you a private coach via your phone, but having someone critique your food choices can also take the joy out of eating.
lead_paragraph: It started with a stir fry. I ordered my usual at a nondescript cafe across the street from work: shrimp, tofu, broccoli and snap peas in spicy teriyaki sauce over brown rice.

headline: China Bends Vow on Using Prisoners’ Organs for Transplants
keywords: ['Organ Donation', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Medicine and Health', 'Transplants', 'Capital Punishment']
abstract: A senior health official said last year that the practice would be stopped, but organs from prisoners, including those on death row, are still used.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — When a senior Chinese health official said last year that China would stop using prisoners’ organs for transplants as of Jan. 1, 2015, human rights advocates and medical professionals around the world greeted the announcement with relief.

headline: Governors Against Refugees' Entry
abstract: Several Republican governors said they opposed letting Syrian refugees enter their states after the terrorist attacks in Paris on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Several Republican governors said they opposed letting Syrian refugees enter their states after the terrorist attacks in Paris on Friday.

headline: ‘Rap Tees’ Catalogs Two Decades of Hip-Hop Merchandising
abstract: DJ Ross One documents more than 500 shirts from a genre’s dawn to its ubiquity in a new century.
lead_paragraph: The new photo book “Rap Tees: A Collection of Hip-Hop T-Shirts 1980-1999” by DJ Ross One documents 500 shirts, from hip-hop’s dawn — the first item is a Sugar Hill Gang shirt from 1980, a year after that group released “Rapper’s Delight,” widely considered the first commercial hip-hop single — to its turn-of-the-millennium ubiquity. All the shirts are advertisements, but they go about their job in vastly different ways: Some emphasize logos, others favor slogans or let photos do the talking; a rare few let artists have their way.

headline: The Uncommon Resilience of Parisian Street Life
abstract: What we can learn from century-old photographs of the sites of the Nov. 13 terrorist attacks.
lead_paragraph: It must be a warm day on the Rue Bichat — a few people have their sleeves rolled up — and the cafes on both sides of the street are open for business, with tables and chairs neatly set up along the sidewalk for customers. Some vendors and deliverymen have left their small carts along the curb. A man, midstride, stares at the camera as he crosses the street, interested in the uncommon event of a photographer setting up his bulky apparatus. A horse-drawn carriage bears a driver and sacks of what appear to be flour or wheat down the Rue Bichat away from its intersection with the Rue Alibert.

headline: Special Section: Wired Well
abstract: We explore the lives of newly wired consumers and the consequences, good and bad, that arise from our increasing reliance on trackers, monitors, guides and a vast array of other devices to better our health.
lead_paragraph: Once personal health technology meant little more than bathroom scales, thermometers and electric toothbrushes. Now, these devices and apps are everywhere: on our wrists, in our phones, the bedroom, the kitchen, even on our children and pets. In this special issue of Science Times, we explore the lives of newly wired consumers and the consequences, good and bad, that arise from our increasing reliance on trackers, monitors, guides and a vast array of other devices to better our health.

headline: Review: Paul Lewis Powers Through a Beethoven Trilogy at White Light Festival
abstract: Mr. Lewis, who missed three Schubert song cycles because of appendicitis, played the three piano sonatas in quick succession, with no intermission.
lead_paragraph: The English pianist Paul Lewis was to have more or less anchored the White Light Festival at Lincoln Center this fall, with major appearances early and late. But appendicitis  prevented him from joining the tenor Mark Padmore in three Schubert song cycles last month.

headline: Obama Aims to Shore Up Asian Allies Against Chinese Might
abstract: During a visit to Southeast Asia, the president will try to deepen diplomatic ties and push for more trade to help bolster countries in the region.
lead_paragraph: ANTALYA, Turkey — President Obama’s arrival in the Philippines on Tuesday morning will kick off five days of presidential diplomacy aimed at bolstering America’s allies in the region against China’s economic and military might.

headline: The Designers Behind Building Block Travel to Taiwan
abstract: Nancy and Kimberly Wu find inspiration — and eat good food — on their recent trip to the country.
lead_paragraph: Nancy and Kimberly Wu find inspiration — and eat good food — on their recent trip to the country.

headline: The Designers Behind Building Block Visit Taiwan
abstract: Kimberly and Nancy Wu, the sisters behind the brand, share with T memories and photos from their recent trip.
lead_paragraph: Since 2011, the designers Kimberly and Nancy Wu have operated Building Block — an L.A.-based design studio that focuses on minimal accessories: handbags, shoes and goods comprised of leather, rubber and wood. Their studio — a whitewashed room (and former feminist art space) in Chinatown — reflects their attitude toward design: simple, clean, not overdone.

headline: More States Are Initiating Programs to Encourage Retirement Savings
abstract: States are increasingly creating their own retirement savings programs, and the Obama administration on Monday took steps to bolster the movement.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 68 million workers do not have access to work-based retirement plans like 401(k)’s for companies and 403(b)’s for nonprofits and government employees. But that is now changing as more states have begun exploring different ways to create savings vehicles for those not covered by existing tax-deferred savings programs.

headline: Pandora Plans to Acquire the Assets of Rdio
abstract: An acquisition would move Pandora, the Internet radio company, into the field of on-demand music, where it would compete with Spotify and Apple Music.
lead_paragraph: Since it began 10 years ago, Pandora Media has been focused on one corner of the digital music universe: Internet radio. Now, it is also moving into the world of on-demand music, competing directly with outlets like Spotify and Apple Music.

headline: Review: ‘Sinatra: The Chairman,’ His World, His Way
abstract: The concluding volume of James Kaplan’s biography charts the singer’s continued rise to international fame and captures the changing times he transited.
lead_paragraph: He was America’s greatest vocalist: a consummate artist who redefined the possibilities of popular music, bringing to it an intimacy, an urban swagger and an emotional vulnerability that stamped songs as indelibly his own. A voice — no, the Voice — who could deliver “In the Wee Small Hours of the Morning” and “I’ve Got the World on a String” with equal authority and self-knowledge. A tough guy with Bond-like sophistication and savoir-faire, who sang with uncommon tenderness about loneliness and yearning. A ring-a-ding-ding Vegas showman, rarely without his posse, who could articulate the heartache and existential solitude of the human condition with more conviction than any singer on the planet.

headline: Review: ‘Professor Brenner,’ a 1911 Play About a Generation Gap
abstract: Young people were just as shallow 100 years ago, according to this David Pinski work, presented by the New Worlds Theater Project.
lead_paragraph: The New Worlds Theater Project, which presents English adaptations of Yiddish plays, has an intriguing find in “Professor Brenner,” a 1911 work by David Pinski that explores a May-December romance. The production isn’t great, but the historical perspective has some value.

headline: C.I.A. Director Discusses Paris Attacks
abstract: John O. Brennan, the C.I.A. director, said that the attacks in Paris showed a sophisticated operation and that surveillance internationally had become challenging.
lead_paragraph: John O. Brennan, the C.I.A. director, said that the attacks in Paris showed a sophisticated operation and that surveillance internationally had become challenging.

headline: Review: The Formulaic ‘Chicago Med’ Extends an NBC Franchise
abstract: This relentlessly paced emergency-room drama from Dick Wolf is exactly what you expect it to be.
lead_paragraph: Most days, Chicago is only the third-largest city in the United States, but beginning this week it may seem as if it’s the dominant one on Tuesdays, as “Chicago Med” joins “Chicago Fire” on NBC’s schedule for that night. If Dick Wolf didn’t have himself a “Chicago” franchise before, he certainly does now; he’s behind those two shows as well as “Chicago P.D.” on Wednesdays.

headline: Review: Jérôme Bel’s ‘Ballet (New York),’ an Exercise in Changing Locations
abstract: Mr. Bel, the Conceptualist French choreographer, gathers 13 New Yorkers whose training in dance runs from seemingly zero to good enough for New York City Ballet.

headline: Review: Carol Lipnik, a Bewitching Blend of Comedy and Mysticism
abstract: “Welcome to the séance!” the singer, songwriter and performance artist told a packed house on Sunday at the East Village restaurant and cabaret Pangea.
lead_paragraph: “Welcome to the séance!” the singer, songwriter and performance artist Carol Lipnik exclaimed to a packed house on Sunday evening at the East Village restaurant and cabaret Pangea.

headline: Review: Yefim Bronfman Plays Prokofiev at Carnegie, Channeling Rage and Grief
abstract: The pianist began a series of sonata performances at Zankel Hall after a moment of silence honoring terrorist victims in Paris.
lead_paragraph: Before the pianist Yefim Bronfman’s concert on Friday evening at Zankel Hall, Clive Gillinson, executive and artistic director of Carnegie Hall, requested a moment of silence in honor of the victims of the terrorist attacks in Paris.

headline: Review: David Rabe’s ‘Good for Otto’ Introduces a World of Pain
abstract: A tiny theater in Chicago is a showcase for a sweeping and deep new work by David Rabe, in powerful form.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The sound of an orchestra tuning up signals the start of “Good for Otto,” the new play by David Rabe having its premiere at the small Gift Theater here. It’s a smart touch from the director, Michael Patrick Thornton, for Mr. Rabe’s moving drama does have a symphonic quality, although an apt analogy would be mournful Shostakovich rather than something jubilantly lyrical from, say, Schubert.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing: Paris, Refugees, Peyton Manning
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day, including updates on the Paris attacks.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Review: Heidi Latsky Dance and Axis Dance at Skirball Center
abstract: Honoring the 25th anniversary of the Americans With Disabilities Act, these troupes, made up of dancers with and without disabilities, performed.
lead_paragraph: Anyone walking down LaGuardia Place in Greenwich Village on Sunday night could glimpse Heidi Latsky’s “On Display” through the tall glass doors of the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts. That was just one inclusive dimension of this hourlong movement installation, which was the prelude to an evening shared by Heidi Latsky Dance and Axis Dance Company honoring the 25th anniversary of the Americans With Disabilities Act. Both troupes are made up of dancers with and without disabilities, and reject the notion that disability is a limitation, exploring the potential of many kinds of bodies.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day, including updates on the Paris attacks.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day, including updates on the Paris attacks.

headline: Plan for New Stock Exchange Stirs Furious Debate
keywords: ['High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The proposal, by the Investors Exchange, would create the first new American stock exchange in five years and would include a 350-microsecond “speed bump.”
lead_paragraph: A proposal to create the first new American stock exchange in five years has set off a fierce debate over how to solve problems created by increasingly complex and high-speed stock markets.

headline: After Paris Attacks, ‘La Marseillaise’ Echoes Around the World in Solidarity
abstract: The French national anthem has been ubiquitous in concert halls and stadiums since Friday, a symbol of support and a sign of the song’s emotional resonance.
lead_paragraph: It rang out at the Metropolitan Opera, with Plácido Domingo conducting, and before performances by the Philadelphia Orchestra, the Lyric Opera of Chicago, the Detroit Symphony Orchestra and others. Muslim leaders sang it in Paris at the scene of one of Friday’s deadly terror attacks. London’s Wembley Stadium will display its lyrics on large screens to help English-speaking soccer fans muddle through it Tuesday when England plays France.

headline: Amid Tabloid Reports, Charlie Sheen Plans ‘Revealing Personal Announcement’
abstract: The troubled television star will appear on the “Today” show Tuesday after reports that he is HIV-positive.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As tabloid reports proliferated on Monday that the troubled television star Charlie Sheen plans to soon reveal his HIV-positive status, one of Hollywood’s top crisis public relations experts confirmed that representatives for Mr. Sheen had in recent months sought his assistance in disclosing the diagnosis.

headline: Paris and Europe’s Anti-Refugee Backlash
keywords: ['Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Fringe Groups and Movements']
abstract: How the attacks will change the politics of asylum policy in Europe.
lead_paragraph: Berlin — IN Europe, it took the right and the extreme right just hours to turn the terrible events of Paris into political fodder: On Saturday afternoon in France, Laurent Wauquiez, secretary general of the Republicans, the conservative party of former president Nicolas Sarkozy, demanded detention camps for some 4,000 people in France considered potential terrorists by the authorities.

headline: Baltimore Police Assailed for Response After Freddie Gray’s Death
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Police']
abstract: The independent report found that the police were unprepared and untrained for the unrest that convulsed the city.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — The first independent review of the Baltimore Police Department’s response to riots in April found “major shortcomings” and said officers were unprepared and untrained for the scale and scope of the unrest.

headline: After Paris Attacks, a Darker Mood Toward Islam Emerges in France
abstract: Unlike after the Charlie Hebdo attacks in January, calls for solidarity with Muslims have been rare while even the left-wing government considers harsher security measures.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — November is not January. That thought has been filtering through the statements of most French politicians and the news media, and most people seem to understand.

headline: Bronx Program Encourages Fathers to Talk About Sex
abstract: The effort is a new approach to curb sexually transmitted diseases and teenage pregnancies in a borough where the rates of both are high.
lead_paragraph: By the time Victor M. Garcia talked to his father about sex, he himself was already a father of four sons.

headline: Justice Antonin Scalia Questions Logic Behind Gay Rights Protections
abstract: The Supreme Court’s decisions protecting gay rights were not rooted in the Constitution, and their logic could as easily apply to child molesters, Justice Scalia told first-year law students at Georgetown.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s decisions protecting gay rights were not rooted in the Constitution, and their logic could as easily apply to child molesters, Justice Antonin Scalia told a room filled with first-year law students at Georgetown University on Monday.

headline: Artificial Intelligence Draws New Connections for Personalization
abstract: A start-up called Sentient could point a way to a future where sitting on a vast trove of data can be even more valuable than it is today.
lead_paragraph: An effort to get people better boots may say much about the future of artificial intelligence in the business world.

headline: Minnesota: Federal Inquiry Sought Into Shooting
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Assaults', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: Mayor Betsy Hodges of Minneapolis called for a federal civil rights investigation into an officer-involved shooting early Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Betsy Hodges of Minneapolis called Monday for a federal civil rights investigation into an officer-involved shooting early Sunday. The man who was shot, identified by activists as Jamar Clark, who is African-American, remained hospitalized Monday evening. His father, James Hill, said his son was brain-dead. Neighbors quoted in the local news media said Mr. Clark was handcuffed at the time of the shooting, but the authorities said he was not. The Minneapolis police, who have not publicly named Mr. Clark, said the man was a suspect in an assault who disrupted paramedics treating his victim and then fought with officers. The shooting prompted protests. Federal officials did not immediately issue a public response to Ms. Hodges’s request.

headline: U.S.T.A. Responds to Eugenie Bouchard’s Suit Over a Head Injury
abstract: The United States Tennis Association contends that Eugenie Bouchard did not follow protocol and refused offers of medical attention after she fell and injured her head.
lead_paragraph: In response to a lawsuit filed a month ago by Eugenie Bouchard seeking damages for a head injury sustained from a fall during the United States Open, the United States Tennis Association contends that the player did not follow protocol and refused offers of medical attention.

headline: Plan to Close Nuclear Plant in Upstate New York Rattles Its Neighbors
abstract: After Entergy announced the shutdown of the James A. FitzPatrick plant, residents of Oswego County became anxious about the loss of jobs and the drain on the local economy.
lead_paragraph: SCRIBA, N.Y. — The huge concrete cooling tower standing near the shore of Lake Ontario might give chills to visitors catching a first glimpse of it. But to many residents of this semirural section of Oswego County, the two nuclear power plants in town have been a comforting presence.

headline: Utah Judge Withdraws in Lesbians’ Foster Case
keywords: ['Foster Care', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Judge Scott N. Johansen first ordered a 9-month-old foster child removed from the home of a married couple, and then reversed himself, before disqualifying himself from the case.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — A judge in Utah who drew national scrutiny for ordering a lesbian couple to give up their infant foster child withdrew from the case on Monday.

headline: Long Island Family Sues Catholic Order and Diocese in Molestation Case

headline: ‘Jane the Virgin’ Season 2, Episode 6: Jumping Ahead
abstract: This week’s episode moves quicker than most.
lead_paragraph: One of the most interesting elements of “Jane the Virgin” is the pacing. It’s always been pretty quick — after all, it is mimicking the style of a telenovela — but in a way that never confuses viewers or feels rushed. “Chapter Twenty-Eight” uses this rapid-fire approach to its advantage by fast-forwarding through entire months without dropping any important story points. The episode begins the day after the events of last week, immediately reassuring us that baby Mateo is O.K. before jumping into this week’s big plots. Jane is officially starting her life with Michael — and starting graduate school — while getting closer to Rafael, even as the two disagree on finances. Petra has her hands full with Milos’s surprise grenades, Michael is on a strange road trip with Nadine, and Rogelio is trying to figure out what his future will be after his television show ends.

First, they use fists, then batons, swinging the clubs down with both hands as the man lies on the ground, moaning.

headline: Texas: Tornado Rips Through Halliburton Plant
abstract: The tornado, one of four that touched down in the area, caused a chemical leak but no immediate reports of injuries.
lead_paragraph: A tornado ripped through a Halliburton plant an hour northeast of Amarillo on Monday, causing a chemical leak that emergency crews were working to contain, the authorities said. The Gray County Sheriff’s Office said two deputies who were exposed to the chemical, which was unspecified, refused medical treatment. There were no reports of injuries. Lt. Zach Kidd said no one was inside the building, in Pampa, Tex., when the tornado struck, and several vehicles parked outside were unoccupied. Radioactive material housed at the site was not affected, he said. The tornado was one of four that touched down in the county as a severe weather system moved across the region, according to the sheriff’s office. Two homes and several businesses sustained damage ranging from minor to severe, officials said.

headline: Syria: Iran Reaffirms a Role for Assad
abstract: A deputy foreign minister said that President Bashar al-Assad should remain in power and be included in elections as part of any diplomatic negotiation aimed at ending the civil war.
lead_paragraph: An Iranian official said Monday that President Bashar al-Assad of Syria should remain in power and be included in elections as part of any diplomatic negotiation aimed at ending the civil war. The statement, by Hossein Amir Abdollahian, a deputy foreign minister, was not a new position for Iran, Mr. Assad’s regional ally. But it reinforced the deep divide that remains over Mr. Assad’s future in the international talks on Syria, even as pressure has intensified for a solution. Diplomats participating in the talks in Vienna over the weekend represented more than a dozen countries, including the United States, which has said Mr. Assad cannot be part of any final settlement. Mr. Abdollahian was quoted by Iran’s Fars News Agency as saying Iran ensured that a statement issued at the meeting’s conclusion excluded any language that would limit Mr. Assad’s role in a postwar government.

headline: Bad Debt Collectors and Their Prey
abstract: Weak laws make it possible for debt collection companies to defraud debtors and then seize nearly everything they own.

But those laws, some of which date to the distant past, have been rendered ineffective by debt collectors using new and devious ways to win court judgments that allow them to seize debtors’ paychecks or bank accounts.

headline: How to Help Save the Mentally Ill From Themselves
abstract: Having lost his own son, the author argues that a bill in Congress could help prevent other families from enduring the same misfortune.
lead_paragraph: MY older son, Matthew Ornstein, died at age 34 on Jan. 3 from carbon monoxide poisoning. It was accidental — he fell asleep in a tent with a propane lantern — but his death was shaped by a lack of judgment driven by a 10-year struggle with mental illness.

headline: Inadequate Transportation Bills in Congress
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Railroads', 'Transportation', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)']
abstract: Legislation that could be approved by the end of this week may make traveling on American roads and railways less safe.
lead_paragraph: Congress could approve a six-year transportation bill by the end of this week, when authorization for federal transportation programs expires. Unfortunately, the legislation will not do nearly enough to improve aging bridges, fix highways or expand the capacity of mass transit and rail systems. Worse, it could make traveling on American roads and railways less safe.

headline: We’re Living Longer. That’s Great, Except for Social Security.
abstract: Despite the political challenges, fixing Social Security is rather simple: Take more money in, send less money out, or both.
lead_paragraph: I wrote last week about rising life expectancy: Children born today will most likely live on average to their late 80s, well above the current average life expectancy of 79. You probably think of this as good news, and from most perspectives, it is.

headline: In Bangladesh, a Half-Century of Saving Lives With  Data
abstract: A research center in rural Bangladesh that formulated and tested oral rehydration solution to stop childhood diarrhea in the 1960s has saved millions of lives since by continuing to monitor public health.
lead_paragraph: NABAKALASH, Bangladesh — Sufia Khatun wears a green sari around her thin 76-year-old frame. Round gold-rimmed glasses perch on her wizened face. When she smiles, she reveals teeth stained brown from betel nut. She has lived all her life in this village in Matlab, a sub-district in central Bangladesh.

headline: Street-Style Star Linda Rodin on Growing Older

lead_paragraph: Linda Rodin began her beauty empire in 2007 with a single product. In turn, Ms. Rodin, a former model, boutique owner and stylist, became a kind of street-style icon, with her signature gray hair, oversize glasses and red lipstick. Ms. Rodin’s first cleanser was introduced last month. She spoke about finding the perfect formula for it, a fondness for clumpy mascara and her philosophy on aging.

abstract: The presidential race’s new emphasis on terrorism has laid bare Mrs. Clinton’s long-held differences with President Obama on foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: In her pursuit of the Democratic nomination for president, Hillary Rodham Clinton has emphasized her ties to President Obama. She regularly tells the story of how he wooed her into serving as his secretary of state and recites, typically to a roar of applause, the line, “President Obama doesn’t get the credit he deserves.”

headline: An African King in Bolivia
abstract: A small-town farmer traces his lineage to a 19th-century African prince who was enslaved and taken to work in the silver mines of Bolivia.
lead_paragraph: Tucked away in an isolated part of Bolivia, there is a royal family whose existence is as surprising as it is humble. Despite his title, King Don Julio I and his wife live in a small apartment atop a small store in Mururata, Bolivia, where he farms coca leaves and other crops.

headline: Sarah Vowell’s ‘Lafayette in the Somewhat United States’
abstract: Lafayette was hailed as a hero on his 1820s American tour.
lead_paragraph: The full name was Marie-Joseph-Paul-Yves-Roch-Gilbert du Motier, which was quite a mouthful for Yankee sensibilities, but the Marquis de Lafayette became one of the first American celebrities anyway. (The new nation had a sweet tooth for the flattery of Frenchmen. That’s also how Tocqueville managed to freeload his way across the Northwest Territories.) Lafayette came over the Atlantic to fight in the American Revolution when he was 19. He went home to France and tried to be a centrist politician during that country’s upheaval. This was rather like aspiring to be a pot roast in a den of wolverines. But he survived the Revolution and the Terror, turned down a job in Napoleon’s government, and in 1824, he returned to the United States at the invitation of James Monroe. He visited all 24 of the states at the time. The tour took more than a year, and Lafayette was cheered at every stop. He survived the sinking of his steamboat in the Ohio River, and lived to help lay the cornerstone of the Bunker Hill Monument in Charlestown, Mass. He also survived an oration by Daniel Webster on that same occasion.

headline: ‘Chicagonomics’ and ‘Economics Rules’
abstract: One book sees a problem with applied economics; another sees a perversion of the Chicago school’s message.
lead_paragraph: He believed that government had a crucial role to play in a well-functioning economy. It should finance and run good schools, as well as build roads, bridges and parks, he argued. It should tax alcohol, sugar and tobacco, all of which impose costs on society. It should regulate businesses to protect workers. And it should tax the rich — who suffer from “indolence and vanity” — to help the poor.

lead_paragraph: NAYPYIDAW, Myanmar — For two decades, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi was a radiant symbol of dignified nonviolent resistance, most of that time confined to house arrest by the generals who have governed Myanmar for half a century.
