headline: Saving the World, Startup-Style
keywords: ['Foreign Aid', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Philanthropy', 'Humanitarian Aid']
abstract: Governments have spent trillions of dollars helping the poor, without finding a foreign-aid strategy that works. What if they learned to invest more nimbly?
lead_paragraph: In 2010, not long after the earthquake hit Haiti, I was about an hour north of Port-au-Prince, standing under a mango tree. Its owner, a woman named Jelen, was telling me that she had two daughters but could afford to send only one to school. She knew this meant the other would be poor, like her, for the rest of her life. She said she was choosing the younger one because she was smarter. She then pointed at her mango tree. It was huge, bigger than a family home, and grew hundreds of mangoes each year. She knew that those mangoes could sell for several dollars each in America, but there was no easy way to get them there. So she sold most of them down the road at a local market for pennies. If she could find a good way to get those mangoes down the highway to the capital and then on a ship to America, she was confident that she could make enough money to send both her girls to school.

headline: Poll Watch: U.S. Public Uneasy With ISIS Strategy Even Before Paris Attacks
abstract: A New York Times/CBS News poll released before the attacks in Paris found that Americans were unhappy with the president’s approach to the radical Islamist group.

But a New York Times/CBS News poll released just before the attacks found that Americans were already unhappy with the president’s approach to the radical Islamist group, also known as ISIS or ISIL.

headline: Making Bathrooms More ‘Accommodating’
abstract: The word implies that a sacrifice is being made for transgender students. But what is being given up?
lead_paragraph: The clearest visual markers of sex difference many of us see in the course of the day are the signs on public bathroom entrances: MEN on one door, WOMEN on the other. Restrooms are public conveniences, freely available in most places and in principle open to all, but the terms for entering them have been fixed. They’re fundamentally fraught spaces, where we undress and obey the dictates of our bodies and therefore feel vulnerable. If people think you’ve confused male and female and walked through the wrong door, you risk discomfort, or even real trouble. This can lead to the spectacle of women standing in line for what feels like forever while the men’s room is empty. Now transgender people, most prominently, are asking society to rethink all of this, from signs to design to who gets to enter where.

headline: Don Lemon Doesn’t Get Offended
abstract: The CNN news anchor promotes open discussion, whether it’s brilliant or ignorant.
lead_paragraph: You have asked some of the most memorable questions in cable-news history, I would say. So what would you ask yourself? I would ask: Why on earth would anyone want to do this job?

headline: In Iceland, a Literary Tour Explores Rich History
abstract: To the residents of Reykjavik, the culture of storytelling seems to be the source of their greatest national pride and Iceland has a nearly 100 percent literacy rate.
lead_paragraph: Standing in the dark outside the Reykjavik public library in the relentless damp chill that comes with a light rain at 40 degrees, I kept trying to zip up my jacket. The charcoal sky was a shade lighter than the inky ocean a few blocks away, but it was noon, not twilight. I had a few minutes to bundle up before an outdoor walking tour on literary Iceland began. As if on cue, the zipper snapped off in my hand.

headline: Terrible Defense Leads Saints to Fire Rob Ryan
abstract: Among those who have been defensive coordinators for at least 10 seasons since 1990, Ryan’s defenses have allowed the most points per game and yards per game.
lead_paragraph: Late Monday, the New Orleans Saints finally parted ways with defensive coordinator Rob Ryan. The move was a reaction to a historically poor defensive performance on Sunday in Washington. Against a mediocre Redskins offense, New Orleans allowed over 300 passing yards and over 200 rushing yards, while giving up 8.9 yards per offensive play. The Saints defense is just the sixth since 1970 to allow an opposing offense to hit those three marks in a single game.

headline: 1940: Italians Bomb Foes
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Italy strikes at enemies in Greece, Crete and Egypt in 1940.
lead_paragraph: ROME — New triumphs for Italy’s aviators were reported today [Nov. 17] by the army high command, which said that in Greece, ‘‘where attacks and counter-attacks were especially fierce in the sector of the 9th army,’’ Italian aviation ‘‘bombed roads, railways, enemy positions and artillery posts, causing fires and explosions.’’ The port of Alexandria and the harbor of Suda, in Crete, have again been bombed, it was said, as well as British bases in Egypt. In Egypt, it was announced, ‘‘our aviation has bombed bases at El Daba and Maaten Bagush, equipment at Mersa Matruh and the railroad from there to Bir Amasin.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 18, 1940

headline: 1965: Youths Spit at Rusk and R.F.K.
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Leftist youths in South America spit at Dean Rusk and Robert F. Kennedy in 1965.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Leftist youths spat at both Secretary of State Dean Rusk and Sen. Robert F. Kennedy yesterday [Nov. 16] in two separate incidents. Mr. Rusk, on his way to an inter-American conference here, had stopped in Montevideo, when he was attacked by an 18-year-old youth who shouted: ‘‘This is in the name of my people.’’ The youth, who spat toward Mr. Rusk, was quickly subdued by police. Sen. Kennedy was spat upon by University of Chile students, who also threw eggs and stones at him in Conception. Sen. Kennedy controlled his anger. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 18, 1965

But the troubled Boston Lyric Opera’s enthralling new site-specific production of his “In the Penal Colony,” a 2000 chamber opera with a libretto by Rudolph Wurlitzer, takes a different approach to making Mr. Glass’s work relevant to contemporary debates.

headline: Museum of the City of New York Names New Director
abstract: Whitney W. Donhauser, a longtime museum administrator and fund-raiser, will succeed Susan Henshaw Jones.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of the City of New York has selected a new director, its board announced on Tuesday.

headline: Republicans Call for Halt to Syrian Refugee Program
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Two senators announced a push for a formal authorization of military force against the Islamic State as Congress moved to respond to the Paris attacks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Seizing on the terrorist attacks in Paris, congressional Republicans on Tuesday demanded the suspension of a program to accept Syrian refugees in the United States, but along with Democrats, they continued to shy away from explicit authorization of military force to confront the Islamic State.

headline: Only a Decade to Go on the New Hudson Tunnel
keywords: ['Bridges and Tunnels', 'Governors (US)', 'Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Railroads', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Transit Systems', 'Transportation']
abstract: A project to repair the tunnels may finally be underway.
lead_paragraph: After a slow start, a series of unhelpful political squabbles and an early fumble by Governor Chris Christie of New Jersey, a massive $20 billion tunnel project under the Hudson River may finally be underway.  Prodded by Senator Charles Schumer, the disparate parties have agreed to step one: They have set up a corporation to oversee this ten-year project. This is good news, even if there are still plenty of years and hurdles to go.

headline: Hillary Clinton Gets Important Labor Backing From S.E.I.U.
abstract: The Service Employees International Union’s endorsement offers Hillary Rodham Clinton the support of a labor group that has been at the forefront of the push for higher wages and also taken a leadership role in the broader social justice movements animating the left.
lead_paragraph: The Service Employees International Union, one of the largest and most politically influential unions, threw its support behind Hillary Rodham Clinton on Tuesday, the latest indication that she is consolidating support among the institutional pillars of the Democratic Party.

headline: From Sedona to the Breakers, Spas With a Sense of Place
abstract: Sylvia Sepielli firmly believes that a spa should channel the history, culture and spirit of a region.
lead_paragraph: Sylvia Sepielli firmly believes that a spa should channel the history, culture and spirit of a region. “I’m very sensitive when something feels out of place,” she said. “If you don’t have a visceral memory of a place that includes the sights and sounds and smells and feels and textures, it doesn’t really stay with you very long.”

headline: Twyla Tharp on Tour: The Right to Assemble
abstract: Ms. Tharp writes about what is was like to perform on Friday evening, after receiving news of the terrorist attacks in Paris.
lead_paragraph: Twyla Tharp is writing about rehearsing, touring and creating new work, 50 years after her first dance concert.

headline: One Parent, on Paris: They Might Have Guns, but We Have Flowers
abstract: Talking with children about the ways we respond to tragedy, good and bad.
lead_paragraph: Standing in Paris, his toddler in his arms, one dad answers the question we all ask: How do I talk to my child about terrorism? About “bad guys with guns?” About war and death and tragedy?

headline: Dance This Week: From Modern to Tango to Flamenco
abstract: On the cultural calendars for the week are dance programs of many flavors and traditions.

headline: Guinea, Last Nation With Ebola, May Soon Be Declared Free of Virus
abstract: A 3-week-old girl now recovering could be the final patient in an epidemic that killed more than 11,300 people, overwhelmingly in West Africa.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — The worst Ebola outbreak in history took a big step toward ending on Tuesday when Guinea, the only nation where the virus had been lingering, began its official countdown to being declared free of the disease.

headline: New Radio Ad Hammers Marco Rubio Over Immigration, on Ted Cruz’s Behalf
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: An ad from a small new “super PAC” assails Senator Marco Rubio’s work to pass a comprehensive immigration reform bill in 2013 as an “amnesty scheme” and part of a pact with the so-called Group of Eight lawmakers and President Obama.
lead_paragraph: The newest “super PAC” supporting Senator Ted Cruz will run a radio commercial in Iowa excoriating Senator Marco Rubio by describing his work to pass a comprehensive immigration reform bill in 2013 as an “amnesty scheme” and part of a pact with President Obama.

headline: ‘City Center Encores! Unscripted': A Talk Show About Musical Theater
abstract: The series “City Center Encores! Unscripted,” will consist of three talks and performances that will be streamed live online, and later made available as videos and podcasts.
lead_paragraph: City Center Encores!, the program that stages revivals of rarely seen but beloved Broadway shows, is partnering with the Jerome L. Greene Space at WNYC to create a new talk show about musical theater.

headline: Review: In Crackle’s ‘The Art of More,’ the White Gloves Come Off
abstract: This 10-episode series from Sony’s streaming service depicts the cutthroat rivalries at high-end auction houses.
lead_paragraph: We love to despise absurdly rich people and revel in their misfortunes, but have we spent enough time doing the same for the enablers of absurdly rich people — sellers of yachts, operators of polo clubs, designers of $10,000 gowns? Probably not. “The Art of More,” a tasty new drama on Crackle, is determined to make up for this oversight.

headline: International Center of Photography Gets Grant from Mellon Foundation
abstract: A $750,000 grant from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation will be used by the International Center of Photography to create what the organization calls a Center for Visual Culture.
lead_paragraph: The International Center of Photography, which is in the process of reinventing itself in a new home scheduled to open next year on the Bowery, has received a $750,000 grant from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation that will be used to create what the organization calls a Center for Visual Culture, a specialized program focusing on how photographic imagery functions in 21st-century life.

headline: Afghan Jobs Program Aims to Stem Exodus of Young
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: The program announced by President Ashraf Ghani, is intended to recreate some of the jobs that disappeared after NATO forces withdrew.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Ashraf Ghani on Tuesday began a modest jobs program to try to stem an exodus of young Afghans to Europe and restore some faith in the struggling government and economy.

headline: A Proposed Smoking Ban in Public Housing
abstract: Ira Glasser, former head of the A.C.L.U., calls the ban “outrageous” because it compels mostly nonwhite residents to give up rights that others have.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Greece and Eurozone Creditors in Deal to Unlock $13 Billion
abstract: The breakthrough was an agreement to protect the most vulnerable indebted homeowners from foreclosure, while buffering banks from the worst bad loans.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Greece and its international creditors said on Tuesday that they had reached agreement on the country’s next round of economic changes, a deal that is meant to unlock as much as 12 billion euros, or about $13 billion, in loan money.

headline: Hiroji Kubota, Photographer
abstract: Hiroji Kubota’s path to Magnum started in Japan when he worked as a fixer and translator for members of the legendary agency.
lead_paragraph: Hiroji Kubota’s path to Magnum started in Japan when he worked as a fixer and translator for members of the legendary agency.

headline: City to Pay $5.3 Million to End Suits Over 2 Rikers Inmates’ Deaths
abstract: The settlements involve Jason Echevarria, who died in after ingesting a soap packet at the jail complex, and Carlos Mercado, who died of complications from diabetes within 15 hours of arriving there.
lead_paragraph: The city has agreed to pay a total of more than $5 million to settle separate lawsuits brought by the families of two Rikers Island inmates who died while in custody at the jail complex, officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Prosecutors Outline Corruption Trial for Senator Skelos and His Son
abstract: In opening statements on Tuesday, the government told jurors that the pair engaged in “abuse of political power to satisfy personal greed,” while their attorneys said the charges amounted to legitimate politics.
lead_paragraph: A prosecutor told jurors on Tuesday in the federal corruption trial of State Senator Dean G. Skelos and his son that they would hear “the age-old tale of abuse of political power to satisfy personal greed,” while the pair’s lawyers suggested that the government was trying to criminalize both legitimate politics and a father-son relationship.

headline: Tempura Matsui
abstract: A Japanese kaiseki meal with a focus on fried food in Murray Hill.
lead_paragraph: A Japanese kaiseki meal with a focus on fried food in Murray Hill.

headline: Germany-Netherlands Match Canceled Over Security Concerns
abstract: The game was canceled less than two hours before kickoff, and the police chief in Hanover, Germany, said there was evidence of plans to detonate a device in the stadium.
lead_paragraph: Germany’s exhibition soccer match against the Netherlands was canceled less than two hours before kickoff on Tuesday, becoming the second marquee game called off in two days in increasingly edgy Europe.

headline: China Faces Sharp Questioning by U.N. Panel on Torture
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Torture', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: The pointed questions came as experts with the United Nations challenged China’s commitment to ending torture and governing by the rule of law.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — China faced robust questioning from United Nations human rights experts on Tuesday as it sought to defend its record on torture and to make the case that it had achieved important progress promoting human rights and with government based on the rule of law.

headline: At Tempura Matsui in Murray Hill, the Pleasures Lie Within
abstract: On the $200, 10-course, no-choice, two-hour-long menu, the diaphanously thin batter is only the beginning.
lead_paragraph: After looking over the menu at Tempura Matsui, the woman at the end of the counter made an announcement that would turn out to be catastrophic for her dinner plans.

headline: Univision Names a Chief Digital Officer
abstract: Isaac Lee, head of Univision’s Fusion unit, is taking on the new position, where he will also lead multicultural efforts and create a music strategy.
lead_paragraph: The Spanish-language broadcaster Univision Communications announced Tuesday that it had named Isaac Lee to the new position of chief digital officer.

headline: N.H.L. This Week: Kane and Rangers Aim to Keep Streaks Alive
abstract: Every Tuesday, The New York Times will look at the week ahead in the N.H.L., highlighting hot — or not so hot — teams and players.
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday, The New York Times will look at the week ahead in the N.H.L., highlighting hot — or not so hot — teams and players.

headline: Victims of VW Scandal May Be Eclipsed by Lawsuit Underwriters
abstract: Litigation financiers earn a good return funding lawsuits, but the benefits for victims are sometimes less clear.
lead_paragraph: The real victims of Volkswagen’s diesel-emissions scandal may end up being eclipsed in court.

headline: The Vile Politics of the Syrian Refugee Crisis [Updated]
keywords: ['Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Governors (US)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Letters', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'States (US)', 'Terrorism']
abstract: As hundreds of thousands flee Syria, a growing number of American politicians are responding with unspeakable cruelty.
lead_paragraph: Since 1975, the United States has resettled more than three million refugees. They have contributed to the economy and culture of all 50 states. As hundreds of thousands of Syrians have fled their war-ravaged homeland, a growing number of American politicians — including more than half of the nation’s governors — are responding with unspeakable cruelty.

headline: Greer Love Letter to Amis Sheds Light on Relationship
abstract: Margaret Simons, an academic and journalist at the University of Melbourne, found the 30,000-word letter in an archive of Ms. Greer’s works that the author sold to the university in 2013.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — An academic and journalist at the University of Melbourne has unearthed a book-length love letter from the feminist author Germaine Greer to the novelist Martin Amis.

headline: Gold-Tone Makeup Glitters for the Holidays
abstract: Products that include eye shadow, mascara, nail color and powders.
lead_paragraph: If there’s ever a time to gild the lily, the holiday season is it. No wonder that luxury makeup companies are unveiling a trove of gold products for nails, lips, eyes and the face. And while they are surely festive, most are not too extreme for day, in finishes that lean more toward a shimmery flourish than a bold statement.

headline: Art That Blurs the Line Between Painting and Sculpture
abstract: Anthony Pearson’s new exhibition finds the longtime abstract photographer working with a very different kind of medium: gypsum cement, poured into frames.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Pearson works in carving — perhaps one of the most ancient artistic mediums — but his practice puts heavy emphasis on new technologies. In his warehouse-sized studio in Los Angeles last month, ahead of his eponymous show opening this week at Marianne Boesky in New York, Pearson explained how he pours gypsum cement into a frame, strings the hardened material to a jig and cuts patterns into it with a carbide-tipped rug-cutting blade. Other times, he just slices at the smooth cement canvases with an angle grinder.

headline: Gawker to Retool as Politics Site
abstract: The website, which has covered New York and the media for more than a decade, is changing focus as part of a broad revamping at Gawker Media.
lead_paragraph: Gawker.com, a site that pioneered the knowing, irreverent tone that has come to define web journalism, will switch from covering New York and the media world, as it has done since its founding in 2003, to focus on politics.

headline: First Same-Sex Marriage Ceremony Held in Ireland
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'Referendums']
abstract: Two 35-year-old men were married in a ceremony that is official after Irish voters approved same-sex marriage in a referendum last May.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — Ireland’s first same-sex marriage ceremony was held Tuesday in County Tipperary after the new marriage legislation became official and after a historic referendum on the issue in May.

headline: Noël Wells on ‘Master of None’ and Her Plan B
abstract: After a dismaying break with “Saturday Night Live,” she has found a role to showcase her talents.
lead_paragraph: “Nobody gets into comedy because they feel like they’re cool and funny,” said Noël Wells, who was named class clown in her Texas kindergarten. “If they do, they’re megalomaniacs.”

headline: Israel Outlaws Islamist Group
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said on Tuesday that Israel has outlawed the northern faction of the Islamic Movement, blaming the group for contributing to a surge in violence in Jerusalem
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said on Tuesday that Israel has outlawed the northern faction of the Islamic Movement, blaming the group for contributing to a surge in violence in Jerusalem

headline: Richard Linklater’s ‘Everybody Wants Some’ Will Open SXSW Film Festival
keywords: ['Movies', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: The film about college baseball players is the director’s follow-up to “Boyhood.”
lead_paragraph: The latest work from a popular Austin filmmaker will open a popular Austin film festival. Richard Linklater’s comedy “Everybody Wants Some,” will be the opening-night film of the 23rd South by Southwest Film Conference and Festival, organizers announced Tuesday.

headline: Giulio Adriani Turns a Gas Station Into Service Station
abstract: A pizza master takes over a former Exxon Mobil spot on the Upper East Side; Mathew Glazier plans a West Village restaurant; Sushi Dojo replaces its executive chef; and more.
lead_paragraph: Service Station  The lubricant is now olive oil, not motor oil, at a former Exxon Mobil station that has been repurposed as a pizzeria, garage doors and all. Giulio Adriani, the consulting chef and a pizza master known for his fried montanara pie, is in charge of the domed oven that also turns out Neapolitan-style versions. Rounding out the menu are appetizers like arancini and fried calamari, and entrees that include lamb chops, skirt steak and lasagna. Bratislav Glisic, a consultant at Employees Only, has the same role here, and he’ll recommend a barrel-aged Negroni with the pizza, or a new-wave margarita with the margherita. “I’ve dreamed of pairing great pizza with great cocktails,” said Mr. Adriani, who added that he was planning to add more crunch to his Neapolitan pizza. The charcoal gray restaurant has a big bar, communal tables and a spacious terrace that may even be comfortable on a sunny day in late fall. (Opens Thursday): 500 East 62nd Street, 212-751-7860, servicestationnyc.com.

headline: Romanian Parliament Approves New Government
abstract: The new cabinet of Dacian Ciolos, nominated as prime minister in response to accusations of government corruption and inaction, includes ministers with experience at home, abroad and in business.
lead_paragraph: BUCHAREST, Romania — Romania’s Parliament on Tuesday approved the government of Dacian Ciolos, who was nominated to replace Victor Ponta as prime minister last week.

headline: YouTube Offers More From Merce Cunningham
abstract: The Merce Cunningham Trust’s YouTube page is one of the most engaging, accessible troves of his work.
lead_paragraph: When the Merce Cunningham Dance Company closed in 2011, two years after Cunningham’s death, people wondered how his dances would live on. A YouTube channel was not among the expected preservation modes, but today, the Merce Cunningham Trust’s YouTube page is one of the most engaging, accessible troves of his work, with nearly 100 (and counting) entries, from 60-second archival clips to 90-minute videos of company class.

headline: Ben Carson Is Struggling to Grasp Foreign Policy, Advisers Say
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The candidate’s remarks on the Middle East and national security have raised questions about his knowledge of the subject, and advisers say tutoring is having little effect.
lead_paragraph: Ben Carson’s remarks on foreign policy have repeatedly raised questions about his grasp of the subject, but never more seriously than in the past week, when he wrongly asserted that China had intervened militarily in Syria and then failed, on national television, to name the countries he would call on to form a coalition to fight the Islamic State.

headline: ‘Unforgettable,’ Apparently Forever
abstract: This crime show, which keeps finding ways to stay on the air, has a new home, A&E.
lead_paragraph: Plenty of decent television shows don’t survive for one reason or another — bad time slot, wrong network, lackluster promotional effort. It’s too bad more of them don’t have the resilience of “Unforgettable,” a good crime show that keeps finding ways to stay on the air. For its fourth season, which begins Friday, Nov. 27, that has meant moving to a new network, A&E.

headline: John Kasich Urges Obama to Not Accept Syrian Refugees, For Now
keywords: ['Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Gov. John Kasich conceded that while Ohio did not have the authority to reject Syrian refugees, he urged President Obama to stop accepting them until the United States can ensure that terrorists are not coming in, too.
lead_paragraph: Gov. John Kasich of Ohio conceded Tuesday that he did not have the power to block the flow of Syrian refugees into his state, but he still urged President Obama to stop accepting them until the United States can ensure that terrorists are not making their way into the country.

headline: At Carnegie Hall, Students Share Varied Sounds
abstract: Programs are coming up from the New York Youth Symphony and the Juilliard Orchestra.
lead_paragraph: Two student orchestras, featuring young players at very different stages of development, will appear this week at Carnegie Hall.

headline: Israel Outlaws Northern Branch of Islamic Movement
abstract: In an effort to quell a recent wave of violence, the Israeli security cabinet said it had outlawed the northern branch of the group, accusing it of collaborating with Hamas.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Israeli security cabinet announced on Tuesday that it had outlawed the northern branch of the Islamic Movement in Israel, accusing it of collaborating with Hamas, the Islamic militant group that controls Gaza.

headline: Electing to Ignore the Poorest of the Poor
keywords: ['Poverty', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Income Inequality', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Selective government assistance programs have left behind the persistently poor, an issue that has not been addressed in the presidential election season.
lead_paragraph: The first few primary debates of the presidential election season are in. We can see where the economic policy discussion is going.

headline: Perfectly Reasonable Question: ‘Trending’
abstract: How is trending different from all the other readership measurements?
lead_paragraph: A Times reader, Janet Kriseman of Cape Town, South Africa, has noticed a new feature attached to the online version of some stories: a list called “Trending.” And she’s puzzled by it. She wrote:

headline: Who Wrote ‘The Diary of Anne Frank’?
keywords: ['Art', 'Biographical Information', 'Books and Literature', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Diaries', 'Law and Legislation', 'Royalties', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: A move to add Otto Frank as the book’s co-author raises broader questions about copyright protections.
lead_paragraph: Copyright law is meant to give authors and their heirs a temporary monopoly over books, songs and other creative works. In practice, however, such monopolies can last indefinitely. The latest example of this phenomenon comes from the Swiss foundation that owns the rights to “The Diary of Anne Frank.”

headline: Xian Zhang Is New Jersey Symphony’s New Music Director
abstract: Ms. Zhang, who was once an associate conductor at the New York Philharmonic, is returning to the region.
lead_paragraph: The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra’s next music director will be familiar to some concertgoers in the region: The orchestra announced on Monday that the role would be filled by Xian Zhang, a rising Chinese-American star who was an associate conductor at the New York Philharmonic for several years before concentrating her recent career in Europe.

headline: Air Liquide to Acquire Airgas for $10.3 Billion
abstract: The deal will expand the Paris-based industrial gas company’s presence in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The French industrial gas company Air Liquide said on Tuesday that it had agreed to buy Airgas for $10.3 billion in a deal that would swell the company’s presence in the United States.

headline: Tribute to Lennon at Symphony Space Endures in 35th Year
abstract: Joe Raiola, now an editor at Mad magazine, founded Theater Within’s John Lennon Tribute, and its 35th annual celebration will be Dec. 4 in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Tuned to “Monday Night Football” on his transistor radio, Joe Raiola nearly wrecked his taxi on Queens Boulevard when he heard the somber news on Dec. 8, 1980: John Lennon had been shot and killed that evening outside his home in Manhattan.

headline: In Berlin, a Space for Design Experiments
abstract: Bocci has moved past its humble 2005 beginnings in a red Canadian barn and leased a 22,000-square-foot derelict courthouse in the Charlottenburg district.
lead_paragraph: In 2005, the Canadian architect Omer Arbel and his business partner Randy Bishop launched Bocci, a contemporary design and manufacturing company, out of a red barn surrounded by hayfields and farms in White Rock, British Columbia. Now based in Vancouver, Bocci has become known for its ethereal lighting products and large-scale installations. And it’s just opened an exhibition space and satellite fabrication laboratory in Berlin.

headline: Whooping Cough in Infants Tied to Epilepsy Risk
abstract: Whooping cough is associated with an increased risk for childhood epilepsy, a new study has found. The findings underscore the importance of pertussis vaccination in infants.
lead_paragraph: Whooping cough in infancy is associated with an increased risk for epilepsy, a new study has found. The findings underscore the importance of vaccination for whooping cough, also known as pertussis, in childhood.

lead_paragraph: When it comes to Saddam Hussein, Senator Bernie Sanders appears to have learned a lesson from another Democratic presidential candidate from Vermont: former Gov. Howard Dean.

headline: American Airlines Revises Its Rewards Program
keywords: ['Frequent Flier Programs', 'Travel and Vacations', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: Changes in American Airlines’ AAdvantage loyalty program will connect points to dollars spent, not miles flown.
lead_paragraph: It’s not how far you fly, it’s how much you spend, that may determine how many frequent flier points you’ll get under American Airlines’ new AAdvantage loyalty program next year.

headline: Engineer Accused of Failing to Assess Manhattan Building Where Falling Debris Killed Girl
abstract: Maqsood Faruqi was arrested after investigators found he did not follow the required inspection protocols, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Six months after a terra cotta windowsill crumbled and fell some eight stories, fatally striking 2-year-old girl on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, investigators announced on Tuesday that they had found a trail of problems with the building’s facade and that the engineer who was hired to inspect the facade did not follow the required protocols in his assessment.

headline: French President Says Way of Life Intact
abstract: President François Hollande, speaking on Tuesday, said the French way of life would not be interrupted by the “barbarity of terrorism.”
lead_paragraph: President François Hollande, speaking on Tuesday, said the French way of life would not be interrupted by the “barbarity of terrorism.”

headline: Bill Clinton to Appear for ‘Super PAC’ Backing Hillary Clinton
abstract: Bill Clinton will appear at a meeting next month with prospective donors to Priorities USA Action, the “super PAC” that is supporting his wife’s presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Former President Bill Clinton will appear as the main attraction at a meeting on Dec. 1 with prospective donors to Priorities USA Action, the “super PAC” that is supporting his wife’s presidential campaign — the first such event he will do for the group.

headline: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: Pumpkin Ravioli With Sage Walnut Pumpkin Butter
abstract: Pumpkin ravioli is easy to make and can be frozen and reheated on Thanksgiving day.
lead_paragraph: Over the last seven years of collecting new vegetarian Thanksgiving recipes on Well, we have learned that inviting a vegetarian or vegan to your holiday table creates more opportunity than challenge. Readers have seen that by making flavorful vegetarian and vegan dishes, they end up enhancing everyone’s meal.

headline: Review: In ‘SPQR: A History of Ancient Rome,’ Mary Beard Tackles Myths and More
abstract: In this book, Ms. Beard examines a thousand years in the early history of a city and an empire.
lead_paragraph: Mary Beard is well known in England, so much so that when the magazine The Oldie — that country’s vastly more sophisticated version of our AARP magazine — named her its 2013 pinup of the year, no one had to ask: Who?

headline: Explaining Terror to Children
abstract: Why a French newspaper for kids refuses to sugarcoat the horror of the Paris attacks.
lead_paragraph: Why a French newspaper for kids refuses to sugarcoat the horror of the Paris attacks.

headline: How to Talk to Children About Terrorism
keywords: ['Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Children and Childhood', 'Terrorism', 'News and News Media']
abstract: In Paris, we’ve all been struggling with what to say.
lead_paragraph: Paris — THE day after the terrorist attacks in Paris was one my children won’t soon forget: They got to watch kids’ television all day long.

headline: How to Fight ISIS
keywords: ['Editorials', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)']
abstract: Military action can be only part of a broader strategy that is joined by many countries and carried out over years.
lead_paragraph: The mass murder of civilians in Paris has inevitably reignited the debate over using military force in the Middle East to attack the Islamic State. The debate, like anything that gets tangled up in American presidential politics, is divorced from reality. The United States, and other nations, is already engaged in military action with some ground forces in Iraq and Syria.

headline: What We’re Reading: Special Edition
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads about the Islamic State from Neil MacFarquhar, Alissa J. Rubin and others.
