headline: Review: ‘Abyss’ Follows Characters Named ‘He,’ ‘She’ and ‘I’ in Love and War
abstract: The German playwright Maria Milisavljevic considers topical questions of European national identities in this play, at Theaterlab.
lead_paragraph: When the cast list for a play identifies its characters only by pronouns, it might as well have a warning sticker attached, reading, “Whimsy alert: severe artiness ahead.” These days, surely only dramatists of Edward Albee’s generation, which came of age in the absurdist shadows of Ionesco and Pirandello, can be forgiven such universal nomenclature, and even they can irritate in that regard.

headline: Marine Le Pen’s Anti-Islam Message Gains Influence in France
keywords: ['Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Terrorism', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: The leader of France’s far-right National Front party has pushed the main center-right party toward a stronger anti-immigrant stance after Friday’s attacks.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Well before the attacks that killed 129 people in Paris on Friday, Marine Le Pen, the president of the far-right National Front party, was parlaying fear of Islam, migrants and open borders into political support. Now, with France angry and in mourning, she is seizing the opportunity to expand her appeal and show her clout, underscoring how far-right messages are resonating across Europe.

headline: A Tour of Fortuny
abstract: The century-old design house welcomes T onto its grounds in Venice.
lead_paragraph: The century-old design house welcomes T onto its grounds in Venice.

headline: Inside a Century-Old Venetian Design House
abstract: Fortuny opens its gardens and showroom, situated on the Guidecca, to T.

headline: Manhattan Psychic Admits Taking Over $550,000 From Lovelorn Client
abstract: Pricilla Kelly Delmaro, who promised she could reunite a man with his dead ex-girlfriend, pleaded guilty to grand larceny and will be sentenced to four years of probation.
lead_paragraph: A Manhattan psychic admitted taking more than $550,000 from a customer whom she promised to reunite with a dead woman, in pleading guilty to grand larceny on Tuesday.

headline: James Welling, Now in Technicolor
abstract: “Choreograph,” coming soon to David Zwirner, presents a different way of deconstructing color.
lead_paragraph: In the past three decades, the postmodern artist James Welling has “made abstract photographs, more normative pictures and experimented with different processes,” he says. “But for the last 10 years, I’ve been very interested in thinking about color.” He captured Philip Johnson’s Glass House in the late aughts through a set of colored filters and he digitally altered his 2009 pictures of Paris’s Maison de Verre. However, with “Choreograph,” on display starting tomorrow at David Zwirner, Welling has developed a more physical way of deconstructing color: feeding three black-and-white images into Photoshop’s red, green and blue color channels, and dragging the “adjustment” sliders until he creates one serendipitous, psychedelic composition.

headline: James Welling’s “Choreograph”
abstract: The photographer’s latest show to experiment with color opens tomorrow at David Zwirner.
lead_paragraph: The photographer’s latest show to experiment with color opens tomorrow at David Zwirner.

headline: Let’s Kick ‘Boots on the Ground’ to the Curb
keywords: ['Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Debates (Political)', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Shoes and Boots', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The term lets politicians distance themselves from the fact that they’re calling for sending young Americans into battle.
lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of the Paris terror attacks, “boots on the ground,” Vietnam-era shorthand for ground troops, has become the rhetorical equivalent of camouflage fashion. Tossing out the term gives politicians a battle-toughened air, while distancing them from the fact that they’re calling for the United States to send young Americans into battle.

headline: Review: Leif Ove Andsnes Gives a Thoughtful Recital at Carnegie Hall
abstract: This Norwegian pianist opened with a selection of seldom-heard Sibelius pieces, then moved on to Beethoven, Debussy and Chopin.
lead_paragraph: Putting together a thoughtfully varied recital program can be as difficult as playing your chosen pieces beautifully. The Norwegian pianist Leif Ove Andsnes demonstrated how to pull off both feats in his superb recital on Monday evening at Carnegie Hall.

headline: Grimes, a D.I.Y. Indie Sensation, Ramps Up Her Sound
abstract: Mining pop past and present with her fourth album, “Art Angels,” this Canadian artist, a.k.a. Claire Boucher is demanding to play in the big leagues.
lead_paragraph: If Grimes is selling out, more musicians should do it her way.

headline: Review: ‘Democrats,’ Chronicling Politics in Zimbabwe
abstract: This documentary from Camilla Nielsson looks at recent efforts to put a constitution into place in that country.
lead_paragraph: “To be called a sellout in Zimbabwe is to be condemned to death.” This observation delivered with a dry, matter-of-fact tone comes late in the director Camilla Nielsson’s outstanding, unsettling documentary “Democrats,” a film that chronicles recent efforts to put a constitution into place in that country.

headline: Chris Stapleton Rides His Own Country Music Wave
abstract: At the end of his tour, Mr. Stapleton reflected on his No. 1 album and his career night at the Country Music Association Awards.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A few minutes before showtime on Monday night, there was a hubbub outside Chris Stapleton’s tour bus, parked just around the corner from the El Rey Theater here. A few people jumped off and began to make their way to the entrance. One of them fixed his attention on a mannequin in a store window, loudly encouraging his friends to look.

headline: Review: ‘A Journey Through Time With Anthony’ Adapts a Chinese Young-Adult Novel
abstract: This light feature, in Mandarin with English subtitles, chronicles a college student’s adventures in life and love.
lead_paragraph: The harmless confection “A Journey Through Time With Anthony,” an adaptation of a popular young-adult novel in China by Ma Liang (under the pseudonym Anthony), offers mild youthful rebellion and even milder youthful ardor.

headline: Canadian Pacific Takes Its Merger Bid to Norfolk Southern
abstract: Though Canadian Pacific said it offered a “sizable premium in cash and stock,” Norfolk Southern called it an “unsolicited” and “low-premium” offer.
lead_paragraph: Canadian Pacific said on Tuesday that it had sent an offer letter to the Norfolk Southern Corporation, proposing a merger that would reshape the North American rail industry.

headline: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing: Paris, Charlie Sheen, Refugees
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day, including updates on the Paris attacks.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: France Steps Up Airstrikes in Syria
abstract: France is using multiple airstrikes to fight back against the Islamic State, or Daesh, which claimed responsibility for the attacks in Paris.
lead_paragraph: France is using multiple airstrikes to fight back against the Islamic State, or Daesh, which claimed responsibility for the attacks in Paris.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
keywords: ['Real Estate Brokers', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York City.
lead_paragraph: RECENT SALE

headline: Review: Juilliard415 Plays Haydn and Telemann, Evoking the Sun’s Arc
abstract: The period-instrument ensemble juxtaposed Haydn’s Symphony No. 6 (“Morning”) and Telemann’s “The Times of Day” at Alice Tully Hall.
lead_paragraph: The sun rose twice on Monday evening during Juilliard415’s concert at Alice Tully Hall: first in Haydn’s Symphony No. 6 (“Morning,” 1761), then in Telemann’s cantata “Die Tageszeiten” (“The Times of Day,” 1757). This was a fascinating juxtaposition of works finished only four years apart and similar in means and expression, by composers generally taken to represent distinct eras (Haydn the Classical, Telemann the Baroque).

headline: Review: ‘Pike St.,’ Where One Woman Speaks for All
abstract: In her new solo play, at the Abrons Arts Center, Nilaja Sun depicts a struggling Lower East Side family, as well as various friends and neighbors.
lead_paragraph: Evelyn, the principal character in Nilaja Sun’s terrific new solo show, “Pike St.,” had her hands full even before news came of the hurricane bearing down on New York. Her 15-year-old daughter, Candi, is severely disabled and needs constant care. Four years ago, Candi had an aneurysm — or some similar catastrophic brain malfunction — and now she can barely speak and cannot feed herself. She also requires a respirator.

headline: New Yorker Staffers (and Their Boss, David Remnick) Just Want to Rock
abstract: The Sequoias, a band of (tall) literary rockers, including David Remnick, channel their 15-year-old selves.
lead_paragraph: “We’re the Sequoias. We’re going to play some songs from the book,” John Seabrook announced from the stage at Bowery Electric in Lower Manhattan last Friday night. The band’s set list, he added, would consist of “Britney Spears, Katy Perry, that kind of stuff.”

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day, including updates on the Paris attacks..
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day, including updates on the Paris attacks..

headline: A Haunting Film Explores the Perilous Interface Between Tigers and People in the Sundarbans
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Movies', 'Poaching (Wildlife)', 'Tigers', 'Wildlife Sanctuaries and Nature Reserves']
abstract: In the Sundarbans of India and Bangladesh, where tigers threaten people and vice versa, a film charts the uncertain journey of a passionate conservationist.
lead_paragraph: Deep in the Sundarbans, a vast mangrove maze where the Ganges and two other great rivers weave their way to the coast in India and Bangladesh, the big-cat conservationist Alan Rabinowitz plays a video clip on his laptop for a cluster of men and women in an impoverished village where tigers — in one of their last big refuges — regularly kill or maim people scouring the shorelines for meager hauls of fish and crabs.

headline: Is This the Most Influential Hairstylist in the World?
abstract: As Jen Atkin styles celebrities like the Kardashians, millions follow her, and her empire grows.
lead_paragraph: The fall months should have been a bonanza for beauty trends as global fashion weeks set the aesthetic of the season in dramatic runway gestures. But arguably the most influential hair arbiter of our time was nowhere near the fog of hair spray that clouds the backstage areas.

headline: End Sought to Fantasy Sites in New York; Yahoo Is Said to Be Added to Inquiry
abstract: The New York attorney general sought an injunction to keep DraftKings and FanDuel from operating there and was said to have expanded his investigation to other companies operating daily fantasy sites.
lead_paragraph: The New York State attorney general has expanded his investigation into daily fantasy sport sites, with measures including the issuance of a subpoena to the online media company Yahoo, according to a person familiar with the inquiry.

headline: Jeb Bush Urges Caution on Accepting Syrian Refugees
keywords: ['Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Mr. Bush said that he supported a call by Speaker Paul D. Ryan to suspend a program to accept Syrian refugees, and that he also respected the right of governors to try to block refugees from coming into their states.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, S.C. — On a swing through South Carolina on Tuesday, Jeb Bush waded into the debate over Syrian refugees that is roiling the nation after the terror attacks in Paris, saying he would take a cautious approach to accepting any refugees into the country.

headline: Storm System Batters Colorado and Texas
abstract: A winter storm brought more than 100 flights to a standstill in Denver, while parts of the central and southern Plains recovered from power failures and tornadoes.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — A winter storm brought more than 100 flights to a standstill in Denver as it moved through eastern Colorado on Tuesday, while parts of the central and southern Plains recovered from power failures and a series of tornadoes.

headline: Bobby Jindal Quits Republican Presidential Race
abstract: “This is not my time,” said the governor of Louisiana, who had never risen high enough in the polls to appear in the prime-time debates.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana, a onetime rising Republican star whose popularity has plummeted in his own state, dropped out of the presidential race on Tuesday, conceding that he was unable to find any traction.

headline: Estefan and ‘La Bamba’ Cover Only Part of America’s Latin Culture in the 1980s
abstract: The Estefans’ musical “On Your Feet!” and the HBO documentary “The Latin Explosion” overlook what else was going on with Latinos in pop at the time.
lead_paragraph: My favorite sound to come out of the Miami Sound Machine goes something like this: Hhhwoo! That happens toward the end of the chorus for “Rhythm Is Gonna Get You,” which kicked off the second side of the band’s album “Let It Loose.” It was 1987, and most of us had to flip something over — an LP, a cassette — to hear it. The song stalked summer radio back then.

headline: Full Results of The New York Times/Siena College Poll
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio's overall approval rating is at 44 percent, down from 52 percent last December.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio's overall approval rating is at 44 percent, down from 52 percent last December.

headline: France-England Game Is a Friendly in Every Sense of the Word
abstract: The exhibition in London, four days after terrorist attacks shook Paris, was a game that meant nothing, but on this night, nothing felt like everything.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — One of the great joys in soccer is its vocabulary. Only in soccer are there dummies and extra time and backheels. Only in soccer are there offside traps and toe pokes. Depending on what country you’re in, there may also be gaffers (managers) or howlers (embarrassing errors) or fixtures (games).

headline: Strikes on Raqqa in Syria Lead to More Questions Than Results
abstract: The strategy is renewing a debate about how effective such attacks can be in defeating the Islamic State, without measures like drying up its financial support or conducting a ground assault.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — First France and then Russia answered Islamic State attacks on their citizens with a strategy of direct reprisal: intensified airstrike campaigns on Raqqa, the militants’ de facto capital within Syria, meant to eliminate the group’s leadership and resources.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Has Lost Support of White New Yorkers, Poll Finds
abstract: Nearly half say that the city is a worse place to live under the mayor’s watch, and 51 percent say New York is now less safe, even as crime statistics reach historic lows.
lead_paragraph: Nearing the midpoint of his term, Mayor Bill de Blasio is confronting a city that is deeply divided about his ability to lead, with his efforts to create a more liberal New York overshadowed by growing worries about homelessness and crime, a new poll finds.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
abstract: A look at the methodology and sampling error of a New York Times/Siena College survey about quality of life in New York City’s five boroughs.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times/Siena College Poll of New York City residents consisted of telephone interviews with 1,961 adults throughout the city, conducted between Oct. 29 and Nov. 11.

headline: A Conversation With David S. Winter
abstract: Mr. Winter is a founder and co-chief executive of Winter Properties, the real estate arm of 40 North Management, a diversified investment company based in New York.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Winter, 38, is a founder and co-chief executive of Winter Properties, the real estate arm of 40 North Management, a diversified investment company based in New York. Winter Properties, formed in 2014, is an outgrowth of the Winter Organization, which was started in the early 1900s by Mr. Winter’s great-grandfather Benjamin Winter Sr.

headline: Senate Votes to Block Obama’s Climate Change Rules
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Air Pollution', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The resolution, aimed at E.P.A. rules on coal-fired power plants, might make it harder for the president to negotiate a climate change accord in Paris in two weeks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate voted on Tuesday to block President Obama’s tough new climate change regulations, hoping to undermine his negotiating authority before a major international climate summit meeting in Paris this month.

headline: Drone Maker DJI Adds Technology to Limit Where Its Machines Can Fly
abstract: DJI, a maker of small-scale drones, is adding so-called geofencing technology that would prevent the aerial devices from going into certain areas, like the skies over a forest fire.
lead_paragraph: Maybe drone makers can ease some of the pressure on themselves by building limits on their own machines.

headline: John Cook’s Memo to Gawker’s Staff
abstract: Mr. Cook, the executive editor of Gawker Media, describes the company’s plans to refashion Gawker.com into a politics website.
lead_paragraph: Gawker.com has covered the news and gossip of Manhattan and the media world since the site started in 2003. On Tuesday, the site’s founder, Nick Denton, announced that it was changing its focus to politics. In a memo to the staff, John Cook, the executive editor of the site’s parent company, Gawker Media, laid out what that shift in focus would entail:

headline: Nick Denton’s Memo to Gawker’s Staff
abstract: Mr. Denton, Gawker’s founder, outlines his ambitions for Gawker Media.
lead_paragraph: Gawker.com has covered the news and gossip of Manhattan and the media world since the site started in 2003. On Tuesday, the website’s founder, Nick Denton, announced that it was changing its focus to politics. He outlined the changes to Gawker.com and its parent company, Gawker Media, in a memo to the staff:

headline: Veronique Hakim Is Named President of New York City Transit
abstract: Ms. Hakim, currently the executive director of New Jersey Transit, will start her new role in December. She will lead the agency that operates the city’s bus and subway service.
lead_paragraph: Veronique Hakim, the head of New Jersey Transit, is leaving the agency to lead New York City Transit as the subway system struggles with chronic delays brought on by booming ridership and aging infrastructure.

headline: Kentucky and Duke Are Looking More Alike All the Time
abstract: John Calipari and Mike Krzyzewski may possess varied temperaments, and their fans may nurse grudges, but their programs provide about as much of a contrast as their respective shades of blue.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — As Kentucky hurtled toward an unprecedented 40-0 record last March while Duke less loudly entered the Final Four, the tournament conversation was dominated by a perceived clash between the programs and between their head coaches — national championship-winning, generational talents who are now both in the basketball Hall of Fame.

headline: Promoting Environmental Awareness Among Practicing Hindus
abstract: Sadhana, an organization based in New York, cleans Jamaica Bay beaches of flotsam resulting from a religious ritual.
lead_paragraph: On an overcast morning this month, a dozen or so people, most of them Hindus, gathered in a circle on the shore of Jamaica Bay and bowed their heads as a priest invoked the deities.

headline: Makers of Nutritional Supplements Charged in Federal Sweep
abstract: A yearlong federal investigation into the dietary supplement industry has resulted in a crackdown on more than 100 companies accused of selling tainted or misleading products.
lead_paragraph: A yearlong federal investigation into the dietary supplement industry has resulted in a widespread crackdown on the sale of tainted or misleading products.

headline: Songs From Coming Adele Album Appear to Be Leaked Online
abstract: Snippets of what appeared to be songs from Adele’s new album, “25,” were leaked online on Tuesday, just three days before the album’s scheduled release.
lead_paragraph: Three days before the release of Adele’s highly anticipated new album, “25,” brief snippets of what appeared to be songs from the album were leaked online, although where they came from was unclear.

headline: A Black History Museum Introduces Itself on the National Mall
abstract: The National Museum of African American History and Culture in Washington kicked off a countdown to its opening with three days of festivities.
lead_paragraph: A new Smithsonian museum dedicated to telling the history of African-Americans lit up the National Mall on Monday night as historical images related to the Civil War, the abolition of slavery and the passage of the Voting Rights Act were projected onto the facade of the five-story building. Called the National Museum of African American History and Culture, it is slated to open next fall.

headline: Review: ‘Captive Audience,’ Seven Plays by David Ives by New York Deaf Theater
abstract: This production features a cast of four deaf and four hearing actors, using both spoken English and American Sign Language.
lead_paragraph: There’s little middle ground in “Captive Audience,” a collection of short works by David Ives: Each play here either sinks onstage or is wonderful to watch. Though, to the credit of the cast, even the pieces that wane don’t lack for trying.

headline: Lyft Said to Seek $500 Million in Funding
keywords: ['Venture Capital', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Mobile Applications', 'Start-ups']
abstract: The ride-hailing start-up is seeking a valuation of about $4 billion, say people briefed on the fund-raising round.
lead_paragraph: Even as questions swirl over the fund-raising environment for hot young start-ups, the ride-hailing sector is barreling into new funding talks at top speed.

headline: Large Banks Postpone Debt Sale as Investor Appetite for Riskier Loans Wanes
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Lenders involved in the financing of a large leveraged buyout, including Bank of America Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley, have decided to delay selling the debt in the face of investor caution.
lead_paragraph: Although the biggest leveraged buyout of the year is still set to be completed on time, some of the banks involved in the financing have postponed plans to sell several billion dollars’ worth of debt meant to support the transaction, people briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

headline: Amherst Mascot Gets Thumbs Down From Faculty
keywords: ['Mascots', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Native Americans']
abstract: In a nonbinding vote that will be presented to the board of trustees next year, faculty members decided unanimously that Lord Jeff should no longer serve as the school’s unofficial mascot.
lead_paragraph: Lord Jeff, Amherst College’s unofficial mascot, tarnished by his dealings with Native Americans more than 200 years ago, has become the latest casualty of the protest movement against racial insensitivity on college campuses.

headline: Mass Surveillance Isn’t the Answer to Fighting Terrorism
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Indiscriminate bulk data sweeps have not been useful, yet intelligence officials complain that restrictions impede their efforts.
lead_paragraph: It’s a wretched yet predictable ritual after each new terrorist attack: Certain politicians and government officials waste no time exploiting the tragedy for their own ends. The remarks on Monday by John Brennan, the director of the Central Intelligence Agency, took that to a new and disgraceful low.

headline: Minnesota: Man Shot by Police Dies
abstract: The police said that Jamar Clark was an assault suspect, and that he was shot after interfering with paramedics trying to treat his victim and fighting with two officers.
lead_paragraph: An unarmed black man shot Sunday by the Minneapolis police died on Monday evening, state investigators said. The police said that the man, Jamar Clark, 24, was an assault suspect, and that he had been shot after interfering with paramedics trying to treat his victim and fighting with two officers. The police disputed witness accounts that said Mr. Clark was handcuffed when he was shot. Though no police camera footage captured the episode, other cameras showed parts of the encounter, said Superintendent Drew Evans of the Minnesota Bureau of Criminal Apprehension, which is investigating the case. Protesters have demanded the release of video evidence and the names of the officers. Mayor Betsy Hodges has requested a federal civil rights investigation.

headline: Spike Seen in Reported Cases of Sexually Transmitted Diseases
abstract: Syphilis, gonorrhea and chlamydia are rising at alarming rates, according to figures released by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
lead_paragraph: Syphilis, gonorrhea and chlamydia are rising at alarming rates, according to figures released Tuesday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Syphilis infections reported by doctors rose 15 percent from 2013 to 2014; cases of gonorrhea increased 5 percent, and chlamydia 3 percent. The agency called the diseases “a substantial health challenge.” Syphilis cases have more than tripled since 2000, and 91 percent are in men — mostly gay and bisexual men. Dr. Gail Bolan, the agency’s director of prevention of sexually transmitted disease, said there was “no single answer” for the increase, but noted several factors. State and local spending on prevention and treatment has shrunk as screening of gay men has picked up. Many gay men start antiretroviral drugs as soon as they are infected with H.I.V., and others take Truvada to prevent infection; there have been reports that condom use has dropped in this population as a result. Although those drugs prevent H.I.V. infection and transmission, they do not prevent the spread of syphilis, gonorrhea, chlamydia, human papilloma virus, herpes or trichomoniasis.

headline: Timeline of Bobby Jindal’s Presidential Campaign
abstract: Once billed as a rising Republican star, Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana had his 2016 presidential bid fail to make it out of 2015, plagued by a flat message and flagging poll numbers.
lead_paragraph: Once billed as a rising star in the Republican Party, Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana had his 2016 presidential bid fail to make it out of 2015 as a flat message and flagging poll numbers plagued his campaign. Mr. Jindal remained fiery on stump until the end, but his conservative message did not resonate in this cycle’s crowded field.

headline: Cubs’ Joe Maddon and Rangers’ Jeff Banister Win Manager Awards
abstract: Maddon, who guided his young team to 97 wins, received 18 of 30 first-place votes in the National League. Banister, who led another remarkable turnaround, won in the American League.
lead_paragraph: As National League finalists appeared on MLB Network for the Manager of the Year Award announcement on Tuesday night, Chicago Cubs Manager Joe Maddon looked on comfortably from an Italian restaurant in Tampa, Fla. His gray hair swept across his head like a wave. He had his sleeves rolled up, his shirt splayed open, a silver chain sticking out.

headline: Boko Haram Is Suspected After Explosion in Nigeria Kills 32
abstract: The blast occurred in the city of Yola on Tuesday night at a market filled with shoppers stocking up on fruit and vegetables for dinner.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — A blast in the northeastern Nigerian city of Yola on Tuesday night tore through a marketplace, killing 32 people and wounding 80 others, according to the local authorities and witnesses.

headline: Jury Gets Case Against Ex-Chief of West Virginia Coal Mine on Safety
abstract: Attorneys for former Massey Energy chief executive, Donald L. Blankenship, said he should not be held responsible for the mine’s many citations, after an explosion killed 29 men.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, W.Va. — More than five years after a powerful explosion ravaged the Upper Big Branch mine and killed 29 men, a federal jury on Tuesday began considering whether the former chief executive of Massey Energy Company could be held criminally responsible for a corporate culture that prosecutors said pursued profits more than safety and integrity.

headline: Out of a Shelter, a Single Mother Studies to Be a Paramedic
abstract: Shareda Waldron, despite steady employment, landed in a homeless shelter with her young son until a housing agency stepped in.
lead_paragraph: Shareda Waldron has a five-year plan. She wants a home in New Jersey, a car and to be a paramedic for the New York Fire Department.

headline: Government to Expand Program to Forgive Student Loan Debt
abstract: Thousands more students who attended programs of Corinthian College, once one of the nation’s largest for-profit education companies, will now be included.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Education announced Tuesday that it would expand its program to forgive federal student loan debt to thousands more students who attended programs of Corinthian Colleges, once one of the nation’s largest for-profit education companies.

headline: A Martha Stewart Store Makes a Leap to Amazon
abstract: American Made, a venture introduced in 2013, was intended to be eBay’s answer to Etsy, the pioneer in the online handmade goods market.
lead_paragraph: Martha Stewart has ditched eBay, taking her American Made store to Amazon’s Handmade marketplace, as the e-commerce giant flexes its muscle in the burgeoning online market for handcrafted goods.

headline: Letter Directing Indiana Organization to Send Syrians Elsewhere
abstract: A letter from an Indiana state agency requesting that the refugee resettlement look to other states to place incoming Syrians.
lead_paragraph: A letter from an Indiana state agency requesting that the refugee resettlement look to other states to place incoming Syrians.

headline: 11th-Hour Detour Puts Family in Connecticut as Indiana Bars Syrian Refugees
abstract: Republican governors and presidential candidates have singled out Syrian refugees as a security risk after one suspect killed in the Paris attacks was found with a Syrian passport.
lead_paragraph: A Syrian refugee family, after waiting for three years in Jordan to be approved to come to the United States, was finally set to land in Indianapolis on Wednesday.

headline: A Manhattan Hardware Store Welcomes Refugees as Governors Vow to Shut Them Out
abstract: Chris Christie of New Jersey and at least 25 other governors have said they do not want Syrian refugees to come to their states; for decades, Wankel’s has hired people fleeing violence and persecution.
lead_paragraph: Chris Christie of New Jersey and at least 25 other governors have said they do not want Syrian refugees to come to their states.

headline: Maryland Campus Closed as Police Continue Search
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks']
abstract: The police issued a warrant for a Washington College student on gun charges stemming from an earlier incident on campus, as the search for him continued in Maryland and Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: CHESTERTOWN, Md. — On the second day of a two-state manhunt for a student believed to be carrying a rifle, the college he attended shut down Tuesday, as officials described the student as being despondent after getting into trouble for drunkenly brandishing a gun on campus last month.

headline: Red Sox’ David Ortiz Is Suited for a Send-Off
abstract: Although there was no formal announcement, Ken Rosenthal reported that 2016 would be Ortiz’s last season. His status in the game might leave him no choice but to have a farewell tour.
lead_paragraph: As the final month of his final season played out, Paul Konerko relished the peaceful ending to his proud career. There was enough hoopla out of the public view, anyway, and he did not want the parting gifts and ceremonies bestowed on other stars.

headline: French Return to Cafes in a Show of Defiance
abstract: The most typical of Parisian scenes — sharing drinks among friends — became a show of defiance after the terrorist attacks.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — At 6 p.m. sharp on Tuesday, Mickel Dagdalar and Maxence Lezeau squeezed behind a tiny bistro table at Le Baromètre, a casual neighborhood hangout on the Boulevard Voltaire. They each lit a cigarette and began sipping at glasses of beer, as the crowd around them swelled.

headline: An ISIS Militant From Belgium Whose Own Family Wanted Him Dead
abstract: The family of Abdelhamid Abaaoud, who is believed to have organized the attacks on Paris, hoped he had died fighting for the Islamic State in Syria.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — When the family of Abdelhamid Abaaoud received word from Syria last fall that he had been killed fighting for the Islamic State, it rejoiced at what it took to be excellent news about a wayward son it had come to despise.

headline: Rick Nash Knows the Score: Rangers Pay Him to Do More
abstract: With the Rangers on a nine-game winning streak, Nash said he was happy with his game, but he has scored only two goals while playing 16 of the team’s 18 games.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The Rangers occasionally call on Rick Nash to kill penalties, and he is pretty good at using his long arms and stick to knock pucks the other way for the third-best unit in the N.H.L.

headline: New York State Accuses Utica School District of Bias Against Refugees
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Discrimination', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman said in a lawsuit that the city diverted immigrants over 16 and unsteady in English into alternative programs in which they could not earn diplomas.
lead_paragraph: For years, the authorities say, administrators for an upstate New York high school turned away refugee children because of their age and their unsteady English while covering up discriminatory enrollment policies.

headline: How to Beat ISIS: Use Arab Armies to Fight the Group
abstract: J.M. Berger, a co-author of “ISIS: The State of Terror,” says regional powers, not Western ones, should lead the way.
lead_paragraph: The following excerpts are from an interview about how to defeat the Islamic State with J.M. Berger, a scholar at the Brookings Institution and a co-author of “ISIS: The State of Terror.”

headline: Watching the Attacks, With Two Daughters
abstract: When violence strikes outside a family's dinner in Paris, a mother is torn between leaving to assist victims and consoling her daughters.
lead_paragraph: When violence strikes outside a family's dinner in Paris, a mother is torn between leaving to assist victims and consoling her daughters.

headline: It’s Superman!
abstract: Zachary Spitz makes an exclamatory New York Times debut.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — It’s a bird! It’s a plane! It’s … a puzzle debut!

headline: College Football Playoff Committee Keeps Top Teams in Place
abstract: Clemson remained No. 1, followed by Alabama, Ohio State and Notre Dame, and the committee’s chairman said the muddled picture surrounding the Big 12 was beginning to become clearer.
lead_paragraph: The top four teams remain unchanged as the College Football Playoff selection committee released its third set of rankings on Tuesday night.

headline: Minnesota: U.S. Will Investigate Police Shooting of Unarmed Man
abstract: Justice Department officials said they would start an inquiry into whether the shooting of an unarmed black man by the police violated civil rights laws.
lead_paragraph: Justice Department officials said Tuesday that they would start an inquiry into whether the shooting of an unarmed black man by the Minneapolis police violated civil rights laws. The man, Jamar Clark, 24, who was shot Sunday, died Monday night. The police said that Mr. Clark was an assault suspect and that he had been shot after interfering with paramedics trying to treat his victim and fighting with two officers. The police have disputed witness accounts that said Mr. Clark was handcuffed when he was shot. Though no police camera captured the confrontation, other cameras showed parts of it, said Superintendent Drew Evans of the Minnesota Bureau of Criminal Apprehension, which is investigating the case. Superintendent Evans said releasing that footage now could compromise the investigation. Protesters, including dozens who were arrested Monday night for blocking highway traffic, have demanded the release of video evidence and the names of the officers. The protesters and Mayor Betsy Hodges requested the Justice Department investigation.

headline: Hans Mommsen, 85, Dies; Documented Volkswagen Slave Labor in Nazi Era
abstract: Mr. Mommsen, a scholar of the Holocaust, was commissioned by Volkswagen to explore the company’s complicity in the crimes of the Third Reich.
lead_paragraph: Hans Mommsen, considered the leading German historian of the Third Reich, whose work encompassed the origins of the Holocaust as well as a widely publicized report documenting Volkswagen’s wartime use of slave labor, died in Tutzing, near Munich, on Nov. 5, his 85th birthday.

headline: How to Beat ISIS: Destroy the Group’s Economy
abstract: Boaz Ganor, a counterterrorism expert, says striking at the Islamic State’s infrastructure and access to money will sap its strength.
lead_paragraph: The following excerpts are from an interview about how to defeat the Islamic State with Boaz Ganor, the director of the International Institute for Counter-Terrorism at the Interdisciplinary Center in Herzliya, Israel.

headline: How to Beat ISIS: First Deal With Assad
abstract: Emile Hokayem, a Middle East security expert, says getting President Bashar al-Assad out of power in Syria will allow the focus to switch to the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: The following excerpts are from an interview about how to defeat the Islamic State with Emile Hokayem, a senior fellow for Middle East security at the International Institute for Strategic Studies who has personal roots in Beirut, Lebanon, and in Paris.

headline: Soccer Match in Germany Is Canceled Over Security Concerns
abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel had been on her way to Hanover for the game with the Netherlands before a “concrete security threat” led to its cancellation.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The German authorities called off an exhibition soccer match between Germany and the Netherlands in Hanover on Tuesday, less than two hours before kickoff, after the authorities received what they called “a concrete security threat.”

headline: How to Beat ISIS: Counter Recruitment of Young People
abstract: Imam Mohamed Magid, the spiritual leader of a large Muslim community in Virginia, says religion should call people to action “in a way that is constructive.”
lead_paragraph: The following excerpts are from an interview about how to defeat the Islamic State with Imam Mohamed Magid, the spiritual leader of the All Dulles Area Muslim Society, a large Muslim community in Sterling, Va. He has been working with other Muslim leaders and government agencies on countering radicalization. This year, he traveled to Nigeria, Sudan, Kenya and Ethiopia to discuss counterrecruitment and deradicalization strategies with religious and government leaders in those countries.

headline: How to Beat ISIS: Russia and the United States Should Join Forces
abstract: Kirill V. Kabanov, a member of Russia’s Human Rights Council, says the focus should be on defeating the Islamic State, not Syria’s president.
lead_paragraph: The following excerpts are from an interview about how to defeat the Islamic State with Kirill V. Kabanov, a member of Russia’s Human Rights Council and a former domestic intelligence agent. Mr. Kabanov has advocated an alliance between the United States and Russia to take on the Islamic State.

headline: How to Beat ISIS: Reform Islamic Teaching
abstract: Two former jihadists say Islam needs to have a “candid conversation” about the connection between church teachings and modern Muslim terrorists.
lead_paragraph: The following excerpts are from an interview about how to defeat the Islamic State with two former jihadists: Maajid Nawaz, a former recruiter for the radical Islamist group Hizb ut-Tahrir, and Mubin Shaikh, a former extremist from Canada who spent time with the Taliban before turning away from radical Islam.

headline: P. F. Sloan, Enigmatic Writer of ’60s Hit ‘Eve of Destruction,’ Dies at 70
abstract: Mr. Sloan wrote the apocalyptic anthem “Eve of Destruction” when he was 19. It became a No. 1 hit for Barry McGuire. He also wrote, with Steve Barri, “Secret Agent Man.”
lead_paragraph: P. F. Sloan, a singer and songwriter of somewhat enigmatic repute, whose apocalyptic anthem “Eve of Destruction,” written when he was just 19, was a seminal protest song of the 1960s, not to mention a No. 1 hit for the singer Barry McGuire, died on Sunday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 70.

headline: Silver Made Misleading Comments About How He Disclosed His Income, U.S. Says
abstract: Prosecutors in Sheldon Silver’s corruption trial in Manhattan played recordings of the assemblyman giving statements to reporters about how he disclosed outside income.
lead_paragraph: Sheldon Silver’s voice was finally heard in a federal courtroom on Tuesday, but not because he took the witness stand.

headline: Porzingis Gives Knicks, and Fans, a Charge
abstract: Porzingis scored a career-high 29 points and collected 11 rebounds, Carmelo Anthony operated as a facilitator, and the Knicks extinguished every rally that Charlotte could muster.
lead_paragraph: After he had dazzled and dunked, after he had sealed the win with a rebound and two free throws, and after the crowd had filled Madison Square Garden with the sound of his name being chanted over and over, as if he were a rock star being called for an encore, Kristaps Porzingis carried an armful of towels for his teammates.

headline: 2 Air France Planes Are Diverted From Paris
abstract: Air France flights from Los Angeles and Washington were diverted to other airports because of security issues, the Federal Aviation Administration said.
lead_paragraph: Two Air France flights bound for Paris from the United States were diverted Tuesday night over threats telephoned to a reservations center, the airline said.

headline: Britain: Couple Found Guilty of Keeping a Nigerian Man Captive Since 1989
abstract: The pair lured the man to Britain with promises of a job, then made him work for free by threatening him with deportation if he tried to escape, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A British couple was found guilty Tuesday of keeping a Nigerian immigrant enslaved for more than two decades, forcing him to work for no pay and threatening him with deportation if he tried to escape, prosecutors said. Dr. Emmanuel Edet, 61, and Antan Edet, 58, held their victim captive from the time he was brought to Britain when he was 14 years old, the Crown Prosecution Service said. The Edets were convicted at Harrow Crown Court in northwest London on charges of child cruelty, slavery and assisting in illegal immigration. They told their captive — whom the BBC identified as Ofonime Sunday Inuk, now 40 — when they brought him from Nigeria in 1989 that they would pay him and give him an education, prosecutors said. Instead, he was forced to cook, clean, garden and care for the couple’s children without pay for up to 17 hours a day, they said.

headline: Joel Elkes, Who Cast Light on Brain Chemistry and Behavior, Dies at 101
abstract: Dr. Elkes, a foundational figure in the study of psychosis, published the first scientific trial of a medication for schizophrenia as he explored the chemical underpinnings of being human.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Joel Elkes, who published the first scientific trial of a medication for schizophrenia and became a foundational figure in modern psychiatry, describing a framework to understand how brain chemistry shapes behavior, died on Oct. 30 in Sarasota, Fla. He was 101.

headline: Why I Provide Abortions

lead_paragraph: IN public health, you go where the crisis is. If there is an outbreak and you have the ability to relieve suffering, you rush to the site of the need. This is why, a year and a half ago, I returned to my hometown, Birmingham, Ala., to provide abortions.

headline: Euro-Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Fringe Groups and Movements']
abstract: Donald Trump shares a lot of common ground with the leaders of anti-immigrant parties in Europe. Their aggrieved supporters have a lot in common, too.

headline: Is Any Place Safe?
abstract: France has been wounded. The solution is not to become like its enemies.
lead_paragraph: Paris — FRIDAY night, after the terrorist attacks in Paris, I went out into the streets. I was confused and afraid, of course. But the terrible things that had happened — I wanted to see them for myself, breathe them in, walk among them. It was a little past 11 and the streets were deserted, silent. Paris no longer existed. Paris had fallen.

headline: France Unsure if Raid Killed Top Suspect in Paris Attacks
abstract: Two people were killed and more than 5,000 rounds were fired in the raid near Paris, but officials were not sure if the suspected ringleader of the attacks was there.
lead_paragraph: ST.-DENIS, France — The assault began before dawn Wednesday at a decrepit squat in a close suburb of Paris when scores of French police officers stormed a third-floor apartment in search of their elusive quarry: Abdelhamid Abaaoud, a Belgian suspected of organizing last week’s deadly attacks in Paris by the Islamic State.

headline: Can Crime Be Ethically Predicted?
abstract: Critics say that crime forecasting infringes on civil liberties and perpetuates racial profiling.

headline: Starwood Devotees Greet Marriott Merger With Dread and Anger
keywords: ['Customer Loyalty Programs', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Every big hotel chain has a loyalty program, but Starwood Preferred Guest stands out for the way it pampers the company’s most frequent customers.
lead_paragraph: Frequent customers of Starwood Hotels & Resorts are reacting emotionally to the news that Marriott International is acquiring Starwood, which owns the Westin, Sheraton and W hotel chains. It seems less like a company they do business with is merging and more like their mother is marrying a man they disapprove of.

headline: Rewatching the Theismann Injury
abstract: How the “most shocking moment in football history” looks, 30 years later.
lead_paragraph: There has perhaps never been a more memorable play in football — or even all of American sports — than the one that ended the career of the Washington Redskins quarterback Joe Theismann, 30 years ago today. Since that play, N.F.L. quarterbacks have attempted nearly half a million passes, and we have never again seen (or heard) such skeletal trauma.

headline: Pitfalls for Proxies
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Dementia', 'Living Wills and Health Care Proxies']
abstract: There are three common traps that the proxy decision-maker should be aware of in trying to guide health care at the end of someone else’s life.
lead_paragraph: Of the many factors that affect the experience of dying, the one that patients and families often have the greatest control over is making decisions that are in the patient’s best interest. I recently participated in research on barriers to quality end-of-life care as part of a study released today in the Journal of Palliative Medicine. Some of the hurdles we identified, such as financial limitations or access to top doctors, may require societal change. But I am focusing here on the personal part of the puzzle that all patients, whatever their socioeconomic status, should have the potential to influence.

headline: How Amazon’s Long Game Yielded a Retail Juggernaut

lead_paragraph: To study the graph of Amazon’s stock performance in 2015 is to witness a series of stepwise lurches toward commanding new heights. Over all, the stock market has been flat this year, and technology companies, as a group, haven’t fared much better.

headline: An Opulent Bronx Library in Decay, and in Search of a Purpose
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Libraries and Librarians', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: A group hopes to raise millions to save Gould Memorial Library at Bronx Community College, a project that is out of reach for the stretched City University system.
lead_paragraph: To reclaim Gould Memorial Library at Bronx Community College, Stanford White’s most dazzling extant structure in New York, its admirers must invent new uses for a building that was intended by a much different institution — New York University — to serve a now-antiquated form of scholarship, using riches of which the community college could only dream.

headline: Hiroji Kubota, Photographer
abstract: Hiroji Kubota’s path to Magnum started in Japan when he worked as a fixer and translator for members of the legendary agency.
lead_paragraph: Hiroji Kubota sounds a little over-the-top when he insists his “life is meaningless” without photography. But a glance at his latest — and 19th — book will convince you he is absolutely right, given how his life has been intertwined with some of Magnum’s legendary photographers, like René Burri, Burt Glinn and my father, Elliott Erwitt. He started out working with some of them as a fixer and translator, even though he refused payment at first. “I was brought up comfortably and didn’t need it,” he said.

headline: Donald Trump Bolsters Lead in New Hampshire, Poll Shows

headline: Going Postal in Turkey

lead_paragraph: ‘‘You have a package at the Karakoy post office.’’ The card was in my mailbox, but there was no address for the post office. Just my name and the message in Turkish.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on a Bone of Contention
abstract: A post-steak-dinner habit draws the ire of a fiancée — and the judge.
lead_paragraph: Dan writes: When I finish a steak at a restaurant, I like to chew on the bone. My fiancée, Liz, thinks it is rude to others and humiliating to her. But steakhouses are expensive. I want to make the most of it. If Liz would like to excuse herself to the restroom while I gnaw, I’d be O.K. with that.

headline: Small Country, Many Tastes
abstract: Learning to make corviches, the tuna-stuffed fritters of the Ecuadorean coast.
lead_paragraph: Everyone just wanted to talk about the guinea pigs: Yes, they were cute. Yes, they come roasted. Yes, they were delicious, and if you couldn’t get into them, were you sure you’d come to the right message board? My first brush with Ecuadorean food on the Internet made it sound fairly single-minded. This was circa 2000, and I confess that I never learned much more after that, as a cuisine seemingly built on guinea pig seemed a little too bony for me.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Christopher Logue, ‘War Music’
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Greek Language', 'English Language', 'Translation and Interpreters']
abstract: A beloved version of the ‘‘Iliad,’’ by a translator who knew no Greek.
lead_paragraph: As an illiterate — which is how Thoreau, one of our supposed avatars of democratic life, saw those of us who have neither Greek nor Latin — I realize that it’s an act of public self-shaming to vouch for a favorite translation of Homer. But it’s even worse than that for me, given I know very little about English translations of the ‘‘Iliad.’’ There are at least 100 of them, and to boast, as I will now, that I’ve read seven, maybe eight, is — at least to the ‘‘literate’’ set — a little like bragging that I’m the shortest guy on the Brooklyn Nets, and, hey, did I mention I can’t dunk?

headline: Can My Workplace Ask Me for a Donation?
keywords: ['Ethicists, The (Times Column)', 'Workplace Environment', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Philanthropy', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Ethics (Personal)']
abstract: A university holds its fund-raising drive just before yearly performance reviews are given.
lead_paragraph: Every year, members of the faculty and staff at my university are asked to make a donation to support the university. Letters and brochures are sent by mail and email and posted on the website.

headline: Coney Island: The Cyclone! The Hot Dogs! The Art!
abstract: An exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum tracks Coney Island through its stylish rise, slow decline and eventual revival.
lead_paragraph: In the days when Coney Island was in ruins, there was a carny at the broken-down game arcade who would, to draw a crowd, sometimes have his schnauzer smoke a cigarette. This was in the 1980s, when a pet dog with a Pall Mall was probably not the strangest thing you could find at the park. Coney back then was a derelict dystopia of burned-out lights and empty rides and sea gulls lying dead beneath the boardwalk — a place of which the smoking dog’s owner once explained, “It’s an interesting kind of crazy.”

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.

headline: In Some Birds, Love Trumps Hunger Pains
abstract: Instead of foraging elsewhere, some birds stand by while a mate feasts, researchers find.
lead_paragraph: Attachment trumps hunger in some wild birds, a new study reports. Researchers at Oxford University devised a clever way to prevent mated pairs of great tits from dining simultaneously: birds were fitted with radio tags linked to feeding stations and were not allowed to access a station if their mates were eating at it. Instead of foraging elsewhere, the researchers found, the excluded birds stuck close to their feeding partners. The study was published in the journal Current Biology.

headline: Coffee Tied to Lower Risk of Dying Prematurely
abstract: More good news on coffee: A large study has found that drinking coffee is associated with a reduced risk of dying from six causes, including heart disease.
lead_paragraph: More good news on coffee: A large study has found that drinking coffee is associated with a reduced risk of dying from heart disease and certain other causes.

headline: Fact Checks of the 2016 Election
abstract: The New York Times will be checking assertions made throughout the 2016 presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times will be checking assertions made throughout the 2016 presidential campaign.

headline: Sepp Blatter and Michel Platini Lose FIFA Appeals and Remain Suspended
abstract: Blatter, FIFA’s president, and Platini, president of the European soccer confederation, challenged 90-day bans that were related to a financial transaction.
lead_paragraph: Sepp Blatter’s latest effort to keep hold of power at FIFA, the governing body of world soccer, has failed.

headline: Classical Music This Week: Stops in Detroit, New Jersey and Berlin
abstract: A look ahead at the week in music.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, music lovers! If you’ve attended performances over the past few days, you may well have heard “La Marseillaise” played as a show of solidarity with France after Friday’s terrorist attacks; The New York Times’s Michael Cooper wrote about the history of the stirring anthem.

headline: Silver Lake Is Said to Invest $100 Million in SolarCity
abstract: The Silver Lake investment firm made the move as a show of confidence in SolarCity, which has shifted strategy recently to focus on positive cash flow.
lead_paragraph: At a time when investors have darkened on the solar power industry, a big investment firm has moved in to buy a stake in SolarCity, the biggest company in the sector.

headline: To Save on New York Hotels, Look Outside Manhattan
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Budget Travel']
abstract: Comparing hotel rates in central and Downtown Manhattan with those in Queens, Brooklyn, Upper Manhattan and New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: Over 56 million people visited New York City in 2014. How many more stayed away because hotels in Manhattan are so expensive?

headline: Tracing Frank Lloyd Wright in Oak Park, Illinois
abstract: The houses he designed in this Chicago suburb show the first traces of his famous work that was to come.
lead_paragraph: As an architecture buff, I had been drawn to the work of Frank Lloyd Wright for years before finally seeing his innovative Frederick C. Robie House on the South Side of Chicago last year.

abstract: The writer’s father wrote her college essay, and the tradition appears to have passed on to her son’s Bar Mitzvah.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

lead_paragraph: An old brick house in Kentucky, a contemporary in Connecticut and a new farmhouse in Maryland

lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, KY.

headline: What Middle Class Means in Malaysia
abstract: A long drive for prosperity is giving way to a debate about how the country shares its wealth.
lead_paragraph: One of my earliest memories of the place where my father grew up, Kelantan — a predominantly rural state on Malaysia’s far northeastern coast — is of its famous flood-measuring point. Built around 1929 and known as Tangga Krai, it consists of a series of flood markers beside a set of steps that rise steeply from the banks of the Kelantan River to a height of about 100 feet — a simple but effective warning in the country’s most flood-prone region.

headline: 1940: U.S. to Lease 7 British Bases
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The United States reaches a deal with the British authorities to lease bases in 1965.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Anglo-American co-operation advanced another step tonight when the Navy Department announced that the British authorities had reached an agreement with Washington on the location of the sites to be leased to the United States government for naval and air bases in the Bahamas, Jamaica, Antigua, St. Lucia, British Guiana, Bermuda and Newfoundland. No agreement has yet been reached regarding Trinidad, the last of the bases involved in President Roosevelt’s trade of fifty American destroyers for the base sites on eight British possessions in the Western Hemisphere. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 19, 1940

headline: In Guyana, a Land Dispute With Venezuela Escalates Over Oil
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Gold', 'Metals and Minerals', 'Foreign Investments', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Venezuela has long insisted it owns everything west of the Essequibo River, including the Guyanese town of Bartica, in a battle that intensified after an oil discovery.
lead_paragraph: BARTICA, Guyana — At a little tin-roofed beer joint on the west bank of the Essequibo River, Rawle Huggins relaxed on a wooden bench and considered his tiny country’s escalating border spat with its much bigger neighbor, Venezuela.

headline: A Five-Bedroom House With a Pool in Rio de Janeiro
abstract: The house, terraced into a hillside near the city’s botanical garden, is on the market for $3.9 million.
lead_paragraph: The house, terraced into a hillside near the city’s botanical garden, is on the market for $3.9 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... Brazil
abstract: After a strong market between 2008 and 2013, with prices rising between 100 and 150 percent across Brazil and 200 percent in Rio de Janeiro, the market has started to slow.
lead_paragraph: A FIVE-BEDROOM HOUSE IN RIO DE JANEIRO

headline: Daily Report: Lyft Looks to Raise More Money
abstract: The company’s valuation is just a fraction of the paper worth of its arch-rival Uber. But a new investment round would still put it comfortably among the tech industry’s “unicorns.”
lead_paragraph: Don’t tell the money-raising folks at Lyft that the days of so-called tech unicorns are numbered.

headline: Refugees Across Europe Fear Repercussions From Paris Attacks
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Terrorism', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: After fleeing their homeland to escape war and Islamist extremism, many now find that their long trek to the Continent may offer no guarantee of protection.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Asylum papers in hand, Raz Mohammad Aryubi recalled his arrival in Austria from his native Afghanistan in spring 2014, and how, at 21, he is now studying for an M.B.A. at the University of Vienna. But his feeling of security in the country he wishes to make his home evaporated, he said, when he saw what happened in Paris.

headline: Democratic Socialism Will Be Topic of Bernie Sanders Speech at Georgetown
keywords: ['Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Socialism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont will deliver the address, which some have equated to President Obama’s speech on race in 2008, at Georgetown University in Washington on Thursday. He will also take questions from students.
lead_paragraph: Dogged for months by questions about being a self-proclaimed Democratic Socialist, Senator Bernie Sanders will address the subject of his political philosophy head on in a long-awaited speech on Thursday.

headline: Revisiting the Mayflower Story
abstract: A picture book presents a new perspective on the adventure-filled tale behind the first Thanksgiving.
lead_paragraph: The story behind the first Thanksgiving — the full story, which starts with a band of harassed outsiders living in exile, then cramming aboard an iffy ship and arriving bedraggled and sick on a different continent, where half of them promptly died and the other half had little idea how to stay alive in the frigid wilderness — has the makings of a great adventure tale. Yet it’s rarely treated that way, perhaps because it’s so bound up in our national mythology. It tends to sag under the weight of its own symbolism, whether the narrative it’s used to uphold emphasizes the upbeat-spiritual or the oppressive-genocidal strain of United States history.

headline: Sarah Treem on ‘The Affair’ and Why She Loves the Character You Hate
abstract: The show runner of Showtime’s “The Affair” discusses the series and answers questions from Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Once mostly anonymous, the producers who oversee top television series have sometimes become as well known as the actors who star in them. On occasion, The Times will pose questions from readers (and pose some of our own) to notable show runners, and post their responses.

headline: Shopping for Health Insurance Is New Seasonal Stress for Many
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Prices fluctuate sharply on the federal health insurance marketplace, driving many cost-conscious consumers to switch coverage every year to avoid higher premiums.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For 2014, the first year she got health coverage through the Affordable Care Act, Gail Galen chose a plan from a new nonprofit insurer, Oregon’s Health CO-OP. But the price jumped for 2015, so Ms. Galen switched to a policy from a different company, LifeWise Health Plan.

headline: Andreessen Horowitz Starts Health Care Fund
abstract: The venture capital firm has raised $200 million for a new fund devoted to start-ups at the intersection of biology and software.
lead_paragraph: When the venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz opened its doors in 2009, its founders consciously sought to focus on their core expertise of software and stay away from specialties like biotechnology.

headline: Kristaps Porzingis Looks Good, Despite Problems With Fouls
abstract: The scoring and offensive rebounding of Porzingis, the 7-foot-3 rookie, have so far outweighed negatives like his shooting percentage and penchant for fouling.
lead_paragraph: After suffering through a miserable 17-win season by the Knicks last season, Madison Square Garden fans are getting excited again, thanks in large part to the play of Kristaps Porzingis. When a 7-foot-3 Latvian rookie comes to town, you might expect him to be a novelty act, beloved by fans but unproductive. But it is starting to look as if Porzingis is actually going to be good.

headline: Jeb Bush Cites Paris Attacks in Calling for Stronger Military
keywords: ['Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida has been struggling to gain traction in polls in early nominating states, but the speech at the Citadel, aides hope, will allow him to cast himself as a serious candidate for serious times, with a proven record of fixing things.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Jeb Bush plans to use a long-scheduled speech at the Citadel on Wednesday to outline his vision for overhauling the nation’s military and responding to the growing threat of the Islamic State.

headline: Inside the Hillary Clinton Campaign
abstract: Carolyn Ryan, the Times political editor, chats with national political reporters about life inside Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Carolyn Ryan, the Times political editor, chats with national political reporters about life inside Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential campaign.

headline: 7 Bryant Park Embraces Its Place in the City
abstract: This 30-story building is not just another spec office tower, but a work that makes the case for why architecture matters.
lead_paragraph: With little fanfare, an eye-catching work of corporate architecture has landed in Midtown: a 30-story, glass-and-stainless-steel building called 7 Bryant Park, between 39th and 40th Streets, along Sixth Avenue.

headline: ‘The Nutcracker’ and Its Many Mysteries
abstract: To a critic who has seen perhaps 50 versions, this ballet is both familiar and fascinating.
lead_paragraph: “The Nutcracker,” though such a familiar fixture in the calendar, is among the most layered of all works of art. Yes, it contains kitsch and cuteness and adorability. Yes, it’s surrounded by merchandising. Even so, this ballet is larger, stranger, more moving than all of that — and more unknowable. There are mysteries at its heart that don’t vanish and wonders that don’t diminish.

headline: Miley Cyrus and the Flaming Lips Hit the Clubs
abstract: The musicians, who collaborated on an album that was released in August, are briefly touring clubs together.
lead_paragraph: It was improbable enough that Miley Cyrus would collaborate with the Flaming Lips, the long-running Oklahoma band steeped in psychedelia, despite a shared interest in altered mental states. In August, they suddenly released a free online stream of the album “Miley Cyrus & Her Dead Petz,” which also had some contributions from the producer Mike WiLL Made-It. The album was an outlet for jokey thoughts on drugs and sex, for studio high jinks and for lyrics flaunting cuss words, but it also had a handful of full-fledged songs and glimmers of thoughtfulness. Now, even more improbably, Ms. Cyrus and the Flaming Lips are briefly touring clubs together. Dan Deacon, opening the show, is a synthesizer-wielding composer who stokes enthusiastic audience participation. (8 p.m. on Saturday at Terminal 5; 610 West 56th Street, 212-260-4700, $69.69.)

headline: 1965: Hijacker Shoots Up Plane
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A teenager opens fire on a National Airlines plane in 1965.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — A frail teen-ager pulled out two pistols aboard a jetliner last night [Nov. 17] and nearly shot Christopher Kraft, Gemini space mission flight director, in the face. The youth was Thomas Robinson, 16, of Brownsville, Texas. He fired six shots aboard a National Airlines DC-8 jetliner before a passenger subdued him. No one was injured. Mr. Kraft, with a score of other top U.S. space officials traveling to Cape Kennedy for a flight readiness review for the next Gemini mission, was threatened by the frail-looking pistol-waving youth who said he was trying to hijack the plane and take it to Cuba. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 19, 1965

headline: Foiling Electronic Snoops in Email
abstract: Trackers inserted into email can detect when a person opens a message and where they are when they do so. And it’s not easy to thwart them.
lead_paragraph: IT didn’t take much for Florian Seroussi, a technology investor in Manhattan, to become suspicious of his email.

headline: Podcast: Inside the Hillary Clinton Campaign
abstract: Carolyn Ryan, the Times political editor, chats with national political reporters about life inside Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Carolyn Ryan, the Times political editor, says that one of the thrills and pleasures of her job is hearing from reporters about what they see on the campaign trail.

headline: Combining Food Preparation and Athletic Participation
abstract: The Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y., is not known for sports, but it fields intercollegiate athletic teams whose stars are future chefs.
lead_paragraph: The Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y., is not known for sports, but it fields intercollegiate athletic teams whose stars are future chefs.

headline: Topping Studies With a Dollop of Athletics at the Culinary Institute of America
abstract: The institute has grown more serious about a longtime staple of campus life, intercollegiate sports, but its players face demands unfamiliar to most of the nation’s student-athletes.
lead_paragraph: HYDE PARK, N.Y. — The basketball team’s starting center missed the home opener because he had to work at Bocuse, the on-campus French restaurant. A 19-year-old woman was a frequent starter at striker for the men’s soccer team. And two years ago, the star of the women’s cross-country team missed out on a fourth straight conference championship because the school’s rolling enrollment schedule meant she graduated two weeks before her final meet.

headline: New Recipes for Thanksgiving
abstract: Holiday dishes from Julia Child and Melissa Clark, plus pizza for dinner.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears on nytimes.com. To receive the email, register here.

headline: Video Review: New Kia Optima Arrives, Sleek and Stylish
abstract: The car is among the most stylish, regardless of price, and the company has addressed some shortcomings of the previous generation model.
lead_paragraph: BEFORE the Nike Air Jordan, there was the Converse Chuck Taylor — a classic design that stood the test of time. But even the classics evolve. Chucks were recently tweaked to be more cushioned and comfortable.

lead_paragraph: It’s the season of prestige pictures, with many films competing for the attention of Oscar voters. But let’s forget about all that for a moment. The “Zoolander 2” trailer is here.

keywords: ['iPhone', 'Virtual Reality (Computers)', 'Privacy', 'Web Browsers', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']

lead_paragraph: Q. Do all web browsers have the anti-tracking feature? How do I turn it on in Firefox and does it actually work?

headline: Barclays to Pay $150 Million More in Currency Inquiry
abstract: The penalty levied by the New York State financial regulator is for misconduct related to automated foreign exchange trading.
lead_paragraph: From 2009 to 2014, employees of Barclays’ automated foreign exchange trading system were directed to “obfuscate and stonewall” if anyone asked why client trade orders were being rejected by the system.

headline: Eagles of Death Metal Make First Statement on Paris Attacks
abstract: The band, which was headlining at the Bataclan on Friday when gunmen stormed the venue, said on Facebook that members were still trying to process what happened.
lead_paragraph: “Love overshadows evil.”

headline: Kurt Sutter Ends ‘The Bastard Executioner’
abstract: The FX period drama was canceled after one season, a move announced in the Hollywood trades.
lead_paragraph: Kurt Sutter swung the ax on his own series, opting to end “The Bastard Executioner” after its debut season, which concluded on Tuesday.

keywords: ['Uighurs (Chinese Ethnic Group)', 'Terrorism', 'Mines and Mining', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
