lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The authorities killed 17 people, including several women and children, in a raid last week in the volatile Chinese region of Xinjiang, a news report said Wednesday.

headline: ‘Scream Queens’ Season 1, Episode 9: ‘Ghost Stories’
abstract: Lots of people died Tuesday on “Scream Queens,” which is finding a nice groove after its uneven start.
lead_paragraph: Sorry this recap is late. For the past 12 hours I’ve been frantically trying to lock down the marketing rights for red and blue toilet paper.

headline: Old-School Flavor at Brancaccio’s Food Shop
abstract: Brancaccio’s Food Shop, in the Windsor Terrace section of Brooklyn, combines home-style Italian cooking with a 1990s hip-hop soundtrack.
lead_paragraph: Brancaccio’s Food Shop, in the Windsor Terrace section of Brooklyn, combines home-style Italian cooking with a 1990s hip-hop soundtrack.

headline: At Brancaccio’s Food Shop in Brooklyn, Love of Food and Hip-Hop
abstract: The shop in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, specializes in hearty dishes rooted in traditional Italian cooking and serves them to a 1990s beat.
lead_paragraph: On a recent weekday afternoon, Joe Brancaccio stood behind the counter of Brancaccio’s Food Shop in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn. He wore a black T-shirt with Raphael’s angels looking skyward, baggy pants and sneakers. And in black-rimmed glasses and a baseball cap, he looked like a cross between Ira Glass of public radio and one of the Beastie Boys.

headline: BlackRock to Wind Down Macro Hedge Fund
abstract: The BlackRock Global Ascent hedge fund has lost 9.4 percent this year and investors in the $1 billion fund were notified over the last week that it would be closed down.
lead_paragraph: BlackRock, the world’s biggest asset manager, is closing a billion-dollar hedge fund that made money for investors with bets on macroeconomic trends around the world.

headline: Verbatim: Chris Christie Gives John Kerry the Goodnight
abstract: “He needs to get some sleep and shut up.” — Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, a Republican running for president, referring to Secretary of State John Kerry and his claim that there was a “rationale” to the Charlie Hebdo attacks in Paris.
lead_paragraph: — Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, a Republican running for president, in an interview with Fox News, referring to Secretary of State John Kerry and his claim that there was a “rationale” to the Charlie Hebdo terrorist attacks in Paris in January.

headline: Europe’s Refugee Problem, and Ours
keywords: ['ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Terrorism', 'Yazidi (Religious Sect)']
abstract: Why the continent risks much more when it accepts refugees than we do.
lead_paragraph: There are two ways to think about the potential dangers involved in admitting large numbers of refugees from the Middle East’s present chaos into Western countries, and both of them have rather different implications for Europe than for the United States.

headline: Obama Criticizes Rhetoric on Refugees
abstract: President Obama addressed the debate over whether to block the entry of Syrian refugees to the United States, saying some of it was "political posturing."
lead_paragraph: President Obama addressed the debate over whether to block the entry of Syrian refugees to the United States, saying some of it was "political posturing."

headline: In Many Obamacare Markets, Renewal Is Not an Option
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Widespread cancellations of health plans reflect continuing shifts in a health insurance market that has existed in this form only since 2014.
lead_paragraph: Last year, we encouraged returning Obamacare customers to shop around for a better deal. This year, a lot of people will have no choice.

headline: Roundabout Adds Chekhov (by Way of Karam) and Bartlett to Next Season
abstract: The Roundabout Theater Company announced two new plays for its 2016-17 season.
lead_paragraph: The Roundabout Theater Company will bring two playwrights with current New York hits on board for its 2016-17 season.

headline: Merce Cunningham Exhibitions in Minneapolis and Chicago
abstract: The Walker Art Center in Minneapolis and the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago are to hold a two-city exhibition, “Merce Cunningham: Common Time,” opening in February 2017,
lead_paragraph: The Walker Art Center in Minneapolis and the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago are to hold an extensive two-city exhibition, “Merce Cunningham: Common Time,” opening in February 2017, the museums announced on Tuesday. The Walker — which has all the sets and costumes that once belonged to the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, including items designed by Jasper Johns, Robert Rauschenberg, Frank Stella and Andy Warhol — is organizing both shows. It investigates Cunningham’s groundbreaking practice and multidisciplinary collaborations.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Ben Carson’s Campaign Has a Geography Problem
abstract: This map of the United States looks . . . unusual.
lead_paragraph: Ben Carson’s campaign shared the map below on Facebook on Tuesday, according to Talking Points Memo, as part of a post opposing the admission of Syrian refugees to the United States. Pay particular attention to the upper right.

headline: Rugs With Personality
abstract: The designer Paul Smith celebrates 15 (colorful) years of collaborating with the Rug Company.
lead_paragraph: “From the very beginning, it’s been an open conversation between me and the Rug Company team,” says the designer Sir Paul Smith, on the 15th anniversary of his partnership with the British home-textile brand. “As time has passed, I’ve certainly come to understand the process better.”

headline: Todd Haynes’s Flash and Finesse at the Film Society of Lincoln Center
abstract: in the program “The Other Side of Dreams,” films from the director are paired with movies by other directors that offer similar themes.
lead_paragraph: In “The Other Side of Dreams,” the Film Society of Lincoln Center’s lovingly curated retrospective of the films of Todd Haynes, selections are paired with films chosen by Mr. Haynes that influenced them. His suburban melodrama, “Far From Heaven,” is coupled with Max Ophuls’s “The Reckless Moment,” which also deals with a scandalous family secret. His HBO mini-series, “Mildred Pierce,” is connected to “Klute,” in which Jane Fonda’s Oscar-winning role as a hardened prostitute is markedly similar to Kate Winslet’s devoted, hard-driving mother in “Pierce.” The flamboyant David Bowie-like rocker (Jonathan Rhys Meyers) in “Velvet Goldmine,” set in London at the height of the glam-rock era, is not unlike the androgynous rock star played by Mick Jagger in Nicolas Roeg and Donald Cammell’s cult classic “Performance.” Mr. Haynes’s AIDS-era parable, “Safe,” is paired with Douglas Sirk’s final Hollywood film, “Imitation of Life,” a critique of racial and class divisions in America disguised as a sudsy weeper. (Through Nov. 29; filmlinc.org.)

headline: Carson Elrod Wears a New Comic Hat While Facing Fashions of the Future
abstract: A comic actor continues his Manhattan comedy streak onstage with Nick Jones’s “Important Hats of the Twentieth Century.”
lead_paragraph: Some performers you simply want to watch in anything, and the quirky, dexterous actor Carson Elrod is on my shortlist. Fortunately, he hasn’t been hard to find of late. In the 20th anniversary revival of David Ives’s “All in the Timing” and Mr. Ives’s more recent “Lives of the Saints,” Mr. Elrod’s puckish humor has been a welcome presence. (That was also him, in blue body paint, spouting gibberish in “The Explorers Club.”)

headline: Soul and Gospel Grit, Caribbean Strains and Denver Roots Rock
abstract: New releases include albums from Judith Hill, Shmu, the Yawpers, Zemog el Gallo Bueno and Floating Points
lead_paragraph: BACK IN TIME

headline: A Former Brewery, Now Hotel
abstract: The design firm Roman and Williams makes its Texas debut in an old San Antonio building.
lead_paragraph: Robin Standefer and Stephen Alesch, the husband and wife behind the celebrated design firm Roman and Williams, make their Texas debut with the 146-room Hotel Emma, housed in a massive former brewery built on San Antonio’s eponymous river in 1894. “There is something extraordinary about these old, vast abandoned buildings and this one was so embedded in the fabric of the region,” says Standefer.

headline: Ted Cruz Challenges President Obama to Debate on Syrian Refugees
keywords: ['Humanitarian Aid', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Law and Legislation', 'Muslim Americans', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Ted Cruz criticized President Obama for his remarks in Manila, which included saying that Republicans were “political posturing” on Syrian refugee policy. The Texas senator delivered this retort: “Come back and insult me to my face.”
lead_paragraph: One day after President Obama assailed the “political posturing” of Republicans who have called for barring the Syrian refugees from entering the United States, Senator Ted Cruz delivered this retort: “Come back and insult me to my face.”

headline: Visualize This: Mapping Regions Polluted by Rigged VW Diesels
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Automobiles', 'Diesel Power', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']
abstract: An interactive map shows Californians where diesel pollution from VW vehicles with rigged emissions software is tainting the air.
lead_paragraph: I’ve written about the challenges and opportunities in visualizing diffuse public health threats in new ways. Here’s a new effort, created by Kevala Analytics for the California Clean Energy Fund. Kevala’s blog post is invaluable.*

headline: La tierra de Stonehenge
abstract: Para muchos visitantes, Stonehenge no es mucho más que una serie de piedras enormes. Pero la historia no está sólo en Stonehenge.
lead_paragraph: Para muchos visitantes, Stonehenge no es mucho más que una serie de piedras enormes. Pero la historia no está sólo en Stonehenge.

headline: Education Dept. Drops Proposal to Rezone Upper West Side Schools
abstract: The move would have shifted some families from the zone of a highly sought after elementary school to that of a school that was labeled persistently dangerous.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Education Department is dropping a controversial proposal to rezone several elementary schools on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, a move that would have shifted many families from the zone of a highly sought-after school where students are mostly white to that of a school with a mostly black and Hispanic population that this year was labeled persistently dangerous.

headline: Misty Copeland to Write Book on Health and Fitness
abstract: Misty Copeland, a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, is expected to release her third book, “Ballerina Body,” in early 2017.
lead_paragraph: Misty Copeland’s big year isn’t over yet. After making history by becoming American Ballet Theater’s first black female principal dancer, performing on Broadway to favorable reviews and starring in a documentary about her life, she will now write her third book.

headline: Girls Aren’t Meaner Than Boys. It Only Looks That Way.
abstract: There aren’t many gender differences in meanness. What’s different is how girls and boys respond.
lead_paragraph: Girls can be mean. Really mean. Yet despite their widespread reputation for cruelty, we have little evidence that girls are meaner than boys. It’s no surprise to learn that boys are more likely than girls to use physical aggression, but we also know that boys surpass girls when it comes to attacking peers verbally and engaging in cyberbullying. Some research suggests that girls pick up the slack by engaging in more relational aggression: being emotionally manipulative, spreading rumors, excluding peers. But other studies find that boys can outpace, or at least match, girls in the use of indirect forms of interpersonal treachery.

headline: With ‘Mustang,’ a Director Breaks Free of Cultural Confines
abstract: Deniz Gamze Ergüven tells the story of what it is to be a girl and a woman in Turkey in France’s foreign-language Oscar submission.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — For a film about death, “Mustang” is incredibly alive. It tells the story of five orphaned sisters in rural Turkey whose boundless lust for life runs up against the confines of a conservative Muslim society, leading some to suicide. A first feature by Deniz Gamze Ergüven — directed, written by and starring young women — it was a hit when it played the Directors’ Fortnight for independent films at Cannes and is France’s foreign-language Oscar submission.

headline: The Cult of the Toto Toilet
abstract: The Japanese toilet is said to be about “comfort, health, functionality,” but in America, the washlet with its bidet has not widely caught on.
lead_paragraph: Last year, Bennett Friedman, who owns a plumbing showroom in Manhattan called AF New York, took a business trip to Milan. On the morning of his return he faced a choice: stop in the bathroom there or wait until he got home. The flight was nine hours. He waited.

headline: Share Your Thoughts: How Should We Balance Civil Liberties and National Security?

lead_paragraph: As France comes to terms with its deadliest domestic attack since World War II, attention has quickly turned to whether European governments need to reassess how they collect, manage and use people’s digital footprint.

But the loyalty programs operated by the two companies, Marriott Rewards and Starwood Preferred Guest (SPG), will remain separate entities for now.

headline: Fall Fashion: Too Warm to Be Cool
abstract: Yes, there are fears that Greenland is melting away. But for some, the impact of climate change is more personal and more immediate: Will they ever get to wear their winter clothes again?
lead_paragraph: Bridget Capobianco, a Brooklyn mother and former boutique owner, was sitting on a playground bench on a Wednesday in early November, wearing shearling-lined clog boots under the gentle patter of a 60-degree rain. “I was impatient to wear these boots, because I love them, but my feet are sweating like crazy,” Ms. Capobianco said.

abstract: Scans revealed obscured writing on Kazimir Malevich’s 1915 “Black Square,” which appears to refer to an earlier French painting.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Sophisticated X-ray technology revealed a mysterious inscription on Kazimir Malevich’s renowned 1915 “Black Square” painting, offering insights into the work’s cultural origins and meaning, experts at the Tretyakov Gallery said at a news conference here on Wednesday.

headline: What Is Good Czech Design?
abstract: A new concept store in Prague displays the best examples of the country’s glass, porcelain, jewelry and furniture — then and now.
lead_paragraph: In Prague, what was once a brick factory is now home to some of the best modern Czech glass, porcelain, jewelry and furniture. The Cihelna Concept Store, which opened quietly over the summer in the old 18th-century building, is just off the Vltava River in the historical Lesser Town district. Its curator, the designer Silvie Lubenova, explains that she deals exclusively in Czech designers and companies, and will rotate solo exhibitions to celebrate the country’s design past and present.

headline: Health Care Law Forces Businesses to Consider Growth’s Costs

abstract: In January, a staff of 50 or more full-time employees will trigger the law’s employer mandate, which has employers weighing the costs of expansion.
lead_paragraph: When LaRonda Hunter opened a Fantastic Sams hair salon 10 years ago in Saginaw, Tex., a suburb of Fort Worth, she envisioned it as the first of what would eventually be a small regional collection of salons. As her sales grew, so did her business, which now encompasses four locations — but her plans for a fifth salon are frozen, perhaps permanently.

keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Airport Security', 'Gun Control', 'Law and Legislation', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Terrorism']
abstract: It’s not Syrian refugees.
lead_paragraph: As Republicans grope for rationales to block asylum for Syrian refugees, Texas State Representative Tony Dale, a gun rights stalwart with an A rating from the National Rifle Association, is arguing that they should all be blocked because it’s far too easy in this country for people with terrorist motives to buy guns and cause mayhem.

headline: Complaints Against Police Officer Jason Van Dyke
abstract: Numerous civilian complaints against Mr. Van Dyke, a Chicago officer, include use of excessive force and using racial slurs. None of the complaints in these pages were sustained.
lead_paragraph: Numerous civilian complaints against Mr. Van Dyke, a Chicago officer, include use of excessive force and using racial slurs. None of the complaints in these pages were sustained.

headline: Review: A Rigorous Tap Dancing Lesson in ‘What the Eye Hears’
abstract: Brian Seibert’s book offers evocations of dance action and a narrative mischief suited to tap’s laid-back, trickster mentality.
lead_paragraph: “What the Eye Hears” is the title Brian Seibert gives his big, smart, wonderfully anecdotal and definitive history of tap dance. Both eyes and ears are needed to get the full effect of tap, the only purely American dance genre we’ve got. Tap, writes Mr. Seibert, a dance critic for The New York Times, “is dance and music, sound and movement.” Here he takes us back a couple of centuries to search out the art’s two-pronged beginnings, then scrolls up to a survey of its revitalized present.

headline: Chicago Rarely Penalizes Officers for Complaints, Data Shows
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Police', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: Data released by two groups provides a rare look into the cloistered world of internal police discipline.
lead_paragraph: In 18 years with the Chicago Police Department, the nation’s second-largest, Jerome Finnigan had never been disciplined — although 68 citizen complaints had been lodged against him, including accusations that he used excessive force and regularly conducted illegal searches.

headline: Russia Strikes Syrian Oil Infrastructure
abstract: Russian airstrikes have started targeting strategic oil infrastructure in Syria controlled by the Islamic State. The Treasury Department estimates that the group earns as much as $40 million per month from oil sales.
lead_paragraph: Russian airstrikes have started targeting strategic oil infrastructure in Syria controlled by the Islamic State. The Treasury Department estimates that the group earns as much as $40 million per month from oil sales.

headline: Review: Twyla Tharp’s Choreography Celebrated to Bach and Jazz
abstract: A tour lauding Ms. Tharp’s career arrives at the David H. Koch Theater.
lead_paragraph: If the thought processes within Twyla Tharp’s dances could be written down in book form, it would be the world’s most densely packed, intelligent, artful guide to high-entertainment dance-making. Already the author of a series of American dance classics, she is celebrating her 50th anniversary as a choreographer by presenting a double bill of premieres. This week, that program, after two months of touring the United States, has reached the David H. Koch Theater (though it’s the Joyce Theater that’s presenting it). The first half is to Bach (“Preludes and Fugues”), the second to jazz (“Yowzie”).

headline: Boko Haram Ranked Ahead of ISIS for Deadliest Terror Group
abstract: A new report tracking terrorist attacks around the world said the Nigerian militant group was responsible for nearly 600 more deaths last year than the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal —  As much of the world remains focused on the Islamic State and its horrific attacks in Paris, another radical band of extremists has, by one account, captured the infamous title of the world’s deadliest terrorist group: Boko Haram.

headline: Paris Attacks Highlight Jihadists’ Easy Path Between Europe and ISIS Territory
abstract: It appears that as many as six of the attackers identified in the Paris massacre were Europeans who traveled to fight and train in Syria before returning home.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — One of the militants in the Paris attacks traveled to Syria from his hometown in France and back, officials said, even after his passport had been confiscated and he had been placed under judicial oversight. So did another, despite having been arrested eight times in petty crimes and having been listed as a national security risk in France.

lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Volkswagen is expected to announce substantial spending cuts on Friday as the carmaker braces for the financial impact of its emissions-cheating crisis — potentially setting up a confrontation with its powerful labor representatives.

headline: Review: New Juilliard Ensemble Embraces Rilke
abstract: In an evening of premieres, Alexandra Razskazoff’s silky soprano enriched “From a Book of Hours” by the composer James Primosch.
lead_paragraph: “Why so little Rilke-music?” a critic from The New York Times asked over 20 years ago, noting how many composers have kept a respectful distance from this great poet. Among those who have heeded the challenge of setting his texts is the composer James Primosch, who has turned to Rilke’s religious poetry for a number of songs that elegantly combine personal fervor and worldly sophistication.

headline: Adviser Who Questioned Ben Carson’s Grasp of Mideast Is Consulted for Op-Ed Piece

lead_paragraph: A foreign policy adviser whom Ben Carson publicly distanced himself from after the adviser criticized Mr. Carson’s grasp of the Middle East provided input for an opinion column Mr. Carson published online in The Washington Post on Wednesday about defeating the Islamic State.

headline: Review: A Pierre Boulez Tribute, Eight Months Late
abstract: Members of the International Contemporary Ensemble are leading a series of concerts meant to hail Mr. Boulez, the former New York Philharmonic music director who turned 90 this year.
lead_paragraph: This city has not done right lately by Pierre Boulez, who turned 90 in March. The New York Philharmonic — of which he was music director from 1971 to 1977, in a tenure now often criticized as recondite in its programming (untrue) and dire in its ticket sales (ditto) — did nothing to honor the birthday. Nor did our other major cultural institutions.

headline: PHD Terrace Brings ‘Downtown Cool’ to Midtown
abstract: A new rooftop bar opens at the Dream Hotel.
lead_paragraph: “Offices, offices, offices,” said Matt Strauss, the managing partner of PHD Terrace in Midtown. “Tourists, tourists, tourists.” He was waving toward the kaleidoscopic lights and humanity glob of nearby Times Square, visible from the two-floor lounge that opened in early October atop the Dream Midtown hotel. “But we’re infusing it with our brand of downtown cool,” he said.

keywords: ['Art', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Book Fairs', 'Nonprofit Organizations', 'Collectors and Collections']
abstract: Now in its 40th year, the nonprofit art bookstore moved into a new two-story shop in Chelsea and stayed true to its mission as a community archive.
lead_paragraph: In 2012, Printed Matter, the nonprofit art bookstore started by Sol LeWitt and the art critic Lucy R. Lippard, lost more than 9,000 books and sustained hundreds of thousands of dollars in damage during Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Review: Krysten Ritter Is a Gumshoe With Superhero Troubles in ‘Jessica Jones’
abstract: Netflix’s latest adaptation of a Marvel property concerns a private investigator who tries to keeps her ability to lift cars and leap onto fire escapes hidden.
lead_paragraph: “Jessica Jones,” the second of Netflix’s original series based on Marvel comic books (after “Daredevil”), is reluctantly superheroic. Created by Melissa Rosenberg, the screenwriter of five “Twilight” movies as well as a writer on TV shows including “Dexter,” and starring the acerbic Krysten Ritter of “Don’t Trust the B____ in Apartment 23,” it’s a clever 21st-century take on film noir, featuring a heroine who hides her superstrength because it’s at the root of her extreme emotional vulnerability and fear. There’s a tricky balancing act going on — crossing a moody detective show with both a comic action thriller and a woman-in-peril psychological drama — but Ms. Rosenberg proves to be mostly up to the task.

headline: Settlement in New York Domestic Violence Case May Set Broader Precedent
abstract: Bon-Ton put an employee threatened by her husband on leave. In a settlement, it agreed to change its policy to allow such employees to stay on the job.
lead_paragraph: The New York State attorney general has reached a potentially significant settlement with Bon-Ton Stores, which has more than 200 department stores across the northern part of the country, over a workplace discrimination complaint filed by a victim of domestic violence.

headline: Review: Adele Holds Firm on ‘25,’ Even as Pop Shifts
abstract: The new album by the soulful British singer shows off all the elements she’s best known for.
lead_paragraph: Absence has a way of ossifying an idea and amplifying a legend. Those have been gifts for Adele, who has just returned after a break of almost five years with her third album, “25” (XL/Columbia).

headline: A Feminist T-Shirt Resurfaces From the ‘70s
keywords: ['T-Shirts (Apparel)', 'Slogans and Mottoes', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Women and Girls', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', "Women's Rights"]

The same month, Ms. Delevingne’s girlfriend, the musician Annie Clark (a.k.a. St. Vincent), wore the same shirt, paired with a white Chanel bag, to the Chateau Marmont in Hollywood.

headline: Review: Celebrating Cecil Taylor, a Pianist of Endless Influence
abstract: Though this jazz musician couldn’t attend the benefit, held at Harlem Stage Gatehouse, his presence was felt through works by Jason Moran and others.
lead_paragraph: “Cecil Taylor: From the Five Spot to the World,” a gala concert at the Harlem Stage Gatehouse on Tuesday night, opened with welcoming remarks wrapped around a disclaimer. “Cecil will not be with us this evening,” Pat Cruz, the executive director of Harlem Stage, announced in a soothing tone, “and we will miss him.”

headline: Half of New Yorkers Say They Are Barely or Not Getting By, Poll Shows
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The survey showed great differences in perceptions of the quality of life in the city’s five boroughs, but it found that economic anxiety was widespread.
lead_paragraph: Half of New York City residents say they are struggling economically, making ends meet just barely, if at all, and most feel sharp uncertainty about the future of the city’s next generation, a new poll shows.

headline: Punk Portraits of New York

headline: Officer Shoots Man Reaching for Gun After Chase in Brooklyn, Police Say
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Kareem Thomas, who had appeared in court earlier in the day in an attempted murder case, was shot after a car and foot chase in the Crown Heights neighborhood, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: For Kareem Thomas, Wednesday started with an appearance in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, where he is fighting charges of attempted murder in connection with a shooting at a bodega in October 2011. By the evening, the authorities said, Mr. Thomas was in Kings County Hospital Center, a gunshot to his lower back from a police bullet.

headline: New York Store Openings and Other Shopping Events
abstract: Plus: A Bombas partnership with Gap to benefit those in need, and sample sales at Tabitha Simmons and Live the Process.
lead_paragraph: Skip your trip to the dry cleaner this week. On Friday, the Laundress, an eco-friendly detergent line founded by Gwen Whiting and Lindsey Boyd, who met studying fiber science at Cornell and left jobs at Chanel and Ralph Lauren to educate consumers about alternative fabric care, will open a shop in SoHo. The cedar-extract, sulphite-free wool and cashmere shampoo ($19) works wonders in the washing-machine delicate cycle. At 199 Prince Street.

headline: Review: Tyshawn Sorey Goes His Own Way at the Vanguard
abstract: Mr. Sorey and his trio, appearing at the Village Vanguard, mix silence, attack and a flowing sense of ritual.
lead_paragraph: It’s going to be rare to see the improvising drummer Tyshawn Sorey do anything mechanically or thoughtlessly at the Village Vanguard this week. He’s got hyperprecision technique; he could keep you engaged for a long time with straight swing or regularly accented music, and he’s done that in plenty of groups led by other people, jazz or otherwise.

headline: Marco Rubio Returns Fire on Ted Cruz
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida has stepped up the attacks on Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, accusing him of trying to cut the military budget and gut the nation’s intelligence programs.
lead_paragraph: Two can play at this game, Senator Cruz.

headline: Hurdles for Canadian Pacific-Norfolk Southern Deal
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Railroads']
abstract: More money may be needed to keep the offer alive, and it may face antitrust concerns as well.
lead_paragraph: Canadian Pacific Railway will probably have to come up with more than $28.4 billion to keep a Norfolk Southern deal on track. The company justifies its unsolicited bid for its American rival by promoting cost savings worth more than $12 billion. But Canadian Pacific shareholders would keep $5 billion of that amount for themselves. Given antitrust risks, the merger price could use stoking.

headline: Results of U.A.W. Vote Show Ford Pact Losing

lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich. — Leaders of the United Automobile Workers union said on Wednesday that a slight majority of workers at Ford Motor Company have so far voted against a proposed new labor agreement.

abstract: Jason Brown will be chief deputy attorney general responsible for criminal prosecutions, and Janet Sabel will be chief deputy attorney general in charge of affirmative litigation.
lead_paragraph: The New York attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, has named two top lieutenants who will split oversight of criminal cases and the civil cases brought by the office.

headline: U.S. to Sue Contractor It Says Bilked the Navy
keywords: ['Defense Contracts', 'Whistle-Blowers', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The complaint accused the company of using improper methods to inflate what it charged to service Navy ships across much of the globe.
lead_paragraph: After nearly two years of settlement talks broke down, the Justice Department announced Wednesday that it was moving forward with a civil fraud lawsuit against one of the ship-supply contractors said to have overcharged the Navy by tens of millions of dollars.

headline: For Its I.P.O., Square Scales Back Valuation by $3 Billion
abstract: The price of $9 a share is below the marketed range, a sign that the party for Silicon Valley may be soon coming to an end.
lead_paragraph: The long-running gold rush into hot technology start-ups showed signs of faltering on Wednesday, as a much-anticipated market debut had to scale back its ambitions.

headline: Pleased With Progress, Jets General Manager Says There Is Still Work to Do
abstract: Mike Maccagnan praised Coach Todd Bowles and said long-term success was the ultimate goal for the Jets, who at 5-4 are on the periphery of the A.F.C. wild-card chase.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — General Manager Mike Maccagnan praised his coach, extolled his starting quarterback, complimented his backup quarterback, hailed the Jets’ depth and lauded their progress. His responses at his midseason news conference Wednesday, in other words, were predictable for a first-year general manager presiding over a team that is — at 5-4 and on the periphery of the A.F.C. wild-card chase — an improvement by any measure over last season’s fiasco.

headline: Fantasy Sports Inquiry Puts Spotlight on a Success for Yahoo
abstract: Yahoo, one of the leading sites for sports fans, has found success with its streams of N.F.L. games, but its push into fantasy sports has drawn scrutiny from regulators.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Yahoo has long been a top online destination for sports fans, and this year, it made two big bets to expand that audience: its multimillion-dollar deal to webcast a National Football League game and its July entrance into the world of daily fantasy sports contests.

headline: Jake Arrieta and Dallas Keuchel, Newly Anointed Aces, Win Cy Young Awards
abstract: Arrieta, of the Cubs, and Keuchel, of the Astros, entered the season with a combined record of 55-59 but then led their teams to the division series.
lead_paragraph: Jake Arrieta and Dallas Keuchel reported to spring training in February with a combined career record of 55-59 and zero appearances on Cy Young Award ballots. By the end of the season they were certified aces, lifting their teams to the division series with shutout pitching in the wild-card games.

abstract: While at Salomon Brothers in the 1970s, Mr. Dall oversaw the first sale of bonds backed by American home mortgages to large private investors.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Dall, an investment banker and a pioneer of the mortgage bond market on Wall Street, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 81.

headline: Review: Complexions Contemporary Ballet Performs to Bach and Metallica
abstract: A program by a company with diversity at its heart might benefit from a broader palette in its actual choreography.
lead_paragraph: Complexions Contemporary Ballet, a company formed in 1994 by Dwight Rhoden and Desmond Richardson, has done what, for many midsize companies, remains impossible: It has lasted. But for a troupe named in honor of the multicultural makeup of its dancers, it remains distressingly bland. Where diversity also matters — in its choreography — is where this company falls short. No matter the mood or music, a sequence often repeats in Mr. Rhoden’s pieces: After a running start, a dancer slides onto the stage, strikes an assertive pose and then — as if trapped inside a force field — shifts position by flicking a hip or tossing off a pirouette before retreating to the wings.

headline: Kristaps Porzingis, Wanting More, Gives the Knicks Hope
abstract: Beyond his 7-foot-3-inch frame and his ability to hit 3-pointers, beyond his spin moves and his putback dunks, Porzingis has impressed teammates with his commitment.
lead_paragraph: Long before it took Kristaps Porzingis all of 12 regular-season games to become a sensation with the Knicks, he plied his trade for Baloncesto Sevilla of Spain’s ACB League. As Sevilla’s general manager, José Luis Galilea became uniquely familiar with Porzingis, and he could sense the player’s bright future.

headline: What Presidential Candidates Have Said About the Black Lives Matter Movement

lead_paragraph: What some of the presidential candidates have said about the Black Lives Matter movement.

lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio, seeking to bolster his administration’s efforts on homelessness, unveiled a plan on Wednesday to create 15,000 units of housing aimed at veterans, victims of domestic violence, people with mental illness and others with complex needs that go beyond the economics of paying for a place to live in New York.

headline: With Eviction Looming, an Injured Worker Accelerates His Job Search

headline: Review: In ‘Steve,’ Contemplating Middle Age and Monogamy
abstract: This New Group production, directed by Cynthia Nixon, portrays a group of gay New Yorkers for whom life was once truly a cabaret.
lead_paragraph: Hello, not-so-young lovers, wherever you are. Do you know what Rodgers and Hammerstein show I’m (sort of) quoting there? Even if you don’t (it’s “The King and I”), you’re likely to have a swell time at “Steve,” a surprisingly serious comedy by Mark Gerrard in which no event is so grave or so trivial that it cannot be annotated with a musical comedy reference.

headline: Reviews Reveal Divisions Within the Clinton Health Initiative, Starting at the Top
abstract: Ira C. Magaziner, the chief executive of the Clinton Health Access Initiative, has long alienated co-workers, but a recent performance review reveals board members are also unhappy with him.
lead_paragraph: Inside the sprawling philanthropy founded by former President Bill Clinton, its health initiative, run by a longtime friend and policy adviser to the Clintons, holds a vaunted place, with the largest budget of any program in the foundation and a distinguished record of fighting diseases like AIDS and tuberculosis in underdeveloped countries.

headline: Jonah Lomu, 40, Dies; Rugby Superstar Melded Power and Speed
abstract: Mr. Lomu’s size and strength made him a nearly unstoppable scorer for the New Zealand national team until a kidney disorder forced him into early retirement.
lead_paragraph: Jonah Lomu, whose size, strength and speed made him one of rugby’s most fearsome wings, a record-setting, nearly unstoppable scorer for the All Blacks, New Zealand’s national team, died late Tuesday or early Wednesday at his home in Auckland, New Zealand. He was 40.

headline: California Judge Orders Frozen Embryos Destroyed
abstract: A state court judge in San Francisco on Wednesday ordered the destruction of five frozen embryos after a man challenged his ex-wife’s right to use them.
lead_paragraph: In the first decision in California to address a dispute over the fate of frozen embryos after a couple’s divorce, a state judge in San Francisco on Wednesday ordered the destruction of five embryos after a man challenged his ex-wife’s right to use them.

headline: Stephen Birmingham, Chronicler of the Rich and Other Elites, Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Birmingham was the author of best sellers about a range of social strata and places like the Dakota apartment building.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Birmingham, the prolific novelist, purveyor of popular sociology and raconteur of the rich and famous in best-selling books like “ ‘Our Crowd’: The Great Jewish Families of New York” and “The Right People: A Portrait of the American Social Establishment,” died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86.

headline: F.D.A. Approves a Nasal Spray to Combat Opioid Overdose
abstract: A nasal spray designed to reverse opioid overdoses won approval from the Food and Drug Administration, expanding the options for treating drug overdoses without medical training.
lead_paragraph: A nasal spray designed to reverse opioid overdoses won approval from the Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday, expanding the options for treating drug overdoses without medical training. Until now, all versions of the overdose reversal drug naloxone were injectable. The spray, called Narcan, will make it easier for ordinary people to treat someone who has taken too much oxycodone, morphine or heroin. Adapt Pharma Inc., the company that makes it, said it would offer the spray at a discount to emergency workers, firefighters and the police.

headline: Syria: Truce Near Damascus Is Planned
abstract: Government forces and insurgent factions in the Damascus suburbs planned to announce a Russian-brokered deal for a 15-day cease-fire.
lead_paragraph: Syrian antigovernment activists said Wednesday that government forces and insurgent factions in the Damascus suburbs planned to announce a Russian-brokered deal for a 15-day cease-fire that could begin as soon as Thursday. United Nations officials and international negotiators are trying to hammer out a countrywide cease-fire as world leaders gather in Vienna in an effort to renew peace talks, and it was unclear whether the Russian-brokered effort was separate and parallel, or a step toward reaching a more comprehensive agreement. The Russian involvement was seen as a sign that it now had the upper hand — more so than Iran, President Bashar al-Assad’s closest ally. The truce would cover the East Ghouta suburbs that have been cut off from Damascus by the fighting. The truce would open checkpoints into East Ghouta, allowing humanitarian aid to get in and civilians to leave, according to several antigovernment activists reached in the area.

headline: Group Led by Turing Chief Acquires Majority of Biotech Firm
abstract: Martin Shkreli, known for having raised the price an old drug fiftyfold, has bought more than half of KaloBios’s outstanding shares.
lead_paragraph: Martin Shkreli, the brash pharmaceutical executive whose abrupt fiftyfold increase in the price of an old infectious disease drug sparked an uproar, has acquired a majority of the shares of a publicly traded biotechnology company that was about to go out of business.

keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'National Book Awards', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Mr. Coates won the nonfiction award for “Between the World and Me,” a blunt exploration of being a black man in America, published in the middle of a national dialogue about race relations.
lead_paragraph: Ta-Nehisi Coates won the National Book Award for nonfiction Wednesday night for “Between the World and Me,” a visceral, blunt exploration of his experience of being a black man in America, which was published this summer in the middle of a national dialogue about race relations and inequality.

keywords: ['Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: A series of riveting, raw wiretapped conversations were used to show what was going on behind the scenes as Dean G. Skelos voted on legislation that the government has said would benefit his son.
lead_paragraph: Jurors at the federal corruption trial of the former State Senate majority leader, Dean G. Skelos, and his son listened on Wednesday to a series of riveting, raw and sometimes bizarre wiretapped conversations. Prosecutors played them as part of an effort to show what was going on behind the scenes as the senator voted on legislation and took other actions that the government has said would benefit his son, a situation most of his fellow legislators were not aware of.

headline: Three Conference Finalists Are Fighting to Return to Last Season’s Level

headline: After Paris Attacks, a Slow Reawakening for City’s Cultural Offerings
abstract: Directors say that culture is a form of resistance, but that they are also navigating security concerns that have the city on edge.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — On Wednesday morning, May Zhang, a tourist from Shanghai, was outside the Louvre using a selfie stick to snap photographs with a friend. The courtyard is normally packed with tourists, but they had it mostly to themselves — and to the dozen or more heavily armed police officers pacing in the background.

abstract: What are some of the quirks and challenges that the athletic program at the Culinary Institute of America faces?

headline: What Are Your Thanksgiving Traditions?
abstract: Does your family serve the same meal every year? Do you have any favorite dishes?
lead_paragraph: You might know the Thanksgiving story — of the Pilgrims feasting alongside Native Americans in 1621 after a bountiful corn harvest. But do you know where your own family’s traditions come from, whether you eat turkey, snicker salad or sopapilla cheesecake?

headline: A Foothold on the Lower East Side
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Sarah Sterns wanted a place to live in New York. The studio she found was small, but fit the bare essentials.
lead_paragraph: After graduating from Syracuse University in 2013, Sarah Sterns landed a job in Norwalk, Conn. She rented a studio in a modest brick building in nearby Stamford for a little more than $1,000 a month.

headline: The Doomsday Scam
keywords: ['Bombs and Explosives', 'Terrorism', 'Chemistry', 'Arms Trade', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Smuggling']
abstract: For decades, aspiring bomb makers — including ISIS — have desperately tried to get their hands on a lethal substance called red mercury. There’s a reason that they never have.
lead_paragraph: The hunt for the ultimate weapon began in January 2014, when Abu Omar, a smuggler who fills shopping lists for the Islamic State, met a jihadist commander in Tal Abyad, a Syrian town near the Turkish border. The Islamic State had raised its black flag over Tal Abyad several days before, and the commander, a former cigarette vendor known as Timsah, Arabic for ‘‘crocodile,’’ was the area’s new security chief. The Crocodile had an order to place, which he said he had received from his bosses in Mosul, a city in northwestern Iraq that the Islamic State would later overrun.

headline: A Virtual Reality Revolution, Coming to a Headset Near You
keywords: ['Virtual Reality (Computers)', 'Headphones and Headsets', 'Movies', 'News and News Media', 'Music', 'Television']
abstract: Pioneers in film, journalism, sports and gaming talk about the challenges of building a new art form from the ground up.
lead_paragraph: Virtual reality — once the stuff of science fiction — is still in its infancy. But there’s already a gold rush around the technology, which plunges viewers into a simulated 3-D environment and lets them explore their surroundings as if they were really there.

headline: Offline, D.I.Y. Weddings Aren’t So Picture Perfect
abstract: A craze that started with home repair sees couples working hard for a personalized wedding.
lead_paragraph: For those couples who like to exhibit their inner Michelangelo or Martha Stewart, weddings have become festivals of do-it-yourself creativity. But in the days leading up to the event, a couple’s desire for those artisanal touches can come at a cost in lost hours and increased anxiety.

headline: U.S. Investigators Struggle to Track Homegrown ISIS Suspects
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Social Media', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)']
abstract: Many in the United States who are believed to have Islamic State ties have never visited Syria, and thwarting them is like trying to prevent a school shooting.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At least three dozen people in the United States suspected of ties to the Islamic State were under heavy electronic or physical surveillance even before the Paris attacks, senior American officials say. But unlike the attackers in France, the officials say, the majority of those under investigation here never traveled to Syria to fight alongside the Islamic State or receive training from it.

headline: Punk Portraits of New York
abstract: William Coupon’s classic style started out in an chaotic place: the Mudd Club. He slowed things down to the pace of formal portraiture, taking the circus out of the tent.
lead_paragraph: William Coupon photographed Ronald Reagan and he photographed Lydia Lunch, both in the same way: against a backdrop of hand-painted Belgian linen, side-lit by a single fixture. For three and a half decades, he has varied little from this method, whether working in the Oval Office or the tribal regions of the Amazon rain forest. “It’s the classic medium shot, chiaroscuro light,” Mr. Coupon, 62, said the other day, describing his method and mission. “I knew if I focused on other subcultures I could hit on a range of people. I thought, I want to photograph everyone in the world.”

headline: A Quarterback’s New Role
abstract: Clint Trickett, a former West Virginia quarterback who was forced to retire because of a number of concussions, is the quarterbacks coach of a top junior college team in Mississippi.
lead_paragraph: Clint Trickett, a former West Virginia quarterback who was forced to retire because of a number of concussions, is the quarterbacks coach of a top junior college team in Mississippi.

headline: Concussions Ended His Football Dreams. Now, at 24, He Helps Others Achieve Theirs.
abstract: Clint Trickett, a former West Virginia quarterback, had to stop playing college football, but he still loves the game, coaching at a community college in Mississippi.
lead_paragraph: SCOOBA, Miss. — For months, reporters have called Clint Trickett wanting to talk about football and, more specifically, about football safety. Some called soon after he announced his retirement as a player last December, when he revealed that he had sustained five concussions in 14 months in the previous two seasons as West Virginia’s starting quarterback — the last one a year ago Friday. Others have called more recently, prompted by the coming release of the film “Concussion,” in which Will Smith plays the doctor who helped identify a degenerative brain disease linked to repeated head trauma.

headline: Paris Attacks Suspect Killed in Shootout Had Plotted Terror for 11 Months
abstract: Abdelhamid Abaaoud is believed to have organized a string of attacks that made him the most talked-about — and, in jihadist circles, feted — terrorist since Osama bin Laden.
lead_paragraph: VERVIERS, Belgium — Black smudges and faded traces of gunfire on a red brick rowhouse here in eastern Belgium mark the death foretold of Abdelhamid Abaaoud. It is the spot where, 11 months before the announcement on Thursday that he had been killed outside Paris, he began plotting an elaborate campaign of terror across Europe.

headline: Hillary Clinton Presents Her Plan to Battle ISIS
keywords: ['Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Terrorism', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mrs. Clinton will deliver an in-depth speech on Thursday at the Council on Foreign Relations in New York about her national security proposals and how she would combat the Islamic State in Syria and Iraq.
lead_paragraph: Republican presidential candidates wasted no time after the terrorist attacks in Paris to put forth their ideas for fighting the Islamic State. They’ve proposed bombing oil fields in the Middle East (Donald J. Trump), allowing only Christian refugees into the United States (Senator Ted Cruz of Texas) and sending 10,000 American troops to Iraq and Syria (Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina).

keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration']

lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Croatia, Macedonia and Serbia have started screening migrants and refugees on the basis of nationality and allowing entry only to those from Afghanistan, Iraq or Syria, the United Nations refugee agency said on Thursday.

lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont will be channeling Franklin D. Roosevelt more than Eugene V. Debs on Thursday afternoon as he delivers the most important speech of his bid for the Democratic presidential nomination: an attempt to demystify Democratic Socialism, his long-held political philosophy, and tie it to his vision of America.

headline: An Unlikely Tourist Attraction in Poland: Storks
abstract: Following the trail of white storks through northeast Poland, where almost three-quarters of them live, offers an opportunity to explore the area’s history, wildlife and landscapes.
lead_paragraph: About a half-mile from the Russian border, hidden in the rolling hills of northernmost Poland, is the tiny village of Zywkowo, population 25 humans and 43 pairs of nesting white storks. It is one of the country’s largest stork breeding colonies — their massive, tousled nests dot chimneys, rooftops and specially made platforms. They are wedged into tree branches and balanced above electrical wires.

headline: Review: ‘The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 2,’ Katniss’s Final Battle
abstract: Jennifer Lawrence returns in the savior role in the closing chapter of this blockbuster series based on Suzanne Collins’s books.
lead_paragraph: There’s no risk that Katniss Everdeen, the warrior who has led the charge against oppression in “The Hunger Games” movies, can ever return to her current incarnation. Even if she and her world are rebooted back into franchise existence by a ravenous studio, her moment was now. Katniss, as played by Jennifer Lawrence over three years and four blockbusters, has evolved from a backwoods scrapper in the first movie into a battle-scarred champion and an exemplar of female power on screen and off — and the battles she’s fought have extended far beyond the fictional nation of Panem.

headline: Running Away With the Circus
abstract: On the road with Ringling Brothers at the end of an era.
lead_paragraph: Just for the sake of argument, consider the Ringling Brothers Circus of the year 1890, roughly 17 years before it became the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus. That year, you could see Anzo, the Human Serpent, slither on the ground. You could see the La Role brothers, Chris and Harry, the two ‘‘Flying Men of the Air,’’ and the wondrous Nellie on her airborne trapeze. You could see Edward Billings, the King of the High Stilts, as he confounded audience members with his height and balance, and watch the ‘‘educated’’ horses ridden two at a time by one man. You could see Barretta, the Boneless Wonder, whom, years before, a young Winston Churchill had begged in vain to see. (According to Boris Johnson’s biography, ‘‘The Churchill Factor,’’ his parents decided the sight would be ‘‘too demoralizing and revolting’’ for a child.)

headline: Geert Wilders: Let the Dutch Vote on Immigration Policy
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: The will of the people is being subverted. The only solution is a direct referendum on refugee policy.
lead_paragraph: The Hague — The first thing France did after last Friday’s terrorist attacks in Paris was to temporarily close its borders. It was a wise move. The attacks showed just how unsafe Europe has become as a result of the European Union’s open border policies and decades of foolish decisions by governments across the Continent to open their doors to mass immigration from Islamic countries.

headline: To Stop Radicalization, the French Need More Fraternité
abstract: If France is going to defeat ISIS, it will have to find solutions for the alienation and seclusion felt by its own Muslim citizens.
lead_paragraph: AS a security professional with counterterrorism experience, I understand the threat posed by religious extremism. As a former Secret Service agent who has taught about radicalization to the C.I.A., the N.S.A., the Department of Homeland Security and the United States military, I have seen up close how Muslims are treated in European society, especially French society.

headline: Leaders of France and Belgium Seek Tougher Security Measures
abstract: Prime Minister Manuel Valls of France said citizens expected “strong, quick and effective reactions’’ in the wake of the terror attacks in Paris.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The prime ministers of France and Belgium sought additional authority on Thursday to respond to the deadly attacks in Paris last week, with Manuel Valls saying the French people want “strong, quick and effective reactions,” and Charles Michel of Belgium asking Parliament to approve a variety of tough new security measures.

And over the years, the video site has increased its policing of pirated material. But too often, the company says, the demands of copyright holders to take down videos go too far.

abstract: The F.D.A. approval clears the way for the first genetically altered animal to enter the American food supply, despite strong opposition.
lead_paragraph: Federal regulators on Thursday approved a genetically engineered salmon as fit for consumption, making it the first genetically altered animal to be cleared for American supermarkets and dinner tables.

headline: 5 Killed in Tel Aviv and West Bank by Palestinian Attackers

lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Five people were killed on Thursday in two stabbing and shooting attacks carried out by Palestinian assailants in Tel Aviv and the West Bank, according to the Israeli authorities, in a renewed burst of deadly violence that came after a few days of relative calm.

headline: World Powers Try Anew for Syria Cease-Fire, but Path Is Tortuous
abstract: Even efforts at a local truce faltered; a nationwide cease-fire would have to be brokered by the very countries backing opposing sides in Syria’s war.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The skies over Syria are crowded with foreign warplanes. Tens of thousands of civilians are on the run. The Islamic State has executed terrorist attacks on three continents in three weeks.

lead_paragraph: For many young companies, the potential of being valued at $2.9 billion by Wall Street investors would be a good thing. But when you already have been valued by private investors at $6 billion — at least on paper — it might be a bit of a comedown.

headline: ‘American Horror Story’ Season 5, Episode 7: Gods and Monsters
abstract: Old Hollywood features prominently in this week’s episode.
lead_paragraph: This week on “American Horror Story: Hotel,” the grand mystery of The Countess was revealed to be quite a common Hollywood story: a young woman came out West, fell in with a bad crowd, and never was the same again. Add polyamory, a vampire romance, and an unfortunate tango number, and you’ve got “Flickers.”

headline: 1940: Samaria Docks After a Scare
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A liner docks after a scare in 1940.
lead_paragraph: The Cunard White Star liner Samaria, her gray hull and super-structure melting into the gray sea, was two days out of Liverpool, without escort, on Nov. 10 when the rhythmic sound of plane motors far off brought her passengers racing to their lifeboat stations, their lifebelts adjusted, eyes fixated on the approaching specks. The next day the passengers learned from the ship’s officers that German bombers had attacked another ship, twenty minutes’ flying time from the Samaria, and had been driven off. The other ship was not identified. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 20, 1940

headline: Philippine Officials Suspect Severed Head Belongs to Kidnap Victim

lead_paragraph: MANILA — Philippine military officials have not yet confirmed the identity of a man whose severed head was left in a bag in front of a police station this week, but they continue to suspect that it was from a kidnapped Malaysian man who was said to have been beheaded by militants.

headline: Golden State Warriors Close In on Longest Perfect Start
abstract: The Warriors, led by Stephen Curry, are 12-0 and have the 1993-94 Rockets, who were 15-0, in their sights.
lead_paragraph: The Golden State Warriors continue to torch the rest of the N.B.A. At 12-0, they are closing in on the record for the longest perfect start, and the biggest hurdle on the way is probably Thursday night against the Clippers.

headline: Women and Blacks Make Little Progress at Big Law Firms

headline: Michael Gross, Who Designed the ‘Ghostbusters’ Logo, Dies at 70
abstract: Mr. Gross, a graphic designer and film producer, created several famous covers for National Lampoon magazine.
lead_paragraph: Michael C. Gross, a graphic designer and film producer who created the logo for the 1984 movie “Ghostbusters” and a series of unforgettable parody covers for National Lampoon magazine, where he was an art director in the early 1970s, died on Monday at his home in Oceanside, Calif. He was 70.

headline: ‘Empire’ Season 2, Episode 8: Hakeem, No Lyon
abstract: Rap battle!
lead_paragraph: Each episode of “Empire” carries forth the show’s permanent, ambient theme: the scrimmage for every player’s control of the family name. So far in its sophomore season, nimble corporate defection has been the primary course by which Cookie, Hakeem and Lucious have made their harried grabs for Lyon supremacy. As if an ode to vintage season one “Empire,” this week saw the family scramble situate itself squarely in the arena that started it all: the music.

headline: 1965: An Independent British Guiana
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: British Guiana announces its independence in 1965.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British government announced today [Nov. 19] that British Guiana will become independent on May 26 and will be known as Guyana. Colonial Secretary Anthony Greenwood said that Guyana will ask for Commonwealth membership. The new country, in South America, will remain a monarchy with a governor-general appointed by Queen Elizabeth. Mr. Greenwood said Britain would be very happy to consult other Commonwealth members on admitting Guyana to membership and would be willing to sponsor Guyana’s membership at the United Nations. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 20, 1965

abstract: A week after officials at the University of Missouri resigned amid protests and claims of widespread racism, Donald J. Trump called those who stepped down “babies” and said he did not think that discrimination was a problem on the campus.

headline: By Chloe Gets Poetic With Vegan in the West Village
abstract: The Bleecker Street restaurant is run by Chloe Coscarelli, a star chef.
lead_paragraph: Allen Ginsberg once lived in a flophouse up the block for $2 a night. He used to loiter on this corner of Bleecker and Macdougal Streets back when it was home to Cafe Borgia, hung with shields of armor and portraits of supposed Borgia family poisoners.

abstract: Readers discuss why New York City’s mayor is polling poorly among whites.

headline: An Invigorating End to Thanksgiving
abstract: After those final few bites have filled whatever space remains, it’s the perfect moment for a resuscitating digestif, or digestivo.
lead_paragraph: First comes the buildup, and then the feast. And then?

headline: Adele Is Said to Reject Streaming for ‘25’
keywords: ['Music', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: The album, “25,’’ being released Friday, is the artist’s first in almost five years.
lead_paragraph: For Adele’s legions of fans, as well as for the music industry at large, a big question has hung over the release of “25,” her first album in nearly five years. The album is all but certain to be a gigantic hit, but would Adele make it available for streaming on services like Spotify and Apple Music?

headline: Taubman Sales Sag Again
abstract: Martin Johnson Heade’s “Great Florida Sunset” sold for $5.9 million, more than double the artist’s auction record — but less than the estimate.
lead_paragraph: The Alfred A. Taubman collection again brought disappointing results for Sotheby’s, which guaranteed the sales for $515 million.

headline: Police Officer Is Shot Dead in Los Angeles County
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Attacks on Police', 'Robberies and Thefts']
abstract: An officer in Downey was shot in the parking lot of the police department. Los Angeles sheriff’s deputies have one suspect in custody while a hunt continues for two others.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A police officer in Downey, about a dozen miles southeast of here, was shot and killed outside the city police department late Wednesday night in what law enforcement officials said was a “botched robbery attempt.”

headline: The Times’s Reviews of National Book Award Winners
abstract: Looking back at reviews of Ta-Nehisi Coates’s “Between the World and Me” and Adam Johnson’s “Fortune Smiles.”
lead_paragraph: Ta-Nehisi Coates and Adam Johnson were two of the big winners at Wednesday night’s National Book Awards ceremony. Mr. Coates’s “Between the World and Me,” one of the year’s top-selling and most-discussed books, won the award for nonfiction.

lead_paragraph: Cindy Holland is the person at Netflix responsible for supplying the world with addictive entertainment.

abstract: In response to a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit by The New York Times, the National Security Agency released these documents on November 10. They largely consist of inspector general reports related to the NSA’s defunct bulk e-mail records collection program.
lead_paragraph: In response to a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit by The New York Times, the National Security Agency released these documents on November 10. They largely consist of inspector general reports related to the NSA’s defunct bulk e-mail records collection program.

headline: ‘Miss Saigon’ Returning to Broadway
abstract: Cameron Mackintosh, the storied British producer best known for bringing the megahits “Cats,” “Les Misérables” and “The Phantom of the Opera” to New York, said he planned to present a revival of “Miss Saigon” on Broadway in the spring of 2017.
lead_paragraph: “Miss Saigon” is helicoptering back to Broadway.

headline: Cindy Holland of Netflix: Learning to Lead on a Pair of Water Skis
keywords: ['Executives and Management (Theory)', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Careers and Professions', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Television']
