lead_paragraph: This interview with Cindy Holland, vice president for original content at Netflix, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Match Shares Gain on Their Debut
keywords: ['Initial Public Offerings', 'Mobile Commerce and Payments', 'Online Dating']
abstract: “There were factors that made us pay a heavier I.P.O. discount,” says the company’s chairman.
lead_paragraph: The Match Group enjoyed a respectable pop in its debut as a publicly traded company on Thursday, despite both a difficult market for initial public offerings and an ill-timed interview by the head of its Tinder dating app.

headline: UnitedHealth Lowers Forecast, Blaming Affordable Care Act
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicare']
abstract: Citing weak growth in the numbers of new people signing up for coverage, the company said it was reducing its earnings estimates for 2015 and 2016.
lead_paragraph: UnitedHealth Group, one of the nation’s largest health insurance companies, stunned investors on Thursday morning when it significantly lowered its profit estimates, placing the blame for an expected loss of hundreds of millions of dollars on selling individual policies under the federal health care law.

headline: More Mexican Immigrants Leaving U.S. Than Entering, Report Finds
abstract: The Pew Research Center found that from 2009 to 2014, about a million Mexicans returned home as 870,000 arrived in the United States, marking an end to a wave of immigration.
lead_paragraph: More immigrants from Mexico are leaving the United States than coming into the country, according to a report published Thursday by the Pew Research Center, a finding that indicates the end of the largest wave of immigration from a single country in American history.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Carol'
abstract: Todd Haynes narrates a sequence from his film featuring Cate Blanchett and Rooney Mara.
lead_paragraph: Todd Haynes narrates a sequence from his film featuring Cate Blanchett and Rooney Mara.

headline: How to Cope With Anxiety During Terror Threats
abstract: Experts offer advice for coping with stress caused by a recent spate of terror attacks and violence.
lead_paragraph: Recent headlines remind psychologists of the anxiety and fear that followed the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline: Review: ‘Carol’ Explores the Sweet Science of Magnetism
abstract: Two women fall in love in this new film from Todd Haynes, based on the Patricia Highsmith novel “The Price of Salt.”
lead_paragraph: Mutual attraction may be central to our notion of love, but it is a curiously rare occurrence in art, which tends to split desire into subject and object. Poetry traces a vector from lover to beloved. (“Shall I compare thee to a summer’s day?”) In painting and sculpture, the eye of the beholder lingers on the face and body of the beheld. Students of film are schooled in the erotic power of the gaze, and readers of romance fiction know the seductions of the first-person narrative and the free indirect style, which concentrate lust and longing within a single consciousness. (“Reader, I married him.”)

headline: Massachusetts Attorney General Proposes Fantasy Sports Regulations
abstract: The proposals by Maura Healey of Massachusetts, where DraftKings is based, include protecting minors and leveling the playing field for all participants.
lead_paragraph: The Massachusetts attorney general proposed regulations on Thursday for daily fantasy sports companies to operate in the state, including raising the age minimum for participants and excluding college sports.

headline: 36 Hours in Montreal
abstract: Whether you want to embrace the season on rinks, trails or runs, or dodge the cold and head to the spa, this vibrant city has it all.
lead_paragraph: Whether you want to embrace the season on rinks, trails or runs, or dodge the cold and head to the spa, this vibrant city has it all.

headline: 1871 | ‘The Paris Agony’
abstract: Paris has borne witness to some of the darkest hours of modern history. And The New York Times has chronicled those dreadful events.
lead_paragraph: It takes nothing away from the devastation of the past week’s events in Paris to recall that the city — when not viewed through a postcard kaleidoscope — is no stranger to horror.

headline: A Feast at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum
abstract: Barbara Lynch ends her stay as an artist in residence at the Boston museum with an art-inspired meal.
lead_paragraph: Barbara Lynch ends her stay as an artist in residence at the Boston museum with an art-inspired meal.

headline: Hillary Clinton Goes Beyond President Obama in Plan to Defeat ISIS
abstract: Mrs. Clinton called for speeding up the American-led operations against the Islamic State including a no-fly zone and more airstrikes.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton called on Thursday for accelerating the American-led operation to defeat the Islamic State, going well beyond what President Obama has proposed by urging a no-fly zone with coalition forces to protect Syrians, more airstrikes and an expanded deployment of special operations troops to assist local ground forces.

headline: Black Woman’s Account Puts Spotlight on Santa Monica Police
abstract: The internal affairs unit has opened an inquiry, and the police chief has responded to her essay about being treated as a burglar in her own home.
lead_paragraph: In September, Fay Wells, a corporate executive, arrived home to her apartment in Santa Monica and discovered that she had locked herself out.

headline: The Five Stages of Ghosting Grief
abstract: A woman dives into the confusing vacuum created by an unanswered text.
lead_paragraph: At 6:30 a.m. I was blow-drying my hair, getting ready for work and accepting the demise of my two-week relationship. The nail in the coffin was that at 10 the night before I had texted him something vaguely sexual, and he hadn’t texted back.

headline: At Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum, Art on the Walls, and on the Plates
abstract: The chef and restaurateur Barbara Lynch ends her stay as an artist in residence at the Boston museum with an art-inspired feast.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — When Barbara Lynch, one of this city’s premier chefs and most prominent restaurateurs, stood before an animated portrait of Isabella Stewart Gardner, Boston’s beloved patron of the arts, she saw food.

headline: Thanksgiving Guest List Woes
keywords: ['Thanksgiving Day', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Social Media', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments']
abstract: Plus: What to do when social media takes on the boss; handling an invitee who changes her mind; setting rules for a boorish house guest.
lead_paragraph: My brother and his wife are divorcing. My sister-in-law usually holds Thanksgiving, but this year I am, due to their circumstances. My brother said he will “give up” the holiday and we should invite his wife and children. (He is seeing another woman and probably wants to spend the day with her. Meanwhile, my sister-in-law has been texting me about his infidelity. Too weird!) I like my sister-in-law, but she’s not family. But if I don’t invite her, we won’t see the kids. I told my brother they should all come, but he was noncommittal. Ideas?

headline: Baryshnikov to Perform at His Arts Center for First Time Since 2010
abstract: Mikhail Baryshnikov will perform in “Brodsky /Baryshnikov” at the Baryshnikov Arts Center in March.
lead_paragraph: Mikhail Baryshnikov, who has performed all over the world during the last four years, will appear at his own Baryshnikov Arts Center for the first time since 2010, from March 9 to 19. He will perform in the United States premiere of “Brodsky/Baryshnikov,” a previously announced work that is part of the center’s spring season, which was announced on Thursday.

headline: House Approves Tougher Refugee Screening, Defying Veto Threat
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Terrorism', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'United States International Relations', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Lawmakers voted overwhelmingly to impose stringent new screening procedures on people from Syria and Iraq seeking resettlement in the United States.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House voted overwhelmingly Thursday to drastically tighten screening procedures on refugees from Syria, seizing on the creeping fear stemming from the Paris attacks and threatening to undermine President Obama’s Middle East policy.

headline: Restaurant Review: At Orama, in Edgewater, a Feast for the Eyes
abstract: At this fine-dining restaurant, which offers stunning décor and views of a twinkling New York City skyline, seafood is the strong suit.
lead_paragraph: Orama instantly wows. The fine-dining restaurant in Edgewater occupies a bi-level Mediterranean-style villa on the Hudson River, and offers views of a twinkling New York City skyline.

headline: Obama and Trudeau Meet in Manila
abstract: President Obama and the newly elected prime minister of Canada, Justin Trudeau, met for the first time on Thursday in the Philippines ahead of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit.
lead_paragraph: President Obama and the newly elected prime minister of Canada, Justin Trudeau, met for the first time on Thursday in the Philippines ahead of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit.

headline: Ruben Brulat’s “Commencements”
abstract: The photographer’s newest body of work comprises self-portraits taken in 130-degree heat in Africa’s Danakil Depression.
lead_paragraph: The photographer’s newest body of work comprises self-portraits taken in 130-degree heat in Africa’s Danakil Depression.

headline: High Risk and Low Benefit in Pfizer’s Pursuit of Allergan
abstract: Buying Allergan would give the drug giant a low-tax domicile in Ireland and one good drug, Botox. But Allergan would accrue nearly all of the upside.
lead_paragraph: Pfizer’s $150 billion Botox gamble is a high-risk, low-benefit deal.

headline: Self-Portraits of a Naked Adventurer
abstract: For his new “Commencements” series, debuting here, the photographer Ruben Brulat braved 130-degree temperatures at remote African lava lakes.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Ruben Brulat was traveling alone through Iceland in 2009 when, in the midst of setting up his camp, he was arrested by the beauty of a rock perched on the mountainside, almost ready to fall from among the clouds seemingly wrapped around its peak. Setting up his camera on a timer, Brulat followed his senses and captured himself lying naked in the primal elements. It was a transformative moment, and it started him on his projects “Primates,” “Paths” and now, seen here for the first time, “Commencements.”

headline: Tie Domi Moves From Penalty Box to Arena Suite, Watching His Son’s Blossoming Career
abstract: Domi, who recently published a memoir about his long career as an N.H.L. enforcer, is enjoying life as a fan as his son Max plays his rookie season with the Arizona Coyotes.
lead_paragraph: Intensely watching his son, Max, battle the Islanders this week, Tie Domi was temporarily distracted when a fellow Canadian appeared in his Barclays Center suite.

headline: When Medicine Reverses Itself
abstract: The “medical reversal,” in which long-accepted practices are disproven by later trials, can lead to dreaded moments in the exam room.
lead_paragraph: The boy in the emergency room sat, swinging his legs. He smiled as I examined him, despite having a fever and a throb in his ear. Crouching at his side, I could see through the otoscope an angry drum, bulging and red — mystery solved.

headline: Readers, and Starwood, React to Starwood Customer Agitation
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: After customers expressed concerns about the Marriott acquisition, Starwood sent one of them a cake with the message “We Still Care.”
lead_paragraph: After my article ran about Marriott International’s acquisition of Starwood Hotels and Resorts, and how upset it has made some frequent Starwood customers, Starwood sent a message to a frequent customer, Charley Cullen Walters: “We still care.”

headline: Economic Fallout of Paris Attacks Hits Hotels Hard
abstract: Executives in the hospitality industry are taking stock of the potential losses as cancellations surge.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The first wave of canceled reservations struck Le Bristol with crushing force after last weekend’s terrorist attacks, across town from the five-star hotel and its elite Right Bank neighborhood. Within 72 hours, the tally of lost bookings exceeded a half-million euros — more than $530,000.

headline: Restaurant Review: The Seductive Spices and Aromas of India at Indigo
abstract: The restaurant in Manchester, Conn., offers a tour of Indian cuisine with the usual favorites and even some fusion dishes.
lead_paragraph: Someday, the culinary trickle-down will bring to the hinterlands the same creativity of Indian cuisine in the metropolis, exemplified in such boundary-blurring concoctions as duck confit samosas or crab cakes wrapped in tamarind-glazed papadums. But for now, we still have chicken tikka masala, lamb saag and the other traditional favorites. And with these dishes, you will do superbly at Indigo Indian Bistro in Manchester.

headline: A New Threat to Your Retirement
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Law and Legislation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Vetoes (US)']
abstract: Proposed legislation could derail a rule requiring retirement advisers to act in their clients’ best interests.
lead_paragraph: In April, the Labor Department proposed an important rule designed to protect Americans’ retirement savings by requiring advisers to act in their clients’ best interests — and not their own. As things stand now, brokers, insurance agents and other salespeople — who often call themselves “consultants” or “advisers” — are allowed to steer clients into high-priced products and strategies when comparable and cheaper ones are available.

headline: Use of High-Tech Brooms Divides Low-Tech Sport of Curling
abstract: Worried that directional fabric in broom pads makes redirecting the stone too easy, the World Curling Federation set new rules on the types of brooms that can be used.
lead_paragraph: Curling, the ice sport with brooms, is roiled in controversy over — what else? — the brooms.

headline: 10 American Cities Chosen for Copa América Next Summer
abstract: Boston, New York, Philadelphia, Orlando, Chicago, Houston, Phoenix, Los Angeles, San Francisco and Seattle will host games.
lead_paragraph: Next summer’s Copa América Centenario soccer tournament, which will feature 16 teams from the Americas and several of the world’s best players, will take place in 10 cities in the United States.

headline: Bernie Sanders, Confronting Concerns, Makes Case for Electability
abstract: The senator from Vermont made a rare formal address to explain his democratic socialism and argue that its principles reflect mainstream American values.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont aggressively confronted voter concerns about his electability as president on Thursday, making a rare formal address to explain his left-wing ideology of democratic socialism and argue that its principles reflected mainstream American values like fairness and equality.

headline: Jared Fogle, Former Subway Pitchman, Gets 15-Year Prison Term
abstract: Mr. Fogle pleaded guilty to sex acts with minors and distribution of child pornography.
lead_paragraph: Jared Fogle, the former pitchman for the Subway sandwich chain, was sentenced on Thursday to more than 15 years in prison after pleading guilty to sex acts with minors and distribution of child pornography.

headline: Backing Up iCloud Contacts
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Cloud Computing', 'Windows (Operating System)', 'Identification Devices', 'Biometrics']
abstract: You can back up the an address book as a vCard file and import it back into the cloud if disaster strikes.
lead_paragraph: Q. Is there a way to back up the contact files that I sync between my computers and iCloud?

headline: Buffett’s Grandson Seeks Own Investment Route: Social Change
abstract: Hoping to build on his family’s legacy, Howard Warren Buffett has co-founded i(x) Investments to put capital to work in ways he hopes will improve the world.
lead_paragraph: At 32, Howard Warren Buffett, the grandson of the Berkshire Hathaway founder Warren E. Buffett, has already enjoyed a diverse career.

headline: Parasites Found to Influence Fertility in Women
abstract: Among indigenous people in Bolivia, women were likely to have more children if they were infected with roundworms
lead_paragraph: Infection with parasitic worms may boost or reduce a woman’s fertility, researchers reported in the journal Science.

headline: Aurel Schmidt’s “Blast Furnace of Civilization”
abstract: The artist opens a small show of drawings and ceramics that explores themes of capitalism.
lead_paragraph: The artist opens a small show of drawings and ceramics that explores themes of capitalism.

headline: An Artist Takes on the Marketing Machine
abstract: Aurel Schmidt presents a new show, “Blast Furnace of Civilization,” that deals with subjects of capitalism.
lead_paragraph: When she began the work for her new show, the artist Aurel Schmidt focused on capitalism — and, particularly, how objects are marketed to the masses. “I am interested in the strange, mutant, man-made objects we buy, we touch, we orbit our identities around,” she tells T in an email. “How they are presented to us, the way they are sold, the images of the objects online — flat and bright — or in stores, pretending to be things they are not.”

headline: Venice Beach’s Influx of Trendy Outsiders
abstract: On Abbot Kinney Boulevard, local institutions are joined by hip new outposts originally from Oakland, Portland and New York City.
lead_paragraph: Just under a mile from Venice Beach and its winding boardwalk, the once-destitute stretch of Abbot Kinney Boulevard has emerged as a buzzy destination with indie shops, luxe fashion boutiques and eateries. Since Gjelina opened there in 2008, its artisanal pizzas have helped draw in a steady crowd of locals, low-key hipsters, fashionable bohos and intrigued out-of-towners. Just this year, the restaurant released a cookbook and introduced Gjusta, an equally popular bakery, deli, smokehouse, coffee and juice bar next door. (Over the summer, the “Top Chef” alum Nyesha Arrington began serving lamb-belly won tons and wakame-cured hamachi out of the new rustic-chic dining room at Leona, on a nearby street. And not far away, and a month later, the charming restaurant-retail storefront Dudley Market opened its doors, selling utilitarian handmade goods, from minimalist ceramics to artistic cutting boards, alongside gourmet pantry offerings.)

headline: Thanksgiving and Christmas Meals at New York Area Restaurants
abstract: Establishments on Long Island are gearing up to serve those who savor special occasions, but not doing the dishes.
lead_paragraph: With the holidays approaching, many home cooks are gathering provisions and getting ready to braise, baste and roast.

headline: N.F.L. Week 11 Previews and Picks
abstract: The most intriguing matchup of Week 11 is between two also-rans, the Cowboys and the Dolphins, which features the return of quarterback Tony Romo.
lead_paragraph: There are still two unbeaten teams, but the most intriguing game of N.F.L. Week 11 is a matchup between also-rans that gets a big boost from the return of a star quarterback.

headline: Clive Barnes Award Nominees Are Named
abstract: Two of the nominated dancers are from the corps of American Ballet Theater and three of the five actors nominated are from Deaf West Theater’s Broadway revival from “Spring Awakening.”
lead_paragraph: Nominees have been announced for the 2015 Clive Barnes Award, which honors young artists in theater and dance.

headline: Attacks in Tel Aviv and West Bank Kill 5
abstract: Five people were killed in two separate attacks, in Tel Aviv and Gush Etzion, in what the Israeli police called terrorist acts.
lead_paragraph: Five people were killed in two separate attacks, in Tel Aviv and Gush Etzion, in what the Israeli police called terrorist acts.

headline: Black on Campus
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Discrimination', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Students protesting racial insensitivity at Purdue University in Indiana showed solidarity with similar demonstrations at the University of Missouri and Yale.
lead_paragraph: Students protesting racial insensitivity at Purdue University in Indiana showed solidarity with similar demonstrations at the University of Missouri and Yale.

headline: Muslims Defend Islam From Being Hijacked by ISIS
abstract: The attacks in Paris that killed 129 people were not the work of Muslims, many say, adding that they see it as their responsibility to defend their religion.
lead_paragraph: Muslims around the world who have condemned the deadly attacks in Paris carried out by militants of the Islamic State are speaking out to defend their religion.

headline: 2 Election Lawyers to Study Impact of ‘Super PACs’ on ’16 Race
abstract: Two election lawyers — Bob Bauer, a Democrat, and Ben Ginsberg, a Republican — will lead a research project with major universities to determine the impact of “super PACs” on the 2016 presidential race.
lead_paragraph: “Super PACs,” the outside groups that can raise unlimited funds but can’t coordinate with candidates they support, have unquestionably had an impact on the 2016 presidential race. But to what extent and in what ways is not yet clear.

headline: Google Picks Diane Greene to Expand Its Cloud Business
abstract: Ms. Greene, a Silicon Valley veteran, has been a board member of Google and founded Bebop Technologies, which Google has agreed to buy.
lead_paragraph: Google is playing catch-up in the booming cloud computing market, well behind the early leader, Amazon. But on Thursday, Google made clear that it was ready to go on the offensive.

headline: Classical Playlist: Villegas, Praetorius, and Boulez’s Mozart
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: ‘Americano’Pablo Villegas, guitar(Harmonia Mundi)This charismatic Spanish guitarist offers repertory from the Americas, including works by Villa-Lobos, Augustín Lara, John Williams, Bernstein (excerpts from “West Side Story”) and lesser-known composers including Luiz Bonfá. Throughout, Mr. Villegas’s virtuosic playing is characterized by its vividly shaded colors and his irresistible exuberance, contrasted with the intimacy he conveys in the more introverted sections. The disc concludes with some foot-tapping bluegrass selections, performed with the guitarist James Chirillo. (Vivien Schweitzer)

headline: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: Sweet Potato Pockets
abstract: Enjoy all the flavors of Thanksgiving — except the turkey — in these cute potato pockets.
lead_paragraph: We have heard from a number of vegans and vegetarians that they often bring their own food to holiday events to be sure something will be served that they can eat.

headline: Review: ‘Drone’ Documentary Examines a New Weapon
abstract: The filmmaker Tonje Hessen Schei looks at the morality and consequences of armed drone use.
lead_paragraph: This probably isn’t the best moment to find a receptive audience for a film that questions the American use of drone strikes in the war on terror. Regardless of whether armed drones would have been useful countering the attacks in Paris, those events have many people locked into a “whatever it takes” mentality when it comes to fighting extremism.

headline: Which Is More Dangerous, M.M.A. or Boxing?
abstract: A study found that although combatants in the octagon get hurt more often, their counterparts in the boxing ring suffer more severe injuries.
lead_paragraph: It’s a question fans of combat sports have long grappled over: What is more dangerous, mixed martial arts or boxing?

headline: After Paris Attacks, Anxiety Returns to the Surface in New York
abstract: Concerns that a catastrophic event at the hands of terrorists could strike the city were revived by the terrorism in France.
lead_paragraph: On a June night in 1919, followers of the anarchist Luigi Galleani set off bombs in New York, Boston, Pittsburgh and other major United States cities in a series of coordinated attacks directed at prominent civic figures, some of whom had supported the deportation of immigrants suspected of engaging in illegal activity.

headline: Review: Juilliard Opera’s Timely Double Bill
abstract: Works by Francis Poulenc and Viktor Ullmann are both lunatic satirical responses to the carnage of World War II.
lead_paragraph: The Juilliard Opera folks could not have known, when they programmed their current double bill, how appropriate it would be at a time of escalating international terrorism. Francis Poulenc’s “Les Mamelles de Tiresias” (“The Breasts of Tiresias,” 1947) and Viktor Ullmann’s “Der Kaiser von Atlantis, Oder der Tod Dankt Ab” (“The Emperor of Atlantis, or Death Abdicates,” 1943), though contrasting in style and mood, are both lunatic satirical responses to the carnage of World War II.

headline: Michel Houellebecq: How France’s Leaders Failed Its People
abstract: The attacks of Nov. 13 would not have happened if the government hadn’t let down its guard.
lead_paragraph: Paris — IN the aftermath of the January attacks in Paris, I spent two days transfixed watching the news. In the aftermath of the Nov. 13 attacks, I hardly turned on the television; I just called the people I knew (no small number) who lived in the neighborhoods that were hit. You get used to terrorist attacks.

headline: In L.A., Female Video Artists Reign
abstract: Solo exhibitions in the city by three women explore the medium in very different ways.
lead_paragraph: Video-based art is having a moment among women in Los Angeles. Three female artists with solo exhibitions on view there this fall aim to shift perceptions of the medium’s potential, using it to capture everything from Op Art-like abstractions to provocative depictions of animal life. Diana Thater, whose career-spanning show opens next week at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, posits that the appeal of video for women might come from the medium’s relative newness — there are no old masters glowering from the textbook pages. “Women could enter into it without this art-historical legacy,” Thater says. “There is no male-dominated history, so there’s more freedom.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
abstract: France and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: France and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: David Bowie Debuts Dark 10-Minute ‘Blackstar’ Video
abstract: The singer’s new album, also titled ‘Blackstar,’ is due on Jan. 8.
lead_paragraph: For David Bowie, even a jazz-influenced new album is best set in a futuristic hellscape featuring a bejeweled skull inside an astronaut helmet and human scarecrows in crucifixion poses.

headline: For Lotus Cars, a New Chief and a Return to Its Vaunted Lightness
abstract: Jean-Marc Gales wants to return Lotus to its roots as a boutique maker of lightweight British sports cars.
lead_paragraph: HETHEL, England — LOTUS CARS will sell fewer than 100 cars in the United States and Canada this year, a long way from the 2,711 the company, based in Britain, sold at its peak in 2005. But its chief executive, Jean-Marc Gales, appears unfazed.

headline: Nov. 19, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from France, Syria, England and the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: Photos from France, Syria, England and the Philippines.

headline: Review: David Hare’s ‘The Blue Touch Paper,’ a Mordant Memoir of His Youth
abstract: With rueful wit, the British playwright vividly recounts his coming of age in the 1960s and his breakthrough success in the late 1970s.
lead_paragraph: The best praise a playwright can get, David Hare writes in his new memoir, “The Blue Touch Paper,” is for an audience member to come up and say, “The two hours flew by.” It’s a tribute to Mr. Hare’s book that it clips along at similar speed.

headline: Martin Wong, an Urban Visionary With a Hungry Eye
abstract: The artist’s first full retrospective in New York, at the Bronx Museum of the Arts, crackles with fervor, desire and coded insider-outsider knowledge.
lead_paragraph: Until 1989, the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s late night was Tuesday. It was a good time for a visit; attendance was sparse. So I went a lot. It was also when I’d bump into the artist Martin Wong who briefly, and somewhat improbably, worked as a clerk in the Met’s bookstore. I say improbably because I was accustomed to seeing him in a different setting, on the Lower East Side, where he often dressed like a rodeo cowboy and ran with graffiti artists who were tagging the neighborhood.

headline: Saying Yes, and No, Shonda Rhimes Style
abstract: Introvert Shonda Rhimes says “yes” for a year. But (maybe more importantly) she also says no.
lead_paragraph: Shonda Rhimes, who is famous for her role as creator, head writer, executive producer and showrunner of “Grey’s Anatomy,” “Private Practice” and “Scandal” and as executive producer of “How to Get Away With Murder,” is an introvert.

headline: Facebook to Make Breaking Up Easier to Do
abstract: Facebook has added an awkward wrinkle to breaking up with someone. But the social media giant has a new tool that helps automate the process of moving on with your life.
lead_paragraph: In the critically acclaimed 2004 film “Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind,” former lovers go through a medical procedure in order to forget each other.

headline: From Neversink Spirits in Port Chester, N.Y., Local Fruit Brandy
abstract: Two distillers pay tribute to the Neversink River’s historical reputation for clear water to make eau de vie, fruit brandy, from nearby produce.
lead_paragraph: Among New York State rivers, the Neversink in the Catskills may not have the name recognition of the Hudson or the Mohawk, but it has long had a legion of devotees who fish its waters.

headline: Things to Do on Long Island, Nov. 20 to 29, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Refugee Vote a Failure for Obama
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'International Relations', 'Iraqi-Americans', 'Law and Legislation', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Terrorism', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Vetoes (US)']
abstract: The president failed to read the mood of Congress, and many Americans, after the Paris attacks.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday the House overwhelmingly passed H.R. 4038, the American Security Against Foreign Enemies (SAFE) Act of 2015, which aims to stop resettlement of Syrian and Iraqi refugees in the United States indefinitely. The Senate is expected to debate the bill after Thanksgiving. Its fate is uncertain there, and if it reaches President Obama’s desk, he has said he will veto it. But in a stunning rebuke to the White House, the legislation passed the House with a veto-proof majority.

headline: From Derek Fordjour, a Sense of Abandoned Ritual
abstract: Mr. Fordjour’s unsettling installation at the Robert Blumenthal Gallery draws on memories of prayer rooms and revival meetings.

headline: Joe Grillo and Zane Lewis in Separate Shows at the Hole
abstract: Mr. Grillo’s raucous, densely composed works are full of apparent pop-culture motifs that are nearly all invented, and Mr. Lewis’s “Badlandz” is a wry zombie formalist installation.
lead_paragraph: Joe Grillo, who emerged at the turn of the century as the youngest member of the Dearraindrop collective, has titled his first solo show in New York City, at the Hole, with an implied streak of profanity, “#%@&?!!!.” His raucous, densely composed works are crowded with apparent pop-culture figures and motifs that are nearly all invented. Rendered in saturated colors outlined in black, they operate in an area bounded by painting, cartooning, graffiti and perhaps video games. Mr. Grillo’s efforts bring new energy to the high-low graphic tradition that includes artists like Pierre Alechinsky, William Copley, Keith Haring, Kenny Scharf and Sue Williams. However, a crazed retinal overload tends to distinguish Mr. Grillo’s works from those of his predecessors. He has pop culture in his veins, but his efforts stop short of garishness and mechanical slickness by being visibly improvised by hand.

headline: David Gilbert’s ‘The Secret Garden,’ Photography as Dreamscape
abstract: This solo show at the Klaus von Nichtssagend Gallery focuses on the allegorical and ethereal.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for Nov. 20-26
abstract: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.
lead_paragraph: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Review: ‘Criminal Activities,’ a Crime Yarn With John Travolta
abstract: Mr. Travolta plays a crime boss with a get-rich-quick investment scheme in this movie from Jackie Earle Haley.
lead_paragraph: John Travolta gets Godfather-y in “Criminal Activities,” a spunky crime yarn in which he does fine work but is overshadowed by a guy who spends most of the film tied up in a chair.

headline: A Paris Changed by Turmoil, a Century Ago
abstract: Parisians returned to the streets this week after recent terror attacks seeking a sense of normalcy, much as they had in 1914 when World War I shattered their city.
lead_paragraph: “France is at war,” President François Hollande declared last week after terrorists attacked Paris. And while Parisians gathered their shattered wits and mourned, the city’s celebrated cultural life — its cafes, its shops, its arts institutions — went quiet. This week, proud and defiant, Parisians returned to the streets, unwilling to give in to terror. But will the city ever return to “normal”?

headline: In ‘Hatched in Prison,’ Gil Batle Carves Jailhouse Life Onto Ostrich Eggs
abstract: The show, at Ricco Maresca, draws on Mr. Batle’s experiences as an inmate who served 20 years in California penitentiaries for fraud and forgery.

headline: Confirming and Debunking on the Terror Beat
abstract: Since the attacks in Paris, many unverified reports have flared about the investigation or new incidents of terrorism. How do we vet them?
lead_paragraph: When major news breaks, reporters and editors at The New York Times focus intensely on determining whether information is credible enough to be published. Rumors often circulate rapidly, especially on social media.

headline: Theater Listings for Nov. 20-26
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: Many shows are closed on Thanksgiving Day; detailed schedules can be found at the productions’ individual websites. Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

abstract: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Things to Do in Connecticut, Nov. 20 to 29, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Documenting the Romantic Strokes of Long-Ago Muralists
abstract: Preservationists have formed a group to locate murals created in the United States before 1860 and to document them in an online database.
lead_paragraph: A new alliance of preservationists wants to hear from anyone who has uncovered murals executed in the United States before 1860. The group has set up the Center for Painted Wall Preservation in Hallowell, Me., to document the works of itinerant artists who painted scenes of pastures, harbors, cityscapes and farmsteads, as well as flowery stenciling.

headline: A History of Head Shots, and an Exhibition on Immigrants’ Tales
abstract: The New York Library for the Performing Arts offers a look at actors’ portraits over the ages, and the Bronx Documentary Center focuses on immigration.
lead_paragraph: The more things change, the more they stay the same. That’s one thought visitors may have when viewing “Head Shots: Performer Portraits From Daguerreotype to Digital,” at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts.

headline: Review: In ‘Censored Voices,’ Soldiers Reflect on the Six-Day War
abstract: In a film by Mor Loushy, Amos Oz and Avraham Shapira revisit talks they recorded with Israeli soldiers returning from the conflict in 1967.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks following the Six-Day War in 1967, the conflict that reshaped a victorious Israel, two kibbutzniks, Amos Oz and Avraham Shapira, recorded a series of talks with other soldiers just coming home. Mr. Shapira assembled those conversations into a book, “The Seventh Day,” which came out later that year and was remarkably reflective given the national euphoria.

headline: Opera & Classical Music Listings for Nov. 20-26
abstract: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Review: ‘Frame by Frame’ Looks at Four Intrepid Afghan Photojournalists
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)']
abstract: In Alexandria Bombach and Mo Scarpelli’s documentary, the suffering the photographers capture tends to undercut the film’s focus on their journalism.

abstract: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.
lead_paragraph: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Things to Do in New Jersey, Nov. 20 to 29, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: ‘#Horror’ Finds the Fear in Cyberbullying and Social Media Threats
abstract: In this feature directorial debut by Tara Subkoff, girls neglected by their parents and obsessed with their cellphones fall prey to perils of the online world.
lead_paragraph: After a seizure-inducing credit sequence, “#Horror” settles down to a world of brittle soullessness as a group of privileged preteen girls gathers for a sleepover. Morbidly attached to their cellphones — where online encounters play out through candy-colored flashes — these bratty babies are about to have the worst night of their lives.

headline: Things to Do in the Hudson Valley, Nov. 20 to 29, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: ‘Kingdom of Shadows,’ a Documentary on the Drug War in Mexico
abstract: Bernardo Ruiz’s documentary takes a front-line look at the grip of Mexican drug cartels from the perspective of three main figures.
lead_paragraph: A Hollywood feature like “Sicario” might strive to capture the merciless grip drug cartels have on Mexico, but Bernardo Ruiz’s visceral documentary “Kingdom of Shadows” gives you a frontline glimpse. Three perspectives predominate: those of Sister Consuelo Morales, a Roman Catholic nun seeking answers for families of the “disappeared” (civilians who have vanished because of drug gangs or police corruption); Don Henry Ford Jr., a Texas rancher who served time for smuggling marijuana from Mexico; and the Homeland Security officer Oscar Hagelsieb, a former undercover operative for the Border Patrol.

headline: Movie Listings for Nov. 20-26
abstract: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.
lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Review: ‘Sweet Micky for President’: How a Pop Star Came to Lead Haiti
abstract: Ben Patterson’s flattering documentary goes on the campaign trail in Haiti with Michel Martelly, but rolls the credits after he wins the election.
lead_paragraph: One of the decade’s odder political stories is revisited, without much illumination, in “Sweet Micky for President,” a documentary by Ben Patterson about how the current president of Haiti, Michel Martelly, came to win that office. It’s a friendly and shallow look at the ascendance of a pop-star-turned-politician whose presidency, now more than four years along, has hardly been a panacea.

headline: Dance Listings for Nov. 20-26
abstract: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.
