abstract: Your Thanksgiving to-do list for the weekend.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears on nytimes.com. To receive the email, register here.

headline: Batman and Rubio? The Drawback of a Youthful Look
abstract: Political psychology research suggests that appearance can play a big role in how voters make up their minds.
lead_paragraph: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

headline: New Technique Can Classify a Fingerprint as Male or Female
abstract: Researchers find that levels of certain amino acids are twice as high in the sweat of women than in that of men.
lead_paragraph: A simple test performed at a crime scene may help forensic scientists determine whether a fingerprint belongs to a man or a woman, a new study reports.

headline: Letters: Jack Kemp and Reaganomics
abstract: Readers respond to a recent review of “Jack Kemp: The Bleeding-Heart Conservative Who Changed America” and more.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Mitch Albom’s latest heartwarming and slightly gooey best seller is about a supernaturally gifted guitarist.
lead_paragraph: Beautiful Music: Almost six years ago, when Inside the List asked a handful of authors to declare their literary New Year’s resolutions, Mitch Albom pledged “to read more books about hope and less about angst.” It was no surprise, frankly. Can anybody picture Albom — whose heartwarming and slightly gooey best sellers include “Tuesdays With Morrie” and “The Five People You Meet in Heaven” — settling in for the night with, say, a dyspeptic Thomas Bernhard novel? Now Albom’s back with “The Magic Strings of Frankie Presto,” about a supernaturally gifted guitarist who influences musicians as diverse as Hank Williams and Wynton Marsalis and Kiss; it’s new on the hardcover fiction list at No. 4. A musician himself, Albom plays keyboards with the Rock Bottom Remainders, where his bandmates include Amy Tan on vocals and Stephen King on rhythm guitar, among assorted other best-selling authors. (“We mostly listen to Dave Barry telling booger jokes,” Albom has said.) “The theme I was trying to build on for this book was that everybody joins a band in life,” he told The Philadelphia Daily News this month. “Everyone joins a band. We may not think we do, but we do. Somebody plays the lead. Somebody is the rhythm. Somebody holds down the beat. Somebody gets to solo and go all over the place, while the other person gets stuck playing the chords. That’s pretty much how it is in a family. That’s how it is in the Army. That’s how it is in a workplace. Everybody has a role that they play.”

headline: Not So Fast, 1 Percent Whippersnappers
abstract: The rise of the whiz kids makes it seem as if the young are grabbing a larger share of the wealth, but research shows that the richest are actually getting grayer.
lead_paragraph: Wealth in America has never looked so young — at least on its face.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: CHINA 1945: Mao’s Revolution and America’s Fateful Choice, by Richard Bernstein. (Vintage, $17.) In the span of a year, America’s friendly rapport with Chinese leaders devolved into fraught antagonism. Here, Bern­stein, a former New York Times correspondent, argues that the longstanding diplomatic strain between the two countries can be traced to China’s political disintegration at the end of World War II.

headline: Taking a Rational Look at the Risk of Threats
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Identity Theft']
abstract: Before paying a fee for threat protection, it’s best to do due diligence on the quality of the adviser providing the assessment.
lead_paragraph: THE terrorist attacks in Paris last week that killed 130 people and injured hundreds more instilled fear in millions of people who weren’t anywhere near the attacks. That, of course, is the point of terrorism.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: David Hare’s Memoir
abstract: This week, David Hare discusses “The Blue Touch Paper”; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Sarah Vowell talks about “Lafayette in the Somewhat United States”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, David Hare discusses “The Blue Touch Paper”; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Sarah Vowell talks about “Lafayette in the Somewhat United States”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Donald Trump’s Horrifying Plan for American Muslims
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'International Relations', 'Law and Legislation', 'Muslim-Americans', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Vetoes (US)', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Mr. Trump says he would require Muslims to register in a national database.
lead_paragraph: To say that it is hard to figure out what Donald Trump is talking about is to state the obvious. But sometimes I have to try because he is in fact running for president and he’s addressing important issues, or at least sort of talking about them.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: LETTERS TO VÉRA, by Vladimir Nabokov. Edited and translated by Olga Voronina and Brian Boyd. (Knopf, $40.) For more than half a century, Nabokov told his wife about his writing, his meals and his observations in exquisite and evocative detail.

headline: Chrissie Hynde’s ‘Reckless: My Life as a Pretender’
abstract: A memoir by the singer and songwriter Chrissie Hynde.
lead_paragraph: As the title indicates, “Reckless” is intended to be a cautionary tale. For 35 years, Chrissie Hynde has carried herself as a keeper of the rock ’n’ roll flame, fearless and invulnerable; while the other members of her band, the Pretenders, continually change, she has never wavered from the punk spirit and pop songcraft, nor the signature bangs and eyeliner, that made her one of music’s great ­frontwomen.

headline: ‘Thirteen Ways of Looking,’ by Colum McCann
abstract: The Wallace Stevens poem from which it takes its title helps structure the novella anchoring Colum McCann’s book of short fiction.
lead_paragraph: Colum McCann has an old-school belief in the capabilities of literature. Even as au courant novelists all around him grow skeptical of the artifices of character and plot, and embrace the self as the fiction writer’s only truly accessible subject, McCann’s work continues to assert that nothing human is alien to him, that the empathetic imagination can and should go where it pleases. He has written eight previous books in which he fearlessly simulates identities dauntingly remote from his own — including the identities of real-life figures both dead and living — and in which plot performs a function that might fairly be described as redemptive. From the perspective of academic fashion it is a hoary, virtually benighted approach to narrative art; yet to judge by the enormous success of his work, most notably the panoramic novels “Let the Great World Spin” and “TransAtlantic,” its appeal to readers somehow endures.

headline: Umberto Eco’s ‘Numero Zero’
abstract: A novel by Umberto Eco recalls a political scandal in Italy in 1992.
lead_paragraph: Umberto Eco’s early novels gained a reputation as intellectual entertainments, dense with esoterica and dotted with Latin, of a heft you’d rather not drop on your toe. By contrast, his new conspiracy thriller is a fleet volume, slim in pages but plump in satire about modern Italy.

headline: 10 Ways to Make an All-Star Game Memorable (Some Better Than Others)
abstract: The N.H.L. has changed the rules for its All-Star Game, part of a tradition across sports that have used the showcase event as a crucible for experimentation.
lead_paragraph: After years of sloppy, defense-free hockey in its All-Star Game, the N.H.L. has decided to try something new this season Nashville: a four-team tournament played three-on-three.

headline: Intel Lawsuit Questions Place of Hedge Funds in Retirement Plans
keywords: ['401(k), 403(b) and 457 Plans', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Hedge Funds', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A former employee sued the computing giant, saying that big bets on hedge funds and private equity increased costs and hurt participants in the plans.
lead_paragraph: “We push the boundaries.”

headline: ‘Custer’s Trials,’ by T. J. Stiles
abstract: The Little Bighorn duly noted, a book recalls George Custer’s brash, colorful life.
lead_paragraph: Is it possible to read a biography of George Armstrong Custer without thinking about his death from the first page? One hundred and thirty-nine years after the Battle of the Little Bighorn, we still cannot say his name without picturing the mutilated bodies of his men or being overwhelmed by the sharp, lingering shame of the Plains Wars and the wholesale slaughter of Native Americans. While we cannot forget how Custer died, however, few of us remember how he lived. Who he was, what he hoped to leave behind, even what brought him to that fateful day in 1876, these questions we cannot answer, and rarely ask.

headline: Desperately Seeking Consensus
abstract: What happened to Europe?
lead_paragraph: The good people at Vox EU are engaged in a laudable effort to clear the ground for euro reform, starting with the formulation of a “consensus narrative” about the origins of the euro crisis. This is a very good idea: How you think about the past plays a very large role in how you think about what should be done next.

headline: Roasted Squash Salad
abstract: The sweetness of delicata squash complements the bitter arugula and radicchio in this colorful salad.
lead_paragraph: The sweetness of delicata squash complements the bitter arugula and radicchio in this colorful salad.

headline: Squash Gives This Winter Salad a Satisfying Twist
abstract: Roasted vegetables add the necessary warming bulk, and their browned edges also bring depth to the bowl’s fresh greenery. (Article plus video.)
lead_paragraph: Summer salads have it easy. With a bounty of greens in season for the taking, it’s easy for them to be fresh, bright and pretty.

headline: Simon Winchester’s ‘Pacific’
abstract: A survey of the Pacific includes chapters on coral reefs, thermonuclear bombs and cyclones.
lead_paragraph: Over the decades, the British-born Simon Winchester has emerged as one of those increasingly rare geographic generalists, migrating from region to region, sharing with his readers an almost tactile sense of the earth, its history and its peoples. His narratives exist within that depressingly vast space between the hairsplitting nuances and abstractions of academia and the vulgar simplicities of cable news pundits. A highbrow out to educate middlebrows, Winchester writes books like someone telling a good yarn around the fireplace, whether about volcanoes, Indian slums or the 19th-century American West. He is an outdoorsman who knows about such things as geology and ocean sailing, which invigorates his prose in the same way as that of another journalistic travel writer, William Langewiesche, who flies planes and also sails. And he certainly has the knack for comparison. When Winchester writes that Hawaii, deep down, “in its perceived cultural essence,” still evokes what “was felt by Gauguin during his time in the Marquesas,” it is reminiscent of the British travel writer Jan Morris describing in 1960 how the smells and landscape of the Lido in Venice ignite thoughts of Carthage and Marrakesh.

headline: At Parigot in SoHo, Parisians Reflect on Terror Attacks
abstract: At an authentically cozy French bistro on Grand Street, a trio of Parisians mourned, talked, worried, remembered and toasted one another.
lead_paragraph: Who knows if it’s their own sensuality or the sensuous nature of their city, but some Parisians can live abroad for decades and still describe, as though they had smelled it only yesterday, that precise, blended odor of baking baguette and rainy sidewalk that hovers outside their favorite bakery on the Rue Lamarck. One imagines that this sensorial attachment to Paris was never stronger than in recent days, after the city suffered terrorist attacks that killed more than 120 people. At Parigot, an authentically cozy French bistro on Grand Street in SoHo, a trio of Parisians mourned, talked, worried, remembered and toasted one another, both missing their city and at the same time perhaps feeling glad that they were far away.

headline: Winnie-the-Pooh’s Skull: Relic of Inspirational Bear Goes on Display
abstract: The skull of Winnipeg, the bear that inspired “Winnie-the-Pooh,” has gone on display in London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The skull of Winnipeg, the bear who inspired “Winnie-the-Pooh,” has gone on display for the first time at the Hunterian Museum in London.

headline: Kurt Vonnegut’s ‘Breakfast of Champions,’ Read by John Malkovich
abstract: Malkovich reads an offbeat 1973 novel.
lead_paragraph: Forgive me for starting with an obvious point, but it’s one I hadn’t really considered before I was asked to review an audiobook, or as they used to be called, “books on CD,” and before that, “books on tape,” and before that, “readings,” and before that, “storytelling.” The point is this: All reading is a form of reading aloud, even when the reading is done in silence. The very act of transferring the words of another into the brain activates the inner voice, the voice that we “hear” when we read to ourselves. All reading is therefore a vocal performance, generally just for an audience of one. Consider how much the language of reading and writing supports this notion: We talk about an author’s voice and tone and rhythm. We ask, “What is the author trying to say?”

headline: Popcast: Adele Returns
abstract: Adele remains one of the most precise and ambitious belters working, and “25” is full of songs that continue her tradition of extracting deep ache, with a few twists courtesy of new collaborators.
lead_paragraph: Listen to this week’s podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | RSS | Stitcher

The following is a handy recap of where the leading candidates stand:

keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Deportation', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']

keywords: ['Medicare', 'Elderly', 'Death and Dying', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Doctors', 'Living Wills and Health Care Proxies']
abstract: Medicare has decided to pay physicians to discuss end-of-life care with patients. But it’s not clear that doctors are prepared for the task.
lead_paragraph: It seemed like a logical idea, the congressman told me, and not a particularly radical one.

headline: Movie Studios Turn to Athletes to Create a Buzz
abstract: Major film studios arrange free private screenings for athletes on the road in the hope they will promote the movies on social media. The teams see the outings as a way to build camaraderie.
lead_paragraph: On a brisk night last week, a group of Nets players and staff members walked seven blocks from their hotel in downtown Sacramento to a multiplex on the second floor of a sleepy shopping mall.

headline: ‘These United States,’ by Glenda Elizabeth Gilmore and Thomas J. Sugrue
abstract: Two historians offer a revisionist account of the years since 1890.
lead_paragraph: This admirably ambitious book seeks to distill a generation’s worth of scholarship into a fresh history of “the long 20th century” from the 1890s to the present — the epoch triumphally heralded by Henry Luce in 1941 as the “American century.”

headline: Mary Beard’s ‘SPQR’ and Tom Holland’s ‘Dynasty’
abstract: One history of ancient Rome and another of the first five Roman emperors.
lead_paragraph: How on earth did they do it? The Greek historian Polybius, writing in the second century B.C., was the first to ask the question: “Who could be so indifferent or so idle that they did not want to find out how, and under what kind of political organization, almost the whole of the inhabited world was conquered and fell under the sole power of the Romans in less than 53 years?” It was not as if Rome was a promising spot: a swampy piece of ground up a barely navigable river surrounded by scrubby hills, its few thousand inhabitants alternately flooded out and ravaged by malaria.

headline: ‘Augustine: Conversions to Confessions,’ by Robin Lane Fox
abstract: A British historian covers roughly the first half of ­Augustine’s life, running from his youth to the writing of “Confessions.”
lead_paragraph: Mihi quaestio factus sum. This Latin phrase bounces around the screen of my sleeping laptop, reminding me of something I know only too well: “I have become a problem to myself.” It comes from St. Augustine’s “Confessions,” his powerful spiritual autobiography that has shaped how Christians and non-Christians in the West have conceived of their life journeys for over 1,500 years. So successful is the book in making readers identify with the author that it has never gone out of print and never seems to age.

headline: ‘Soda Politics’ and ‘Saving Gotham’
abstract: Two books examine the dire health consequences of soda, and the effort to limit them.
lead_paragraph: A single can of soda, I think we can all agree, will do you no harm. Twelve ounces of carbonated, sugar-sweetened liquid won’t send you spiraling into metabolic syndrome. All it takes, in fact, is 23 minutes of cycling to burn off the 140 calories from all that “scary” sugar — the very same sugar, it’s worth pointing out, that’s found in healthy foods, such as apples, pears and strawberries.

headline: Carrie Brownstein’s ‘Hunger Makes Me a Modern Girl’
abstract: Brownstein’s memoir highlights the role of music in her life.
lead_paragraph: Last February, Sleater-Kinney took the stage at Terminal 5 in New York City for the first time in nearly 10 years. Carrie Brownstein, stage right as always, was all our rock-star dreams come true, her arms windmilling, her legs high-kicking, brandishing her guitar above her head, her voice a rough demand. It blended with and crashed against the preternatural wail of her bandmate, the guitarist Corin Tucker, backed with the insistent drums of Janet Weiss; three women making a noise we felt all through our bodies. Playing with them again, Brownstein writes in “Hunger Makes Me a Modern Girl,” was like being home.

headline: ‘The Money Makers,’ by Eric Rauchway
abstract: Monetary policy’s role in overcoming the Great Depression.
lead_paragraph: In 2008, the international economy came within weeks of catastrophic collapse. Concerted action by the world’s monetary authorities staved off disaster. Although stagnation continues to plague much of the globe, especially Europe, a major depression was avoided.

headline: ‘Magna Carta: The Birth of Liberty,’ by Dan Jones
abstract: Magna Carta’s historical importance is still debated, but the story behind it has its own merits.
lead_paragraph: Modern liberal democracy, we hear, began 800 years ago in England on a marshy field near London. Pressed by his aggrieved subjects, a hated king accepted strict new limits on royal power. The pact, named Magna Carta (Great Charter), became entrenched in British law. A bulwark against oppressive rulers, it inspired 17th-century England’s parliamentarians and 18th-century America’s revolutionaries. It remains a founding text of Western constitutional government.

headline: ‘Lights Out,’ by Ted Koppel
abstract: Ted Koppel says a cyberattack on the nation’s power sources is likely, and we’re nowhere near ready.
lead_paragraph: The possibility that terrorists or a hostile foreign state could take down the American power grid either by a cyberattack or by an electromagnetic pulse attack is one of those haunting possibilities that keep strategic planners from sleeping peacefully at night. In “Lights Out: A Cyberattack, a Nation Unprepared, Surviving the Aftermath,” Ted Koppel, one of America’s most experienced and best-known journalists, has attempted to show readers why the danger is real, the degree to which the authorities are unprepared and the steps we can take now to be ready when the power goes down.

headline: Aural Sex
abstract: Audio recordings of erotic fiction are a booming business.
lead_paragraph: Last month I finished recording an audio version of my new book in four days — a full day ahead of schedule — and I was feeling pretty good about it. It helped that the audio technician at ­DuArt, a film and recording studio in Midtown Manhattan, could hear like a bat and caught every stomach gurgle. As I was about to leave, I jokingly asked the audiobook studio director if he could make the book a runaway audio best seller.

headline: Joe Klein’s ‘Charlie Mike’
abstract: A group of veterans start a volunteer organization for soldiers who have returned to civilian life.
lead_paragraph: Kenneth Harbaugh, a former Navy pilot, believes that humor can be “wrung from the most awful things.” As he recalls, one of his fellow veterans, a double amputee, used to laugh about losing “$300 worth of tattoos.” But the joke turned somber when Harbaugh’s friend added that what he regretted most wasn’t the loss of his tattoos or limbs; it was that “he didn’t stop enough shrapnel with his own body to save his squad mate from getting hit.”

headline: Faction
abstract: New novels include roles for Friedrich Engels, Alice James and Mark Twain.
lead_paragraph: MRS. ENGELSBy Gavin McCrea389 pp. Catapult, paper, $16.95.

headline: The Expansionary Austerity Zombie
abstract: Keynes denial, still.
lead_paragraph: The doctrine of expansionary austerity — the proposition that cuts in government spending would actually cause higher growth despite their direct negative impact on demand, thanks to the confidence fairy — was all the rage in policy circles five years ago. But it brutally failed the reality test; instead, the evidence pointed overwhelmingly to the continued existence of something very like the old-fashioned Keynesian multiplier.

headline: Hostages Seized at Hotel in Mali
abstract: Reports say dozens were killed on Friday morning after an unknown number of gunmen stormed the Radisson Blu in the country’s capital.
lead_paragraph: Reports say dozens were killed on Friday morning after an unknown number of gunmen stormed the Radisson Blu in the country’s capital.

headline: Thieves Steal 17 Artworks From Verona Museum
abstract: The works, stolen by masked bandits, are estimated to have a total value of $10.7 million to $16 million.
lead_paragraph: ROME – Masked bandits broke into one of Verona’s most important museums and stole 17 paintings, including works by Mantegna and Rubens, and five pieces by Jacopo Tintoretto. The museum estimated the total value at between $10.7 million and $16 million.

headline: CNN Sets Polling Requirements to Make Main Stage at Next G.O.P. Debate
abstract: CNN said that Republican candidates will need to have either a national polling average of 3.5 percent or higher, or be polling at 4 percent or higher in Iowa or New Hampshire, to qualify for the prime-time debate, which will be held in Las Vegas on Dec. 15.
lead_paragraph: CNN is broadening its criteria for next month’s Republican presidential debate, including polling from Iowa and New Hampshire to determine which candidates make the main stage.

headline: A Panic Button for the Phone
abstract: After his sister died when medical help was available, Michael Nelson devised an app, iUDAME, to ensure that in a traumatic event, the right people will know immediately.
lead_paragraph: Samantha Nelson was only 32 when she died after a heart attack in 2010. Ms. Nelson, who had been on the phone with her mother and sister just a couple of hours before she died, had pledged to call back after she took a bath, but had not been heard from. Then the call came. Ms. Nelson was frantic; she had just awaked in a tub filled with scalding water with little clue as to how she got there.

headline: Millennials Investing in Rental Properties
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Millennial Generation']
abstract: For all the talk about millennials’ being slow to move toward homeownership, some young adults are drawn to real estate as an investment opportunity.
lead_paragraph: Travis Killian, a business owner in Austin, Tex., is a typical 27-year-old in that he doesn’t own his own home — he is a renter. But unlike many of his peers, he can afford to buy. In fact, he owns nine single-family rental properties in various cities around the country, and is in the process of buying eight more.

headline: Online Support Grows for Missing Maryland College Student
abstract: Many people have posted messages on social media in an effort to reach Jacob Marberger, whose disappearance and possible possession of a rifle closed his Maryland college.
lead_paragraph: The search for a Maryland college student who was last seen on Monday and may have a rifle has taken a more personal turn as people reached out through social media posts addressed to “Jacob.”

headline: Cable & Wireless Looks Past John Malone’s Complex Deal
abstract: By offering a tracking stock as payment, the transaction is comically complex, even by Mr. Malone’s standards of craftiness.
lead_paragraph: The deal to acquire Cable & Wireless Communications undercuts one of John C. Malone’s favorite and most fiendish pieces of financial engineering.

headline: In Jordan Matter’s Photos, Dancers Make All the World Their Stage
abstract: The photographer’s images in “Dancers Among Us,” at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers, frames sublime action in everyday settings.
lead_paragraph: It is hard not to feel buoyant looking at the images in “Dancers Among Us: Photographs by Jordan Matter,” at the Hudson River Museum. Dancers leap through the air, extending their limbs into gravity-defying poses that combine exuberance, grace, virtuosity and whimsy.

abstract: Studies show the schools benefit poor, nonwhite students in cities, but in suburbs they do no better than public schools, and sometimes worse.
lead_paragraph: Charter schools are controversial. But are they good for education?

abstract: The director and writer shares the titles he’d most want to take with him on a desert island.
lead_paragraph: For his bookshop installation, One Grand, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is the cult film director and writer John Waters. He shares his list exclusively with T.

headline: Jiehae Park’s ‘Peerless’ to World Premiere at the Yale Repertory Theater
abstract: Ms. Park’s darkly comic play relocates elements of “Macbeth” to an American high school in the Midwest during college admissions season. “Peerless” opens on Nov. 27.
lead_paragraph: If there were standardized tests for emerging playwrights, it’s a good bet that Jiehae Park would ace them. Her darkly comic play “Peerless,” which relocates elements of “Macbeth” to an American high school in the Midwest during college admissions season, opens on Nov. 27 at the Yale Repertory Theater in New Haven. This major, highly esteemed credit now joins a long list of brand-name honors, grants and play-development workshops on her sterling résumé.

headline: Manhattan Dentist Is Arrested on Drug and Pornography Charges
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Child Pornography', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Teeth and Dentistry', 'Methamphetamines']
abstract: The dentist, John Wolf, 59, is accused of exchanging dental work for methamphetamine with a dealer, and possessing videos of child pornography.
lead_paragraph: John Wolf, a dentist in the Chelsea section of Manhattan, is well known in the neighborhood — not only for his popular, light-filled offices, but also for his AIDS activism. He studied the disease in dentistry school, according to his Google profile, and as a practicing dentist in the 1980s he brought, and won, a prominent lawsuit against a landlord who did not want him to treat patients with AIDS.

headline: Fidelity Joins Growing Field of Automated Financial Advice
abstract: Fidelity is testing an online platform called Fidelity Go as part of its move into the so-called robo-adviser segment of the investment market.

lead_paragraph: Jordan Thomas is chairman of the whistle-blower representation practice at Labaton Sucharow and was a former assistant director in the enforcement division of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Paris: One Week Later
keywords: ['Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Life in Paris is slowly returning to normal, but people are still recovering from the terrorist attacks of Nov. 13. Here, four Parisians discuss the attacks and what has followed.
lead_paragraph: Life in Paris is slowly returning to normal, but people are still recovering from the terrorist attacks of Nov. 13. Here, four Parisians discuss the attacks and what has followed.

headline: Escape Rooms Bring New Attractions to New Jersey
abstract: Escape rooms, where guests gather clues to find exits, are growing in popularity in the Garden State and across the country.
lead_paragraph: Eric Rama and Teresa Pulcrano were strangers when they walked into Exit Strategy in Montclair recently. An hour later, when they emerged, Mr. Rama was praising Ms. Pulcrano’s sports trivia knowledge.

headline: What We Know and Don’t Know About the Terrorist Attack in Mali
abstract: Mali, a former French colony in West Africa, has been fighting an Islamist insurgency for the past three years.
lead_paragraph: Gunmen seized a hotel in Bamako, the capital of Mali, on Friday, taking about 100 people hostage and killing more than two dozen. The attack is the latest eruption of violence in Mali, a former French colony in West Africa that has been racked by an Islamist insurgency for the past three years.

headline: How Nicole A. Taylor, Cookbook Author, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Ms. Taylor, the author of “The Up South Cookbook: Chasing Dixie in a Brooklyn Kitchen,” seeks out Southern flavors as she dines in and out over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: In college, a friend of Nicole A. Taylor’s called her “the black Betty Crocker,” which is not a bad catchphrase to recall when you’re promoting a new cookbook during the holidays. A Georgia native, she is the author of “The Up South Cookbook: Chasing Dixie in a Brooklyn Kitchen” and the host of the podcast “Hot Grease,” in which she tells stories related to Southern food. Ms. Taylor, 37, who said Southern cooking didn’t become part of her career until she moved to New York City in 2008, lives with her husband, Adrian Franks, 39, an artist and a user-experience design director at IBM, in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn.

headline: For Woman Dead in French Police Raid, Unlikely Path to Terror
abstract: Hasna Aitboulahcen once liked to drink, smoke and stay out late. She spent her last days in a St.-Denis hide-out for Islamist militants.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When about 100 heavily armed police officers and soldiers took position shortly after 4 a.m. Wednesday outside the building in the Paris suburb of St.-Denis where the presumed ringleader of the Paris attacks was holed up, a young woman appeared in a window.

headline: Iowa Coach Kirk Ferentz Guides Undefeated Hawkeyes to Unfamiliar Heights
abstract: Ferentz, whose job may have been in jeopardy after last season, has Iowa in a position to make a run at its first national championship since 1958.
lead_paragraph: IOWA CITY — In the early 1970s, amid the Iowa football team’s 19-year streak without a winning season, the former University of Iowa president Willard Boyd arrived early to a Big Ten meeting and made small talk with his friend Novice Fawcett, the president of Ohio State.

headline: A Tender, Intimate Video by Dash Snow
abstract: The artist’s “Sisyphus, Sissy Fuss, Silly Puss” depicts his partner, Jade Berreau, and daughter, Secret, exploring nature in upstate New York.
lead_paragraph: The exhibition “Dash Snow: Freeze Means Run,” on view now at the Brant Foundation Art Study Center in Greenwich, Conn., was conceived as a labor of love. The career-spanning retrospective was organized in part by three of the late artist’s best friends: Dan Colen, Hanna Liden and Nate Lowman. Their mission to honor the memory of their comrade and (sometimes literal) partner in crime is evident throughout the show, which comprises many of the artist’s best known and most controversial works — including the front pages of newspapers he infamously decorated with his own bodily fluid — but which is more striking in its inclusion of more personal work from Snow. Among the more than 100 previously unexhibited Polaroids on display are many that depict Snow and his friends drinking and drugging, or in lithe, louche repose — windows on a moment in time that seems, in retrospect, inevitably brief.

headline: Thanksgiving Leftovers Go Beyond the Turkey Sandwich
abstract: Three graceful ways to prepare the remains of your holiday feast.
lead_paragraph: Some cooks prefer the Thanksgiving meal proper, with its generous platters and long, festive table. Others are impatient for the after-party, the prospect of raiding the fridge at midnight, or the anticipated snack the next day, when the bounty is neatly packed away.

headline: ‘Jessica Jones’ Episode 1: The Worst in People
abstract: The show, the latest Marvel TV property, debuted on Netflix on Friday.
lead_paragraph: While immediately engaging, “A.K.A. Ladies Night,” the first episode of “Jessica Jones,” sometimes leans too hard on its title character’s alienated, hyper-cynical worldview. The pilot’s pseudo-hard-boiled (read: moodily under-lit) style and intricate narrative, with multiple overlapping subplots integrating by episode’s end, is mostly an effective continuation of the Hell’s Kitchen-focused, adult-oriented brand of drama that Marvel Comics and Netflix first tried with “Daredevil” earlier this year.

headline: An Eerie New Sound Installation, Made From Broken Instruments
abstract: The artist Susan Philipsz opens “War Damaged Musical Instruments” at the Tate Britain this weekend. She talks to T about making the piece.
lead_paragraph: When visitors enter the Duveen galleries in London’s Tate Britain this weekend, they’ll be greeted by the sound of bugles that once played at the battle of Waterloo and the Charge of the Light Brigade. The breathy, rasping tones — which are broadcast from 14 large, horn-shaped speakers — are part of “War Damaged Musical Instruments,” a new work by the sound artist Susan Philipsz.

headline: For Transgender Rights Opponents, Houston Wasn’t Enough
keywords: ['Age, Chronological', 'Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Discrimination', 'Gender', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Men and Boys', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Segregation and Desegregation', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Women and Girls', "Women's Rights"]

lead_paragraph: The Houston Equal Rights Ordinance would’ve granted those who visit, live or work in Houston protection from “discrimination based on sex, race, color, ethnicity, national origin, age, familial status, marital status, military status, religion, disability, sexual orientation, genetic information, gender identity or pregnancy.”

headline: A West Village Penthouse for $25.49 Million
abstract: Two new downtown penthouses were the sales of the week — one at the Greenwich Lane in the West Village, and another at the Sterling Mason in TriBeCa.
lead_paragraph: The latest in a flurry of sales at the Greenwich Lane, an almost blocklong condominium complex on the site of the former St. Vincent’s Hospital campus in the West Village, was filed with the city this past week — a spacious duplex penthouse with a private rooftop terrace that sold for $25,489,849.99 and was the most expensive closed sale, according to public records.

headline: British Police Apologize for Undercover Officers’ Intimate Tactics
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Women and Girls', 'Police']
abstract: The Metropolitan Police apologized for the behavior of officers who used intimate relationships, one nine years long, to gather intelligence and infiltrate activist groups.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — They lived together, traveled abroad on vacation and, for five years, behaved like any other couple. Then one day the man, who called himself Mark Cassidy, disappeared, leading his bewildered ex-partner to eventually discover that she had been living with a married police spy.

headline: In Los Angeles, Jewelry Mingles With Midcentury Design
abstract: Lisa Eisner opens “Nomad 1957,” a weeklong installation inside the Jean Prouvé structure outside of Maxfield.
lead_paragraph: It took some convincing to get Tommy Perse, the owner of the L.A. boutique Maxfield, to agree to the jewelry installation “Nomad 1957.” But Lisa Eisner is nothing if not persuasive. A longtime patron of the Los Angeles fashion institution, Eisner, a jewelry designer (and sometime artist, stylist, photographer and publisher), began selling pieces at Maxfield earlier this year. Three months ago, the store approached her to do an out-of-the-box installation with her pieces. Eisner’s first instinct was to ask about Structure Nomade — a large, prefab space designed by the French architect Jean Prouvé in 1957 that sits just outside Maxfield’s entrance, which had never been used for anything.

headline: Funeral in Pakistan for Militants Killed in U.S. Strikes Draws Hundreds
abstract: Twenty coffins were involved in the mass funeral for local militants said to have been killed in neighboring Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: LOWER DIR, Pakistan — A mass funeral on Friday for as many as 20 local militants said to have been killed by American airstrikes in neighboring Afghanistan drew hundreds of mourners in the northwestern Pakistani district of Lower Dir, according to local residents and participants.

headline: The Divergent Styles of Jane Freilicher and Jane Wilson
abstract: An exhibition of the works of the two artists, running through Jan. 18, shows their different approaches to same subject: Long Island’s East End.
lead_paragraph: The artists Jane Freilicher and Jane Wilson had a lot in common besides their first names. Both were painters, both worked in the East End of Long Island starting in the late 1950s, both lived at the same address for a time and both died recently at age 90, within five weeks of each other.

lead_paragraph: Deforestation threatens more than half of all tree species in the Amazon, a new study suggests.

abstract: At Symphony Space, Mr. de Mare gave the New York premieres of the Final Pieces in His “Liaisons: Reimagining Sondheim From the Piano.”
lead_paragraph: It’s all in the details. That could almost be a motto for Stephen Sondheim, who works so hard to get the details right in his songs.

headline: Review: ‘Saints & Strangers,’ a Thanksgiving Story Told in a Native Tongue
abstract: National Geographic’s two-part film has its cast members playing American Indians speak their lines in a language called Western Abenaki.
lead_paragraph: In “Saints & Strangers,” National Geographic’s compelling two-part film about the Mayflower settlers and the first Thanksgiving, the cast members playing American Indians speak their lines in an almost extinct language called Western Abenaki. It’s a bold choice, both because of the challenge for the cast and because it means much of the film is subtitled. But it’s strikingly appropriate, since in this story, the language barrier is everything.

headline: Review: Lizt Alfonso Dance Cuba Brings Precision to a Fusion
abstract: The troupe, in “Cuba Vibra!” at the New Victory Theater, offers a family show that refers to romance and women’s power.
lead_paragraph: Hamstrings can’t be the only strained body parts for a member of Lizt Alfonso Dance Cuba. They must also need to ice their jaws. These dancers smile so hard that after the third or fourth number, your own mouth may start to ache in solidarity.

lead_paragraph: In mid-September, in the enduring boil of the national debate over race and the police, President Obama appeared one afternoon in the Eisenhower Executive Office Building to host a screening of a new documentary from Vice magazine on the criminal-justice system. It was one of those carefully organized Washington affairs: There were speeches, panel talks and a curated guest list that included Senator Cory A. Booker of New Jersey, the hip-hop artist Ludacris, the actor Tim Robbins, the Rev. Al Sharpton, an activist from Ferguson, Mo., some former prison inmates and Shane Smith, the chief executive of Vice.

abstract: The editor of Avenue magazine lives within view of the Washington Square Park arch.
lead_paragraph: When Daisy Prince and her husband, Hugh Chisholm, returned to New York in 2009 after eight years in London, they moved to Greenwich Village, where she had wanted to live since she was a college student in the 1990s. “I attended Barnard, and you spend most of your time trying to go downtown to a club or hear music,” she said. “And then when we moved downtown, I was like, wait a minute, I missed the memo — when did everyone move to Brooklyn?”

headline: Why ‘Cool’ Is Still Cool
keywords: ['Language and Languages', 'Senses and Sensation', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Research']
abstract: Our senses have a big impact on which words thrive and which fizzle out.
lead_paragraph: THE word “cool” has been cool for a long time. Originally associated with temperature, by the 16th century the term had evolved to describe not just the atmosphere, but also an internal state of calm, almost icy composure. And by the late 1800s it began to signify style and hipness and some of the other meanings with which it is associated today. Now cool is used as a synonym for almost anything good. Music can be cool and restaurants can be cool. Every so often even a minivan seems cool.

headline: Review: Julia Murney in Honesty Mode at Feinstein’s/54 Below
abstract: Ms. Murney’s untitled show at Feinstein’s/54 Below includes a sing-along with four-letter-words but no selections from “Wicked.”
lead_paragraph: Julia Murney doesn’t mince words. The high point of her untitled opening-night show at Feinstein’s/54 Below on Thursday was a sing-along rendition of Sara Bareilles’s “Sweet as Whole.” It was prefaced by an anecdote about a man urinating in a New York subway station, Ms. Murney’s disgust and another observer’s mean-spirited reaction.

headline: My Life as a Muslim in the West’s ‘Gray Zone’
keywords: ['Muslim Americans', 'Muslims and Islam', 'English Language', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: With the attacks in Paris, ISIS has declared war on the ‘‘gray zone.’’ But the language of some American politicians is also questioning coexistence.
lead_paragraph: Some months ago, I gave a reading from my most recent novel in Scottsdale, Ariz. During the discussion that followed, a woman asked me to talk about my upbringing in Morocco. It’s natural for readers to be curious about a writer they’ve come to hear, I told myself. I continued to tell myself this even after the conversation drifted to Islam, and then to ISIS. Eventually, another woman raised her hand and said that the only Muslims she saw when she turned on the television were extremists. “Why aren’t we hearing more from people like you?” she asked me.

headline: Review: ‘More Up a Tree,’ Performance Art Through the Looking Glass
abstract: Eve Sussman created this performance in which spectators watch the dancer Claudia de Serpa Soares and the drummer Jim White in a glass enclosure.
lead_paragraph: Ten minutes before the start of “More Up a Tree,” if you had walked into the Fishman Space, the black-box theater within BAM Fisher, you would have first seen the performers themselves, the dancer Claudia de Serpa Soares and the drummer Jim White, both in the middle of a wood-framed glass enclosure in the center of the room. You had nothing else to look at — except the other members of the audience, free to walk around the enclosure before and during the performance.

headline: Americans View Paris Attacks With Empathy, Fear and Resolve
keywords: ['Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Terrorism', 'Social Media', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: In interviews around the country, many Americans were sorry about what had happened and fearful of attacks at home.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — It made parents worry for their children studying abroad. It sent a shiver of fear into plans for vacations to France. Cafes and nightclubs in Miami and Los Angeles felt newly vulnerable, not so different from the bloody scenes unfolding on people’s phones and televisions. For Americans accustomed to tuning out foreign conflicts, it brought the world crashing in.

headline: Fox Drops Ratings for Live Viewership
abstract: Becoming the first broadcast network to stop relying on same-day numbers, Fox said the data was irrelevant in an era of delayed viewing and streaming.
lead_paragraph: Fox became the first broadcast network to declare that it no longer would acknowledge or release ratings for its shows that measure only live or same-day viewing, calling the figures irrelevant as viewers increasingly stream shows or watch on DVRs or on demand.

headline: Greek New Testament Papyrus Is Discovered on eBay
abstract: The credit-card-size fragment is believed to contain about six lines of the Gospel of John on one side and an unidentified Christian text on the other.
lead_paragraph: Last January, Geoffrey Smith, a scholar of early Christianity at the University of Texas, noticed something startling: an eBay listing for an ancient Greek papyrus fragment of the Gospel of John — with an opening bid of only $99.

headline: Bill Cunningham | City Blues
abstract: A surprise: blue among the autumnal foliage.
lead_paragraph: A surprise: blue among the autumnal foliage. It was all over the city, from Storefront Academy’s 1890s rowhouse porches in Harlem to, for the first time, morning glories that cascaded over the Fifth Avenue fence of the 1914 Frick home that now houses Henry Clay Frick’s art collection. Some wearers added burgundy hats to their outfits that were the shade of some of the closed morning glories in the evening.

headline: A Dutch ISIS Fighter Takes Questions on Tumblr
abstract: Israfil Yilmaz, who abandoned a career in the Royal Netherlands Army to join Islamist rebels, replied with personal, technical and theological answers.
lead_paragraph: Usually, by the time the public learns the names and biographies of Islamic State militants, or radicals from other groups who attack civilians, they are already dead, and so unable to speak for themselves, except occasionally in the ritualized form of martyrdom videos or manifestoes posted online.

Many feel familiar: A project is too big or too unsightly and will blight a neighborhood or force out people of modest means or end the long run of a beloved mom-and-pop shop.
