headline: Ta-Nehisi Coates: ‘I Don’t Want to Be Anybody’s Expert’
abstract: Mr. Coates reflects on winning the National Book Award for “Between the World and Me,” and about his dislike of being called a public intellectual.
lead_paragraph: As he accepted the National Book Award for nonfiction for “Between the World and Me” on Wednesday, Ta-Nehisi Coates took a moment to marvel that he had written the book at all.

headline: Russian Newspaper’s Scoop? Based on Fake Letters, U.S. Says
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The State Department told the newspaper Izvestia that letters supposedly proving that Russian gay rights activists were traitors were obviously faked.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — When reporters at Russia’s government-leaning newspaper Izvestia found an archive of letters, supposedly written by State Department employees to a prominent Russian gay, bisexual, transgender and intersex activist, they thought they had stumbled upon an extraordinary trove.

headline: Adam Johnson, Inspired by Holograms, Humor and Escape
abstract: Mr. Johnson, whose “Fortune Smiles” won the National Book Award for fiction, talks about his surprise at winning and why he became a writer.
lead_paragraph: When Adam Johnson’s short-story collection “Fortune Smiles” won the National Book Award for fiction on Wednesday night, Mr. Johnson joined an elite group of literary greats who have won that honor and the Pulitzer Prize in quick succession, a club that includes Philip Roth, Wallace Stegner, Saul Bellow and Eudora Welty.

headline: Mark Zuckerberg Plans 2-Month Paternity Leave From Facebook
abstract: Family leave policies have become the subject of much discussion in the tech industry, and a number of top companies have increased the parental leave they offer.
lead_paragraph: Facebook’s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, said he planned to take two months of paternity leave after his daughter is born this year, amid a debate about work-life balance at technology companies.

headline: With Permanent Squad, New York Police Step Up Fight on Terrorism
abstract: The Critical Response Command, whose ranks will swell to 527 officers by the end of the year, shows the city’s evolving approach to fighting terrorism.
lead_paragraph: In January, several days after heavily armed terrorists attacked Charlie Hebdo, a satirical newspaper in Paris, top officials with the New York Police Department held a drill to test the city’s response to such an attack and found they had a problem.

headline: Mexico’s Participation in ’16 Olympics Imperiled by Intramural Dispute
abstract: A feud between the government and sports federations over how public money is spent could mean Mexican athletes in Rio would compete under the I.O.C. banner.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — A dispute between Mexico’s government and the nation’s sports federations over how public money is spent and how athletes will be selected for the 2016 Olympics could result in Mexico’s being barred from participating as a team at the Games.

headline: U.N. Security Council Approves Resolution Urging Countries to Combat Islamic State
abstract: The resolution, approved in a 15-to-0 vote, called on countries around the world to take “all necessary measures” to fight the jihadist group.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations Security Council on Friday adopted a resolution, drafted by France, calling on countries around the world to take “all necessary measures” to fight the Islamic State.

headline: Argentina Considers Shift as Upstart Rises in Presidential Race
abstract: With Mauricio Macri leading in polls for Argentina’s election on Sunday, many in the country are gauging the impact of a shift away from Peronist policies.
lead_paragraph: HUMAHUACA, Argentina — Winding down a presidential campaign that is upending this country’s politics, Mauricio Macri dutifully chewed on coca leaves, a symbol of the resilience of indigenous culture in this remote corner of northern Argentina. Raising his voice barely above a murmur, he asked Mother Earth for the wisdom to guide Argentina down the “righteous path.”

headline: Benjamin Clementine Wins 2015 Mercury Prize
abstract: The singer-songwriter’s album “At Least for Now” was selected over 11 other records, including ones by Aphex Twin, Florence and the Machine and Jamie xx.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin Clementine, a pianist, poet, singer-songwriter and former Paris busker, was awarded the 2015 Mercury Prize on Friday in London for the best British or Irish album of the year. The prestigious award, which calls itself “the music equivalent to the Booker Prize for literature and the Turner Prize for art,” comes with a cash prize of 20,000 pounds, or about $30,500.

headline: Syrian Family Diverted From Indiana Feels ‘Welcomed’ in Connecticut
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: A family of three from Homs, Syria, arrived to Kennedy International Airport on Tuesday amid a political backlash.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — The couple from Syria arrived at Kennedy International Airport on Tuesday only to face one more shock in a four-year journey of loss, anxiety and upheaval. They had no idea they had landed in a political maelstrom.

headline: F.D.A. Takes Issue With the Term ‘Non-G.M.O.’
abstract: The F.D.A.’s stance on labeling has not changed, but it has added some confusion to the mix for consumers and for those companies that are voluntarily including more information on their packaging.
lead_paragraph: Lost in the news about the Food and Drug Administration’s approval of genetically engineered salmon on Thursday was its long-awaited guidelines on labeling food with or without genetically altered plant ingredients.

headline: Administration Is Seeking Ways to Keep Prescription Drugs Affordable
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Obama administration on Friday hosted a forum to address ways in which the government could help protect against high pharmaceutical costs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration began building a political case Friday for government actions to protect people against high pharmaceutical costs, saying millions of Americans were unable to afford lifesaving prescription drugs.

headline: John E. Zuccotti, Urbanist, Financier and Would-Be Mayor, Dies at 78
abstract: Mr. Zuccotti was a street-smart urbanist and an unsung hero of New York City’s fiscal crisis in the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: John E. Zuccotti, a street-smart urbanist who was an unsung hero of New York City’s fiscal crisis in the 1970s, died on Thursday in Brooklyn. He was 78.

headline: Donald Trump’s Take on de Blasio? ‘The Worst Mayor in the U.S.’
abstract: Donald J. Trump took aim on Twitter at Mayor Bill de Blasio on Friday, accusing him of “ineptitude.”
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump tore into Mayor Bill de Blasio on Twitter on Friday, accusing New York City’s top elected official of “ineptitude” and calling him “the worst Mayor in the U.S., & probably the worst Mayor in the history of #NYC.”

headline: After Unusual Stumbles, Rafael Nadal’s Year Ends in Hope
abstract: For Nadal, who is now ranked fifth, the road back to No. 1 gets more difficult each passing year. But a late-season resurgence this year brings hope for the next.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On the eve of the year-end ATP World Tour Finals, Rafael Nadal mused, “In the work, always there is a solution, no?”

headline: A Plague of Bucks and Does on Staten Island
abstract: The number of deer in New York City and in the borough has continued to grow and the fall mating season has increased the incidences of human-deer friction.
lead_paragraph: Last month, a stag reportedly gored a German shepherd named Sprocket, puncturing the dog’s lung with an antler. Two days later, one jumped through a window at a T.J. Maxx store, then bounded bloodied up and down the aisles of clothes.

headline: Workers Ratify U.A.W. Contracts With General Motors and Ford
abstract: The agreements, following one in October with Fiat Chrysler, brought to a close a tumultuous bargaining season with American vehicle manufacturers.
lead_paragraph: Bringing to a close a tumultuous bargaining season with American vehicle manufacturers, the United Automobile Workers ratified contracts Friday with General Motors and Ford Motor.

headline: Groups Claiming Responsibility in Mali Attack Have History of Resilience
abstract: Al Mourabitoun and Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb have complicated histories but maintain ties to Al Qaeda and nomadic tribesmen.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The two Islamic extremist groups that claimed responsibility for the assault on the Radisson Blu hotel in Mali on Friday are among the most dangerous and resilient in a hodgepodge of terrorist organizations in northwest Africa that have ties to nomadic tribesmen as well as Al Qaeda.

headline: Tom Buckley, Versatile and Colorful Times Reporter, Dies at 87
abstract: Mr. Buckley, who worked at The New York Times from 1953 to 1982, covered a multitude of subjects including the United Nations and the war in Vietnam, and later wrote the column “About New York.”
lead_paragraph: Tom Buckley, a versatile reporter for The New York Times who covered the United Nations and the war in Vietnam, wrote columns about New York City and articles for the Sunday magazine, and as a television critic panned “Hill Street Blues,” died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87.

headline: Lego’s Success Leads to Competitors and Spinoffs
abstract: Lego has made new products based on its interlocking bricks, and its creations have been featured in animated films. Its success has encouraged competition.
lead_paragraph: When Paul Hollingsworth tried to recreate “Jurassic Park” in a video using Lego bricks, he ran into a roadblock. Lego offers plenty of T. rexes, velociraptors and other dinosaurs, but not Richard Attenborough or Jeff Goldblum, who played characters in the movie.

headline: Paris and Mali Attacks Expose Lethal Qaeda-ISIS Rivalry
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Kidnapping and Hostages']
abstract: The competition between the two groups, first provoked by differing strategies in Syria, will be hard to stamp out even if armies can weaken the jihadists in the Middle East and Africa.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Before the hostage crisis at a Malian hotel was over, before the gunmen had even been identified, admirers of Al Qaeda and the rival Islamic State started jostling on social media over which of the jihadist organizations was more righteous and more prominent.

headline: Donald Trump Sets Off a Furor With Call to Register Muslims in the U.S.
abstract: Mr. Trump drew back from his call for a mandatory registry of Muslims in the United States, capping a week where candidates discussed their approaches to terrorism.
lead_paragraph: Under assault from Democrats and Republicans alike, Donald J. Trump on Friday drew back from his call for a mandatory registry of Muslims in the United States, trying to quell one of the ugliest controversies yet in a presidential campaign like few others.

headline: Paris Attacks Force European Union to Act on Border Controls
keywords: ['Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Terrorism', 'Passports']
abstract: Officials met in an emergency session and vowed to complete French proposals for tighter controls by the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — If Europe’s system of passport-free travel was not under enough pressure after a summer of chaotic migration, then last week’s attacks in Paris have fortified doubts over how much longer that freedom of movement — one of the most cherished accomplishments of the European Union — can survive.

headline: What the Saudis Miss When They Focus on Iran
abstract: Saudi Arabia’s single-minded preoccupation with its regional rival is diverting attention from other pressing issues.
lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — It doesn’t take long in Saudi Arabia to see evidence of an obsession with Iran, the Shiite foil to this Sunni country. In recent conversations, government officials, analysts and members of the royal family were quick to describe how incensed they were that President Obama hadn’t found a way to remove Bashar al-Assad, the Syrian president and Iran’s close ally, from power.

headline: Iowa’s Climate-Change Wisdom
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Carbon Capture and Sequestration', 'Soil', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Wind Power', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Solar Energy']
abstract: In America’s heartland, farmers are taking steps to help the environment and return carbon to the soil.
lead_paragraph: Iowa City — NEGOTIATORS en route to the United Nations conference on climate change in Paris, scheduled to begin later this month, should take a detour on rural roads here in Johnson County. A new climate narrative is emerging among farmers in the American heartland that transcends a lot of the old story lines of denial and cynicism, and offers an updated tale of climate hope.

headline: Jury Orders Washington to Pay Wrongfully Convicted Man $16.65 Million
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Sex Crimes', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Donald E. Gates served 27 years in prison for the 1981 rape and murder of a Georgetown University student.
lead_paragraph: The government of Washington, D.C., has agreed to pay $16.65 million to a man after a federal jury found that two police detectives had framed him for the 1981 rape and murder of a college student, a crime for which he was wrongly imprisoned for 27 years.

headline: Brinkmanship in the South China Sea
keywords: ['Editorials', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Law of the Sea (UN Convention)']
abstract: There is no sign yet that summit meetings in the region will make progress on resolving the dispute over Beijing’s claim to sovereignty.
lead_paragraph: Few issues are more important to Asia than the free flow of navigation through the South China Sea, a channel for some $5 trillion in annual trade. And no threat to that trade is as grave as China’s claim to “indisputable sovereignty” over fully 90 percent of the sea. It is no surprise that President Obama and several other leaders were giving the issue high priority this week during back-to-back summit meetings in the region.

headline: The Price of Fear
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Fear (Emotion)', 'Muslim Americans', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Terrorism']
abstract: In the reaction and overreaction to terrorism comes the risk that society will lose its way.
lead_paragraph: After the attacks in Paris, the world is again challenged by fear. With every bombing, beheading and mass shooting, the dread spreads, along with the urgency of defeating this nihilism.

headline: Coalition Pushes for Memorial to the Triangle Fire
keywords: ['Triangle Shirtwaist Factory Fire (1911)', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Fires and Firefighters']
abstract: The 1911 fire, which killed 146 workers in a building near Washington Square, led to sweeping safety reforms and marked a turning point in women’s rights and labor rights.
lead_paragraph: A block east of Washington Square, not far from the neighborhood’s boutiques and chic restaurants, was the site of one of the nation’s worst industrial disasters. Many New Yorkers might be unaware of this.

headline: Fighting Scoliosis, and Dreaming of Having Her Own Business Again
abstract: Carmen Gonzalez came to New York from Puerto Rico and made a life for herself, but her professional, financial and personal successes crumbled when her spine condition worsened and she underwent two operations.
lead_paragraph: After her lifelong disability worsened, Carmen Gonzalez’s hard-fought professional, personal and financial successes started to crumble rapidly. To improve her health, she underwent surgery, which left her with 22 screws in her back and in perpetual pain.

headline: You Can’t Please Everyone
abstract: Natan Last continues our great weekend of puzzles.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I say this a lot, but if this is where you get off the weekly crossword carousel, so to speak, get back up on that horsie and ride again. You won’t be sorry.

headline: Pregnant Woman Killed in Stabbing in the Bronx
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: Police are still trying to determine a motive for the killing, in which a baby was cut out of the pregnant victim.
lead_paragraph: A baby girl, only a few minutes old, swaddled in a blanket or clothes, was breathing on the hood of a car in the Wakefield section of the Bronx. Inside a two-family home nearby, her 22-year-old mother lay on the floor in a pool of blood, fatally stabbed several times in her torso and neck, the authorities said. She had been close to nine months pregnant.

headline: Uterine Transplants
abstract: A doctor raises concerns about plans for the first operation in the United States to transplant a uterus into a woman without one.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Mexico’s Inhuman Rights
abstract: The United Steelworkers writes that Mexico repeatedly obtained Interpol “red notices” against the leader of the Mexican mineworkers union.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Monumental Women
abstract: A reader says public monuments to women should be put “at eye level, where New Yorkers can encounter them every day.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: For an Ethics Bill in Albany
abstract: A reader writes that ethics legislation in New York State “will have the same beneficial effect” as civil rights laws.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. and French Responses to Refugees
abstract: Readers discuss a House vote to make it harder for Syrian refugees to enter the United States, and the balance of security and civil liberties.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Paul Laffoley, Painter Inspired by Time Travel and Aliens, Dies at 80
abstract: Mr. Laffoley, an outsider artist whose work was exhibited at Woodstock, said an extraterrestrial encouraged him to move the universe into the fifth dimension.
lead_paragraph: Paul Laffoley, whose annotated diagrammatic paintings, with their kaleidoscopic representations of abstruse philosophic systems, made him one of the most distinctive and cerebral of the outsider artists, died on Nov. 16 at his home in Boston. He was 80.

headline: 7 New York City Schools Will Reserve Slots for Disadvantaged Students
abstract: In an effort to curb segregation, the Education Department said it would allow seven elementary schools to reserve some slots for children from low-income or non-English speaking families.
lead_paragraph: Taking a small step to address segregation in New York City schools, the Education Department announced on Friday that it would allow seven schools to reserve slots for children from low-income or non-English speaking families.

headline: U.S. Victim of Mali Attack Worked on Women’s Health
abstract: Anita Ashok Datar, an American who was killed in the Mali attack, was devoted to her young son and to helping women in poverty around the world.
lead_paragraph: Anita Ashok Datar, an American public health worker from the Washington suburbs, was killed Friday when gunmen attacked a luxury hotel in Mali’s capital, Bamako, killing at least 19 people and taking as many as 100 more hostage.

headline: Skelos’s Son Wanted C.E.O. Removed in Failed Takeover Bid, Witness Says
abstract: Adam Skelos, the son of the former State Senate majority leader, asked for an executive’s help removing a C.E.O. and threatened a bank loan officer, according to testimony on Friday during the corruption trial of Mr. Skelos and his father.
lead_paragraph: It was a request that would have been extraordinary and unreasonable, no matter who had made it.

headline: Islanders Are Adjusting Faster to Their New Home Than Their Fans Are
abstract: The Islanders are playing at a level that should keep them in the playoff race all season. But not many are coming to their new home in Brooklyn to watch.
lead_paragraph: The Islanders have a winning record. They are coming off a 101-point season and are playing at a level that should keep them in the playoff race all season.

headline: Knicks Win, Surviving Late Rally by Thunder
abstract: With each passing game and every fresh victory, the Knicks have pushed the horrors of last season deeper into the past.
lead_paragraph: In their not-so-distant past, road trips were the stuff of nightmares for the Knicks. Opposing crowds loved seeing them come to town. Things have changed. The Knicks ventured to Oklahoma City on Friday and sent another message in a month full of them by defeating the Thunder, 93-90.

headline: Paris Victims, Remembered
abstract: At least 130 people were killed Nov. 13. They included an architect, an American college student, an Algerian violinist and many, many music fans. Here are some of their stories.
lead_paragraph: At least 130 people were killed Nov. 13. They included an architect, an American college student, an Algerian violinist and many, many music fans. Here are some of their stories.

headline: Yankees Lose Whitley
abstract: The right-handed pitcher Chase Whitley, who is recovering from Tommy John surgery, was claimed off waivers from the Yankees by Tampa Bay.
lead_paragraph: The right-handed pitcher Chase Whitley, who is recovering from Tommy John surgery, was claimed off waivers from the Yankees by Tampa Bay. The Yankees also added pitchers Johnny Barbato and Rookie Davis, as well as outfielder Ben Gamel, to the 40-man roster, which had to be finalized by Friday.

headline: Republicans Discuss Geopolitics at Thanksgiving Table in Iowa
abstract: Rather than the social issues the candidates might have come ready to address before some of Iowa’s most influential conservative voters, geopolitics and the threat of terrorism intruded.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Seven Republican candidates sat around a mocked-up Thanksgiving table here on Friday night, gathered to discuss issues of hearth and home before an audience of more than 1,000 Christian evangelicals.

headline: Seeking Remedies From Home
abstract: Immigrants turn to stores known as botanicas that sell plant-based medicines and herbs for cures to what ails them.
lead_paragraph: Immigrants turn to stores known as botanicas that sell plant-based medicines and herbs for cures to what ails them.

headline: What to Watch Saturday
abstract: An early turkey day, whether “Fifty Shades of Grey” or a few movies starring the actual bird. Then Adele is on Saturday Night Live.
lead_paragraph: Get your Saturday night jollies with the turkeys, whether “Fifty Shades of Grey” or a couple of movies starring the actual bird. Then fall asleep to bittersweet lullabies from Adele.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 21, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “There was no plan. We were just hoping for the best.”

headline: Corrections: November 21, 2015
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, November 21, 2015.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: 9 Foreigners Killed in Mali Are Identified
abstract: The China Railway Construction Corporation said three men were killed by gunmen who attacked a hotel, and the airline Volga-Dnepr said six Russian employees were also killed.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Three senior executives of a Chinese state-owned rail construction company and six Russian employees of a cargo company were among the 19 victims of the gunmen who attacked a hotel in the capital of the West African nation of Mali.

headline: Cate Blanchett’s Oscars Looks
abstract: With “Carol,” the actress is back in the Oscar race and with it the inevitable red carpet question: “Who are you wearing?”
lead_paragraph: With “Carol,” the actress is back in the Oscar race and with it the inevitable red carpet question: “Who are you wearing?”

headline: Unilever Finds That Shrinking Its Footprint Is a Giant Task
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Sustainable Living', 'Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs']
abstract: Unilever has pledged to cut its environmental impact in half while improving the health of one billion people, but sustainability is turning out to be complicated.
lead_paragraph: Hellmann’s mayonnaise is known for many things — making egg salad delicious, being loaded with fat, that old “bring out the best” jingle. To date, however, it hasn’t been associated with sustainability. Mayo is a processed food made by huge conglomerates, not a symbol of environmentalism.

headline: The Nanny Factor in Hollywood Marriages
abstract: Once a no-nonsense figure, a nanny has come to be regarded as a potential home wrecker. And in some high-profile cases, she has been.
lead_paragraph: When Jennifer Schuur Herbert passes a rack of tabloid magazines in her Los Angeles neighborhood, she is often reminded of what can happen in even the most glamorous Hollywood marriages.

headline: Why Snapping Is the New Clapping
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Text Messaging', 'Social Media']
abstract: “You can’t applaud while taking a selfie or texting.”
lead_paragraph: Christian Bailey, a 58-year-old physicist who works for a manufacturing company in Elkton, Md., was attending a conference on progressive health care issues when he began to feel self-conscious. He would look around and notice a key difference between himself and nearly everyone else in the room.

headline: The True Story of Sergeant Goosby and His 19 Dogs
abstract: The head canine trainer for the Los Angeles Police Department seems like he’s right out of crime novels and film.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “If they ask you to wear the bite suit, say no.”

headline: Lee Miller’s Journey From Model to War Photographer
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Photography', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Museums']
abstract: Two retrospectives focus on a woman who went from the covers of magazines to the front lines of war.
lead_paragraph: London — In 1927, a chance encounter on a New York sidewalk with the media mogul Condé Nast made the gamine beauty Lee Miller a magazine cover girl and modeling sensation. Later, as the lover and muse of the artist Man Ray, her face and body were preserved in some of the most striking solarized portraits of the Surrealist age.

headline: Cate Blanchett and Her Red Carpet Journey
abstract: With “Carol,” the actress is back in the Oscar race, and with it comes the inevitable red carpet question: “Who are you wearing?”
lead_paragraph: It was shortly after 8 a.m. on Wednesday and Cate Blanchett was 15 minutes late to breakfast.

headline: Are Squirrels Able to Enjoy the Changing Colors of Fall?
abstract: Squirrels do have color vision, but they cannot see the difference between the green leaves of summer and the red leaves of fall, researchers say.
lead_paragraph: Q. Do squirrels see the colorful fall display of red, yellow and brown leaves?

headline: Inside Raqqa, the Capital of ISIS
abstract: A bustling city has been transformed under the group’s brutal rule.
lead_paragraph: A bustling city has been transformed under the group’s brutal rule.

headline: The Week on Instagram
abstract: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took followers from scenes of mourning on the streets of Paris to the stage at the David H. Koch Theater.
lead_paragraph: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took followers from scenes of mourning on the streets of Paris to the stage at the David H. Koch Theater.

headline: Refugees Must Not Be Turned Away, Obama Says
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: President Obama, speaking in Malaysia, where he met with children who had fled violence, said the United States should not close itself to the world’s refugees out of fear.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — President Obama vowed on Saturday to keep America’s borders open to the world’s refugees “as long as I’m president,” even as he met with child migrants and refugees here and his administration refused to yield in a long-distance feud with his critics over the issue.

headline: ISIS Women and Enforcers in Syria Recount Collaboration, Anguish and Escape
abstract: Three young women who fled to southern Turkey recalled their experiences as members of the Islamic State morality police in Raqqa, Syria.
lead_paragraph: SOUTHERN TURKEY — Dua had only been working for two months with the Khansaa Brigade, the all-female morality police of the Islamic State, when her friends were brought to the station to be whipped.

headline: Brussels Placed at Highest Alert Level; Subway Is Closed
abstract: Belgian authorities halted public transit and warned citizens to avoid public places after a “serious and imminent” threat of a Paris-style terrorist attack.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Warning of a “serious and imminent” threat of a Paris-style terrorist attack, the authorities in Belgium on Saturday shut down the Brussels subway system, canceled soccer games and advised citizens to avoid public places amid a security lockdown across the Belgian capital.

headline: FIFA Ethics Committee Recommends New Sanctions for Sepp Blatter and Michel Platini
keywords: ['Soccer', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'World Cup (Soccer)']
abstract: FIFA’s top ethics investigator has completed his inquiry into a financial transaction between the men in 2011.
lead_paragraph: Ethics investigators for FIFA, the ruling body of world soccer, have recommended sanctions be imposed on Sepp Blatter, the organization’s longtime president, and Michel Platini, the head of soccer’s European confederation, the organization said on Saturday.

headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: Turkeys, News and News Turkeys
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'News and News Media', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)']
abstract: On whether instant reactions to breaking news make it preferable to avoid the Internet and television altogether until facts are sorted from fiction.
lead_paragraph: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: When the Noisy Neighbor is a Church
abstract: All-day church music; a neighboring house in disrepair; and limits on reverse mortgages.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: ‘The Knick’ Season 2, Episode 6: A Circus Sideshow
abstract: The consequences of inquisitiveness and desperation were fully on display this episode.
lead_paragraph: Early 20th-century medicine often looks like a circus sideshow on “The Knick,” but never as literally as in this week’s episode. Haunting the dime-museum arcade, John Thackery took in a not-very-convincing hypnotist and a very persuasive pair of conjoined Russian sisters. Both put ideas into his head. Hypnotism seemed like a possible answer in his search for a cure to addiction, though an experiment involving Tom Cleary didn’t go so well. The sight of the twins inspired his pure medical curiosity, and soon, with Cleary’s help, he was kidnapping them from their manager and pimp and preparing to surgically separate them, with the help of his trio of protégés, Bertie Chickering, Algernon Edwards and Everett Gallinger. (The pimp was played with understated grotesquerie by Fred Weller of “In Plain Sight,” while the sisters were played by Miranda and Rebecca Gruss and an armature of artificial flesh.)

headline: Hyundai Cars Are Recalled Over Faulty Brake Switch
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles']
abstract: The automaker is recalling more than 300,000 2011-12 Sonatas because the transmission can be moved out of park without pressing the brake pedal.
lead_paragraph: Hyundai is recalling about 305,000 of its 2011-12 Sonata models because the automatic transmission could possibly be moved out of park without pressing the brake pedal, allowing the car to roll or drive away, according to a report from the automaker posted this week on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration’s website.

headline: A Cherished Custom at Penn, Any Way You Slice It
abstract: Penn students’ tradition of throwing toast can be traced to an alcohol ban in the 1970s, and it appears to be linked to a scene in “The Rocky Horror Picture Show.”
lead_paragraph: University of Pennsylvania fans have a peculiar way of displaying school spirit at home games. They throw toast.

headline: Breaking a Toshiba Laptop Owner’s Cycle of Repair
keywords: ['Customer Relations', 'Laptop Computers', 'Consumer Protection', 'Guarantees and Warranties', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: After 30 hours on the phone with tech support for a frozen trackpad, three visits from a technician and a replacement unit, a Toshiba user was not happy with the company’s offer.
lead_paragraph: Now and then, the Haggler is called a cynic. Invariably, it is by horrible people who are motivated by selfishness and greed — just like every human being on the face of the earth.

headline: U.A.W. Vote at Ford and G.M. Ends Painful Process for Big Three
abstract: The new contracts, which were finalized after a painstaking process, include raises and bonuses for all unionized workers and provide a path for newer employees to eventually achieve wage parity with veteran workers.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — After five months of bargaining and divisive ratification votes, the United Automobile Workers on Friday completed new labor contracts covering more than 140,000 workers at the three largest American automakers.

headline: Variety: A Tough Cryptic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon make me work for my cryptic fix, and the passing of Rosalie Moscovitch.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Before we get started, I wanted to take a moment to mention the passing of Rosalie Moscovitch, who contributed cryptics and other variety puzzles to The New York Times. I never had a chance to meet her in person, but we corresponded behind the scenes. Ms. Moscovitch died Nov. 10 and she will be missed. If you would like to try her last variety puzzle that she co-wrote with Joe Cabrera, you can find it here.

headline: ‘Jessica Jones’ Episode 2: The Devil Did
abstract: Jessica and Luke Cage learn a little more about each other.
lead_paragraph: Control is everything in another thoughtfully character-driven, albeit tonally wonky episode of “Jessica Jones.” We are constantly reminded of the show’s thematic concern with control through dialogue that underscores the way that everyone, from supervillain Kilgrave to good guy Luke Cage, struggles to stay on top of their lives. Jones knows that struggle well, as we see when she nurses a drink while investigating Kilgrave’s case. She snaps at her upstairs neighbors for the same reason: She can’t see the world beyond her own problems, and therefore despises people she imagines can’t handle their own private lives — in private.

headline: Mali Hotel Attackers Are Tied to an Algerian Qaeda Leader
abstract: A member of Al Qaeda said the attack on the Radisson Blu Hotel in Bamako was carried out by a jihadist group loyal to Mokhtar Belmokhtar, a Qaeda operative.
lead_paragraph: A member of Al Qaeda in Africa confirmed Saturday that the attack Friday on a hotel in Bamako, Mali, had been carried out by a jihadist group loyal to Mokhtar Belmokhtar, an Algerian operative for Al Qaeda.

headline: Pentagon Expands Inquiry Into Intelligence on ISIS Surge
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: The Pentagon has seized a trove of emails and documents as it widens an investigation into Central Command over accusations that officials had overstated the progress of airstrikes against the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Islamic State fighters overran a string of Iraqi cities last year, analysts at United States Central Command wrote classified assessments for military intelligence officials and policy makers that documented the humiliating retreat of the Iraqi Army. But before the assessments were final, former intelligence officials said, the analysts’ superiors made significant changes.

headline: Finding Ways to Thwart the Jerk at Work
abstract: Some employees are what researchers call “de-energizers,” spreading a dispiriting attitude around the office. In nonacademic terms, these people are known as jerks.
lead_paragraph: Most of us have days at work when we walk around with a spring in our step and perform our tasks with gusto — and other days when our feet drag and we just can’t seem to get motivated. A new study encourages employees to look more closely at the people around them as one reason for that disparity.

headline: Bored to Tears by a Do-Nothing Dream Job
abstract: An overworked newspaper editor has his daydream fulfilled: eight hours a day at a desk, with nothing to do. But that dream turns into a nightmare.
lead_paragraph: More than a decade ago, I was in the type of job where, if I had sat down at my desk and worked for 100 hours straight, I would be only slightly less behind than when I started. I was a newspaper editor, stuck in the type of never-ending grind that caused me to begin having a regular daydream.

headline: Wall St. Ties Linger as Image Issue for Hillary Clinton
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: At a time when liberals are ascendant in the party, some Democrats believe Hillary Rodham Clinton’s time representing Wall Street as a senator could become a vulnerability.
lead_paragraph: John Wittneben simmered as he listened to Hillary Rodham Clinton defend her ties to Wall Street during last weekend’s Democratic debate. He lost 40 percent of his savings in individual retirement accounts during the Great Recession, while Mrs. Clinton has received millions of dollars from the kinds of executives he believes should be in jail.

headline: The Refugees of Roanoke
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: Our mayor tried to turn his back on fleeing Syrians. That’s not our way.
lead_paragraph: ROANOKE, Va. — ON Friday, David Bowers, the Democratic mayor of Roanoke, apologized for comments in which he called for halting the resettlement of Syrian refugees and suggested that our situation was similar to the one Franklin D. Roosevelt faced when he imprisoned Japanese-Americans.

headline: Computing by Design
abstract: Readers respond to “Setting Free the Squares” (Nov. 15).
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Hotel Attack in Mali Reverses Gains in Fight Against Extremism
abstract: The fatal attack on a hotel in Mali’s capital leads to questions about how a democratic society can protect itself from a few determined extremists.
lead_paragraph: BAMAKO, Mali — The terrorists chose carefully: There are nearly always French, Russian and even a few American visitors to be found in the hotel restaurant, around the pool, in the health club or on the thin black-leather sofas of the glass-fronted lobby, now shattered by gunfire.

headline: Vocal Strain Poses Long-Term Risks for Coaches. Anyone Have a Lozenge?
keywords: ['Basketball (College)', 'Coaches and Managers', 'Voice and Speech', 'Medicine and Health', 'Larynx', 'Throat']
abstract: Yelling is a way of life for college basketball coaches, who have adopted various remedies to try to ease the damage to their vocal cords.
lead_paragraph: Some college basketball coaches protect their voices with daily cups of tea. Others gargle with salt water in the morning and before games. Others stick with Life Savers and cough drops. Or at least they try.

headline: Bert Olmstead, Hall of Fame Passer in Canadiens Dynasty, Dies at 89
abstract: Olmstead, with pinpoint passing, helped Montreal win five Stanley Cups in the 1950s. He did the same with the Toronto Maple Leafs in 1962.
lead_paragraph: Bert Olmstead, a Hockey Hall of Fame wing who played on five Stanley Cup championship teams, four times with the Montreal Canadiens of the 1950s, died on Tuesday in High River, Alberta. He was 89.

headline: Gay Marriage Derailed in Northern Ireland
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: A motion to legalize same-sex marriage in Northern Ireland is blocked, causing a disconnect along the border.
lead_paragraph: It was Oscar Wilde, Ireland’s peerless playwright and essayist, who suffered imprisonment for his homosexuality but wryly advised, “The proper basis for marriage is mutual misunderstanding.”

headline: Uncertain Journeys
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Our resolve to help refugees should be stronger than ever after the attacks in Paris.
lead_paragraph: Our resolve to help refugees should be stronger than ever after the attacks in Paris.

headline: Are Good Doctors Bad for Your Health?
keywords: ['Doctors', 'Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Heart', 'Medicine and Health', 'Surgery and Surgeons', 'Research']
abstract: Having a heart attack? Better hope that the star cardiologist is out of town.
lead_paragraph: PRETTY regularly, I receive an urgent call from a distraught friend or friend of a brother. “Zeke, Mom was at home and her heart stopped. The E.M.T.s are rushing her to XYZ hospital in Miami. Can you help me find the best cardiologist there for her?”

headline: Don’t Let Progress on Tobacco Evaporate
abstract: House Republicans are seeking to slash government programs that have helped lower the adult smoking rate.
lead_paragraph: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported this month that the adult smoking rate in the United States has fallen to a new low, a testament to the decades of education about the dangers of tobacco and measures to discourage its use. Now Republicans in the House are seeking to slash the very government programs that have helped to achieve such remarkable success.

headline: Searching for Richard Nixon
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: What the current field of presidential hopefuls could learn from Tricky Dick.
lead_paragraph: IT’S a truth universally accepted that every Republican who runs for president wants to be Ronald Reagan, and that every Democrat wants to be either Franklin Roosevelt or (God help us) John F. Kennedy.

headline: How ISIS Defeats Us
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Terrorism', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: If we can’t behave more logically than ideologically, we’re doomed.
lead_paragraph: I DON’T know how we win the war against ISIS.

headline: The Danger of Placing Your Chips on Beauty
keywords: ['Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Terrorism', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Paris is a natural target for those who would destroy the human spirit.
lead_paragraph: Paris — MEMORIES, the French poet Guillaume Apollinaire wrote, are like the sound of hunters’ horns fading in the wind. I have loved in Paris, had children, dreamed, wandered, gotten lost, found myself again. At every intersection there is an invitation, on every bridge a recollection. The carnage, in this city, feels like a personal matter.

headline: ‘The Statue of Liberty Must Be Crying With Shame’
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Christians and Christianity', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Terrorism', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Japanese-Americans']
abstract: Luckily House Republicans weren’t in charge when Jesus was a refugee.
lead_paragraph: AS anti-refugee hysteria sweeps many of our political leaders, particularly Republicans, I wonder what they would have told a desperate refugee family fleeing the Middle East. You’ve heard of this family: a carpenter named Joseph, his wife, Mary, and their baby son, Jesus.

headline: The Strip
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Pacific Trade and Worker Rights
keywords: ['Editorials', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership']
abstract: The success of the Trans-Pacific trade pact will depend on how well the nations actually enforce new labor standards.
lead_paragraph: President Obama says that the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a trade agreement his administration negotiated with 11 other countries, will help raise labor standards in developing nations like Vietnam, Malaysia and Mexico. The deal, the text of which was published earlier this month, could deliver on that promise, but much will depend on factors beyond Mr. Obama’s control, like how T.P.P. countries and future presidents carry out  the pact.

headline: Ann Ravel
abstract: The chairwoman of the Federal Election Commission on poetry, daily pictures of her dog and her playlist of California music.
lead_paragraph: Ann Ravel is the chairwoman of the Federal Election Commission, the agency that governs the financing of federal elections. Previously, she was the chairwoman of the California Fair Political Practices Commission, which also oversees the regulation of campaign finance.

headline: Choose to Be Grateful. It Will Make You Happier.
abstract: In concept, saying you’re grateful even if you’re not seems bourgeois and saccharine. But it’s actually a tool to a better end.
lead_paragraph: TWENTY-FOUR years ago this month, my wife and I married in Barcelona, Spain. Two weeks after our wedding, flush with international idealism, I had the bright idea of sharing a bit of American culture with my Spanish in-laws by cooking a full Thanksgiving dinner.

headline: Ruling From the Shadows
keywords: ['Corporations', 'ACCOUNTING AND ACCOUNTANTS', 'Executive Compensation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The most boring, most important, issues in politics.
lead_paragraph: WE’VE come to expect bickering from our politicians. We’re often exasperated by this state of affairs and sometimes we yearn for a quieter, gentler age, when compromise wasn’t a dirty word. But the raucous rivalry in Washington has its benefits: a political process thick with competition. By contrast, political competition in other important parts of our democracy is worrisomely thin.

headline: Why Are Student Protesters So Fearful?
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Youth', 'Sex Crimes', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', "Women's Rights", 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Today’s campus movements are rooted in a feeling of acute vulnerability.
lead_paragraph: THE message coming out of recent student protests on college campuses, from Princeton and Yale to the University of Missouri, couldn’t be clearer: Students are rightly pained by the racist and sexual abuse still shockingly common into the 21st century, and for good reason they are indignant that institutions they trust — or wish to trust — fail to stop the culprits, or even to acknowledge publicly the harm they do.

headline: Debates on Campus
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: Readers discuss the political, social and intellectual environment on campuses today.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss the controversies over free speech and safe spaces on college campuses.

headline: Herbert Scarf, an Economist’s Mathematician, Dies at 85
abstract: Mr. Scarf, a Yale mathematician, never took an economics class, but his theories were accepted by businesses and governments.
lead_paragraph: Herbert Scarf, a Yale mathematician who never took an economics course but whose groundbreaking theories were embraced by businesses and governments, died on Nov. 15 at his home in Sag Harbor, N.Y. He was 85.

headline: Whiff of Suspicion Keeps the Hall of Fame Far Away
abstract: Even with changes to the voting bloc, which might increase the chances of some athletes with tainted histories, the threshold of 75 percent for induction remains a daunting standard.
lead_paragraph: The most important number to remember, when considering the evolving process of voting for the Baseball Hall of Fame, is the figure that remains constant: 75. That is the percentage that candidates must reach to be elected by the writers, and it is truly an overwhelming majority.

headline: How to Host Thanksgiving: Dos and Don'ts
abstract: The Times’s Florence Fabricant gives etiquette advice for entertaining on Thanksgiving.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Florence Fabricant gives etiquette advice for entertaining on Thanksgiving.

headline: In Argentina, a Quiet Data Cruncher Aims to Bring Sense to a Raucous Election
keywords: ['Statistics', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Elections', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: A low-key data cruncher, Andy Tow, has emerged as a guide to Argentina’s contested presidential race. Along the way, he has won fame, influence and ire.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — With his fusty corduroy blazer, diffident mien and unpolished website, Andy Tow, an anonymous civil servant with a flair for data crunching, is emerging as an unlikely rock star of Argentina’s election season.

headline: Are Banks Europe’s Problem?
abstract: Japan’s story repeats.
lead_paragraph: For those of us who worried a lot about Japan in the late 1990s and now find the whole advanced world facing similar problems, deja vu comes so often that we get deja vu about getting deja vu. A case in point is the rise and fall of European bank-blaming — that is, the argument that the weakness of banks is what’s holding European recovery back.

headline: Game Management Humbles Even the Best N.F.L. Coaches
abstract: The one constant is that game management, and all that it entails, seems to mystify coaches every week, regardless of their pedigree. No one is immune from scrutiny or gaffes.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — As the coach of the Baltimore Ravens, Brian Billick would devote part of his Friday practices to play-calling oddities. If the moment called for an intentional safety or a hurried field-goal try while the final seconds of a half ticked off, he wanted his players to feel prepared — and they were, he said.

headline: Sunday’s Matchup: Jets at Texans
abstract: Here’s what you need to know when the Jets play the Texans.
lead_paragraph: 1 p.m., CBS

headline: Grassley Says His Former Aide Is Not Source for Huma Abedin Disclosures
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Senator Charles E. Grassley said another person, not a former aide of his now working in the State Department, was a source of information for an inquiry of Huma Abedin’s work while she was an aide to Hillary Rodham Clinton at the State Department.
lead_paragraph: Aides to Senator Charles E. Grassley, the Iowa Republican whose committee is reviewing issues surrounding Hillary Rodham Clinton‘s tenure at the State Department, are trying to quell questions raised by Democrats about who has provided him with previously undisclosed information.

headline: Woman Charged in Grisly Death of Pregnant Mother Left a Cryptic Trail
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: Police officials said they had no indication that the suspect, Ashleigh Wade, was actually expecting a child, and neighbors said they had not seen signs that she was.
lead_paragraph: A woman charged with fatally stabbing an expectant mother and cutting a baby from her womb in the Bronx on Friday had been telling people for months that she herself was pregnant, according to interviews on Saturday.

headline: Op-Photo: Unjustly Convicted, Robert Jones Is Free (for Now)
abstract: Mr. Jones was released from prison on Friday after prosecutors revealed evidence that could exonerate him. But he could be convicted again.
lead_paragraph: The case of Robert Jones, the editorial board wrote in October, is only “the latest example of misconduct out of New Orleans.” Mr. Jones’s conviction in a 1992 kidnapping, rape and robbery was vacated after prosecutors revealed evidence calling their case into question — evidence they had before Mr. Jones’s trial but failed to share with the defense.

headline: Heat’s Hassan Whiteside Proves Value While Playing at Bargain Price
abstract: Whiteside, once a little-known defensive specialist, is having the type of season that should put to rest the notion that last season was a fluke.
lead_paragraph: When the little-known defensive specialist Hassan Whiteside unexpectedly became a borderline star with the Miami Heat in the second half of last season, the big question was whether he was a one-season wonder or a player at the beginning of a special career.

headline: A Long-Awaited Homecoming, Marred by Multiple Tragedies
abstract: After 13 years, Katimi Bouare finally returned to Ivory Coast to introduce her father to his American grandchildren. But death, illness and an apartment fire plagued her homecoming at every step.
lead_paragraph: It was supposed to be a joyous, overdue reunion. Instead, Katimi Bouare’s homecoming unexpectedly coincided with tragedy.

headline: Fighting Evictions, a Single Mother Draws Strength From Her Children
abstract: Gardenia Valerio, 30, lives in the Bronx and plans to earn her high school equivalency diploma and become a medical assistant.
lead_paragraph: Gardenia Valerio’s two-bedroom apartment in the Soundview section of the Bronx, steps from the Bruckner Expressway, was welcoming and calm.

headline: Philippine Grandparents, Struggling to Start Fresh in a New Homeland
abstract: Fortunato and Adelaida Dilan immigrated to the United States in search of new opportunities. But illness and financial hardship have made that search into a struggle.
lead_paragraph: When Fortunato Dilan first felt a lump on the crown of his head five years ago, he did his best to keep it a secret from his wife, Adelaida. He wore a baseball cap or tilted his face upward when they spoke.

headline: A New Life, New Challenges and a Firm Resolve
abstract: Three stories of immigrants touch on the challenges they have faced and the ways in which they have persevered, part of the coverage of the 104th annual campaign of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
lead_paragraph: New York’s immigrant population numbers about 3.1 million people, a record high, according to a 2013 city report, “The Newest New Yorkers.” Foreign-born residents make up about 37 percent of the overall population of 8.2 million, according to the report.

headline: Fire at Chicago’s John Hancock Center Injures 5
abstract: The fire broke out on the 50th floor Saturday afternoon, and it was quickly brought under control.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — A fire broke out Saturday afternoon on the 50th floor of the John Hancock Center, one of this city’s tallest skyscrapers, but was quickly brought under control. Chicago Fire Department officials said five people, including a police officer, sustained minor injuries.

headline: Long Way for a Snub in a Qualifying Match
abstract: The Iraqis flew Columbus’s Justin Meram in business class to Chinese Taipai for a World Cup qualifier, then left him sitting on the bench without an explanation.
lead_paragraph: Justin Meram apologized in advance for any yawns that might occur during the interview. He had just endured a 27-hour journey from Taiwan that had included two layovers, 13 time zones and one very troublesome, existential question:

headline: Both Poised and Playful, Lydia Ko Finds Her Winning Balance
abstract: With a successful defense of her Tour Championship title, Ko on Sunday can secure the Vare Trophy, awarded to the player with the lowest season stroke average.
lead_paragraph: NAPLES, Fla. — Lydia Ko’s mother, Tina, was walking the first hole of Tiburon Golf Club during the second round of the L.P.G.A. season finale when two men stopped her in her tracks. “Your daughter’s awesome,” one said as the other nodded enthusiastically. The speaker expounded his thought. “She hits a bad shot and seconds later she’s laughing. She is so relaxed.”

headline: Evening Hours | Fall Swing
abstract: Parties for holiday windows, the arts and the elderly.
lead_paragraph: Parties for holiday windows, the arts and the elderly.

headline: Martin Truex Jr. Embraces a Shot at Nascar’s Championship
abstract: Behind garage doors in Denver, Truex’s racing team has done everything in its power to prepare Truex and his No. 78 Chevrolet for the opportunity to win the Sprint Cup Championship.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Far from the Nascar hotbed of Charlotte, N.C., sits a nondescript auto shop with no sign out front, smack in the middle of the Colorado Rockies. It is the last place a race fan would expect to find Martin Truex Jr., one of four drivers competing Sunday for the 2015 Sprint Cup Championship at Homestead-Miami Speedway in Homestead, Fla.

headline: China’s Nuclear Vision Collides With Villagers’ Fears
keywords: ['Nuclear Energy', 'Air Pollution', 'Coal', 'Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Rural Areas']
abstract: Hubin Village is among the inland sites where officials plan to build atomic reactors over the next decade, but residents are nervous.
lead_paragraph: HUBIN VILLAGE, China — This placid, leafy hamlet tucked beside a dam in the countryside hardly seems like the next testing ground over China’s efforts to cut smog and greenhouse gases. But here among cornfields and crumbling stone homes skirted by persimmon trees, the government intends to build a nuclear power plant.

headline: Massachusetts’s Rejection of Common Core Test Signals Shift in U.S.
abstract: As states have rejected tests tied to the Common Core standards, no about-face has resonated more than that of Massachusetts, known as a leader in education reform.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — It has been one of the most stubborn problems in education: With 50 states, 50 standards and 50 tests, how could anyone really know what American students were learning, or how well?

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines in Sports.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Turn Off Your Devices? Sometimes Plays Turn Them On
keywords: ['Theater', 'Social Media', 'Smartphones', 'Text Messaging', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Wireless Communications', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Increasingly, playwrights regard digital communications as essential plot elements, and try different ways of dramatizing them.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a recipe for a terrible play: Characters are rarely in the same room as one another; conversations are typed rather than spoken; one side of a dispute can’t be heard by the audience.

headline: Bangladesh Hangs 2 Leaders Convicted of War Crimes
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Capital Punishment']
abstract: The opposition leaders had been convicted of atrocities dating back to the 1971 war for independence from Pakistan, going through trials that had been criticized as biased toward the prosecution.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The Bangladeshi authorities on Sunday hanged two senior opposition leaders convicted of atrocities dating to Bangladesh’s 1971 war for independence from Pakistan.

headline: Right On, Right On!
abstract: Samuel A. Donaldson and Jeff Chen get us all turned around.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — I know. You thought this was going to be another one of those themes where the entry drops off and makes a sharp turn somewhere and that would be it, right? That’s so ho-hum. There’s something more in store for you today.

headline: Five Indicted in Leak of Confidential Vatican Documents
abstract: The five defendants were charged with “illegally procuring and successively revealing information and documents concerning the fundamental interests of the Holy See and the state.”
lead_paragraph: ROME — Vatican prosecutors on Saturday formally indicted five people in connection with the theft of confidential documents used to write two tell-all books describing purported mismanagement in the Roman Catholic Church’s bureaucracy.

headline: Chicago Set for Protests Over Shooting by the Police
keywords: ['Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: The city has been ordered within a matter of days to release police video of the fatal shooting of a black 17-year-old by a white police officer.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — For months, leaders here watched as other cities faced angry demonstrations over police conduct, shootings and relations with black people, often captured in painful videos. As cities like Ferguson, Mo., Baltimore and New York have been consumed by fatal encounters involving the local police that have fueled national attention since 2014, this city managed to keep a lower profile.

headline: Afghan Kidnappers Prey on Hazaras
abstract: A campaign of kidnappings against the Hazara ethnic group intensified on Saturday as gunmen stopped a number of buses along Afghanistan’s main highway and separated out the Hazara passengers, officials said.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A campaign of kidnappings against the Hazara ethnic group intensified on Saturday as gunmen stopped a number of buses along Afghanistan’s main highway and separated out the Hazara passengers, officials said.

headline: Kim Young-sam, South Korean President Who Opposed Military, Dies at 87
abstract: Mr. Kim, an outspoken critic of military dictators, became the first civilian leader in South Korea in more than three decades when he was elected in 1992.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Kim Young-sam, the former president of South Korea who replaced the last of the country’s military leaders, purged politicized generals and introduced a landmark reform aimed at transparency in financial transactions, died on Sunday in Seoul. He was 87.

headline: Michigan State Stuns Ohio State With a Late Field Goal
abstract: The Spartans, despite being without their steadfast starting quarterback Connor Cook, played their best game of the year and upset the Buckeyes, 17-14, ending with a 41-yard field goal in the final seconds.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Michael Thomas and Jalin Marshall, Ohio State’s best wide receivers, both had inexplicable drops on what should have been simple throw-and-catches against Michigan State on Saturday. The drops came on two of the staggering six three-and-out drives the No. 2 Buckeyes had.

headline: Cutting Water Use, but Still Getting Soaked
keywords: ['Water', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Drought', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Rationing and Allocation of Resources']
abstract: Amid drought in California, a disparity has emerged in who gets fined for excessive water use, with many wealthier residents getting off scot-free.
lead_paragraph: Amid drought in California, a disparity has emerged in who gets fined for excessive water use, with many wealthier residents getting off scot-free.

headline: In California, Stingy Water Users Are Fined in Drought, While the Rich Soak
keywords: ['Water', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Drought', 'Rationing and Allocation of Resources', 'Fines (Penalties)']
abstract: The contrast between strict enforcement on some struggling to conserve water and unchecked profligacy in places like Bel Air has unleashed anger and indignation.
lead_paragraph: APPLE VALLEY, Calif. — Outside her two-story tract home in this working-class town, Debbie Alberts, a part-time food service worker, has torn out most of the lawn. She has given up daily showers and cut her family’s water use nearly in half, to just 178 gallons per person each day.

headline: Donald Trump Calls for Surveillance of ‘Certain Mosques’ and a Syrian Refugee Database
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Mosques', 'Muslims and Islam', 'September 11 (2001)', 'Muslim Americans', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The Republican presidential candidate also claimed to have watched “thousands” of people cheering in Jersey City as the World Trade Center towers fell on Sept. 11, 2001.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump said Saturday that he would order surveillance of “certain mosques” to combat terrorism after the Paris attacks and claimed to have watched as “thousands and thousands of people were cheering” while the World Trade Center towers fell on Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: John Bel Edwards, Democrat, Defeats David Vitter in Louisiana Governor’s Race
abstract: Mr. Edwards soundly beat Mr. Vitter, who said in his concession speech that he would not run for re-election to the Senate next year.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — With a victory that defied political geography and near universal predictions from just months earlier, a previously little-known Democrat, State Representative John Bel Edwards, soundly defeated United States Senator David Vitter in a runoff election on Saturday to become the next governor of Louisiana.

headline: Missing Maryland College Student Is Found Dead in Apparent Suicide
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Missing Persons', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: Jacob Marberger, whose disappearance and possible possession of a firearm prompted his college to shut down, died from a self-inflicted gunshot, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A troubled student whose disappearance with a rifle case on Monday led his college in Maryland to shut its doors until the end of the month was found dead from a self-inflicted gunshot Saturday at a bird sanctuary in Pennsylvania, the police said.

headline: Ilissa Samplin, Michael Behr
abstract: The couple met at Stanford University, from which they graduated, she with a law degree and he with an M.B.A.
lead_paragraph: Ilissa Stacy Samplin, a daughter of Caren L. Samplin and Marc L. Samplin of Merrick, N.Y., was married Saturday evening in Miami Beach to Michael Scott Behr, the son of Debra L. Behr and Glenn S. Behr of Longwood, Fla. Rabbi Steven W. Engel officiated at the Miami Beach Edition, a hotel and resort.

headline: Naomi Kaplan, Eric Morris
abstract: The couple met at the University of Pennsylvania, from which they graduated, she summa cum laude and he cum laude.
lead_paragraph: Naomi Dena Kaplan, a daughter of Amy K. Kaplan and Dr. Barnard A. Kaplan of Voorhees, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Eric Charles Morris, a son of Nancy A. Karr and Howard J. Morris of Needham, Mass. Rabbi Aaron Krupnick performed the ceremony at Congregation Beth El in Voorhees.

headline: Thomas Donovan, Raj Raghavan
abstract: The couple met on Valentine’s Day in 2004.

White and Gregory A. White of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Alvin Wainhaus officiated at Weylin B. Seymours, an event space in the former Williamsburg Savings Bank building in Brooklyn.

Simela of North Woodmere, N.Y. Michael Davis, a cousin of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at the Liberty Hotel in Boston.

Thomas E. Nicoll of Greenville, S.C. The groom’s father, who retired as the rector of St. John’s Episcopal Church in Larchmont, N.Y., officiated at South Seas Island Resort on Captiva Island in Florida. The groom’s maternal grandfather, Canon David R. Forbes, also an Episcopal priest, participated.

Carolyn Trager Kliman, the groom’s sister who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, is to officiate at a ceremony that will incorporate Jewish wedding traditions.

headline: The Best Moments in College Football This Week
abstract: A look at some of the top story lines from the twelfth week of the 2015 college football season.
lead_paragraph: NATE SUDFELD The Indiana senior, above, threw for 385 yards and four touchdowns, and the Hoosiers rallied from an early 18-point deficit to top host Maryland, 47-28, for its first Big Ten win of the season. Sudfeld completed 23 of 35 passes and also ran for a score.

headline: Saúl Álvarez Wins W.B.C. Middleweight Title, Beating Miguel Cotto
abstract: In a highly anticipated matchup with nationalistic overtones, Canelo of Mexico, 25, won by a unanimous decision over Cotto, 35, of Puerto Rico, possibly setting up a title unification bout with Gennady Golovkin.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The fans, many of whom sported red, white and green attire, roared when the Mexican boxing legends Marco Antonio Barrera and Julio César Chávez were shown on the big screen at the Mandalay Bay Events Center on Saturday night.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 22, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “For me, it was about power and money, mostly power. Since my relatives had all joined, it didn’t change a great deal to join. I just had more authority.”

headline: Crimea in Dark After Power Lines Are Blown Up
keywords: ['Power Failures and Blackouts', 'Sabotage (Crime)', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Tatars (Ethnic Group)']
abstract: Russian news reports said saboteurs were responsible for shutting down the lines in the disputed peninsula.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Saboteurs blew up the main power lines leading into Crimea early Sunday, plunging the disputed peninsula into darkness and prompting the Russian government to impose a state of emergency there.

headline: Obama Orders Inquiry Into Intelligence on ISIS
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']

lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — President Obama said on Sunday that he had ordered his senior defense officials to find out whether intelligence reports had been altered to reflect a more optimistic assessment of the American military campaign against the Islamic State.

headline: 1915: War Hospital In Paris Becomes Prey To Flames
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A war hospital, set up in the Bon Marche, catches fire in Paris in 1915.
lead_paragraph: Fire yesterday practically destroyed the annex of the Bon Marché, the great store on the left bank of the Seine so well known to all residents in the American Quartier Latin of Paris. The upper floors of the annex, which is situated at the corner of the rue de Sèvres and at the rue du Bac, were used as a war hospital, nearly 200 wounded soldiers being tended there. Exciting scenes occurred during the rescue of these helpless heroes, and the doctors and nurses of the hospital showed remarkable devotion.

headline: States Lead Effort to Let Pharmacists Prescribe Birth Control
keywords: ['Drugstores', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Women and Girls', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Starting sometime in the next few months, California and Oregon will allow women to get a prescription directly from a pharmacist, a move that advocates hope becomes a national model.
lead_paragraph: Groundbreaking laws in two Western states will soon make access to birth control easier for millions of women by allowing them to obtain contraceptives from pharmacists without a doctor’s prescription.

abstract: If Brock Osweiler can find a way to get the ball to Demaryius Thomas, Emmanuel Sanders and Vernon Davis, they know how to get it into the end zone.

abstract: All anyone wants to talk about is Cam Newton’s dancing.

abstract: J.J. Watt will be the best player on the field Sunday, but the Jets will be the better team.
lead_paragraph: Jets (5-4) at Texans (4-5)

headline: At Boucheron, the Bleu de Jodhpur Collection

lead_paragraph: Gaj Singh II, the maharaja of Jodhpur, and Claire Choisne, Boucheron creative director, add the feel of India into the jewelry house’s collection.

headline: 1940: Fascists Driven From Key City in Greece
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Italian troops flee from Koritza in Greece in 1940.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Capture by the Greeks of Koritza, Italian base eight miles inside the Albanian frontier, was announced today [Nov. 22] by the Italian high command. It said two Fascist divisions which since the opening of hostilities with Greece had held defensive positions on the Greco-Albanian frontier near Koritza had retired, after eleven days of fighting, to a line west of the city.

headline: Barbara Taylor Bradford: An Author’s Collection
abstract: Ms. Bradford has a story for almost every piece of her jewelry.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Bradford has a story for almost every piece of her jewelry.

headline: From Barbara Taylor Bradford: A Life Story That Dazzles
abstract: The novelist has a tale for almost every piece in her jewelry collection.
lead_paragraph: The best-selling novelist Barbara Taylor Bradford had 40 pieces from her jewelry collection auctioned in 2013.

headline: ‘I Want to Be a Boy Scout.’ There’s Just One Hitch.
abstract: In a year in which gender roles in American institutions have undergone major changes and challenges, five girls in Santa Rosa say they want to spend more time camping and less selling cookies.
lead_paragraph: SANTA ROSA, Calif. — Five girls wearing makeshift scout uniforms stood before top Boy Scout brass this month and made an announcement: We want in.

headline: With Ben Carson, the Doctor and the Politician Can Vary Sharply
abstract: As a surgeon, Dr. Carson was praised for his dedication and attention to detail, but as a candidate, he has sometimes seemed imprecise or ill informed.
lead_paragraph: When he was not in the operating room at Johns Hopkins Hospital, performing one of his 400 surgeries a year, Dr. Ben Carson could often be seen walking slowly through the hallways, hands behind his back, nodding, smiling and speaking softly to co-workers and students who approached.

headline: The 2015 N.F.L. Playoff Picture: Simulate the End of the Season for Any Team
abstract: How can my team make the N.F.L. playoffs? It’s a simple question, but answering it can be devilishly complicated. This interactive simulator walks you through the scenarios.
lead_paragraph: How can my team make the N.F.L. playoffs? It’s a simple question, but answering it can be devilishly complicated. This interactive simulator walks you through the scenarios.

headline: From Vaccines to Creationism, Ben Carson’s Views Perplex Some
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Creationism and Intelligent Design', 'Malpractice', 'Football']
abstract: Ben Carson answered questions on a variety of topics, including vaccines, creationism and his decision to run for president.
lead_paragraph: As a surgeon for three decades, Ben Carson carefully balanced his responsibilities as a physician with his deeply religious personal philosophy.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Our cooks share a few of their recipes for the Thanksgiving holiday.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears on nytimes.com. To receive the email, register here.

headline: Practicing the Art of Misdirection, With Unsavory Intent
abstract: Combining polished coordination with improvisation, the police said, three suspected thieves from Colombia stole from several people in Manhattan in recent months — until they aimed too high.
lead_paragraph: The three Colombians worked as a team, the police said, with polished coordination and improvisation, like a criminal jazz combo. Until they aimed too high.

headline: 7 Feet, 7 Blocks: Kristaps Porzingis Looms Ever Larger
abstract: After scoring 24 points, grabbing 14 rebounds and blocking seven shots against the Rockets, Porzingis continues to raise his own ceiling.
lead_paragraph: Kristaps Porzingis is a player who inspires many debates. The arguments include what nickname best suits him — Godzingis and Three-Six Latvia are gaining traction after he said he was not a fan of Zinger — and his potential as a player.

headline: For Auto Enthusiasts, the Right to Tinker With Cars’ Software
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Air Pollution', 'Software', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)']
abstract: Federal copyright law now allows drivers to beef up their vehicle’s performance without incurring the legal wrath of carmakers.
lead_paragraph: Car owners in the United States can soon play Volkswagen engineer, courtesy of the federal government.

headline: Storied Brooklyn Church to Lose Its Keeper of History
abstract: Lois Rosebrooks arrived at Plymouth Church, known for its abolitionist stance in the 19th century, in 1957. She is retiring from her position as the director of history ministry services.
lead_paragraph: The woman in the lavender jacket sat carefully on a bench beneath a portrait of a 19th-century preacher with bushy sideburns. They were almost as bushy as those on the more famous preacher she would spend the next 90 minutes talking about — the one for whom “Beecher boats,” “Beecher bibles” and the “Beecherama” were named.

headline: Jason Rezaian of Washington Post Said to Be Sentenced to Prison
abstract: The announcement from the Iranian judiciary, reported by a news agency in Iran, contained no information about the length of his prison term.
lead_paragraph: A spokesman for the Iranian judiciary announced on Sunday that the jailed Washington Post reporter Jason Rezaian had been sentenced to prison, an Iranian news agency reported.

headline: Defiance and Necessity Spur Mali Back to Normal After Attack
abstract: Most in Bamako returned to their normal lives after the terrorist attack on a hotel despite little evidence of increased security.
lead_paragraph: BAMAKO, Mali — On a sunny weekend morning, one day after gunmen went on a murderous rampage at the Radisson Blu hotel, a local dignitary sped across town in his official government S.U.V.

headline: What to Watch Sunday
abstract: A lineup that includes the American Music Awards, a sequel to a Disney favorite and some rock ’n’ roll classics from the women who made the men sound great.
lead_paragraph: It’s Singalong Sunday, with contemporary hits at the American Music Awards, a sequel to a Disney favorite and some rock ’n’ roll classics from the women who made the men sound great. Also, Trevor Noah flaunts his worldview.
