lead_paragraph: How can my team make the N.F.L. playoffs? It’s a simple question, but answering it can be devilishly complicated.

keywords: ['Movies', 'Sex Crimes', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Football (College)']
abstract: A lawyer for Jameis Winston, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers quarterback, said the documentary, “The Hunting Ground,” is libelous.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In the face of threatened legal action from the football star Jameis Winston, CNN did not back away from broadcasting “The Hunting Ground,” a documentary about sexual assault on college campuses that has stirred controversy since its January debut at the Sundance Film Festival.

headline: Addicted to a Fantasy
abstract: Josh Adams owed $30,000 to friends and family when he finally decided to face his gambling addiction. Then he discovered fantasy sports.
lead_paragraph: Josh Adams owed $30,000 to friends and family when he finally decided to face his gambling addiction. Then he discovered fantasy sports.

headline: ‘The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 2’ Opens Big, but Not Big Enough
abstract: The finale to one of the decade’s biggest film franchises opened to about $101 million.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – It was one of those weekends when a movie opened to massive ticket sales and still disappointed: “The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 2,” the finale of one of the decade’s biggest film franchises, took in about $101 million at North American theaters, a 17 percent decline from initial sales for “Part 1.”

headline: Thinking About the Trumpthinkable
abstract: What’s to stop him?
lead_paragraph: Alan Abramowitz reads the latest WaPo poll and emails:

headline: 16 Arrests in Belgium Terrorism Raids
abstract: The authorities in Brussels announced that 16 people had been arrested in an operation, though they said Salah Abdeslam was not among those arrested.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — After a dramatic security sweep late Sunday marked by the deployment of soldiers in the historic center of the Belgian capital, the authorities here announced early Monday that 16 people had been arrested in a joint police and military operation to try to head off what the prime minister earlier described as a “serious and imminent” threat of a Paris-style terrorist assault.

headline: VSPs and the Case of the Disappearing BPEA
abstract: Some mostly self-serving thoughts.
lead_paragraph: Brad Delong has nice things to say about my old Brookings Papers on Economic Activity on the liquidity trap, and asks why central bankers still don’t seem to get some of the basic points I made way back then, especially about the desirability of a higher inflation target. I actually have a few thoughts, which are inevitably mostly — but not entirely! — self-serving.

headline: Pfizer and Allergan Reach $150 Billion Merger Deal
keywords: ['Tax Shelters', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Botox (Drug)', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Relocation of Business']
abstract: The deal, to be announced Monday, would create a huge new pharmaceutical giant and could potentially help Pfizer lower its American tax rate.
lead_paragraph: Pfizer has clinched a blockbuster merger with a fellow drug maker, one worth more than $150 billion, that can best be described in superlatives.

headline: Donald Trump Again Insists He Saw Celebrations in New Jersey on Sept. 11
abstract: Mr. Trump repeated his claim about Sept. 11 despite denials from officials in New Jersey and also said he would support waterboarding to fight terrorism.
lead_paragraph: It’s a scene that, as Donald J. Trump describes it, would seem to be seared into the American consciousness.

headline: Cartoon: Heng on the Asia Pacific Summit
abstract: President Obama has called on China to halt its construction on reclaimed islands in the South China Sea.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has called on China to halt its construction on reclaimed islands in the South China Sea.

headline: Donald Trump Says He Supports Those Who ‘Roughed Up’ Protester at His Event
abstract: Mr. Trump described his supporters’ response as preferable to that of Senator Bernie Sanders, who yielded his microphone to Black Lives Matter protesters earlier this year.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump said on Sunday he was in favor of the actions of his supporters who reportedly punched and kicked a protester from the Black Lives Matter movement who interrupted Mr. Trump’s campaign rally the previous day in Birmingham, Ala.

headline: Israeli Woman and 3 Palestinian Attackers Killed in West Bank
abstract: An Israeli woman was stabbed to death in Etzion block as violence flared with three Palestinians carrying out separate attacks in the occupied West Bank.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Three Palestinians who each attacked Israeli Jews in separate episodes across the occupied West Bank on Sunday, were shot dead by Israeli civilians and soldiers, officials and witnesses said. One Israeli woman was killed in the attacks.

headline: Marco Rubio’s Campaign Unveils First Television Ad
abstract: Mr. Rubio focuses on terrorism and national security in his first presidential advertisement, which was introduced on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Marco Rubio’s campaign is hitting the airwaves, releasing its first television ad on Sunday.

headline: Five Touchdowns for Cam Newton as the Panthers Remain Undefeated
abstract: Newton was unstoppable in the red zone, and Carolina’s defense dominated the Washington Redskins
lead_paragraph: Cam Newton spent the week dealing with the public’s debate of his ostentatious dancing. After he threw a career-high five touchdown passes Sunday, while helping his team reach 10-0, the public should talk about his ability to play football instead.

headline: Pearson’s Big Paydays Defy the Odds Against Print Media
abstract: The sales of The Financial Times and The Economist for about $2 billion cumulatively raise questions about whether the deals will pay off financially for the buyers.
lead_paragraph: It has been tough sledding for print media. More than 150 newspapers have closed or converted to digital-only offerings in the last two years. Recently the magazine giants Condé Nast and Time Inc. have both cut employees and closed magazines.

headline: Lack of Enthusiasm From Supporters May Undermine Clinton’s Lead
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voting and Voters', 'Youth', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Surveys of voters show that young people, independents and possibly even blacks and Hispanics are not excited about Hillary Rodham Clinton’s candidacy.
lead_paragraph: There’s cause for concern in Hillaryland, the constellation of Democratic advisers, supporters and politicians counting on the former secretary of state to lead the party to a sweeping victory next November.

headline: Cowboys Still Alive After Tony Romo’s Return
abstract: Romo throws two touchdown passes for the Cowboys, who are only two games back in the N.F.C. East.
lead_paragraph: Tony Romo was not exactly the cure-all that the Dallas Cowboys were hoping for, but the star quarterback did enough in his much-anticipated return from injury to get his team its first win since Week 2, beating the Miami Dolphins, 24-14.

headline: Q. and A.: Jindong Cai on ‘Beethoven in China’
abstract: During a visit to his native Beijing, Mr. Cai discussed classical music, Beethoven’s popularity and why there are so many new concert halls in China.
lead_paragraph: Jindong Cai, 59, is an orchestra conductor and a professor at Stanford University. He has conducted many orchestras in China and has been a guest conductor at numerous orchestras in the United States since moving there in 1985. With his wife, the writer Sheila Melvin, he has written numerous articles on China and two books on music in China: “Rhapsody in Red: How Western Classical Music Became Chinese” and their latest, “Beethoven in China: How the Great Composer Became an Icon in the People’s Republic.”

headline: Paris Attacks and Other Assaults Seen as Evidence of a Shift by ISIS
abstract: Attacks carried out far from the Islamic State’s base in Iraq and Syria upend the view held by the United States and its allies that the group was a regional threat.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The recent attacks in Paris and Beirut and the downing of a Russian airliner in Egypt were the first results of a centrally planned terrorism campaign by a wing of the Islamic State leadership that oversees “external” targets, according to American and European intelligence officials.

headline: Adele’s ‘25’ on Track to Break Sales Records
abstract: The album seems set to sell at least 2.5 million copies in the United States in its first week.
lead_paragraph: When Adele released her new album, “25,” on Friday, it was sure to be an instant hit. The only question was how big.

headline: Jets Drop Ball, and J. J. Watt Drops Jets
abstract: Led by Watt, who had two sacks, five quarterback hits and five tackles for loss, the Texans sent the error-prone Jets to their fourth loss in five games and damaged their playoff hopes.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The Jets tried holding on to their playoff aspirations Sunday, but they dropped them, like the deep balls botched by their rookie receiver. The Jets tried sustaining those aspirations, but they were depleted by every sack they allowed, every interception they threw, every dose of gadgetry that stunned them into mediocrity.

headline: Sky’s the Limit for Porzingis, and He’s Closer to It Than Most
abstract: The rookie power forward Kristaps Porzingis brings to mind another effective former Knicks big man, Lonnie Shelton, but with a lot more potential.
lead_paragraph: When Mike Breen and Walt Frazier, announcing on television, discussed how Kristaps Porzingis had tied the Knicks’ rookie single-game mark of seven blocked shots, Butch Beard had a flashback to the player who had set it.

headline: Once Again, the Big 12 Looks to Be on the Outside Looking In
abstract: For the second year in a row, neither Texas Christian nor Baylor are well-positioned to make college football’s four-team playoff.
lead_paragraph: In the third quarter of Saturday night’s game between Texas Christian and Oklahoma, with T.C.U. trailing by a manageable 23-13, Horned Frogs quarterback Foster Sawyer heaved a throw downfield right into the arms of Sooners safety Ahmad Thomas. Trevone Boykin, who had thrown 29 touchdown passes and accounted for nearly 3,500 yards in the air in a Heisman Trophy-worthy campaign before injuring his ankle in the previous week’s victory against Kansas, might have done better.

headline: Review: In ‘Beasts,’ BalletX Explores Nature and Nurture
abstract: This Philadelphia dance company celebrated its 10th anniversary with the world premiere of Nicolo Fonte’s show.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — There are many dance styles around America that aren’t to be found in New York, from local brands of hip-hop to individual subsections of ballet — and this is good for the dance health of the whole nation. Recently, when Ballet Memphis came to the Joyce Theater in New York, the sheer non-New-York-ness of its choreography and dancing struck many observers. I like to think that around the country there are many other such companies that New York audiences never see.

headline: Review: Jeremy Denk and Stefan Jackiw’s Lessons in Ives’s Nostalgic Sonatas
abstract: The pianist Jeremy Denk, an Ives champion, and the violinist Stefan Jackiw gave arresting accounts of four astonishing pieces at the 92nd Street Y.
lead_paragraph: A concert offering all four of Charles Ives’s craggy violin sonatas might seem at first more a music history lesson than an engaging program. If not quite rarities, these fiercely original works are pretty close.

headline: Review: JACK Quartet and Anthony McGill Perform a Menu of American Delicacies
abstract: This concert at Roulette in Brooklyn was the first New York event for the American Music Project, which promotes and commissions classical works.
lead_paragraph: “The Wind in High Places” is a string quartet by John Luther Adams that uses only open strings and natural harmonics. Written in 2011 in memory of a friend and hiking companion, it evokes the glassy stillness of the Alaskan wilderness that for decades was Mr. Adams’s home and inspiration.

headline: Review: Max Emanuel Cencic and Il Pomo D’Oro Bring Baroque to the Met
abstract: Mr. Cencic, a countertenor accompanied by this ensemble, sang arias in Italian during a program featuring selections by composers associated with Naples.
lead_paragraph: How a singer conveys the text is usually an integral part of a vocal performance, assuming the listener understands the words and story or can rely on subtitles. Deciphering unfamiliar lyrics when syllables are elongated and ornamented can be a challenge in any language: Subtitles are often provided even for English librettos.

headline: Review: In ‘Beatlebone,’ an Imagined Trip With John Lennon
abstract: Kevin Barry’s new novel follows an emotionally raw Lennon on a 1978 journey through western Ireland to commune with nature and himself.
lead_paragraph: “Beatlebone,” the strange and exhilarating new novel by the Irish writer Kevin Barry, is about John Lennon — kind of. It follows him closely for around 200 pages, through a few comically calamitous days in 1978, as he travels through western Ireland to an island off its coast, bought on a lark 11 years earlier. He’s nearing 40 here; past drugs, past scream therapy, far past the Beatles, and stripped raw emotionally, tired “but not for sleeping,” full of “large sad warmish feelings.”

headline: Nepal Police Kill 3 Protesters in Clashes Over Constitution
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Constitutions', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Violence flared in southern Nepal when the police opened fire on protesters from the Madhesi group who had been blocking the country’s main highway.
lead_paragraph: KATHMANDU, Nepal — Violence flared in southern Nepal when the police open fire on protesters who had been blocking the country’s main highway, an official said on Sunday. The shootings threatened to deepen a political crisis over the country’s new Constitution.

headline: Review: A Beethoven Cycle From Simon Rattle and the Berlin Philharmonic
abstract: Mr. Rattle and his orchestra performed the nine symphonies over five nights at Carnegie Hall. The cycle has become a summit to be climbed over and over and over again.
lead_paragraph: Claudio Abbado. Herbert von Karajan. Wilhelm Furtwängler. You are weighed upon golden scales, if you are the chief conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic. And for good or ill, the balance tilts hardest in what is still thought of as classical music’s core repertoire: Mahler, nowadays; Brahms, naturally; Beethoven, forever.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Nov. 23
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: ‘Dark Knight III: The Master Race’ Comic Book Prompts Reflection and a Look Ahead
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Comic Books and Strips', 'Batman (Fictional Character)']
abstract: Frank Miller, the creator of the “Dark Knight” Batman comics series, spoke about the character and the series ahead of the Wednesday release of the latest “Dark Knight” issue.
lead_paragraph: The opening panels of “Dark Knight III: The Master Race” depict a break-in at the Batcave. A display case containing the imposing costume of Batman, the DC vigilante, is smashed open and his emblematic cape and cowl are stolen, leaving only a bare mannequin.

headline: Persistence Pays Off
abstract: The return of Parker Lewis.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — When last we saw Parker Lewis, he had constructed two New York Times puzzles in 2011. Before, Mr. Lewis had spent a couple of years in Namibia as a member of the Peace Corps, teaching MATH to middle school “learners,” as they are called in Africa.

headline: Review: Thomas Adès Calls for Complexity at City Center
abstract: An ambitious program of four Adès scores, each accompanied with a dance by a different choreographer.
lead_paragraph: When did dance audiences last see and hear a composer perform his own works with the revelatory mastery shown by Thomas Adès? Because the quadruple bill of his works “Thomas Adès: Concentric Paths — Movements in Music” came over the weekend to New York City Center, the mind flew to Stravinsky.

headline: Review: In ‘Beyond Time,’ U-Theater Dances and Drums With Precision
abstract: This Taiwanese production featured 15 performers creating music as they executed synchronized movements at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: A solar eclipse and a torrential downpour descended on the stage of the Howard Gilman Opera House at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Friday night. Those were among the natural phenomena digitally conjured in “Beyond Time,” a production by the Taiwanese dance and drumming company U-Theater that was having its American debut.

headline: Review: Paco Peña’s Troupe Flaunts Its Inventive Flamenco Style at Town Hall
abstract: With a blend of drama, precision and playfulness, the company seemed to hold the audience spellbound.
lead_paragraph: The Paco Peña dance troupe, based in London, passes through New York about once every two years, usually for a one-night-only concert. For anyone with a taste for flamenco at its most exciting, that isn’t nearly enough.

headline: Heroin, Survivor of War on Drugs, Returns With New Face
abstract: Heroin is back. But today’s crisis is markedly different from the devastation of past years. It has settled not so much in large cities, but in suburbs and rural areas, and users are mostly white.
lead_paragraph: United States military operations in Afghanistan, now in their 15th year, are routinely described as America’s longest war. For overseas combat, that is true. But nothing tops the domestic “war on drugs” that an American president declared more than four decades ago. The casualty rate has been exceedingly high.

headline: Thanksgiving, With College Students: Fantasy, Reality, and Getting It Right
abstract: For college students, coming home is a choice. Here’s how to make it one you’re all glad they make.
lead_paragraph: Here is the fantasy: After months of missing our college kids we eagerly await their return for Thanksgiving. In our dreams we spend cozy hours in the kitchen listening to them recount their experiences and marveling at the newly mature teen who sits before us. Our kids have looked forward to these days of rest and reunion and are thrilled to come home to the embrace of their families. Food will be abundant and family time sacred.

headline: Panels Advise Bolstering W.H.O. for Crises Like Ebola
abstract: Both groups said that the United Nations health agency’s outbreak and emergency response capacities should be strengthened, and protected from political meddling.
lead_paragraph: In recent months, numerous groups of health experts have gathered to debate how to prevent another crisis like the Ebola epidemic in West Africa, which jumped borders, spread fear across the globe, and directly killed more than 11,000 people. Many more died as hospitals and clinics closed for months.

headline: Petco Nears $4.7 Billion Sale to CVC and Canadian Pension Plan
abstract: The deal is likely to be announced on Monday, according to a person who spoke on the condition of anonymity because the discussions were still private.
lead_paragraph: Petco is near an agreement to be acquired by CVC Capital Partners and the Canadian Pension Plan Investment Board for $4.7 billion, a person briefed on the matter said on Sunday.

headline: Bahrain Abuses Continue Despite King’s Pledge, Rights Group Says
keywords: ['Torture', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Detainees', 'Sex Crimes', 'International Relations']
abstract: Human Rights Watch released a report saying it had interviewed 10 detainees who described torture and other practices that King Hamad bin Isa al-Khalifa promised to end four years ago.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Bahrain’s security forces torture detainees using electric shocks, beatings and sexual abuse, despite a public pledge by the king of Bahrain four years ago to end such practices, according to a report released on Monday by the New York-based Human Rights Watch.

headline: Saeed Jaffrey, Actor in ‘Gandhi’ and ‘The Man Who Would Be King,’ Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Jaffrey, best known in his native India for roles he characterized as “the naughty uncle,” had a career in radio, film, TV and onstage encompassing three continents.
lead_paragraph: Saeed Jaffrey, an Indian-born character actor known internationally for his work in films like “Gandhi,” “The Man Who Would Be King” and “My Beautiful Laundrette,” died on Nov. 14 in London. He was 86.

headline: On Foreign Trip, Obama Yet Again Contends With Events Elsewhere
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Terrorism', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership']
abstract: The president has been dealing with the attacks in Paris and Mali while visiting Asia, another in a series of travels in which events have disrupted his planned message.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — President Obama traveled more than 12,000 miles last week to shower attention on Asia. But he spent most of the trip in grim consultations about the attacks in Paris and Mali and in a long-distance war of words with Republicans.

abstract: Do the bells of St. Patrick’s Cathedral and St. Thomas take turns ringing?

headline: Towering, Teeming Hong Kong — Where the Buffalo Roam
keywords: ['Cattle', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Land Use Policies', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Water Buffaloes', 'Wilderness Areas']
abstract: Most of Hong Kong is not an urban jungle, but rather a real one, bristling with monkeys, pythons and boars — and a lot of feral cattle.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A water buffalo grazes in a lush open field, an egret standing sentinel on its back. A herd of wild cattle bathes in the sunshine along the side of a winding road.

headline: American Music Awards 2015 Red Carpet
abstract: Zendaya, Selena Gomez, Gigi Hadid and more at the American Music Awards on Sunday night in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Zendaya, Selena Gomez, Gigi Hadid and more at the American Music Awards on Sunday night in Los Angeles. See photos from the red carpet.

headline: Gov. Cuomo to Order Large Increase in Renewable Energy in New York by 2030
abstract: State officials hope a mandate on clean sources for half of all power in New York will delay the planned shutdown of two nuclear power plants on the shore of Lake Ontario.
lead_paragraph: Frustrated by the pending shutdown of two nuclear power plants on Lake Ontario, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo plans to order state regulators to mandate that, by 2030, half of all power consumed by New Yorkers be generated from renewable sources that emit much less carbon dioxide, people briefed on the matter said.

headline: Artist’s Death Sentence Follows a String of Harsh Punishments in Saudi Arabia
keywords: ['Shariah (Islamic Law)', 'Capital Punishment', 'Art', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Palestinians']
abstract: The case of Ashraf Fayadh, who was sentenced to death on charges of apostasy, is one of several that have fueled comparisons between Saudi Arabia and the jihadists of the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: SANLIURFA, Turkey — For years, Ashraf Fayadh, an artist and poet, has served as an unofficial ambassador for Saudi Arabia’s small contemporary art scene, organizing shows and working to introduce Saudi art to the world.

abstract: A reader objects to an Op-Ed writer’s portrayal of conservative Christians.

headline: Louisiana’s John Bel Edwards Overcame Big Obstacles to Win Governor’s Race
abstract: In a race that many other Democrats once considered hopeless, Mr. Edwards defeated his opponent, United States Senator David Vitter, by a wide margin on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — One evening in 2013, two weary Democratic legislators sat at their desks in the State Capitol, stared across the emptying House chamber and considered another unsuccessful day of fighting the governor. “Sam,” said one of the men, Representative John Bel Edwards, “I’m not staying in the House. I’m not doing this anymore.”

abstract: Beating Tom Brady in Foxborough may be beyond the capabilities of the up-and-coming Bills.
lead_paragraph: 8:30 p.m., ESPN

headline: Kyle Busch Wins First Sprint Cup Championship
abstract: Kyle Busch opened the season in a hospital bed and ended it in victory lane with the championship trophy.
lead_paragraph: HOMESTEAD, Fla. — Jeff Gordon did not have the storybook finish that he had hoped for to end his 24-year career, but he still had a day to remember.

headline: In Rebuke to Kirchner, Argentines Elect Opposition Leader Mauricio Macri as President
abstract: The victory by Mauricio Macri, 56, the mayor of Buenos Aires, revealed deep fissures in Argentina and was seen as an affront to the departing president, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Argentine voters handed a victory to Mauricio Macri in the country’s presidential election on Sunday, delivering a mandate to an opposition political figure seeking to roll back some of the protectionist economic measures of the departing president, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner.

headline: At End of Sheldon Silver’s Corruption Trial, the ‘Law Guys’ Take Over
abstract: The legal specialists bring a freedom to think deeply about issues because they do not have the day-to-day burden of conducting the case.
lead_paragraph: As the public corruption trial of State Assemblyman Sheldon Silver heads to closing arguments on Monday, the clash in the courtroom has been handled largely by well-staffed government and defense legal teams, each with a wealth of experience in handling corruption cases.

headline: Black Friday, a Test for Pixar and HP Earnings
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'United States Economy', 'Company Reports']
abstract: This week all eyes are on Black Friday sales, which are widely considered a barometer for the health of the wider economy. In addition, Pixar will release a new film and Hewlett-Packard will release earnings.
lead_paragraph: With a host of contentious issues to discuss, American and Chinese trade officials are scheduled to conclude three days of top-level talks on Monday. The talks, known as the United States-China Joint Commission on Commerce and Trade, are being held in the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou and are being led by Commerce Secretary Penny Pritzker and Wang Yang, the vice premier of China in charge of trade. Against the backdrop of the recently unveiled Trans-Pacific Partnership, which has been championed by the Obama administration but excludes China, the annual bilateral talks are expected to address issues like market access, particularly for agricultural companies. —Neil Gough

headline: For Addicts, Fantasy Sites Can Lead to Ruinous Path
abstract: Compulsive gamblers say they have lost thousands after being drawn in by aggressive pitches and promises of quick payouts.
lead_paragraph: AUBURN, Ala. — A giant cardboard picture, tattered by time, rests against a wall in Joshua Adams’s home. It shows a radiant young woman with an Auburn University corsage hugging the university’s mascot, a tiger. She is Auburn’s homecoming queen — and Mr. Adams’s mother.

headline: The Ad Council Adapts to Stay Relevant in an Age of Social Action
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Bullies', 'Emojis and Emoticons', 'Online Advertising', 'Nonprofit Organizations', 'Slogans and Mottoes', 'Social Media']
abstract: The longtime creator of public service announcements hopes its new eye emoji, which is part of the “I Am a Witness” campaign, will resonate with the public in a way that’s reminiscent of Smokey Bear.
lead_paragraph: Could an eye emoji become as beloved — and recognizable — as Smokey Bear?

headline: Bob Foster, Whose Left Hook Decimated All but the Heavyweights, Dies at 76
abstract: Foster became a light-heavyweight champion in 1968 and went on to fight the legendary heavyweights Joe Frazier and Muhammad Ali, but he was knocked out by both.
lead_paragraph: Bob Foster, a devastating puncher who was one of boxing’s most dominant light-heavyweight champions but failed in his quest to capture a heavyweight title when he was knocked out by Joe Frazier and Muhammad Ali, died on Saturday in Albuquerque. He was 76.

headline: Start-Up Leaders Embrace Lobbying as Part of the Job
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Start-ups']
abstract: Today’s tech companies have accepted lobbying as an essential part of doing business.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Last year, the personal butler service Hello Alfred won a top prize in Silicon Valley created for promising new technology start-ups, putting the company on a path toward millions of dollars in investment.

headline: Checkpoints Isolate Many Immigrants in Texas’ Rio Grande Valley
abstract: The Border Patrol has traffic checkpoints up to 100 miles north of Mexico, confining undocumented immigrants to a small world and, in the extreme, blocking children from specialized medical care.
lead_paragraph: BROWNSVILLE, Tex. — Elizabeth Lopez swam across the Rio Grande 19 years ago to come to America, where she began cleaning houses and raising three daughters in this city of swaying palm trees at the southern tip of Texas.

headline: Creditors Signal Potential Support for Overhauling Puerto Rico Debt
abstract: Puerto Rico proposed to exchange existing bonds for new debt that would be less burdensome, and influential creditors for the first time were receptive.
lead_paragraph: Some of Puerto Rico’s most influential creditors are for the first time signaling support for the broad outline of a government proposal to overhaul the island’s crushing debts.

headline: To Cam Newton, the Only Numbers That Matter Are 10 and 0
abstract: Newton is not among the N.F.L. leaders in most passing categories, but he is the heart and soul of the 10-0 Panthers, one of only two undefeated teams this season.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Cam Newton is the perfect answer to those who say that numbers don’t lie.

headline: At Princeton, Woodrow Wilson, a Heralded Alum, Is Recast as an Intolerant One
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Names, Organizational', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Efforts to remove Mr. Wilson’s name from a residential complex and the public policy school at Princeton University have raised difficult questions about a prominent graduate’s racist legacy.
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, N.J. — Few figures loom as large in the life of an Ivy League university as Woodrow Wilson does at Princeton.

headline: Virginia Commonwealth Coach Leads by Example, One Mile at a Time
abstract: Will Wade instills discipline in his players through his own example of willpower. By running daily, without excuse, he sets the tone.
lead_paragraph: Will Wade has started every day since January the same way: with a run of a mile, often more.

headline: Duke Gets 32 Points From a Guard, and a Narrow Victory Over Georgetown
abstract: Grayson Allen lifted No. 5 Duke over Georgetown, 86-84, in the championship of the 2K Classic at Madison Square Garden on Sunday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: A brilliant second-half performance by Grayson Allen lifted No. 5 Duke over Georgetown, 86-84, in the championship of the 2K Classic at Madison Square Garden on Sunday afternoon.

headline: Review: Naomi Wallace’s ‘Night Is a Room’ Unfurls a Complex Reunion
abstract: As a birthday present for her husband, a woman sets up a surprise meeting for him with his biological mother in this play, at Signature Theater.
lead_paragraph: There are gifts the giver comes to regret — the costly bauble that isn’t worth the expense, or the squawking toy that brings on a splitting headache. Then there’s the present that the well-meaning Liana has planned for the 40th birthday of her husband, Marcus: a surprise meeting with his biological mother.

headline: ‘The Walking Dead’ Season 6, Episode 7: Glenn’s Fate Is Revealed
abstract: A mystery is resolved and things get intense in Alexandria in advance of next week’s first-half finale.
lead_paragraph: Reminder: This recap (obviously) contains spoilers for this week’s episode of “The Walking Dead.”

headline: ‘Homeland’ Recap: Season 5, Episode 8, ‘All About Allison’
abstract: Allison and Carrie exchange memories in this week’s episode.
lead_paragraph: Season 5, Episode 8 Recap: “All About Allison”

headline: ‘The Leftovers’ Season 2, Episode 8: Stop Thinking in Straight Lines
abstract: This was a genuinely brain-shredding episode.
lead_paragraph: Some of the best television series of the past 25 years have given us at least one mind-scrambler episode: a slice of brazenly surreal storytelling that dazzles, confuses, amuses or — ideally, when all the pots on the weirdo stove are really cooking — accomplishes all three at the same time.

headline: Game of the Week: Heat at Knicks
abstract: The Knicks and Miami play twice this week, but the game to watch will be Friday’s at Madison Square Garden, where Kristaps Porzingis is stirring crowds the way Jeremy Lin once did.
lead_paragraph: Jeremy Lin signed with the Knicks on Dec. 27, 2011. The team played the Miami Heat that night, but Lin was not on the floor, and there was not much heard from him for a couple of months. Then, in February, Lin started putting together big games. Twenty-five points, 7 assists and 5 rebounds against the Nets. Thirty-eight points against the Lakers at Madison Square Garden. A winning 3-pointer to down the Raptors on the road. Jeremy Lin had officially arrived, and the tabloids spouted neologisms in approval.

headline: Review: ‘The Second Mrs. Wilson’: A Faltering President and His Steadfast Wife
abstract: A new drama at the George Street Theater reveals how Edith Wilson, whom President Woodrow Wilson married in 1915, gained a singular place in American history.
lead_paragraph: Edith Bolling Galt, a comely widow, met President Woodrow Wilson in spring 1915, when he was mourning the recent loss of his beloved wife, Ellen. A romance blossomed, and they wed that December.

headline: New Orleans Park Shootout Injures 16
abstract: At least 10 of the victims were hospitalized, but the extent and nature of the injuries were still being determined.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — At least 16 people were injured, 10 of them hospitalized, after a shootout on Sunday night in a park here where hundreds of people had gathered for the filming of a music video, the New Orleans Police Department said.

headline: Sickened in Rubble After 9/11, a ‘Lost Soul’ Longs for Her Old Life
abstract: As an ironworker in New York City, Susan Bentley’s expertise placed her on the front lines with rescue workers after the Sept. 11 terrorist attack. But she suffered debilitating illnesses from working at ground zero.
lead_paragraph: Construction sites, ubiquitous in New York City, set off pangs of loss within Susan Bentley.

headline: Mandolin Brothers on Staten Island Angles for Graceful Exit
abstract: After the death last year of Stan M. Jay, the owner of the stringed instruments specialty store, his family seeks a way to bow out of the business.
lead_paragraph: Eric Jay carried a newly delivered guitar case into a display room inside Mandolin Brothers, a musical instrument store on Staten Island. As his mother, Bea Jay, and his sister, Alison Reilly, watched, he unclasped the case and lifted the lid. There, resting on plush, purple lining, was a white Gretsch G7593T Billy Duffy Falcon guitar, named after the guitarist for the Cult.

headline: ‘The Affair’ Season 2, Episode 8: This Guy’s Hopeless
abstract: Even in his moment of triumph, Noah Solloway will find a way to turn us against him.
lead_paragraph: Noah, Noah, Noah.

headline: What to Expect in Week 4 of Sheldon Silver’s Trial
abstract: The week will begin with closing arguments, and the jury could receive the case and start deliberations before the court closes for Thanksgiving.
lead_paragraph: Issues that could arise in the fourth week of the trial of Sheldon Silver, 71, the former speaker of the New York State Assembly.

headline: Endangered White Rhino Nola Dies at San Diego Zoo Safari Park
abstract: Nola was euthanized after her health deteriorated because of an infection, leaving just three known northern white rhinos, which live under armed guard in Kenya.
lead_paragraph: Nola, one of only four known northern white rhinoceroses, died on Sunday at the San Diego Zoo Safari Park, the park said in a statement. The park said that Nola, 41, had a bacterial infection, as well as age-related health issues, and that officials made the decision to euthanize her after her condition worsened overnight on Saturday.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, November 23, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “It would be akin to an alcoholic finding out about a whole new street of bars that he never knew about — exciting, great bars. For an addict, it wasn’t what I needed.”

headline: The Best of Week 11 in the N.F.L.
abstract: The top performers and key injuries in the league this week.
lead_paragraph: Jameis Winston threw five touchdown passes in the Buccaneers’ rout of the Eagles, tying the N.F.L. rookie record for the most in a game. Winston, who completed 19 of 29 passes for 246 yards over all, had four touchdown throws in the first half, to four receivers. He tied Matthew Stafford’s rookie mark from 2009 in the third quarter on an 8-yard pass to Cameron Brate, the fifth Tampa Bay receiver with a scoring catch on Sunday. Entering the day, Winston had not thrown for more than two touchdowns in a game.

headline: After Deliberate Search, Dodgers Are Said to Be Hiring Dave Roberts as Their Manager
abstract: Dave Roberts, whose parents are African-American and Japanese, is the Dodgers’ first minority manager and the third in baseball
lead_paragraph: The Dodgers are expected to announce Monday that they have filled the last opening for a manager in the major leagues with the hiring of Dave Roberts, according to multiple media reports. Roberts, 43, whose parents are African-American and Japanese would be the Dodgers’ first minority manager and the third in baseball, along with Fredi Gonzalez of the Atlanta Braves and Dusty Baker, recently hired by the Washington Nationals.

headline: Police Name Suspect in Shooting of New Orleans Medical Student
abstract: The authorities said they were searching for Euric Cain, 21, after surveillance video captured him shooting Peter Gold, 25, in the stomach.
lead_paragraph: The New Orleans police identified a suspect on Sunday in the shooting of a Tulane University medical student who had tried to help a woman being dragged down a sidewalk toward a vehicle in the pre-dawn hours on Friday.

headline: What to Watch on Monday
abstract: Eddie Murphy dusts off his Bill Cosby impression, corporations dilute science with spin, and a British whodunit is likened to a supernatural “Broadchurch.”
lead_paragraph: Monday’s grab bag features the funny and the not so, with Eddie Murphy skewering Bill Cosby and corporate public relations firms diluting science with spin. And another intriguing British whodunit is available to stream.

headline: A Year After Democracy Protests, Hong Kong Vote Reflects Split on China
abstract: Participants in last year’s democracy movement won seats in some areas, and supporters of closer ties with the Beijing government gained ground in others.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Voters here went to the polls on Sunday, choosing hundreds of neighborhood representatives in the first election since concern about China’s influence over the electoral process set off immense sit-in protests last year.

headline: Syrian Refugees Biking to Safety
keywords: ['Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Photography']
abstract: Syrian refugees seeking safe haven in Europe have taken to the Arctic Circle, where they cycle the final stretch across the border from Russia into Norway.
lead_paragraph: Amid all the dramatic stories of terrified Syrian refugees seeking safe haven in Europe, one odd detail struck Alessandro Iovino: People were riding bicycles along a new path to freedom through the Arctic Circle. Their choice of transport was an ingenious response to a vexing 390-foot final stretch along the border between Russia and Norway. The Russians banned foot traffic, while the Norwegians prohibited vehicles carrying people without visas.

headline: The Politics of Paid Time Off to Have a Baby
keywords: ['Family Leaves', 'Paid Time Off', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Work-Life Balance', 'Women and Girls', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: It’s no small victory to hear Democrats and one Republican presidential contender talk about support for working parents.
lead_paragraph: In 1980, when Hillary Rodham Clinton was about to become a mother, she was working as a partner at Rose Law Firm in Arkansas. At the time, paid maternity leave, or leave at all, was a rare benefit. Her firm, she has said, had no maternity leave plan until she told her partners she would be taking four months off, thus establishing its first policy. Just five of the top 30 employers for women, as selected by Working Mother magazine when it first started the list in the 1980s, offered paid maternity leave, and those that did gave between one week and eight, often only at partial pay.

headline: Health Reform Lives!
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: There has been some negative news lately about Obamacare, but it is still a big success story.
lead_paragraph: To the right’s dismay, scare tactics — remember death panels? — and spurious legal challenges failed to protect the nation from the scourge of guaranteed health coverage. Still, Obamacare’s opponents insisted that it would implode in a “death spiral” of low enrollment and rising costs.

headline: Giving Billions to the Rich
abstract: Congress is once again considering a package that will provide special, unneeded tax breaks for corporations.
lead_paragraph: IT’S that time of year again, when Republicans and Democrats put aside their differences to dole out gifts of corporate welfare to a lucky few.

headline: Anti-Muslim Is Anti-American
keywords: ['Muslim Americans', 'Discrimination', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Religion and Belief', 'Law and Legislation', 'Shariah (Islamic Law)']
abstract: Demonizing a single religion is a slippery slope, with the danger of hateful acts getting progressively worse.
lead_paragraph: There seems to be no bottom to the cesspool of Islamophobic rhetoric coming from Republican candidates.

headline: Cut Sentences for Low-Level Drug Crimes
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Mandatory Sentencing', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Law and Legislation', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: Making a real dent in the federal prison population will require broader reforms than what Congress is currently considering.
lead_paragraph: Now that Congress is within sight of passing the most significant federal sentencing reforms in a generation, it’s worth taking a closer look at where the legislation falls short.

headline: Moral Dispute or Cultural Difference?
abstract: We can come to accept another person’s moral beliefs as true, even if we don’t adopt them ourselves.
lead_paragraph: The word “relativism” tends to generate strong reactions. This is odd, given that the word is not generally used with a clear and agreed upon meaning. I want to offer a specific proposal about what it means, with a view to navigating the following “real-world” problem, discussed by Alex Rosenberg here at The Stone in July: What should we do when we face what are often described as irresolvable moral disagreements?

headline: The 911 System Isn’t Ready for the iPhone Era
abstract: First responders are still relying on an emergency system based on dangerously outmoded technology.
lead_paragraph: IN 1999, Congress established 911 as the nationwide emergency number, and called for a system that would use the best technology available to deliver emergency assistance. Now, 16 years later, our emergency response system faces an emergency of its own in the form of outdated technology. To fix this, our emergency responders — police, fire and ambulance — urgently need the help of government leaders at all levels.

headline: ‘Empire of Self: A Life of Gore Vidal,’ by Jay Parini
abstract: A new biography of Gore Vidal, novelist, playwright, screenwriter, social and political player.
lead_paragraph: Easily the best, most entertaining book about Gore Vidal is his 1995 memoir “Palimpsest.” But with the possible exception of “In Bed With Gore Vidal,” Tim Teeman’s 2013 tell-all, “Palimpsest” is also the least reliable of the Vidal books. Vidal was a tireless self-mythologizer, and as his title suggests, that book is a layering of rememberings, re-rememberings and mis-rememberings. In his new, much sounder biography, “Empire of Self,” Jay Parini suggests that even the account of Vidal’s idyllic romance with his high school friend Jimmie Trimble, one of the touchstones of “Palimpsest” — the story of a love so perfect and unearthly that it could never be duplicated — was most likely a fabrication.

headline: ‘The Complete Works of Primo Levi’
abstract: Three volumes bring into focus the breadth and coherence of Levi’s genius.
lead_paragraph: Primo Levi studied chemistry at Turin and worked as a chemist until, at 24, he joined the Italian “partisans” resisting the Nazi occupation of northern Italy in 1943. He was arrested by Italian Fascists and turned over to the Germans, who sent him to Auschwitz — he called it the Lager, the German word for a concentration camp — where he survived partly by luck, partly because he was put to work in a synthetic-rubber factory that used prisoners as slave labor. Returning to Italy, he wrote his memoir of Auschwitz, “If This Is a Man” (1947), and worked 30 years for a paint factory while writing stories, poems, memoirs, essays, a novel and “The Periodic Table” (1975), his idiosyncratic autobiography in which each chapter was named for a chemical element and some chapters were short stories.

headline: With Google’s Offline Maps, Getting Around Gets Cheaper
abstract: Google is rolling out a set of tools designed to help millions of travelers figure out where to go, when to go and how to get there.
lead_paragraph: Using your smartphone to look up a museum address or get turn-by-turn directions on a street in a foreign city can end up costing a small fortune in data charges. Those who download Google Maps’s new Offline Maps won’t have to pay a dime.

headline: 1940: Yugoslavs Fear Isolation
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Yugoslavs fear isolation by the Axis in 1940.
lead_paragraph: BELGRADE — As the procession of statesmen from central and southeastern Europe flies by in the direction of Adolf Hitler’s reception room, many Yugoslavs are watching nervously, and with a growing conviction that their country is being isolated. Every time one of these statesmen signs on the dotted line, the iron ring forged around the countries on the Yugoslav border is tightened. This fact is brought out by a glance at a map of Yugoslavia. Reading from left to right, this country’s neighbors are Benito Mussolini’s Italy, Hitler’s Germany, a Hungary which has just joined the totalitarian three-power pact, Iron Guard Rumania, where German soldiers stand ready, a Bulgaria which is making territorial demands on Yugoslavia, and finally Greece and Albania. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 24, 1940

headline: 1965: Russia Shifts Position on A-war
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Russia begins to regard the use of nuclear weapons as not inevitable in future wars in 1965.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The weight of Soviet military thinking is apparently shifting toward the position that nuclear weapons would not inevitably be used in a future war, qualified sources reported today [Nov. 23]. This departure from the opposite view identified with Nikita S. Khrushchev, that the immediate or early use of nuclear arms had to be expected, was cited as the most meaningful change in Soviet strategy in the year since the former premier fell. It is a welcome change to the United States, which made a similar shift itself about five years ago. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 24, 1965

headline: In Praise of the Good Enough Holiday
abstract: When it comes to holiday entertaining, rough-around-the-edges is not only acceptable, but preferable.
lead_paragraph: The winter celebrations are upon us, bringing with their glee the return of insecurities like: Is your centerpiece of the right niveau? Should you drape the banisters with balsam fir, or is boxwood more current? Which breed of artificial bird is trending to clamp among the boughs? And will you be able to hold your head up if you have not personally raised from poulthood the turkey that graces the holiday table (as Martha Stewart suggests) or hand-pressed the apple cider with which you braised the brisket?

headline: After a Horrid Start, the Chiefs Are Making a Playoff Run
abstract: Of the 158 teams from 1970 to 2014 that started an N.F.L. season with a 1-5 record, only one made the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: The 1970 Cincinnati Bengals have been widely credited with bringing the West Coast offense to the N.F.L. The team’s coach, Paul Brown, and offensive coordinator (and future San Francisco 49ers coach), Bill Walsh, were faced with a challenge, as quarterback Virgil Carter was a smart player with a weak arm. Under Walsh’s tutelage, the Bengals operated a short-passing game that was effective in those run-heavy days. A year later, Carter led the N.F.L. in completion percentage.

headline: Agriculture Linked to DNA Changes in Ancient Europe
abstract: Geneticists at Harvard have found that the rise of agriculture some 8,500 years ago led to widespread changes, affecting height and skin color.
lead_paragraph: The agricultural revolution was one of the most profound events in human history, leading to the rise of modern civilization. Now, in the first study of its kind, an international team of scientists has found that after agriculture arrived in Europe 8,500 years ago, people’s DNA underwent widespread changes, altering their height, digestion, immune system and skin color.

headline: A Corner of Tuscany Where Olive Oil Is a Deeper Green

The arrival of late autumn here signals the season of the olive harvest, as it has since the 1300s, when the city’s noble families first built vacation homes with farms and groves on the fertile slopes of the province, supplying their households with olive oil, wine and firewood throughout the year.

headline: ‘Jessica Jones’ Episode 3: You’re a Good Person
abstract: A more action-intensive episode than the first two.
lead_paragraph: This episode of “Jessica Jones,” which picks up seconds after the previous one, feels like a corrective for every little imperfection in the first two. Jones finally seems to be taking active strides to regain control of her life. For example: Jones doesn’t treat Hope Schlottman, the latest victim of Jones’s arch-nemesis Kilgrave, like a client that she also happens to care personally about. Instead, Jones does her best to protect Hope because she primarily wants to stop Kilgrave, and summarily feels obligated to protect people from him.

Mendel, Peter Pilotto and Adolfo Dominguez) mentions the hectic calendar, the multiplying number of collaborations, the never-ending game of musical chairs — and, sometimes, a lack of rationale. “Fashion is an industry, so it needs to be sustainable,” he says. “The shows should have a reason, the campaigns… everything should have a reason.”

headline: Syrian Refugees Rejected, Rerouted and Resettled
abstract: The reporter Liz Robbins describes her afternoon visit with a Syrian family newly arrived in New Haven.
lead_paragraph: They moved from street to street in Syria, dodging bullets and bombs. Finally, they fled to Jordan, where they lived an anxious existence as unwelcome refugees. And then, after three years of interviews and security checks, a Syrian family — a 33-year-old man, his 23-year-old wife and their almost 5-year-old son — were granted refugee status in the United States.

headline: Review: Rachmaninoff Chemistry at the 92nd Street Y
abstract: Daniil Trifonov plays well with others at Kaufmann Concert Hall in the New York Philharmonic’s festival devoted to the composer.
lead_paragraph: There was something a bit perverse about the chamber-music program presented by the New York Philharmonic at the 92nd Street Y on Sunday, part of its three-week Rachmaninoff festival. Sure, the promise of the breathtaking pianist Daniil Trifonov joining forces with the violinist Sheryl Staples and the cellist Carter Brey in the seething “Trio Élégiaque” (Op. 9) was all it took to fill the Kaufmann Concert Hall. But to round out the program with two unfinished string quartets — works that Rachmaninoff abandoned, surely with good reason — when there is a luscious, masterly cello sonata begging to be played?

headline: Breast-Feeding Is Good for Mothers, Not Just Babies, Studies Suggest
abstract: Breast milk may provide the ideal nourishment for an infant, but two recent studies are putting a different spin on the bottle-versus-breast debate.
lead_paragraph: Breast milk may provide the ideal nourishment for an infant, but two recent studies are putting a different spin on the bottle-versus-breast debate, suggesting it is mothers, and not just babies, who may have much to gain from breast-feeding.

headline: Review: Ian Fleming’s James Bond Letters in ‘The Man With the Golden Typewriter’
abstract: This collection includes specifics and asides about Mr. Fleming and his famous spy character.
lead_paragraph: Ian Fleming adored women, fast cars, golf, martinis and cards, and he cheerfully assigned these same hobbies to his most famous fictional creation, Agent 007. But “The Man With the Golden Typewriter: Ian Fleming’s James Bond Letters” is much less about Fleming’s glamorous cavorting than it is about his brazen hustle to become a famous commercial novelist. This will come as a disappointment, perhaps, to anyone who dives into this collection and expects an orgy of vice. But to anyone who has ever worked on a book — writing one, editing one, marketing one, publishing one — or, heck, even just read one, this volume is a giant stalk of catnip.

lead_paragraph: The protagonist in “Shadowland,” the latest evening-length work from the athlete-illusionists of Pilobolus, is really down on her luck. A teenage girl lost in a dark dream, she’s at the mercy of a mysterious giant who, with the rustle of one imposing hand, turns her into a dog from the waist up. Both before and after this transformation, she is chased, threatened, prodded, eaten, humiliated, even tied up and whipped. Who’s the target demographic here?

headline: Fantasy Sites vs. Congress: A Matchup That Could Be Bruising
keywords: ['Fantasy Sports', 'Gambling', 'Athletics and Sports', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Lawmakers are well aware that most constituents are more interested in what’s on ESPN than what’s going on at the U.S.D.A.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Early in 2008, I had a casual hallway conversation in the Capitol with Senator Arlen Specter, about his pick to win the Super Bowl, that ended up touching off a furor right before the kickoff between the New England Patriots and the New York Giants.

headline: Benjamin Netanyahu Plans Separate Bypass Roads for Israelis in Parts of West Bank
abstract: The prime minister said Israeli drivers would be able to bypass certain intersections in the occupied West Bank, where an Israeli soldier was killed in the latest spate of attacks by Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Under pressure from Israeli settlers in the occupied West Bank, who are demanding better security after weeks of attacks by Palestinians, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said on Monday that his government would establish bypass roads for Israeli drivers in certain areas and revoke the work permits of attackers’ extended families.

headline: Luxembourg Goes in for an Image Makeover
abstract: Such national rebranding efforts rarely work, but the small European nation is spending heavily to divert attention from allegations of financial chicanery.
lead_paragraph: Luxembourg, the country once known as the European “Death Star” of financial secrecy, is looking to improve its image.

headline: Austin Kiplinger, Co-Founder of a Personal Finance Magazine, Dies at 97
abstract: Mr. Kiplinger co-founded what is now Kiplinger’s Personal Finance magazine and expanded its parent company into a $100-million-a-year enterprise.
lead_paragraph: Austin H. Kiplinger, who with his father started what is now Kiplinger’s Personal Finance magazine and expanded the family’s financial publishing company into a $100-million-a-year enterprise by the late 1990s, died on Friday in Rockville, Md. He was 97.

headline: Iran Sentences an American Journalist
abstract: Jason Rezaian, a Washington Post correspondent in Iran, has been unfairly sentenced to an undisclosed term in prison.
lead_paragraph: Authorities in Iran announced on Sunday that the American journalist Jason Rezaian, a Washington Post reporter held by the government for 16 months and charged with espionage, had been sentenced to prison.  The Iranian government made the announcement with as much transparency as it has shown in this case all along: none.

headline: Deliveroo, an On-Demand Food Delivery Service, Raises $100 Million
abstract: The London start-up, which offers logistics to restaurants looking to increase their online food orders, plans to use the new investment primarily to expand into Asia and the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: From San Francisco to Paris, there are hints that the world’s booming tech industry maybe be slowing down.

lead_paragraph: Update: Yes, I know there’s a cat in the picture; I took it from Slate, “The Cats of War.” I’ve used that image before, to lighten things up slightly. Apparently I didn’t succeed.

headline: With a Home or Without, Children’s Schooling Is Front and Center

headline: China and U.S. Say They’ve Made Strides in Trade Talks
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Negotiations yielded modest commitments from the Chinese, including efforts protecting trade secrets and on opening markets wider to American drug and medical device makers.
lead_paragraph: GUANGZHOU, China — In their first top-level trade talks since President Obama hosted China’s leader in September, the United States and China said on Monday that they had made progress on sticking points, including preventing the theft of trade secrets and opening the Chinese market more broadly to American multinationals.

headline: What’s It Like to Get Sick on the New York Subway? Readers Share Their Stories
abstract: Commenters on a New York Times story about sick passengers on the subway tell their tales of being ill and seeing those who were.
lead_paragraph: About 3,000 subway trains in New York are delayed each month because of sick passengers, as Emma G. Fitzsimmons writes in a New York Times article published on Monday. Readers, some of whom had gotten sick on the train themselves, wrote in to share their stories.

headline: Elliott Management Appoints Jonathan Pollock as Co-Chief Executive
abstract: For the first time, the founder of Elliott Management will run the $27 billion investment firm with a partner.
lead_paragraph: For most of its 38 years, Elliott Management has been a lucrative hedge fund run solely by its founder, the billionaire Paul E. Singer, a man known for his hard-nosed trades and outsize influence in politics.

headline: Future Ford Cars Won’t Use Takata Airbag Parts
abstract: Ford said it would stop using Takata airbag inflaters with ammonium nitrate as a propellant in any products under development.
lead_paragraph: Ford Motor on Monday became the fourth automaker to announce that it would stop using certain airbag components made by the Japanese supplier Takata in future vehicles.

headline: William Ackman Raises Valeant Stake to 9.9% From 5.7%
abstract: The billionaire investor has sharply increased his position as the embattled drug company comes under scrutiny.

headline: Nestlé Reports on Abuses in Thailand’s Seafood Industry
keywords: ['Fishing, Commercial', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Seafood', 'Human Trafficking', 'Forced Labor', 'Maritime Crime']
abstract: The report on the seafood industry in Thailand cataloged deceptive recruitment practices, hazardous working conditions, and violence on fishing boats and in processing factories.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The seafood industry in Thailand suffers from widespread labor and human rights abuses, exposing virtually all American and European companies that buy seafood from there to the “endemic risk” of having these problems as part of their supply chain, according to a report released on Monday by the food giant Nestlé.

headline: Ken Johnson, Only Loser of 9-Inning No-Hitter, Dies at 82
abstract: The Houston Colt .45s pitcher threw a brilliant game against the Cincinnati Reds on April 23, 1964, only to lose in the ninth.
lead_paragraph: Baseball, that statistics-mad enterprise, has served up its share of rare performances by individual players. Fifteen fielders have turned unassisted triple plays. Thirteen hitters have hit two grand slams in a game, including one, Fernando Tatis, who in April 1999 did so in the same inning, which may be the game’s most remarkable anomaly, though Don Larsen’s perfect game for the Yankees against the Dodgers in 1956 — the only no-hitter thrown in the World Series — is better known and better remembered.

headline: Edible, but Ugly

lead_paragraph: To combat food waste, Imperfect Produce, a San Francisco Bay Area start-up, sells fresh fruits and vegetables that never make it to grocery store shelves.

keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']

lead_paragraph: Every year, the largest banks have to undergo a theoretical test to assess how they might fare in a period of extreme stress in the markets and the economy.

headline: ‘Jessica Jones’ Episode 4: Think About Me
abstract: The series takes a trip into “case-of-the-week” land.

headline: Civilian Review Board Criticizes Arrest of Thabo Sefolosha
abstract: The board ruled that while the police had not used excessive force in arresting the Atlanta Hawks player, they were wrong to arrest him.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s Civilian Complaint Review Board ruled on Monday that the police had no right to arrest Atlanta Hawks basketball player Thabo Sefolosha outside a nightclub in April, but that officers had not used excessive force when they knocked him to the ground and broke his leg.

headline: Donations Help the S.S. United States Fend Off the Scrapyard
abstract: Contributions of more than $600,000 will provide more time for those interested in preserving the S.S. United States to work with interested developers and investors.
lead_paragraph: For now, at least, the next port of call for the S.S. United States — the fastest oceanliner ever built — will not be the scrapyard, thanks to an outpouring of donations from ship lovers around the world.

lead_paragraph: The billionaire and activist investor Carl C. Icahn took aim at another famous American company on Monday, the Xerox Corporation, and he stepped up pressure on the insurance giant American International Group.

headline: Joyce Carol Oates on Twitter: Is Nothing ‘Joyous’ in ISIS?

keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)']

lead_paragraph: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates — With the Obama administration under mounting pressure from some of its own top former officials to take a more aggressive approach to combating the Islamic State, Secretary of State John Kerry said Monday that he would like to see the American-led military and diplomatic effort in Syria “go faster.”

headline: Bill Blocking Plan to Reduce Mute Swans Is Vetoed
abstract: In the dispute between those who see mute swans as an invasive species and those who question the science behind that label, the nadir did not arrive until Monday.
lead_paragraph: It was always destined to bring public relations misery: a state agency’s campaign, approved by experts but undeniably unpleasant, to exterminate the lithe-necked, snow-white mute swans of New York State, in the name of ecological health.

headline: Adele Mailer, Artist Who Married Norman Mailer, Dies at 90
abstract: Mrs. Mailer embraced the downtown arts scene and a bohemian lifestyle. In 1960, her husband stabbed her in the heart.
lead_paragraph: Adele Mailer, an artist and actress who made headlines in 1960 when her husband, the novelist Norman Mailer, stabbed and seriously wounded her at a drunken party in their apartment, died on Sunday in Manhattan. She was 90.

headline: Chris Christie’s Bid Gains New Life as He Invokes 9/11 Amid Fear
abstract: The Paris attacks have brought a sudden intensity, attention and focus to the once-moribund candidacy of Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: STRATHAM, N.H. — In the course of a two-hour campaign stop here, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey brought a handful of men and women to tears describing the deathbed wishes of his cancer-ridden mother, cracked them up with the declaration that his presidency would be golf-free and riveted them with his remembrances of the family friends he lost on Sept. 11, 2001.

keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']

lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a significant reversal of British government policy, Prime Minister David Cameron promised on Monday to bolster military spending, ending years of cutbacks that had prompted critics to claim that Britain was retreating from its global role.

headline: Pfizer-Allergan Merger Reignites Tax Reform Discussion

abstract: The blockbuster pharmaceutical merger has put new pressure on Congress and the White House to overhaul the corporate tax code.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For almost four years, Congress and the White House have done little to make their long-promised overhaul of the corporate tax code a reality. Now the blockbuster pharmaceutical merger of Pfizer and Allergan has put new pressure on all sides to act.

headline: FanDuel, Facing Opposition, Maintains Its Visibility in New York

lead_paragraph: As FanDuel braced for a court hearing that could determine the fate of daily fantasy sports in New York, the company demonstrated that it remained committed to advertising its website there.

headline: Washer Action
abstract: Gary Cee will make you tumble to his theme.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — There comes a time in every homeowner’s life when it becomes necessary to make a sacrifice to the god of home appliances in the form of large amounts of money. I encountered that moment shortly after moving into my current house, when I tried to track down the mysterious sounds emanating from my basement, only to discover my washing machine performing a conga across the floor in mid-SPIN CYCLE.

headline: Heat Defenders Swarm Porzingis, Who Can’t Save Knicks
abstract: Kristaps Porzingis was productive once again, collecting 20 points and 14 rebounds. But he worked for everything, shooting 7 of 18 from the field against waves of defenders.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Heat players pledged before Monday’s game to learn from the mistakes of their predecessors. They would actually defend Kristaps Porzingis, the newly minted wunderkind of the Knicks. They would roam with him to the perimeter, denying him open looks at 3-pointers. They would challenge him.

Skelos and his son testified at their trial on Monday that days after Hurricane Sandy hit in 2012, the senator provided valuable business intelligence that the company felt would be helpful.

headline: ‘Fargo’ Season 2, Episode 7: This Family Deserves the Ground

headline: Egypt: Forces Kill 5 Sudanese at Border
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The deaths came eight days after Egyptian border guards were accused in the fatal shootings of at least 15 Sudanese migrants trying to cross the frontier.
lead_paragraph: Egyptian security forces on Monday shot and killed at least five Sudanese migrants who were trying to cross the border from Egypt into Israel, the military said in a statement.   The deaths came eight days after Egyptian border guards were accused in the fatal shootings of at least 15 Sudanese migrants trying to cross the frontier.  Human rights groups have for years criticized the Egyptian authorities as resorting too quickly to lethal force against migrants and asylum seekers, mostly from East Africa, who travel through the Sinai Peninsula to reach Israel.  In the latest episode, the military said the border guards fired warning shots and were moving to arrest the migrants when the Egyptian guards came under fire.  In addition to the five migrants who were killed, six others were injured, the statement said.

headline: Admissions Quota Proposed in Brooklyn School Rezoning
abstract: The Education Department said that students receiving subsidized lunches would be given admissions priority for half the seats at a Brooklyn school that is the subject of a contested rezoning proposal.
lead_paragraph: Responding to concerns that a plan to redraw two Brooklyn school zones would fill an elementary school with affluent white children that currently serves mostly low-income minority children, Education Department staff members said on Monday that students receiving free or reduced-price lunches would be given admissions priority for half the seats in each class at the school.

headline: Documentary About Rape at Colleges Draws Viewers in Key Demographic
abstract: “The Hunting Ground,” which was shown in full on CNN despite a threat of legal action from a lawyer for Jameis Winston, had an average of 179,000 live and same-day viewers in the 25-to-54 age group.
lead_paragraph: “The Hunting Ground,” a documentary about rape on college campuses, attracted an average of 179,000 live and same-day viewers Sunday night in the 25-to-54 age group, the highest average for cable news networks during the nearly two-hour period that began at 8 p.m. Eastern.

headline: Researchers Track Tricky Payment Theft Scheme
abstract: About two years after a hack at Target became national news, retailers are determined to avoid a similar disaster.

headline: Albert Einstein and Relativity in the Pages of The Times

lead_paragraph: When Albert Einstein and his work first became known to the broader public, articles in The Times often seemed to alternate between exasperation and fascination.

headline: Space, the Frontier Right in Front of Us
abstract: Art, architecture and music were altered by the idea that space is not just a void, but an aesthetic force of its own.
lead_paragraph: With the publication of his general theory of relativity a century ago, Albert Einstein swept aside traditional notions of a static and unchanging space and instead gave us the stretchy, supple miracle fabric of the space-time continuum.

headline: A Century Ago, Einstein’s Theory of Relativity Changed Everything
abstract: The equation that describes fundamental workings of the universe is as compact and mysterious as a Viking rune.
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, N.J. — By the fall of 1915, Albert Einstein was a bit grumpy.

headline: What Is General Relativity?
abstract: Einstein presented his general theory of relativity more than 100 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Einstein presented his general theory of relativity more than 100 years ago.

headline: Who Wins in Photo Contests?
abstract: As photographers and editors cull the previous year’s work in preparation for major contests, several reflect on what competitions can and cannot do.
lead_paragraph: As the holiday season approaches, many photographers turn to reviewing their year’s work and entering photography contests. These competitions run the gamut: Some spotlight local achievement, while others honor photographers from all over the world. There are contests by nonprofits that are free to enter and many others whose business plan depends on entry fees from photographers wanting to be noticed.

headline: Adjust Social Security
abstract: A reader suggests a solution: Increase or eliminate the earnings cap.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Tales of the Super Survivors
abstract: Many people bounce back from traumatic events to be even stronger than before. There are reasons.
lead_paragraph: The age of terror is an age of shocks. Individuals, families and whole societies get torn apart by unexpected stabbings, shootings and bombings.

headline: Abortions in the South
abstract: A reader calls for cultural changes to reduce the high number of unplanned pregnancies and abortions.

headline: Mr. Trump’s Applause Lies
abstract: It’s up to the media to confront demagogy with the truth.
lead_paragraph: America has just lived through another presidential campaign week dominated by Donald Trump’s racist lies. Here’s a partial list of false statements: The United States is about to take in 250,000 Syrian refugees; African-Americans are responsible for most white homicides; and during the 9/11 attacks, “thousands and thousands” of people in an unnamed “Arab” community in New Jersey “were cheering as that building was coming down.”

headline: Can Democrats Make Running for Office Seem Cool?
keywords: ['State Legislatures', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'United States Politics and Government', 'States (US)', 'Elections, State Legislature']
abstract: With Republicans largely in control of state legislative maps, the Democratic farm team has gone to seed.
lead_paragraph: Under normal circumstances, the weirdness of this presidential cycle — the historically large and fragmented Republican field, the dominance of outsider candidates and the slow-rolling revival of nationalism in the conservative base — would be enough to make Democrats giddy. But they shouldn’t feel too smug; they have their own party leadership problem. It’s not as visible, but it is potentially more disastrous.

headline: Should Woodrow Wilson’s Name Be Erased at Princeton?
abstract: Readers on both sides weigh in.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Force-Feeding: Cruel at Guantánamo, but O.K. for Our Parents
abstract: Tube feeding has become commonplace, especially for patients with dementia, but it causes them pain and provides no benefits.
lead_paragraph: THE practice of forced feeding has been highlighted by its use on hunger strikers in Guantánamo Bay and, more recently, in Israel, where a vigorous debate about the ethics of such a practice is taking place. But you don’t have to be in prison to have a feeding tube jammed up your nose. Millions of elderly Americans are fed through tubes despite a lack of substantial evidence pointing to any clinical benefit.

headline: What Woodrow Wilson Cost My Grandfather
abstract: My grandfather lost his prestigious job after President Wilson segregated the government.
lead_paragraph: OVER the last week, a growing number of students at Princeton have demanded that the university confront the racist legacy of Woodrow Wilson, who served as its president before becoming New Jersey’s governor and the 28th president of the United States. Among other things, the students are demanding that Wilson’s name be removed from university facilities.

headline: Pfizer’s Big Breakthrough: Global Tax Avoidance
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Tax Shelters', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Relocation of Business', 'Corporate Taxes']
abstract: The $160 billion deal to combine Pfizer and Allergan does not appear to be illegal, but it should be.
lead_paragraph: The $160 billion deal to combine Pfizer and Allergan, the maker of Botox, does not appear to be illegal. But it should be. This merger is a tax-dodging maneuver that enriches shareholders and executives while shortchanging the public and robbing the Treasury of money that would pay for a host of government programs — including education, scientific research and other services that also benefit corporations.

headline: Amid Failure and Chaos, an Ebola Vaccine
abstract: Under the pressure of spreading calamity, vaccines were readied to stem the Ebola epidemic even as it sputtered out. Now they’re available to rein in the next outbreak.
lead_paragraph: Ebola lingers. A 15-year-old boy in Monrovia, Liberia, his father and his brother are sick with the disease, the first cases in Liberia since June. How the boy caught Ebola is a mystery, but it is likely he had contact with an Ebola survivor. The virus also lingers in the body — and can sicken its host and infect others — even months after recovery.

headline: Which U.S. Infrastructure Is in Most Need of Attention?
abstract: Roads, power grids, water mains. The list goes on, but what's the priority, and how should America finance needed repairs?

headline: Why Punish Drug Users at All?
abstract: Parents should be more worried that their children will get caught and punished than that the drugs they use will harm them.
lead_paragraph: This interview, the latest in a series on political topics, discusses philosophical issues concerning the criminalization of drug use. My interviewee is Douglas Husak, professor of philosophy at Rutgers University. He is the author of “Overcriminalization: The Limits of the Criminal Law.” – Gary Gutting

headline: Heritage and Style at TAG Heuer
abstract: Christoph Behling, the brand’s lead designer, blends change into the house’s traditional approach.
lead_paragraph: Christoph Behling is a Swiss designer working for a Swiss watchmaker, but it is fair to say he goes against the grain of this traditional industry.
