headline: A Dream of Secular Utopia in ISIS’ Backyard
keywords: ['Kurds', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: At a college in Kurdish Syria, Rojava tries to train its future leaders.
lead_paragraph: One of the safer crossings into Syria is at a small town called Fishkhabour, in the far northwestern corner of Iraq. In a whitewashed shack on the shore of the Tigris River, an official from Iraq’s Kurdistan Regional Government pointed out the window toward a pontoon bridge that bobbed in the cola-colored water. A year ago, 30,000 refugees fleeing an Islamic State massacre in Syria walked for 30 hours before crossing it in the opposite direction, half-starved, half-dead, terrorized. The official told me and my interpreter, Mohammed Ismael Rasool, that a few days before we arrived, an Italian volunteer was arrested by a border patrolman while trying to swim back toward Iraq. ‘‘Don’t change your mind,’’ he said, wagging a finger.

headline: The Serial Swatter
abstract: Internet trolls have learned to exploit our over-militarized police. It's a crime that's hard to stop — and hard to prosecute.
lead_paragraph: Early one weekend morning in January 2014, Janet was sleeping fitfully in her parents’ home in Toronto. A junior studying elementary education at a nearby college, she had gone home for the weekend in a state of nervous collapse. For months, someone going by the name ‘‘Obnoxious’’ had been harassing her online. He had called her cellphone repeatedly and sent her threatening texts. Worst of all, he had threatened to ‘‘swat’’ her at school — to make a false emergency call to the police and lure a SWAT team to her door.

headline: Bob Mankoff Thinks Cats Are Funnier Than Dogs
abstract: The cartoon editor of the New Yorker on why cartoonists, like cockroaches, will survive anything.
lead_paragraph: You’re the cartoon editor of The New Yorker and the subject of a new HBO documentary, “Very Semi-Serious.” In it, cartoonists often try to explain their cartoons to you if you aren’t initially sold. Does that ever work? I’m not infallible. I might be the king of cartoons; I’m not the pope. But what I say to cartoonists is that there is often something to “get” in New Yorker cartoons — anyway, we hope so — but it should never feel like a puzzle to the reader.

Basically, how little they actually understood about the recent housing and credit bubble before researching their roles. “I thought I knew, but I didn’t really know anything at all,” Mr. Gosling said.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Kitchen Timer
abstract: A simple time-management device can free you from exhausting task of self-control.
lead_paragraph: It began, as many habits do, in desperation. In my first year of working from home, I had discovered how crucial it was that I stay fastened to my desk. This sounded simple, but it was, in fact, as difficult to accomplish as it would have been at a desk on a ship caught in a typhoon. Never before had I felt so many gusts of trivial desire: I needed to buy stamps at the post office, to dust the window sills, to locate the jump-rope I was fairly sure I’d left in the back of the closet.

headline: The Winter Hat Trick
keywords: ['Hats and Caps', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Winter (Season)', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: When the temperature drops, no one can argue against the need for a hat. But is it possible to find a way to wear one that isn’t ridiculous?
lead_paragraph: Here they come now, winter hats, making their annual flight from the recesses of our closets to the crests of our persons. The plain-­spoken stocking caps, the trapper hats, the rabbit-­fur fantasia — to watch these and a hundred other designs re-­enter circulation is at once to witness the most natural thing in the world and to size up something strange. Hats seem essential in frigid air, but many seem ­impossible to wear with a straight face, given the cultural climate. Get a whiff of the models that served our grandfathers well: They now combine the must of a midcentury hatbox with the musk of 21st-­century body spray. Take a look at the grown-­ups wearing wool caps decorated to the verge of doubling as stuffed animals. The impish self-­consciousness of such nonsense shows that gussying up the head is, however awkward, serious business.

headline: How to Talk to Your Relatives About Politics at Thanksgiving

headline: In Arguments Over Terrorism, Echoes of World War II
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Terrorism', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Seven decades on, it is remarkable how many of our political arguments continue to focus on the resistance of Nazi-like behavior, whether in ourselves or others.
lead_paragraph: It gets your attention when a leader says we are at “the beginning of a terrorist world war.” It carries greater weight when that leader runs a major intelligence agency. And more weight still when that agency is German, its very name a product of the last world war and its lessons about fear and evil and the terrifying ease of losing one’s soul: the Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution.

headline: 1940: A Mass for All War Victims
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: 50,000 people attend a mass celebrated by the pope for all war victims in 1940.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Fifty thousand persons packed St. Peter’s Church and Square this morning [Nov. 24] at a mass celebrated by Pope Pius XII for all the victims of the war and listened to an address by him before the altar in which he prayed to God to bring the peoples of the world to a peace based on justice and expressed his belief that the present hour was one of the gravest in human history. After rehearsing once more how, as head of the Church, he had worked long to re-establish peace among nations, Pope Pius said that although the noise of war seemed to drown his voice he turned to God for consolation. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 25, 1940

headline: ‘Jane the Virgin’ Season 2, Episode 7: New Pants Wednesday

That’s hard enough, but Jane has an additional, unconventional worry because she has no idea what Sin Rostro currently looks like and could, unknowingly, hire this evil woman to take care of her baby. “Jane the Virgin” is dramatic but, fortunately, not that dramatic. headline: 1965: Sheikh Abdullah of Kuwait Dies
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Sheikh Adbullah al-Sabah, the ruler of Kuwait, dies in 1965.
lead_paragraph: KUWAIT — Sheikh Abdullah al-Sabah, 73, ruler of this major oil-producing nation and one of the world’s richest men, died today [Nov. 24] of heart failure. The crown prince, Sheikh Sabah al-Salem al-Sabah, was proclaimed the new ruler. Sheikh Abdullah had ruled Kuwait since its independence from Britain in 1961, and had been emir of the oil sheikhdom since 1950. Under his rule, the sandy little country on the east coast of Arabia acquired one of the most advanced social welfare systems in the world, and became a democracy with an elected parliament. He founded Kuwait’s first parliament and cabinet and enrolled the sheikhdom in the United Nations. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 25, 1965

lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Demonstrators took to the streets of this city’s downtown in tense but largely peaceful protests after the release of video on Tuesday showing the fatal shooting of a black teenager by a white Chicago police officer.

headline: Rigatoni Sets You Up for Thanksgiving
abstract: The pasta dish with tomatoes, black olives and yellow pepper will appeal to all ages and satisfy vegetarians and meat eaters alike.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy to feed family and friends gathered at your house on the days after Thanksgiving. But what about the days before? That’s when my teenage son, just home from school and with friends in tow, is hungriest for home cooking.

headline: Fewer Golfers, but Some Lush Courses Are Coming Back
abstract: The National Golf Foundation says there are four million fewer golfers than a decade ago. Yet at some communities, homes can go for $5 million.
lead_paragraph: BOCA RATON, Fla. — Weeds, crabgrass and fallen palm fronds cover the wildly overgrown greens of what was once the Mizner Trail Golf Club, its decrepit state emblematic of the fate of hundreds of golf courses around the country, many of them derisively known as “rabbit patches” or “goat farms.”

headline: “Impossible Wardrobes”
abstract: A new book chronicles three performance-art projects by Tilda Swinton and Olivier Saillard.
lead_paragraph: A new book chronicles three performance-art projects by Tilda Swinton and Olivier Saillard.

headline: A Car Dealers Won’t Sell: It’s Electric
keywords: ['Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Automobiles', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Energy Efficiency']
abstract: Car dealers are showing scant enthusiasm for putting consumers into electric cars, despite large fan clubs and governmental pledges.
lead_paragraph: More than seven years ago, President Obama called for one million electric cars to be on the road by this year, and the vehicles have gained a large fan club. Environmentalists promote them as a smart way to cut dangerous emissions. Owners love their pep and the gas money they save. Apple and Google have jumped into the race to build next-generation battery-powered cars.

headline: Sorting Out What Russia and Turkey Say Happened in the Sky
abstract: Comparing the conflicting versions of the events.
lead_paragraph: Comparing the conflicting versions of the events.

headline: ‘Brief Candle in the Dark,’ by Richard Dawkins
abstract: Dawkins’s second memoir plumbs his grown-up research, reflections and controversies.
lead_paragraph: Some lumbering robot, this Richard Dawkins. “Lumbering robots” was one of the ways in which this scarily brilliant evolutionary biologist described human beings vis-à-vis their genes in “The Selfish Gene,” his first and probably still his most influential book — more than a million copies sold. (His atheist manifesto, “The God Delusion,” has sold more than three million.) We’re essentially a means of physical and, more important, temporal transportation for our genes, he explained. They can live on for eons after we take our own inherited genes and mate with those of that handsome boy behind us in the ­movie-ticket line who ended up sitting next to us or the ones belonging to that pretty girl whose change we picked up by mistake at the newsstand and with whom we then had an apologetic coffee. And so on down the line. Our lines. Dawkins has also called us “throwaway survival machines” for our genes. But only, I think, to make a biological point.

headline: Tilda Swinton, Olivier Saillard and the Art of Dressing
abstract: An actress and a curator plumb the depths of what we wear.
lead_paragraph: Over the last few years, Tilda Swinton has collaborated with the fashion curator Olivier Saillard on three rather unusual live performances, now documented in a catalog called ‘‘Impossible Wardrobes.’’ In one piece, Saillard and Swinton made a dress to measure, with Swinton as a dress form. For another, the actress painstakingly carried historically significant items of clothing, like Napoleon’s coat, down a runway. ‘‘In many ways,’’ she explains, ‘‘the clothes operated as a bridge to the person no longer inside them — almost as if the garment is a symptom or a leaf shed from a tree.’’ In the final work, Swinton assumed the role of coat-check attendant, leaving bits of personal ephemera, like a drop of perfume or a lipstick-smeared tissue, in visitors’ pockets. ‘‘I still prize the old shoes and tiny cardigans of my now sky-scraping children,’’ Swinton says. ‘‘They link to the past like portals.’’

headline: In Renovation of Golf Club, Donald Trump Also Dressed Up History
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Golf']
abstract: Historians say a plaque installed by Mr. Trump at a golf course on the Potomac River commemorates a Civil War event that never happened.
lead_paragraph: STERLING, Va. — When Donald J. Trump bought a fixer-upper golf club on Lowes Island here for $13 million in 2009, he poured millions more into reconfiguring its two courses. He angered conservationists by chopping down more than 400 trees to open up views of the Potomac River. And he shocked no one by renaming the club after himself.

headline: Human Error Cited in U.S. Strike on Kunduz Hospital
abstract: The intended target of an airstrike on a Doctors Without Borders hospital last month was a compound believed to be a Taliban base, military officials briefed on an inquiry said.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The American airstrike that destroyed a Doctors Without Borders hospital in Kunduz last month was the result of human errors, failures in procedure and technical malfunctions, according to military officials briefed on the internal investigation.

headline: Cuomo Reaches Deal to Keep Open Alcoa Plant in Upstate New York
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo promised nearly $70 million in subsidies to keep the plant operating in Massena, N.Y., a hard-hit corner of the state.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Tuesday that the state had come to an agreement to keep open an Alcoa plant on the St. Lawrence River after promising the company nearly $70 million in state subsidies.

headline: N.H.L. This Week: A Friday Afternoon National Broadcast
abstract: The Rangers visit Boston on Friday afternoon for NBC’s first national hockey broadcast of the season.
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday, The New York Times will look at the week ahead in the N.H.L., highlighting hot — or not so hot — teams and players.

headline: Abid Naseer Receives 40-Year Sentence for Bomb Plot
abstract: Mr. Naseer, a member of Al Qaeda, was arrested in 2009 after a scheme involving a car bombing at a shopping center in Manchester, England, and an attack on the New York subway system.
lead_paragraph: A member of Al Qaeda who plotted, but did not carry out, a car bombing of a shopping center in Manchester, England, was sentenced on Tuesday to 40 years in prison.

headline: Pfizer’s Desire to Split Has Faded
abstract: The deal with Allergan will cut taxes and add solid assets, but it is also prompting Pfizer to defer a decision on splitting up until 2018.
lead_paragraph: Pfizer’s huge deal for Allergan will lower the drugmaker’s taxes, add solid assets such as Botox and reduce leverage. But it has also created a material adverse event. Pfizer is delaying a decision on whether to split the company by two years.

headline: YouTube Kids App Faces New Complaints Over Ads for Junk Food
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Online Advertising']
abstract: Consumer advocacy groups say marketing aimed at children has permeated the YouTube app designed specifically for children, and they are asking the government to examine the issue.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Visit YouTube Kids and typically it will not be long before promotions for junk food appear. The advertisements regularly show up in the form of funny contests and animated stories.

headline: Review: Christopher Hitchens Expounds in ‘And Yet ...’
abstract: This collection of Mr. Hitchens’s essays, book reviews and reported pieces covers topics political, social and literary.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Hitchens died of complications from esophageal cancer in 2011. Were he living, he’d turn 67 in the spring.

headline: Paging Dr. Pigeon; You’re Needed in Radiology
abstract: Researchers have found that the birds can be trained to tell the difference between malignant and benign breast tumors.
lead_paragraph: Dogs that detect cancer? Check. Fruit flies can do it? Check.

keywords: ['Chaldean Catholic Church', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']

lead_paragraph: One way of running a presidential campaign is to treat it like a continuous game of magnetic poetry — throwing words together at random without regard for their meaning. And no, I’m not talking about Donald Trump or Ben Carson.

headline: Lukewarm Drinks, Enthusiastic Reaction
abstract: Manhattan bartenders find that chilling dulls the flavor of some cocktail ingredients.
lead_paragraph: The temperature of a drink is not an issue typically up for discussion at the bar. Cocktails are cold, preferably very cold, except in those special time-honored instances (toddies, Irish coffee, Tom & Jerry) when they’re hot. Whatever the temperature of the room may be, the cocktails are not that.

headline: Donald Trump’s Affinity for Ted Cruz May Soon Be Changing
abstract: A new poll shows Ted Cruz in a statistical tie with Donald J. Trump for the lead in Iowa, raising the prospect that the billionaire developer may soon have to redirect criticism of his top Republican rivals the Texas senator’s way.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has been unyielding when it comes to trying to pinpoint the weaknesses of his top rivals for the Republican presidential nomination and exploiting them to no end. Except when it comes to Senator Ted Cruz.

lead_paragraph: This time, Jeffrey P. Bezos’ rocket went up — and it came down in one piece.

abstract: Send us your sports-related dream gift — the one thing in the sports world that would make you happier than anything else — and we’ll compile the best ones. Then, this weekend, you can read what other New York Times readers wished for.
lead_paragraph: Send us your sports-related dream gift — the one thing in the sports world that would make you happier than anything else — and we’ll compile the best ones. Then, this weekend, you can read what other New York Times readers wished for.

headline: A Mixed Week for Plays at Broadway Box Office
abstract: Lackluster reviews didn’t hurt “Misery,” with Bruce Willis, which is the second-highest-grossing play behind David Mamet’s “China Doll.”
lead_paragraph: Unhappy critics don’t always hurt. Ecstatic ones don’t always help. That was the lesson last week for two plays new to Broadway, according to figures released on Monday by the Broadway League.

headline: Rare Video of Russian Amur Tiger and Cubs Hints at Progress in Poaching Fight
abstract: Conservationists see a bit of hope for Russia’s tigers in video of a female and three grown cubs.
lead_paragraph: The Wildlife Conservation Society is working on many fronts to conserve wildlife and critical habitat. In recent weeks, developments have been grim, particularly the murder of two forest guardians working with the group in Cambodia. That gives extra value to small signs of success, including fresh camera trap video from Russia’s far east showing a female Amur tiger and three grown cubs exploring an overgrown logging road.

headline: Identities of Jurors in Trial Over Freddie Gray’s Death Will Be Shielded
abstract: The judge cited potential “undue harassment” of jurors in the trial of the first of six police officers charged in the death of Mr. Gray, a black man who suffered a spinal injury after his arrest.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Citing “intense media scrutiny” around the coming trial of the first of six police officers charged in the death of Freddie Gray, a 25-year-old black man who sustained a spinal injury after being arrested in April, a judge ruled Tuesday that jurors in the case will remain anonymous.

headline: ‘Dark Matter and the Dinosaurs,’ by Lisa Randall
abstract: Dark matter, according to Lisa Randall, may be responsible for the extinction of dinosaurs and the subsequent rise of mammals.
lead_paragraph: A good theory is an act of the informed imagination — it reaches toward the unknown while grounded in the firmest foundations of the known. In “Dark Matter and the Dinosaurs,” the Harvard cosmologist Lisa Randall proposes that a thin disk of dark matter in the plane of the Milky Way triggered a minor perturbation in deep space that caused the major earthly catastrophe that decimated the dinosaurs. It’s an original theory that builds on a century of groundbreaking discoveries to tell the story of how the universe as we know it came to exist, how dark matter illuminates its beguiling unknowns and how the physics of elementary particles, the physics of space, and the biology of life intertwine in ways both bewildering and profound.

headline: Ian Kershaw’s ‘To Hell and Back: Europe, 1914-1949’
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'World War I (1914-18)']
abstract: The first volume of a new history of modern Europe covers two world wars and the troubled years between them.
lead_paragraph: Ian Kershaw’s chilling epic-size history produces aftershocks connected to our current news headlines. Polish soldiers close border. . . . Rise of Austrian right. . . . Grim jobs report. . . . Shocking British vote. . . . Germans want sanctions against Russia. . . . Europe migrant crisis boils over. . . . They are all so reminiscent of the drum rolls that preceded Europe’s descent into “the pit of barbarism” during a century of two world wars that almost destroyed its civilization, followed by 40 years of Cold War. Seventy years after the democracies, together with the Red Army, triumphed in World War II, and 25 years after the reunification of Germany, the new Europe has made what Kershaw deems an “astonishing recovery.”

headline: “Artists II” by Jason Schmidt
abstract: The photographer discusses his images of James Turrell, David Byrne and more.
lead_paragraph: The photographer discusses his images of James Turrell, David Byrne and more.

headline: Inside the Artists’ Studios
abstract: The photographer Jason Schmidt’s latest book includes pictures of Mike Kelley, Joan Jonas and Terence Koh at work.
lead_paragraph: “Do you remember studying Joseph Campbell’s ‘The Power of Myth’?” asks the photographer Jason Schmidt. “I’ve always been drawn to artists; maybe it sounds corny, but they’re the mythmakers of our time. But,” he continues to think out loud, “they’re also people who decode human experiences and what it means to be human.”

headline: Podcast: Fear and the High Cost of Terror
abstract: The Times’s editorial page editor, Andrew Rosenthal, reflects on the debate over balancing national security with personal liberty in the new age of terror.
lead_paragraph: Terror attacks in Paris, Beirut, Mali and elsewhere around the globe reignited a familiar debate over balancing national security with personal liberty. How much of the latter are we willing to give up to protect our safety?

headline: Harlem’s Beauty Boom
abstract: In the last year, choices for skin care, laser hair removal and other cosmetic services have increased dramatically.
lead_paragraph: In the last year, choices for skin care, laser hair removal and other cosmetic services have increased dramatically.

headline: Tunisia Declares State of Emergency After Explosion on Bus
abstract: President Béji Caïd Essebsi declared a 30-day state of emergency after an explosion in Tunis tore through a bus carrying members of his security guard, killing at least 12 people.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — An explosion tore through a bus carrying members of the president’s security guard through the heart of Tunisia’s capital on Tuesday evening, killing at least 12 people and prompting the president to declare a 30-day state of emergency.

headline: $100 Million in Grants Announced for Indiana Culture
abstract: Fourteen groups received grants of between $5 million and $10 million for capital projects, endowments and programming.
lead_paragraph: Indiana’s cultural institutions just got $100 million richer, thanks to a series of grants that were announced on Tuesday morning by the Lilly Endowment.

lead_paragraph: If you’re looking for a colorful dish to brighten your holiday table, try this simple and elegant Vegetable Tian.

abstract: Portobello mushrooms are a great option for a vegan or vegetarian main course because they are large enough to fill a plate,and can be stuffed with a variety of flavors.
lead_paragraph: Portobello mushrooms are a great option for a vegan or vegetarian main course because they are large enough to fill a plate and can be stuffed with a variety of flavors.

headline: Danish Composer Wins $100,000 Prize
abstract: The 2016 Grawemeyer Award went to Hans Abrahamsen for the song cycle “let me tell you.”
lead_paragraph: Hans Abrahamsen, a Danish composer, has been awarded the 2016 Grawemeyer Award for Music Composition, a prestigious international prize that comes with a $100,000 award.

headline: Light May Work on Nonseasonal Depression, Study Finds
keywords: ['Depression (Mental)', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD)', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation']
abstract: The study says bright light therapy, which has been used effectively for seasonal affective disorder, may also work to treat the more common nonseasonal depression.
lead_paragraph: Bright light therapy has been used effectively for seasonal affective disorder, the kind of depression that comes on at a specific time every year, often the dark days of late fall and winter, and then lifts. Now a new study has found that it may work to treat nonseasonal depression as well.

headline: Travel Deals: Food Tours of Eastern Europe
abstract: Tours include visits to Slovenia and Croatia, or to Macedonia and Montenegro, sampling home-cooked meals and street food and traveling to markets.
lead_paragraph: Intrepid Travel is expanding its food tour offerings into Eastern Europe in 2016 with its “Real Food Adventures,” introducing travelers to home-cooked meals, street food and local food markets in four countries. The first trip,  to Slovenia and Croatia, leaves May 29 (from $2,119) and the second, to Montenegro and Macedonia, on June 9 (from $1,647), destinations where “slow food” is a way of life. Both 10-day tours include culinary and cultural highlights.

headline: Review: In ‘Creed,’ Rocky’s Back, as a Mentor, Not a Fighter
abstract: No. 7 in a series, “Creed” stars Michael B. Jordan as Sylvester Stallone’s protégé. It’s a rarity, A. O. Scott writes: “a terrific boxing movie.”
lead_paragraph: At a recent screening of “Creed,” as the familiar fanfare of Bill Conti’s beloved “Rocky” score signaled the start of the final round of the big fight, the audience burst into spontaneous applause. This was no sneak-preview crowd, primed with free admission and popcorn, but a room full of critics and journalists armored in professional skepticism. A cynic might say that the cheering was a Pavlovian reflex set off by a piece of commercial entertainment in the hands of a skilled, manipulative director. This cynic, however, was too busy choking up and clapping to form the thought.

headline: Two Hours Into Deliberations, a Juror in the Sheldon Silver Trial Wants Out
abstract: In a highly unusual move, a juror sent a note to the judge pleading to be excused less than two hours after the jury convened to decide whether Assemblyman Silver was guilty of fraud.
lead_paragraph: Not long after jurors convened on Tuesday to decide whether Assemblyman Sheldon Silver, once one of the most powerful politicians in New York State, was guilty of fraud, there were already unmistakable signs that their deliberations had taken a contentious turn.

headline: Into Africa: New West Africa Bureau Chief Makes Herself at Home
abstract: Dionne Searcey writes about moving her family to Senegal.
lead_paragraph: CONAKRY, Guinea — Dionne Searcey chronicles her adventures in Senegal, where she works as The Times’s West Africa bureau chief.

headline: Jonathan Mayer, Well-Known Online Security Expert, Joins F.C.C.
abstract: Mr. Mayer, a lawyer and vocal consumer advocate, will be the chief technologist in the agency’s enforcement bureau.
lead_paragraph: Among privacy groups in the United States, Jonathan Mayer is known as a vocal advocate who has defended the right of consumers to turn off online tracking of their browsing activities.

headline: ‘Jessica Jones’ Episode 5: I’ve Seen Heroes
abstract: One character proves that you can control your destiny.
lead_paragraph: Like Netflix’s “Daredevil” before it, “Jessica Jones” sets itself apart from other Marvel movies and TV shows by offering a view at a psychologically complex character. Jessica goes down various roads you probably would never expect a superhero — specifically one who may very well bump into Captain America or Iron Man at some point — to go down. And the show has, by and large, done a better job than “Daredevil” of laying out the tortured, masochistic logic that compels its characters to agonize over roads they didn’t take and commitments they can’t keep. The same is true of “AKA The Sandwich Saved Me,” the show’s fifth episode, and the one that best explains why Jones is one of the most nuanced contemporary superheroes.

headline: Prescience About Iraq
abstract: A reader recalls the “plausible solution” offered by Joe Biden and Leslie H. Gelb almost 10 years ago.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Vatican Trial Begins Over Leaked Documents
keywords: ['News Sources, Confidential Status of', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Libel and Slander', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Five people, including two authors and a monsignor and his assistant, face charges related to information in two books about mismanagement at the Vatican.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Five people, including two Italian journalists, went on trial in a Vatican courtroom on Tuesday on charges of illegally procuring and circulating confidential documents that were used to write two tell-all books detailing suspected mismanagement and corruption at the Vatican.

headline: Chris Christie’s Low Profile in Courage
abstract: Mr. Christie talks a lot about his memories of 9/11 — but he gets fuzzy when it comes to debunking false claims about Arabs celebrating in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a bumper sticker — Chris Christie: Because You’re Scared.

headline: New York Police Officers Fill Courtroom as Man Is Charged in Their Colleague’s Death
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Attacks on Police', 'Police']
abstract: Mr. Howard was charged with the murder of a police officer, two counts of robbery, gun possession and other crimes after the fatal shooting of Detective Randolph Holder in October.
lead_paragraph: Scores of police officers packed a Manhattan courtroom on Tuesday to watch as a convicted drug dealer was formally charged with murder in the shooting of a plainclothes officer last month.

headline: It’s Sort of Good to Be the King
abstract: A picture book in the tradition of “The Little Prince” delivers minimalist philosophical lessons on power.
lead_paragraph: Like a more elliptical version of “The Little Prince,” this book (which was originally published in Germany) assembles a series of very short tales about a king who has much to learn, mostly about power and its limits. His expectations — that others will obey him automatically, that the universe itself will acquiesce to his wishes — are thwarted again and again. Yet with each snub or disappointment, this king actually appears to be learning and gaining perspective, giving the book an unusually thoughtful, philosophical backbone.

headline: Le Garage Adds a French Touch to Bushwick, Brooklyn
abstract: A beer hall in Long Island City, Mediterranean seafood in Sheepshead Bay, and more.
lead_paragraph: Le Garage Catherine Allswang, a native of Normandy, has owned and cooked in restaurants in San Francisco and Paris. Her daughter, Rachel, an interior designer who grew up at her mother’s side in the kitchen, has teamed up with her to open a place in New York. They have turned a former garage in Bushwick, Brooklyn, into an intimate restaurant, largely French, where the temptations on a concise menu include steamed mussels, foie gras with winter radishes and beets, potatoes stuffed with snails, pork shoulder braised in milk, and chicken for two. Creative cocktails are named for Frenchwomen like Simone de Beauvoir, who is represented by an alluring mix of Byrrh aperitif, Dolin dry vermouth, orange bitters and tonic water. The décor, by Rachel Allswang, combines hard-edged industrial and sleek Art Deco: 159B Central Avenue (Suydam Street), Brooklyn, 347-295-1700, legaragebrooklyn.com.

headline: Brad Pitt, Ryan Gosling and Other Stars at ‘The Big Short’ Premiere
abstract: The star-studded cast attended the movie’s opening at the Ziegfeld Theater in Midtown Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The star-studded cast attended the movie’s opening at the Ziegfeld Theater in Midtown Manhattan.

lead_paragraph: A look at what Times critics had to say about the original “Rocky” (1976), and the new “Creed,” the latest entry in the franchise.

headline: After Attacks, the Soul of Paris Endures
abstract: Seven essays by Americans — expats, travelers and writers — trying to take the long view of Paris and pick up the pieces after the Nov. 13 attacks.
lead_paragraph: Seven essays by Americans — expats, travelers and writers — trying to take the long view of Paris and pick up the pieces after the Nov. 13 attacks.

headline: Margaret Keane of Synchrony Financial: When Hardship Informs Leadership
abstract: Ms. Keane says struggles early in life helped define her as a leader, with respect and decisiveness becoming crucial components of her style.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Margaret Keane, C.E.O. of Synchrony Financial, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: E.U. Proposes a Common Deposit Insurance Program for Eurozone
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Deposit Insurance', 'Euro (Currency)']
abstract: A plan to supplement and eventually replace national deposit insurance plans could face opposition from Germany, which has resisted sharing fiscal risks.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union authorities on Tuesday proposed a system to share the cost of protecting savers during banking crises.

headline: HBO Sets Its ‘Sesame Street’ Debut
abstract: HBO will run two consecutive 30-minute episodes on Jan. 16, followed by new 30-minute episodes each Saturday.
lead_paragraph: “Sesame Street” will make its debut on HBO on Saturday, Jan. 16 at 9 a.m., the premium cable network announced on Tuesday.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Seeks to Reduce, Not Ban, Carriage Horses in Central Park
abstract: A new proposal from City Hall would relocate stables and shrink the number of carriage horses allowed to traverse Central Park’s paths from 220 to just a few dozen.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio is pursuing a new twist on his longtime effort to end the Central Park horse carriage industry: reducing, not eliminating, its hoof print.

headline: Brad Pitt, Ryan Gosling and Other Stars at ‘The Big Short’ Premiere
abstract: The star-studded cast attended the movie’s opening at the Ziegfeld Theater in Midtown Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Brad Pitt stood on a red carpet Monday night getting angry. He wasn’t addressing the paparazzi, who have been known to stalk his wife and children. “They’re in Cambodia,” he said, explaining why he arrived solo.

headline: Vintage Art Jackets With Cult Appeal
abstract: London’s ICA has unearthed a trove of jackets designed by the artist Peter Blake — and, beginning next month, will put them up for sale.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, an employee of London’s Institute of Contemporary Arts (ICA) went into the institution’s basement and found quite a treasure: piles of jackets designed by the Pop artist Peter Blake in 1978. The color-blocked jackets, which read “The ICA Likes Art,” had been in storage for almost four decades — but were surprisingly intact. So, beginning next week, the museum will sell 70 of the original jackets for £70 (roughly $105) — just in time for its 70th anniversary in 2016.

headline: Thomas Libous, Ex-New York State Senator, Gets Probation and Home Confinement in Corruption Case
abstract: Mr. Libous, a Republican from the Binghamton area, avoided prison time because he has prostate cancer that he has described as terminal.
lead_paragraph: WHITE PLAINS — Calling his conduct “disgraceful,” a judge on Tuesday sentenced Thomas W. Libous, once the second-highest ranking Republican in the New York Senate, to two years of probation, six months of home confinement and a $50,000 fine for lying to federal agents during a corruption investigation.

headline: Adele on ‘25’: Song by Song
abstract: The British songwriter talks about the inspiration behind “Hello,” “I Miss You” and more songs on her record-breaking new album.
lead_paragraph: Adele’s “25” is easily shaping up to be the best-selling album of 2015: Billboard reports that Adele Adkins’s third album has broken the record for single-week sales set by  ‘N Sync’s “No Strings Attached” in March 2000. With at least 2,433,000 copies of the album sold in just over three days, “25” is also set to more than double the first-week sales of some of the biggest albums of the past 15 years, including Taylor Swift’s “1989,” the Beatles’ “1” and Eminem’s “The Eminem Show.”

headline: The Art of the Thanksgiving Table
abstract: Graciousness and hospitality build the framework for good manners, experts say.
lead_paragraph: HARTSVILLE, S.C. — Of the many places to learn the nuances of traditional Thanksgiving etiquette, none are quite like Wardie Sanders’s high school classroom.

headline: Handed Life’s Twists, Notre Dame Quarterback Turns It Around
abstract: DeShone Kizer went from self-doubting third-stringer to comfortable starter, all while his girlfriend continued to deal with the serious aftereffects of having a tumor removed.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH BEND, Ind. — Notre Dame quarterback DeShone Kizer is stuck in a moment of self-reflection, having scrambled around the jarring juxtaposition that separates his present from his not-so-distant past.

headline: Review: Juilliard String Quartet Shows Agility at Alice Tully Hall
abstract: This ensemble, soon to begin a new era, played a program featuring Schubert, Debussy and Elliott Carter
lead_paragraph: Bittersweetness tinged the Juilliard String Quartet’s first Lincoln Center performance this season, an exhilarating, penetrating, often splendidly harrowing concert on Monday at Alice Tully Hall. Joel Krosnick, the quartet’s cellist since 1974 and its longest-serving member by far, announced in May that he would leave the group at the end of this season. With no musician remaining on the roster who played with any of the Juilliard’s founding artists, a new era for a hallowed institution awaits.

headline: Striving to Make Travel Truly Pet-Friendly
abstract: Melissa Halliburton of BringFido.com sees a golden age for pet-friendly travel around the bend.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Halliburton’s inspiration for creating a global resource for travelers with pets in tow came from personal experience. After graduating from college, she settled on a petite Jack Russell-Chihuahua mix called Rocco. But taking him on the road proved to be a challenge in the Boston metropolitan area where she lived. “I called several hotels and even though signs said ‘pet friendly’ much of the information was incorrect,” she lamented.

headline: Rise in Early Cervical Cancer Detection Is Linked to Affordable Care Act
keywords: ['Cervical Cancer', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Researchers say there has been a substantial increase in women under the age of 26 who have received a diagnosis of early-stage cervical cancer since the health law came into effect in 2010.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Cancer researchers say there has been a substantial increase in women under the age of 26 who have received a diagnosis of early-stage cervical cancer, a pattern that they say is most likely an effect of the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Hotels Offer Variations on an Afternoon Tea Theme
abstract: Some properties are doing away with the predictability by offering creative interpretations of the classic pastime.
lead_paragraph: Hotel afternoon teas have often tended to be pomp-and-circumstance affairs with traditional menus consisting of scones, dainty sandwiches and bite-size pastries. Some properties today, though, are doing away with the predictability by offering creative interpretations of the classic pastime.

headline: Review: Ballet Hispanico’s ‘If Walls Could Speak’ Offers Vignettes of Urban Life
abstract: The dance company presented the premiere of this work by the Brazilian-born choreographer Fernando Melo, at the Apollo Theater.
lead_paragraph: A man returns to his apartment after a hard day. He slumps into a chair by a table and turns on a hanging lamp. After a while, the light flickers and the man looks startled. Was that a ghost he just saw? Or was it merely his reflection in the mirrored wall behind him?

headline: Bad Loans Weigh on European Banks, Regulator Reports
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: European banks had one trillion euros, or about $1.06 trillion, in nonperforming loans, according to the European Banking Authority.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Bad loans continue to weigh on the bottom lines of European banks despite efforts by the region’s lenders to raise more capital and improve their risk profiles since the financial crisis, according to regulators.

headline: Pop Facebook Quiz: Should You Take It?
abstract: Hundreds of quizzes created by a single company on the social network are creating a privacy concern.
lead_paragraph: More than 17 million people have taken a delightful little quiz on Facebook that displays their most-often used words in a sweet word cloud.

headline: ‘The Humans’ Sets Broadway Opening Date
abstract: Stephen Karam’s family drama will begin performances Jan. 23 at the Helen Hayes Theater.
lead_paragraph: For the family gathering for dinner in Stephen Karam’s play “The Humans,” Thanksgiving is fraught with secrets, sadness and tension. For the writer and creative team, however, the holiday brings good news: The drama, now playing Off Broadway in a Roundabout Theater Company production, will move to Broadway in January.

headline: Ben Carson’s Book Tour Draws Campaign Finance Complaint
abstract: The American Democracy Legal Fund says Mr. Carson violated campaign financing laws on a 26-day book tour in Iowa last month because his publisher, Sentinel, paid his travel expenses.
lead_paragraph: On a 26-day book tour last month, Ben Carson held a news conference in a Books-a-Million store in Iowa, appeared often on TV to discuss his candidacy and sandwiched campaign rallies between book signings.

headline: Afghan Soldiers and Foreigners Captured After Landing in Taliban-Held Area
abstract: A firefight with the Taliban after the emergency landing killed at least three Afghan soldiers, and at least 13 were taken prisoner, along with two foreigners.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban captured at least 13 Afghan soldiers and two foreigners after their aircraft made an emergency landing in the northern Afghan province of Faryab on Tuesday, officials said.

headline: The Artistry of Stephen Curry
abstract: The Warriors guard’s moves on the basketball court draws bravos from the world of ballet.
lead_paragraph: Taras Domitro was not a basketball fan when he joined the San Francisco Ballet as a principal dancer in 2008.

headline: Coverage of Paris Terror Attacks Lifts Network News Ratings
abstract: The evening newscasts on NBC, ABC and CBS had their biggest viewership in at least eight months.
lead_paragraph: The three network evening newscasts had their biggest viewership in at least eight months with their coverage last week of the Paris terrorist attacks.

headline: Chris Christie Defends Stance on Dangers of Accepting Refugees
abstract: Under fire for being heartless when it comes to refugees, Gov. Chris Christie defended his view that it was too dangerous to take in persecuted Syrians and warned that America could pay a deadly price for being politically correct about the matter.
lead_paragraph: Under fire for being heartless when it comes to refugees, Gov. Chris Christie on Tuesday defended his view that it was too dangerous to take in persecuted Syrians and warned that America could pay a deadly price for being politically correct about the matter.

headline: Final Earnings at the Old Hewlett-Packard Fall Short of Wall St. Expectations
abstract: Meg Whitman, who runs the new Hewlett Packard Enterprise, said that the split-off company was off to a strong start.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Hewlett-Packard ended its life as one public company with a whimper.

headline: Political Intelligence Firm to Pay S.E.C. Penalty
abstract: The agency says the Marwood Group obtained material nonpublic information twice in 2010 on policy issues or pending regulatory approvals.
lead_paragraph: A firm that gathered intelligence inside the Washington Beltway for the benefit of its hedge fund customers agreed to pay a $375,000 penalty to the Securities and Exchange Commission over compliance failures.

headline: Ways to Celebrate Thanksgiving, Old and New
abstract: In New York, Chicago, Atlanta and Los Angeles, holiday activities include the traditional (turkey trots) and a departure or two (zipping around the zoo).
lead_paragraph: Many families have their own traditions for Thanksgiving, whether it is an intergenerational breakfast, a game of flag football in the neighbor’s backyard, or something that takes people farther outside their homes, like a parade or a special volunteer activity. There are also a number of newer and nontraditional events in many American cities.

headline: Kentucky Governor Restores Voting Rights to Thousands of Felons
keywords: ['Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Ex-Convicts', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: Gov. Steve Beshear issued an executive order that will immediately grant the right to vote to about 140,000 nonviolent felons who have completed their sentences, lifting a lifetime ban.
lead_paragraph: Weeks before he leaves office, the governor of Kentucky on Tuesday issued an executive order that immediately granted the right to vote to about 140,000 nonviolent felons who have completed their sentences.

headline: Anger at Turkey’s ‘Stab in the Back’ Fills Russian Social Networks and Airwaves
abstract: After Russia’s president called the Turkish strike on one of his nation’s warplanes a “stab in the back,” his words were transformed into a hashtag.
lead_paragraph: Within a few minutes after President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia called the Turkish downing of one of his nation’s warplanes on Tuesday a “stab in the back,” the phrase had been transformed into a hashtag on social networks by enraged Russian bloggers.

headline: No Bail for Chicago Officer Jason Van Dyke
abstract: A court document describes the shooting of Laquan McDonald and recommends that Officer Van Dyke, charged in his death, is held without bail.
lead_paragraph: A court document describes the shooting of Laquan McDonald and recommends that Officer Van Dyke, charged in his death, is held without bail.

headline: Review: Gabriel Missé and Guillermina Quiroga, Together for the First Time
abstract: Gabriel Missé and Guillermina Quiroga: Perhaps we should call them the Fonteyn and Nureyev of tango.
lead_paragraph: Tango people keep late hours; I’ve been at gatherings where the best dancers arrive at midnight. For this reason, my tango-watching is limited; I seldom have the stamina. On Saturday, however, I was ready at 11 p.m. at the Clemente Soto Vélez Cultural and Educational Center in SoHo to watch an event in tango history: Gabriel Missé performing with Guillermina Quiroga for the first time. Excitement among the audience in the packed ground-floor room was intense. The stars did not disappoint; people were calling for more.

headline: Joe Biden Skips Thanksgiving in Nantucket; Meets With Martin O’Malley
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Thanksgiving Day', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: For the last four decades, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. has made a tradition of spending Thanksgiving with his family in Nantucket, Mass. But not this year, as he is still grieving the death of his son Beau.
lead_paragraph: For the last four decades, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. has made a tradition of spending Thanksgiving with his family in Nantucket, Mass.

headline: Review: Franco Zeffirelli's 'La Bohème' Revisits a Take on Love and Loss
abstract: The Metropolitan Opera revives Mr. Zeffirelli’s production of this Puccini work, a classic melodrama it has performed 1,275 times.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera revived Franco Zeffirelli’s 34-year-old production of “La Bohème” on Monday. Well, “revived” may be too strong a word. It implies a quality of animated freshness that didn’t much characterize this tired performance.

headline: Fantasy Sports Site Closes Digital Loophole Ahead of Hearing
abstract: The Times could not make a bet on DraftKings in Iowa, a state where daily fantasy sports is illegal, suggesting a technique for disguising a computer’s true location is now being blocked.
lead_paragraph: One of the largest fantasy sports companies appears to have closed an easily accessible loophole that had been available for users to make bets from states where daily fantasy sports is illegal.

headline: Advice to Retire By
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The financial industry wants people to believe they have to choose between biased investment advice and none at all. That’s false.
lead_paragraph: I have been writing for a while about the mismatch between the unbiased investing advice that people need and the self-interested recommendations they often get from advisers, a.k.a. salespeople, at banks, brokerages and other financial firms.

headline: Review: Rockettes in ‘Radio City Christmas Spectacular’
abstract: The Rockettes once again are kicking off the holiday season at Radio City Music Hall, with a few new flourishes.
lead_paragraph: Legs. Stretched out bare on a beach, they unmistakably signal summer. But encased in velvet or sequins, prancing by the dozens across a celebrated New York stage and rising into the air like Roman candles, they can mean only one thing: Winter is almost here.

headline: Thanksgiving TV Fare: Wild Animals, a Tame Train and a Tribute
abstract: Selections include marathons of “Gone With the Wind” cheek by jowl with “The Godfather,” or “Joey+Rory” honoring the terminally ill Joey Feek.
lead_paragraph: One channel hopes your most fervent Thanksgiving wish is to be bored to death. Another is convinced there’s nothing people want more than to rewatch movies they’ve already seen a zillion times.

headline: Pfizer and Allergan Deal Comes With an Extensive Prenup
abstract: The two companies have outlined the various termination fees they will pay each other in the event the $152 billion merger collapses.
lead_paragraph: Pfizer and Allergan thought up several situations where their blockbuster $152 billion merger agreement could meet resistance, including from shareholders, regulators and lawmakers, and even rival suitors.

lead_paragraph: Macedonia and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Review: ‘Victor Frankenstein’ Recasts a Tale That Keeps On Giving
abstract: This film, starring James McAvoy and Daniel Radcliffe, recasts a ghoulish story into something of a buddy movie.
lead_paragraph: You cannot keep a good monster down, especially when there’s franchise money to be made. This doubtless explains “Victor Frankenstein,” a pop romp that exhumes Mary Shelley’s famous monster-maker for a jaunty bromance with his bestie, Igor. It’s a hyperventilated resurrection that owes less to Shelley (or most Frankenstein flicks) than to Guy Ritchie’s Sherlock Holmes diversions, which turned Holmes (Robert Downey Jr.) and Dr. Watson (Jude Law) into 19th-century action heroes complete with cheerfully deployed violence and self-regarding smiles.

headline: Review: In ‘The Good Dinosaur,’ a Reptile Tends to His Human Pet
abstract: Homo sapiens and giant reptiles co-exist in this animated, alternate universe version of Earth history.
lead_paragraph: Blink and you may miss the sly joke that sets “The Good Dinosaur” on its enchantingly eccentric way. It begins with a near apocalypse 65 million years ago and an asteroid racing toward Earth. And while that’s around the time, more or less, that science hypothesizes the dinosaurs bit the dust, the wizards at Pixar have forged another creation story. Instead of crashing, the space rock zips past the big blue marble. Fast forward a few million years to what looks like the American Northwest, where two apatosaurs are farming the land, tilling the soil with honest sweat and giant noses.

headline: The Video of Celebrations That Was Broadcast on 9/11
abstract: Video does exist of people celebrating after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, but the cheering took place in the Middle East, not in New Jersey, as Donald J. Trump has asserted.
lead_paragraph: The exact origin of Donald J. Trump’s insistence that he saw live television images on Sept. 11, 2001, of “thousands and thousands” of Arabs in New Jersey “cheering” as “the World Trade Center came tumbling down” remains a mystery.

lead_paragraph: How alarmed were New Jersey officials by reports of Muslims dancing in the streets of Jersey City and Paterson on Sept. 11, 2001, to celebrate the destruction of the World Trade Center?

keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Corporations', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Start-ups']
abstract: The shape of the company that used to be called Google is starting to become more apparent. What is not so clear is whether a new kind of Google can operate more effectively than the old.
lead_paragraph: The enduring struggle of life is figuring out how to maximize all the good parts and minimize all the bad. So it is with Alphabet, the technology giant formerly known as Google.

headline: Peace Deal Comes With Hummus at Israeli Restaurant
abstract: The owner of the Hummus Bar is giving half off every hummus plate to tables shared by Jews and Arabs.
lead_paragraph: KFAR VITKIN, Israel — The unassuming proprietor of an unassuming hummus place in this little village near the Mediterranean Sea has a dream: that one day, he will run a chain of restaurants across Israel where the sons of Isaac and the sons of Ishmael will be able to sit together at the table and share hummus. At a steep discount.

headline: Douglass C. North, Maverick Economist and Nobel Laureate, Dies at 95
abstract: In a seven-decade teaching career and in many books and articles, Mr. North became known for challenging traditional market-based methods of economic analysis.
lead_paragraph: Douglass C. North, a Nobel laureate whose work in applying economic theory to history offered a new understanding of how societies coordinate people’s behavior, died on Monday at his home in Benzonia, Mich. He was 95.

Stern Architects, and while there designed, among other things, the feature animation building for the Walt Disney Company in Burbank, Calif.

lead_paragraph: Ruth Teichroeb, the communications officer for Oceans North: Protecting Life in the Arctic, an initiative of the Pew Charitable Trusts, sent a note this evening about new steps related to an issue I’ve covered here before – the rare and welcome proactive work by Arctic nations to ban fishing in the central Arctic Ocean ahead of the “big melt” as summer sea ice retreats more in summers in a human-heated climate.

headline: Terrorism Response Puts Belgium in a Harsh Light
keywords: ['Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Terrorism', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: As Brussels remains locked down for a fourth day, the failure to stop two brothers flagged as extremists before the Paris carnage has highlighted Belgium’s perennial dysfunctions.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — A month before the Paris terrorist attacks, Mayor Françoise Schepmans of Molenbeek, a Brussels district long notorious as a haven for jihadists, received a list with the names and addresses of more than 80 people suspected as Islamic militants living in her area.

headline: Rare White House Accord With Koch Brothers on Sentencing Frays
abstract: The Justice Department balks on the package because one of the bills, supported by Koch Industries, would make it harder to prosecute polluters and white-collar criminals.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For more than a year, a rare coalition of liberal groups and libertarian-minded conservatives has joined the Obama administration in pushing for the most significant liberalization of America’s criminal justice laws since the beginning of the drug war. That effort has had perhaps no ally more important than Koch Industries, the conglomerate owned by a pair of brothers who are well-known conservative billionaires.

headline: U.S. Inquiry Finds Agency Chief Violated Rules
keywords: ['Government Contracts and Procurement', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: A government report found that the Commission for the Preservation of America’s Heritage Abroad, which employed a registered federal lobbyist as its executive director, violated federal rules.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An obscure federal agency that employed a registered federal lobbyist as its executive director, and paid him a salary of more than $100,000 for his part-time work, violated federal contracting rules, according to a report sent to President Obama on Tuesday from the government’s special ethics office.

headline: Charles M. Cawley, Credit Card Pioneer, Dies at 75
abstract: Mr. Cawley’s MBNA Corporation introduced affinity credit cards, which are tied to sports teams, universities, professional associations and other organizations that inspire consumer loyalty.
lead_paragraph: Charles M. Cawley, who founded MBNA Corporation in a supermarket basement, transformed the company into the world’s largest independent credit card issuer, and sold it two decades later to Bank of America for nearly $35 billion, died on Nov. 18 at his home in Camden, Me. He was 75.

headline: France’s Ambassador ‘Knows How to Throw an Elbow’
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations', 'Terrorism', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Gérard Araud is not afraid to speak his mind to support his country, even if that means standing up to Jeb Bush or Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the hours after the terrorist attacks in Paris left 130 dead, Gérard Araud, the French ambassador to the United States, thanked all Americans for their solidarity except for one: Donald Trump, the Republican presidential candidate who pointedly said that the mass shootings had occurred in “one of the toughest gun control countries in the world.”

headline: An Impasse Over Migration Strands Cubans in Costa Rica
abstract: The crisis has drawn attention to a surge in the number of Cubans leaving the island over the past year.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Cuban and Central American officials met in El Salvador on Tuesday but could not agree on how to resolve a standoff over migration policy that has marooned hundreds of Cuban migrants in Costa Rica and tested regional relations.

headline: Montreal’s Message to an American Captain: Bienvenue
abstract: Max Pacioretty, a native of Connecticut, is flourishing in Montreal as the captain of the Canadiens.
lead_paragraph: Montreal’s significant French influence spills over to its beloved Canadiens. Francophone coaches are considered essential, as the team’s bench bosses give interviews in French and English before and after each game.

headline: Jim Perry, 82, Bustling Host of a Range of Game Shows, Dies
abstract: Mr. Perry was a mainstay of a broad range of such shows in the United States and Canada.
lead_paragraph: Jim Perry, the genial host of the popular NBC game shows “Card Sharks” and “$ale of the Century” in the 1970s and ’80s, died on Friday at his home in Ashland, Ore. He was 82.

headline: A Single Mother’s Busy School Days (and Nights)
abstract: Natasha Jackson of the Bronx is a 41-year-old college senior with a daughter, 14, a son, 9, and a job as administrative assistant with a state authority.
lead_paragraph: The alarm on her phone goes off at 5:30 a.m. Natasha Jackson reaches for her glasses. It is Monday morning, and she will be racing the clock a dozen more times before the day is over.

headline: West Virginia: Mistrial Request Refused in Mine Case
abstract: A federal judge refused to declare a mistrial in the case of Donald L. Blankenship, the chief executive of Massey Energy Company when 29 mine workers were killed in 2010.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Tuesday refused to declare a mistrial in the case of Donald L. Blankenship, who was the chief executive of Massey Energy Company when 29 workers were killed in a company mine in 2010. Mr. Blankenship’s lawyer asked for the mistrial ruling after jurors finished their fifth full day of deliberations. But Judge Irene C. Berger of Federal District Court in Charleston said that she did not “have any reason to believe that they are deadlocked” and that extensive deliberations were not surprising after weeks of testimony. Mr. Blankenship is accused of securities fraud and of conspiring to violate mine safety regulations. Deliberations will resume on Monday.

headline: Big Feller
abstract: Duncan Kimmel and Clara Williamson make their New York Times debut.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — In most crossword puzzles, solvers are given a clue and are expected to open their minds to the possibility that there are more things in heaven and earth, Horatio, than are dreamt of in your philosophy. Or at least to guess what kind of pun the constructor is making. Today, we’re doing the opposite.

headline: Canada: Graft Pervaded Awarding of Contracts in Quebec, Panel Says
keywords: ['Building (Construction)', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Government Contracts and Procurement', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: The judge who led the commission said the problem “was broader and more deeply rooted than we believed.”
lead_paragraph: A “culture of impunity” surrounded the awarding of government contracts in Quebec, Justice France Charbonneau of the Quebec Superior Court said Tuesday in a statement before issuing a sweeping report on the ties among contractors, politicians, party fund-raisers, bureaucrats and members of organized crime. Testimony at public hearings held by a commission led by Justice Charbonneau captivated the province and led to several resignations, including that in 2012 of Gérald Tremblay, a Montreal mayor who the commission found “did not adequately fulfill his role of control and monitoring his administration.” Justice Charbonneau said the commission “confirmed there was a real problem in Quebec and that it was broader and more deeply rooted than we believed.” Its report, which is about 1,700 pages long, makes 60 recommendations, including term limits for mayors and the adoption of anticorruption legislation based on an American law, the False Claims Act.

headline: For Readers of The Times, a Preference for Keeping Liberties in Days of Terror

lead_paragraph: As France reacts to the recent terrorist attacks in Paris with a show of force — the police have been breaking down doors to raid homes, conducting searches without warrants and hauling suspects to police stations — the debate over how societies should balance civil liberties and national security takes on even greater relevance.

headline: Who Are the Turkmens of Syria?
abstract: Tensions between Russia and Turkey have increased lately over the downing of a Russian warplane in a Turkmen area near the Syrian border.
lead_paragraph: Turkmens or Turkomans are a Turkic people who live in significant numbers in many countries in Central Asia and the Middle East, including Afghanistan, Iran and Iraq, and are the dominant group in Turkmenistan. They have a culture and language related to Turkish; their name is said to derive from words meaning “Turk-like.”

headline: Canada: Syrians’ Arrival Is Delayed, and Officials Cite Need to Prepare
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)']
abstract: Several cabinet ministers said that only 10,000 of the planned 25,000 refugees would arrive by the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: Canada’s new Liberal government has delayed its plan to bring 25,000 Syrian refugees into the country by the end of the year. At a news conference on Tuesday, several cabinet ministers said that only 10,000 would arrive by the original deadline, with the balance coming by the end of February. “We want to bring them in fast, but we also want to do it right,” said John McCallum, the immigration minister. Mr. McCallum said the delay was not caused by security concerns after the recent attacks in Paris. Rather, he said, it related to preparing housing and services for the refugees, who will become permanent residents upon entry. Government officials said the selection process would favor families, women who are at risk and gay, lesbian bisexual and transgender people. Single men will be admitted only if they fall under the sexual orientation categories or if they travel with their parents. About 36 cities have agreed to accept Syrian refugees who are to be flown to Canada by the military, which will also provide temporary accommodations for about 6,000 people at some of its bases.

headline: Freshman Standout Propels Marquette to a Title
abstract: Henry Ellenson had a team-high 18 points and 11 rebounds in the Legends Classic tournament championship game, an overtime win over Arizona State.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, most of the nation’s top college basketball coaches traveled to tiny Rice Lake, Wis., trying to persuade Henry Ellenson to join their programs. Kentucky’s John Calipari, Duke’s Mike Krzyzewski, North Carolina’s Roy Williams and Michigan State’s Tom Izzo were among those who showed up in the town of 8,000 to woo the 6-foot-10 Ellenson, a forward with guard skills.

headline: The Case Against Woodrow Wilson at Princeton
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Discrimination', 'Names, Organizational', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Government Employees']
abstract: The honor that Princeton bestowed on an unrepentant racist decades ago should be rescinded.
lead_paragraph: Student protesters at Princeton performed a valuable public service last week when they demanded that the administration acknowledge the toxic legacy of Woodrow Wilson, who served as university president and New Jersey governor before being elected to the White House. He was an unapologetic racist whose administration rolled back the gains that African-Americans achieved just after the Civil War, purged black workers from influential jobs and transformed the government into an instrument of white supremacy.

headline: Woodrow Wilson Cost My Grandfather Too
abstract: Readers share stories about how the former President’s racist policies affected their families.
lead_paragraph: Gordon J. Davis’s Nov. 24th Op-Ed, “What Woodrow Wilson Cost My Grandfather,” recounted the story of his grandfather, John Abraham Davis, an African-American man whose prestigious career in the Government Printing Office was destroyed after President Wilson segregated the government in 1913. In recent weeks, students at Princeton — where Woodrow Wilson also served as president — have demanded that his name be removed from university facilities. Below are some highlights from the hundreds of reader comments on the article.

Although he was uncertain how people would respond to the exhibit, he felt that after the Charlie Hebdo attacks in January in Paris that it was important to encourage people to think about Muslims in ways that did not play into stereotypes.

headline: Letter From Saudi Arabia
keywords: ['Social Conditions and Trends', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Social Media']
abstract: A stirring for change is evident during a visit to the kingdom and an evening with the 30-year-old deputy crown prince.
lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — Saudi Arabia is a country that is easier to write about from afar, where you can just tee off on the place as a source of the most austere, antipluralistic version of Islam — the most extreme versions of which have been embraced by the Islamic State, or ISIS. What messes me up is when I go there and meet people I really like and I see intriguing countertrends.

headline: Thanksgiving, With or Without Turkey
keywords: ['Thanksgiving Day', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Families and Family Life', 'Holidays and Special Occasions', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: From the pilgrims to today’s immigrants, the real meaning of this American holiday is family.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — FOUR centuries after the pilgrims, families are still celebrating their successful arrival on North American shores with a big meal at the end of November. But the big roasted turkey doesn’t always have the starring role.

headline: One Jet Closer to a Wider Confrontation
abstract: Turkey’s downing of a Russian fighter jet added new uncertainty to an already complicated Syrian civil war.
lead_paragraph: Turkey’s downing of a Russian fighter jet on Tuesday is just the kind of volatile incident that has been feared since Moscow’s military intervention added new uncertainty to the already complicated Syrian civil war. The attack adds to tensions between Ankara and Moscow, which support different factions in Syria, and threatens to worsen relations between Russia and Turkey’s NATO allies, which have been going downhill since Russia invaded Ukraine.

headline: A Better Way to Screen for Prostate Cancer
abstract: It is time to focus on ways to use the screening test more effectively.
lead_paragraph: With prostate cancer, as with other diseases, there has been a vigorous debate about who should be tested. Screening too many people leads to unnecessary treatment, too few and you miss cancers that could have been stopped. A new study points to what may be a better approach: “screen smarter.”

headline: Paris and the Presidential Election
abstract: If terror remains as high in voters’ consciousness in 2016 as it is now, it is likely to pose a major problem for Democrats.
lead_paragraph: The Paris attacks — as well as developments in Brussels, Egypt and Mali — may have improved Republican prospects in 2016.

headline: A More Conservative Catholic Church Awaits Pope Francis in Africa
keywords: ['Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: As Francis begins his first-ever trip to Africa, he will face a powerful and assertive Roman Catholic Church that is wary of his message of tolerance.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Headlines here call him the “Pope of Hope.” Because of him, Kenyans say they are more enthusiastic about going to church, praying regularly and treating others kindly. They want him to preach about corruption, living in peace and governing fairly.

headline: Mothering My Dying Friend
abstract: When you take care of someone helpless, the constant thrum of doing often drowns out the bigger existential story.
lead_paragraph: In a Venn diagram of tending helpless people at the extremes of life, the circle of caring for a dying person overlaps almost completely with the one for caring for a baby. Both are repetitive, intimate, often gross, sometimes funny, weirdly frantic even as they’re crushingly tedious, and a total act of devotion. In the nonoverlapping part of the end-of-life circle, there’s pain, grief, despair and a dreadful fading. There is movement not forward, toward consciousness, but backward, away from it. And for all of your endless patience there is nothing at the end. Just death, and your only job is a kind of mothering right up to the lip of the abyss.

headline: South Korea Says It’s Working to Halt Refugees’ Return to North

headline: A Year After Phillip Hughes’s Death, Cricket Inches Forward on Safety
abstract: The sport has never seriously considered outlawing the bouncer, even though Phillip Hughes of Australia died after he was struck in the neck by a ball.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 25 last year, the Australian cricketer Phillip Hughes was attempting to win a recall to the test-playing national team. He had reached 63 runs during a domestic match in Sydney, Australia, when he received a short ball aimed near his head. Trying to attack the delivery, Hughes was struck on the top of the neck and, after staggering for a few seconds, he collapsed on the field. Within 48 hours he was pronounced dead, three days before his 26th birthday.

headline: 1940: Britain Expects Aid from U.S.
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Britain expects aid from U.S. in the form of credits, warplanes, ships and munitions in 1940.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Marquess of Lothian, British Ambassador, who said on his return from London Saturday that the British were nearing the end of their cash resources, had long talks with President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull this afternoon [Nov. 25], after which he told reporters that Great Britain expected substantial aid from the United States next year in the form of credits, warplanes, ships and munitions. However, he said the President had made no promises. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 26, 1940

headline: Morning Agenda: Treasury Secretary Warns Foes of Dodd-Frank
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Bitcoin (Currency)', 'Credit Unions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Hedge Funds', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Law and Legislation', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Private Equity', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Venture Capital', 'Vetoes (US)']
abstract: Calpers Reveals Private Equity Fees and Profits | A Season of Silly Deal-Making | Bureacracy Ends Experimental Credit Union
lead_paragraph: TREASURY SECRETARY WARNS FOES OF DODD-FRANK | Last year, Congress passed a measure dismantling a piece of the Dodd-Frank Act that governed swaps by attaching the new legislation to a wider spending bill. On Tuesday, Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew warned critics of Dodd-Frank against trying the same tactic again, saying he would push back against any attempts to weaken financial regulation through amendments to the spending bill, which Congress must pass by Dec. 11 to avert a government shutdown,  Peter Eavis reports in DealBook. “I have publicly made clear that my recommendation to the president would be that if there are legislative measures that will roll back the clock, that would take us back toward where we were before the financial crisis, I would recommend a veto,” Mr. Lew said via email.
