headline: ‘Sleep Apnea’
abstract: Selected by Natasha Trethewey.
lead_paragraph: Often when I read a poem, I encounter an experience I haven’t actually had — the language and imagery evoking a shared emotional response. But reading this poem, I found a vivid depiction of my own actual experience: listening for the breathing of my father, holding my breath like the speaker as I waited.

headline: ‘Orpheus and Apollo,’ Dismantled, May Be Gone for Years, Some Fear Permanently
abstract: The fate of Richard Lippold’s immense, gravity-defying metal sculpture at Lincoln Center, removed in 2014 for cleaning and restoration, remains uncertain.
lead_paragraph: Will Orpheus return from the underworld this time? Will Apollo ever glitter again in sunlight? Is it possible that one of the largest works of public art in New York — a five-ton, 190-foot-long, 39-foot-high sculpture — could disappear with few people noticing?

headline: The 11.15.15 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: RE: THE FUTURE

headline: How to Navigate By the Stars
abstract: Find your north. Go out between 2 a.m. and 5 a.m.
lead_paragraph: ‘‘Use the stars to find the four cardinal directions,’’ says Chadd Onohi Paishon, a master navigator with the Polynesian Voyaging Society who steers double-hulled canoes from Hawaii to Tahiti and beyond without any instruments or charts. Paishon doesn’t know how to use a GPS device or a magnetic compass, but he can orient himself on land or sea with a glance at the heavens. Determine north by finding the North Star, which does not set when you’re north of the Equator. As seafarers have done for millenniums, you can determine about how many miles north of the Equator you are by measuring the distance between the North Star and the horizon. To do this, stretch out your arm. For most, one fist equals approximately 10 degrees; latitudinal degrees each represent about 69 miles. The farther north you go, the higher the star looks in the sky. South of the Equator, you won’t see the North Star but must rely on a constellation called the Southern Cross to help you find south.

headline: Should My Rich Friends Apply for Financial Aid?
keywords: ['Ethicists, The (Times Column)', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'Workplace Environment', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Beauty Salons', 'Nails (Body Part)', 'Tips and Tipping', 'Privacy', 'Ethics (Personal)']
abstract: The ethicist weighs in on a wealthy family’s request for help with tuition, a parent’s proud oversharing, a conflicted manicure enthusiast and more.
lead_paragraph: Close friends of mine are raising four young children in a city with an extremely high cost of living. Not a small feat. They are not millionaires, but they are not poor either. Because of the school zone in which they live, they prefer to send their children to a private school, where tuition is upward of $27,000 per year per child. They made the situation work when only two children were of school age, but in the next academic year, there will be three children enrolled, and four not long after.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on the Elaborate Handshake
abstract: You can take the friend out of Emporia, but you can’t take the Emporia out of the friend.
lead_paragraph: Joe writes: My friend insists that we high-five and then snap our fingers when saying goodbye, as he did with his friends back in Emporia, Kan. He’s so pushy that I now refuse to high-­five. I instead offer a fist bump or a choice ‘‘Cool Runnings’’ quote. I’ve never seen anyone sadder to get a fist bump.

headline: Watch Lynsey Addario Discuss ‘The Displaced’ With Cate Blanchett
abstract: A Women in the World conversation about the global refugee crisis.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks since New York Times Magazine readers had the opportunity to experience the magazine’s “The Displaced” virtual-reality film with Google Cardboard V.R. viewers delivered to subscribers, the film has been shown around the world. Before a screening in New Delhi on Friday, Women in the World, a live-event series associated with The Times, hosted a discussion on the global refugee and migrant crisis moderated by the actress Cate Blanchett and featuring the photojournalist and frequent Times Magazine contributor Lynsey Addario among its guests.

headline: Drinking Food
abstract: Learning the art of curing eggs from a Japanese bartender.
lead_paragraph: Yusuke Shimoki runs Engawa, a tiny bar in Kaga, in the Ishikawa Prefecture of Japan, on the mountainous north-central coast, near the Sea of Japan. When he recently came to America for a visit, he packed bottles of local sake into his luggage. He also brought six styles of glassware to serve it in, as well as a bottle of his favorite soy sauce and, for no particular reason other than he is proud of it, a framed certificate naming him a qualified sake sommelier in Japan. There was little room for clothes.

headline: Edmund de Waal and the Strange Alchemy of Porcelain
abstract: The sculptor and writer wants us to rediscover our sense of touch by working with our hands.
lead_paragraph: Within a few minutes of my meeting Edmund de Waal, he was putting things in my hands. He handed me, for instance, a 1,000-year-old Chinese porcelain plate — the kind of object you would expect to see in a climate-controlled glass case in a museum, protected, at great expense, from clumsy, meaty, oily, inexpert hands like mine. De Waal just passed it to me as if it were nothing. To understand an object, he believes, you have to touch it.

headline: Poll Shows Hillary Clinton Wins Iowans’ Heads, but Not Hearts
abstract: More than four out of five Iowa Democrats think Hillary Rodham Clinton can win the general election compared to only half who think the same of Senator Bernie Sanders, according to a Quinnipiac University poll released Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: More than four out of five Iowa Democrats think Hillary Rodham Clinton can win the general election, compared with only half who think the same of Senator Bernie Sanders.

headline: Koch Brothers Woo Hispanic Voters With Turkeys and Questionnaires
abstract: Tapping some Democratic strategies, the Libre Initiative seeks to win over Hispanics by promoting economic freedom and smaller-government principles.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The crowd that lined up around a megachurch here last week — largely Hispanic and mostly poor — came for the Saturday services, but also for the free flu shots that were being offered in the church, and for the Thanksgiving turkeys being given away just outside.

headline: Looking for a Break From the Campaign? Stay Away From the TV
abstract: Presidential campaigns and the groups supporting them have booked almost $5 million in advertising time during Thanksgiving week in Iowa, New Hampshire, Nevada and South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: For residents of the four early voting states seeking respite this holiday weekend from the political rantings of a charged relative, the traditional comfort of television might not provide much of an escape.

headline: Silicon Valley Is Growing Up, Giving Parents a Break
abstract: Mark Zuckerberg’s decision to take two months of parental leave is a sign of a shifting culture.
lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley is beginning to admit it isn’t just for young people anymore.

keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Military Aircraft', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Tatars (Ethnic Group)']
abstract: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan had nuanced reasons to allow Turkish pilots to open fire, analysts say, including his irritation with Russia over issues beyond Syria.
lead_paragraph: ANKARA, Turkey — Turkey and Russia promised on Wednesday not to go to war over the downing of a Russian military jet, leaving Turkey’s still-nervous NATO allies and just about everyone else wondering why the country decided to risk such a serious confrontation.

headline: Small Shops Take Pride in Turning Their Backs on Black Friday

abstract: Some independent retailers are choosing closed doors over doorbusters and even forgoing all holiday discounts, saying that doing so makes smart business sense.
lead_paragraph: On Black Friday, as hordes of people begin their holiday shopping rites, Nan Morningstar will keep the door closed at Free Radicals, the clothing and costume boutique she and her husband own in Albuquerque.

headline: Francine Prose’s Food Crawl Down Sunset Boulevard
abstract: Along one of the most famous streets in Southern California, there are stars on the menus as well.
lead_paragraph: For many people, especially those who don’t live in and around Los Angeles, the idea of Sunset Boulevard conjures up the iconic Billy Wilder film of that name, or the fictional nightclub at 77 Sunset Strip, where one of the most popular TV series of the early 1960s was set, or images of historic Hollywood landmarks: the Chateau Marmont hotel, whose poolside bar is prime territory for movie-star sighting, and where several recent films (Sofia Coppola’s “Somewhere” and David Cronenberg’s “Maps to the Stars”) were shot; the Laugh Factory, where some of the country’s greatest comedians, from Richard Pryor and Jerry Seinfeld to Robin Williams and Eddie Murphy, have performed. But for Los Angeles residents, those two words — Sunset Boulevard — are more likely to seem like shorthand for their shared obsession: traffic.

headline: Where to Shop in Rome’s Campo Marzio
abstract: In a neighborhood in Rome’s historic center, locals come to hit the collection of clothing and lifestyle boutiques featuring goods produced in Italy.
lead_paragraph: In a neighborhood in Rome’s historic center, locals come to hit the collection of clothing and lifestyle boutiques featuring goods produced in Italy.

headline: 1965: Mobutu Seizes Power in Coup
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Mobutu seizes power in a bloodless coup in the Congo in 1965.
lead_paragraph: LEOPOLDVILLE — In a bloodless, almost troopless coup, Gen. Joseph Mobutu seized power in the Congo today [Nov. 25]. He dismissed President Joseph Kasavubu, named himself head of state for five years and asked Col. Leonard Mulamba to form a broadly based government. The coup was prompted by a political deadlock that had threatened to open a new chapter of violence in the Congo. It also was seen as an attempt to close an opening to the left within the Kasavubu government. The 35-year-old general said his move was not designed to impose a military dictatorship. He said he had acted ‘‘to save the nation, to put a definite end to chaos and anarchy.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 26, 1965

lead_paragraph: Stedman Bailey, a receiver for the St. Louis Rams, was hospitalized after he was shot in Florida on Tuesday evening, the police said.

lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The Indian Army killed three militants in the Kashmir region on Wednesday in an hourslong gun battle at an army base close to the highly militarized border with Pakistan.

headline: The Eternal Drama of the Red Lip
abstract: Perfectly matte crimson lips are more than just alluring. They’re an event.
lead_paragraph: In May 1969, Claes Oldenburg and a group of students, faculty and alumni mounted a towering tube of red lipstick on a tank on the grounds of Yale University. ‘‘Lipstick (Ascending) on Caterpillar Tracks’’ was a protest against the Vietnam War and a joke about American consumer culture — as well as an advance guard for Yale College’s first female students, who arrived on campus the next semester. Most women weren’t wearing heavy makeup in 1969, but Oldenburg wasn’t aiming for social realism. Red lipstick is symbolic of symbols. It’s what you put on when you want to make a statement.

headline: Anonymous Hackers Fight ISIS but Reactions Are Mixed
abstract: Wholesale efforts to block Twitter activity sometimes sweep up journalists and others who track the terror group.
lead_paragraph: People from various hacking collectives have tried for several months to block social media accounts that spread propaganda and attempt to recruit fighters for the Islamic State, but those campaigns gained a new energy on Twitter after the Paris attacks.

headline: World Press Photo Introduces New Ethics Guidelines for Contest
abstract: After two years of controversy over images submitted to the World Press Photo contest, the organization has announced major changes to the competition’s rules.
lead_paragraph: The World Press Photo Foundation on Wednesday announced major changes to its photo contest for 2016, including a code of ethics for entrants and detailed guidelines regarding digital manipulation of images. The new rules also include an independent fact-checking process for the captions of winning photos and a 36-hour period for entrants whose images may have been unduly altered to explain their process.

lead_paragraph: An experiment in the Maya Biosphere Reserve is testing whether the most effective way to protect forests is to give control of them to those who already live there.

keywords: ['Forests and Forestry', 'Land Use Policies', 'Logging Industry', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Carbon Dioxide']
abstract: Ranchers, loggers and smugglers all threaten tropical forests, but in areas given to local communities, the deforestation rate is close to zero, a study finds.
lead_paragraph: UAXACTÚN, Guatemala — Deep in the jungle, where the forest canopy bends sunlight into a lattice of overlapping greens, where jaguars glide and the throaty cries of howler monkeys resound over the bird song, sits a sawmill that slices giant mahogany logs.

headline: LoftOpera Takes on Britten’s ‘Rape of Lucretia’
abstract: Laine Rettmer directs this chamber opera at 501 Union, a former auto restoration shop in Gowanus, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: In just a few seasons, LoftOpera — an innovative company that stages full operas and excerpts in unusual spaces like a former warehouse in Bushwick, Brooklyn — has impressed with the caliber of its stylish ventures. For its new multimedia staging of Britten’s unsettling chamber opera “Rape of Lucretia,” the company returns to 501 Union, a former car restoration shop in Gowanus, Brooklyn.

headline: Tere O’Connor Thinks Big With ‘The Goodbye Studies’
abstract: With his new work, Mr. O’Connor turns away from individualism to focus on the power of the crowd.
lead_paragraph: For one semester a year, Tere O’Connor trades New York City for the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign, where he is a professor of dance. The good part is that he always returns, ready to start a new work, and this season it’s a doozy in sheer numbers alone.

headline: Bill Murray in ‘A Very Murray Christmas’ Full of Stars
abstract: A search-friendly Netflix show with Paul Shaffer, Rashida Jones, Amy Poehler, Michael Cera, Maya Rudolph, Chris Rock, George Clooney and Miley Cyrus.
lead_paragraph: Take Nick the Lounge Singer and mix with Bing Crosby, add an uptown hotel, two shots of bubbly, a scoop of cheer and a sprinkle of hipster cred. Shake, pour and — faster than you can say “Scrooged” — it’s “A Very Murray Christmas,” streaming Friday, Dec. 4, on Netflix and starring Bill Murray as a singer whose Christmas Eve cabaret act at the Carlyle Hotel goes bust when New York is shut down by the blizzard of the century. So he improvises, with the help of his pianist sidekick, Paul Shaffer, as well as Rashida Jones, Amy Poehler, Michael Cera, Jason Schwartzman, Maya Rudolph, Chris Rock, Jenny Lewis, David Johansen and the band Phoenix, as guests and staff. It’s all a little boozy, a little woozy, as if your coolest, most vocally gifted friends were transported into a Sofia Coppola flick. Which it is.

headline: ‘Pop,’ Robert Smithson’s Playful Drawings Inspired by New York Detritus
abstract: James Cohan’s inaugural show in his new space on the Lower East Side focuses on works on paper and sculpture dating from 1963 to 1965.
lead_paragraph: It makes sense that James Cohan is opening his Lower East Side gallery with a show devoted to Robert Smithson. Titled “Pop,” it features works on paper and sculpture dating from 1963 to 1965, when the artist was in his 20s. Though far better known for his Earthworks of the late 1960s and early 70s, like “Spiral Jetty,” Smithson was prolific on paper.

headline: Kelela Continues the Swagger of ’90s R&B on ‘Hallucinogen’
abstract: The artist, who also nods to the experimental urges of the contemporary dance music underground, plays the Music Hall of Williamsburg.
lead_paragraph: In 2013 Kelela released “Cut 4 Me,” her debut mixtape full of narcotic R&B, and one of the jumping-off points for a new wave of genre reimagination.

headline: ‘Anomalisa,’ a Stop-Motion Feature at MoMA
abstract: Dino Stamatopoulos and both the fellow “Moral Orel” alumnus Duke Johnson and Charlie Kaufman meld melancholy and wonder into this animated world.
lead_paragraph: Between 2005 and 2008, Cartoon Network’s late-night programming block Adult Swim ran “Moral Orel,” a hilariously stinging and subversive stop-motion series created by Dino Stamatopoulos. “Moral Orel” — a lampoon of 1960s and ’70s inspirational children’s fare like Art Clokey’s “Davey and Goliath” — avoided glib messages of uplift in its tales of a Midwestern boy whose religious faith remains steadfast despite the shortcomings of adults around him.

abstract: The holiday through the years with presidents, their families, carving knives and turkeys (some survived).
lead_paragraph: The holiday through the years with presidents, their families, carving knives and turkeys (some survived).

headline: Daily Report: Turkey, Travel and Technology
abstract: Traveling during the holiday can be difficult, let’s be thankful for a minute — for the intersection of technology and travel.
lead_paragraph: Nothing says Thanksgiving like overcrowded airports and traffic jams. But given the holiday, let’s be thankful for a minute — for the intersection of technology and travel.

headline: Giving Thanks for a Proper ‘Got Your Nose’ Bit
abstract: How to distract children on the verge of holiday meltdowns by combining the threat of facial disfigurement with the giggles of survival, in 11 easy steps.
lead_paragraph: My own father never took my nose. He is a member of the Greatest Generation, which perhaps had bigger concerns (hellooo…Nazis!). From an early age, at holiday gatherings, when I saw my cousins and friends get their noses taken by their fathers, I never understood what was going on. It seemed horrific, but the kids always laughed in the end. I missed out, and today I can only think it was due to the fact that thrusting a fist in my face with a “thumb-that-seems-to-be-a-nose” sticking out between two fingers and then taunting me about it until I laughed at the incredulousness of it all possibly hit too close to home for him. War, you know.

headline: Q. and A.: Holly Holm and the Thrill of the Fight
abstract: Holm, Ultimate Fighting Championship’s new bantamweight champion, discusses her upset of “unbeatable” Ronda Rousey and what it feels like to drop somebody in the ring.
lead_paragraph: It does not take much to go from mostly unknown athlete to the talk of the sports world. All it takes is dominating and then knocking out a fighter generally considered to be unbeatable.

headline: City Chefs Gone Country

lead_paragraph: Four New York City chefs who have taken their Brooklyn-style farm-to-table cuisine upstate — giving weekend travelers yet another reason to get out of town.

headline: Becoming Modern: The Met’s Mission at the Breuer Building
abstract: Sheena Wagstaff, the Met’s curator of Modern and contemporary art, brings a global vision to the first exhibition at the Met Breuer.
lead_paragraph: It is probably revealing that Sheena Wagstaff, who was brought to the Metropolitan Museum of Art to ramp up its presence in contemporary art, is about to make her debut at the museum’s new Breuer building with an exhibition of an artist who has been dead for more than 20 years. Nasreen Mohamedi  is a beloved if little-known modernist who is sometimes called the Indian Agnes Martin, a reference to her penchant for pristine grids.

headline: U.S. General Says Kunduz Hospital Strike Was ‘Avoidable’
keywords: ['Hospitals', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Several service members have been suspended after an internal military investigation of the American airstrike on a Doctors Without Borders facility in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The top American commander in Afghanistan, Gen. John F. Campbell, said Wednesday that several service members had been suspended from duty after an internal military investigation of the American airstrike on a Doctors Without Borders hospital in Kunduz last month.

headline: At Bluestockings, a Manhattan Activist Center, Radical Is Sensible
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Books and Literature', 'Gender']
abstract: Bluestockings, a bookshop and activist center on the Lower East Side, has become a kind of clearinghouse for tolerance and anarchist ideas.
lead_paragraph: “Are we anarchist?” Senia Hardwick asked. “Technically, yes.” Mx. Hardwick, 27, who prefers not to be assigned a gender — and also insists on the gender-neutral Mx. in place of Ms. or Mr. — is a staff member at Bluestockings, a bookshop and activist center at 172 Allen Street on the Lower East Side. Mx. Hardwick was explaining that the ethos of Bluestockings, which is run by a collective of volunteers, is difficult to classify. But if you must: “Anarchist is O.K.”

headline: Q & A with Austin Meyer, 2015 Win-a-Trip Winner
abstract: Austin Meyer traveled to Baltimore, India and Nepal with Nick Kristof. Here’s his advice for 2016 applicants and thoughts on the trips.
lead_paragraph: Austin Meyer was Nicholas Kristof’s 2015 win-a-trip winner, and he traveled first to Baltimore, where he wrote about heroin use, and later to rural India and Nepal, where he wrote about malnutrition and cataract surgery. For students applying this year, and those curious about what it’s like to travel with Nick, Austin has answers. (Speaking of which, if you’re a student with a U.S. passport studying at a U.S. university and want to apply for his 2016 trip, here are the details.)

lead_paragraph: LONDON — “Sectarianism failed,” Bahrain’s foreign minister, Sheikh Khalid bin Ahmed al-Khalifa, told a news conference attended by Secretary of State John Kerry in Washington last week. It had not gained “a foothold in our country,” he went on, “but we will continue to be on our toes facing it.”

headline: 2 Valeant Dermatology Drugs Lead Steep Price Increases, Study Finds
abstract: The study found that prices for 19 brand-name dermatology drugs increased about 400 percent in the last six years, but two of Valeant’s increases were the biggest.
lead_paragraph: Two drugs sold by Valeant Pharmaceuticals International to treat cancer-related skin conditions increased in price by about 1,700 percent over the last six years, according to a newly published survey that found big increases in the cost of dermatology drugs across the board.

headline: Ousted Founder of Men’s Wearhouse Watches His Old Company Struggle
keywords: ['Hedge Funds', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Two years ago, George Zimmer was pushed out of the company closely associated with his face. Now its stock is suffering, while he has started two online businesses.
lead_paragraph: When George Zimmer, founder and public face of the retail chain Men’s Wearhouse — “You’re going to like the way you look. I guarantee it.” — was fired two years ago by his handpicked board, there was no sugarcoating the message.

headline: Gardening Start-Up in China Chances Upon U.S. Marijuana Market
abstract: Lennon Tsai started a company to supply urban Chinese farmers with all the necessary hydroponics equipment, but he found a surprising secondary market in America.
lead_paragraph: In China, concerns about food safety are so serious that residents at times take to the green spaces between tenements to plant gardens. Others farm on windowsills and balconies, or use specialized e-commerce services to track down safe vegetables and meats.

headline: At the Movies With François and Hitch
abstract: A new documentary, “Hitchcock/Truffaut,” recalls a seminal conversation about the art, science and craft of filmmaking and the impact it had.
lead_paragraph: Culled from six days of interviews that the French director François Truffaut conducted with his idol Alfred Hitchcock, the book “Hitchcock” immediately stood out from other books about movies when it was published in an English translation in 1967.

headline: Putin Criticizes Turkish Leaders
abstract: A day after Turkey shot down one of Moscow’s jets, Russian president Vladimir V. Putin said Turkey’s political leaders had been "supporting the Islamization of their country."
lead_paragraph: A day after Turkey shot down one of Moscow’s jets, Russian president Vladimir V. Putin said Turkey’s political leaders had been "supporting the Islamization of their country."

headline: Miguel Gomes Blends Fantasy and Real Life ‘Arabian Nights’
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'New York Film Festival']
abstract: The director’s latest effort is a suite of three feature-length volumes mixing magic realism and social reportage.
lead_paragraph: Many current filmmakers make hybrid films or so-called documentary fictions, but the Portuguese director Miguel Gomes may be the most baroque in dreaming up new ways to combine the factual and the fantastic. One attribute of his cinema is its denial of categories. Another is the degree of self-reflexivity: to watch his films to think about how they were made.

headline: Which Is More Ludicrous? Donald Trump Edition
keywords: ['Golf', 'Heraldry', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In this game, we try to figure out which act by a presidential candidate is more ridiculous. And nobody wins.
lead_paragraph: In this campaign season, when so much of what Republican presidential candidates say is made up, I thought it would be fun to play a game: “Which Is More Ludicrous?”

headline: Making the Crossing to Lesbos
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Under Europe’s system of open internal borders, this thinly patrolled, easily accessible coastline might as well be the frontier of France or Germany or Sweden.
lead_paragraph: Under Europe’s system of open internal borders, this thinly patrolled, easily accessible coastline might as well be the frontier of France or Germany or Sweden.

headline: Regulating Flow of Refugees Gains Urgency in Greece and Rest of Europe
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)']
abstract: Efforts to create centers to better process migrants heading to Europe have come into the spotlight after the terrorist attacks in Paris this month.
lead_paragraph: MYTILENE, Greece — On a recent day here on the Greek island of Lesbos, hundreds of asylum seekers squatted on ragged hillsides or rested in a warren of tentlike structures, clothes drying on leafless trees, as they waited to be registered and sent by ferry to the European mainland.

headline: Black Friday Deal or Dud? How to Shop Smart This Holiday Season
keywords: ['Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'E-Commerce', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Only a small fraction of Black Friday discounts are true bargains, according to the editor of The Wirecutter, a product recommendation site. But there’s a way to check which purchases are worthwhile.
lead_paragraph: Before lining up at a retail store or firing up your computer for Black Friday bargains this week, ask yourself one question: Have you ever scored a great deal from the annual post-Thanksgiving shopping bonanza?

Retailers are promoting them heavily online and on catalog covers, and they are an increasingly common sight on city streets across America. But in many places — from New York State to individual schools, malls and stores — they are illegal.

She was at a Hästens showroom in the Flatiron district, lounging on a mattress covered in a tasteful checked throw that clashed apologetically with her bright pink puffer jacket and flowered socks. “There’s nothing like expensive,” she sighed. “Makes you want to sink right in.”

But his work at an orphanage there and its life-changing aspects have become the basis for “Invisible Thread,” a musical he wrote with his partner, Matt Gould, coming to Second Stage Theater.

headline: How Allergan Deal Will Rebuild Pfizer’s War Chest
abstract: An offshore tax address means there’s no reason to keep over $60 billion of cash on its balance sheet. That’s a lot of financial firepower to buy back shares and fuel more acquisitions.
lead_paragraph: It sounds counterintuitive, but Pfizer’s $152 billion takeover of Allergan will rebuild the acquisitive drug giant’s war chest to do even more deals. Because it was structured as a merger, allowing it to flip its tax liabilities overseas, most of what Pfizer is paying comes in the form of stock. That means the pharma mega-beast will be flush with cash and eager to put it to work.

headline: With TV Proposal, Ahmad Rashad Married Sport and Pop Culture
abstract: Few wedding proposals captured the zeitgeist like the one between Rashad, the broadcaster, and the “Cosby Show” mom Phylicia Ayers-Allen on a Thanksgiving Day game broadcast in 1985.
lead_paragraph: In the Henry Wadsworth Longfellow poem “The Courtship of Miles Standish,” the titular Pilgrim proposes to the lovely Priscilla Mullins by proxy — his roommate, John Alden, does it for him. Thirty Thanksgivings ago, on Nov. 28, 1985, the sportscaster Ahmad Rashad performed a similar ritual, asking for his intended’s hand through an intermediary on live television, before an estimated 40 million viewers.

headline: Black Friday Falters as Consumer Behaviors Change
abstract: The decline in impact of the day after Thanksgiving suggests a shift in the way consumers spend. They’re going online more, and buying furnishings instead of sweaters.
lead_paragraph: In 1939, the nation’s largest retailers sent Franklin D. Roosevelt an urgent plea. Thanksgiving fell on the last day of November that year, giving merchants too few days before Christmas to unleash the season’s sales.

headline: ‘Workshops of Empire,’ by Eric Bennett
abstract: A look at the graduate writing programs that enshrined a literature of American values.
lead_paragraph: Less than a lifetime ago, reputable American writers would occasionally start fistfights, sleep in ditches and even espouse Communist doctrines. Such were the prerogatives and exigencies of the artist’s existence, until M.F.A. programs arrived to impose discipline and provide livelihoods. Whether the professionalization of creative writing has been good for American literature has set off a lot of elegantly worded soul-searching and well-mannered debate recently, much of it in response to Mark McGurl’s seminal study, “The Program Era.” What Eric ­Bennett’s “Workshops of Empire” contributes is an understanding of how Cold War politics helped to create the aesthetic standards that continue to rule over writing workshops today.

headline: ‘I’m Frightened’: After Attacks in Paris, New York Muslims Cope With a Backlash

But increasingly, enterprising fans, filmmakers and archivists are bringing little-known talents to light. The folk musician Rodriguez became a sensation following “Searching for Sugar Man,” the Oscar-winning documentary exploring his disappearance. The singer Vashti Bunyan released one album in 1970, returning in 2005 after she was discovered by a new school of “freak folk” performers.

headline: ‘The Big Green Tent,’ by Ludmila Ulitskaya
abstract: Three friends drawn into the dissident movement use art and activism to oppose the Soviet regime.
lead_paragraph: Ludmila Ulitskaya’s latest novel, “The Big Green Tent,” is as grand, solid and impressively all-encompassing as its title implies. Yet the fact that it covers the Soviet dissident movement with such force shouldn’t be surprising. After all, Ulitskaya has an intimate knowledge of the subject. One of 21st-century Russia’s most prominent writers, she was among the dissidents of the Soviet era and she opposes Vladimir Putin now.

lead_paragraph: A THOUSAND MILES TO FREEDOMMy Escape From North KoreaBy Eunsun Kim with Sébastien FallettiTranslated by David Tian228 pp. St. Martin’s, $24.99.

headline: Margaret Atwood: By the Book
abstract: The author, most recently, of “The Heart Goes Last” met Günter Grass at a Cold War literary festival in Finland: “He thought I was either the secretary or the floozy, I’m not sure which.”
lead_paragraph: The author, most recently, of “The Heart Goes Last” met Günter Grass at a Cold War literary festival in Finland: “He thought I was either the secretary or the floozy, I’m not sure which.”

headline: ‘India at War,’ by Yasmin Khan
abstract: India contributed a huge, though badly treated, army to the Allied cause in World War II.
lead_paragraph: In October and November 1962, India and China fought a brief war in the high Himalayas. That conflict is still a large part of the Indian consciousness, with dozens of scholarly works and popular accounts being written about it. It is seen as a moment of humiliation, both personal and national, when Jawaharlal Nehru lost his credibility as prime minister and India lost the leadership of Asia to its archrival, China.

headline: Kevin Barry’s ‘Beatlebone’
abstract: A novel centered on an island actually owned by a Beatle is fashioned on what we know and think we know about him.
lead_paragraph: Some of the very best fiction is spun from a single filament of fact woven ­tightly — or loosely, if necessary — in and out of an asymmetrical framework of empathy, imagination and sheer audacity. Michael Ondaatje’s “Coming Through Slaughter” (about the early jazz trumpeter Buddy Bolden) and Nick Tosches’ “In the Hand of Dante” (about, among other things, the writing of “The Divine Comedy”) come to mind, both masterly literary extrapolations.

headline: John Irving’s ‘Avenue of Mysteries’
abstract: Irving’s latest novel chronicles the rise of a child genius from a trash heap in Mexico to literary stardom.
lead_paragraph: As the author of 14 novels, John Irving flaunts his obsessions: fatherless children, clergymen, prostitutes, circuses and, of course, writers. Alongside these fascinations is the one that haunts us all: the personal past that surrounds us “like faces in a crowd.”

headline: ‘The Evolution of Everything,’ by Matt Ridley
abstract: Ridley argues that the emergence of big ideas has little to do with top-down direction.
lead_paragraph: What are we to make of the following ­developments?

headline: Mary Gaitskill’s ‘The Mare’
abstract: An emotionally electric triangle of a woman, a girl and a horse is mutually transformative.
lead_paragraph: Desire and damage have long intertwined, an inseparable couple, in the work of Mary Gaitskill. With her first collection of stories in 1988, “Bad Behavior,” Gaitskill staked out her territory: love, or something, among the ruins — the ruins of self, the ruins of hope, the ruins created by cruelty, both literal and psychological. In Gaitskill’s work, people hurt one another for fun, for spite, inadvertently, because they can, and (as she titled a later collection) because they wanted to. In one of Gaitskill’s most famous stories, “Secretary,” which later became a film of the same name, an alienated young woman is sexually used by her boss, but finds the encounter has an array of effects. She is simultaneously dissociated, disgusted, turned on, depressed, oddly loyal to the boss and somehow liberated. It is not right, and it also awakens something vital in her. Gaitskill’s story doesn’t prioritize one emotion over any others or draw any moral conclusions. As she wrote in a 1994 Harper’s essay, “On Not Being a Victim,” “pain can be an experience that defies codification.” In that story, as in much of Gaitskill’s work, the heroine’s ability to remain aware of all uncodifiable experience, to turn it over and examine it, is how she stays alive.

abstract: Tunisian authorities, who have declared a state of emergency, also temporarily closed the border with Libya after an attack in the capital on Tuesday.

headline: Review: In Carly Simon’s Memoir, Few Secrets Left Untold
abstract: “Boys in the Trees” ends in the 1980s, after Ms. Simon divorced James Taylor, but covers her upbringing, the early stages of her singing career and her romances.
lead_paragraph: Carly Simon would like to correct the notion that she is any kind of bourgeois princess, even if one of the first things she did after marrying in 1972 was to change her Bloomingdale’s charge card to read “Mrs. James Taylor.” Her upbringing as a privileged daughter of Richard L. Simon, a founder of Simon & Schuster, used to be held against her. In her bohemian days — that is, when she wore bohemian clothes — it may even have hurt her professionally. Albert Grossman, the manager whose clients included Bob Dylan, called her “a nine out of a perfect 10,” docked one point because of her prosperous background. It’s rare for managers to take offense at money.

headline: On ‘Dark Sky Island,’ Enya Doesn’t Stray Far From Continuity and Comfort
abstract: On the latest album by the Irish singer, themes of loss and separation rear up at times, but her signature overdubbed vocals remain largely unchanged.
lead_paragraph: “Dark Sky Island”

headline: Britain’s Treasury Chief Drops Plan to Cut Welfare
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: The move by George Osborne, chancellor of the Exchequer, was a significant tactical retreat, in the face of political opposition, in his drive to shrink the British state and balance its budget.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — George Osborne, the British chancellor of the Exchequer, abandoned a plan on Wednesday to cut welfare benefits, making a significant tactical retreat in his drive to shrink the British state and balance its budget.

headline: Classical Playlist: Beethoven, Handel and Bach
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: BEETHOVEN: Symphonies No. 5 and 7Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra; Manfred Honeck, conductor(Reference Recordings)Ninety seconds is all it takes to understand that Manfred Honeck’s is no sanitized Beethoven: the plethora of colorations, articulations and moods through which he forces the Fifth’s famous motto sees to that. Every phrase, every balance has been thought through in interventionist readings that are idiosyncratic but fully attuned to the spirit, if not the letter, of the scores. Despite superb playing and audio quality, Beethoven so Romantic won’t convince everybody. Still, this partnership seems incapable of laying down an ordinary recording. (David Allen)

headline: Review: New Books by Anna Gavalda, Daniel Sada, George Singleton and Others
abstract: In Ms. Gavalda’s book, a woman obsesses about an unkempt man; Mr. Sada writes about twins who delight in confusing people; and Mr. Singleton conjures a backwater town with distinct characters.
lead_paragraph: By George Singleton

lead_paragraph: One of the final cooperating witnesses in the federal government’s long-running investigation into insider trading at SAC Capital Advisors is soon to be sentenced.

headline: No, the Tryptophan in Turkey Won’t Make You Sleepy
abstract: A common myth suggests that the tryptophan in turkey will make you drowsy, but that’s not why you might be ready for bed after Thanksgiving dinner.
lead_paragraph: As the common myth goes, you’re ready for bed soon after Thanksgiving dinner because the turkey you eat is loaded with tryptophan, which makes you drowsy and drags you into slumber.

lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — An American drone strike on Wednesday killed a senior commander of the Pakistani Taliban in Afghanistan, near the border with the North Waziristan region of Pakistan, according to Pakistani intelligence officials in the tribal belt.

lead_paragraph: Sound from the play.

headline: Judge Hears Arguments on Fantasy Sports
abstract: At issue is whether daily fantasy sports contests are games of skill, or games of chance — and therefore run afoul of New York State gambling laws.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers from FanDuel and DraftKings appeared in New York State Supreme Court on Wednesday to fight efforts by the New York State attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, to bar state residents from playing daily fantasy sports contests on the companies’ websites.

headline: Review: Music on the Edge Makes Its New York Debut
abstract: This contemporary chamber ensemble brought unpredictability to its concert at SubCulture.
lead_paragraph: “Are you still working on that?” It’s a line that’s instantly familiar, a refrain chanted out by harried, underpaid restaurant servers. There’s a ritual to eating out, and a liturgy that goes with it, meant to move the diner from hunger to satisfaction (or not) and out of the door.

headline: ‘Friday Night Lights’ Spoof Musical Planned in Los Angeles
abstract: “Friday Night Lights” will be turned into a musical starring Scott Porter, who starred on the television show.
lead_paragraph: There was the book, then the movie, then the television show, and now … the musical? An unauthorized stage adaptation of “Friday Night Lights” is in the works, according to Variety. The Los Angeles project, slated for 2016, will star Scott Porter, who played Jason Street in the television show, and be produced by Lindsey Rosin and Jordan Ross, producers behind musical spoofs of “Cruel Intentions” and “The O.C.”

headline: Review: Arca Keeps Moving With ‘Mutant’
abstract: The second full-length album from the Venezuelan electronic-music producer comes from a wordless, abstract, deep-inside-the-head place.
lead_paragraph: “Mutant”

headline: Review: With ‘Silver,’ Fourplay Celebrates 25 Years of Smooth Jazz Stylings
abstract: The group, which first took shape in 1990, adheres to form on its new album, a sleek but relaxed collection that highlights the band’s strengths as a rhythm section.
lead_paragraph: “Silver”

headline: Review: Juilliard Orchestra, Grabbing the ‘Ring’ Cycle
abstract: Alan Gilbert of the New York Philharmonic showed off the fruits of his other job, teaching at Juilliard, with a concert of Schumann, Berg and Wagner.
lead_paragraph: You might think that being the music director of a major orchestra provides sufficient challenges and opportunities for any conductor. Yet for many, one such post is not enough. Not long after Andris Nelsons finished his first season as music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra earlier this year, he was also appointed to the Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra in Germany.

headline: This Thanksgiving, Let’s Talk About Science
keywords: ['Thanksgiving Day', 'Science and Technology', 'Families and Family Life']

lead_paragraph: Six conversation starters from the fields of science and medicine that we hope will keep your family Thanksgiving gathering more fun than fraught.

headline: Black Pastors Expected to Endorse Donald Trump
abstract: Donald J. Trump will take the next step in his religious outreach effort next week when he announces the endorsement of a group of 100 African-American pastors and religious leaders at his Manhattan headquarters.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump will take the next step in his religious outreach effort next week when he announces the endorsement of a group of 100 African-American pastors and religious leaders at his Manhattan headquarters.

headline: An Unwelcome Loophole for Robocalls
keywords: ['Cellular Telephones', 'Consumer Protection', 'Credit and Debt', 'Debt Collection', 'Personal Finances', 'Telemarketing', 'Text Messaging', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: A move by Congress could leave millions of people with government-backed loans vulnerable to robocalling.
lead_paragraph: Few things are more irritating than answering the phone to a recording or getting a text message requesting action or selling unnecessary goods. In most cases, such irritations can be dealt with by hanging up immediately or deleting an offending text. The next step should registering that phone on the government’s do-not-call list at donotcall.gov.

headline: Dear Eater: Conversation Topics for Thanksgiving Dinner
abstract: Questions from our Dear Reader column for your Thanksgiving dinner.
lead_paragraph: Questions from our Dear Reader column for your Thanksgiving dinner.

abstract: Fantasy football analysis for Thursday’s three games, including Eagles-Lions and and Panthers-Cowboys.
lead_paragraph: Fantasy football analysis for Thursday’s three games. Check back Friday for analysis of Sunday’s games and Monday’s matchup between the Baltimore Ravens and the Cleveland Browns. You can also follow the Sablich brothers on Twitter at @5thDownFantasy.

headline: Progesterone May Not Help Women With History of Miscarriages, Study Finds
abstract: Giving progesterone to women who have had three or more miscarriages does not increase their chances of carrying a pregnancy to term, according to a new study.
lead_paragraph: Giving progesterone to women who have had three or more miscarriages does not improve their chances of carrying a pregnancy to term, according to a study published on Wednesday.

headline: Hey, Are You Looking at Me? Good. Now, Buzz Off.
abstract: The recent tradition of the look-at-me-don’t-look-at-me stunts has become a rite for modern celebrities.
lead_paragraph: Let’s see. There’s slow food, slow TV, slow cinema, slow theater, slow art, and now slow fame, in which stars spend several hours (or a few days) critiquing being famous. Two weeks ago, the actor turned stunt artist Shia LaBeouf took a seat toward the front of the house at the Angelika Film Center in Manhattan and watched all 29 of his movies, uninterrupted, in reverse chronology. The camera positioned in front of his aisle seat recorded and streamed live every second of his willing descent into stewed narcissism, which was called #AllMyMovies.

headline: U.S. Announces Sanctions on 2 Accused of Dealings With Assad or ISIS
abstract: The moves are the latest attempt by the administration to financially squeeze the Syrian leader and to choke off the Islamic State’s cash flow.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Treasury Department on Wednesday announced sanctions against a Syrian construction executive it said was helping President Bashar al-Assad buy oil from the Islamic State, as well as against a Russian businessman who leads the World Chess Federation and who is accused of having financial dealings with the Syrian leader.

headline: Photos of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
abstract: Greece and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Greece and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Bad Cheer: The Holiday Exchange Precipitating ‘Bridge of Spies’
abstract: In 1944 — before the event inspiring the climax of Steven Spielberg’s thriller — a trade-off in packages set into motion forces resulting in that peak Cold War moment.
lead_paragraph: The events that lead to the chilling climax on a Berlin trestle in Steven Spielberg’s “Bridge of Spies” — the solemn exchange of captives between the United States and the Soviet Union — were ignited in real life at a nondescript Automat on 38th Street just west of Broadway in Manhattan.

headline: What James Donovan Did After the Bridge of Spies
abstract: After he negotiated the exchange of a Soviet spy for an American one, Mr. Donovan was sent to Cuba to talk to Fidel Castro about Bay of Pigs prisoners.
lead_paragraph: Just six months after the spy swap at the center of Steven Spielberg’s “Bridge of Spies,” James B. Donovan, the New York lawyer who negotiated that exchange in real life, sat down in Havana with Fidel Castro for high-stakes talks about the prisoners captured after the disastrous Bay of Pigs invasion attempt.

headline: Nov. 25, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Greece, the West Bank, Saudi Arabia and the United States.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Greece, the West Bank, Saudi Arabia and the United States.

headline: What Will Your Kids Cook for Thanksgiving?
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Holidays and Special Occasions', 'Parenting', 'Thanksgiving Day']
abstract: Giving a child a dish to prepare helps him make Thanksgiving his own.
lead_paragraph: Even for the most seasoned, passionate cooks, Thanksgiving for a crowd is daunting. (Right? Tell me I’m right.) I love to cook, but the big meal for 20 coming up Thursday does have me frantically scrawling grocery lists and timetables and enlisting various family members to produce their specialties (and to buy the wine).

headline: The Short-Order Sofa
abstract: A new breed of online furniture manufacturers offers high-end quality and customization – and often a quick turnaround time – at low-end prices.
lead_paragraph: A new breed of online furniture manufacturers offers high-end quality and customization – and often a quick turnaround time – at low-end prices.

headline: Review: Complexions Contemporary Ballet Recycles With ‘Chronicle’
abstract: The two-part work, performed at the Joyce Theater, feels more like cut and paste than a fully realized work, Gia Kourlas writes.
lead_paragraph: Choreographers are often fueled by the last dance they made, so for the vigilant viewer watching how one bleeds into the next can be an enthralling way to follow an artist’s career. Dwight Rhoden, who along with Desmond Richardson is a founding artistic director of Complexions Contemporary Ballet, quelled that notion on Tuesday with his two-part “Chronicle,” in which he takes inspiration from an older dance to create an evening-length work.

headline: The Near-Impossibility of Assimilation in Belgium
abstract: Why the atmosphere that produced the Paris attackers isn’t going away anytime soon.
lead_paragraph: Some years ago, I was invited to sit on a panel in Antwerp — “together with other distinguished foreigners,” in the words of the panel organizer — to discuss language and culture in Flanders. I had, by then, become a naturalized Belgian, but I had never felt accepted enough to claim that identity; when people asked where I was from, I still said Nigeria. I had come to Belgium as an adult. Neither my Dutch nor my French was as fluent as the average Belgian’s. Perhaps, I reasoned, people had every right to deny me access to that identity.

headline: Thanksgiving Throwdowns Are Good for You
keywords: ['Thanksgiving Day', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Families and Family Life', 'Debates (Political)']
abstract: Where else will you really engage with ‘your Republican uncle’?
lead_paragraph: The Democratic National Committee is ready for Thanksgiving — and any fraught family moments that all the holiday togetherness might bring. On Tuesday, the organization released an updated version of YourRepublicanUncle.com, a website aimed at arming Democrats with the rhetorical ammunition they need to argue with conservative relatives.

headline: Perfect Black Friday Fare: An Oversized Book About Overconsumption
keywords: ['Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'Population', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Sustainable Living']
abstract: Giant books about Earth’s endangered places and overconsumption seem to send a mixed message.
lead_paragraph: As the world (no longer just the United States) prepares for the shopping blitz called Black Friday, which has increasingly migrated into Thanksgiving Thursday in the United States, I find myself asking a question about some illustrated books on environmental themes that have come to me at The Times in recent months.

headline: Eagles of Death Metal Recount the Paris Attack and Their Escape From the Bataclan
abstract: The band members recalled the moments, roughly one hour into their set, when they realized something was wrong and scrambled to escape.
lead_paragraph: Eagles of Death Metal, the California band that was performing at the Bataclan concert hall in Paris on Nov. 13, has given its first interview since assailants killed 89 people and held hundreds of hostages there. Speaking to Vice in a video interview, the band’s singer, Jesse Hughes, broke down in tears several times while describing coming face to face with one of the gunmen and the horrors that audience members endured. But he vowed the band would return to France.

headline: E.P.A. Revokes Approval of New Dow Herbicide for G.M.O. Crops
keywords: ['Defoliants and Herbicides', 'Genetic Engineering', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Biotechnology and Bioengineering']
abstract: The herbicide, which contains the old herbicide 2,4-D, was to be used on crops genetically modified to be resistant to it.
lead_paragraph: The Environmental Protection Agency, in a surprising move, has decided to revoke the approval of a herbicide that was made to be used on a new generation of genetically modified crops.

headline: Finding the Noir Without Looking
abstract: Jason Langer said he is attracted to the main big themes in life: “love, sex and death.” He keeps those ideas in his back pocket, as he captures stark black-and-white photos on film of simple New York moments.
lead_paragraph: Jason Langer said he is attracted to the main big themes in life: “love, sex and death.” He keeps those ideas in his back pocket, as he captures stark black-and-white photos on film of simple New York moments.

lead_paragraph: An American military investigation found a series failures that resulted in an attack on a Doctors Without Borders hospital in Kunduz.

keywords: ['Catfish', 'Fish Farming', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Protectionism (Trade)', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Seafood']
abstract: Inspections of imported catfish are now under the much stricter Agriculture Department, risking retaliation from America’s trade partners.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After years of delay, the Agriculture Department on Wednesday established tough new rules to inspect imported catfish, yielding to pressure from domestic catfish producers that risks retaliation from America’s trade partners.

headline: Rikers Island Guard Is Arrested on Charges of Smuggling
keywords: ['Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Smuggling']
abstract: The correction officer, Kevin McKoy, was found with packages containing scalpels, synthetic marijuana and a prescription painkiller concealed in his pants, the Investigation Department said.
lead_paragraph: A Rikers Island correction officer has been arrested on charges that he tried to smuggle seven scalpels, synthetic marijuana and a prescription painkiller into the New York City jail complex, presumably to sell to inmates, the city’s Investigation Department announced on Wednesday.

headline: What Is It About Adele?
abstract: Record-breaking sales notwithstanding, success doesn’t seem to have spoiled the singer.
lead_paragraph: Adele has had quite a week.

headline: Obama Signs Defense Bill, Despite Guantánamo Objections
abstract: The president said he still believed that provisions in the defense policy bill making it harder for him to close the prison in Cuba might be unconstitutional and not necessarily binding.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Wednesday signed a defense bill into law despite provisions that will continue to impede his goal of closing the wartime prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. But he again suggested that he thought those provisions might be unconstitutional and not necessarily binding.

headline: Shouted Down at a Trump Rally
abstract: Protesters at Donald J. Trump's campaign event in Columbus, Ohio, on Monday were booed and yelled at by an angry crowd, and ordered removed by Mr. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Protesters at Donald J. Trump's campaign event in Columbus, Ohio, on Monday were booed and yelled at by an angry crowd, and ordered removed by Mr. Trump.

lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — They looked as if they didn’t belong.

headline: Suspicious Package Near Port Authority Bus Terminal Disrupts Travel
abstract: The package caused the New York Police Department to briefly evacuate and close some entrances to the Manhattan terminal.
lead_paragraph: A suspicious package found near the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan on Wednesday evening briefly disrupted travel ahead of Thanksgiving Day, according to the police.

headline: Russia and Ukraine in a Standoff Over Crimea Power Outage
keywords: ['Electric Light and Power', 'Tatars (Ethnic Group)', 'Power Failures and Blackouts']
abstract: As Crimean Tatar activists and Ukrainian nationalists prevented repair crews from getting to downed electricity pylons, Kiev closed its airspace to Russian planes and Moscow cut off gas supplies to Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: CHONGAR, Ukraine — Ground zero of the latest confrontation between Ukraine and Russia was a sea of mud and not much else on Wednesday.

headline: Highly Unlikely
abstract: We’ve arrived at a point where not only is reality stranger than fiction, but we don’t allow our fiction to be even close to how strange real life is every day.
lead_paragraph: When something extraordinary happens, we often say it’s stranger than fiction. But reality routinely, every minute of every day, outdoes all realist fiction in its strangeness. Recently two women working on the same floor of a Florida hospital discovered they were sisters (they had been adopted by different families in the 1970s). We read this item in the newspaper and accept it as astonishing, but real. The same occurrence in a realist novel, though, would be called unlikely or unbelievable. We’ve arrived at a point where not only is reality stranger than fiction, but we don’t allow our fiction to be even close to how strange real life is every day.

headline: Freeing Thanksgiving From My Family
abstract: I thought I wanted to celebrate the holiday on my own terms.
lead_paragraph: IT was a few hours before dawn, and the cartoon characters were in sad shape. There they lay, half inflated in the streets encircling New York City’s Museum of Natural History: Snoopy and Hello Kitty and Kermit the Frog and Superman. They were tethered to the ground with giant nets, like something out of “Gulliver’s Travels.”

headline: Pfizer’s Plan to Leave U.S. Unsettles Drug Lobbyists
keywords: ['Relocation of Business', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Escalating drug prices and now a major company’s pending move overseas leads to concern about “too much obvious greed” in the pharmaceutical industry.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Pharmaceutical giant Pfizer has long been the most politically active drug maker in Washington, and its representatives have tended to wrap themselves in the American flag while pressing their concerns with lawmakers and regulators.

headline: Despite Global Events, U.S. Gasoline Prices Remain Low
abstract: Prices for the Thanksgiving weekend are at their lowest since 2008 despite tensions in the Middle East and terrorist attacks.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — American travelers are being treated to bargains at the gasoline pump this Thanksgiving weekend. Prices are at their lowest level for the holiday since the financial crisis of 2008 despite heightened tensions in the Middle East and a spate of terrorist attacks that would normally lead to higher prices.

headline: After Paris Attacks, Ties That Bind Patrons at a Cafe Also Burn
abstract: In a city where corner bistros are havens for neighbors and friends, the terrorist attacks in Paris hurt families related by blood and banter.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — La Belle Équipe, where 19 people died during this month’s terrorist attacks, means “the beautiful team,” and those who frequented the corner bistro in the bourgeois bohemian 11th Arrondissement say the name is all too fitting.

headline: Decorating Homes With Pilgrims and Turkeys Before Elves and Reindeer
abstract: Some residents who decorate their homes for Thanksgiving said the practice seems to have fallen out of fashion, with most people focused on displays for Halloween and Christmas.
lead_paragraph: “I went to Long Island to get a turkey,” Nunzio Gambino said. “It was $40.”

headline: Pillow Fights at West Point Are Banned After Injuries
abstract: The pillow fights at the United States Military Academy came under scrutiny after dozens of cadets were injured at one in August.
lead_paragraph: The superintendent of the United States Military Academy disclosed Wednesday that he would ban pillow fights like the one on Aug. 20 that left two dozen freshmen cadets with concussions and six with other injuries.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: PENELOPE FITZGERALD: A Life, by Hermione Lee. (Vintage, $17.95.) Elusive and eccentric, Fitzgerald (1916-2000) published her first book, a biography, when she was 58 and went on to win the Man Booker Prize with her third novel a few years later. Lee, a veteran biographer of literary figures (including Edith Wharton and Virginia Woolf), approaches her subject with surgical precision in this volume, one of the Book Review’s 10 Best of 2014.

headline: F.S.U. Reported Few Rape Cases to the U.S.
abstract: The university reported only 14 of 113 cases of student-reported rape to the federal government because many of the reported assaults occurred off-campus.
lead_paragraph: In court papers that Florida State University fought to keep confidential, the former director of the school’s Victim Advocate Office testified that in 2014, a total of 113 students reported being sexually battered, which is the same as rape in Florida. But the college reported only 14 cases to the federal government, records show.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: SPQR: A History of Ancient Rome, by Mary Beard. (Liveright, $35.) Like New Yorkers, Romans were aggressive and acquisitive and came from somewhere else; Beard’s wonderfully concise history unpacks the secrets of the city’s success.

headline: Treating Mental Illness in New York, From All Angles
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio unveiled a citywide initiative to tackle mental illness and addiction.
lead_paragraph: As too many people know only too well, mental health is a world of unmet needs and untold suffering. Society’s ability to identify and treat emotional ailments and addiction is painfully inadequate. Families, left to themselves, struggle and fail. They often lack the resources to confront problems or don’t try: two things in plentiful supply are ignorance and denial.

headline: Mother Who Left Baby at Queens Church Is Found; No Charges Will Be Filed
abstract: Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, said that the woman, whom he did not identify by name, had “followed the spirit of New York’s ‘Safe Haven’ Law.”
lead_paragraph: The mother of a baby who was left this week in an unadorned crèche inside a Roman Catholic church in Queens was found and will not face criminal prosecution, the county district attorney said late Wednesday.

headline: Black Leaders in Chicago Push for Investigation of Police Department
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Police', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Some of Chicago’s most prominent black leaders called for a Justice Department investigation into the police department and its handling of a shooting of a black teenager by a white officer last year.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — A day after city officials released graphic video of a white police officer shooting a black teenager 16 times, some of the city’s most prominent black leaders called on Wednesday for investigations into the Chicago Police Department and its handling of the shooting. They expressed anger and dismay toward the department’s leadership, and some demanded the resignation of the police superintendent.

headline: Verizon Commercial Suggests a Thanksgiving Without Phones
abstract: Verizon is introducing a television ad encouraging people to enjoy family and friends rather than their small screens.
lead_paragraph: Imagine Thanksgiving without Instagram.

headline: Mack McCormick, Student of Texas Blues, Dies at 85
abstract: Mr. McCormick, a folklorist who spent a lifetime searching out forgotten or unrecorded singers all over Texas, traveled thousands of miles to amass a blues archive.
lead_paragraph: Mack McCormick, a folklorist who spent a lifetime searching out forgotten or unrecorded blues singers all over Texas, helped revive the career of Lightning Hopkins and unearthed a trove of historical material on hundreds of blues singers, including Blind Lemon Jefferson and Lead Belly, died on Nov. 18 at his home in Houston. He was 85.

headline: David Canary, Star of ‘All My Children,’ Dies at 77
abstract: After first appearing on the soap opera in 1984, Mr. Canary won five Daytime Emmy Awards and received 16 nominations in the outstanding lead actor category.
lead_paragraph: David Canary, who played the Chandler twins — evil Adam and guileless Stuart — on the soap opera “All My Children” for nearly 30 years, died on Nov. 16 in Wilton, Conn. He was 77.

headline: Court in China Reduces Prison Sentence for Gao Yu, Prominent Journalist
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'News and News Media', 'Political Prisoners', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Ms. Gao, 71, who was convicted of leaking a document that laid out plans for a campaign against Western ideas, will now serve five years rather than seven.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A court in Beijing on Thursday reduced the prison sentence being served by a well-known journalist, Gao Yu, who had been convicted of leaking a Communist Party document that laid out plans for a campaign against Western liberal ideas, according to her lawyers.

headline: Detective Shoots Unarmed Man During Raid in Brooklyn
abstract: The man, Kyron Cradle, was hit in the leg by a detective with the Emergency Service Unit of the Police Department as the police were executing a search warrant for a gun.
lead_paragraph: A detective with an elite unit of the New York Police Department shot and wounded an unarmed 32-year-old man in his Brooklyn apartment on Wednesday as a team of officers tried to execute a search warrant for a gun, the police said.

headline: N.C.A.A. Clears Players, Then Absolves Itself
abstract: The top recruits Cheick Diallo of Kansas and Kassoum Yakwe of St. John’s are finally allowed to play after the N.C.A.A. concluded an investigation that raised questions about the organization, not the players.
lead_paragraph: So this is how the N.C.A.A. saves face.

headline: Tall Lineup Frustrates Porzingis and Knicks
abstract: Carmelo Anthony scored a game-high 28 points, but the Knicks’ bench contributed only 12 in 100-91 loss.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Scott Skiles, the Magic’s coach, sought to improve his team’s balance by shuffling his starting lineup for Wednesday’s game against the Knicks. With the Magic coming off two straight losses, Skiles moved Victor Oladipo to the bench and replaced him with Channing Frye. It was not an easy decision for Skiles.

headline: You Might Be Indignant
abstract: Ed Sessa underlines the reason copy editors exist, and Wordplay wishes you a happy Thanksgiving.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Puzzle solvers are known for being especially fussy about things like spelling errors. Are you the type of person who notices a typo wherever they appear? Let’s see how good you really are.

headline: Charity’s Onetime Leader Begins a Work-Release Program
abstract: William E. Rapfogel, the former chief executive and executive director of the Metropolitan Council on Jewish Poverty, had admitted to stealing more than $1 million from his own charity.
lead_paragraph: A former Jewish community leader serving up to 10 years in prison for his role in stealing more than $9 million from the charity he ran has been moved to a work-release program in Manhattan less than two years into his sentence, New York State corrections officials said on Wednesday.

headline: 4 Arrested in Shooting at Black Lives Matter Protest Are Identified
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Discrimination']
abstract: The police on Wednesday released the names of four men arrested in connection with a shooting during a Black Lives Matter protest in Minneapolis outside a police station that injured five protesters.

headline: King Kevin Versus Queen Cersei

abstract: Let the cacophonous feasting, with right wings of the turkey and left, begin!
lead_paragraph: THE intense interest in the thrill-a-minute, through-the-looking-glass 2016 race, fueled by anger at maladjusted Washington and anxiety after the Paris attacks, has spawned predictions that Thanksgiving political debates will be noisier and nastier than ever. Plenty of turkeys with a bone to pick and plenty of dressing down to go with the dressing. The Democratic National Committee actually issued talking points for the “lively” conversations with Republican uncles, aunts and brothers. Clearly, the people at the D.N.C. don’t have any Republican relatives. It’s never a parley. It’s a lecture. So I decided to let my Republican brother offer his red-state soliloquy now, hoping he’d let me eat my white meat in peace. He-e-e-ere’s Kevin:

headline: An Infant, Breast-Feeding and a Wedding
abstract: Plus: pride at work; encouraging creativity; and in-flight manners.
lead_paragraph: My wife and I are invited to her cousin’s wedding six weeks after our baby is due. She plans to breast-feed at the festivities using a special dress and cape. (Neither breast nor baby shows.) But her mother and aunts are adamant that she use the bathroom. At 90 minutes a feeding, based on her experience, she would be there for hours. Same with pumping: She pumps for an hour every two hours. We will be flying cross-country with three small children for this wedding, and my wife doesn’t want to spend the day alone. May she breast-feed discreetly in public?

headline: In Miami, the Brainy Side of the Beach
abstract: Attractions like classical music, museums and a graffiti district make Miami a draw away from the beach.
lead_paragraph: On the kind of balmy February evening that draws snowbirds by the flocks to South Florida, I split from the flip-flop crowd clogging Lincoln Road Mall in Miami Beach and veered one block north to the New World Center. The Frank Gehry-designed glass and steel symphony hall opened in 2011, and at once established South Beach as a cultural destination. A cluster of patrons formed a white-haired clot in front of the box office where I learned that the evening’s program, a recital by a third-year horn fellow with the center’s New World Symphony, was sold out. True, it was a free event, but it required reservations and Dominic Rotella, the musician, was apparently the hottest ticket in town.

headline: Theater Troupe Gives Those on the Margins a Front-Row Seat

headline: A 1950s-Era Timepiece, Reborn
abstract: The venerable Swiss brand Vacheron Constantin brings back a classic chronograph.
lead_paragraph: From the time chronograph technology started to catch on in the late 1800s until the middle of the 20th century, the venerable Swiss brand Vacheron Constantin produced highly coveted timepieces. But in 1955, it stopped making the wristwatches, which had become too elaborately wonkish to suit changing tastes. Although the company began gingerly reintroducing chronographs in the late 1980s, the final ’50s-era model, the Cornes de Vache, continued to obsess collectors. Only 36 were ever made: 26 in yellow gold, eight in rose gold and two in platinum. Now the company has reinterpreted the design. The Historiques Cornes de Vache 1955, available only in platinum, is, like the original, a sober classic distinguished by its cow-horn-shaped lugs. But a slightly wider face gives the watch a more modern, balanced look and feel. With its raised Roman numerals, midnight-blue alligator strap, sapphire-hued tachometric dial and clear crystal back, it makes keeping track of time an immeasurable pleasure.

headline: 1940: Italy Breathes Easier After Pact
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Tension ends in Italy as the Axis powers meet in 1940.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The diplomatic offensive launched by the Axis powers against Great Britain after the meeting between Benito Mussolini and Fuehrer Adolf Hitler at Brenner Pass is believed here tonight [Nov. 27] to have ended for the time being. Tension in Rome over a possible imminent spread of war in the Balkans also has passed suddenly. In the highest diplomatic circles, it was said today that no signing of any agreement by either of the Axis powers with Bulgaria was likely soon. Turkey, armed to the teeth under martial law and moving up fresh divisions toward the Bulgarian border, may also be expected to remain out of the war for some time. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 27, 1940

headline: ‘Empire’ Season 2, Episode 9: On the Road
abstract: Cookie goes to Philly in search of her sister.
lead_paragraph: Cookie and Laz Delgado’s whirlwind romance reached its logical conclusion this week as a chance meeting with Lucious finally inspired someone to hit Google and figure out that he’s aligned with his girlfriend’s enemies and coolly playing Big Heavy’s goons against Lyon Dynasty. Kicking him out may do more harm than good, though, as no one knows how hard Laz has advocated for the dynasty or how anxious the neighborhood guys are for a bigger bite of their profits. Without a sympathetic party talking the gang out of terser negotiations, business is bound to get prickly. With Cookie’s Cookout looming on the horizon, one wonders how long Lyon Dynasty really is for the earth. The independence from Lucious that Cookie and Hakeem have gone to desperate extremes to cultivate finally feels perfectly unsustainable.

headline: Time Before Iraq Invasion Holds Lessons for Fight Against ISIS
abstract: The constellation of alliances and perceived national interests has shifted over the past 12 years.

headline: 1965: French Launch First Satellite
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: France becomes the world’s third space power in 1965.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — France today [Nov. 26] launched a 92.4-pound satellite into orbit, thereby becoming the world’s third full-fledged space power after the United States and the Soviet Union. The satellite, launched from the French Sahara base of Hammaguir, will orbit the earth for the next two weeks, sending back radio messages to tracking stations near Paris and around the world. President Charles de Gaulle hailed the launching as ‘‘an important accomplishment.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 27, 1965
