lead_paragraph: Yankees pitcher Lefty Gomez once said he would rather be lucky than good, but so far this season, the Rangers have been both.

headline: West End Avenue, Two Days Before Thanksgiving
keywords: ['Poetry and Poets', 'Thanksgiving Day', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: A poem about the modern celebration, from the frenzy of travel through the hellos, hugs and shared memories, and the long goodbyes.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Review: In ‘Submerged,’ a Limo Ride Hits Rough Waters
abstract: Much of the action is underwater in this thriller starring Jonathan Bennett as a limo-driving bodyguard who must rescue a young woman from kidnappers.
lead_paragraph: There’s claustrophobia to burn in Steven C. Miller’s “Submerged,” a modest thriller offering glints of talent amid predictable plot threads. Matt (Jonathan Bennett), a military reservist, struggles to raise his faltering younger brother, Dylan (Cody Christian), after the death of their parents. He also covets — and looks out for — Jessie, the daughter (Talulah Riley) of a wealthy businessman (Tim Daly) for whom he is a driver and surrogate son.

headline: Review: A Whiff of Hidden Toxins in ‘Stink!’
abstract: A strange odor emanating from the fabric of his daughter’s new pajamas leads a filmmaker to investigate the toxic chemicals allowed in consumer goods.
lead_paragraph: When Jon Stewart signed off from “The Daily Show” with the instruction, “If you smell something, say something,” he wasn’t speaking literally. Yet he would probably approve of “Stink!,” a heartfelt documentary about the chemical industry’s aggressive efforts to conceal the thousands of potentially toxic ingredients contained in everyday products.

headline: Portugal’s New Premier Takes Office, Facing Financial Balancing Act
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The new government of António Costa, the Socialist leader and a former mayor of Lisbon, brings to an end to almost two months of political instability.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — António Costa, the Socialist leader, on Thursday took office as Portugal’s new prime minister, at the helm of a minority government that has pledged to comply with European fiscal commitments while also reversing some of the austerity measures that had turned Portugal into a model student for international creditors.

headline: Review: In ‘Killing Them Safely,’ a Debate on the Virtues of Tasers
abstract: This heavily researched documentary by Nick Berardini becomes a dense stew of words and death.
lead_paragraph: The rise, use and abuse of the Taser form the discomfiting subject of Nick Berardini’s “Killing Them Safely,” but an equally formidable weapon also goes on display: words. In the 1990s, the brothers Rick and Tom Smith amped up a decades-old invention to create their electricity-zapping “home run product.” Since then, their company, Taser International, has defended the Taser’s virtues with on-message verbiage in the face of deaths associated with the weapon.

headline: A Spieth Who Doesn’t Live in His Brother’s Shadow, at Least at Home
abstract: The Brown basketball player Steven Spieth, brother of the No. 1-rated golfer Jordan Spieth, and their sister, Ellie, have been blessed with parents who don’t play favorites.
lead_paragraph: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — Steven Spieth has five inches of height, and nearly that much hair, over his older brother, Jordan. But since the basketball season has started up again at Brown, fans at opposing arenas have zeroed in on what Jordan has that the 6-foot-6, mop-topped Steven will never possess.

headline: Review: In ‘Karski & the Lords of Humanity,’ a Holocaust Spy
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: This documentary by Slawomir Grunberg focuses on Jan Karski, who reported to the Allies about the Nazi campaign against Polish Jews.
lead_paragraph: One of the many interviewees in “Shoah,” Claude Lanzmann’s definitive nine-and-a-half-hour 1985 documentary about the Holocaust, was Jan Karski, a Pole whose undercover missions in World War II gave early information to the Allies about the extermination of Polish Jews. Slawomir Grunberg’s stately documentary “Karski & the Lords of Humanity” focuses exclusively on Karski’s courageous adventures in intrigue and espionage.

headline: ‘Mama Says That Santa Claus Does Not Come to Poor People’
abstract: New books reveal heart-rending letters to Santa Claus as well as a scandal that involving a fraudulent Santa Claus Association.
lead_paragraph: New books reveal poignant, 19th-century pleas to Santa Claus as well as the bizarre fate of some heart-rending mail addressed to his workshop.

headline: Review: In ‘Tamasha,’ Finding a Path to Love, Show Business and Adulation
abstract: A Bollywood melodrama about a boy, a girl, storytelling and make-believe.
lead_paragraph: The clues come early in the Bollywood melodrama “Tamasha,” when a song mentions a love story within a larger story. The film (named after a kind of Marathi theater) begins with a boy, Ved, enraptured at the feet of a wizened storyteller in Shimla, India. Later, as an adult (Ranbir Kapoor), he meets Tara (Deepika Padukone) on vacation in Corsica. Their largely chaste relationship revolves around playacting, and they avoid exchanging real names. When Tara returns to India, they decide to never meet again, their idyll forever in amber.

headline: Joseph Kosuth Show at Sean Kelly Gallery
abstract: ‘Agnosia, an Illuminated Ontology,’ an installation by the Conceptual artist, features words and phrases in neon and other lighting.
lead_paragraph: The 1950s and ’60s were peak years for “the linguistic turn,” a philosophical movement that looked to the analysis of language for solutions to traditional puzzles about consciousness and reality. Few artists were more profoundly affected by that trend than Joseph Kosuth, a pioneer of ’60s-style Conceptualism. “Agnosia, an Illuminated Ontology,” a visually exciting and conceptually bookish installation designed by Mr. Kosuth, gathers together more than 40 works from 1965 to 2015 that feature electrically illuminated words, phrases and sentences. (Agnosia is an inability to make sense of sensory information, a condition usually caused by brain damage.)

headline: Carl Andre’s Minimalism, Suitable for Walking On
abstract: Mr. Andre’s sculptures in this show, largely derived from tiles of lead, zinc and copper, are accompanied by 10 works by his Minimalist contemporaries.

headline: Sheila Hicks, a Weaver Flirting With Installation Art
abstract: Ms. Hicks’s creations range from 10 inches square to constructions that venture into sculpture and almost environmental dimensions.
lead_paragraph: These two exhibitions confirm the ambition and physical command exuded by the work of Sheila Hicks, who started out in weaving and has spent her long career formulating different ratios of art, craft and design, with varying degrees of success.

headline: Loie Hollowell’s Abstract Body Landscapes
abstract: The nine paintings here, Ms. Hollowell’s first solo exhibition, steps into the historical lineage of painters like Georgia O’Keeffe and Judy Chicago.

headline: Hollis Frampton’s Singular Sensibility
abstract: The photography exhibition “ADSVMVS ABSVMVS” is a mordantly wacky, show-and-tell stand-up routine on mortality.
lead_paragraph: The filmmaker, photographer, essayist, poet, teacher, fabulist and proto-digital pioneer Hollis Frampton (1936-1984) eased off on producing photography after the 1960s but came back to it at the end of his too-short life. His final work in the medium, a portfolio of 14 pictures with the curious title “ADSVMVS ABSVMVS,” makes up this exhibition, which is also — but how can this be? — his New York gallery solo debut.

headline: Review: In ‘Janis: Little Girl Blue,’ Exploring Joplin’s Demons
abstract: The documentary recounts the emotional wounds Janis Joplin sustained growing up as the antithesis of the all-American prom-queen ideal in Texas.
lead_paragraph: In Amy Berg’s documentary “Janis: Little Girl Blue,” the sound that erupts from Janis Joplin singing the ’60s R&B classic “Cry Baby” comes as close as I’ve heard to a grown-up singer capturing a baby’s primal squall. Heard today, this raw, insistent scream, from Joplin’s posthumously released 1971 album, “Pearl,” is as disturbing and powerful as ever.

headline: Art Basel Miami Beach: A Focus on Female Artists
abstract: A number of galleries are showcasing works by women at the annual art fair.
lead_paragraph: There may come a day when having a critical mass of women featured in an art fair is no longer noteworthy, but we’re not there yet. So it’s worth noting that Art Basel Miami Beach, which starts next week, has a significant number of female artists.

headline: Review: ‘Iraqi Odyssey’ Shows the Arc of a Family and a Country
abstract: In this documentary, the director Samir reflects on his family’s history and diaspora, by extension, the story of the family’s homeland.
lead_paragraph: “Iraqi Odyssey,” a two-and-a-half-hour personal history written and directed by the Swiss filmmaker Samir (full name, Samir Jamal Aldin), is the kind of documentary whose length and complexity make you approach it with some apprehension. Watching it is like slowly leafing through a giant scrapbook whose contents include the individual stories of a large extended family.

headline: Storm King to Present Earthworks by Dennis Oppenheim
abstract: Architecture and whimsy combine in the artist’s manmade and natural landscapes.
lead_paragraph: With 500 acres of verdant exhibition space, Storm King Art Center, in New York’s Hudson Valley, is uncommonly positioned to execute large-scale earthworks conceived by Dennis Oppenheim but never fully realized in his lifetime.

headline: China Bars Anastasia Lin, Miss World Canada (and Rights Advocate)
keywords: ['Beauty Contests', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Miss Canada, Anastasia Lin, was denied a visa to attend the international pageant, apparently because she is outspoken about human-rights abuses in the country of her birth.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Clasping hands with youngsters in red Communist Youth League scarves, contestants from more than 110 nations descended on the southern Chinese island of Hainan this week for the 65th annual Miss World contest.

headline: Review: ‘The Danish Girl,’ About a Transgender Pioneer
abstract: In Tom Hooper’s new film, Eddie Redmayne and Alicia Vikander portray the 1920s artists Einar and Gerda Wegener as Einar became Lili Elbe.
lead_paragraph: “The Danish Girl,” Tom Hooper’s new film, is a story of individual struggle that is also a portrait of a marriage. In this respect and others it resembles “The King’s Speech,” Mr. Hooper’s earlier historical drama, a multiple Oscar winner a few years ago. In that case, the union of George VI and Elizabeth, the Queen Mother, was the foundation on which the tale of George’s elocutionary striving was built. Here, the marriage is bohemian rather than aristocratic, but the stakes, while personal, are every bit as profound and consequential as the matters of state that drove the monarch to the microphone.

headline: Review: ‘Lorca Madly in Love’ Portrays a Forbidden Romance Through Flamenco
abstract: David Morales choreographs and stars in this work that centers on the Spanish poet Federico García Lorca and his last affair with a man, Juan Ramírez de Lucas.
lead_paragraph: After the great Spanish poet and playwright Federico García Lorca was assassinated during the Spanish Civil War, his homosexuality was concealed and suppressed for decades. In contemporary Spain, the truth is now widely acknowledged, but for an artist to treat the subject frankly, especially in the tradition-bound world of flamenco, as David Morales does in his show “Lorca Madly in Love,” still counts as taboo-breaking and bold.

headline: 50 Years Ago, ‘Unsafe at Any Speed’ Shook the Auto World
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: Today, even some critics of Ralph Nader’s 1965 book acknowledge its impact on the auto industry and safety.
lead_paragraph: FEW DRIVERS could imagine owning a car these days that did not come with airbags, antilock brakes and seatbelts. But 50 years ago motorists went without such basic safety features.

headline: Britain Adopts Black Friday With an All-American Frenzy
keywords: ['Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Christmas']
abstract: Some retailers are trying to dial back, because for a nation that prides itself on decorum, last year was ugly; or, a typical American Black Friday.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British don’t celebrate Thanksgiving, of course, but they have enthusiastically embraced another great American holiday tradition: Black Friday. A little too enthusiastically, it seems. Now, some retailers are even trying to dial back some of the frenzy they unleashed just a few years after introducing the whole idea.

headline: Making Merry With Music
abstract: The pop and jazz critics of The New York Times survey some of this year’s music releases as gift-giving suggestions.
lead_paragraph: Each holiday season brings an opportunity to tackle old standards or to add new hits to the canon. Here, the pop and jazz critics of The New York Times survey some of this year’s releases. (Prices may vary, depending on where purchases are made.)

headline: Canada’s New Leadership Reverses Course on Climate Change
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change']
abstract: The new prime minister, Justin Trudeau, has moved climate-change policy to the top of the country’s political agenda after it spent nearly a decade as an afterthought.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — In less than a month, Canada has executed a complete about-face on global climate change.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for Nov. 27-Dec. 3
abstract: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.
lead_paragraph: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Parents Ready for Some Love From Silicon Valley Companies
keywords: ['Work-Life Balance', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Parenting', 'Family Leaves', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Mark Zuckerberg’s decision to take two months of parental leave is a sign of a shifting culture.
lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley is beginning to admit it isn’t just for young people anymore.

headline: Hoping Not to Repeat the Past
abstract: Calls by governors to turn away new Syrian refugees are resurrecting memories of World War II internment camps for Japanese-Americans.
lead_paragraph: Calls by governors to turn away new Syrian refugees are resurrecting memories of World War II internment camps for Japanese-Americans.

headline: Resistance to Syrian Refugees Calls to Mind Painful Past for Japanese-Americans
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Japanese-Americans', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: The dark memories of seven decades ago have bubbled to the surface in recent weeks for many people who were sent to Japanese internment camps.
lead_paragraph: Before the attack that changed the country, a group of girls would meet their 14-year-old friend, Yuka, at her house every morning. They would walk to school together and discuss their plans for the day.

headline: Colleagues Ponder Sheldon Silver’s Role in Albany if He Is Acquitted
keywords: ['State Legislatures', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Mr. Silver, a Democrat on trial for corruption, could return to the capital for the legislative session next year, but few, if any, believe he would regain the speakership.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — It’s a hypothetical that few lawmakers in Albany will openly entertain. But what happens if — just if — Assemblyman Sheldon Silver walks out of a Manhattan courtroom a free man?

headline: Man Scales White House Fence as Obamas Celebrate Thanksgiving Inside
keywords: ['White House Building (Washington, DC)', 'Fences and Property Barriers']
abstract: Agents apprehended a man draped in an American flag on the North Lawn on Thursday, moments after he cleared the fence, the Secret Service said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A man climbed over a fence in front of the White House on Thursday as President Obama and his family were inside celebrating Thanksgiving, the Secret Service said.

headline: Crop Insurance Subsidies Prove Cutting Budget Is Easier Said Than Done
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Crop Controls and Subsidies', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Insurance']
abstract: Determined to rein in spending, Congress celebrated agreement on a plan to save trillions. Yet one of the few cuts actually passed now faces repeal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In April, Republicans newly in control of Congress celebrated their agreement on a plan to save $5 trillion — that’s trillion, with a “T” — and balance the budget in a decade. “We continue to get things done for the American people,” boasted the House speaker at the time, John A. Boehner.

headline: Macau Gambling Industry Faces Challenges on Multiple Fronts
abstract: The once-booming gambling industry in Macau now confronts an array of obstacles, ranging from restrictive local policies to China’s economic slowdown and crackdown on corruption.
lead_paragraph: MACAU — Macau’s newest gambling palace has plenty to beckon deep-pocketed Chinese visitors looking for a good time.

headline: Guy Lewis, Coach of Houston’s Phi Slama Jama Teams, Dies at 93
abstract: Lewis coached the Cougars for 30 years, and to five Final Fours, but he is best remembered for his squads of the 1980s and their thunderous style of play.
lead_paragraph: Guy Lewis, a Hall of Fame basketball coach known for leading the University of Houston’s Phi Slama Jama teams of the early 1980s, died on Thursday at a retirement home in Kyle, Tex. He was 93.

headline: El Salvador: Priest Faces Abuse Inquiry
abstract: A high-ranking priest was suspended while the church investigated allegations that he had sexually abused a girl over an eight-year period.
lead_paragraph: The archdiocese of San Salvador said Thursday that it had suspended a high-ranking priest while the church investigated allegations that he had sexually abused a girl over an eight-year period beginning when she was 9 years old. The accused priest, Msgr. Jesús Delgado, 77, the archdiocese’s vicar general until his suspension, played a crucial role in the effort to canonize Archbishop Óscar Romero, who was assassinated in 1980. “We ask for forgiveness from the victim and from society,” said Msgr. Rafael Urrútia of the archdiocese.

headline: Number of Migrants Illegally Crossing Rio Grande Rises Sharply
abstract: Once again, smugglers are bringing hundreds of women and children each day to the Mexican banks of the river and sending them across in rafts.
lead_paragraph: MISSION, Tex. — The numbers of migrants crossing the Rio Grande illegally have risen sharply in recent weeks, replaying scenes from the influx of Central American children and families in South Texas last year.

headline: Cynthia Robinson, Sly and the Family Stone Trumpet Player, Dies at 71
abstract: Ms. Robinson was part of the band’s biggest hits in the late 1960s and early ’70s.
lead_paragraph: Cynthia Robinson, a trumpet player and original member of the seminal psychedelic-funk-soul group Sly and the Family Stone, died on Monday in Carmichael, Calif. She was 71.

headline: Black Friday Retail Workers Try to Make the Most of a Shopping Slump
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Employees of companies like American Apparel will be putting in extra effort to turn around what is shaping up to be a dismal shopping season.
lead_paragraph: On Black Friday, Jeffery Santos, 23, will rise at 4 a.m., grab a bagel and a strong espresso, jump on a train from the Bronx into Manhattan, and ready an American Apparel store on Broadway for its big 6 a.m. opening.

headline: Open Season Is Seen in Gene Editing of Animals
keywords: ['Genetic Engineering', 'Breeding of Animals', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Cattle', 'Livestock', 'ANIMALS', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Crispr (DNA)']
abstract: New techniques have made previously impossible goals fast and cheap enough for many to find worth pursuing.
lead_paragraph: SIOUX CENTER, Iowa — Other than the few small luxuries afforded them, like private access to a large patch of grass, there was nothing to mark the two hornless dairy calves born last spring at a breeding facility here as early specimens in a new era of humanity’s dominion over nature.

headline: Influx of West Africans in the Bronx Spurs Demand for Interpreters
abstract: A growing population of immigrants may not have enough knowledge of English to deal with the complexities of immigration paperwork, the courts, housing applications or educational offerings.
lead_paragraph: Conversations were still bubbling when Afua Atta-Mensah took the microphone and welcomed everybody to the African Community Town Hall, held in the basement of the Bronx Museum of the Arts this month.

headline: Safety Lapses and Deaths Amid a Building Boom in New York
abstract: An increase in fatalities and injuries has mostly affected undocumented immigrant laborers and far exceeds the rate of new construction.
lead_paragraph: Manuel Colorado, a 36-year-old construction worker, was installing decking last year at a new building in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, when he lost his balance and fell 19 feet to his death.

headline: Turnaround Gives UConn Bowl Security Other Teams Envy
abstract: A year after going 2-10, Connecticut is eligible for a bowl with one game remaining, while the fate of 17 other teams is still up in the air.
lead_paragraph: Needing to win one of its last two regular-season games to become bowl eligible in Bob Diaco’s second season as head coach, Connecticut got the job done on the first weekend, stunning Houston, previously unbeaten and nationally ranked, on Saturday in East Hartford, Conn.

headline: Donald Trump Says His Mocking of New York Times Reporter Was Misread
abstract: The candidate denied that he had mocked the appearance of a New York Times reporter with a physical disability at a campaign rally.
lead_paragraph: Responding to criticism over remarks he made on Tuesday, Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential candidate and real estate developer, denied on Thursday that he was mocking the appearance of a reporter for The New York Times with a physical disability.

headline: The Mute Swan, a Surface Beauty in New York Parks
abstract: Depending upon your perspective as a naturalist, mute swans can be breathtakingly beautiful or emblematic of a nature gone out of balance.
lead_paragraph: The approach of winter probably finds more New Yorkers anticipating the return of Tchaikovsky’s “Swan Lake” to the New York City Ballet than the return of the mute swans to Willow Lake, but there are at least a few hardy souls who visit the real thing within the wilds of city parks each year.

headline: Coffee Table Books About New York
abstract: Among coffee-table volumes of local interest are celebrations of landmarks, federal courthouses, Central Park paintings and the Dakota.
lead_paragraph: Looking for gift books? Need to cover an empty coffee table? Or to construct one? Here are some hefty holiday offerings, all about New York.

headline: Cellphone Recording Leads to Arrest of Brazilian Senator on Obstruction Charges
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Delcídio do Amaral, an ally of President Dilma Rousseff, was charged with impeding an investigation into Brazil’s state-owned oil company.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The young actor aroused the suspicions of the senator’s chief of staff as they were about to meet in a hotel suite in Brasília this month.

headline: Things to Do in the Hudson Valley, Nov. 27 to Dec. 6, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Felled by Tumor, Model Finds Strength to Walk Again
abstract: Jinji Nicole was told she might no longer walk because of trauma a tumor had done to her spine. She proved everyone wrong, including herself.
lead_paragraph: It was a day in late September when Jinji Nicole stepped out her door, crossed Fifth Avenue and went for a walk around the Central Park reservoir.

headline: Things to Do in Connecticut, Nov. 27 to Dec. 6, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Mixing Whimsy and Prudence at the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade
abstract: About 2,500 law enforcement officers kept watch over the parade in Manhattan amid heightened alert after the terrorist attacks in Paris.
lead_paragraph: Minutes before the balloons began bobbing through the streets of Manhattan, crowds pushed up against the barricades that lined Avenue of the Americas and, just out of earshot, counterterrorism officials from the New York Police Department huddled on the sidewalk, the Radio City Music Hall sign looming overhead.

headline: Restaurant Review: Delta’s Serves No-Nonsense Soul Food
abstract: Delta’s in New Brunswick, N.J., serves no-nonsense soul food with all the fixings in a lively atmosphere.
lead_paragraph: Delta’s is the kind of place where your expectations are crucial to how much you’ll enjoy yourself. If you’re looking for no-nonsense soul food like your mom made, in an upscale atmosphere — with prices to match — you’re in luck. If you’re expecting a modernized version of soul food, you might be disappointed.

headline: Ben Carson to Visit Refugees in Jordan Amid Scrutiny of His Foreign Policy Credentials
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Terrorism', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The Republican presidential candidate has slipped in opinion polls as concerns have been raised over his readiness to lead during a national crisis.
lead_paragraph: Ben Carson, who is facing increasing scrutiny over his grasp of foreign policy, is traveling to Jordan on Friday to visit Syrian refugees, in order to gain an understanding of the pressing issue and to polish his candidacy.

headline: Fall Out of Line
abstract: A fun, freestyle Friday by Peter Wentz.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Fairly easy for a Friday, or at least mostly in my wheelhouse. Not only that, but this themeless by Peter Wentz was a fun solve, with some terrific 10-letter entries orbiting the grid.

headline: Fatal Brooklyn Crash Renews Fears of Drag Racing
abstract: Questions linger in the death of James Miro, 31, whose body was found in a submerged car near a stretch of road that local residents say is frequented by drag racers.
lead_paragraph: There are many questions about why James Miro, a young local barber, ended up dead in a Brooklyn creek this month, his car submerged for more than a day. Why was he driving there at 5 a.m., and why does surveillance video show him traveling at a high speed on Gerritsen Avenue, which he most likely knew was a dead end beyond which lay water?

headline: Gunmen Strike Shiite Mosque in Bangladesh
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Mosques', 'Shiite Muslims', 'Terrorism', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: Gunmen opened fire during evening prayers at the mosque, killing one person and wounding three, in the second recent attack on Bangladesh’s tiny Shiite population.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Unidentified gunmen opened fire on a Shiite mosque in northern Bangladesh on Thursday evening, killing one man and injuring three others during evening prayer, in an attack that echoes last month’s bombing of a Shiite procession.

headline: Woman Is Fatally Struck in Brooklyn
abstract: The woman was hit while trying to get into her car, the police said. About a dozen other people, including the driver, suffered minor injuries.
lead_paragraph: A driver fatally struck a woman in Brooklyn on Thursday night, then injured about a dozen people — including himself — as he tried to flee, the police said.

headline: What to Watch Friday
abstract: Bruce Springsteen on ‘The River,’ his landmark album; a new supernatural thriller series with Mena Suvari; and the Holderness family celebrates Christmas.
lead_paragraph: Suffering from a Thanksgiving hangover? Soothe your tummy and temper with songs from Bruce Springsteen and Andrea Bocelli, binge on a supernatural thriller series, or slip into your pj’s with members of the Holderness family of North Carolina, known for their “Christmas Jammies” video.

headline: Corrections: November 27, 2015
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Friday, November 27, 2015
lead_paragraph: BUSINESS DAY

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, November 27, 2015
lead_paragraph: “I’m just an acting student and a beauty queen. What could they possibly be so afraid of?”

headline: Finding the Noir Without Looking
abstract: Jason Langer said he is attracted to the main big themes in life: “love, sex and death.” He keeps those ideas in his back pocket, as he captures stark black-and-white photos on film of simple New York moments.
lead_paragraph: The pictures suggest a murder mystery, or at least a thickening plot. But the truth is far more innocent. These photographs were taken by Jason Langer, who lives in Portland, Ore., when he was visiting friends in New York City.

headline: Donald Trump’s Police State
abstract: The Republican front-runner has outlined a series of measures that would make the United States an authoritarian nightmare.
lead_paragraph: In “The Plot Against America,” the novelist Philip Roth imagines an alternative history at the dawn of World War II. Charles A. Lindbergh, aviator hero and crypto-fascist, defeats Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1940. Rather than go to war against Nazi Germany, he foments an atmosphere of hatred directed at Jews in the United States.

headline: Immigrant Women
abstract: The American Friends Service Committee of Arizona writes that there is a financial interest in keeping these women under strict surveillance.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Inside the Republicans’ Opposition Research Machine
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A visit to the Republican National Committee’s opposition research team, who have their eyes on Hillary Rodham Clinton all the time.
lead_paragraph: The vast right-wing conspiracy Hillary Rodham Clinton once cited in 1998 works from cluttered offices on Capitol Hill, led by a man who was in high school when she first made the charge.

headline: Europe the Unready
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The hope for a growing European unity has suffered setbacks amid terrorism, the refugee crisis and financial challenges.
lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving as we know it dates not to colonial days but to the middle of the Civil War, when Abraham Lincoln made it a federal holiday. It is, in other words, a celebration of national unity. And our national unity is indeed something to be thankful for.

headline: The G.M.O. Debate Turns to Salmon
abstract: Reactions to the F.D.A.’s approval of genetically engineered salmon that does not need to be labeled as such.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Where Are the Post-Boomers in Democratic Politics?
abstract: Readers discuss an Op-Ed essay about a “lost generation of Democrats.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: New York Schools Gap
abstract: A school psychologist asks, If, “on the Upper West Side, we cannot face this, how can the country?”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How to Prosecute Abusive Prosecutors
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Public Defenders and Court-Appointed Lawyers (Criminal)', 'District Attorneys']
abstract: Federal law allows for criminal charges against abusive judges and district attorneys.
lead_paragraph: WHEN it comes to poor people arrested for felonies in Scott County, Miss., Judge Marcus D. Gordon doesn’t bother with the Constitution. He refuses to appoint counsel until arrestees have been formally charged by an indictment, which means they must languish in jail without legal representation for as long as a year.

headline: The ‘Made in Israel’ Label
abstract: The European ambassador to the United States defends E.U. guidelines for products made in the settlements.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: False Alarms About a National Crime Wave
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Urban Areas', 'Statistics', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: Despite concerns over a short-term rise in murder rates, overall crime statistics are still at a low point compared with those in recent decades.
lead_paragraph: The headlines are alarming: Murder is up around the country, caused by anything from more guns to a heroin epidemic to the so-called “Ferguson Effect” — the disputed idea that police officers have become less aggressive out of fear that their actions will be recorded by civilians and criticized after the fact.

headline: Turn the Volume Down on Drug Ads
abstract: Consumers should be skeptical of prescription drug advertisements.
lead_paragraph: Watching television these days means sitting through ads for drugs to ease pain, induce sleep, overcome sexual dysfunction, alleviate depression, ease urinary tract symptoms and more. Some patients say the ads are helpful, but many doctors warn that they are often misleading.

headline: Black Tape at Harvard Law
abstract: People seem to assume that I should feel deeply alarmed and hurt after an incident on campus. I don’t.
lead_paragraph: Cambridge, Mass. — IN a grand corridor of Harvard Law School, framed professors’ photographs hang on a wall. A week ago, someone put slivers of black tape over the faces of most of the African-American professors. I am one of those whose photograph was marked.

headline: Communities of Character
abstract: If we actually want to build real character, we should model on schools that build real community.
lead_paragraph: We live in an individualistic age. As Marc J. Dunkelman documents in his book “The Vanishing Neighbor,” people tend to have their close group of inner-ring family and friends and then a vast online outer-ring network of contacts, but they are less likely to be involved in middle-ring community organizations.

headline: Chinese Stocks Plunge 5.5%, Their Biggest Single-Day Drop in 3 Months
abstract: Investors appeared to be cashing out to invest in new initial public offerings, and they were reacting to news that two brokerage firms were being investigated.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Just when it looked as if a relative calm was returning to Chinese markets, stocks nose-dived again on Friday. The main Shanghai share index lost 5.5 percent.

headline: Paris Slowly Coming to Terms With a New Vulnerability
abstract: The city wants to get past the lost tourism and uncertainties that followed the Nov. 13 attacks. But as candles burn low and bouquets wilt, a certain shock lingers.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Two weeks after the Nov. 13 attacks here, many of the memorials around the monument in the Place de la République are bedraggled, the hand-drawn signs rain-soaked, the candles exhausted, the flowers dropping their petals.

headline: Tighter Lid on Records Threatens to Weaken Government Watchdogs
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Archives and Records']
abstract: Investigations are being hampered by a dispute between the White House and its own watchdogs over the shrinking access of inspectors general to confidential files.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Department watchdogs ran into an unexpected roadblock last year when they began examining the role of federal drug agents in the fatal shootings of unarmed civilians during raids in Honduras.

headline: Teammates for Life
abstract: Madelyn Walters and Jason Wheeler were brought together by baseball, and as he works to reach the major leagues, they are determined to support each other’s dreams.
lead_paragraph: Madelyn Walters and Jason Wheeler were brought together by baseball, and as he works to reach the major leagues, they are determined to support each other’s dreams.

headline: Teammates and Cheerleaders for Life
abstract: When the baseball player Jason Wheeler spent a summer with Madelyn Walters and her family in Massachusetts, his prospects picked up.
lead_paragraph: There are no fancy hotels, first-class flights or rubbing elbows with celebrities in the anxious life of a minor-league baseball player as he dreams of making it to the major leagues. Most of those dreams take place on late-night bus rides along the lonely roads and dimly lit highways that run through the heart of baseball’s minor league circuit.

headline: Chinese Rights Advocate Known as Guo Feixiong Convicted of Unexpected New Charge
abstract: The addition of new charge, “picking quarrels and provoking trouble,” means that he will spend an additional two years in prison, according to his lawyers.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Yang Maodong, a hardened veteran of political protest in southern China, knew he had virtually no hope of winning his freedom on Friday when he was brought into a courtroom to face a judge’s verdict on charges that he had disturbed public order.

headline: A Patek Watch and a Record Price
abstract: A Reference 5016A-010, custom made with a steel case, sold at auction in Geneva for $7.3 million, a wristwatch record.
lead_paragraph: Watch industry buzz has been continuing all month about the $7.3 million price — a record high for a wristwatch — achieved by the Patek Philippe Reference 5016A-010 (left) at the Only Watch auction in Geneva. The amount was 10 times the low estimate of the sale price.

headline: Statement by Chinese Rights Campaigner Sentenced to 6 Years in Prison
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: Yang Maodong, known as Guo Feixiong, wrote down his thoughts in anticipation of the ruling, and the document was released by his wife.
lead_paragraph: Yang Maodong, a Chinese human rights campaigner better known by his pen name, Guo Feixiong, was sentenced on Friday to six years in prison on charges of “assembling a crowd to disrupt public order” and “picking quarrels and provoking trouble.” Prosecutors had cited his role in organizing support for journalists protesting censorship at the Guangzhou newspaper Southern Weekend and for rallies calling for China to ratify the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

headline: Six French Films That Speak to the Identity of the Nation
abstract: Revisiting a half-dozen movies that seem especially relevant to the work of thinking and understanding that lies ahead after the Nov. 13 attacks on Paris.
lead_paragraph: The shock of the Nov. 13 attacks in and around Paris refocused attention on debates that have convulsed French society for decades — about the marginalization of the Muslim population, about the tensions between Islam and French Republican ideology, about the identity of the nation itself.

headline: Art for the Holidays: A New York Visitors Guide
abstract: A user’s guide to art, indoors and outdoors, in New York during the holiday season.
lead_paragraph: So you’re coming to New York City around the holidays, and you’d like to see some art?

headline: Online Polls Are Rising. So Are Concerns About Their Results.
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voting and Voters', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Nowhere is the question of the accuracy of the new Internet polls more evident than in the results for Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Two of the most important trend lines in political campaign polling might be about to cross.

headline: Q. and A.: Lu Yang on Art, ‘Uterus Man’ and Living Life on the Web
abstract: The Shanghai-born new media artist has produced a series of boundary-pushing multimedia works that explore neuroscience, mortality and religion.
lead_paragraph: While the new media artist Lu Yang was studying at the China Academy of Art in Hangzhou in the 2000s, she drew up a series of works dealing with mind control. Many were deemed too sensitive, even borderline unethical, and remain unrealized. But with the help of the Fukuoka Asian Art Museum in Japan, Ms. Lu was able to obtain dead frogs that had been used in a medical dissection to produce one of the works. The result is a six-minute video called “Reanimation!  Underwater Zombie Frog Ballet” (2011), in which frogs wired to electrodes dance in water to a funky electronic beat.

headline: Turkey Seeks to Ease Tensions Over Shooting Down of Russian Jet
abstract: Ankara said airstrikes against the Islamic State in Syria had been suspended as it sought a solution, possibly at the Paris climate talks next week.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkey took steps on Friday to calm relations with Russia over the shooting down of a Russian warplane this week, calling for a presidential-level meeting, possibly at the climate talks in Paris next week.

headline: 100 Notable Books of 2015
abstract: The year’s notable fiction, poetry and nonfiction, selected by the editors of The New York Times Book Review.
lead_paragraph: The year’s notable fiction, poetry and nonfiction, selected by the editors of The New York Times Book Review. This list represents books reviewed since Dec. 7, 2014, when we published our previous Notables list.

headline: In ‘Transparent,’ a Heroine Evolves Further Still
abstract: For Season 2 of Amazon’s hit show, the director and showrunner Jill Soloway explores family history and introduces new shades into the character of Maura.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — On the set of “Transparent,” a handful of actors dressed for a flashback scene on a 1930s ocean liner — cloche hats, woolen jackets, long skirts — crowd together on benches in a large wooden container perched atop a gimbal, a device that can simulate the rolling of a ship. Sitting cross-legged on a long table a few yards away, the director Jill Soloway, who created this Amazon series, quietly throws out a few suggestions to the gently swaying actors.

headline: 1957 | When Pfizer and The Times Worked Closely
abstract: The editorial board said this week that the Pfizer-Allergan merger should have been illegal. In the ’50s, The Times was much more solicitous.
lead_paragraph: Our editorial board wasted no words this week in describing the planned combination of the drug companies Pfizer and Allergan as a “tax-dodging maneuver that enriches shareholders and executives while shortchanging the public and robbing the Treasury of money.”

headline: 1915: Goal of American Red Cross
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The Red Cross hopes to raise $100 million in 1915.
lead_paragraph: One hundred million dollars is the financial goal of the American Red Cross Society, announced yesterday [Nov. 9] at a meeting held at the residence of Mrs. Whitelaw Reid, 451 Madison Avenue. A movement was also started to place all war relief societies organized here since the outbreak of the war under the direct control of the Red Cross. Miss Mabel Boardman, head of the Red Cross organization, said she hoped the money would be given as an endowment fund to place the society on the same basis as the Rockefeller and Carnegie funds. She urged every man, woman and child in this country to join the Red Cross and give $1.50 a year to help in this new movement for preparedness. Mr. Joseph H. Choate presided at the meeting. — The New York Herald, European Edition, November 28, 1915

headline: Student Debt in America: Lend With a Smile, Collect With a Fist
keywords: ['Student Loans', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Credit and Debt', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Debt Collection']
abstract: The story of how a teacher ended up $410,000 in debt reveals the deep contradictions in the federal government’s approach to student loans.
lead_paragraph: The American student loan crisis is often seen as a problem of profligacy and predation. Wasteful colleges raise tuition every year, we are told, even as middle-class wages stagnate and unscrupulous for-profit colleges bilk the unwary. The result is mounting unmanageable debt.

headline: Financial Abuse of the Elderly: Sometimes Unnoticed, Always Predatory
abstract: Exploiters are increasingly taking financial advantage of older adults, often through investments, contracts or other fraud.
lead_paragraph: It was only after Mariana Cooper, a widow in Seattle, found herself with strained finances that she confessed to her granddaughter that she was afraid she had been bilked out of much of her savings.

headline: Finding a Path Back to Iraq, and Toward Securing Women’s Freedom
abstract: Yanar Mohammed runs a secret network of safe houses in Iraq meant to give women a second chance, but running them did so for her.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — YANAR MOHAMMED runs a secret network of safe houses in her native Iraq. The women who come through its doors are honor-killing runaways, rape survivors, war widows and assorted others who have been to the cliff edge of hell and back.

headline: Financial Considerations for Collectors of Art, Antiques and the Esoteric
keywords: ['Collectors and Collections', 'Personal Finances', 'ANTIQUES', 'Art', 'Finances', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Collectors who amass a sizable number of valuable objects; whether paintings, canes or history-changing machines, face a number of financial questions — not least how to dispose of their legacy.
lead_paragraph: LOOKING back on some of the most popular antiques he has sold, Bill Rau, chief executive of M.S. Rau Antiques in New Orleans, said two truly stood out for both their value and scarcity.

headline: 1940: Students Clash in Zagreb
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Radical Croatian students fight supporters of Yugoslav national unity in 1940.
lead_paragraph: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia — An incident that carries with it a heavy charge of political dynamite occurred in the Croatian university town of Zagreb today [Nov. 27] when extreme Croatian Nationalist students clashed with a group of ‘‘moderate’’ students supporting Dr. Vladko Matchek’s policy of co-operation with the Serbs. The fight, in which a number of students were seriously wounded, occurred on the occasion of a meeting held within the university by the extremist group, which favors independence for Croatia. The university was closed and guarded by the police so as to avoid a possible disturbance, but the ‘‘moderate’’ students — those favoring Yugoslav national unity — forced their way in through the cellar and tried to break up the meeting. The clash which ensued ended only when the police quickly restored order and made a number of arrests. The incident assumed special importance in view of Yugoslavia’s uncertain diplomatic relations with a number of her neighbors. The position of this country, nearly surrounded by potential foes, resembles that of Czecho-Slovakia in 1939. In the internal situation, too, there is a parallel. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 28, 1940

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Richard Paul Evans, whose novel “The Mistletoe Inn” is No. 9 on the hardcover fiction list, once heard from his fourth-grade teacher: “Your parents lied to you. There is no Santa.”
lead_paragraph: Killing Santa: Every year, around the time mall stores start playing “Frosty the Snowman” and Starbucks breaks out its red cups, the best-seller list hangs its stockings by the fire and waits for a visit from Richard Paul Evans. You know Evans: He’s the one whose self-published debut, “The Christmas Box,” sold something like eight million copies in the mid-1990s and landed him a fat contract with Simon & Schuster; since then, his cozy holiday-themed books have included “Finding Noel,” “The Christmas List,” “A Winter Dream” and “The Mistletoe Promise,” among others. Now he’s back, right on cue, with “The Mistletoe Inn,” new on the hardcover fiction list at No. 9. What draws Evans so repeatedly to Christmas? Readers prone to psychoanalyzing might find a clue on his website, where Evans describes the “tsunami of misfortune” that hit his family in 1970, the year he turned 8. “My father lost his job and couldn’t find work, and my mother began to exhibit the first signs of severe depression. My Tourette’s syndrome manifested that year and I was ticking like crazy. In addition, I wet the bed every night, made worse since I shared the bed with my brother,” he writes. “During this dark time I had a soul-crushing fourth-grade teacher named Mrs. Covey. I’ll never forget two weeks before Christmas when she ridiculed those of us who still believed in Santa with the words: ‘Your parents lied to you. There is no Santa.’ Crushed, I went home and asked my mother if she had lied. My mother frowned. She said, ‘Santa is the spirit of giving.’

headline: What Is Holding Back the Economy?
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Minimum Wage', 'Organized Labor', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Productivity', 'Recession and Depression', 'States (US)', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Conditions could be worse. They could also be so much better.
lead_paragraph: The Great Recession began in December 2007, and ended officially in June 2009. As of October 2015, the unemployment rates in half the states in the country had fallen to or below their pre-recession levels. In the other half, unemployment rates were still higher than before the recession.

headline: France, 2 Weeks After Paris Attacks, Observes National Day of Mourning
abstract: At an official ceremony, President François Hollande described the victims as “130 laughs that we won’t hear anymore, 130 voices that went quiet forever.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — France, still reeling from deadly terrorist attacks two weeks ago, held a national day of mourning on Friday, centered on a memorial service in Paris that was tinged with patriotism, solemnity and no lack of defiance.

headline: Iceland, Ireland, and Devaluation Denial
abstract: Ire was worse than Ice.
lead_paragraph: One of the big lessons of the euro crisis has been that Milton Friedman was right — not about monetarism, but about the case for flexible exchange rates. When big adjustments in a country’s wages and prices relative to trading partners are necessary, it’s much easier to achieve these adjustments via currency depreciation than via relative deflation — which is one main reason there have been such big costs to the euro.

headline: Kobe Bryant’s Decline Puts Lakers on Wrong Side of History
abstract: Despite poor numbers, Bryant remains the focal point of the Lakers, whom the Warriors beat to improve to 16-0 this week and who could provide a win for the 0-16 76ers next week.
lead_paragraph: The Warriors have become the first N.B.A. team to start a season 16-0. On Tuesday, the 76ers could become the first to start 0-19. In each case, the opponent for the record-breaking game is the Lakers.

headline: With N.F.L. Defenses Mining for Fumbles, Runners Treat the Ball Like Gold
abstract: Fumbles are on the decline as every team emphasizes ball protection, so some defenses go to extraordinary lengths to practice jarring the ball loose.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Greeting entrants to the locker room at the Eagles’ training complex is a nearly 7-foot-tall orange tackling dummy. Its right arm, elevated at a 90-degree angle like a passer’s, and its left, lowered and tucked into the body like a runner’s, each have half of a football stitched into them.

headline: Amaranto in Bushwick Is a Family Effort
abstract: This modest Mexican restaurant makes a thrilling tamale.

Mussels gawk from the bowl, mouths full of chorizo, cut in hunks like lardons.

headline: As Pope Francis’ Visit Nears, Central African Republic Violence Rises
abstract: The United Nations warned that a resurgence of violence has driven tens of thousands of people from their homes and threatens humanitarian aid.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Only days before Pope Francis is scheduled to visit the Central African Republic, the United Nations warned on Friday that a resurgence of violence in the conflict-torn nation has driven tens of thousands of people from their homes and increasingly threatens the delivery of humanitarian aid to the impoverished population.

headline: An Alley Entrance for a NoHo Condo
abstract: Great Jones Alley, between Broadway and Lafayette Street, will assume a more rarefied role when it becomes the exclusive entrance for a 12-story condominium.
lead_paragraph: The New York City alley, in all its grittiness, has long been a Hollywood favorite. Yet, in reality, New York has only a handful of them, as the designers of the city’s grid left little room for such passageways. Now one of the remaining few, Great Jones Alley, between Broadway and Lafayette Street, will assume a more rarefied role when it becomes the exclusive entrance for a 12-story condominium.

headline: Jim Gilmore Uses Free Airtime for Ad Tied to ISIS Threat
abstract: Jim Gilmore is using free on NBC airtime to demonstrate his national security credentials and his ability to confront the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: Don’t say Donald J. Trump hasn’t done Jim Gilmore any favors.

headline: At Grace Farms, Encountering Art at Every Bend
abstract: The 80-acre preserve in New Canaan opened to the public last month, with outdoor walkways linking spaces designed by famed architects for play and reflection.
lead_paragraph: Up close, each of the small silvered glass cubes in Teresita Fernández’s installation “Double Glass River” holds a tiny reflection of the glorious landscape it faces. From farther away, approximately 10,000 of those cubes coalesce into a flowing form stretching 61 feet across a curved wall. Wherever viewers stand, the piece changes with the weather, the season and the time of day.

headline: Israel to Open Diplomatic Office in United Arab Emirates
abstract: The mission at the International Renewable Energy Agency will be the first time in more than a decade that there will be an official Israeli presence in the Persian Gulf.
lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — Israel will open a diplomatic office in the United Arab Emirates, officials said Friday, the first time in more than a decade that there will be an official Israeli presence in the Persian Gulf.

headline: What Consumers Need to Know About Takata Airbag Recalls
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: Here’s what several automakers said when asked if new vehicles have Takata airbag inflaters, faulty versions of which have been linked to several deaths.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what several automakers said when asked if new vehicles have Takata airbag inflaters, faulty versions of which have been linked to several deaths.

headline: Navigating the Takata Airbag Recall
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: More than 19 million vehicles have already been recalled, and millions more could be affected in the next few years.
lead_paragraph: People take dozens of uncalculated risks each day. Every time they swallow a pill, bite into a burger or get behind the wheel, they are trusting the systems that delivered those products to market.

headline: Stuff We Liked: Thanksgiving Facts and Renaissance Table Manners
abstract: Our weekly roundup of amusing sites and links has a focus on festivity and food.
lead_paragraph: It should come as no surprise that some of the stuff we liked this week was Thanksgiving-related.

headline: Gentrification in a Brooklyn Neighborhood Forces Residents to Move On
abstract: Amid rapid gentrification, African-Americans and West Indians living in Crown Heights for generations are going east, or sometimes even out of the country.
lead_paragraph: They are a living reminder of the challenges facing a city struggling to make room for all its current residents, and all the new ones to come: the people of an older Crown Heights, who cannot afford the new.

headline: Working to Lower Drug Costs by Challenging Questionable Patents
abstract: The Coalition for Affordable Drugs goes after pharmaceutical companies that it says exploit the patent system to keep prices and profits high.
lead_paragraph: J. Kyle Bass made a fortune in the financial crisis when his hedge fund, Hayman Capital Management, bet big against subprime mortgages. Now Mr. Bass is wagering against pharmaceutical companies that he says exploit the patent system, keeping drug prices — and their profits — in the stratosphere.

headline: A Famous Crooner Paints the Good Life
abstract: Mornings in Central Park, Tony Bennett can often be found indulging his passion for painting before the crowds arrive.
lead_paragraph: Mornings in Central Park, Tony Bennett can often be found indulging his passion for painting before the crowds arrive.

headline: Tony Bennett Finds His Heart in Central Park
abstract: Mr. Bennett’s identity as a painter is entwined with the park, which he says nourishes his creativity and is his antidote to urbanity.
lead_paragraph: Tony Bennett sat on a green bench in the morning calm of Central Park, painting the fiery foliage of a tree reflecting against a duck pond.

headline: New York Celebrates Billy Strayhorn’s Centennial With Special ‘A Train’ Ride
abstract: Concerts celebrating the jazz great will take place Sunday evening and Nov. 29 will be designated “Billy Strayhorn Day.”
lead_paragraph: All aboard the A Train! This Sunday, Jazz at Lincoln Center will celebrate the centennial of jazz great Billy Strayhorn with a series of performances — including a surprise pop-up concert on the subway that inspired Strayhorn’s most famous composition, “Take the A Train.”

abstract: This week’s properties include a five-bedroom in Holmdel, N.J., and a six-bedroom in Sea Cliff, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a five-bedroom in Holmdel, N.J., and a six-bedroom in Sea Cliff, N.Y.

headline: Big Ticket | The Dakota
abstract: Lauren Bacall’s three-bedroom co-op apartment was sold by her estate for $21 million.
lead_paragraph: Lauren Bacall’s three-bedroom co-op apartment was sold by her estate for $21 million.

headline: Lauren Bacall’s Dakota Apartment Sold for $21 Million
abstract: The grand three-bedroom at the landmark Upper West Side co-op building was the sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: The grand apartment at the landmark Dakota that Lauren Bacall called home for more than half a century, filling its nine commodious rooms with an eclectic mix of artwork, antiques and countless mementos, many of them from her fabled Hollywood career, sold for $21,000,000 and was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: How Daniel Jacobs, Boxing World Champion, Spends His Sundays
abstract: In the months before a fight, Mr. Jacobs lives and trains on Long Island, leaving only Sundays to spend with his partner and their son in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Jacobs, a son of Brownsville, Brooklyn, is the World Boxing Association’s middleweight champion. Before that, he was a cancer survivor. Mr. Jacobs, 28, learned he had osteosarcoma in 2011, which could have ended his career. Instead, after surgery and radiation, he returned to the ring 19 months later and has been undefeated since. He is set to defend his title against Peter Quillin at Barclays Center next Saturday. In the months before a fight, Mr. Jacobs lives and trains on Long Island, leaving only to spend Sundays in Brooklyn with his partner, Natalie Stevens, 28, a makeup artist, and their son, Nathaniel Jacobs, 6.

headline: Once in Guantánamo, Afghan Now Leads War Against Taliban and ISIS
abstract: Officials describe Hajji Ghalib as a fiercely effective fighter against the insurgency, and the American military supports his men with airstrikes.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Hajji Ghalib did just what the American military feared he would after his release from the Guantánamo Bay prison camp: He returned to the Afghan battlefield.

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
abstract: This week’s properties are in the East Village; in Greenwich Village; and in Park Slope Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in New York City:

headline: A Review of ‘Miracle on 34th Street: The Musical’
abstract: A musical version of a classic Christmas movie brings the search for the truth about Santa Claus from the screen to the the John W. Engeman Theater at Northport.
lead_paragraph: When the show now known as “Miracle on 34th Street: The Musical” had its Broadway premiere in 1963, it was called “Here’s Love,” and received reviews that varied wildly, including a rather dismissive one from The New York Times (“right off the assembly line, shrewdly engineered,” the critic Howard Taubman wrote).

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties are in the East Village; in Greenwich Village; and in Park Slope Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are in the East Village; in Greenwich Village; and in Park Slope Brooklyn.

headline: When Some Turn to Church, Others Go to CrossFit
abstract: A for-profit gym franchise has become the focus of study by researchers trying to pinpoint what constitutes religiosity in America.
lead_paragraph: Ali Huberlie, a 27-year-old education consultant in Boston, awakens at 4:45 every morning to go to her CrossFit “box,” or gym, where she spends two hours. When she and her boyfriend, whom she met through CrossFit, went apartment-hunting, they chose a neighborhood near their box. This year, as a student at Harvard Business School, Ms. Huberlie wrote a case study about a founder of CrossFit that was incorporated into the school’s curriculum. And when Harvard Divinity School researchers were studying spaces other than churches that function as spiritual communities, they interviewed Ms. Huberlie.

headline: Fantasy Football Week 12: Rankings and Matchup Analysis
abstract: Fantasy football analysis for N.F.L. Week 12 games, including Monday’s matchup between the Baltimore Ravens and the Cleveland Browns.
lead_paragraph: Fantasy football analysis for N.F.L. Week 12 games and Monday’s matchup between the Baltimore Ravens and the Cleveland Browns. You can also follow the Sablich brothers on Twitter at @5thDownFantasy and see their complete Week 12 player rankings.

headline: Her Art Hangs in Museums and ‘Empire’
abstract: Ebony G. Patterson, a multimedia artist from Jamaica, tackles social issues in her colorful portraits.
lead_paragraph: AGE 34

headline: Suspect Charged in Chicago Shooting
abstract: Chicago police announced that charges have been brought against 27-year-old Corey Morgan for shooting 9-year-old Tyshawn Lee.
lead_paragraph: Chicago police announced that charges have been brought against 27-year-old Corey Morgan for shooting 9-year-old Tyshawn Lee.

headline: Anger Over Killing by Police Halts Shopping in Chicago
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: Demonstrators are demanding changes in the aftermath of the death of Laquan McDonald, a black 17-year-old, who was shot 16 times.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Hundreds of demonstrators on Friday marched down the middle of North Michigan Avenue, the city’s premier downtown shopping district, forcing the police to close the six-lane thoroughfare to vehicles and prompting some businesses to lock their doors for at least part of one of the busiest shopping days of the year.

headline: Justin Bieber and Ariana Grande Use an Award Show to Speed a Comeback
abstract: Pop stars are bouncing back with whiplash-inducing speed thanks to social media.
lead_paragraph: Watching the rapturous reactions to the performances of Justin Bieber and Ariana Grande on the American Music Awards last Sunday, you would have been hard-pressed to recall that one was an immature scofflaw recently dismissed as a has-been, and the other’s career seemed all but dead after getting caught on video licking a doughnut at a Southern California bakery and saying, “I hate America.”

headline: Baking Books 2015
abstract: Dessert cookbooks from Food52, the Violet Bakery in London, François Payard, and more.
lead_paragraph: Dessert cookbooks from Food52, the Violet Bakery in London, François Payard, and more.

headline: Joseph Silverstein, Violinist and Boston Symphony Concertmaster, Dies at 83
abstract: Mr. Silverstein, a conductor and violinist, joined the orchestra as its youngest player in 1955 before becoming its ninth concertmaster in 1962.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Silverstein, a conductor and violinist who was concertmaster of the Boston Symphony Orchestra for 22 years, died on Nov. 21 in Springfield, Mass. He was 83.

headline: The Sound of Mavericks at Copland House
abstract: Dedicated to the creation and presentation of American music, Copland House will present “American Mavericks” on Dec. 6, in Westchester.
lead_paragraph: The sun was setting outside Aaron Copland’s home in Cortlandt Manor as November winds began to blow. But inside, amid the cozy music room, the rehearsal was heating up as the pianist Michael Boriskin and the ensemble Music From Copland House rendered a rousing version of Charles Ives’s epic Trio for Violin, Cello and Piano.

headline: Baking Cookbooks That (Gently) Push the Limits
keywords: ['Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Desserts', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: From Scandinavia, France, England and the United States, these recipes sweetly tweak tradition. (Article plus video.)
lead_paragraph: With cookbooks, those on the savory side have a lot more leeway to showcase innovative ideas and far-flung dishes. Armchair chefs are just as happy to read about smoking eels over green hay and butchering small game as they are to find a recipe for the best macaroni and cheese.

headline: 3 Are Dead in Colorado Springs Shootout at Planned Parenthood Center
abstract: A police officer and two civilians were killed and the authorities arrested a suspect, suggesting he had brought explosive devices with him.
lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — A gun battle erupted inside a Planned Parenthood center here on Friday when a man armed with an assault-style rifle opened fire and began shooting at officers as they rushed to the scene. The authorities reported that three people were killed, a police officer and two civilians, and nine were wounded before the suspect finally surrendered more than five hours after the first shots were fired.

headline: Things to Do in New Jersey, Nov. 27 to Dec. 6, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Scientists Link Moon’s Tilt and Earth’s Gold
abstract: Two planetary scientists believe that large objects passed the moon repeatedly over tens of millions of years and tipped its orbit, some hitting Earth and leaving precious metals behind.
lead_paragraph: The moon’s orbit is askew, and two planetary scientists believe that they have come up with a good reason.

headline: ‘Black-ish’ Star Yara Shahidi Is a Role Model Off-Screen
abstract: When the 15-year-old actress isn’t taping her hit ABC sitcom, she is a full-time activist and honor student.
lead_paragraph: “Life as a teenager can be down right chaotic,” the actress Yara Shahidi, 15, told an audience last month at Cipriani 42nd Street, where she was being honored by the Young Women’s Leadership Network. “We must also realize that it is up to us whether these years will feel like a melancholy struggle or an opportunity for growth or experiences of a lifetime.”

headline: Supreme Court Justice Intervenes in Native Hawaiian Election
abstract: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy ordered officials not to tally votes or name winners until the full court can rule on the election, which opponents say is discriminatory.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Anthony M. Kennedy on Friday ordered officials in Hawaii not to count ballots or name the winners of an election there in which only people of native Hawaiian ancestry could vote.

headline: News Article Appears to Contradict Trump’s Claim About Reporter
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'News and News Media', 'Newspapers', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'September 11 (2001)']
abstract: The New York Daily News on Friday released an archived news article that seemed to contradict a claim by Donald J. Trump that he knew nothing about a reporter whose disability Mr. Trump appeared to mock at a rally earlier this week.
lead_paragraph: The New York Daily News released an archived news article on Friday that seemed to contradict a claim by Donald J. Trump that he knew nothing about a reporter whose disability Mr. Trump appeared to mock at a rally earlier this week.
