headline: Review: Trifonov Caps Rachmaninoff Fest With Pianistic Verve
abstract: Daniil Trifonov, newly on the New York Philharmonic board, played the Third Piano Concerto in a program with “Symphonic Dances,” led by Ludovic Morlot.
lead_paragraph: Not every new board member of the New York Philharmonic gets to celebrate his or her ascendance by playing Rachmaninoff’s Third Piano Concerto to a full house at David Geffen Hall. And thank goodness for that.

headline: Adele Goes Viral, No Selfies or Tweets Needed
keywords: ['Music', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Records and Achievements']
abstract: A 27-year-old mother who pretty much ignores social media is selling more albums than anyone in the sagging music business thought was still possible.
lead_paragraph: There is no one in music quite like Adele.

headline: Adele Joins Limp Bizkit in an Exclusive Club
abstract: The singer’s “25” sold 3.38 million copies in the United States through its first week. The last time an album sold nearly that well was in 2000, when 2.4 million copies of “No Strings Attached” by ’N Sync were sold.
lead_paragraph: The singer’s “25” sold 3.38 million copies in the United States through its first week. The last time an album sold nearly that well was in 2000, when 2.4 million copies of “No Strings Attached” by ’N Sync were sold.

headline: 36 Hours in Adelaide, Australia
abstract: No longer simply a stop on the way to its celebrated wine region, the city has seen a revival of cafes and an arts scene, among other draws.
lead_paragraph: No longer simply a stop on the way to its celebrated wine region, the city has seen a revival of cafes and an arts scene, among other draws.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review Podcast: Lisa Randall’s ‘Dark Matter and the Dinosaurs’
abstract: Randall talks about her new book, and Louisa Lim discusses five memoirs about fleeing North Korea.
lead_paragraph: Listen to this week’s podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | Stitcher

headline: Review: Ann Hampton Callaway Honors Her Predecessors at Feinstein’s/54 Below
abstract: Ms. Callaway performs songs from the likes of Ella Fitzgerald and Sarah Vaughan in her show “Feminine Persuasion: Ann Hampton Callaway Celebrates Women Songwriters.”
lead_paragraph: Ann Hampton Callaway belongs to the school of gifted pop singers for whom majestic vocal display is not enough. Along with Barbra Streisand and Celine Dion, to name two obvious examples, Ms. Callaway uses pyrotechnics as a platform for conveying inspirational messages of peace and hope. And the opening-night performance of her new show at Feinstein’s/54 Below, “Feminine Persuasion: Ann Hampton Callaway Celebrates Women Songwriters,” often had a sticky undertone of sentimentality.

headline: Shooting in Planned Parenthood Clinic
abstract: Authorities responded to an “active shooter” near a Planned Parenthood clinic in Colorado Springs.
lead_paragraph: Authorities responded to an “active shooter” near a Planned Parenthood clinic in Colorado Springs.

headline: The Pain in Spain Falls Mainly Away From BBVA
abstract: Unlike its domestic peers, the Spanish bank didn’t lend to the teetering engineering group. Nor did it invest in Bankia’s failed I.P.O. or Spain’s bad bank, Sareb.
lead_paragraph: BBVA, Spain’s second-largest bank, is often seen as more conservative than its Spanish peers. That reputation now looks deserved. The bank is the only major domestic player that does not have exposure to Abengoa, the Spanish engineering company seeking protection from its creditors.

headline: Restaurant Review: Porta Napoli Offers Pizza for Every Palate
abstract: The Harrison restaurant lists more than 40 kinds of pie, such as margherita and meatball, and sweet variations like Nutella and vanilla bean.
lead_paragraph: In early September, Porta Napoli in Harrison took the place of Rue des Crepes, known for its theatrical Parisian décor and its neatly folded buckwheat crepes. It is Naples, not Paris, that the new proprietors hope to bring to mind. “Authenticity” is the catchword. Wood embers glow in a fire-engine-red pizza oven, which spreads cheer like a giant emoji. Menu headings are in Italian (sfizi, insalate, pizze rossi, pizze bianche). The flour in the supple pizza dough is “00” (doppio zero), as required by the Associazione Verace Pizza Napoletana. The wine list covers regions from Sicily to the Alps but never strays beyond Italy’s borders.

headline: In London, Portuguese Fare, Served With a Twist
abstract: At Taberna, the food is traditional Portuguese as seen through the eyes of an imaginative, skilled chef. But this sharp focus does not mean monotony.
lead_paragraph: Though the chef Nuno Mendes was born in Lisbon and trained mostly in the United States, it’s his London restaurants — Chiltern Firehouse, for example — that have gained attention. His latest is Taberna do Mercado in East London’s Old Spitalfields Market. The informal, tightly packed 40-seat restaurant (with additional tables and a charcoal grill outside) looks like a sleek version of a Portuguese tavern: nothing fancy, but with plenty of attention to materials and details (including seating that is all too authentic: Some of the wooden chairs are really too small for grown-ups). The atmosphere is convivial; we had fun at the tiny concrete-topped bar, drinking and watching sausages being sliced.

headline: As World Leaders Launch Paris Climate Talks Monday, Bill Gates Will Launch a Supporting Science Push
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change']
abstract: As Paris talks on new climate targets begin, Bill Gates will unveil a new science push to help achieve emissions goals.
lead_paragraph: Here’s the White House announcement on “Mission Innovation” and Bill Gates’s explanation of the Breakthrough Energy Coalition:

headline: Permanent Punk Invasion
abstract: Denise Mercedes, who is in her 60s, plays in three bands and still looks and dresses like a glam goddess rock star.
lead_paragraph: “This is Pepe,” said Denise Mercedes, pulling out another cigarette and walking past her resplendent white cockatoo. “You should see him dance. He knows more about music than half the people I’ve played with.”

headline: Review: ‘Nora,’ Ingmar Bergman’s Adaptation of Henrik Ibsen’s ‘A Doll’s House’
abstract: Austin Pendleton has directed this version, at the Cherry Lane Studio, in which Torvald Helmer is startlingly different from what is expected.
lead_paragraph: Torvald Helmer isn’t generally viewed as a likable guy, but Ingmar Bergman thought of him that way. To him, the injured party at the end of Henrik Ibsen’s “A Doll’s House” is Helmer, crushed by the “aggression and brutality” of his wife, Nora.

headline: What We’re Reading
keywords: ['Comic Books and Strips', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Jenna Wortham, George Gustines and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week.

headline: Restaurant Review: At Atelier Florian in New Haven, Seafood Is King
abstract: The main attractions at this Belgian bistro are the seafood options, including the bouillabaise, and moules frites — mussels, steamed in dry vermouth and served with fries.
lead_paragraph: Is there a better finish to a cold, blustery day on the New England coast than a steaming bowl of bouillabaisse? I mean the real deal: a rich, tomatoey, fish broth fragrant with saffron, fennel and garlic, and crowded with seafood that — if you’re lucky — was caught just a few miles away.

headline: Restaurant Review: At Sandbar, Familiar French Hands Behind the Menu
abstract: Good looks aside, for Long Islanders the draw at Sandbar is Guy Reuge, the award-winning Frenchman who opened Mirabelle Restaurant in St. James in 1983.
lead_paragraph: Sandbar, a sparkling new restaurant that opened in Cold Spring Harbor in late September, is a beauty. Diners enter through a bar with a soaring glass ceiling and emerge into an elegant dining room with plenty of windows, 11 chandeliers and pale, sand-colored walls. The light, bright room nonetheless has a subdued nautical look, with antique mahogany half hulls lining the walls, along with lovely paintings of the harbor by local artists.

headline: Window Onto a Butcher Shop at the Cooper Hewitt
abstract: The Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum in Manhattan allows visitors to digitally view items that are located offsite in Newark, N.J., including an 18th-century model of a British butcher’s shop.
lead_paragraph: When visitors walk through the big bronze doors of the Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, they are issued the Pen, the institute’s remarkable Internet-accessible stylus. The 1901 Beaux-Arts building then becomes, in the words of The Atlantic magazine, “the museum of the future.”

headline: An Expat’s Eye on Greece
abstract: Dimitri Mellos’s guide to his native land aims to take viewers past the pretty postcard images of sun-drenched beaches.
lead_paragraph: Dimitri Mellos’s guide to his native land aims to take viewers past the pretty postcard images of sun-drenched beaches.

headline: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
abstract: France and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: France and More — Pictures of the Day

abstract: Christmastime windows at department stores grow more elaborate.
lead_paragraph: Christmastime windows at department stores grow more elaborate.

headline: The Artist Behind Candice Swanepoel’s Leather Victoria’s Secret Wings
abstract: Jordan Betten, a model turned designer, created leather wings for the most recent Victoria’s Secret runway extravaganza.
lead_paragraph: A hairy wolf’s head that doubles as a shoulder bag glowers from a wall at Jordan Betten’s studio in West Chelsea. Striking it may be, but it’s not for sale, said Mr. Betten, the 41-year-old founder of Lost Art, a leather goods company that caters pretty much exclusively to fashion and rock royalty.

headline: Nov. 27, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from France, Kenya, Greece and Belgium.
lead_paragraph: Photos from France, Kenya, Greece and Belgium.

headline: Foul-Mouthed and Proud of It on the ’16 Campaign Trail
abstract: Seemingly taking a cue from Donald J. Trump, the Republican field is cursing in public at a rate unheard of in modern presidential politics.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump pledged to bomb the, uh, stuffing out of the Islamic State.

headline: ‘Jaco,’ a Documentary About the Jazz Musician Jaco Pastorius
abstract: A master of the fretless electric bass guitar, Pastorius died tragically at the age of 35.
lead_paragraph: When Jaco Pastorius first met Joe Zawinul, the keyboardist and composer behind Weather Report, he had his introduction ready. “My name is John Francis Pastorius III,” he said, as Zawinul later remembered. “I’m the greatest bass player in the world.”

headline: New Women’s Political Party in Britain Demands Faster Equality
keywords: ["Women's Rights", 'Discrimination', 'Women and Girls', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Gender', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Weary of delays, a comedian and two journalists have begun the daunting process of forging a party separate from the traditional political power base.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It may seem an inopportune time to start a new party, given Britain’s crowded political scene, but Sandi Toksvig says she is tired of waiting.

headline: National Geographic Takes Travelers to the Falklands
abstract: Lindblad Expeditions-National Geographic is introducing Falklands 360°, its circumnavigation of the Falkland Islands.
lead_paragraph: Lindblad Expeditions-National Geographic is introducing Falklands 360°, its circumnavigation of the Falkland Islands. The voyage will also feature a visit to Argentina’s Isla de los Estados, a national nature preserve. Set aboard the 102-passenger National Geographic Orion, the 13-day expedition will depart twice in October next year. Rates begin at $10,850 per person based on double occupancy.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Bagatelle
abstract: Accessories and charms are dangling from bags and carryalls.
lead_paragraph: Accessories and charms are dangling from bags and carryalls. The idea started with the Fendi Lagerfeld fur-doll charm, but Victor-John Villanueva’s portraits have enlarged the idea to the level of a child’s fantasy or the balloons in the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade. A favored subject of Mr. Villanueva is the late performance artist Leigh Bowery, an outrageously dressed drag provocateur from Australia who was the toast of London clubs in the 1980s.

headline: Evening Hours | Pre-Thanksgiving Rush
abstract: Celebrating a Parisienne’s style, cultural exchange and more.
lead_paragraph: Celebrating a Parisienne’s style, cultural exchange and more.

headline: Review: In ‘The Spymasters,’ C.I.A. Leaders Recount Tactics of the Post-9/11 Years
abstract: This two-hour documentary on Showtime abaout the secret wars that have wholly remade a spy agency is at turns engrossing, maddening and unsatisfying.
lead_paragraph: “The Spymasters” begins with an act of vengeance.

headline: The Season’s Fashion Books From Cindy Crawford, Terry Richardson and More
abstract: Holiday gift books offer insight into American greats.
lead_paragraph: There’s often an exotic quality to the massive, lushly photographed books that emerge on coffee tables every holiday season: They dazzle the eye with distant icebergs, cheetah-flecked savannas, endangered birds midflight, coral reefs and majestic mountains. But some of this year’s most striking gift books evoke the natural beauty of monuments much nearer at hand.

headline: Preparing ‘The Golden Bride’ for Its Big Day
abstract: After a reconstruction decades in the making, this Yiddish-language operetta, which was a hit when it had its premiere in 1923, is about to have its first fully staged production.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Policar, a 27-year-old with a master’s degree in vocal performance, has been trained to sing German, French and Italian. Yiddish? Not so much.

headline: Kentucky, Beacon for Health Law, Now a Lab for Its Retreat
keywords: ['Series', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicaid', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The only Southern state to embrace the Affordable Care Act appears headed in a different direction under a new governor, Matt Bevin.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Carolyn Bouchard, a diabetic with a slowly healing shoulder fracture, hurried to see her doctor after Matt Bevin was elected governor here this month.

headline: A Slippery Number: How Many Books Can Fit in the New York Public Library?
abstract: Estimates for the capacity of the old shelves at the library have ranged widely, and critics are skeptical of a new 2.5 million figure.
lead_paragraph: As New York mysteries go, it hardly competes with “Who’s buried in Grant’s tomb?” or “How many pigeons live in the five boroughs?” But for devotees of the New York Public Library, the question of how many books can be stored in the majestic central stacks on Fifth Avenue is far from academic. They say it goes to the heart of the library’s mission to keep as many research books as possible within arm’s reach of scholars.

headline: Gunfire at a Colorado Planned Parenthood Clinic
abstract: A gunman inside the clinic in Colorado Springs engaged in a shootout with the police, killing three people and wounding others.
lead_paragraph: A gunman inside the clinic in Colorado Springs engaged in a shootout with the police, killing three people and wounding others.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Bill Gates will announce the creation of a multibillion-dollar clean energy fund on Monday at the opening of a Paris summit meeting intended to forge a global accord to cut planet-warming emissions, according to people with knowledge of the plans.

lead_paragraph: Naomi Campbell, Gigi Hadid, Demi Lovato and more sport winter’s It-chop.

lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — With its chief executive in jail, BTG Pactual tried to calm investors on Friday, saying that it would cooperate with any investigation.

headline: Maps of the Shooting at a Planned Parenthood Clinic
abstract: A gunman injured at least 11 people, including five police officers, at a Planned Parenthood clinic in Colorado Springs.
lead_paragraph: A gunman injured at least 11 people, including five police officers, at a Planned Parenthood clinic in Colorado Springs.

headline: Friday Night Music: The Civil Wars, Billie Jean
abstract: Speaking of covers.
lead_paragraph: Last week I featured The Lone Bellow reinterpreting the Rolling Stones, which was great; but by far the most revelatory cover I’ve ever heard is this one, by the oh-so-sadly broken-up Civil Wars:

headline: Black Voices Against Black Friday
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Protesters gathered on Chicago’s main shopping streets Friday to disrupt the shopping frenzy and draw attention to what they say is police brutality.
lead_paragraph: Protesters gathered on Chicago’s main shopping streets Friday to disrupt the shopping frenzy and draw attention to what they say is police brutality.

headline: Road to Robotic Parking Is Littered With Faulty Projects
abstract: Software and hardware mishaps, including some that have smashed or trapped cars, have occurred at robotic garages around the country, but dozens of them are proposed or underway.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI BEACH — It seemed like the perfect night life accessory for the South Beach set — an automated robotic parking garage where trendy clubgoers could park their Porsches with a futuristic touch of a button.

headline: Cubans Protest Stricter Rules for Traveling to Ecuador
abstract: Cubans crowded outside an Ecuadorean embassy, worried about a new visa requirement to enter Ecuador, a vital step to reach the United States.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Dozens of Cubans crowded outside Ecuador’s embassy in Havana on Friday, worried and angry about new rules that require Cubans to have a visa to enter Ecuador, which is a vital steppingstone for islanders trying to migrate to the United States.

headline: Instability in Marketplaces Draws Concern on Both Sides of Health Law
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'States (US)']
abstract: Insurers’ struggles in marketplaces created by the Affordable Care Act have emboldened both conservatives who want to shrink the federal role and liberals who want to expand it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The latest turmoil in health insurance marketplaces created by the Affordable Care Act has emboldened advocates on both sides of the political spectrum, providing ammunition to conservatives who want to shrink the federal role and liberals who want to expand it.

headline: Paris Attacks Darken Tone of G.O.P. Campaign Ads
abstract: Candidates and outside groups are starting to feel comfortable running ads about the attacks, navigating a delicate line in politicizing a tragedy.
lead_paragraph: The terrorist attacks in Paris immediately changed the course of the presidential race as national security and foreign policy rose to the top of stump speeches and television interviews.

headline: M.T.A. Contract Workers Push for Higher Wages and Better Working Conditions
abstract: Citing inadequate pay, discrimination and a bedbug-ridden office, call center workers for Access-A-Ride have filed a class-action lawsuit and threatened to strike.
lead_paragraph: Month after month, workers from a call center in Queens arrived at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s board meetings in Lower Manhattan to complain about low wages, a hostile work environment and bedbugs in their office.

headline: With Fewer Skaters, N.H.L. Hopes for More All-Star Competitiveness
abstract: The rules used in overtime during the regular season are popular with fans, and the league adopted them for its midseason showcase.
lead_paragraph: The N.H.L. announced last week that the All-Star Game, which had essentially become an Ice Capades, with virtually no contact and far too many goals, would be played in a three-on-three format, which has been used for the first time this season in the five-minute overtime period.

headline: Mental Illness Cited in Murder Case of Manhattan Hedge Fund Manager
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Thomas Gilbert Jr., who is accused of killing his father in January during an argument over spending money, has a serious mental illness, his lawyer argued in a hearing this month.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, Thomas Gilbert Jr. appeared to have it all: movie-star looks, wealthy parents, an Ivy League education and entree to elite social circles in Manhattan and the Hamptons.

headline: Two Sets of Twins Trace Lifetime Link to Two Teammates
abstract: Three decades ago Steve DeOssie and Jim Jeffcoat became friends, as did their wives. Each couple had twins, one boy and one girl apiece. Now the two boys play for the N.F.L., while the girls are co-workers in Colorado.
lead_paragraph: As a rookie linebacker and long snapper with the Dallas Cowboys in 1984, Steve DeOssie assumed a mentality of being “crazy all the time.” A second-year teammate, however, made an important impression. Defensive end Jim Jeffcoat showed DeOssie that it was possible to assume a separate mentality off the field.

headline: Black Friday Shopping Shifts Online as Stores See Less Foot Traffic
keywords: ['E-Commerce', 'Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'Mobile Commerce and Payments', 'Toys']
abstract: Total online sales are expected to generate $2.6 billion on Black Friday, a 14 percent increase compared to the same day last year.
lead_paragraph: In shops across the country, including the empty malls of Georgia and the “not too crazy” crowds at struggling J. Crew, the relative calm that accompanied Black Friday shopping this year belied a frenzy for deals — many of them on the web.

headline: The New Atomic Age We Need
abstract: If we are serious about replacing fossil fuels, we are going to need nuclear power.
lead_paragraph: THIS past summer, the Group of 7 nations promised “urgent and concrete action” to limit climate change. What actions exactly? Activists hope for answers from the coming United Nations climate conference in Paris, which begins Monday. They should look instead to Washington today.

headline: Affordable Housing vs. Gentrification
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Zoning', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Gentrification', 'Affordable Housing']
abstract: New Yorkers are finally getting their chance to say what they think of Mayor de Blasio’s plan.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio has a plan that he says will preserve economically diverse neighborhoods in New York City, significantly and permanently increase the affordable-housing supply and create a more attractive streetscape. In community meetings across the city, New Yorkers are finally having their chance to say whether they agree with him.

headline: France’s Cult of Fearlessness
abstract: Parisians won’t admit that they go to the gym, let alone that they’re scared of terrorists.
lead_paragraph: Paris — SINCE the attacks two weeks ago, I’ve been avoiding supermarkets — which seem like potential targets — and doing most of my shopping at a minimarket. The cashier there, a young man from Mali, keeps telling me not to be afraid.

headline: President Obama’s Hypocrisy on Syria
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: The refugee crisis illuminates the failure of his approach to politics.
lead_paragraph: IN 2008, Barack Obama won the presidency promising that he would heal our political divisions. Instead, Mr. Obama has been as polarizing as any president in the history of modern polling. The debate over the Syrian refugee crisis illustrates why.

headline: The Danger of Urban Oil Drilling
abstract: Los Angeles is accused of failing to address environmental consequences, especially in lower-income minority neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: Many Los Angeles residents are familiar with a sight that may seem strange to outsiders: an oil pump operating mere feet from businesses or homes. A recent lawsuit claims that the city has systematically failed to address drilling’s environmental consequences, especially in lower-income neighborhoods that are majority black and Latino.

headline: Helping Others and Accepting Help
abstract: A retired man cleans up his home with support from the Neediest Cases Fund.
lead_paragraph: Marvin Grossman, who will turn 79 on Tuesday, is used to doing things on his own. He never married or had children, but his life is filled with reading, writing and classical music. He is always willing to lend a hand to an elderly neighbor by running errands or doing the laundry.

headline: Setsuko Hara, Japanese Star of Films by Ozu and Kurosawa, Is Dead at 95
abstract: Ms. Hara was lauded for her portrayal of tragic heroines torn between duty and desire. Her abrupt retirement in the 1960s shocked Japan.
lead_paragraph: Setsuko Hara, one of Japan’s most beloved actresses, best known for her subtle portrayals of women torn between the demands of family and their own desires in “Late Spring,” “Tokyo Story” and other films directed by Yasujiro Ozu, died on Sept. 5 in Kamakura, near Tokyo. She was 95.

headline: Eldzier Cortor, Painter of Scenes From African-American Social Life, Dies at 99
abstract: Mr. Cortor was perhaps best known for elegant paintings of nude black women in an era when they were rare in mainstream art.
lead_paragraph: Eldzier Cortor, a painter and printmaker perhaps best known for his elegant paintings of nude black women created when such works were seldom seen in the mainstream art world, died on Thursday at his son’s home in Seaford, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 99.

headline: Unblinking Gazer
abstract: Tough-but-fair love from Ned White.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — On Saturdays, you have to approach a crossword carefully, with a healthy dose of suspicion, at least as it applies to the clues. Things are definitely not what they seem, but that’s what can make solving the toughest puzzle of the week so much fun. And today, the cluing is especially thoughtful and tricky.

headline: Joan Duddy, Nurtured Dance and Joyce SoHo in Manhattan, Dies at 78
abstract: Ms. Duddy was an influential curator and advocate for new dance as the founder and director of the dance program at the Dia Center for the Arts (now Joyce SoHo) in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Joan Duddy, an influential curator and advocate for new dance as the founder and director of the dance program at the Dia Center for the Arts (now Joyce SoHo) in Manhattan for 18 years, died on Nov. 7 in Cambridge, Mass. She was 78.

headline: A Rite to Improve Karma for Man, Creature and, Now, the Environment
abstract: Buddhists priests and local wildlife rescuers partner to ensure a more responsible release ritual, in which rehabilitated animals are freed in their natural habitats.
lead_paragraph: “It works better with turtles — turtles just stand there and stare at you,” Shi Benkong said as he stood near the Great Lawn in Central Park on Tuesday near several cardboard boxes containing not turtles but restless, rustling birds.

headline: With Legal Aid, Immigrant Advocates Turn Focus to Citizenship
abstract: With immigration reform stalled, New York advocacy groups have set their sights on shepherding legal residents on the path toward citizenship.
lead_paragraph: This election season, Sandra Ocampo is running her own campaign.

headline: Former Rikers Inmate Who Received Settlement Is Fatally Shot in Brooklyn
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Ex-Convicts', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: Robert Hinton, who was brutally beaten by guards while he was incarcerated, was killed on Friday, just months after receiving a $450,000 settlement from the city.
lead_paragraph: For Robert Hinton, 2015 was supposed to be a year of new beginnings. In March, he was released from prison after serving time for a parole violation. In September, he was awarded $450,000 by New York City to settle a lawsuit against several jail guards who hogtied and severely beat him in 2012 while he was incarcerated at Rikers Island.

headline: With Little Bench Relief, Knicks Run Out of Steam
abstract: The Knicks withered against the Miami Heat, their third consecutive defeat. The ugly loss ensured that the searching and tinkering would need to continue for the team.
lead_paragraph: The Knicks won 17 games last season, so the mere fact that they are no longer an unmitigated laughingstock has engendered an understandable measure of satisfaction among the team and its fans.

headline: Battling Blindness and a Family Health Crisis, but Seeing Hope
abstract: After Cimeron DuBose lost part of her eyesight, she focused on taking care of her loved ones. Then she and two other family members learned they had cancer.
lead_paragraph: Impaired vision has kept Cimeron DuBose from working for nearly 20 years. The days could be tedious, but they were also filled with purpose.

headline: Garrett Swasey, Officer Killed in Colorado, Is Recalled for Courage and Faith
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: The university police officer who was killed at the site of a Planned Parenthood shooting in Colorado Springs was a married father of two and co-pastor at a church.
lead_paragraph: Garrett Swasey, 44, the University of Colorado Colorado Springs police officer who was shot and killed while responding to a shooting at a Planned Parenthood office, was described by his fellow church members and friends as a courageous man and loving father who drew strength and inspiration from his Christian faith.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 28, 2015
lead_paragraph: “There are people out there for whom this may be the only record they’ve bought in five years. The last one may have been ‘21,’ and now they’re coming back in force.”

headline: What to Watch Saturday
abstract: A walk on the wild side in “Tangerine,” edible homes on the Food Network and spy movies — one real, one not so much.
lead_paragraph: Take a walk on the wild side with “Tangerine,” watch the Property Brothers build edible homes and choose between a couple of spy movies — one real, one not so much.

abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, November 28, 2015.

headline: Addicted to Distraction
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'E-Mail', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: How I lost, and found, my focus.
lead_paragraph: ONE evening early this summer, I opened a book and found myself reading the same paragraph over and over, a half dozen times before concluding that it was hopeless to continue. I simply couldn’t marshal the necessary focus.

headline: A New York Trainer to Men About Town
abstract: Stephen Cheuk runs S10 Training, a downtown Manhattan gym with a stylish male clientele.
lead_paragraph: Brendan Fallis, the D.J., entrepreneur and fashion model who is engaged to Hannah Bronfman, had a conundrum that many men concerned with fitness and style can relate to.

headline: OMG! The Hyperbole of Internet-Speak
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Text Messaging', 'English Language', 'Language and Languages', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Instant Messaging']
abstract: On death by Internet and the linguistic arms race to out-hyperbole each other with phrases like “Omg literally dying,” “I can’t even” and “yassssss.”
lead_paragraph: The text exchange was unspectacular: a friend explaining a video that had been posted by a classmate to his Snapchat feed. Jordana Narin, my 20-year-old research assistant, was half paying attention, sitting in my living room working on a project, texting between breaks.

headline: Swell of Tupperware-Type Parties Overwhelms City Dwellers
abstract: With trendy wares and social networking, a modern host can move far beyond Tupperware.
lead_paragraph: Nine women were gathered in the immaculate Midtown East apartment of Mallorie Corcoran, 29. Tall, svelte and long-maned, the guests and their hostess clustered around a table in the living room, picking at fruit platters and sandwiches but generously pouring themselves wine and seltzer.

headline: Elaborate Holiday Windows Dress Up New York Department Stores
keywords: ['Christmas', 'Shopping and Retail', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Windows', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Christmastime displays, long a tradition in the city, grow more embellished every year, as retailers hope to lure enchanted passers-by inside.
lead_paragraph: It was 61 degrees on a recent November evening, but the scaffolds outside Lord & Taylor on Fifth Avenue were trimmed with artificial fir, and Santa Claus himself was bopping with Liz Rodbell, the store’s president, to Austin Mahone’s “Mmm Yeah.”

headline: The Return of Werner Erhard, Father of Self-Help
abstract: The creator of EST resurfaces as a kinder, gentler purveyor of self-actualization.
lead_paragraph: The silver-haired man dressed like a waiter (dark vest, dark slacks) paced the aisle between rows of desks in a Toronto conference room. “If you’re going to be a leader, you’re going to have to have a very loose relationship with this thing you call ‘I’ or ‘me,’” he shouted. “Maybe that whole thing in me around which the universe revolves isn’t so central!”

headline: Paris Climate Talks Avoid Scientists’ Idea of ‘Carbon Budget’
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'Carbon Dioxide']
abstract: Nations have pointedly declined to take up a recommendation from scientists, made several years ago, that they set a cap on total greenhouse gases.
lead_paragraph: After two decades of talks that failed to slow the relentless pace of global warming, negotiators from almost 200 countries are widely expected to sign a deal in the next two weeks to take concrete steps to cut emissions.

headline: Tibetans Fight to Salvage Fading Culture in China
abstract: New measures scaling back the teaching of minority languages like Tibetan have threatened the survival of ethnic identities and traditions in China’s vast west.
lead_paragraph: YUSHU, China — When officials forced an informal school run by monks near here to stop offering language classes for laypeople, Tashi Wangchuk looked for a place where his two teenage nieces could continue studying Tibetan.

headline: Tashi Wangchuk: A Tibetan’s Journey for Justice
abstract: Worried about the erosion of Tibetan culture and language, one man takes his concerns to Beijing, hoping media coverage and the courts can reverse what he sees as a systematic eradication.
lead_paragraph: Worried about the erosion of Tibetan culture and language, one man takes his concerns to Beijing, hoping media coverage and the courts can reverse what he sees as a systematic eradication.

headline: In Colorado, Bustling With Shoppers, Then Gripped by Chaos
abstract: A barrage of bullets turned a busy, snow-covered shopping center in Colorado Springs into a tableau of chaos and fear that lasted over five hours.
lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — The injured man staggered into the grocery store, his face and chest bloodied. Customers stopped and stared. “He lifted his shirt up, and he had holes in his chest,” said Miranda Schilter, 17, who had been waiting for a drink at an in-store coffee shop.

headline: The Week on Instagram
abstract: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took followers from Hong Kong to the Lower East Side of New York.
lead_paragraph: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took followers from Hong Kong to the Lower East Side of New York.

headline: A Plumbing Problem: Sludge in the Bathtub
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Plumbing', 'Smoke Detectors', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Cooperatives']
abstract: Fixing a pipe, qualifying for tax abatement, and installing smoke detectors.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: The Roots of China’s Real Estate Rush
abstract: Chinese money is reshaping real estate markets, as companies and individuals snap up commercial and residential properties.
lead_paragraph: Chinese money is reshaping real estate markets, as companies and individuals snap up commercial and residential properties.

headline: Chinese Cash Floods U.S. Real Estate Market
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Foreign Investments', 'Series', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Some of the Chinese money pouring into the global economy has gone into residential property, in major American cities and places like Corinth, Tex.
lead_paragraph: Canyon Lake Ranch was once a playground for Christian day campers, and then was a corporate retreat with water-skiing, barbecues and cowboy shoot-’em-up shows. Hawks now circle above 108 sunbaked acres occupied by copperhead snakes, a few coyotes and the occasional construction truck.

headline: House-Hunting, Chinese-Style
abstract: Chinese families are looking for a safe place to invest their renminbi. From rural Texas to Silicon Valley, American real estate is an increasingly popular destination for their cash.
lead_paragraph: Chinese families are looking for a safe place to invest their renminbi. From rural Texas to Silicon Valley, American real estate is an increasingly popular destination for their cash.

headline: Ohio State Band Shows Flair Even as It Sticks to the Script
abstract: The Ohio State marching band’s signature formation is Script Ohio, but it has also gained attention for animated depictions of Michael Jackson and a dinosaur.
lead_paragraph: As fans clad in scarlet and gray clapped along to “Le Régiment de Sambre et Meuse” on a warm September day in Columbus, members of Ohio State’s marching band and its alumni went about precisely spelling “Ohio” in script on Ohio Stadium’s field.

headline: Prominent Kurdish Lawyer Is Killed in Southeast Turkey
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Kurds', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Threats and Threatening Messages']
abstract: Tahir Elci, an outspoken human rights lawyer, and a police officer were killed by gunmen after he spoke at a news conference in Turkey’s Sur District.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — A prominent Kurdish lawyer and a Turkish police officer were killed on Saturday when clashes erupted after he spoke at a news conference in Turkey’s volatile southeast.

headline: Pope Francis Offers Mass in Uganda at Shrine for Christian Martyrs
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: Hundreds of thousands came to see the pope at the Namugongo shrines, which are dedicated to 19th century Christian converts who were killed for refusing to renounce their beliefs.
lead_paragraph: NAMUGONGO, Uganda — On the very spot where some of this nation’s first Christians were burned to death for adhering to their beliefs, Pope Francis offered a Mass for hundreds of thousands of Ugandans on Saturday.

headline: Big City Book Club
abstract: As the year winds down, the Big City Book Club is seeking the wisdom of the crowds to help make our next selections. We are asking for suggestions: What is the best New York-centric book you read in 2015?
lead_paragraph: As the year winds down, the Big City Book Club is seeking the wisdom of the crowds to help make our next selections. For our next meeting, which will convene in early January, we’re asking for your suggestions: What is the best New York-centric book you read in 2015? For those of you just joining us now, you can read about previous choices here. There were some heavy hitters set in the city published this year, like “City on Fire,” by Garth Risk Hallberg, about New York in the ’70s; “Smash Cut,” by Brad Gooch, about the ’80s; and “A Little Life,” by Hanya Yanagihara, about traumatic transitions to adulthood. But the books you propose need not have been published in 2015. One of our liveliest recent discussions was about “The Custom of the Country,” by Edith Wharton, published in 1913.

headline: Nudging the Boss for Your Performance Review
keywords: ['Performance Evaluations (Labor)', 'Workplace Environment', 'Working Hours', 'Paid Time Off', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: An employee who is supposed to have a performance review every six months hasn’t had one in a year and seeks advice on how to request and prepare for one.
lead_paragraph: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: Anh Nguy: Research Is Her Recipe
abstract: Ms. Nguy creates food concepts for food companies and restaurants as a culinologist, or research chef, at Ingredion. She works in Bridgewater, N.J.
lead_paragraph: Anh Nguy, 41, is a culinologist at Ingredion. She works in Bridgewater, N.J.

headline: 2 Dead in Brooklyn House Fire Caused by Power Strip, Officials Say
abstract: The blaze engulfed a two-story home in the East Flatbush neighborhood early Saturday, killing an 81-year-old woman and an 86-year-old man.
lead_paragraph: Sharon Hinds, a home health attendant, was walking home from a party along a street in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn early on Saturday when she heard screams and smelled smoke coming from a two-story house.

headline: Variety: An Acrostic That Floats
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon offer us an acrostic that floats.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Do you have a hobby, a pastime, a passion that you find difficult to describe adequately to people who do not share your passion?

headline: Obama Says ‘Enough Is Enough’ After Colorado Shooting
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Gun Control', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: President Obama responded angrily Saturday to the mass shooting in Colorado Springs that took three lives, calling the country’s recurring outbreak of gun violence “not normal.”
lead_paragraph: President Obama responded angrily on Saturday to the mass shooting that took three lives, including that of a police officer, at a Planned Parenthood facility in Colorado Springs over the Thanksgiving holiday, calling the country’s recurring outbreaks of gun violence “not normal.”

headline: Big Companies Put Their Money Where the Trash Is
abstract: The Closed Loop Fund, backed by nine major corporations, is making loans to local governments and companies to build recycling infrastructure.
lead_paragraph: The recycling industry has a dirty little secret: Much of the plastic that consumers diligently sort is never actually recycled. Instead, some of those yogurt containers, translucent takeout boxes and bottle caps are buried in landfills or incinerated.

headline: A Pitch Is Framed by Diplomacy in Cuba
abstract: An American group wants to have a major league team’s minor league affiliate based in Havana, but its first mission is to build good will.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — A minibus of Americans rumbled through a city in transformation, past the run-down housing and round-the-clock construction, the sparsely stocked bodegas and chic new restaurants, to a reception at the residence of the American chargés d’affaires. The hint of change teased the November night.

headline: Demand, Supply, and Macroeconomic Models
abstract: Hicks good, Friedman/Phelps not so much.
lead_paragraph: I’m supposed to do a presentation next week about “shifts in economic models,” which has me trying to systematize my thought about what the crisis and aftermath have and haven’t changed my understanding of macroeconomics. And it seems to me that there is an important theme here: it’s the supply side, stupid.

headline: Healthier, Wiser and Back With the Giants
abstract: Craig Dahl’s knee injuries cut short a promising career with the Giants in 2007, but after a trip back to college and then six seasons with two other teams, he finds himself back where he started.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Craig Dahl, an undrafted rookie safety from North Dakota State, was a long shot to make the Giants in 2007. His roommate that season, linebacker and long snapper Zak DeOssie, was another first-year player trying to make the team.

headline: With Steve Kerr Sidelined, Warriors’ Perfect Start Raises Questions of Credit
abstract: Luke Walton, the Warriors’ interim coach, has guided the team to the longest winning streak to start a season, but official credit for the victories could go to Kerr.
lead_paragraph: In a flawless start to the season, it is tempting to try to find fault amid the perfection. With the Golden State Warriors displaying no obvious issues on the court, close watchers of the team have set their sights on a rule that prevents Luke Walton, the interim coach, from getting credit for any of the victories.

headline: Marco Rubio Bets the Grand Old Party Is Ready for His Younger Face
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Endorsements']
abstract: Age, or the conspicuous lack of it, is something that infuses almost every element of the Rubio campaign.
lead_paragraph: There is nothing particularly flashy about the endorsements that have been rolling in for Senator Marco Rubio lately: a handful of Republican members of Congress, mostly junior and not terribly influential.

headline: A Step Forward for Contraceptive Access
abstract: Two states are making it easier to get contraceptives by allowing patients to skip the doctor’s visit and go straight to the pharmacist.
lead_paragraph: Patients seeking birth control pills today typically have to get a prescription from a doctor, but reproductive health advocates have long argued that this process is unnecessary since the pills are safe for a vast majority of women. Now two states are about to allow patients to get them from a pharmacist without seeing a doctor first. Other states should consider similar moves.

headline: Voting and Self-Interest
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Welfare (US)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Income Inequality', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Medicaid', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Readers discuss why many poor people support politicians who are opposed to a generous safety net.
lead_paragraph: Why do many poor people support politicians who are opposed to a generous safety net?

headline: One Governor’s Extraordinary Year
abstract: Larry Hogan, a Maryland Republican, successfully battled cancer. Can he vanquish partisanship as well?
lead_paragraph: ANNAPOLIS, Md. — NEWLY bald and always blunt, Gov. Larry Hogan was wondering about his hair. When it might grow back. How it might grow back.

headline: Don’t Feel Bad About ‘Bad Sex’

headline: Another Baltimore Injustice
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Bail', 'Police', 'Discrimination', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: The officers in the Freddie Gray case are receiving preferential treatment in court.
lead_paragraph: Baltimore — THE trials of the six officers charged in the death of Freddie Gray, the 25-year-old black man who died after suffering a spinal injury in police custody, begin tomorrow. As a public defender here, I have watched the cases of the officers move through the Baltimore City Circuit Court.

headline: Could Your Healthy Diet Make Me Fat?
abstract: When it comes to food, the simple rules are still the best.
lead_paragraph: SOME people eat as little fat as possible to lose weight and stay healthy, while others avoid carbohydrates. A vegan diet (with no animal products) and the paleo diet (with lots) both have enthusiastic devotees. One popular diet encourages intermittent fasting, another frequent small meals. Who’s right?

headline: Notes on the China I’m Leaving Behind
abstract: Eight years of bearing witness to the nation’s patchwork progress.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — I GOT together at a restaurant the other night with some Chinese and expatriate friends. While bossa nova played in the background, we sipped French merlot and snapped iPhone photos of one another making goofy faces.

headline: Frank Sinatra in Hoboken: If I Can Make It There ...
abstract: Where The Voice was born.
lead_paragraph: HOBOKEN, N.J. — “How did all these people get into my room?” Frank Sinatra happily shouted in 1966, as he arrived before a cheering crowd and a swinging band eager for his concert at the Sands Hotel in Las Vegas. Backed by the Count Basie Orchestra, Sinatra recorded a virtuoso album that graying Sinatra fans still listen to for a whiff of life’s sheer exuberance and drive.

headline: What Comes Out in the Wash
abstract: Fibers from your winter fleece are adding to the plastic junk in the environment.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — ASK most people about the problem of waste plastics in the environment and they will talk about plastic bags caught in trees and the vast slicks of plastic trash found in remote areas of the Atlantic and Pacific. But the most menacing plastic waste problem is less visible and not so well publicized.

headline: What the Paris Climate Meeting Must Do
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'Global Warming']
abstract: The conference will succeed if it fosters a sense in countries large and small that all must play a part in finding a solution.
lead_paragraph: In 1992, more than 150 nations agreed at a meeting in Rio de Janeiro to take steps to stabilize greenhouse gases at a level that would “prevent dangerous anthropogenic interference with the climate system” — United Nations-speak for global warming.

headline: Digital Culture, Meet Analog Fever
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Music', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Science and Technology', 'Electronics']
abstract: The marginalization of the physical has propelled it into the realm of luxury.
lead_paragraph: IN the course of a recent move, I decided to “cut the cord” — that is, walk away from cable television and fully embrace the streamed-entertainment revolution. I felt very digital. Just a few weeks later, however, I discovered something that surprised me: Thousands of my fellow cord-cutters have taken to buying antennas, to pick up the seemingly quaint format of over-the-air television signals.

headline: Tales of a Warmer Planet
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Earth', 'Environment', 'Research']
abstract: By running civilization on fossil fuel, we are creating and destroying climates.
lead_paragraph: Paul Smiths, N.Y. — IT’S a mistake to think the climatic effects of our carbon emissions will be over within a few decades or centuries. Our intergenerational responsibilities run much deeper into the future.

headline: Contaminating Our Bodies With Everyday Products
keywords: ['Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Chemicals', 'Consumer Protection', 'Medicine and Health', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists']
abstract: The political system was slow to respond to the truth about cigarettes. Now it’s similarly behind in protecting us from toxic chemicals.
lead_paragraph: IN recent weeks, two major medical organizations have issued independent warnings about toxic chemicals in products all around us. Unregulated substances, they say, are sometimes linked to breast and prostate cancer, genital deformities, obesity, diabetes and infertility.

headline: Versatile Standout Finds a Position, and a Home with Portland Timbers
abstract: Darlington Nagbe, a newly-minted American citizen, is growing more comfortable in his evolving role with the Timbers, one that gives him more touches on the ball.
lead_paragraph: There was never any doubt that Darlington Nagbe had talent. Talent is what made him the national player of the year in college, and it is what earned him goal of the year honors in his rookie season in Major League Soccer. It is also what drew the attention of United States Coach Jurgen Klinsmann, who eagerly threw Nagbe into two games this month almost as soon as the ink on his new citizenship papers was dry.

headline: Red Bulls’ Home Edge Faces Stiff Test
abstract: If the club manages to erase its two-goal deficit to the Columbus Crew, it will host the M.L.S. Cup final at Red Bull Arena.
lead_paragraph: The Red Bulls’ playoff game against the Columbus Crew on Sunday is already the biggest match at Red Bull Arena this season. The result will determine if it is also the last.

headline: Spain Yesterday, Syria Today
keywords: ['Spanish Civil War (1936-39)', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Echos of the 1930s in today’s Middle East, but with crucial differences as well.
lead_paragraph: BETWEEN 1936 and 1939, the Spanish Civil War condensed the awful drama of the 1930s into one conflict. Spain was where left-wing illusions about Stalinism went to die, where Hitler’s war machine tuned up for the Blitzkrieg, where aerial bombardments of civilians and politically-motivated “cleansing” were normalized. It was a proxy war for the totalitarian powers, a magnet for volunteers from around the Western world, and an object lesson in the impotence of Europe’s liberal democracies.

headline: The Heart Disease Conundrum
abstract: Why do South Asians account for so many of the world’s cardiac patients?
lead_paragraph: SOUTH ASIANS today account for more than half of the world’s cardiac patients. Heart disease is the leading cause of death in India, Pakistan and Bangladesh, and rates have risen over the past several decades. South Asian immigrants to the United States, like me, develop earlier and more malignant heart disease and have higher death rates than any other major ethnic group in this country.

lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The good news about the Jets is how well they tend to play after halftime. Only three teams — New England, Arizona and Houston — have outscored opponents by more points in the second half than the Jets have (49).

lead_paragraph: AMHERST, Mass. — Hundreds of students crammed into Amherst College’s Robert Frost Library for a sit-in against racial injustice that turned into a confessional, as one black or Hispanic student after another rose to talk about feelings of alienation and invisibility on campus.

abstract: Climate change has become a hallmark for President Obama’s second term, and potentially a signature achievement.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At a joint news conference here Tuesday with President François Hollande of France, President Obama veered from his focus on the terrorist attacks in Paris to bring up the huge international gathering beginning in the French capital on Monday to hammer out a global response to climate change.

headline: Ohio State and Ezekiel Elliott Run Wild Against Overmatched Michigan
abstract: Behind Elliott’s 214 rushing yards and two touchdowns, the Buckeyes earned their 11th victory against Michigan in 12 years, reminding the Wolverines how lopsided the series has been in recent years.
lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Jim Harbaugh stood near the line of scrimmage, bent over, his hands on his knees, watching intently as Ohio State lined up needing a yard to convert a fourth down. Ohio State had knifed through Harbaugh’s defense all day. He looked as if he wanted to run onto the field and tackle Ezekiel Elliott, the Buckeyes’ running back, himself.

headline: In Spain, New Political Party Makes Gains From Surprising Place — the Center
abstract: The party, Citizens, has expanded its base, shot up in the polls and unseated Spain’s other insurgent party, Podemos, as the rising threat to Spain’s established parties.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — The splintering of politics in Europe has spawned the rise of numerous upstart parties, usually on the extremes, be they left or right.

headline: Transgender Argentines Confront Continued Murder and Discrimination
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Recent unsolved killings of transgender women have jolted Argentina, which has introduced some of the most liberal civil rights legislation in Latin America.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Diana Sacayán was found tied up in a 13th-floor apartment in Buenos Aires in October, stabbed to death. A month earlier, Marcela Estefanía Chocobar, 26, was decapitated and her body dumped on a vacant lot in Río Gallegos, in Patagonia. Also in September, in Santa Fe, a city on Argentina’s Pampas lowlands, the corpse of Fernanda Olmos, 59, was discovered on her bedroom floor, a plastic bag pulled over her head. She had also been stabbed.

headline: Siege Highlights Security Used in Abortion Clinics
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Cameras']
abstract: The advanced camera system at the Planned Parenthood, which helped officers during the siege, was just one sign of the increasingly elaborate security measures that have been adopted by abortion clinics around the country.
lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — As the heavily armed police officers entered the Planned Parenthood clinic here to hunt down the gunman and rescue those trapped inside, they had an advantage that seemed like something out of the movies. Officers in the command center outside the clinic were able to tap into security cameras throughout the complex, watch the siege unfold and give precise instructions to officers inside.

headline: Four-Letter Words
abstract: Alex Vratsanos is big with the four-letter words. Don’t tell his mother.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — What does it say about someone’s character if they are wont to throw around four-letter words? Probably nothing; I’m not sure why I even brought that up.

headline: Norman C. Pickering, Who Refined the Record Player, Dies at 99
abstract: Mr. Pickering, an engineer and musician, devised the Pickering pickup, a lightweight mechanism that reduced sound distortion and made records last longer.
lead_paragraph: Norman C. Pickering, an engineer, inventor and musician whose pursuit of audio clarity and beauty helped make phonograph records and musical instruments sound better, died on Nov. 18 at his home in East Hampton, N.Y. He was 99.

headline: Josephine Chaus, Co-Founder and Re-Inventor of Fashion Brand, Dies at 64
abstract: After her husband died and her company, Bernard Chaus Inc., faltered, Mrs. Chaus was able to rescue it from the brink of collapse in a way that surprised industry veterans.
lead_paragraph: Josephine Chaus, a fashion executive who founded Bernard Chaus Inc. with her husband and later rescued it from the brink of collapse, died on Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 64.

lead_paragraph: BERLIN — With as many as one million refugees having arrived in Germany this year, Chancellor Angela Merkel has found herself increasingly isolated in Europe and markedly less popular at home than she was during the crisis over the euro this spring.

headline: Ex-Wife Says Robert Dear, Suspect in Colorado Rampage, Showed Few Signs of Obsession

lead_paragraph: GOOSE CREEK, S.C. — The blue eyes of Pamela Ross, 54, wince and cloud when she thinks back on the years that she spent with her ex-husband, Robert L. Dear Jr. They were together 16 years or so, and married for about a dozen of them.

headline: Black Artists and the March Into the Museum
abstract: After decades of spotty acquisitions and token exhibitions, American museums are rewriting the history of 20th-century art to include black artists.
lead_paragraph: The painter Norman Lewis rarely complained in public about the singular struggles of being a black artist in America. But in 1979, dying of cancer, he made a prediction to his family. “He said to us, ‘I think it’s going to take about 30 years, maybe 40, before people stop caring whether I’m black and just pay attention to the work,’ ” Lewis’s daughter, Tarin Fuller, recalled recently.

headline: Giants Losing Linemen
abstract: The Giants will face the Washington Redskins on Sunday without much of their starting offensive line.
lead_paragraph: The Giants will face the Washington Redskins on Sunday without much of their starting offensive line as both center Weston Richburg and left guard Justin Pugh did not travel to Washington with the team Saturday. Pugh is recovering from a concussion and was not expected to play, but the Giants had been hopeful about Richburg, who sprained his ankle in the Giants last game on Nov. 15. The veteran John Jerry will replace Pugh, and Dallas Reynolds, a longtime N.F.L. backup, will most likely be the center. The starting tight end Larry Donnell, who has a neck injury, has also been ruled out for Sunday’s game.

abstract: If this turns into any sort of shootout, the Steelers will have the advantage.
lead_paragraph: Steelers (6-4) at Seahawks (5-5)
