headline: As World Leaders Kick off Paris Climate Talks, Prescriptions Abound, from a Carbon Tax to a New Nuclear Push
keywords: ['Carbon Dioxide', 'Energy Efficiency', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Taxation', 'United Nations Convention on Biological Diversity']
abstract: A host of approaches to limiting global warming emerge as world leaders gather in Paris to launch two weeks of climate talks.
lead_paragraph: As world leaders assemble in Paris for the Monday launch of the 21st round of negotiations aimed at improving on the ineffective 1992 climate change treaty, I’ve assembled some worthwhile reading on the risks attending human-driven climate change and a host of prescriptions worth considering. None will be easy to achieve.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Sam Sifton’s ideas for your weekday meals: scallops, roast chicken and more.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: 1890: Germany’s Gift to the World
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: In Germany, there is hope for a cure to tuberculosis, in 1890.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Herr Von Gossler, the Minister of Public Instruction replied to-day [Nov. 29] in the Prussian Chamber of Deputies to the interpellation of Herr Graf relative to the discovery of Professor Koch. The Minister replied that Professor Koch’s discovery was for the present only an infallible means of diagnoses for tuberculosis, but that as a means of cure it would require years of experience to test it. There was, however, great hope that the results would be good. In any case Professor Koch has rendered an immense service to science in connection with all kinds of infectious diseases. The minister added that it was he who prevented Professor Koch from publishing the method of preparation of his remedy, for fear that it might be badly prepared and do more harm than good. The Prussian Government, he said, intended to purchase the secret and manufacture the remedy with its own guarantee, and supply it free of cost to all the hospitals of Germany and other countries. — The New York Herald, European Edition, November 30, 1890

headline: The Winter Garden at Brookfield Place
abstract: A bit of competition for the tree at Rockefeller Center.
lead_paragraph: A bit of competition for the tree at Rockefeller Center.

headline: Basking in a New Holiday Glow, No Evergreen Needed
abstract: A lighting installation by the designer David Rockwell seeks to make the Winter Garden in Lower Manhattan a destination to rival New York’s most famous Christmas tree.
lead_paragraph: The designer David Rockwell has created high-energy sets for Broadway hits like “Kinky Boots” and “Hairspray,” and he has given Nobu restaurants and W hotels their flashy looks. But lately he has been telling people he is working on “the living room of Lower Manhattan.”

headline: Lawyers for Tamir Rice’s Family Release Outside Reports Criticizing Shooting
abstract: The two reports, by former high-ranking officials at California law-enforcement agencies, were at odds with previous investigations and called the shooting “unreasonable.”
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Lawyers for the family of Tamir Rice, the 12-year-old boy fatally shot last year by the Cleveland police, have presented Ohio prosecutors with two outside reports that call an officer’s decision to shoot the boy “unreasonable.”

headline: Cartoon: Heng on China-Africa Ties
abstract: President Xi Jinping is scheduled to visit Zimbabwe and South Africa early next month.
lead_paragraph: President Xi Jinping is scheduled to visit Zimbabwe and South Africa early next month.

headline: On a Wall in the West Bronx, a Gentrification Battle Rages
abstract: Citing fears of a growing hipster migration reaching north of Manhattan, two graffiti artists have painted a comic-style mural that dramatizes the stakes.
lead_paragraph: Alberto Serrano has declared war on the shock troops of gentrification: hipsters. He has chosen as his front line a part of the Bronx, specifically a stretch along Walton Avenue in the Mount Hope neighborhood, which — for now — is free from goofy bars, twee crochet sculptures and overpriced cafes. His weapon? A huge mural depicting a grand comic-strip battle of the hip versus the hopeful.

headline: 1940: Rome Declares Counterattack Has Halted Foe
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Italy says it has brought the Greek advance to a standstill in 1940.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Stiff counter-attacks by reinforced and reorganized Italian troops were said here tonight [Nov. 29] to have brought the Greek advance in Albania to a standstill. As the high command announced a turn for the better in the tide of battle, Gen. Ubaldo Soddu, who went to Albania recently to take command at the front, received promotion by royal decree. Greek efforts to advance yesterday, the high command said, were stopped by a counter-attack of the Ferrara, Siena and Centauro divisions of the 11th Army Corps. In the Koritza sector of the 9th Army Corps, all was reported quiet. Authoritative quarters were denied reports that the Greeks had captured Argyrokastron, one of the Italian bases in Albania, and that Gen. Pietro Badoglio had taken up headquarters in Tirana. Badoglio is in Rome, it was said, and Soddu is in supreme command at the front. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 30, 1940

headline: Breyer Sees Value in U.S. Supreme Court’s Looking to Foreign Law
abstract: Justice Stephen G. Breyer suggests the court should check abroad for guidance because about 20 percent of cases are affected by what happens outside the United States.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Stephen G. Breyer, a progressive force on the United States Supreme Court for more than two decades, advocates the courts taking into account foreign law. That’s the stuff of a good debate, befitting a justice who got to the bench courtesy of former President Ronald Reagan and the archconservative Senator Strom Thurmond.

headline: 3 Killed and 12 Injured in Crash Involving Cattle Trailer in New Jersey
abstract: A series of collisions occurred after a Maine man pulled his truck onto the shoulder of Interstate 287 to fix his trailer.
lead_paragraph: A passenger van packed with restaurant workers returning home from work hit a car, a truck and a trailer hauling cattle that were parked on the shoulder of Interstate 287 near Bernards Township, N.J., on Saturday night. Three people were killed and 12 were injured.

headline: E.U. Offers Turkey 3 Billion Euros to Stem Migrant Flow
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: European Union leaders met with Turkey’s prime minister on Sunday, promising aid and other inducements in exchange for Turkish action to clamp down on asylum seekers.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Under heavy pressure from Germany to get a grip on the migrant crisis in the Continent after months of dithering, the European Union agreed to a deal on Sunday with Turkey that aims to slow the chaotic flood of asylum seekers into the 28-nation bloc.

headline: Holiday Crowds Turn Out for ‘Creed,’ ‘The Good Dinosaur’ and ‘Mockingjay Part 2’
abstract: Two new releases, “The Good Dinosaur” and “Creed,” bolstered ticket sales, but they could not best Katniss Everdeen and her crew.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Rocky Balboa made a near-triumphant return to movie theaters over the five-day Thanksgiving weekend, helping to bolster total domestic ticket sales by about 12 percent compared with the same period last year.

headline: What to Watch Sunday
abstract: Get up and move with the Soul Train Awards, prepare for the final season of “Downtown Abbey” or follow some mountain climbers into thin air.
lead_paragraph: Groove into the workweek — and whittle off some holiday pudge — with the Soul Train Awards, complete with a how-to video. Can’t move from the couch? Prepare for the final season of “Downton Abbey” or follow some elite mountain climbers into thin air.

headline: Review: In ‘Gluten!’ the Fashion Is in the Hazmat Suits
abstract: This dystopian comedy by Stephen Kaliski at 59E59 Theaters follows a couple apartment hunting after half the population has died from environmental toxicity.
lead_paragraph: Those with sensitivities to milk, eggs, shellfish and ground and tree nuts have nothing to fear from “Gluten!,” a new comedy by Stephen Kaliski at 59E59 Theaters. Those with an allergy to labored satire may want to seek other fare.

headline: In ‘Oh, Hello,’ Nick Kroll and John Mulaney Have a Stage Senior Moment
abstract: Mr. Kroll and Mr. Mulaney are riding a comic wave with their stereotypical characters in this bit, which has grown into an Off Broadway show.
lead_paragraph: Backstage at the Kings Theater in Brooklyn one recent Friday night, Nick Kroll and John Mulaney had finished putting on their silver-haired wigs, wrinkle makeup and billowy, threadbare bohemian clothing. These comedians had a few minutes before showtime, and as they relaxed, a familiar aroma began to fill the air: the scent of tuna fish, coming from a large plastic container that Mr. Kroll was emptying onto a slice of bread.

headline: Murdoch’s British Tabloids Clean Up Their Acts
keywords: ['Newspapers', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'News and News Media', 'Bribery and Kickbacks']
abstract: Years after a phone-hacking scandal exposed a pattern of illicit information-gathering, the unspoken laws of tabloids have been reconfigured.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A July article on a front page of The Sun on Sunday tabloid, owned by Rupert Murdoch, was a classic of its kind. Titled “Lord Coke: Top peer’s drug binges with £200 prostitutes,” its highlights included cross-dressing, bare breasts lined with cocaine and the 69-year-old deputy speaker of the House of Lords excitedly burbling, “I just want to be led astray.”

headline: Adele’s ‘25’ Sells Record-Shattering 3.38 Million Copies
keywords: ['Music', 'Records and Achievements', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: That’s nearly a million more than the previous high mark for first-week sales — ’N Sync sold 2.4 million copies of “No Strings Attached” in 2000.
lead_paragraph: The final numbers are in, and they confirm expectations: Adele is a phenomenon.

headline: Chinese Report on Climate Change Depicts Somber Scenarios
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Environment']
abstract: An assessment from state-appointed experts was released just before negotiations in Paris for a new international agreement to lower greenhouse-gas pollution.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Rising seas besieging China’s economically vital coastal zones. Mighty feats of infrastructure, like the Three Gorges Dam and railway in Tibet, strained by turbulent rainfall and the melting of frozen earth. And on the Himalayan frontiers, the risk in future decades of international conflict over dwindling water supplies as glaciers retreat.

headline: Israel Aims to Recreate Wine That Jesus and King David Drank
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Wines', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Jews and Judaism', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Israeli Settlements', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Grapes']
abstract: The redevelopment of local varietals — like so many things in this contested land — is not free of political friction.
lead_paragraph: HEFER VALLEY, Israel — The new crisp, acidic and mineral white from a high-end Israeli winery was aged for eight months — or, depending on how you look at it, at least 1,800 years.

headline: Review: ‘George Balanchine’s The Nutcracker’ at Lincoln Center
abstract: New York City Ballet’s version of this holiday classic returns to the David H. Koch Theater, with Andrew Litton as the company’s music director.
lead_paragraph: “George Balanchine’s The Nutcracker” begins with a yawn. The child heroine, Marie, has an exciting night ahead of her: a Christmas party with presents and dancing, the attention of a mysterious godfather and a handsome boy, a tree that grows 40 feet tall, a battle with giant mice, a walk in a blizzard and a journey to the Land of Sweets. And yet her first gesture suggests not just sleepiness but also boredom.

headline: How to Use Google Now on Tap
abstract: Tips on activating and taking advantage of Google Now on Tap, which can be handy in providing more details about what you’re seeing on your smartphone or tablet screen.

headline: Andy Murray Propels Britain to Victory in the Davis Cup
abstract: The world’s No. 2 player capped an emotional tournament by beating David Goffin of Belgium in straight sets, giving Britain first title in 79 years.
lead_paragraph: GHENT, Belgium — Giant foam fingers. A remarkable variety of percussion instruments. Vuvuzelas. Disturbingly oversize photos of the home players on wooden sticks. Copious face paint. And at least one trombone.

headline: Peeling Back the Layers of a Born Salesman’s Life
keywords: ['Crime and Criminals', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Probation and Parole']
abstract: A career criminal and con artist, Michael Forman, had been in and out of prisons most of his adult life. But he could tell a story.
lead_paragraph: The woman on the telephone had news. Michael Forman was dead. She asked a reporter if there was any known next of kin.

headline: L.S.U.’s Les Miles Gets Another Chance. Some Teams Won’t Be So Lucky.
abstract: Louisiana State’s athletic director said Miles would remain as its coach, but Saturday’s most notable development was Oklahoma’s win, which left only one Playoff spot looking up for grabs.
lead_paragraph: After Louisiana State’s 19-7 victory against Texas A&M on Saturday, players hoisted Tigers Coach Les Miles onto their shoulders. He interrupted an on-field interview to sing along to the university’s alma mater — “And may thy spirit live in us, forever L-S-U” — before he was asked about the crowd chanting his name, in recognition of widely circulated reports that Miles was about to be fired.

headline: Searching for Answers and Comfort After Killings at Planned Parenthood
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The governor of Colorado and other national leaders condemned Friday’s attack as a form of terrorism in discussions on the factors behind such frequent shootings.
lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — After the congregation shared memories of a fallen police officer, Garrett Swasey, and cheered and cried through a grainy video of him competing at a 1992 skating championship, its members bowed their heads on Sunday morning to pray for the man accused of killing him at a Planned Parenthood clinic.

headline: Rutgers Fires Its Football Coach and Athletic Director
abstract: On a date known as Black Friday for the number of struggling coaches that lose their jobs, Rutgers fired Coach Kyle Flood and replaced Athletic Director Julie Hermann with Patrick Hobbs. Georgia, Virginia, Virginia Tech and Iowa also made big changes.
lead_paragraph: Rutgers announced Sunday that it had fired its football coach, Kyle Flood, and athletic director, Julie Hermann, and had hired her replacement, Patrick Hobbs — three moves amid a flurry of personnel changes in major college football programs.

headline: Nokia Tries to Reinvent Itself, Again, by Taking Over Alcatel-Lucent
abstract: Rajeev Suri, Nokia’s 48-year-old chief executive, says his company’s $16.6 billion takeover of Alcatel-Lucent is exactly what Nokia needs to execute its yearslong makeover, which has included layoffs and the sale of unwanted assets.
lead_paragraph: ESPOO, Finland — Tucked away down a corridor at Nokia’s headquarters here is a reminder of its 150-year history. A colorful display traces its transformation from a maker of rubber boots in the 19th century to the world’s largest manufacturer of cellphones, whose market capitalization once peaked at almost $250 billion.

headline: Optimism Abounds as Burkina Faso Votes for President
abstract: After 27 years under the same president and months of political turmoil, there was heavy voter turnout to choose from a slate of a dozen candidates.
lead_paragraph: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso — A country that has endured months of upheaval that ousted one president and nearly toppled an interim government cast ballots Sunday in national elections intended to steady its shaky political environment.

headline: Chicago to Expand Use of Police Body Cameras
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Cameras', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: The announcement comes amid protests sparked by the release of a video from a police dashboard camera that showed a white police officer shooting a black teenager 16 times.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Mayor Rahm Emanuel announced on Sunday that the city would soon increase the number of police officers wearing video cameras, an expansion of a pilot program started in January in one police district.

headline: Giants Wake Up Too Late to Seize a First-Place Opportunity
abstract: The Giants had a chance to solidify their position atop the feeble N.F.C. East, but they now share that spot with the Redskins, who beat them Sunday.
lead_paragraph: LANDOVER, Md. — The Giants refuse to conform. On the verge of prosperity, they wobble in the other direction. Dogged by adversity, they unexpectedly thrive. To the Giants, predictability is for losers, something they have now proved six times in 11 games this season.

headline: How a Former Fugee Helped Elect the President of Haiti
abstract: The documentary “Sweet Micky for President” follows Prakazrel Michel, known as Pras, as he works to put a Haitian musician into office.
lead_paragraph: When Kanye West announced his candidacy for the 2020 presidential election at the MTV Video Music Awards in August, it was his drop-the-mike moment. His remarks were met with cheers and howls of laughter that night and were captured in endless memes for weeks afterward.

headline: Timely Lift for Jets’ Sagging Morale
abstract: For the Jets, Miami, hapless on offense and defense, proved to be the antidote to their recent struggles as they make their playoff push. In sweeping the season series against the Dolphins for the first time in eight years, the Jets bolstered their hopes of making the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Jets had played some horrendous football the previous two games. The kind of football that produced embarrassed locker rooms, provoked a postgame tirade from their coach and prompted their hirsute quarterback to trim a beard more prolific than their offense.

headline: Review: The Rio 65 Trio Resurrects the Barreling Sounds of a Samba-Jazz Band
abstract: The original trio members Dom Salvador and Sérgio Barroso were joined by Duduka da Fonseca, who took the place of Edison Machado, who died in 1990.
lead_paragraph: A few years after the invention of bossa nova in Brazil, in the late 1950s, there appeared a wave of samba-jazz groups, often piano trios. The two styles are linked at the root by samba rhythm, but they can feel like opposites. The best bossa nova was light, sensitive, skeptical, measured, full of silence. The samba-jazz of the early ’60s was dense and fast and barreling, and the Rio 65 Trio, who made two records in 1965 and 1966, embodied that sound.

headline: Review: At Bargemusic, a Masterful Duo Dives Into Strauss With Breakneck Élan
abstract: The violinist Noah Bendix-Bagley and the pianist Orion Weiss played Brahms, Janacek and an especially vivid Strauss sonata at this floating venue in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: As a sort of postscript to the Berlin Philharmonic’s recent week of Beethoven at Carnegie Hall, Noah Bendix-Balgley, the newest of the orchestra’s three “first concertmasters,” played at Bargemusic on Friday evening with the pianist Orion Weiss.

headline: Review: In ‘Alison’s House,’ a Family Struggles to Protect a Literary Legacy
abstract: This revival of Susan Glaspell’s 1930 play, loosely based on events surrounding Emily Dickinson, provides an opportunity to reflect on defending women’s freedom in a man’s world.
lead_paragraph: There are many lenses through which to view “Alison’s House,” Susan Glaspell’s 1930 drama exploring a family’s angst over the literary output of a beloved dead relative. You could examine Glaspell’s early-20th-century feminist politics, or meditate on how the competing demands of celebrity and privacy have and have not shifted in the 85 years between its premiere and the current production, directed by Alex Roe at the Metropolitan Playhouse.

headline: Woodrow Wilson’s Legacy Gets Complicated
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Names, Organizational', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Segregation and Desegregation', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Student protesters at Princeton have touched off a wide debate about racism and the former president’s proper place in history.
lead_paragraph: Was Woodrow Wilson a key founder of modern liberalism, a visionary whose belief in an activist presidency laid the groundwork for the New Deal and the civil rights legislation of the 1960s?

headline: Review: In Paolo Giordano’s ‘Like Family,’ the Nanny Departs and Cracks Emerge
abstract: This short novel details how the fabric of a small family unravels when its hardworking housekeeper falls ill and resigns.
lead_paragraph: How, exactly, does one describe the role of that warm, hardworking woman (for she is almost always a woman) who appears at a family’s doorstep day after day, year after year, to make its life possible? Is she simply an employee? A paid proxy aunt? Is her influence felt in every room and in every interaction, or is she weightless, invisible, a tidying ghost?

headline: Review: Miley Cyrus’s World of Excess
abstract: The singer, on a brief tour for her album “Miley Cyrus & Her Dead Petz,” employed excess like a blunt utensil, bludgeoning the senses again and again.
lead_paragraph: Onstage at Terminal 5 on Saturday night, Miley Cyrus sang, “I feel like a slab of butter that is melting in the sun” and struggled to grab her crotch. Her movement was restricted, because she was dressed like a stick of butter, in a rectangular costume that ended halfway to her knees. In the venue’s balcony, two girls posed for a selfie, a middle-aged gentleman in a sport coat pressed record on his iPhone and a young man with a beard full of glitter glided by. We had just hit peak 2015.

headline: Behind Puerto Rico’s Woes, a Broadly Powerful Development Bank
abstract: Much of the $72 billion in debt the island cannot repay stems from loans extended and guaranteed by its Government Development Bank
lead_paragraph: If anything stands as a symbol of how Puerto Rico ended up mired in billions of dollars of debt, it is an oceanside golf resort going to seed some 15 miles east of San Juan.

headline: Review: Not the Real Rob Schneider, Just One He Plays on ‘Real Rob’
abstract: The comedian takes a second shot at his own sitcom (the first was the short-lived “Rob” on CBS in 2012) with this Netflix series.
lead_paragraph: What’s “Real Rob” doing on Netflix, besides bringing down the curve?

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Nov. 30
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Review: Baby Jane Dexter Is Back With a Vengeance and Pungent Wit
abstract: In her new show at the Metropolitan Room, the longtime cabaret star soldiered through revelatory renditions of songs that underscored her bluntness and humor.
lead_paragraph: “Hang on!” When Baby Jane Dexter, a downtown cabaret fixture for more than four decades, sang those two words from the R.E.M. anthem “Everybody Hurts” at the Metropolitan Room on Saturday, her mighty pop contralto descended into a baritone and she exuded the authority of an inspirational commander-in-chief. Ms. Dexter has endured more than her share of hard times, but she keeps hanging on. And her new show, “It’s Personal!, is an impressive recovery after an engagement last year when she seemed to have lost the ability to sing on pitch or to remember lyrics.

headline: In ‘2 Dope Queens’ a Duo Muses Over Life, and Stanley Tucci
abstract: The comics Jessica Williams and Phoebe Robinson performed at Union Hall in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: In the cramped basement at Union Hall in Brooklyn, Jessica Williams and Phoebe Robinson have argued over Jay Z, clashed about Anita Baker and gone to war over Patti LaBelle. But when it comes to Billy Joel, they are on the same page.

headline: Paris Deal Would Herald an Important First Step on Climate Change
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'United States International Relations', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Kyoto Protocol']
abstract: There are reasons to believe the Paris negotiations are different from previous failed efforts, but an agreement would hardly halt global warming.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — President Obama and more than 100 world leaders will convene with thousands of diplomats on Monday on the outskirts of Paris to open two weeks of intense negotiations aimed at forging an accord that could begin to avert the most devastating effects of global warming and redefine the economy of the 21st century.

headline: Moneymaking Skill
abstract: How to look at words like a crossword constructor, as taught by Ian Livengood.
lead_paragraph: “Da da da da …Da da da da …” – Excerpt from Beethoven’s Fifth Symphony in the KEY of C minor

headline: Kohl’s Invests in Beatles Tune for Holiday Campaign
abstract: The department store commissioned covers of “All Together Now” for a series of spots depicting a diverse extended family coming together during the holidays.
lead_paragraph: AS Beatles songs go, it’s no “Hey Jude.” But the department store Kohl’s hopes that the group’s light, bouncy tune “All Together Now” will be the one that’s stuck in consumers’ heads this holiday season.

headline: Colorado Victims Identified as Iraq Veteran and Woman From Hawaii
abstract: Ke’Arre M. Stewart, a former Army specialist, and Jennifer Markovsky, the wife of an Army veteran, were killed along with a police officer, Garrett Swasey.
lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — As an Army specialist in Iraq, Ke’Arre M. Stewart lived with fear and saw tragedy, a friend said. At home in the United States, he felt safe. Then a man in a trench coat opened fire at a Planned Parenthood clinic here — and shortly after, Mr. Stewart, 29, along with two others, was dead.

headline: First Trial in Freddie Gray Death Is Set to Start in Baltimore
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Racial Profiling']
abstract: Some see the case against Officer William G. Porter, one of the six officers charged in Mr. Gray’s death, as a test of the criminal justice system.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Seven months after this city erupted into riots over the death of Freddie Gray, a 25-year-old black man injured while in police custody, Baltimore is preparing for the criminal trial of the first of six officers charged in his death — another turn in the intensifying national debate over race and policing.

headline: Thai Economy and Spirits Are Sagging
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Shopping and Retail', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: Thailand was once the torchbearer of freedom and prosperity in Southeast Asia. But now when Thais look to their neighbors, they feel envy, not pity.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Do not be fooled by the throngs of Chinese tourists clogging the entrance to the gilded Grand Palace, the roads buzzing with traffic or the plastic smiles of hostesses greeting the business lunch crowd at luxury hotels.

headline: ‘Jessica Jones’ Episode 7: Fear and Self-Loathing
abstract: Jones spends way too much of Episode 7 putting herself down, often in the least productive ways imaginable.
lead_paragraph: There’s enough truth to the glaring streak of self-loathing that runs throughout the seventh episode of “Jessica Jones” to make it both palatable and believable. That’s no small feat for an episode that encourages viewers to forgive Jones, but never forces her to confront the demons that she’s courting. Instead of accepting and confronting the guilt she feels over killing Reva Connors, Jones yo-yos between steps two and four of the five stages of grief: anger and depression.

headline: Disney’s ‘Star Wars’ Attracts Investors in Midst of ESPN Woes
abstract: Movies — in particular one movie -- have started to drive Disney’s stock. The question is whether that is sustainable.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — FOR roughly a decade, ever since the DVD market started to implode, movie studios have been investor afterthoughts. Hits? Misses? Ho-hum, and back to the cable networks. With its steadily climbing subscriber fees, the Wall Street theory has held, cable would always save the day for the media conglomerates.

headline: Tensions With Russia Add to a Chill in Turkey’s Economy
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: Even before Russia imposed sanctions over the downing of a combat jet, an influx of migrants and a loss of export markets hindered Turkey’s economy.
lead_paragraph: ESKISEHIR, Turkey — A new high-speed rail line, completed last year, now links Eskisehir with Istanbul to the west and Ankara to the east. A narrow, serpentine river meanders through downtown, spanned by graceful blue bridges at almost every block, drawing tourists. Factories here make everything from cakes and cookies to refrigerators, large Ford freight trucks and aircraft parts.

headline: Kobe Bryant Announces Retirement
abstract: The Los Angeles Lakers star announced Sunday on The Players’ Tribune website that he will retire after this season, his 20th in the N.B.A.
lead_paragraph: Kobe Bryant of the Los Angeles Lakers announced Sunday that he would retire from professional basketball after the end of this season, his 20th in the N.B.A., bringing to a close one of the most decorated careers in the history of the sport.

headline: Elegant Railroading of the Past
abstract: Recalling the linen tablecloths, stewards and thick ham slices at breakfast on Amtrak.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Injured in Hurricane Sandy, an Immigrant Faces Eviction
abstract: Viktoriya Ignatyeva, a once-resourceful woman from Ukraine who was disabled while helping rescue others during the storm, must leave her single room in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Resourcefulness once dictated much of Viktoriya Ignatyeva’s life.

headline: Ted Cruz Surges in Iowa, Powered by Outsider Fervor
abstract: The Texas senator’s Iowa bandwagon, long churning in relative obscurity, seems to be approaching capacity.
lead_paragraph: CHARITON, Iowa — Around 10 p.m. Saturday, with locals here stuffing the entryway of a general store known for something called taco pizza, the presidential campaign of Senator Ted Cruz seemed to be winning a bet with itself.

headline: Marvel to Release Free Reprints of Hip-Hop Homage Comic Book Covers
abstract: The variant comic book covers, which reinterpret hip-hop album covers with Marvel characters, have drawn fans including many hip-hop artists themselves.
lead_paragraph: Jay Z and the Black Panther. LL Cool J and the Punisher. Missy Elliott and the Black Widow. Vanilla Ice and Deadpool. These are some of the pairings that fans of Marvel Entertainment have been treated to since October as part of a series of comic book covers inspired by hip-hop album covers. On Jan. 6, at participating stores, Marvel will give away a 32-page comic that reprints 14 of the homage covers.

headline: Tax Status of Museums Questioned by Senators
keywords: ['Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Museums', 'Art', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Senator Orrin G. Hatch suggested that some museums may offer minimal benefit to the public while enabling donors to reap substantial tax advantages.
lead_paragraph: The Senate Finance Committee is scrutinizing nearly a dozen private museums opened by individual collectors, questioning whether the tax-exempt status they enjoy provides sufficient public benefit to justify what amounts to a government subsidy.

headline: In Utah Feud Over ‘Dirty’ Sodas, Flavored Darts Are Fired

abstract: Despite efforts to limit any disruption to a two-week global climate conference in Paris, 174 people were taken into custody when demonstrators fought with the police.

headline: Cuomo to Highlight New York’s Progress in AIDS Fight
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is expected to announce Tuesday that more New Yorkers are taking the H.I.V. drug Truvada, and that the number of infections transmitted from mother to child has dropped to zero in the state.
lead_paragraph: Prescriptions for Truvada, a drug that protects against H.I.V. infection, have more than tripled since summer 2014 among people enrolled in Medicaid in New York State. Separately, the transmission of H.I.V. infections from mother to child dropped to zero in the state for the first time since the AIDS epidemic began.

headline: The Best of Week 12 in the N.F.L.
abstract: The top performers and key injuries in the league this week.
lead_paragraph: With Jamaal Charles out for the year and Charcandrick West sitting with a hamstring injury, Spencer Ware got his first career start and ran for 114 yards and a score in a Chiefs victory over the Bills. Ware, who had 96 yards on 11 carries last week, was on Kansas City’s practice squad until Charles was hurt. A 2013 sixth-round draft pick by the Seahawks, he had just three career carries entering the season. But Ware seemed confident heading into the Buffalo game, writing on Twitter last week, “Dont let others define u Dont let da past confine u.”

headline: Packing Guns in the Day Care Center
abstract: A vote against an Ohio measure that extends concealed-carry privileges would be a rare vote for sanity.
lead_paragraph: The gun lobby’s drive to extend the range of citizens with gun permits to the most vulnerable circles of society — from college campuses to busy restaurants — is now advancing on day care centers. That’s right: Legislation approved two weeks ago by the Republican-controlled Ohio House would allow state residents with concealed-carry permits to pack their loaded, hidden guns into day care centers when they drop off the kids.

headline: Why I Miss George W. Bush

headline: The Inheritance of Disaffection
abstract: For black Americans, the protests on campus and elsewhere are a refusal to accept the shackles handed down to them.
lead_paragraph: “Daddy, are you happy?” This is a question my son asks me on a regular basis. It is a beautiful yet sad question. It is beautiful because it is proof that my state of being registers with him, and that fact is the basis of essential virtues like sympathy, friendship and love. It is sad because often I am not happy and my son sees it just like I saw it on my own father’s face with troubling regularity.

headline: Women Behind Bars
abstract: The United States has nearly one-third of all female prisoners in the world.
lead_paragraph: In the last few years, America’s out-of-control incarceration boom has finally started to get the sustained public scrutiny, and condemnation, that it deserves. But one key element of the story still receives too little attention: the number of women in the nation’s prisons and jails.

headline: Time to Bring Cuba Online

lead_paragraph: Millions of Cuban citizens could have affordable access to the Internet in a matter of months. The only thing keeping the island in the digital Dark Ages is a lack of political will. Cuban officials have long blamed the American embargo for their nation’s obsolete telecommunications systems. They no longer have that excuse.

headline: Es hora de conectar a Cuba a Internet

Desde hace mucho tiempo, los líderes cubanos han dicho que el deplorable estado de la infraestructura de telecomunicaciones en la isla es culpa del embargo de Estados Unidos. Ya no tienen esa excusa.

abstract: Truth is more often the fruit of diligence than revelation, of discarding than accumulation.
lead_paragraph: The second paragraph of Ernest Hemingway’s short story “A Way You’ll Never Be” describes a cluster of dead Austrian soldiers encountered during World War I: “They lay alone or in clumps in the high grass of the field and along the road, their pockets out, and over them were flies and around each body or group of bodies were the scattered papers.”

headline: Ex-Senator’s Annual Fight Against Government Waste Gets New Champion
abstract: Former Senator Tom Coburn of Oklahoma’s annual tome detailing 100 federal projects that he viewed as wasteful was a tradition beloved by government waste-watchers. The report has been given a new twist by Senator James Lankford, who was elected in 2014 to finish Mr. Coburn’s truncated term.
lead_paragraph: As Congress reconvenes on Monday after the Thanksgiving break, it will head right into its annual end-of-year rituals, including spending fights and senatorial Secret Santas.

headline: G.O.P. Hopes to Send Message of Discord as Climate Talks Begin in Europe

headline: Over-the-Counter Medicines’ Benefits and Dangers
abstract: Nonprescription drugs are convenient, but they can be overused or used for the wrong purpose.
lead_paragraph: Four out of five American adults commonly take over-the-counter medications, most often to treat ailments like aches and pains, coughs and colds, fever, allergies, skin disorders, and heartburn and other digestive problems. The reasons are easy to understand. O.T.C.s are convenient, readily available in groceries and big box stores as well as pharmacies, and they are less expensive than going to the doctor and perhaps paying for a costly prescription.

headline: When an Expense Becomes a Wise Investment Choice

headline: 1940: Nanking Treaty Is Signed
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Japan gains important economic advantages with the Nanking Treaty in 1940.
lead_paragraph: NANKING — Japan gained important commercial and economic advantages in China while conceding abolition of extra- territoriality and Japanese concessions, according to the provisions of the treaty signed here today [Nov. 30] by Lieut. Gen. Nobuyuki Abe, Japanese Ambassador, and Wang Ching-wei, head of the Nanking regime sponsored by Japan. Japan further agreed to withdraw her armed forces within two years after general peace had been restored, except in North China and Inner Mongolia, where she would ‘‘order and carry out defense against Communistic activities and station required forces in specified areas for the necessary duration.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, December 1, 1940

headline: 1965: Hanoi Feels Strain of War
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: North Vietnam suffers from the toll of war in 1965.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — North Vietnam is severely strained by the simultaneous effort of fighting the war in South Vietnam and coping with American bombing of the North. Washington and Hanoi are presently engaged, among other things, in matching resources in their efforts to prevent the other’s victory in South Vietnam. North Vietnam is closed to almost all impartial observers. But scholars and political analysts in Hong Kong keep a constant watch on developments there. These observers can confidently draw broad pictures which have, in the past, proved substantially accurate. North Vietnam is hurting on a number of fronts. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, December 1, 1965

headline: The French Jewelry House Repossi Teams Up With LVMH
abstract: The luxury conglomerate will take a minority stake in the 95-year-old jewelry company.

In the eight years since, the brand has become known for its sleek cuffs, sculptural tiered rings and multiple-piercing earrings inspired by architecture.

headline: With Shipwreck Treasure Easier to Reach, a Duel Is On
abstract: As technology exposes more sunken booty to commercial explorers, they are facing resistance and counterclaims by governments, the United Nations and marine archaeologists.

More than 400,000 coins and at least 1,417 bars were lost over a 40-mile trail.

headline: Coin Toss Retains Its Place in History, if Not in Cricket

headline: The Ritz Paris, by the Numbers
abstract: In honor of its grand reopening, a statistical look at the storied hotel on Place Vendôme.
lead_paragraph: In its 117 years, the Ritz Paris has been more than a backdrop to world events — it has figured grandly into them. Its gossip-filled lobby was Marcel Proust’s inspiration; its cocktail bar a hub for French resistance during the Nazi occupation; its foyer a paparazzi magnet that Princess Diana traversed before her deadly car ride. But while the fabled luxury hotel on Place Vendôme has always been an independent icon, its decaying standards told another story. In 2011, the French tourism ministry humiliatingly left the Ritz off its list of ‘‘palaces’’ (a classification for five-star hotels of special character), compelling the hotel’s owner, Mohamed Al-Fayed, to upgrade. Now, after three years and an estimated $227 million renovation by the architect Thierry Despont, the 142-room Ritz is ready to reopen — complete with upgraded suites, a spacious new fitness center and, unsurprisingly, an untouched Bar Hemingway. A recognition, perhaps, that while time and technology march on, history is one luxury that can never be replaced.

headline: Needed for Paris Climate Talks: Handwarmers, Sleeping Bag, Stamina

headline: Dark Clouds Over the Internet
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Privacy']
abstract: Governments have legitimate reasons to seek user data beyond their territorial reach, and privacy advocates ignore that need at their peril.
lead_paragraph: LEXINGTON, Ky. — The Internet is routinely described as borderless, and that is often how it feels. Tweet a photo or post a comment, and it is instantly viewable in nearly every country in the world. But a global Internet unbounded by territorial limits is pure fantasy.

headline: Making It Harder to Prove White-Collar Crimes
abstract: The starting point for two recently introduced bills is the proposition that criminal punishment should be imposed only on those who are morally blameworthy.
lead_paragraph: One of the most potent words in politics is “reform” because everyone is in favor of making things better. Legislation introduced in the House and Senate to change what the government must prove for some white-collar crimes, especially those involving corporate executives, could end up making it harder to obtain convictions.

headline: Martin Gardner’s Impromptu
abstract: Do you believe in mind reading? Try this experiment in clairvoyance with the late recreational mathematician, Martin Gardner.
lead_paragraph: Martin Gardner was a giant in the recreational math world — many of the puzzles we take on each week here at Numberplay are direct descendants of the many counter-intuitive conundra that Gardner curated in the 20th century. He was such a significant force in math puzzles that we forget — or have a hard time really believing — that he had other lives, including that of a popular and influential magician. This week I’m pleased to present a book that captures this magical life: Martin Gardner’s Impromptu. The book is absolutely gorgeous: beautifully designed and full of detail, with hundreds of pages of original notes and sketches by Martin Gardner (the book itself is over 800 pages long). Click here to enjoy selections from the color section of the book, and here for an introduction to MiniTrix, a series of short videos featuring Martin Gardner performing various impromptu tricks.

headline: Humor: ‘The Comedians,’ ‘A Carlin Home Companion’ and More
abstract: The season’s books include Kliph Nesteroff’s history of comedy, stuffed with obscure trivia and arguments that challenge common wisdom.
lead_paragraph: No one ever questions the value of analyzing tragedy, but skepticism about breaking down comedy is a strangely enduring prejudice. Blame E.B. White. “Humor can be dissected, as a frog can,” he memorably groused, “but the thing dies in the process and the innards are discouraging to any but the purely scientific mind.”

headline: Review: Science and Politics Collide in ‘The Death of Cancer’
abstract: Dr. Vincent T. DeVita Jr. provides a rare view of the struggle to move cancer treatment into the modern age.
lead_paragraph: The scene is a wild cocktail party in Washington at the tail end of the Kennedy administration. Our innocent young narrator, new to the rituals of power, watches in fascination as one of his superiors dances by with a half-undressed woman slung over a shoulder. By the end of the evening, he has helped hoist another of his bosses, dead drunk, out of a bathtub.

headline: BTG Pactual Has Strengths, but They May Not Be Enough
abstract: The investment bank may have no problem continuing business as usual after the Petrobras scandal. But that’s not always how banking works.

But that will depend on the bank retaining the trust of trading partners and customers through the crisis caused by Mr. Esteves’s arrest as part of Brazil’s wide-ranging investigation into corruption at the national oil giant Petrobras.

headline: Times Drops ‘Rodham’ in Referring to Hillary Clinton
abstract: The Times is dropping “Rodham” from its references to Hillary Clinton, reflecting how the Democratic candidate for president refers to herself these days.
lead_paragraph: After Bill Clinton lost the governor’s seat in Arkansas in 1980, Hillary Rodham (reluctantly) took the name Clinton. “I learned the hard way that some voters in Arkansas were seriously offended by the fact that I kept my maiden name,” she wrote years later.

headline: Travel: ‘Dispatches From Pluto,’ ‘Driving Hungry’ and More
abstract: An English writer’s account of living in the Mississippi Delta, a filmmaker’s travels in South America and more.
lead_paragraph: There is no such place as untrammeled earth. A journey to any spot on the globe is certain to cross the traces of past civilizations, the residue of different eras. They may announce themselves in wreckages of marble or stone, or they may have discreetly sunk beneath the dirt. Yet wherever we may travel, the ghosts of history beckon. They remind us of our predecessors and also of our own transience. The essentially changing character of nature means that we never have true ownership of any patch of ground; we’re all just renting for a season before we’re forced to move on. In their own different ways, the authors of these new travel narratives pay tribute to the earth’s earlier guests.

headline: Taking Trump at His Word

headline: Yawning and the Tears That Follow

headline: Sports: ‘The Grind,’ ‘Billion-Dollar Ball’ and More
abstract: New books about sports include looks at baseball’s “endless season” and the lives of today’s greatest marathoners.
lead_paragraph: I can’t swim. I can’t dribble a basketball without staring at it, severely compromising my mobility. And I’ve never raised my voice to a stranger, let alone my fists. In sum, I’m not an athlete. But these facts only deepen my admiration for those who are. It’s why I love sports, and the exhilarating, joyously cliché-ridden prose it inspires.

headline: From Nude Model to War Reporter
abstract: Molly Crabapple’s new memoir, “Drawing Blood,” charts the artist and writer’s progress from sketching club founder to political correspondent.
lead_paragraph: Molly Crabapple made her name in 2005 as the founder of Dr. Sketchy’s Anti-Art School — a sketching club with scores of chapters around the world where the nude models were the stars — then as house artist for the Box nightclub, where she lined the New York demi-monde in a style recalling both Aubrey Beardsley and Toulouse-Lautrec. Recently, however, Crabapple has reinvented herself as a political reporter, returning dispatches from places like Guantanamo Bay, the Gaza Strip and Syrian refugee camps for publications like the Guardian, Vanity Fair and Vice, where she’s a contributing editor. Her new memoir, “Drawing Blood” ($30, out Dec. 1 from Harper Collins) chronicles this transformation, and, fittingly, it’s the first book Crabapple is releasing as a writer rather than an illustrator.

headline: ‘Of Beards and Men’ and ‘True Style’

headline: Blood Pressure, a Reading With a Habit of Straying
abstract: Measuring it once is a relatively simple task. Measure it again and again, and you might find yourself on a roller-coaster ride.
lead_paragraph: Measuring blood pressure seems so straightforward. Stick your arm in a cuff for a few seconds, and there they are: two simple numbers, all the information you need to know whether you are in a healthy range or high enough that you should be taking one of the many cheap generic drugs that can bring down your blood pressure.

headline: Meet Tumblr’s 15-Year-Old Secret Keeper
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Friendship', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Emily Trunko, an Ohio teenager, has collected thousands of letters and text messages from anonymous people on the Internet.
lead_paragraph: On the Internet, the word “heartbreaking” is often used as a device to get us to click and gawk at remarkable tales of loss — the bride left at the altar, the long-lost family pet. On The Last Message Received Tumblr, the heartbreak doesn’t really need a headline to sell itself.

The guests included security guards, electricians and janitors; part-time employees and full-time employees — anyone who worked with the team in the 2014 season.

headline: What We Fear When We Fear Terrorism
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Boston Marathon Bombings (2013)', 'Organized Crime', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Why the fear of conspiracy makes terrorism seem more threatening than other crimes.
lead_paragraph: In addition to the inevitable abortion politicking, the murderous rampage of Robert Dear at a Planned Parenthood facility in Colorado has inspired a number of writers to contrast the stiff upper lip with which many Americans seem to handle the general prevalence of gun violence on our shores with the highly-politicized anxiety surrounding the acts that we decide to call “terrorism.” This contrast is widely invoked as evidence of American xenophobia: We fear attacks from a nebulous or specifically-Islamic “Other” more than we fear violence by angry white men, it’s alleged, even if the Other isn’t likely to hurt us nearly as much as a bunch of heavily-armed heartlanders, because Americans still identify with whiteness/maleness/Christianity too closely to fully imagine “white Christian terrorism” as something to be feared.

headline: Steve Carell Does Not Mock the Undeserving
abstract: The actor on "The Big Short," playing boneheaded characters and why “The Daily Show” shifted away from snark.
lead_paragraph: You didn’t start out with the intention of becoming a comic actor. Now that your career has finally drifted toward dramatic acting, I’m curious: What was the vision of the kind of career that you thought you might have? I didn’t set the bar very high for myself, I’ll be honest. I didn’t have a vision. I just wanted to be employed, and I was willing to do almost everything short of pornography to continue working as an actor. I know that’s a pretty horrible image.

headline: Review: ‘New York Animals,’ a Musical About Intersecting Lives
abstract: Eric Tucker’s Bedlam theater troupe performs this show from Steven Sater and Burt Bacharach at the New Ohio Theater.
lead_paragraph: Toward the end of the fragmented new musical “New York Animals,” a tubercular homeless man inevitably wheezes out E. M. Forster’s immortal dictum: “Only connect.” There’s a macabre drollness about this decree, issued in a Manhattan hospital emergency room, since the most fertile points of connection would seem to be between the speaker’s germs and the vulnerable immune systems of everybody around him.

headline: For Survivors of Paris Attacks, Mental Scars May Outlast Wounds
abstract: Most of the wounded and their families, and a large number of medical personnel, are receiving psychological support for emotional trauma.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Lying in a narrow hospital bed, Djamel Cheboub gingerly lifted his right foot to drain fluid from a wound inflicted by one of three bullets he took the night of the Paris attacks. His left leg, damaged by a shot to the thigh, was immobile. Six metal pins protruded from his left arm, which was partly blown away.

keywords: ['Renminbi (Currency)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'US Dollar (Currency)', 'United States Economy', 'Currency']

But as I have become firmly ensconced in middle age, I find myself all too aware of what Len Evans, the Australian impresario, used to call his Theory of Capacity.

Thanks to the legacy of military rule and a culture of breaking rules of all sorts, Argentina has become one of the best places on earth to find people who could show you how.

headline: Seeking a Cancer-Free World
abstract: The vastness of the problem and the possibility that a singular cure won’t be found cannot erode a willingness to fight the fight.
lead_paragraph: My grandfather received a diagnosis of brain cancer a week before I had to hand in my master’s thesis. The very first chapter discussed a scientific paper about his type of brain tumor. I found comfort in losing myself in the work: I sat by his hospital bed as he slept, and analyzed cancer data, typing out equations filled with Greek symbols that he had joked were some kind of sorcery.

headline: Hyperglobalization and Global Inequality
abstract: Things changed around 1990.
lead_paragraph: I’ve mentioned before that I’m a big fan of work by my CUNY colleague Branko Milanovic showing that if you look at income growth by percentile of the whole world population for the past 25 years, you see “twin peaks”: rapid growth near the middle, representing China’s middle class, and at the top, representing the global elite, with a sag in the region representing the OECD working class. But was it always thus? I asked Branko what a similar picture looked like for the previous generation — and he has obliged.

headline: Planned Parenthood and the Tinderbox of Abortion Rhetoric
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Should we be surprised when the language of brutality and violence boils over into the real thing?
lead_paragraph: Abortion opponents have been quick to distance themselves from the Nov. 27 shooting at a Planned Parenthood clinic in Colorado Springs, which left three people dead. The anti-abortion groups lining up to condemn the violence included the Center for Medical Progress, which released videos in July accusing Planned Parenthood of selling fetal parts and tissue. Planned Parenthood denied making sales, saying one of its 700 health centers was being reimbursed for supplying fetal tissue to researchers, who have used fetal cells to produce lifesaving vaccines and treatments. But the doctor caught on camera spoke in graphic medical terms while sipping wine over lunch, and the videos prompted five separate congressional investigations into Planned Parenthood’s practices. Testifying before a House committee in October, the group’s president, Cecile Richards, said it would continue facilitating the tissue donations, with patients’ consent, but stop accepting reimbursements. The Center for Medical Progress called this “an admission of guilt.”

headline: Oregon Valley Wasn’t Always Forest-Covered, Study Says
abstract: Researchers found that frosty meadowlands and patchy subalpine forest predominated in the Triangle Lake region during the last ice age.
lead_paragraph: Forests cover the mountainous Triangle Lake valley of the Oregon Coast Range, but that was not always the case, researchers found. Sediment samples from 200 feet below the surface of Little Lake, the remnant of an ancient lake that was much larger, show that frosty meadowlands and patchy subalpine forest predominated in the region during the last ice age, 26,000 to 13,000 years ago. The primary cause of erosion then was not rainfall but frost cracking. Erosion rates were at least two and a half times higher than today’s rates, according to the researchers, who published their study in Science Advances. Parts of the United States not covered by glaciers during the period, from Oregon to Georgia, may have resembled southeastern Alaska, they said.

headline: 3.2 Millimeters: A Troubling Rise in Sea Level

headline: Review: ‘Black Flags,’ Tracing the Birth of ISIS
abstract: Joby Warrick creates the most revealing portrait yet laid out in a book of Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, the founding father of the organization that would become the Islamic State, or ISIS.
lead_paragraph: In the last month, terror attacks that left 130 dead in Paris and 43 dead in Beirut and took down a Russian airliner with 224 people aboard have made the entire world horribly aware that the Islamic State not only seeks to establish a caliphate in Syria and Iraq, but also is beginning to export its monstrous savagery abroad. Although the Islamic State has been in the headlines for only two years, and its metastasis has been alarmingly swift, the seeds of the group — in its many incarnations — were planted many years ago, as Joby Warrick’s gripping new book, “Black Flags,” makes clear.

lead_paragraph: Last week’s holiday turned out to be a most bountiful one for theater producers, as Broadway enjoyed its best-attended Thanksgiving week since official record keeping began 31 years ago.

headline: Doc Martens: From Punk to High Fashion
abstract: The boots, originally made for blue-collar workers, are now on the runways.
lead_paragraph: The boots, originally made for blue-collar workers, are now on the runways.

headline: The Story Behind the Return of ‘The Wiz’
abstract: A new production to be broadcast live on NBC this week before hopping to Broadway will include a tweaked score and of-the-minute dance moves.
lead_paragraph: BETHPAGE, N.Y. — Perched atop a spiky chariot, Mary J. Blige rolled onto a set here and began making demands. “What’s that there?” she yelled, pointing to an invisible blotch. Underlings scurried to clean up. “Worrrk!” she bellowed.

headline: Suspect in Planned Parenthood Attack Hears Murder Charge
abstract: Robert Dear wore a white padded vest with his hands and legs shackled in his first court appearance to answer an initial charge of first-degree murder.
lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — Wearing a padded vest meant to prevent suicide, and shackles on his hands and legs, the man accused of fatally shooting three people during a rampage at a Planned Parenthood clinic here last week made his first court appearance on Monday afternoon.

headline: Dave Navarro’s ‘Mourning Son’ Tells the Story of His Mother’s Murder
keywords: ['Movies', 'Music', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Mr. Navarro, the Jane’s Addiction guitarist, appears in a very personal documentary, directed by Todd Newman.
lead_paragraph: One morning in 2013, the rock musician Dave Navarro and his best friend, Todd Newman, pulled into the visitors’ parking lot at San Quentin State Prison in a stretch limousine. They had traveled from Los Angeles, six hours away, with a plan to pay an unannounced visit to the man responsible for the 1983 murders of Mr. Navarro’s mother, Connie Navarro, and a close friend of hers, Sue Jory.

headline: Jury Selection in Freddie Gray Death Offers Look at Life in Baltimore
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Jury System']
abstract: More than half the potential jurors said that they or immediate family members had been a victim of crime, investigated, charged or incarcerated.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — As jury selection opened Monday in the trial of the first of six police officers charged in the death of Freddie Gray, more than half of roughly 75 potential jurors told a judge that they or their immediate family members had been either a victim of crime, investigated, charged or incarcerated.

headline: Review: ‘The Two Pigeons,’ Frederick Ashton’s Look at Love
abstract: The Royal Ballet revives this 1961 Ashton work, which will be broadcast in New York in March.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Imagery in choreography is often easy to miss. Who in the audience really sees the eagle, snake, moon crossing the sky, emeralds, rubies and unicorns that are said by Balanchine connoisseurs to be present in his ballets?

headline: Review: ‘The Unrepeatable Moment,’ Six Plays by John Yearley
abstract: This grab bag at the Barrow Group has a though-provoking start, an exhilarating finish and a few weak spots, Laura Collins-Hughes writes.
lead_paragraph: “There’s something uniquely awful about bad theater, isn’t there?” a guy named Robert asks his fiancée in “Hating Beckett,” and you have to admit it’s a disarming way to begin a play. Instantly we’re in league with Robert and the playwright who wrote him, because they’re right.
